title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: Britain ordered the expulsion of two Soviet diplomats and a Soviet journalist today because of ''unacceptable activities'' - a phrase usually used to describe espionage.

title: FRANCE LURCHES ON
description: President Francois Mitterrand has come under heavy fire. He has ceded some, but doesn't seem to have buckled. He is surprisingly relaxed, appearing more confident and decisive in private than in public, as he commands the angry and bewildered French to tighten their belts several notches.

title: I.R.S. Studying Certain Notes
description: The Internal Revenue Service said it is studying the tax treatment of adjustable-rate convertible notes issued by several companies in recent months.

title: FINK ATTACKS KOCH'S COURT BILLS
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink told Mayor Koch yesterday that Mr. Koch was offering ''simplistic'' answers to the problems of New York courts.

title: BRIEFING
description: Packwood's Noncampaign

title: ARAFAT REACHES AMMAN, BUT HUSSEIN DELAYS MEETING
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, arrived here today for talks with King Hussein that are expected to determine whether Jordan will enter peace negotiations with Israel on the basis of the President Reagan's Middle East peace plan.

title: ADDISON-WESLEY PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
BORG LOSES AND SAYS GOODBYE
description: Bjorn Borg battled into a third-set tiebreaker today before losing the last match of his illustrious career to Henri Leconte.

title: No Love Lost For No-Pets Clause
description: Landlords are moving to enforce the no-pets clause in most New York leases, say Assemblymen Pete Grannis and Mark Alan Siegel. So, the two Democrats from Manhattan are co-sponsoring a bill to protect pet owners from eviction.

title: SHAME IN NICARAGUA
description: Unison Whiteman, the Foreign Minister of Grenada, said the other day that he had ''evidence'' that his nation was the target of an ''imminent attack'' by the United States.

title: Nippon Electric's Billion-Bit Chip
description: The Nippon Electric Company said it had developed a new magnetic memory concept that will make it possible to store one billion bits of information on a single chip.

title: SOVIET IS CRITICAL OF NEW MISSILE BID
description: The first Soviet commentary on President Reagan's offer to reduce the planned deployment of missiles in Europe said today that the plan would upset the strategic balance between the United States and the Soviet Union and ''can hardly play a constructive role.''

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
VICTIMS' RIGHTS BILL DRAWS MIXED REVIEWS IN CALIFORNIA
description: Rogelio Villifana Ruiz, a 28-year-old illegal alien from Mexico, was convicted here last week of burglarizing six homes and was sentenced to 14 years and four months in prison, the longest sentence ever given for burglary in Santa Barbara County.

title: HOW NOT TO RUN A COMMUTER RAILROAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Fines for Hockey Fight
description: In addition to automatic fines totaling $4,400 that the Minnesota North Stars and the Chicago Black Hawks were assessed by the National Hockey League for a brawl March 21, the teams yesterday were further fined $2,000 each by Brian O'Neill, the N.H.L. executive vice president. The fight occurred in the third period of the game and lasted almost an hour. Brian Lewis, the referee, doled out 173 minutes in penalties, 91 to the Black Hawks.

title: DISNEY BACKS SECOND STAGE PRODUCTION
description: Walt Disney studios will be financing a workshop production of Arthur Giron's ''Becoming Memories,'' which will open April 14 at the South Street Theater. This second toe into the waters of New York theater follows Disney's $50,000 workshop of Larry Atlas's ''Total Abandon'' at the Perry Street Playhouse.

title: Man Who Hit Justice White Given 10-Day Term and a Fine
description: Newton C. Estes was sentenced today to one year in prison for punching Associate Justice Byron R. White of the Supreme Court, but the sentence was suspended for a 10-day jail term, a $500 fine and two years' probation.

title: Honored for Service To the City
description: A miniature version of ''Alamo,'' the steel cube by Tony Rosenthal that pivots in Astor Place, is the new annual award honoring Doris Chanin Freedman, the city's first Director of Cultural Affairs. It was Mrs. Freedman, who died in 1981 at the age of 53, who brought art to the city's public places.

title: HIGHLIGHTS AND A FEW SIDELIGHTS AT THE CIRCUS
description: FROM the Ringling Brothers to the Felds, father and son, from the Fratellini clowns to the Flying Wallendas, the circus has always been a family business. Children are ''born into the circus.'' Generations of aerialists, gymnasts and lion tamers are swept into dynasties.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: G.M. AND FORD CUT RATE ON SOME LOANS TO 9.9%
description: With sales of its small cars languishing, the General Motors Corporation announced today that it was cutting its auto loan rate to 9.9 percent from 11.9 percent for consumers who purchase its compact and subcompact cars and light trucks.

title: PAY 'N PAK STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
DELTA DRILLING CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. c-After an extraordinary charge of $29,750,000. Year-ago results have been adjusted to reflect an accounting change.

title: OUTLET CO reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net loss resulted mostly from discontinued operations and the sale of the company's third and last retail division.

title: Goodyear Merger
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company and the Celeron Corporation said that they had signed a definitive merger agreement under which Celeron, an oil and natural gas concern, would become a wholly owned subsidiary of Goodyear. Under the $833 million plan announced last month, each Celeron common share would be converted into 1.15 Goodyear common shares. Shareholders would also receive one common share of Celeron's subsidiary, the Trans Louisiana Gas Company, for each 50 shares held.

title: MAXIMUM SENTENCE IS GIVEN TO YOUTH IN KILLING OF BLACK
description: An 18-year-old Brooklyn youth was sentenced yesterday to the maximum of 5 to 15 years in prison for manslaughter in the beating of a black transit worker by white youths last June.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FURY ON EARTH: A BIOGRAPHY OF WILHELM REICH. By Myron Sharaf. 550 pages. St. Martin's Press/Marek. $24.95.

title: DELMED INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $799,000 for the latest year and $246,000 for the previous year. Results for both years include operations of Sherlof Inc., acquired in 1981, and American Medical Products Corp., acquired in 1982. These acquisitions were accounted for on a pooling of interest basis.

title: ACCORD IS REACHED IN RAILWAY STRIKE ON 9 JERSEY LINES
description: A tentative contract agreement was reached today between N.J. Transit and a faction of the United Transportation Union that struck nine state-owned rail lines March 1.

title: 'PRIVATE SCHULZ' SERIES FROM BRITAIN GETS START
description: PUBLIC TELEVISION'S ''Masterpiece Theater'' comes up with a diverting surprise on Sunday night at 9 on Channel 13 when it starts ''Private Schulz,'' a six-episode import from Britain. The cast of characters hardly looks promising in terms of laughs. This World War II story features Nazi officers, sleazy criminals and even an Adolf Hitler. But the script by the late Jack Pulman manages to be almost wickedly clever as it hones in on the foibles of not only the Germans but also of the British.

title: AIRLINES COULDN'T TAKE AN OIL-IMPORT TAX
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
description: Results for the latest year include operations of Modern Merchandising since October 1982 and Basco since July 1982.

title: Stories of Courage
description: It's been a big month for rewarding heros. Eric J. Sorenson, a 14-year-old eighth grader, was awakened a year ago by a crash outside his home in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: OWNER-OCCUPIED HOUSES: NEW TEST IN SOUTH BRONX
description: Charlotte Street in the Crotona Park East section of the South Bronx became a national symbol of urban decay a few years ago. It was a regular stop on the periodic tours taken by public officials to view the worst ravages of owner abandonment of rental housing in the nation. On one celebrated occasion in 1977, President Carter visited it and committed the Government to help the city rebuild.

title: New Music at Kitchen
description: The pianist and composer Anthony Davis will present a concert of new works tonight and tomorrow at 8:30 P.M. at the Kitchen, 484 Broome Street (925-3615). Mr. Davis's music draws on both classical and improvising traditions, including jazz and Eastern music.

title: MEETING HOUSING NEEDS FOR HOMELESS FAMILIES
description: As New York City struggles to provide temporary shelter for swelling numbers of homeless families, the issues of welfare rent allowances and the quality of emergency housing have become matters of increasing concern.

title: Chinese Art in Brooklyn
description: ''Painting the Chinese Dreams: Chinese Art 30 Years After the Revolution,'' an exhibition of paintings, sculpture and ceramics by 23 Chinese artists, some of it never shown outside China, is on view through May 5 at the Brooklyn Museum, Washington Avenue and Eastern Parkway.

title: CONVENTION CENTER PROBLEMS PARTLY RESOLVED
description: The problems in fabricating the metal space frame that will form the centerpiece of New York City's new Convention Center have been partly resolved, the president of the Convention Center Development Corporation said yesterday.

title: CHICAGO PNEUMATIC TOOL CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $321,000. c-Including a gain of $808,000 on the early extinguishment of debt and utilization of tax credits. d-Net income. Results for the latest periods reflect reorganization and facility rearrangement costs of $5,552,000 associated with Europe.

title: Nicaraguan Aide Blames U.S.  For Fighting Near Honduras
description: Foreign Minister Miguel D'Escoto blamed the United States today for the fighting in Nicaragua near the Honduran border, and said ''a lot of people are being killed because they are being made to fight the United States' war.''

title: SOUTH AFRICA TO POLL WHITES ON CHARTER REVISIONS
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha has announced that a referendum will be held among white voters on his proposals to transform South Africa's Constitution.

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Dameronia at Blue Note
description: Dameronia, a nonet with a repertory of music by the jazz composer Tadd Dameron, will appear tonight through Sunday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). The group is led by the drummer Philly Joe Jones, for whom Mr. Dameron wrote the tune ''Philly J.J.,'' and also includes Frank Wess on saxophones and Walter Davis Jr. on piano. Sets begin at 9:30 and 11:30 P.M. and 1:30 A.M.; there will be a $7.50 cover and a $7.50 minimum for each set.

title: U.S. LOOKS AT ANTITRUST ISSUE IN OIL COMPANIES' SAUDI LINKS
description: The Justice Department is looking into possible antitrust violations in the relationship of four major American oil companies that jointly pump and buy most of the oil produced by Saudi Arabia.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: THIS week's social events ranged from small family seders c elebrating Passover to black-tie dinner-dances for charitable c auses. It was the week the circus came to town, as did Princess C aroline of Monaco.

title: AIR FORCE'S PRECISION TEAM, AFTER 5 DEATHS, TO FLY AGAIN
description: Undeterred by crashes that have killed five of its pilots in the last 19 months, the Air Force Thunderbirds, a precision flying team, is taking to the air for public shows again this week.

title: 33 Accused in Turkey Of Seeking Islamic State
description: The Istanbul martial law authorities have charged 33 people with aiming to establish an Islamic state in Turkey, it was announced today.

title: SENATE MAJORITY VS. A WITHHOLDING PROVISION
description: To the Editor:

title: Canada's 'Acid Rain' On Channel 13 Tonight
description: The question about ''Acid Rain: Requiem or Recovery?'' is not whether it is good or bad television, but whether it is political propaganda. The Justice Department says it is; environmental groups and the Canadian Government say it is not. To me it seems propaganda of a benign kind, although the political content is moot. The documentary, produced by Environment Canada, a Government agency, will be shown on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight. Acid rain is the name given to the industrial air pollution created when sulfur and nitrogren oxides travel through the atmosphere and then fall to earth as either dry particles or acidic rain or snow. Factories in both Canada and the United States emit the pollution, but prevailing winds apparently cause most of it to fall on Canada. The Canadian Government has said the Reagan Administration doesn't care. Its Minister of the Environment, for example, has called acid rain ''the single greatest irritant in the United States-Canadian relationship.'' The Minister of External Affairs has raised the matter with Secretary of State George P. Shultz. On rainy days in Washington, Canadian diplomats carry umbrellas that say, ''Acid Rain Umbrella.'' The discord, however, is not reflected in the documentary, which is assiduously bilateral. If acid rain is eradicating the salmon in nine rivers in Nova Scotia, it is also eradicating the brook trout in 180 lakes in the Adirondacks; if 48,000 lakes in Ontario are threatened, the salamanders in the Northeastern states are threatened, too.

title: THE PRESIDENT OUT FRONT
description: News Analysis

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 1, 1983
description: International

title: Help for Homeless Criticized in Audit
description: An audit released yesterday by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin criticized the city's emergency services for homeless families and concluded that there was an urgent need to improve the quality and delivery of those services.

title: SCHOOL LEADER CHOICE: WHEN THE BEST IS BLACK
description: To the Editor:

title: BRANCH INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $646,800.

title: ART: 'SMOOTH' CAN VASES AT LELAND BELL EXHIBIT
description: LELAND BELL is a painter who might conceivably be turned to after a surfeit of the new Expressionism. His canvases are smooth and measured, where those by others are crusty and hyper, and none is too large to enter an ordinary house. The drawing is expert, and the colors are strong, unmodulated and, in the cloisonne tradition, separated by black lines. Nor does the artist address ''big'' themes, preferring to draw inspiration from his domestic life.

title: TIMES SAYS IT WILL CONTINUE TALKS ON EXTENDED PACTS WITH 7 UNIONS
description: The New York Times, which had been seeking three-year contract extensions with its unions by yesterday, said that it was prepared to continue negotiations with the seven units that have not as yet agreed to the proposal.

title: DRYSDALE CHAIRMAN'S GUILTY PLEA
description: Joseph V. Ossorio, chairman of the Drysdale Securities Corporation, pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal charges that he had made fraudulent reports inflating the value of investment accounts involving several million dollars.

title: Settlement at a Glance
description: Length of contract - Four years, effective next season.

title: U.S. IS OUT AS HOST OF SOCCER
description: The five-member World Cup Organizing Committee said yesterday that it had eliminated the United States and Canada as possible sites for the 1986 soccer competition. It said that Mexico was now the only country under consideration.

title: No Time for Rancor Against Banks
description: Congress must vote soon on the proposal to expand the capacity of the International Monetary Fund to aid countries that are over their heads in debt. But there's no relief for debtors that will not also give some relief to their once-enthusiastic lenders, including major American banks. Tempting as it may be to punish bankers for the freewheeling lending that fueled this crisis, the national interest calls for prudence.

title: JARDINE MATHESON & CO LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2.6 million and a charge of $83.7 million for the company's share in Hong Kong Land Co. c-After a charge of $4.3 million and an extraordinary credit of $39 million.

title: Little Rock Racial Plan Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the Little Rock School District's desegregation plan, which makes the enrollment of four schools almost entirely black.

title: STRIDE RITE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 4.
description: b-Includes operations of Keds, which Stride Rite acquired in December. The year-ago share earnings were restated for a 2-for-1 stock split in February.

title: Florida State Gets A Year Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today put Florida State on probation for a year for basketball recruiting violations, which included giving a suit to a player.

title: Craig Returns
description: Fresh from helping the United States hockey team qualify for the 1984 Winter Olympics, Jim Craig will be back in goal in the National Hockey League.

title: Default in Taiwan
description: The Taiwanese Government has no plans to bail out the Great International Corporation, Taiwan's fifthlargest trading company, which has been defaulting on its debt payments, an official of the Economic Ministry said. Twenty-seven financial institutions, including six foreign banks, are owed more than $50 million by Great International and its affiliate, the We Sheng Group, which has been defaulting on payments since late last year. Local bankers said they were bracing for what could become Taiwan's largest commercial banking loss.

title: A corner of Spain and one of France.
description: THERE are few good restaurants in the financial district and few that offer good Spanish food anywhere in town. It is, therefore, a double bonus to come across El Rincon de Espana on Beaver Street, a branch of the Greenwich Village restaurant of the same name that has maintained a two-star rating since 1979. The financial district's ''Corner of Spain'' is the more comfortable of the two, with a larger, brighter dining room and a lively, atmospheric bar. Basically done up in a style that suggests a gaudy cocktail lounge, the dining room has just enough Spanish trimmings to give it a bit of character, and the staff is one of the friendliest and most accommodating around.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think I like it even better than Easter morning services.

title: YANKS IMPRESS RANDOLPH
description: Willie Randolph is a year and three months from his 30th birthday, but he has become one of the three senior members of the Yankees. Graig Nettles, who is 38, Lou Piniella, 39, and Randolph are the only current Yankees who played the entire 1976 season with the team and have been Yankees ever since.

title: Opera Shop Presents Donizetti's 'Betly'
description: The Opera Shop of the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street, off Second Avenue, will present ''Betly,'' a two-act comic opera by Donizetti, from April 2 to April 17. It is the first fully staged New York production since 1861.

title: Big East Seniors In All-Star Game
description: David Russell of St. John's and Villanova's John Pinone are among 10 Big East players who have agreed to play in the game against USA Basketball that is scheduled for April 8 at Manley Field House here.

title: ROAD TO KENTUCKY DERBY IS CROWDED
description: The glut of entrants yesterday for the most important Kentucky Derby preps to date has certified a growing suspicion: The 3 year-old division is in such confusion this year that as many as 80 horses are still Derby possibilities.

title: ITEL CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including income of $12.1 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $20 million. c-Including income of $31.4 million from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $38.4 million.

title: Karate Passbooks
description: Although it is not yet nine years old, the Professional Karate Association is years ahead of boxing in administration and management. The latest example of the association's determination to police its sport is the issuance of passbooks starting today to the 2,000 registered amateur and pro fighters.

title: N.B.A. STRIKE AVERTED WITH ACCORD ON 4-YEAR PACT
description: The National Basketball Association and the players union reached agreement in principle yesterday on a new four-year contract that includes a revenue-sharing plan, the first of its kind in team sports. The contract also establishes a minimum and maximum in team payrolls that is expected to increase parity among teams.

title: RARE CHICK PECKS WAY INTO WORLD
description: A California condor was hatched in captivity for the first time Wednesday. The bald, half-pound, wrinkled chick, which scientists hope will be the key to saving the species, spent its first day out of the egg sleeping, ''like most babies,'' its keeper said today.

title: ISRAEL DISMISSES CHARGE IT PLANS TO STRIKE SYRIA
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin today dismissed allegations that there was a threat of war with Syria, saying a Soviet warning of such a danger was ''artificial.''

title: A NEW ERICH SEGAL LOVE STORY
description: BOB BECKWITH, an American professor of English, has just finished delivering a lecture to some French colleagues, offering, as one of them puts it, ''a day the Sorbonne will never forget.'' That same day, he is injured slightly in an auto accident and brought to the office of the beautiful Nicole, who is deemed ''the best doctor in all of Normandy.'' Once Bob is patched up, he and Nicole stroll through a picturesque fishing village. ''Now I understand why so many Impressionists came here to paint,'' Bob declares.

title: Israel Asks U.S. Team To Study Illness Report
description: The Israeli Health Ministry said today that it had asked the United States Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta to send a team of experts to assess the Israeli finding that poison was not the cause of mysterious ailments affecting hundreds of West Bank Palestinians.

title: TIGERS OR 'TOP GIRLS,' VALERIE MAHAFFEY ADAPTS
description: VALERIE MAHAFFEY'S short life has been one violent leap after another - from adventurous toddler in Sumatra, where tigers padded up to the front porch; to prissy miss at a girls' boarding school in Devon, and ''dateless nerd'' at a high school in Austin, Tex.

title: DANCE: NEW OFFERING BY SPAIN'S PILAR RIOJA
description: PILAR RIOJA, the Spanish dancer who created one of the quiet sensations of the dance season last September, has returned to New York to cast her spell again.

title: Lindsay's Son Held On Drug Charge
description: John V. Lindsay Jr., the 22-year-old son of the former New York City Mayor, was arrested yesterday in Bridgehampton, L.I., on charges that he sold three grams of cocaine to undercover Suffolk County detectives last December.

title: No Love Lost
description: The hype began yesterday for the May 20 heavyweight fight card involving Larry Holmes-Tim Witherspoon, Michael Dokes-Mike Weaver and Renaldo Snipes-Greg Page. But instead of Holmes and Witherspoon exchanging verbal shots over their World Boxing Council title fight, the real barrage during a brunch at the Plaza Hotel in New York City involved Holmes and Slim Jim Robinson, Witherspoon's trainer.

title: Chinese Energy Report
description: China's Zhongyuan oilfield is expected to produce 36.5 million barrels of crude annually, about 5 percent of current national output, the New China News Agency said today. Geologists expect to verify 3.7 billion barrels of oil reserves and 50 billion cubic meters of natural gas in the field in Henan and Shandong provinces, it said. The field is expected to produce 600 million cubic meters of natural gas annually by 1985 and to become the biggest gas producer in north China, the agency said.

title: Mubarak to Visit China
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt is due here Friday on the first visit to China by an Egyptian head of state. He is to stay until April 4 and then visit North Korea, Japan and Indonesia.

title: Money Funds Show Decline
description: The assets of the nation's money market funds fell $2.2 billion for the week ended Wednesday, to $182.1 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Bogus Professor Wins Reduction in Bail
description: Paul Arthur Crafton, accused of teaching at two Pennsylvania colleges under false names, won a reduction in bail and was released today after 10 days in jail.

title: Mrs. Vucanovich Recovering
description: Representative Barbara F. Vucanovich, Republican of Nevada, underwent breast and cancer surgery at the Bethesda Naval Hospital ''and is recovering nicely,'' her office said today. Mrs. Vucanovich entered the hospital late Tuesday after doctors discovered lumps in her right breast in a routine physical examination, a news release issued by her office said.

title: Interest Rates Climb Slightly; Fed Funds End at 10 1/2%
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday in what Government securities dealers said was one of the quietest days of the year. Speculators and investors were largely inactive in advance of the Good Friday holiday and prices changed in a very narrow range.

title: EASTER IN NEW YORK - OUTDOORS AND INDOORS
description: THERE is much for families to do without leaving the city this Easter weekend, and a lot of it has to do with eggs. You can roll, toss and avoid eggs at the Bronx Zoo, push eggs across Central Park, hunt for eggs in Van Cortlandt Park Stadium or at the Sheraton Centre and see eggs turn colors on Second Avenue. Non@-egg activities include racing, dancing, yelping and, of course, the Easter Parade, which is no parade at all - just a communal midtown amble on Fifth Avenue that gets under way in force at about 11 A.M. on Sunday.

title: Award Deadline Extended
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has announced that it is extending the deadline until next Friday for its New York members to vote in the best-foreign-languange-film category. The extension will permit these members to view ''Alsino and the Condor'' (Nicaragua) and ''To Begin Again'' (Spain), two nominated films that had been unavailable to them until this week.

title: FIT FOR A PRESIDENT, THE NEWLY REFURBISHED YACHT SEQUOIA ONLY LANGUISHES
description: Swaying gently in her solitary berth just off East Potomac Park, across from Washington's crowded waterfront, the former Presidential yacht Sequoia has never looked more beautiful.

title: Transcript of speech, page A8.
description: President Reagan said today that until Israel withdraws its forces from Lebanon, he will not permit the transfer of some 75 F-16 fighter jets that have been held up since last summer.

title: MONOLITHIC MEMORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 20.
description: The latest quarter included 12 weeks compared with 13 weeks in year-ago period.

title: Market Place; 2 New Funds Start Out Big
description: TWIN mutual funds set up to invest in science and technology stocks on a global scale will begin operations today with $835 million in total net assets. This represents by far the biggest pool of money ever gathered in an initial public offering for the mutual fund industry. The previous record, $270 million, was set in 1966 by one fund and was matched last year by another.

title: Miss Daniel Ties for Lead in Coast Golf
description: Beth Daniel sank a 40-yard wedge shot for an eagle on the 11th hole, and Sandra Spuzich hit 15 greens in regulation as they shot three-under-par 69's and shared the lead after the opening round of the $400,000 Nabisco-Dinah Shore Invitational golf tournament today.

title: Mandel and Maryland In Pact on Furniture
description: Former Gov. Marvin Mandel and the State of Maryland signed a pact today involving $23,000 in furniture and other items he was accused of taking from Government House when he left office in 1977.

title: ACTON CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $111,000 for the latest year and $779,000 for the previous year.

title: NIGERIA ACCEPTING BRITISH CUTS
description: The Justice Department is checking possible antitrust violations by four American oil companies that pump oil in Saudi Arabia. Page D3.

title: 'This Summit Was Brought to You ...'
description: To limit the costs of the Williamsburg summit meeting, The Times reports, the Reagan Administration is calling on major companies to provide goods and services free. It must have seemed a splendid idea when it bloomed in the brain of a White House adviser:

title: 60 DEAD, WITH TOLL OF 200 FEARED; The Associated Press
description: Much of the southwestern mountain city of Popayan was devastated today by an earthquake that killed at least 60 people and injured 500. But with the Roman Catholic cathedral and other buildings in ruins, it was estimated that the death toll would reach at least 200.

title: HOUSE OF FABRICS INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid Jan. 21.

title: WITH A JOYFUL NOISE, CHURCHES RESUME ANCIENT EASTER VIGIL
description: Tomorrow night, parishioners of the Advent Lutheran Church on Broadway at 93d Street will rattle noisemakers and hoist balloons to welcome Easter, while at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration on East 29th Street two infants and one adult will be baptized as new Christians during a similar service.

title: Walks in Bronx Parks
description: Free walking tours in two Bronx parks will be led this weekend by the Urban Park Rangers.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: BIENNIAL SHOW
description: SEEN through the lens of the Whitney Museum's 1983 Biennial Exhibition, today's photography would seem to be almost totally preoccupied with questions of personal identity and the effects of the mass media. The world as it is - as it exists outside the boundaries of the imagination - barely makes an appearance in the work of the eight artists who have been identified as photographers by the Biennial's curators. Portraiture, landscapes, photojournalism - these traditional genres have very little bearing on our understanding of the pictures on view. Their references are not so much to photography itself as to television, the movies, commercial advertising and the art world of painting and sculpture.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE notion of art songs written in a rock-and-roll idiom seems almost a contradiction in terms. But for many, Randy Newman's rich blend of musical styles and serious humor go far beyond ordinary pop in the way that the best of the Kurt Weill-Bertolt Brecht songs do.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income

title: TRIAL BEGINS IN THE CBS MURDER CASE
description: A prosecutor opened the murder trial of Donald Nash yesterday by asserting that a ''myriad of facts and circumstances'' would prove that the defendant had been hired by the head of a jewelry manufacturing company to kill a Federal witness, and that the conspiracy had led to the murders of five people.

title: Mobile Phone Plan Cleared
description: The Federal Communications Commission approved, with conditions, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's $1.47 billion plan for financing its subsidiary for cellular radio mobile telephone service through 1986.

title: Cox Communications Promoting Its President
description: Clifford M. Kirtland, the chairman of Cox Communications Inc., will step down on June 1 and be replaced by William A. Schwartz, president and chief operating officer of the Atlanta-based broadcast company. The change was announced yesterday at the company's annual meeting.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Musical Cars
description: The New Yorker who keeps his car on the street thinks of alternate-side-of-street parking the way a summer camper thinks about a sadistic counselor.

title: TELETEXT AUTHORIZED BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission today authorized the broadcasting of pages of teletext services for reception by television sets.

title: U.D.C. MOVING TO LIMIT COSTS OF CONSULTANTS
description: In its first move to limit reliance on outside consultants, the state's Urban Development Corporation has dropped five law firms, including one that billed the agency for more than $1 million in services last year.

title: FRENCH UNRUFFLED ON SOVIET GAS PRICE
description: Gaz de France, this country's state-owned monopoly gas supplier, said today that if oil prices remain low next year it will seek to work out a lower price for the natural gas it has agreed to buy from the Soviet Union.

title: REV. HERBERT H. COOPER
description: The Rev. Herbert Hannan Cooper, former rector of Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills, N.J., died March l7 in Stuart, Fla., where he had lived since retiring. He was 73 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * General Electric said that it would spend about $316 million to automate its Erie, Pa., locomotive plant by 1986, increasing production capacity by one-third.

title: LET'S BURN, NOT BURY, OUR TOXIC WASTES
description: To the Editor:

title: James Jarrett Jr., 90, Doorman At Bendel's for Over 70 Years
description: James Jarrett Jr., the doorman at Henri Bendel's for more than 70 years, died Wednesday in a nursing home in Queens after suffering a stroke. He would have been 91 years old yesterday.

title: REAGAN CALLS NUCLEAR FREEZE DANGEROUS
description: President Reagan, stepping up his opposition to the enactment of a nuclear freeze resolution in Congress, appealed today to supporters of the measure to put aside ''partisan politics'' and unite behind his Administration's arms control proposals to the Soviet Union.

title: RANGERS WIN ON 2 LATE GOALS
description: Patience, resilience and the mercurial talents of Reijo Ruotsalainen lifted the Rangers to a 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers tonight in a preview of next week's opening-round playoff series.

title: No Alterations In Rules Seen
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's Basketball Rules Committee is not expected to incorporate either a shot clock or a 3-point shooting line in next season's rules, according to the senior member of that committee.

title: Friday; THREE MEN ON A CHELSEA STAGE
description: Three troupers of many parts, a comic mime, a juggler and a clownjuggler perform alone and together in ''Foolsfire,'' a lighthearted collaboration of a sort the same three have done before. At one point Bob Berky, the comic mime, tries to take a shower. At another, Fred Garbo, the clown-juggler, assays a unicycle. Michael Moschen, the juggler, tosses, among other things, airplanes and - in a serious sequence for which he is known - crystal balls. The three men can be seen at 11 P.M. on Fridays and Saturdays through April 16 at the Dance Theater Workshop, 219 West 19th Street, in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, as part of the late-night ''Economy Tires Theater'' series. Admission is $6, and the number for reservations, which are recommended, is 924-0077. KAREN AKERS AT CARNEGIE HALL

title: MUD CLOTHS ADD A DASH OF PATTERN
description: This winter, they were a bright counterpoint to all the black that everyone seemed to be wearing. This spring, they are serving the same purpose, even if black is giving way in some quarters to gray.

title: Times Square Plan Upheld by Court
description: The state's highest court decided today that a $1 billion renovation project of New York City's Times Square area should move forward.

title: FOR 'CAPITAL STEPS,' NIGHTTIME IS FOR SATIRE
description: Political satire has long been a staple of after-hours life in the capital and now a new group, composed of nine young Congressional staff members and named ''The Capital Steps,'' has taken to song and dance to spoof their bosses, their political parties and themselves.

title: Kyocera to Merge With Yashica
description: The Kyocera Corporation said it plans to merge with the Yashica Company on Oct. 1.

title: TIDWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
ART: WAR PICTURES BY GEORGE BELLOWS
description: ''GEORGE BELLOWS and the War Series of 1918'' at the Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street, is as nasty an exhibition as this visitor has ever had to work his way through. But as a record of an important phase in the career of a painter for whom many Americans feel a particular affection, it should undoubtedly be seen.

title: 'OPERATION TIT FOR TAT' READY FOR THE RUSSIANS
description: With little advance publicity, the State Department on Friday is starting something one official called ''Operation Tit for Tat.''

title: PARTY SAID TO SCAN APPOINTEES
description: Some Cabinet departments routinely send the Republican National Committee the names of potential appointees to departmental boards and commissions, Administration sources said today.

title: E.P.A.'S DOW TESTS FIND HIGH TOXICITY
description: The Environmental Protection Agency reported today that it had found more than 40 toxic organic compounds, including dioxins, in the waste water that the Dow Chemical Company pumps into the Tittabawassee River in Michigan.

title: THE REGION
description: Westchester County has added more buses to help commuters during the Metro-North rail strike, a county official said today.

title: Salvador Rebels Report Big Battle With Army
description: The Salvadoran Army rushed reinforcements today to a northern province where guerrillas said they had killed 84 soldiers in a major battle that would lead to the military's ''total collapse.''

title: Ex-Coach Sues
description: Pam Parsons, a former women's basketball coach at the University of South Carolina, has filed a libel suit against Sports Illustrated, charging that an article accusing her of homosexual involvement with her players had ''totally devastated'' her career. Also named in the suit were two school officials. Miss Parsons, who resigned Jan. 4, 1982, called the February 1982 article ''a false, biased and totally irresponsible portrayal'' of her tenure at the school. Barbara Orlando, a spokesman for Time Inc., said here, ''Our legal department hasn't seen the papers so we really can't comment on it.'' ... Attorneys for Aaron Pryor, the World Boxing Association's junior welterweight champion, and ABC-TV have asked the Ohio Supreme Court to set aside a lower-court ruling that could put off his title bout with Sang Hyun Kim of Korea tomorrow in Atlantic City. The fight's status is uncertain because of an injunction issued by a Common Pleas Court judge in Hamilton County, Ohio, and upheld by Ohio's First District Court of Appeals. The lower courts agreed that the fight could not take place because it had not been approved by Pryor's estranged manager, Buddy LaRosa. Pryor has a suit pending in which he is attempting to be released from the contract with LaRosa. ... Twelve minority stockholders of the Cleveland Cavaliers have sued the majority owner, Ted Stepien, charging him with mismanagement and seeking to prevent him from linking the sale of his television station to the sale of the team.

title: HODGES GETS SHOT IN METS' SPOTLIGHT
description: He does not earn big bucks, and he has never been a regular in 10 seasons in the big leagues. But in the job scramble of the final four days of spring training, Ron Hodges stood today as perhaps the most secure and indispensable of the 32 players in the camp of the Mets.

title: Stewards Uphold Victory in Stakes
description: Stewards at Latonia Race Course today declared Marfa winner of the disputed $200,000-added Spiral Stakes last Saturday after rejecting two appeals on the colt's eligibility.

title: NATIONAL KINNEY CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses of $850,000 and $9,400,000 from provisions for losses on disposition of discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income after a $667,000 loss from discontinued businesses, a $750,000 loss from a provision for loss on disposition of discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $16,670,000. d-Net income after a loss on discontinued businesses of $773,000, a loss of $750,000 from the provision for loss on disposition of discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $16,870,000. The 1982 results include a gain of $6,351,000 realized on the sale of an office building subsidiary.

title: SHARP RISE FOUND IN DISEASE THAT IS DANGER IN PREGNANCY
description: The incidence of a life-threatening disease of pregnancy in which the fetus develops outside the uterus has increased dramatically in the United States in the last decade, researchers said yesterday.

title: FEBRUARY ATTEMPT BY REAGAN TO ASSURE SOVIET IS DISCLOSED
description: President Reagan met with the Soviet Ambassador, Anatoly F. Dobrynin, in February to assure him that the United States was sincere about negotiating with Moscow, White House officials said today.

title: Vira Ingham Heinz, 95; Food Concern Leader
description: Vira Ingham Heinz, the first woman to become a member of the board of directors of the H.J. Heinz Company, died today in Shadyside Hospital after a long illness. She was 95 years old.

title: Ford Unit to Offer $300 Million Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for $300 million of floating rate notes. Interest on the notes will fluctuate according to changes in the London interbank offering rate for six-month deposits.

title: NOW RECONSIDER DISARMING
description: The accomplishments of the strategy of arms control, which emerged in the 1950's as a ''practical'' alternative to disarmament, have been mixed and meager. Today, we must pronounce this strategy fatally defective, because neither in the theory nor practice of arms control is there a program or vision that moves humanity beyond the arms race. The alternative remains disarmament, integrally linked to the forging of a world security arrangement.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF SPEECH BY REAGAN IN BEVERLY HILLS ON HIS ARMS CONTROL POLICY
description: Following is a transcript of a speech by President Reagan to the Los Angeles World Affairs Council yesterday in Beverly Hills, as recorded by The New York Times. He was introduced by Henry Singleton, head of the group.

title: DEVILS LOSE HOME FINALE, 8-5
description: The New Jersey Devils took 40 shots on goal in the final game of their first season at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, but they were defeated, 8-5, by the Buffalo Sabres before a crowd of 13,286.

title: HERALDS OF FAITH IN AGE OF CHANGE
description: As stewards of the mysteries of God, the Rev. Robert A. Shires and the Rev. Harold L. Myers Jr. have shared a common call. Between them, they have spent 48 years in the pulpit, and, at different times, both have been shepherds of the same flock.

title: A Rate Ceiling To End Today
description: The process of bank deregulation will move forward one additional step today with the removal of ceilings on the amount of interest that banks and savings institutions may pay on 2 1/2-year certificates of deposit.

title: DUTY-FREE IMPORTS CUT BY $1.4 BILLION
description: President Reagan signed an order today reducing by $1.4 billion, to $7 billion, the value of imports from developing countries that may come into the United States duty-free annually.

title: Flexi-Van's Chief Expects a Contest
description: Lewis Rubin, the 45-year-old president and chief executive of the Flexi-Van Corporation, worked in his New York office yesterday in shirt-sleeves and gave the appearance of a pragmatic manager intent on day-to-day operations.

title: Man of parts directs first film at 80.
description: THE ''New Directors/New Films'' series, which ended at the 57th Street Playhouse yesterday, was nothing if not adventurous. One double feature brought us ''Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop: We Cut Heads'' and ''The Truuuuth.'' ''Joe's Bed-Stuy'' was made as Spike Lee's thesis film for $12,000. New York University's graduate film school furnished the equipment; Mr. Lee did the rest. Mr. Lee is 25 years old; Cesare Zavattini, who made ''The Truuuuth,'' is 80. ''The Truuuuth'' was his first directing effort, and he also wrote and starred in it as an escaped lunatic who tries to convince passing strangers that any man's death diminishes them. Mr. Zavatttini's protagonist believes we can't tell ourselves we're good people just because we ooh and ah over children dismembered by bombs; we have to take responsibility for stopping such disasters.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Lonrho Loses Bid In Harrods Spinoff
description: Lonrho Ltd.'s bid to spin off the giant Harrods department store from the House of Fraser, the retailing company in which Lonrho has a 30 percent stake, was rejected by the retailing group's directors.

title: TELEPICTURES CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss on discontinued operations of $52,500.

title: Judge Bars Closing of Kearny Plant
description: A Federal judge yesterday enjoined the Western Electric Company from closing down its Kearny, N.J., plant until it receives court permission.

title: THE SOUL MUSIC OF INDIA
description: THERE are many Indias, but as far as most Americans are concerned, there is only one sort of Indian music. The fact is, there are two. The Indian musicians who are best known in this country - Ravi Shankar and Ali Akbar Khan, for example - play northern Indian music. Southern Indian music, which has been called India's ''soul'' music, is heard infrequently in this country. Yet the southern Indian style (also known as the Carnatic) has its own system of ragas (melodic forms) and talas (rhythmic cycles), its own terminology and a history that is older than that of the northern Indian style.

title: HART SCHAFFNER & MARX reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including a gain of $1,765,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: JOB SAFETY AGENCY TO WEIGH TOUGHER BENZENE RULE
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration announced today that it would soon consider tightening the standards for limiting exposure to benzene, a substance known to cause leukemia.

title: DOROTHY DONEGAN CURBS THE 'HAMMINESS' OF OLD
description: DOROTHY DONEGAN is playing piano at Jimmy Weston's, and people who deal with her say that this once-feisty, temperamental woman has, at the age of 58, mellowed. She agrees.

title: PUBLISHING: RECESSION PROMPTING NEW STRATEGIES
description: CONVERSATION overheard between two publishers: ''How's business?'' ''Terrific, but we hope it'll get better soon.'' As the effects of the recession linger in many publishing houses, with lists cut back and seasoned editors let go or quitting under pressure to produce best sellers, one hears more about diminishing subsidiary rights and efforts to sell everything but the squeal (as they used to say around the Chicago stockyards).

title: A DISMISSED STANFORD PH.D. CANDIDATE'S WRONG PROTEST FORUM
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER: SUICIDE TALK IN ''NIGHT MOTHER'
description: ''WE'VE got a good life here,'' says Thelma Cates to her daughter, Jessie, in Marsha Norman's new play, '''Night, Mother.'' Many would agree. Thelma, who is a widow, and Jessie, who is divorced, live together in a spick-and-span house on a country road somewhere in the New South. There are no money problems. Nights are spent in such relaxed pursuits as crocheting and watching television.

title: THEATER: 'THE GREAT CONFESSION'
description: ''THE GREAT CONFESSION,'' the play running through Sunday at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, is about a marriage that may have been made somewhat below the heights of Heaven and that runs briskly downhill when the television set breaks down and the man and wife have only each other to speak to.

title: AN UNDER SECRETARY WITH A RARE BENT FOR CANDOR
description: In an Administration that has vigorously striven to stifle public expression of internal dissent, Richard D. DeLauer stands out as an individualist. Mr. DeLauer, who is Under Secretary of Defense for Research and Engineering, is given neither to pulling his punches nor deleting his expletives.

title: Italy's Inflation Rate
description: Italy's consumer price index rose nine-tenths of 1 percent in March, down from a 1.3 percent increase in February, the Government reported today. The March rise put the year-to-year gain in the cost of living at 16.4 percent.

title: G.M. Denies Plan To End Chevette
description: The General Motors Corporation plans to start phasing out its Chevrolet Chevette in 1985 and has been studying what to do with its two Chevette plants in Georgia and Delaware, United Automobile Workers officials say. But Roger B. Smith, G.M. chairman, repeatedly has denied any such plans and a G.M. spokesman, John Mueller, said he knew nothing about such a phase-out.

title: Alabama Stops Trucks Carrying Tainted Soil
description: State troopers stopped 20 trucks loaded with contaminated soil Wednesday after state environmental officials said the trucks had come from Florida without a permit to carry hazardous waste in Alabama.

title: California High Court Cuts Malpractice Law
description: Hospitals convicted of malpractice must pay damages in a single sum, the California Supreme Court ruled today, striking down a key section of a law adopted by the Legislature in 1975.

title: 'Sun-Maid' on Raisin Box Dies
description: Lorraine Collett Petersen, the model for the glowing young woman on the Sun-Maid Raisin box, died here Wednesday. She was 90 years old.

title: Mies pavilion to rise again.
description: PLANS to reconstruct Ludwig Mies van der Rohe's 1929 German Pavilion, which the architect Philip Johnson has called ''the paradigm of that period of architecture,'' were announced last week at the Museum of Modern Art by Mayor Pasqual Maragall of Barcelona.

title: Fragile Lilies And the Threat of Cold
description: Forecasts of freezing temperatures left Carl T. Miller nervous as he oversaw the planting yesterday morning of more than 800 Lilium longiflorum - creamy white, heavily scented Easter lilies - in the marble beds at Rockefeller Center.

title: New Orleans Police Oust 3 of 7 in Rights Case
description: Three detectives convicted Monday of civil rights violations were dismissed today by the Police Superintendent.

title: Backing of Wagner Draws Criticism
description: The president of One Hundred Black Men yesterday criticized Frank J. Macchiarola, head of the New York City Partnership, for the way in which he endorsed a candidate to be his successor as Schools Chancellor.

title: Help Wanted: Soccer Players
description: Team America will play its first games abroad next week as the national soccer team of the United States, but Coach Alkis Panagoulias is finding it difficult to get players.

title: 2 FRANCES, 1 PROBLEM
description: France is caught today between two kinds of problems - between the technical realities of finance and the mythological world of ideology. After more than 35 years as a committed leftist, I find with some surprise that ideology doesn't mean very much in the face of economic necessity.

title: Underground Poles Vow Not to Disrupt Papal Trip
description: Underground leaders of the outlawed Solidarity union have pledged not to demonstrate during the visit of Pope John Paul II in June,but to press for protests on May Day.

title: CHICAGO CANDIDATE RECEIVES $93,000 IN NEW YORK
description: Representative Harold Washington collected $93,000 in political contributions in New York yesterday and heard his campaign for mayor of Chicago characterized as a referendum on racism.

title: RISE URGED IN TARIFFS ON CYCLES
description: President Reagan's trade advisers are urging him unanimously to impose sharp tariff increases on motorcycles during the next five years to help the Harley-Davidson Motor Company in its battle against rising Japanese imports, Administration officials said today.

title: A SOPHOMORE WHO LISTENED
description: The sophomore would not shoot the ball. His jump shot was his team's best weapon against the zone defense, but he would pass the ball back to his older teammates rather than shoot.

title: Economic Scene; Technology And Jobless
description: NEW data on the labor market in March, to be released today, will be scanned for signs that the recovery is strengthening or weakening. But whatever the new numbers show, it looks like a very long haul back to anything that can be called ''full employment,'' which was once thought to be equivalent to 4 percent unemployment.

title: F.A.A. Progress Cited In Employee Relations
description: An independent panel that warned last year of serious management-employee problems in the Federal Aviation Administration agreed today that progress has been made toward improving the working environment.

title: JUDGE GIVES TEAMSTER CHIEF LONG TERM
description: Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was sentenced today to a long prison term in a bungled attempt to bribe a United States Senator.

title: Prices to Farmers Rise
description: Prices farmers get for raw products rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in March, the third consecutive monthly increase, matching levels of a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today. Higher prices for beef cattle, tomatoes, corn, eggs and wheat were mostly responsible for the increase, but lower prices for hogs, oranges and broilers partially offset the gains for the other commodities, the department said.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 4-for-3 stock stplit paid in January.

title: Remy on Disabled List
description: Jerry Remy, who hit .280 last season as the leadoff man for the Boston Red Sox, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday because of a pulled muscle in his lower back.

title: JAPAN'S LEADERSHIP AMONG CAR MAKERS FACING TESTS ABROAD
description: These are heady days for the Japanese auto industry. Ridiculed as recently as two decades ago as producing cheap, unreliable vehicles, it is today the largest and strongest in the world, having surpassed the American industry in sales in 1980. Long-established auto companies in the West are forging alliances with Japanese companies to share in Japan's advances in quality and production techniques. Even the General Motors Corporation, the world's largest industrial company and long considered a model of scientific management, has decided it must turn to the Japanese for help with smaller cars.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Wednesday, quoting a General Motors press release, erroneously reported part of the company's plans for repairing 240,000 of its X-cars that are being recalled under an agreement with the National Highway Safety administration. The company said yesterday that it would replace the parking brake cables in all 240,000 cars so that the parking brakes would meet Federal standards.

title: FRIDAY, APRIL 1, 1983
description: Energy

title: VOLCKER SET TO TESTIFY BEFORE A HOUSE PANEL
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, is scheduled to testify before the House Baning Committee on April 12, according to officials at the Fed.

title: MOYNIHAN QUESTIONS C.I.A.'S LATIN ROLE
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the vice chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee, says Congress may have to tighten restrictions on American intelligence activities in Central America to prevent involvement in efforts to overthrow the Government of Nicaragua.

title: Jazz Pianos at Forum
description: The jazz pianists Jaki Byard and Tommy Flanagan will perform duets on a pair of Steinways tonight and tomorrow at the Jazz Forum, 648 Broadway at Bleecker Street (477-2655), accompanied by Major Holley on bass and Richard Allen on drums. Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M., and admission for all three is $8.

title: LOTTERY IS PLANNED FOR LOW-POWER TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission today adopted a plan to distribute licenses to operate low-power television stations by lottery, but with special preferences for black, Hispanic and other minority applicants.

title: Bridge:; Culbertson's Asking Bids Have Been Much Revised
description: Modern tournament players who use asking bids employ a much simpler version than that urged unavailingly by Ely Culbertson nearly half a century ago.

title: Joe Cooper Finds a Role
description: Playing center for the San Diego Clippers has been a risky proposition over the last two seasons. Three of the centers - Swen Nater, Bill Walton and Jerome Whitehead -have been sidelined with injuries. But that didn't discourage Joe Cooper when he received a telephone call last Sunday from Paul Phipps, the Clippers' general manager.

title: Dow Loses 13.26 Points; Oil Issues Surge
description: Stock prices as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled in active trading yesterday, but oil issues surged on the strength of buy recommendations from some major brokerage houses. The Dow, after being ahead 8 points in early trading, fell 13.26 points, to 1,130.03.

title: Dow, Dioxin and Poisoned Carp
description: Dioxin has once again demonstrated its formidable reach. The potent poison that ravages Times Beach and many other sites in Missouri has turned up in Michigan's Saginaw Bay and in its carp, some of which are eaten in New York.

title: Jersey City Getting New York Concern
description: The Manhattan-based Metropolitan Tele-Tronic Corporation said today that it would move its operations to two waterfront warehouses in Jersey City.

title: BUSY TIME FOR PAULA MCGEE OF U.S.C.
description: Paula McGee has a lot on her mind. Today, she was named to the Kodak women's all-America basketball team. On Friday night, she leads Southern California against Georgia at the Scope in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's championship. And with all that, she worries where her fiance is going.

title: THAIS SAY VIETNAM RAIDS CAMBODIANS
description: Thailand said today that a large force of Vietnamese troops had attacked three Cambodian refugee and guerrilla camps along the Thai-Cambodian border and that at least 7,000 civilians had fled westward into Thai territory.

title: Comings and Goings
description: In his 41 years at DePaul, Ray Meyer has won more games (697) than any other active basketball coach, and he's not through yet.

title: ALMY STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After a charge of $428,000 for the closing of two unprofitable stores. c-Net income.

title: GRACEFUL SETTINGS FOR AN EASTER BRUNCH
description: INVITING as a stylish brunch can be at any time of the year, Easter Sunday seems the most appropriate day for it. Perhaps it is the combined appeal of spring, new clothes and a holiday air that suggests an especially festive brunch in one of the city's more gracefully pretty settings. This year, because many restaurants are putting the emphasis on dinner rather than on brunch, the choice is somewhat more limited than usual. Nevertheless, there is a fairly wide choice around the city. Most of these restaurants are serving both light dishes suitable for those who want what is basically a breakfast and more substantial dishes for lunch, or the meal of the day, by any name. Reservations are accepted unless otherwise noted.

title: RECORD DIVORCE RULING ISSUED BY JUDGE ON COAST
description: A judge overseeing the largest divorce action in history today ordered Sheik Mohammed S.A. al-Fassi to give his wife half his fortune, which she says is worth $6 billion.

title: POP: JOHNNY JOHNSTON, SINGER
description: THE passing years have had little effect on the repertory of Johnny Johnston, the singer who first sang ''That Old Black Magic'' in the 1942 film ''Star Spangled Rhythm'' and introduced ''Laura'' on his radio show in 1945. At Michael's Pub, where he is picking up his singing career after a 12-year retirement and making his first appearance in a New York club in two decades, Mr. Johnston emphasizes his allegiance to the songs of the 30's, 40's and early 50's as he introduces his performance with a parody of an Ira Gershwin lyric, singing ''They're Writing Songs Today/But Not for Me''.

title: Claims of Newly Jobless Down
description: First-time claims for government unemployment benefits declined in the week ended March 19, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Tosco Is Granted Waivers by Banks
description: The Tosco Corporation, one of the nation's largest independent oil refiners, announced yesterday that it expected to report a $40 million operating loss for the first quarter and that its bankers had waived certain covenants to avoid putting the company in default on its loans.

title: FOREIGN PRIESTS IN CHILE RISKING THE RULER'S WRATH
description: The Rev. Aloysius Connaughton is an Irish Roman Catholic priest in Chile. He suffers a private agony. For nearly 10 years Chile has been ruled by Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Torture is common, political dissent is outlawed and the economy is depressed. More than half of the workers in Father Connaughton's parish in this shabby residential city near Santiago are out of work.

title: POKER IS DISCOVERED BY A NEW GENERATION
description: After work one afternoon, Larry Novak strolled into a windowless room in the State Capitol in Albany and joined the poker game that is almost always in full swing there at that time of the day. Mr. Novak, a special assistant to the New York State Commissioner of Taxation and Finance, was scowling at his cards when the telephone rang.

title: GAS TAX RISE LIKELY TO SHOW UP AT PUMP
description: A 5-cent-a-gallon increase in Federal gasoline taxes becomes effective today, and most or all of the increase is expected to be passed directly through to the driving public.

title: Brown Denies Rumor
description: Despite the Nets' success ths season, there has been talk that Coach Larry Brown may leave the pros in favor of a college coaching job. Brown, who is in his second season with the Nets, dismissed the talk as ''rumor.''

title: PROPERTY AT ISSUE IN THE MARX CASE
description: The judge who presided over a 10-week trial of the Bank of America's dispute with Erin Fleming, Groucho Marx's longtime companion and business manager, must now decide whether Miss Fleming has to give up two houses, business holdings and a luxury car in addition to paying more than $450,000 in damages awarded the bank.

title: Beal Considers A Bid for Reita
description: The Real Estate Investment Trust of America, the target of an unfriendly takeover attempt, said that Beal & Company, another real estate concern, is considering acquiring Reita for $45 a share.

title: EX-AIDE AT AGENCY IS NOW AT PARADYNE
description: A computer expert who used to work at the Social Security Administration is now working for a computer company that won a $100 million contract to provide a telecommunications system linking 1,400 Social Security offices throughout the country.

title: DANCE: BURACZESKI COMPANY
description: THE program presented on Saturday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church by the Danny Buraczeski Dance Company might have proved a surprise to anyone familiar with contemporary jazz dance. There weren't many thrusting pelvises, grinding hips or stretched scat arms here. Mr. Buraczeski's work is an inventive departure from the form.

title: Letter Campaign
description: Letters from school children in Lawrence, Kan., may be responsible for the presence of 18 Soviet track and field athletes at the Kansas Relays April 20 through 23.

title: Rampage on T.C.U. Campus
description: Members of a Texas Christian University fraternity, disgruntled over the organization's suspension for hazing, went on a rampage Wednesday night that caused $2,000 damage to a dormitory, a school spokesman said. The Sigma Alpha Epsilon fraternity members broke windows, dumped trash and damaged ceiling tiles and a fire alarm at Martin-Moore Hall, a T.C.U. dormitory where 34 of the fraternity members live.

title: M. A. Paige, First Black To Be a City Magistrate
description: Myles A. Paige, the first black to be named as a New York City magistrate, died Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. Mr. Paige, who was 84 years old, was a retired judge of the Family Court in New York.

title: STATE APPEALS COURT STRIKES DOWN A BAN ON ALCOHOL IN PUBLIC
description: New York State's highest court yesterday struck down a Monticello, N.Y., ordinance that banned open containers of alcoholic beverages in public places. It called the ordinance overly broad and said it could be used to control ''innocuous behavior.''

title: Emerson set tops sale list.
description: AMERICAN books and manuscripts, which are collected more quietly these days than they were five to 10 years ago when great private collections sold at record-breaking auctions, will be up for bidding next Wednesday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue and 72d Street. American literature of the 19th and 20th centuries dominates the sale, with the most important lot being a gilded green-morocco-leather, 23-volume set of the works of Emerson from 1903-14, which may sell for as much as $6,000. The set has faded spines (green fades fast) and contains 25 leaves of special autograph material tipped in - a document signed by Hawthorne and letters signed by Whittier, Longfellow, Lowell and Oliver Wendell Holmes. Another interesting American offering is the first four volumes of Audubon's ''Birds of America,'' from the 1840's (up to $3,500).

title: Guessing is over on the return of 'Caine Mutiny.'
description: WHEN John Rubinstein, Michael Moriarty and William Atherton starred in a revival of Herman Wouk's ''Caine Mutiny Court-Martial'' in January at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn., there was a lot of speculation about who would be behind the production's inevitable move to Broadway. Now, the guessing has stopped. Circle in the Square and the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington are bringing it in as a co-venture. ''The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial'' will begin previews at Circle in the Square on April 15, under the direction of Arthur Sherman, and will open on May 5. The producers' plan is to run the play in New York as long as possible and then move it to the Kennedy Center.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: PHILHARMONIC: WAGNER, BRUCKNER AND HISTORY
description: THE programs of symphony orchestras often look as if they had been pulled out of a hat or made up by a devotee of I Ching. However, history presented Zubin Mehta with the chance to give last night's New York Philharmonic program a unifying theme and the orchestra's music director seized it. The result was a concert that went together with a rare sense of simple logic as well as musical cohesiveness.

title: CONNECTICUT SENATE PASSES TAX BILL AND O'NEILL SIGNS IT
description: Starting Friday, motorists in Connecticut will see at least an 8-cent-a-gallon jump in gasoline prices - 5 cents in the Federal tax to rebuild the nation's highways and 3 cents in the state tax to help offset a growing state deficit.

title: Advertising; Curtis: In Search of Big Profits
description: PACKAGE goods marketers have a number of options with a new product: selling it as a private label or generic brand and the lowest price possible for the consumer; raising the price slightly, using a moderate amount of promotion but using the low price as the advertised consumer benefit, or pushing up the price, finding a meaningful consumer benefit and then promoting it heavily.

title: ROCK MUSIC WAR
description: IN the summer and fall of 1980, a crew of film makers went to work capturing concert performances by more than 25 new wave rock groups in New York, California and Europe. A sound track album from ''Urgh! A Music War'' was released in 1981, but the film is only coming to the surface now. It opens a one-week run today at the Bleecker Street Cinema and starting April 8 it will be shown on Fridays and Saturdays at midnight.

title: CENTURY OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Society's Duty at Birth
description: Last spring an Indiana baby with Down's Syndrome and an incomplete esophagus died six days after he was born. The death of ''Infant Doe'' was, in one sense, natural: he died of starvation. In another, it was not: his parents had chosen not to feed him, and the courts complied with their wish.

title: MAN WITH KNIFE ATTACKS A GUARD IN M.T.A. OFFICE
description: An intruder armed with a knife who said he had ''something'' to give the chairman of the Metropolitan Transit Authority slashed at a policeman guarding the midtown office yesterday and then fled into an elevator and escaped.

title: PROTEST IN BRITAIN STRETCHES 14 MILES
description: Thousands of protesters formed a human chain stretching 14 miles across the English countryside today.

title: 2 Fights for Cooney
description: Gerry Cooney, who has not fought other than in an exhibition since being stopped in the 13th round by Larry Holmes last June 11, has two weekend afternoon fights scheduled on CBS. He will meet a former sparring partner, Phillip Brown, on June 18, and Gordon Racette, a Canadian club fighter, on July 23. Mike Jones, one of Cooney's managers, said that in addition a non-televised fight might be scheduled for late May.

title: NVF CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Includes equity in the net loss of affiliates of $15.1 million for the quarter and $10.4 million for the year. c-Includes equity in the net earnings of affiliates of $2.5 million for the quarter and $13.3 million for the year. d-Net income The 1982 net loss also included a charge of $9.6 million resulting from the valuation of certain LIFO inventories and partially offset by benefits of $5.9 million relating to a liquidation of other LIFO inventories. Results for 1982 and 1981 included realized gains on the sales of equity securities of $5 million, or 6 cents a share, after tax, and $22.2 million, or 23 cents a share, after tax, respectively.

title: SPACECRAFT CREW ARRIVES FOR FLIGHT
description: The four astronauts who are to fly the first mission of the new space shuttle Challenger arrived here late this afternoon as countdown preparations proceeded smoothly toward a scheduled launching Monday.

title: Wage Freeze Arranged At Washington Opera
description: Two unions at the Washington Opera have agreed to a wage freeze for next season, and the opera says it will use the savings to produce an additional opera. The unions are the Musicians Local 161-710 and the Stagehands Local 22.

title: SCAN-DATA CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
8 SOVIET JEWS SEEK TO COMBAT ZIONISM
description: Eight Soviet Jews - writers, scholars, a military man and a cinematographer -published a statement in Pravda today that criticized ''international Zionism'' for purporting to speak on behalf of Soviet Jews.

title: Big Eggs
description: A mid the warehouse and loft buildings in SoHo, some enormous bunny had apparently paused to deliver 50 three-foot-high eggs - pink, lavender, yellow, green and blue - to Architectural Sculpture, Lafayette Street near Spring.

title: GANG RAPE STUNS OLD BOSTON SECTION
description: Before dawn one day this week, the police arrived to wake and arrest seven young men in the Charlestown section here on charges of kidnap, indecent assault and rape.

title:
PATENTS;
Exploding Napkin With Printed Message
description: When a customer picks up a cocktail napkin, his fingers cause gasfilled bubbles in the margin to explode with a bang, calling his attention to a printed message. The new advertising medium is described in patent 4,378,391, granted this week to Michael L. Allen of Rockford, Ill. A sample message given is ''Pop away your tension as you drink Brand X.''

title: JUDGE IN MARX CASE DENIES MISTRIAL BUT WON'T ASSIGN PROPERTY
description: A Superior Court judge today denied a defense motion for a mistrial in the Groucho Marx estate case. But she ruled that Erin Fleming, the comedian's companion for the last years of his life, would not have to turn over to the Bank of America two houses and other gifts.

title: SIX ARE ARRESTED ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Six people were arrested and $1 million worth of heroin and $83,000 in cash, along with weapons and drug-processing paraphernalia, were seized in raids in Manhattan and the Bronx, drug enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: AMERICAN QUASAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income including a gain of $23.5 million from the sale of a Canadian subsidiary.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Per Series A common share. c-Per Series B common share. Series A share earnings have been adjusted for intervening stock dividends and for a 2-for-1 stock split. Series B share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income

title: MARITIME ELECTRIC CO LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
SHAPELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net loss c-Includes a gain of $1,909,000, or 97 cents a share, cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting principle. The latest year's net loss included a pre-tax charge of $3.7 million for the reduction of certain real estate assets to net realizable value. The 1981 quarter and year losses included a pre-tax charge of $13 million for the reduction of certain real estate assets to net realizable value.

title: FRENCH CALL ARCHIVIST A SOVIET SPY
description: French police officials said today that they had arrested a man for of passing industrial secrets to the Soviet Union. The police said the man, Patrick Guerrier, 25 years old, an archivist for a company that officials would not identify, had photocopied documents and passed them to officials of the Soviet Embassy whom the police identified as agents of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence agency.

title: DANCE: LUISE WYKELL TROUPE DEMONSTRATES THREE THEMES
description: Just as certain old friends are always pleasant to see again, so certain familiar choreographic themes can bear repetition. Thursday night's program by Luise Wykell and Company at the Marymount Manhattan Theater was devoted to three tried-and-true themes. But Miss Wykell's choreography made at least two of them seem like welcome friends.

title: THAIS ACCUSE VIETNAM OF KILLING 200 CAMBODIANS
description: The Thai Foreign Ministry said today that Vietnamese soldiers had killed at least 200 Cambodian refugees, wounded hundreds more and driven 30,000 across the frontier since overrunning a Cambodian guerrilla camp near the Thai border on Thursday.

title: ELSIE EAVES
description: Elsie Eaves, one of the first women to become a civil engineer, died Sunday at St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn, L.I. She was 84 years old and lived in Port Washington, L.I.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP MODESTLY
description: The nation's basic money supply rose a modest $400 million in the latest reporting week, the Federal Reserve said yesterday. M-1, which measures checking accounts, cash and other deposits that are readily available for spending, climbed to $497.2 billion for the week ended March 23, roughly in line with expectations.

title: Reagan Nominates Admiral
description: President Reagan has nominated Adm. William N. Small as commander in chief of United States naval forces in Europe and of allied forces in Southern Europe, the Pentagon announced today.

title:
PATENTS;
Study of Inventions In Microelectronics
description: A study of inventions in microelectronics, including talking games and means for the verbally handicapped to communicate orally, has been issued by the Office of Technology Assessment and Forecast, a unit in the Patent and Trademark Office.

title: ENERGY VENTURES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
BEACON PHOTO SERVICE INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $384,000 for the latest year and $39,000 for the previous year.

title: A Borg Epilogue
description: A day after Bjorn Borg had been eliminated from the Monte Carlo Open, which was expected to be his last major tournament, the president of the International Tennis Federation, Philippe Chatrier, suggested that the retirement of the Swedish star might have implications for other players.

title: WESTINGHOUSE IS SUED IN NUCLEAR PLANT DEFECTS
description: Two California utilities have filed a $260 million suit against the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, contending that the company is responsible for defects in three key components of a nuclear plant near San Clemente.

title: ARMY HELICOPTERS EVACUATE COLOMBIAN QUAKE VICTIMS
description: Army helicopters brought tents, food and other emergency supplies today and evacuated seriously injured victims of the earthquake that killed more than 200 people and devastated this Andean provincial capital.

title: F.T.C. Cites Ethyl, Du Pont
description: The Ethyl Corporation and E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company have restrained competition in the market for lead-based antiknock gasoline additives and must stop their illegal pricing practices, the Federal Trade Commission said.

title: ROLE OF 'BENNO BLIMPIE' AS SEEN BY PETER EVANS
description: Peter Evans, who wears a gigantic padded costume and eats himself to death each night in ''The Transfiguration of Benno Blimpie,'' the critically praised play written and directed by Albert Innaurato at Playwrights Horizons, handed the script back to the playwright after reading it for the first time 12 years ago. ''Not my cup of tea,'' he said, to which Mr. Innaurato replied ''One day you will do this part.''

title: BALTEK CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $622,000 for the quarter and $18,000 for the year and extraordinary tax credits of $644,000 for the quarter and $111,000 for the year.

title: MILLIONS OF G.M. CARS CITED FOR SAFETY DEFECT
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today that it had reached a preliminary finding that could lead to a recall of more than five million General Motors vehicles.

title: FED WAS SPLIT BY 8 TO 4 ON ANNUAL POLICY GOALS
description: The Federal Reserve Board, in an unusually sharp split, voted, 8 to 4, in setting its annual monetary policy targets for this year, according to the minutes of the annual policy meeting released this afternoon.

title: PITTSBURGH & WEST VA RR reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
TEAM INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net income
