title: OF FREE SPEECH AND FREE RESPONSE
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THORN BIRDS' RATING SECOND ONLY TO 'ROOTS'
description: ''The Thorn Birds,'' the four-part, 10-hour television series aired earlier this week by ABC-TV was the second-highest-rated brief series in television history, according to the A.C. Nielsen Company. ''Roots,'' broadcast by ABC in 1977, remains first.

title: Ohio Court Clears Pryor-Kim Fight
description: Aaron Pryor found out yesterday afternoon that this afternoon he would be able to defend the World Boxing Association's juniorwelterweight title against Sang Hyun Kim of South Korea.

title: BACK, BOY, BACK!
description: Though not eager to reach my dotage, I was not melancholy about the prospect until I heard of the latest Reagan plan for getting the Government off the people's back. One of my children phoned me about it.

title: Comings and Goings
description: For the third straight year, Ralph Sampson, the 7-foot-4-inch Virginia center, was named The Associated Press's college basketball player of the year. Sampson, who got 49 of the 80 votes in a poll of sportswriters and broadcasters, is the first three-time winner since the poll was started in 1961. ... Guy Lewis of the Houston Cougars was named coach of the year in The A.P.'s poll. ... The Pittsburgh Pirates placed Don Robinson, a 25-year-old right-hander, on the 21-day disabled list because of an inflamed right shoulder.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title:
PATENTS;
Apparatus Devised For Analyzing Voice
description: A human voice analyzing apparatus useful in communications and in recording voices for later recognition has been invented for Motorola Inc. Bruce Fette, a staff member at the plant in Phoenix, obtained patent 4,378,469 this week.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 25.
description: b-Net loss

title: NICARAGUANS FINDING HAVEN IN COSTA RICA IN GROWING NUMBERS
description: In the midst of the jungle six miles from here, a barbed-wire barrier marks the frontier between Costa Rica and Nicaragua. A concrete marker, knee-high and nearly covered by grass, notifies the visitor that this is the border. Otherwise, the barrier looks more like the work of a farmer trying to keep his cattle from wandering too far.

title: HOME SITES THAT BELONG TO THE SEA
description: To the Editor:

title: Farewell to the Ink Tax
description: There is ''substantial evidence,'' the Supreme Court noted the other day, that special taxes on the press ''would have troubled the Framers of the First Amendment.'' Colonial America resisted British duties on newspapers as ''taxes on knowledge,'' part of a licensing system for controlling criticism of the Government. In that tradition, the Court struck down Minnesota's selective taxation of those publishing necessities, ink and paper.

title: Poland Allows U.P.I.  To Resume Operation
description: United Press International resumed newsgathering activities in Poland today, nearly two months after its operations were suspended by the Warsaw authorities, the Foreign Ministry said.

title: OBJECT RECOGNITION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Letter: On the Chemical Industry; An Oil Tax Rise Would Raise Havoc
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL CONTRACTORS: WHEN SPEND THEY MUST
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERSUPPLY IN PETROCHEMICALS
description: The international petrochemical industry, despite the recent decline in crude oil costs, continues to be hurt by huge overcapacity and a decline in demand that has hit prices hard.

title: JMB REALTY TRUST reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including a gain of $573,109, or 81 cents a share, from two land investment sales.

title: AMQUEST CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: G.O.P. Candidate in Chicago Hasn't Sought Reagan's Help
description: The White House said today that President Reagan had not endorsed Bernard E. Epton, the Republican mayoral candidate in Chicago, because Mr. Epton had not ''requested'' his endorsement.

title:
PATENTS;
Mobile Air Sampler To Check for Pollutants
description: A mobile air sampler that can be operated anywhere on a highway or in a tunnel, instead of at a fixed point, for analysis of the concentration of pollutants was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Reita and Beal End Merger Talks
description: The Real Estate Investment Trust of America announced that it and Beal & Company had terminated discussions regarding a possible acquisition of the trust by Beal. The trust, also known as Reita, had said Thursday that Beal, also a real estate investment concern, was considering an acquisition for $45 a share.

title: AS MUBARAK CRACKS DOWN ON GRAFT, BAKSHEESH LOSES A LITTLE OF ITS LUSTER
description: A driver protested furiously on a chaotic main street this week as a Cairo traffic policeman scribbled a parking violation ticket. The driver's angry cries drew a crowd, most of whom sympathized with him. But the policeman was unmoved.

title: Ex-Agent Sentenced In Plot to Aid Soviet
description: A former Central Intelligence Agency operative was sentenced today to a year's probation for plotting to ship a diesel truck assembly line to the Soviet Union, a violation of export laws to protect national security.

title: BUTTES GAS & OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Coach Hired
description: Athletic officials at Brigham Young in Provo, Utah, looked far and wide for a new basketball coach, but in the end they settled on one who was close and convenient - Ladell Andersen, the athletic director at Utah State, just up the road in Logan. The 53-year-old Andersen, State's basketball coach from 1961 to 1971, replaces Frank Arnold, who resigned under pressure last month. Andersen, who compiled a 176-95 record as coach at Utah State.

title: INTERCONTINENTAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable April 1, 1983.

title: MATCHUP IS PERFECT BUT EARLY
description: The argument has been presented that the true matchup for the national college basketball championship, the game everyone has been waiting to see, will take place late Saturday afternoon. But when Houston (30-2), the top-ranked team in the nation, and Louisville (32-3), the second-ranked team, meet at the University Arena, all that will be at stake will be a spot in the national championship game.

title: KNICKS ARE DEFEATED BY LAKERS, 102-88
description: If the past week is an indication, the Knicks' season might be over a bit earlier than expected. For the second time on a rare late-season West Coast swing, they were defeated, losing to the Los Angeles Lakers, 102-88, tonight before a sellout crowd of 17,505 fans at the Forum.

title: RCM TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
BARRINGER RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
King Games in Need
description: The Martin Luther King International Freedom Games, established in 1969 as a memorial to the civil rights leader, may be headed for oblivion. That's the word from Brooks Johnson, the track coach at Stanford University in California, where this year's two-day meet ends today.

title: SRC LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
UNEMPLOYMENT RATE RISES TO 11% IN NEW YORK CITY, A 6-YEAR HIGH
description: New York City's unemployment rate rose sharply in March to 11 percent, up from 9.2 percent in February, and the highest rate since January 1977. But at the same time, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the number of city residents with jobs also increased.

title: 5TH AVE. SNAG: AWAITING THE VANDALS
description: The driver was turning left onto East 92d Street, but the car died before he could complete the turn. The driver then got out and walked away, leaving the car in the middle of Fifth Avenue, where it has remained since 1 A.M. Thursday.

title: OIL CUTS AFFECT JORDAN, TOO
description: The Arab oil boom of the last decade not only fueled the unbridled growth of the Arab oil exporting countries but also the economies of their oil-poor neighbors. Lebanon, the Yemens and Jordan all rode the crest of the Middle East oil rush.

title: MX PANEL SUGGESTS BASING 100 MISSILES IN STURDIER SILOS
description: President Reagan's special commission studying ways to deploy the proposed MX missile has decided to recommend basing 100 missiles in existing but newly strengthened silos, Administration officials said tonight.

title: WIRETAPPING COST A RECORD IN TRIAL
description: The 12 months of wiretapping that led to the bribery conspiracy conviction of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, cost the Justice Department at least $1,004,110, according to a belated accounting required by law. The effort was described in court as the most extensive telephone surveillance in the history of electronic interception.

title: PREVIEW OF '85
description: It's not often one gets a glimpse of the future, but such a moment occurred on Thursday at the headquarters of District Council 37, the city's biggest public-employee union. A fund-raising luncheon for Representative Harold Washington, the Democratic candidate for Mayor of Chicago, turned into a potential preview of our own next mayoral election in 1985.

title: 2 Receive Long Terms For Dealing in Heroin
description: Two heroin dealers were sentenced to long terms in prison yesterday after pleading guilty in a case involving extensive narcotics trafficking by organized crime.

title: AT SHABBY JAIL, CONTROVERSY ON CROWDING
description: In the House of Detention for Men, the oldest jail on Rikers Island, each inmate's cell is 6 feet by 8 feet. In the back is a lightbulb, and in many cells the socket is torn from the ceiling. Inmates turn on the lights by hooking two bare wires together.

title: COOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $339,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $1,571,000 for the quarter and year and extraordinary tax credits of $1,824,000 for the quarter and $2,129,000 for the year.

title: Your Money; Withdrawals From an I.R.A.
description: AS the April 15 deadline nears for opening an individual retirement account for 1982, advertisements from banks, brokerage firms, insurance companies and others are trumpeting the advantages of these tax-deferred plans. But the equally important information about the choices that can be made concerning withdrawals from an I.R.A. are not as easily available.

title: U.S. AIDES SAY THE SALE OF F-16'S WOULD VIOLATE 'SPIRIT OF THE LAW';
description: The Reagan Administration has held up final approval of the sale of 75 F-16 fighter-bombers to Israel not because of any specific Israeli violation of arms agreements with the United States, but because providing the planes now would violate ''the spirit of the law,'' Administration officials said today.

title: TEXAS AMERICAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income

title: THE M.T.A. BURDEN IN A PENSION RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: DESPAIR AMONG JOBLESS IS ON RISE, STUDIES FIND
description: As the economy struggles toward recovery, thousands of unemployed workers have sunk into a psychological depression that is often worse than that suffered by jobless Americans in the 1930's, behavioral scientists say.

title: Bridge: Big Planners May Forget Some Needs at the Table
description: It is perhaps odd that intelligent people who have no difficulty planning activities several months, or even years, ahead in social or business matters have trouble planning a few tricks ahead at the bridge table.

title: Miss Daniel Leads by 2
description: Beth Daniel shot a second straight three-under-par 69 today to take the lead after two rounds of the $400,000 Dinah Shore Invitational.

title: Happy Easter for Kotar
description: Doug Kotar, the former Giant running back who has an inoperable brain tumor, is taking a leave from a Pittsburgh hospital to spend Easter with his family in nearby Canonsburg. Kotar has been at the hospital since last October, when he was transferred there from a Newark hospital to be close to his wife, Donna, and their children, 9-year-old Doug Jr. and Christie, 6. In an exploratory operation last August, doctors concluded that the tumor, which was discovered just a short time before, was malignant and could not be removed by surgery.

title: Utah Governor Vetoes Bills To Regulate Sex on Cable TV
description: Gov. Scott M. Matheson Wednesday vetoed two bills aimed at banning sexually explicit programs from cable television. He said the bills would have a ''chilling effect'' on freedom of choice.

title: Agnes de Mille Tribute Is Planned for May 16
description: Agnes de Mille will be honored on May 16 at a benefit in the Shubert Theater sponsored by the Friends of the Theater Collection of the Museum of the City of New York.

title: STANDARD METALS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
NBC SEEKS SHARE OF PLAYOFF RIGHTS
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball tournament would be televised by two networks and could be worth almost twice as much in TV revenue as at present under a proposal by NBC Sports.

title: Motorcyclists Convicted As a Drug and Vice Ring
description: Thirteen members of a motorcycle gang, the Outlaws, were found guilty today of racketeering charges in Federal District Court.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 37.

title: City Again Denies Tax Aid to Trump
description: New York City has again denied Trump Tower, the 59-story skyscraper at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, a tax abatement the city has said would be worth $20 million, officials said yesterday.

title: Forging a Family Life for Unwanted Children
description: The magnolia tree is just about ready to bloom in Katie King's front yard, the pink-and-white torpedo buds on the verge of busting loose from their pale green coverings. Inside the house in South Ozone Park, Queens, the dress shirts are still in their plastic bags, the new shoes in their boxes, the soles pristine. Samantha's blue and white suit hangs in her closet like a promise.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS DOWN 2%
description: Spending on new construction dipped 2 percent in February after showing a robust 7.2 percent increase in January, the Commerce Department reported today. The decline had been expected because February's weather conditions were markedly worse than in January.

title: Purcell Reaches Monaco Semifinal
description: Mel Purcell beat Shlomo Glickstein today, 6-0, 7-6, and advanced to the semifinals of the $300,000 Monte Carlo Open tennis tournament.

title: DEVILS TIE RANGERS ON VERBEEK'S 2D GOAL
description: Pat Verbeek, the 18-year-old rookie of the Devils, scored his second goal of the game with 64 seconds left at Madison Square Garden last night and lifted New Jersey to a 3-3 tie with the Rangers.

title: Red Cap Service
description: The area that includes the central and South Bronx suffers from the highest arson rate in New York City. But perhaps not for long. Yesterday, the Fire Department's Red Cap antiarson squad moved into the area.

title: ALASKA GOLD INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After nonoperating losses of $4,766,000 for the latest year and $5,127,000 for the previous year.

title: AMERICAN GUARANTY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After realized investment losses of $594,000 for the quarter and $642,000 for the year. c-Net income including a realized investment gain of $6,000. d-Including a realized investment gain of $209,000. Year-ago results have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in May 1982.

title: BIOSTIM INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $12,000 for the quarter and $22,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
HENDERSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $35,000 and a credit of $118,000 representing the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting. c-Net loss. Revenue figures include income of $537,400 for the latest year and $103,500 for the previous year from the sale of assets.

title: MILITARY AGENCY IS SEEKING FUNDS FOR DEVELOPING 'SUPERCOMPUTERS'
description: The Defense Department's top research agency is asking Congress for new funds to support research to develop computers that are 1,000 times as fast as the speediest ones that exist today, an agency official said Thursday night.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: Michigan Dioxin Taint Is Called Exaggerated
description: The head of a Michigan environmental agency said today that the state's dioxin contamination problem ''has been blown out of proportion.''

title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,325,000 for the quarter and $6,880,000 for the year, a provision of $1,108,000 for the quarter and year for estimated loss on disposition of scontinued operations and a gain of $3,963,000 for the quarter and year from the sale of tax credits. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,418,000 for the quarter and $6,110,000 for the year.

title: AMERICAN MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: BANKS MAKES GOOD ON A VOW
description: The television set was turned on in McWhorter Hall, the athletic dormitory at the University of Georgia, and James Banks watched a basketball game with more than a casual interest. A little more than a year ago, after Georgia had been eliminated in the first round of the Southeastern Conference tournament and before it received a bid to the National Invitation Tournament, there was not much else for Banks to do.

title: COMARCO INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including net income from discontinued operations of $159,000. Shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared in November 1982.

title: Quote of Week
description: From Larry Holmes, World Boxing Council heavyweight boxing champion: ''I'm a seventh-grade dropout, but I'm a Ph.D. when it comes to common sense.''

title: Apartheid Will 'Explode,' Zambian Warns U.S.
description: President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia warned the United States today that failure to act more forcefully against South Africa's apartheid system of strict racial segregation will lead to a major catastrophe in the region.

title: Computer Unit In Chapter 11
description: Computer Input Services Inc., a concern whose financial records have been under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, has filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Japan Cartel Extension
description: The Japanese Government's Fair Trade Commission said today that it had approved a three-month extension of the antirecession cartel of 12 Japanese petrochemical companies to regulate ethylene production because of low domestic demand. The producers in the cartel may run their operations at 55.9 percent of capacity and produce 845,000 tons in the three months ending in June, down 9.2 percent from the same 1982 period, it said. Under the previous cartel agreement the companies cut ethylene production to 1.56 million tons in the five and a half months ended Thursday.

title: PACIFIC EXPRESS HOLDING reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-There were no revenue figures because the company began operations the following year. c-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $112,000 for the quarter and $124,000 for year. d-Includes losses from discontinued operations of $94,000 for quarter and $719,000 for the year.

title: Child Is Killed In Brooklyn Fire
description: A child was killed and six other people, including three children and a firefighter, were injured yesterday in an apartment fire in Brooklyn, authorities said. The firefighter fell from a ladder while battling the blaze.

title: Arts and Letters Group Chooses 15 for Awards
description: Fifteen authors have been chosen by the literary-awards committee of the American Academy-Institute of Arts and Letters to receive the 1983 prizes for artistic merit, John Hollander, chairman of the organization's literary committee, has announced. The awards will be presented at the Academy-Institute's annual ceremony on May 18.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 2, 1983
description: International

title: GEOCRUDE ENERGY INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
CORRECTION
description: An article March 26 incorrectly described the mandatory loan that French taxpayers must make to their Government. The loan is 10 percent of taxes otherwise due.

title: BIRDSBORO CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including equity in net income of affiliates of $67,000 for the quarter and $641,000 for the year. c-Net income including equity in net income of affiliates of $146,000. d-Including equity in net income of affiliates of $377,000.

title: OPERA: AMERICAN PAIR AT THE NEW YORK LYRIC
description: Dominick Argento's ''Miss Havisham's Wedding Night'' and ''The Death of the Virgin'' by Richard Owen appeared side by side at the New York Lyric Opera Thursday night. They had a number of things in common. Both are by American composers, both are new and - curiously enough - both are set in foreign countries.

title: COVERING NICARAGUA FIGHTING: BIG PROBLEM IS GETTING THERE
description: For dozens of reporters in Nicaragua trying to gather evidence of what is happening between Government troops and rebel forces along the Honduran border, the last week has been a series of frustrated attempts to reach the fighting.

title: BETWEEN CONSTITUENCIES AT CAPITOL AND AT HOME
description: Last fall, when he campaigned for a first term in Congress, Buddy MacKay preached the doctrine of fiscal conservatism, opposing deficit financing and urging tax reductions and a lid on social spending.

title: LA. TECH WILL PLAY U.S.C. FOR THE TITLE
description: Top-seeded Louisiana Tech and secondseeded Southern California scored impressive victories tonight in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball championship. They will meet for the title Sunday afternoon.

title: Zoot Sims and Joe Cohn In Sax-Guitar Duo
description: The combination of a saxophone and a guitar in a jazz duo is an unusually demanding situation for both instrumentalists because they have to fill in a background that might normally be provided by piano, bass or drums. It is a challenge that Zoot Sims and Joe Cohn are meeting in provocative fashion at Village West, Hudson at Bank Streets, where they will be playing through tomorrow.

title: VENEZUELA DRAFTS AUSTERITY PROGRAM
description: The Venezuelan Government, facing serious financial problems caused by a decline in oil revenues, has drafted an ''economic adjustment program'' aimed at stabilizing the country's international currency reserves, controlling inflation and reducing imports and public sector spending.

title: PENINSULA RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: LOCAL THREATENS NEW RAIL STRIKE ON JERSEY LINES
description: The union leaders and transit officials involved in the negotiations to end a monthlong rail strike in New Jersey said yesterday that despite a tentative agreement, there was still uncertainty whether the trains would run Monday.

title: WILSON BROTHERS Qtr to Dec 31 1982 1981 reports earnings for Sales.
Who Gets the Drug War Profits
description: Big-time drug dealers are often too arrogant and affluent to be much fazed by the mere threat of imprisonment. A more effective way to cut them down to size, some law-enforcement experts suggest, is to seize their assets: bank accounts, cars, boats, airplanes, houses, jewelry, furs.

title: ASTROCOM CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
COORS TRIES TO CONQUER SOUTHEAST BEER MARKET
description: A favorite souvenir of many travelers in the West used to be a case of Coors beer, which was not for sale east of the Mississippi River. Now, however, Coors fanciers in the Southeast can probably buy the product at their corner tavern.

title: HI-SHEAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Reflecting equity in net loss of affiliate of $8,423,000 for the quarter and $10,755,000 for the 9 months and a tax credit of $549,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income including equity in net income of affiliate of $204,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,099,000, or 23 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Irish Chamber Group Led by James Galway
description: The New Irish Chamber Orchestra is an engaging and disciplined ensemble. Under the direction of James Galway, who also served as flute soloist, it presented an enjoyable array of musical desserts in Avery Fisher Hall Sunday night.

title: A Friendly Deed And a White Lie
description: A woman visited the New York Road Runners Club headquarters on Thursday to pick up a friend's number for the Perrier 10-kilometer road race today in Central Park.

title: BRIEFING
description: Tower-Califano Tie?

title: Guatemala Dismisses Its Envoy to Vatican
description: Guatemala dismissed its Ambassador to the Vatican today for reportedly failing to deliver a note from Pope John Paul II calling for clemency for six men condemned to death.

title: MY SON, THE MARINE
description: My son, a marine in Lebanon, has written home frequently since his departure on the U.S.S. Guadalcanal from Morehead City, N. C., in late January. The Atlantic crossing on the Guadalcanal, a modest version of an aircraft carrier, was without incident in spite of several severe storms, which the massive, lumbering ship took in stride. He pays tribute to the skill and dedication of the men who man the ship and contrasts the ability of the Guadalcanal to weather high seas to that of the troop ships I was aboard during World War II in the Pacific.

title: Wrestlers Galore
description: The New York Athletic Club has one of the stronger amateur wrestling teams in the country. How strong will be demonstrated today and tonight when the club will be the host for an all-day competition involving teams from California (the Sunkist Kids), Iowa (the Hawkeyes), the United States Marines and Japan.

title: MIDLAND RESOURCES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income includes a tax credit of $1,835,000, or 12 cents a share, and after a loss from discontinued operations of $202,000.

title: 3 Are Charged In Silver Fraud
description: Three former brokerage firm members have been indicted by a Federal grand jury for their involvement in a scheme to defraud silver futures traders by dealing in a $25 million account without adequate margins, an Assistnat United States Attorney, Luke Kolman, said.

title: U.S. Denies Oil Investigation
description: The Justice Department said today that it monitored international oil markets for possible antitrust violations but was not specifically investigating a meeting between the Saudi Arabian oil minister and the heads of four major United States companies.

title: AMENDED VOTING LAW AIDS BLACKS' RIGHTS ACTIONS
description: Changes in the voting rights law enacted nine months ago have given blacks a powerful tool they are using to challenge and change election practices in cities and counties through the South, according to civil rights leaders, legal experts and government officials.

title: U.S. RAISES TARIFF FOR MOTORCYCLES
description: In an unusually strong protectionist action, President Reagan today ordered a tenfold increase in tariffs for imported heavyweight motorycles.

title: TAXING MUSEUMS?
description: New York City rightly prides itself on being America's cultural capital. One reason the city remains a major financial, legal and corporate service center is that people working in those fields are attracted by the richness of its cultural offerings. A recent tax ruling, however, may undermine some of the city's cultural institutions.

title: UNITED STATES MUTUAL REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
Drug Put in Vitamin Bottle
description: A pregnant woman suffered an allergic reaction after taking what appeared to be an over-thecounter muscle relaxant placed in a bottle of vitamins, officials said today. They characterized it as an ''isolated incident,'' because a random sampling of the brand of vitamins failed to turn up any more bottles containing the drug and the bottle appeared to have been tampered with after it left the manufacturer. The woman's doctor said he did not expect any damage to the fetus.

title: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Doctors Say Wallace May Soon Quit Hospital
description: Dr. Thomas James, who is coordinating treatment for Gov. George C. Wallace at University Hospital, said today he was encouraged by Mr. Wallace's response to exercise and that the Governor might be back at work early next week.

title: JOHNSTOWN AMERICAN COS reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $9,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $188,000 for the year.

title: Chrysler, A.M.C.  To Lift Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced increases ranging from 1.1 percent to 3.1 percent in the base prices for its more expensive four-door models, effective Monday.

title: FISHERMAN OUTNUMBER THE TROUT ON SEASON'S OPENING DAY
description: A bumper sticker on Harold Williamson's car reads ''Think Trout,'' and that he does. His friend, Cecil Barnett, suggests it goes further than this, that Mr. Williamson is unable to live a normal life and needs to be deprogrammed.

title: RSR CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
PACESETTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for year to Jan 1.
description: b-Net income

title: METS WILL RETURN STRAWBERRY TO MINORS
description: Frank Cashen, the Mets' general manager, said today that the Mets had abandoned efforts to trade for a catcher and confirmed that the rookie star Darryl Strawberry would be returned to the minor leagues in the final team cutdown this weekend.

title: EQUAL-TIME PROVISIONS WITH A VITAL PURPOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
AMERICAN PACESETTER reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods include operations acquired Jan. 1, 1982. American Pacesetter is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: BAVARIAN WARES COME TO 5TH AVE. IN A NEW STORE
description: In Munich, Ludwig Beck is an imposing 110,000-square-foot department store known for its textiles, men's and women's clothing and buttons and ribbons. But the recently opened New York branch has little in common with its European parent.

title: TEXAS GENERAL INC. FILES FOR PROTECTION
description: Texas General Resources Inc., a holding company for a group of small energy companies based here, and two of its subsidiaries - International Drilling Services Inc. and Texas General Resources International N.V. - have filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: EASTER SIGNIFIES A REBIRTH FOR WRITER
description: It will be dark outside Grace Episcopal Church tonight when David Michaelis is baptized. But inside the church at Broadway and 10th Street, the Easter candle will be lighted as a symbol of the birth of faith.

title: CLEARING CHECKS: WAITING TIME VARIES
description: In New York City, where banks are coming under increased pressure to take action on the way they clear consumers' checks, a survey of the practices of 11 banks shows that they vary greatly in how quickly they make available funds from out-of-town checking accounts.

title: Yefim Bronfman Plays Piano at Met Museum
description: Though at an early stage in his career, the pianist Yefim Bronfman has a strong expressive profile. He plays with virile determination, forthright intelligence and a bit of fury; that temperament provides the frame of reference for even his most introspective gestures.

title: SYSTEMHOUSE LTD reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: The year-ago figures were restated.

title: UNION REACHES ACCORD WITH STEEL COMPANY ON TEMPORARY PAY CUT
description: The United Steelworkers of America and one of the nation's largest specialty steel companies reached a new contract today that temporarily cuts wages 50 cents an hour.

title: The Wounds of Vietnam
description: Charlie Company: What Vietnam Did to Us. By Peter Goldman and Tony Fuller, with Richard Manning, Stryker McGuire, Wally McNamee and Vern E. Smith. Illustrated. 358 pages. Morrow. $15.95.

title: Psychological effects of joblessness may be more severe today than in 1930's, researchers say. Page A24.
description: Unemployment in March was virtually unchanged from the two months before, at 10.1 percent of the labor force, the Labor Department said today. But there were signs of moderate improvement in the number of people employed in manufacturing,

title: Vial of Deadly Nerve Gas Shatters in Army Lab
description: A small vial of deadly nerve gas shattered in a laboratory at the Umatilla Army Depot Thursday, but no one was injured, the Army disclosed today.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 10.

title: Coming of Age
description: Although his teammate, Dereck Whittenburg, was named the most valuable basketball player in the West Regionals, the bold inside play of Lorenzo Charles helped to send North Carolina State to the Final Four semifinals today against Georgia. In the four National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament games, Charles averaged 14.5 points and a team-high 9.5 rebounds.

title: RICHARDSON SUPPORTED BY NETS
description: Joe Taub, the Nets' president and principal owner, said yesterday that Michael Ray Richardson would continue to play for the team despite a published report that he has a problem with cocaine.

title: COURT UPHOLDS WHITE FEDERAL WORKER'S BIAS SUIT
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld a discrimination lawsuit by a white male Federal employee who complained he had been effectively demoted to make room for a black man in the Carter Administration.

title: CHICAGOANS TRIED TO AVOID KOCH
description: Campaign aides of Representative Harold Washington, a black who is the Democratic candidate for Mayor of Chicago, tried to prevent his joint appearance with Mayor Koch, the campaign press secretary said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was a regrettable pronouncement.'' - Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel. (1:6.)

title: BSD MEDICAL (CO) reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
ELECTROSOUND GROUP LTD reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $129,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $137,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary charge of $220,000. d-Net loss after a pretax loss of $735,000 from discontinued operations.

title: LONG SHOTS BASE HOPE ON '66 FINAL
description: North Carolina State and Georgia point to history to justify a conviction that either has as good a chance to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association title this year as those two recognized powers in this Final Four - Houston and Louisville.

title:
Patents;
Two New Rubik Puzzles
description: ERNO RUBIK, the Hungarian professor who invented the famous Rubik's Cube but never patented it in the United States, was awarded two patents here this week for other puzzles called spatial logical toys.

title: Dance Program Changed
description: The Paul Taylor Dance Company, which begins a monthlong run in the City Center next Tuesday, has announced a change in its opening night gala program.

title: Soviet Official Rejects Putting Missiles in Cuba
description: The Soviet Union, which has said it might place new missiles close to the United States if America deploys new medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe, will not install such missiles in Cuba, a Soviet official has told the French newspaper Le Monde.

title: JUDGE UPHOLDS EXTRADITION OF COAST NOW LEADER
description: A Superior Court judge today upheld an order to extradite the president of the California chapter of the National Organization for Women to Louisiana to face charges stemming from a 1965 slaying.

title: THE TALLEST SPECTATOR
description: One way or another, Ralph Sampson has now been to the Final Four in each of his four seasons at Virginia, but he brought along his sneakers and his teammates only once.

title: NEVADA RESOURCES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Historical Exchange
description: Lord Gibson, head of Britain's National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty, arrived from London last week to pass the hat. The trust administers a half million acres of park lands and 286 castles, mansions and gardens.

title: Spooning It Out
description: Yesterday being April Fool's Day, James Randi, the magician and self-appointed debunker, chose it to announce his fifth annual Uri Awards for Parapsychology at the Time-Life Building.

title: FOR SPRING, DANDELION GREENS
description: If there is one symbolic springtime food that belongs on tomorrow's Easter menu, it is a salad of dandelion greens, dressed with olive or walnut oil, wine vinegar, garlic and, as prized by both the French and Germans, with matchstick strips of hot, half-crisp bacon.

title: MARX'S EARLY BREAK WITH HUMANISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Lunsford Joins Generals
description: Mel Lunsford, a 32-year-old defensive back who played under Coach Chuck Fairbanks on the New England Patriots of the National Football League, has rejoined Fairbanks on the New Jersey Generals in the United States Football League. The Generals also deactivated Shafer Suggs, the safety who formerly played for the New York Jets, because he missed three practices for personal reasons. Suggs, signed late last week, was placed on the developmental squad, making him ineligible for Sunday's game against Arizona.

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock and commodity exchanges in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Good Friday, as were most foreign stock exchanges.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 2, 1983
description: The Economy

title: DIXICO INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 27.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $51,000. c-Net loss including income of $84,000 from discontinued operations.

title: CONESCO INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: ACKERLY INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income

title: XRG INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: 8 L.I. HOMES CONTAMINATED BY PESTICIDES, THE STATE SAYS
description: At least eight homes on Long Island have been contaminated over the last 16 months by exterminators' chemicals that state environmental officials say were misapplied in unrelated incidents.

title: PIZZA VENTURES INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 2.
DANGERS OF LEAD IN CANNED FOOD
description: Lead, a toxic substance, occurs naturally in food, soil, water and air. But the Food and Drug Administration is concerned about the element's unnatural occurrence in some canned foods.

title: PAINE AIDE POSED AS LAWYER
description: Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. has been fined $1,000 and cited for contempt of court because the vice president in charge of the firm's litigation department - a law school graduate who failed the bar examination in 1969 and never took it again - falsely held himself out as a lawyer.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company changed its fiscal year-end.

title: PRIVATE CONCERN STARTS MANAGING 2 STATE AIRPORTS
description: Two state-owned airports troubled by mounting deficits and other problems have been turned over to a private company to manage for five years.

title: FRANCE BLOCKS JAPANESE BID FOR INFORMAL TIES TO NATO
description: Japan has tried to set up an informal consultation arrangement with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but the move has been blocked by France, Japanese officials and foreign diplomats here report.

title: NETS WIN A PLAYOFF BERTH AND 3D IN ROW FROM 76ERS
description: The New Jersey Nets, getting 20 points each from Buck Williams and Mike O'Koren, defeated the Philadelphia 111-104, tonight to end the 76ers' chances of breaking the league record for victories. The Nets also clinched a berth in the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Ear Magazine to Benefit From Concert on Friday
description: Laurie Anderson, Joan La Barbara, Robert Ashley, Derek Bailey and William Hellermann will be among the performing composers participating in a benefit for Ear, the experimental-music magazine.

title: COMPUTER ENTRY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. c-Including extraordinary income of $108,000, or 3 cents a share, for the latest year and $132,000, or 4 cents a share, for the previous year.

title: MCRAE CONSOLIDATED OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: Effective Dec. 31, 1981, the company changed its fiscal year to a calendar year and comparison figures for the year ended Dec. 31, 1981, are unaudited.

title: ISRAEL DESCRIBES DECISION ON F-16'S AS 'REGRETTABLE'
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that President Reagan had made ''a regrettable pronouncement'' in announcing that the United States would not give final approval for the sale of 75 F-16 fighter planes to Israel until it withdrew from Lebanon. He said the statement came just as Israel and Lebanon were ''close to agreement'' on an Israeli withdrawal.

title: BLACK HOLES 'N' YOU
description: The following questions and answers are excerpted from the latest issue of Science 'n' You magazine, the monthly devoted to how the century's advances in theoretical physics have affected all of us. The topic (fasten your space belts): Black Holes....Dear You: So-called ''black holes'' - what are they? If they're so great, why don't we spend billions to land a spaceship on them instead of on defense programs? N.B., Los Alamos, N.M. Dear N.B.: Black holes - so dubbed by Princeton physicist John A. Wheeler, who postulated that, theoretically (it is as yet unproved), they may or may not, but could, result when the nuclear fuel of enormous stars runs out, and collapse upon themselves with a force that no known resistance can halt, their matter racing inward at unimaginable speeds to a point of infinite density and beyond, a point which, though incomprehensible, and possibly impossible, but at present the only possible explanation for what seems to occur in these stars, scientists believe could exist, a point of infinite mass in zero volume or less, where the force of gravity is so strong that even light cannot escape, the very edge of space and time, a point at which an observer, if he could (he couldn't) could see that it (space and time) have come to a virtual standstill, where everything as we know it, including the concepts of ''space,'' ''time,'' and ''etc.'' would cease to exist as we know them because here would be a universe we do, and can, know nothing about - are now believed, with the highest degree of certainty that is possible in a realm where the only certainty is uncertainty, either to or to not exist.

title: LETTER FROM STOESSEL TO PERCY
description: Following is a letter sent by Walter J. Stoessel Jr. on July 15, 1982, when he was Acting Secretary of State, to Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The letter, classified when sent, was declassified on Sept. 10. Dear Mr. Chairman: I'm providing the following information pursuant to section 3 (c) (2) of the Arms Export Control Act. On June 6, Israeli forces entered Lebanon and began a series of military operations against Palestinian and Syrian forces. These operations have involved the use of a large quantity and variety of defense articles that had been furnished to Israel under the Foreign Military Sales program, including armored vehicles, aircraft and munitions of various types.

title: Court Delays Braniff Action
description: Braniff International has been granted two more weeks to submit its reorganization plan to United States Bankruptcy Judge John Flowers.

title: TEECO PROPERTIES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including gains on the disposition of real estate of $152,000 for the latest year and $6,943,000 for the previous year.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TIME SPAN

title: HELM RESOURCES (CO) reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss of $18,000 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations. c-Net income.

title: HOW TO DECONTROL HIGHER EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: OVERMYER CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
U.S. Congresswoman Raises Greek Ire
description: A Greek Government source criticized a visiting member of the United States House of Representatives today who reportedly described Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou as ''NATO's bad boy.''

title: DRIVERS IN CONNECTICUT AWAKEN TO 8 GAS RISE
description: What it took OPEC years to do, the tax men undid overnight. Recent squabbles in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries finally pushed the price of gasoline down. But as Connecticut motorists slept Thursday night, up it went again by 8 cents a gallon - 5 cents of that a new Federal tax and 3 cents a new state levy. With the 99-cent gallon suddenly a thing of the past again, motorists from Greenwich to Norwich could do little today but complain.

title: KIMBARK OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Maureen Grady Engaged To Barry Gillin, Engineer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Grady of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Frances Grady, to Barry J. Gillin, son of Mr. and Mrs. George F. Gillin of Commack, L.I.

title: AIRCRAFT USERS PRESS FOR NIGHT FLIGHTS AT WESTCHESTER AIRPORT
description: Accusing Westchester officials of ''bad faith'' in out-of-court negotiations, an organization of business aircraft users has announced that it will return to court to end the county's ban on night flights at Westchester County Airport.

title: High Technology Versus Humanities
description: Connecticut has entered a period of economic change with little grasp of the criteria by which it might assess and guide its own performance. This poverty of perspective is particularly unfortunate at a time when the cult of technological determinism has become increasingly fashionable among our state's leaders. It is now apparent that the technology lobby has succeeded in blurring the central issues about the future development of Connecticut.

title: Ohio Man Held in Deaths Of Relatives and Renters
description: A man who walked into Police Headquarters Friday and said he knew where four bodies could be found was charged with murdering his father, his grandmother and two other women, the police said.

title: Correction
description: A photograph of a troika sleigh ride in Moscow that appeared on page 1 of Travel on March 20 was incorrectly captioned. The picture was taken at the park of the Exhibition of National Economic Achievement.

title: DEALERS SEE MARKET PERKING UP
description: FOR THE first time in at least three years, antiques dealers are responding to spring with irrepressible good humor, thanks to the fact that their markets are picking up both in activity and values.

title: Bali
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE BUDGET DEBATE
description: It would seem that Washington's battle of the budget started the day Ronald Reagan took office and never paused. But now, with the beginning of the fiscal 1984 cycle, the budget debate is heating up once again. As the temperature rises, Congress, the White House and hordes of lobbyists are letting their proposals fly, each advocating their own rich mixture of budget cuts and new ''revenue enhancements,'' once known as taxes.

title:
GARDENING;
SELECTING PLANTS FOR THE GARDEN
description: WITH the spring planting season at hand, home gardeners will be flocking to the garden centers to take advantage of special plant sales. Certainly, there is nothing wrong with that. It is only natural to want to get the best price possible. A bargain is no bargain, however, if the plants purchased are not well-suited to the planting site and purpose for which they are intended. Plant characteristics and site requirements should be considered before a purchase.

title: Protesting the Military Look
description: Anne Hollander's article, ''The Appeal of Military Detailing'' (Fashions of The Times, Feb. 27), was upsetting to me, as it promoted military apparel as fashion. Are Miss Hollander and the designers mentioned in the article dressing the women of our nation in preparation for a nuclear holocaust? For, after all, she claims ''that there is a suggestion in a uniform, that the challenged party may lose not just a round of the game, but life or limb.''

title: BOSSES FACE LESS RISK THAN THE BOSSED
description: Executive stress has been a popular subject for years among industrial psychologists and mass market writers. But the greater cause for concern in occurrence of heart disease, as a group of American and Swedish researchers now sees it, might appropriately be called nonexecutive stress.

title: Whose Obligation Is Health Care?
description: A Presidential commission on medical ethics last week stopped short of declaring health care a citizen's constitutional right, but not by much. ''Equitable access,'' the panel said, is the ''ethical obligation'' and ''ultimate responsibility'' of the Federal Government, even in austere times. As for austerity, the commission - eight members of which were appointed by President Reagan and three, including the chairman, by President Carter - called health care cost control measures unacceptable if they widen the gap between those who get adequate care and those who don't, or get none at all.

title: Lubeck
description: To the Editor:

title: Kenyan Leads Rally
description: Vic Preston Jr. of Kenya, in an Audi Quattro, arrived into Nairobi today 32 minutes ahead of Timo Salonen of Finland in a Datsun Works 240-RS for the second-leg lead in the East Africa Safari rally. Preston had a time of one hour 55 minutes after covering 1,920.2 miles of the 3,146-mile event. Salonen posted 2 hours 27 minutes for the two legs of the three-legged race.

title: 36-1 SHOT CAPTURES FLAMINGO
description: On a stormy August evening in 1981, a gray colt was led into the yearling sales ring at Saratoga and Roger Laurin prepared to raise his hand and bid on the colt. Suddenly all the lights went out in the pavilion.

title: DANCE: NEWMAN GROUP PERFORMS '4: STORIES'
description: Rosalind Newman began Thursday night's performance at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, where she and her company will be through April 11, by talking. She spoke of the dances to come, how she'd made them and what she was trying to achieve. Seldom a good idea, the talk was particularly superfluous here. Miss Newman is a gifted choreographer. Bold, intelligent and full of imagination, her dances speak for themselves, particularly in this extraordinary program.

title: SEEING A COMIC MIND EMERGE
description: Whenever a writer gets around to presenting us with his own portrait of the artist as a young man, he invariably does two things. He makes his young man sensitive, very sensitive. A blossom on the vine that will wither and die unless it is promptly given succor. And he makes his young man a victim, a stranger in the household who is not going to be properly nurtured because he is so blatantly misunderstood; he must escape the obtuseness about him at all costs. You know how it goes.

title: CAMPUS FREEDOM LTD.
description: To the Editor:

title: RONDO REVIVING TWO HUMPHREY WORKS
description: THE Rondo Dance Theater will revive two major works by the choreographer Doris Humphrey during performances next Saturday and Sunday at the State University of New York at Purchase. The 10-member Westchester-based troupe, directed by Elizabeth Rockwell, will present Humphrey's ''Day on Earth'' (1947) and ''Ritmo Jondo'' (1953) on the program, along with ''Whirl'' by Addison Hoffman and ''Woody Says,'' choreographed by Sophie Maslow.

title: Miss Rushton to Wed M.S. Wein, Executive
description: Paula M. Rushton of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Margaret Raye Rushton, to Marc Steven Wein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Wein of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: YO-YO MA IN MONTCLAIR
description: Yo-Yo Ma is only 27 years old, but Isaac Stern, the violinist, has called the cellist ''one of the greatest instrumental talents alive.''

title: LEADERS OF BUSINESS SEEK SUMMER WORK FOR CITY'S YOUTH
description: Business leaders have begun their third annual campaign to find summer jobs for needy New York City youths, hoping to fill nearly 16,000 jobs in private industry by the end of August.

title: Russian Church Leader Assails Reagan Speech
description: In an open letter to President Reagan, published as an advertisement today in The New York Times, the head of the Russian Orthodox Church said he was ''deeply shocked and sincerely distressed'' by the President's criticism of the Soviet Union last month.

title: IS BURGLARY THE PRICE OF PRIVACY?
description: IN my suburban neighborhood there are lots of burglaries. One reason is that there are two major ''escape routes'' close by. Another is that the neighborhood is thought of as being affluent.

title: FOR ART VAGABONDS IN FRANCE
description: When the talk turns to reincarnation some people have big ideas. They see themselves as Alexander the Great, Plato, Michelangelo, Shakespeare, Mozart, Abraham Lincoln, Einstein - that sort of thing. Nothing less will do.

title: Nairobi
description: To the Editor:

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: SCHOOL administrators have until June 27 to comply with a Federal regulation requiring school buildings to be tested for asbestos fibers.

title: E.P.A. ISSUES PROPOSED STANDARDS FOR REDUCING RADIOACTIVITY
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has issued proposed standards aimed at reducing the level of radioactivity in the atomosphere from Government facilities and various industries.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
BIG STEEL TURNS INTO AN IMPORTER
description: U.S. Steel, after years of haranguing Congress about the need to keep cheap foreign steel out of this country, is trying to import some for itself. It hopes to buy steel slab - a product not covered by quotas - from the British Steel Corporation for less than it would cost to make at the company's big mill in Philadelphia. But the price to be paid could be much higher than the cost of some cold-rolled steel. The whole idea has infuriated the United Steelworkers union, which recently agreed to wage cuts that management said were necessary to save jobs -jobs that union officials feared they would lose to cheaper imports. Now the workers have lost both money and faith in management.

title: Betrothal Announced For Marcia Hutchens
description: Mr. and Mrs. Julius Koppelman of Princeton, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Marcia K. Hutchens, to Colin Moor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Moor of Falmouth, Mass.

title: CAMPAIGN COSTS SOAR AS MEDIAN SPENDING FOR SENATE SEAT HITS $1.7 MILLION
description: Political campaign spending soared across the nation in 1982 as candidates spent 69 percent more to win a seat in the Senate than in 1980 and 48 percent more to win a seat in the House. An analysis of campaign spending reports filed with the Federal Election Commission showed that the median expenditures by winning campaigns increased far faster than the 14.6 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index from November 1980 to November 1982.

title: THE ORIOLES AND ROYALS SHOULD WIN, BUT NOT EASILY
description: The following American League preview was written by Murray Chass. The teams are listed in predicted order of finish with the Yankees picked for second in the Eastern Division. EASTERN DIVISION BALTIMORE

title: Oxford Beats Cambridge
description: Oxford University's multinational oarsmen had no trouble recording an eighth straight victory over the Cambridge University eight today in England's 129th Boat Race. The Oxford eight won by four and a half lengths - 13 seconds - over the 4-mile-374-yard River Thames course.

title: Beer Prices And Franchises
description: The March 20 article entitled ''Beer Franchise Issue Confronts Albany'' has told but one side of a complicated and extremely important issue for all Long Islanders and all New Yorkers.

title: HELLO, YOU GUYS OUT THERE IN TV-LAND
description: ''THE MOVING TARGET,'' a new book by Rena Bartos, has caught the attention of the advertising community. In it, Mrs. Bartos, an executive with the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, examines the changing women's market and the way advertisers can reach it.

title: DECLINE OF DOGWOOD IN REGION PUZZLES EXPERTS
description: TALES told by longtime nurserymen such as Stanley Bulpitt of Darien include one about the early Americans who bathed their mangy dogs with a concoction boiled down from the wood of a certain tree.

title: BASEBALL: THE GAME IS ENTERING GOLDEN AGE
description: BY now the Phillies are old news, pardon the expression, but still i ntriguing: This season the Phillies will be fielding some of the o ldest players in baseball, and if they go on to win the World S eries, they would probably be the oldest team in history to do so. O n opening day, Tuesday against the Mets, each of the Phillies' s tarting players except one will be 30 years old or over. Two will be4 0 or over.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Celtics Beat Bullets in Overtime, 120-117
description: Larry Bird scored 8 of his 34 points in overtime, including two free throws with four seconds remaining, as the Boston Celtics defeated Washington, 120-117, ending the Bullets' eight-game winning streak.

title: Canadiens Edge Bruins by 2-1
description: Mark Napier scored his 40th goal of the season tonight and led the Montreal Canadiens to a 2-1 victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: ROAD TO EXTINCTION
description: I'd hate to be called an ''extreme environmentalist'' or an ''environmental extremist.'' These are nasty words nowadays. They suggest that you're the kind of subversive who would rather shrink industrial profits than drink industrial wastes, or, to use an antiquated term, ''un-American.''

title: REBUILDING THE METS
description: On the 43d floor of 245 Park Avenue in Manhattan, Nelson Doubleday sits at a huge desk and contemplates his two unlikely dominions: books and baseball. There are plenty of books on all sides, but no baseballs. Still, Nelson Doubleday needs no reminders of the $21.1 million gamble he took three years ago when his successful bookpublishing company bought the unsuccessful New York Mets and entered the high-risk business of reviving a professional sports franchise.

title: SEAVER PASSES TEST ON THIGH AND MAY START OPENER
description: On a windy and misty field 1,100 miles from New York, the Yankees and the Mets waited 40 minutes in the rain today before canceling their 69th meeting and disappointing a sellout crowd of 8,000.

title: WASHINGTON 8 TAKES CUP AFTER RE-ROW
description: A foul that caused a re-rowing of the Copley Cup, the final race for men's heavyweight crews, was the only blemish in what were otherwise ideal conditions for the 10th annual San Diego Crew Classic today.

title: WILANDER REACHES FINAL WITH PURCELL
description: Mats Wilander and Mel Purcell moved into the final of the $300,000 Monte Carlo Open tennis tournament today.

title: EXPLORING BOLIVIA'S CITY IN THE CLOUDS
description: Sixteen life-size statues stand watch over Sucre from the cathedral towers of this Bolivian city 420 miles from La Paz. According to local legend, 12 of the figures are Apostles but the four closest to heaven are the Saints of Sucre, a legend that provides an indication of the lofty esteem in which the inhabitants hold their city.

title: John F. Stafford, Amy C. Negreann Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Saul S. Negreann of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Carson Negreann, to John Frederick Stafford, son of Mrs. Frederick M. Stafford of New York and New Orleans and the late Mr. Stafford.

title: Nordiques 5, Whalers 4
description: Blake Wesley scored a power-play goal at 17:32 of the third period to break a 4-4 tie.

title: CONTEMPORARY MUSIC
description: As its name quite straightforwardly suggests, the Dance Theater Workshop is devoted primarily to dance. But David White's lively West 19th Street performance space has also taken in recent years to sponsoring contemporary music series, as well.

title: 'MERE MAN' FULLY EQUIPPED TO RAISE HIS CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: ALL-DIGITAL SOUND IS HERE
description: Light the torches, ring the bells: The digital phonograph has arrived. Audio fans of the more hard-bitten sort have waited years for this. Now it is no longer just a promise dangling before them like the carrot before the donkey. They can go out and actually buy it.

title: 4,000 in Glasgow Take Part In 'Die-In' on Nuclear Arms
description: With tape-recorded sirens wailing in the background and with the backing of the city government, 4,000 people lay down in the city's main square today in a noontime ''die-in'' protesting the nuclear arms programs of Britain and its NATO allies.

title: Suit Against Globe Stands
description: Judge Irving Goldblatt of Superior Court has refused to dismiss a $1.8 million libel suit filed against The Boston Globe by former Gov. Edward J. King. The Globe had requested a summary judgment in the suit, which Mr. King filed in 1982 while he was still in office. He charged that a number of articles, editorials and political cartoons published by the newspaper libeled him.

title: Arms and the Man
description: Well, what's it to be, Mr. President - a holy war against Soviet evil or a sober struggle to find a way to share the planet with the devil?

title: ONE PROFESSOR'S LIMIT
description: To the Editor:

title: THE OTHER WOMAN WAS A CAR
description: CHRISTINE By Stephen King. 526 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $16.95.

title: WATERZOOI A LA GANTOISE
description: Belgians will argue about anything so long as it has to do with food. In a country that cares deeply about what it grows and raises, there seems to be an incessant debate over whether the eels of East Flanders are better than those of West Flanders, whose endives are the crisper, which leeks braise better, whether the in-season mussels of the Netherlands are truly more plump than those brought in from Spain to satisfy the year-round Belgian appetite.

title: A Pause That Doesn't Refresh
description: While the opposition gloated last week, France's ruling Socialists were apprehensive that history might be catching up with them. The austerity measures introduced by President Francois Mitterrand's Socialist-Communist coalition to beat inflation and restore the shaky franc were what a conservative government might have decreed.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: IT was not the final call for a Broadway blockbuster. No director hunched in his seat in a darkened theater, no luck would put one's name in lights on a golden marquee. No stars would be born with this audition.

title: HALF A POUND OF HOPE FOR CONDORS
description: A face that only a zookeeper could love pecked out of its shell and into history last week at the San Diego Zoo. It was the first California condor ever hatched in captivity, and could be the key to saving a species whose numbers have dwindled from 60 to 19 over the past two decades.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Detroit Tigers, at St. Petersburg, Fla., 12:30 P.M. The Mets' last spring game before they come to New York for a workout at Shea Stadium tomorrow in preparation for their Tuesday opener there against Philadelphia. It now looks as if Mike Torrez, instead of Tom Seaver, will start the opener against Steve Carlton. (Radio - WHN 1050, 12:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Kansas City Royals, at Fort Myers, Fla., 1:30 P.M. This is the final Yankee exhibition game before the season opener Tuesday at Seattle, in which Ron Guidry will probably face Gaylord Perry. (Radio -WABC 770, 1:15 P.M.) Basketball Seattle SuperSonics vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Inglewood, Calif. (Television - ESPN, 4:30 P.M.) Cleveland Cavaliers vs Philadelphia 76ers, at Richfield, Ohio (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.).

title: Johns Hopkins Wins
description: Del Dressel scored four goals and Bill Cantelli and Peter Scott made three each as top-ranked Johns Hopkins defeated Virginia, 12-6, in lacrosse today. Hopkins is now unbeaten in five games. Virginia is 4-1.

title: The Courtliest Tennis Game
description: Robert W. Stock's article on court or real (royal) tennis was surely entertaining, but one point deserves further mention (''The Courtliest Tennis Game of Them All,'' March 6).

title: WHY ARTISTS DESIGN FOR PAUL TAYLOR
description: Paul Taylor, who studied art in college before being won over to the dance, is highly regarded for his astute taste in stage designers. His keen visual instincts, and predisposition to artistic adventure, have led him over the years to engage young artists who later went on to become some of the greatest names in modern American painting.

title: THE RECOVERY: HOW FAR WILL IT FLY?
description: JUST about everybody - in Washington as much as on Wall Street - agrees that the economy is off the ground after a severe recession. The preliminary ''flash'' estimate by the Commerce Department indicates that the gross national product rose at an annual rate of about 4 percent in the first quarter - subpar by standards of past economic recoveries, but still the best performance in two years.

title: NEW QUESTIONS ARISE ON POLICING POLICE
description: A Federal jury in Dallas last week convicted three of seven New Orleans policemen charged with violating the civil rights of blacks who claimed they had been brutally interrogated during a hunt for a white officer's killer.

title: WHEN A DRAWER BEGINS TO STICK, FIX IT SOON---HERE'S HOW
description: WHEN drawers in a dresser or cabinet begin to stick or bind every time you try to open or close them, it is best to take corrective measures promptly. Otherwise the constant tugging and pulling may eventually loosen the joints of the drawer to such an extent that it actually starts to fall apart. Or, one day you may find that the drawer is completely stuck closed and you cannot open it at all.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A PLAN THAT WON'T ENDURE COMPETITION
description: AMERICAN AIRLINES'S proposal for a uniform mileage fare is a rare a nd remarkable act of business statesmanship. The few examples of s uch corporate daring mostly occurred before 1970 and were little m ore than thinly veiled attempts to reduce competition and overcharget he consumer. American's plan continues this fine tradition.

title: Briton Retains Title In Central Park Run
description: Geoff Smith of Liverpool, England, a student at Providence College, successfully defended his title in the Perrier 10-kilometer run yesterday at Central Park.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUE PAYS TRIBUTE TO FORMER YOUTH CORPS
description: The Civilian Conservation Corps, created in the Great Depression to revitalize two of the nation's most wasted resources - its young men and its land - was one of the most successful of the New Deal recovery programs launched by President Franklin D. Roosevelt in the historic first 100 days following his inauguration on March 4, 1933.

title: Vizi Lange to Wed Charles William Miles 3d in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Woldemar Lange of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie-Louise Virginia Anne Lange, to Charles William Miles 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miles 2d of Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Karen Anderson Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carl Anderson of Schenectady, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Rand Anderson, to Thomas Finletter Mitchell, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F.B. Mitchell of Stonington, Conn.

title: 6 PROTESTERS ARRESTED AT HOUSTON KLAN MARCH
description: About 50 Ku Klux Klansmen marched in downtown Houston today, and at least six people were arrested as hundreds of demonstrators lined the parade route chanting ''Death to the Klan.''

title: ISABELLA TYSON GILPIN
description: Isabella Tyson Gilpin, a philanthropist whose farm, Scaleby, in Virginia's Shenandoah Valley, was a thoroughbred horse breeding center between the World Wars, died of a stroke Friday in Berryville, Va. She was 88 years old.

title: U.S. PLANS TO EASE RULES FOR HIRING WOMEN AND BLACKS
description: The Labor Department intends to issue new rules that relax requirements for Federal contractors to recruit and promote blacks, women and Hispanic people.

title:
ART;
MUSEUM TRUSTEES HAVE THEIR DAY
description: A VITAL museum is fueled by an active and well-connected board of trustees, so it is understandable that the trustees sometimes yearn to do some of the actual driving. Through May 8, the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield has allowed six of its trustees to curate, and each has taken his own route. Though the work chosen hits about every point on that proverbial scale from 1 to 10, the relish with which the trustees apply themselves is pervasive and spirited.

title: Hypertrophic Captures Carolina Steeplechase
description: Charles C. Fenwick's Hypertrophic, with Richard McWade in the saddle, scored an upset today in the 51st running of the Carolina Cup steeplechase at Springdale.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Town Hall has instituted a new 6 P.M. debut-recital series, designed to attract the concertgoer who may wish to get home early or even to catch another concert later in the evening. The hall has a noble history, of course, and its acoustics still offer a welcome antidote to the brighter, closer sound of such spaces as Carnegie Recital Hall and the Abraham Goodman House.

title: PAY TV CHALLENGES NETWORKS
description: ''This is the first grown-up year for us,'' says Michael Fuchs, president of the entertainment division at Home Box Office, the nation's largest pay television service. Having built a highly profitable business over the past decade by offering uncut movies without commercial interruptions on cable television, HBO has committed more than $60 million during the next two years for new programming. The objective is to attract new viewers to its already existing audience of 12 million and thus increase its revenues.

title: Late Shot by Bucks Beats Nets, 105-103
description: Brian Winters took a pass from Sidney Moncrief and hit a 15-foot jumper from the side with 13 seconds remaining tonight to give the Milwaukee Bucks a 105-103 victory over the Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: METRO-NORTH STRIKERS SAY CUOMO'S THREAT DOES NOT HURT UNITY
description: Four weeks after taking to the picket lines, many Metro-North conductors and trainmen appeared determined to continue their strike despite Governor Cuomo's threat to intervene on Monday if a settlement is not reached.

title: ON THE EGG TRAIL
description: Tiny chocolate eggs will be hidden in the leaves and brush along the woodland trails of the Greenburgh Nature Center today, to be discovered by search parties of children led by center staff members.

title: Calvi Case Reopened
description: Maybe it was the rocks they found in Roberto Calvi's pockets as he hung by the neck from a London Bridge last year, an apparent suicide.

title: ARAFAT SAID TO BALK AT APPROVING JORDAN ROLE
description: Yasir Arafat met with King Hussein today amid indications that the Palestine Liberation Organization will not authorize the King to enter into negotiations on the basis of President Reagan's Middle East peace plan.

title: Withdrawal Negotiations Inch Forward
description: Israel and Lebanon last week seemed closer to agreement on a troopwithdrawal formula that could ''let Lebanon be Lebanon,'' in President Reagan's phrase. The two countries agreed on the principle, but not the particulars, of joint supervision of a zone 25 miles north of the Israel-Lebanon border.

title: IS IT FIRST COME, FIRST SERVED ON COAL AND URANIUM?
description: In 1921, Commissioner Henry Conroy steamed down the Mackenzie River to make the Indians of the Northwest Territories an offer they apparently could not refuse. In return for signing a treaty, each Indian was given $12 ($32 for chiefs), a silver medal, a flag and the promise of a new suit every three years.

title: ROBERT T. LAWRENCE
description: Robert T. Lawrence, senior vice president of William A. White & Sons, a real estate concern, died yesterday of cancer at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Islip, L.I. He was 69 years old and lived in West Islip.

title: Dickinson Beats Neff To Take Bowling Title
description: Gary Dickinson, a 14-year veteran from Burleson, Tex., won his first major title today by defeating Steve Neff in the $140,000 Bowling Proprietors Association of America's United States Open on the Pro Bowlers Tour.

title: U.S.C. IS SPARKED BY PLAYGROUND GUARD
description: When Louisiana Tech and Southern California meet Sunday afternoon at the Scope for the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's basketball championship, the key player may be an undersized 18-year-old freshman from the New York City playgrounds.

title: So It Goes In Chicago
description: ''Unless something changes soon,'' the Chicago Tribune lamented editorially early last week, ''Chicago's mayoral election will be one decided on the issue of race.'' Things changed a little, but there was still nothing at all high-minded about the contest between Representative Harold Washington, the black Democratic candidate, and Bernard E. Epton, the white Republican nominee.

title: REALIZING A HOUSING DREAM
description: CLUSTERED in only a few square blocks near the Roslyn Long Island Rail Road station there is an almost textbook-like display demonstrating the evolution of 20th-century housing policy in the United States. As 24 families look forward eagerly to home ownership - buying into the American dream they thought they could never achieve -they are characters in what may be the final pages of the story begun five decades ago when President Franklin D. Roosevelt directed the resources of the Federal Government to alleviate the plight of an ill-housed one-third of the nation.

title: INSTILLING DISCIPLINE IN THE BANKS
description: FOR most of the last half century, competition in financial servicesw as tightly controlled. Both price and product competition were c urtailed by law. Entry into the business was carefully regulated, asw as expansion. It was rare for a bank to fail.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: GOVERNOR KEAN will be the keynote speaker at a celebration marking the first anniversary of the New Jersey Republican Progressive Association. The event will take place Thursday through Saturday at the Parsippany-Hilton Hotel.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
LIFE SEEN AS EARTHLY HELL
description: Joel-Peter Witkin's photographs have an extraordinary originality and power that sets them apart from anything else in contemporary photography. And yet they do, up to a point, fit into accepted categories. In recent years Witkin has been shown in the company of photographers who paint or draw on their photographs in an attempt to go beyond or get around the naturalism of the unmanipulated photographic image - for instance, in ''Six Markers'' at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art in 1981. He has also exhibited with photographers in whose work special photographic printing processes play a conspicuous part - for instance, in ''The Photographer as Printmaker,'' sponsored by the Arts Council of Great Britain in 1982.

title: ALONE IN THE CROWD ON THE ROAD
description: I HAVE come to the conclusion that anyone who travels at the legal s peed limit is considered a hindrance if not a menace to society. We w ho observe the limit do not even belong in the far-right slot of thee xpressway. That is reserved for cars moving at least 63 miles an h our. However, clearly the most vexing situation in which to drive t he posted rate of speed is in a residential area.

title: Car Blocking 5th Ave. Towed After 2 1/2 Days
description: A car that impeded traffic on Fifth Avenue near 92d Street for two and a half days was towed away yesterday afternoon by the police.

title: PACT NEAR ON TEMIK FILTERS
description: SUFFOLK COUNTY and the Union Carbide Corporation are near settlement on an agreement that offers some relief to East End residents whose wells have been contaminated by the agricultural pesticide Temik, a Union Carbide product.

title: DOWN-HOME COOKING
description: There has been a good deal written recently about the ''revolution'' in cooking that is ''all-American.'' It involves the creation and putting to use of new and innovative foods that are basically native.

title: Willard Straight
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Concepts at a Convention

title: Morgan C. Dodd to Wed Jura Koncius
description: Mr. and Mrs. Liudas J. Koncius of Irving, Tex., and South Dennis, Mass., formerly of Mendham, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jurate Maria Grazina Koncius, to Morgan Cary Dodd, son of Jeanne Bowlan Dodd of Mountain View, Calif., and D. Cary Dodd of Fort Launderdale, Fla.

title: Miss Ulrich Plans Wedding for May
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Alden Ulrich of Orange, Conn., and Grafton, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Anne Ulrich, to Peter Michael Connorton, son of Mrs. John V. Connorton of New York and Carmel, N.Y., and the late Dr. Connorton.

title: MX Basing Revisited
description: Controversy over the defense of the American continent, namely how to deploy the proposed MX missile, was also due to start up again. A special Presidential commission decided last week that 100 MX's should be based in existing but strengthened Minuteman silos, a solution already rejected by Congress. The commission, named in January, was expected to report in about 10 days but whether Congress would change its mind is a ''tough call,'' according to an Administration official.

title: NEW YORK STATE'S DISCIPLINE OF PHYSICIANS COVERS A RANGE OF MISCONDUCT
