description: An examination of the cases against physicians disciplined last year by the State Department of Health and the Board of Regents, the licensing agency that acts on the Health Department's recommendations, showed that the highest percentage of them involved charges of fraud in Medicaid, the illegal prescribing or personal use of narcotics, alcoholism and gross incompetence.

title: There's Only One N.A.A.C.P.
description: Since their separation in 1957, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. have been linked by name only. Last week a Federal judge upheld the association in breaking that vestigial tie, ordering the fund to remove ''NAACP'' from its name.

title: DEMOCRATS BEGIN TESTING THEIR STRATEGIES FOR 1984
description: As the Democratic Presidential candidates prepare for the straw vote at the Massachusetts Democratic convention in Springfield on Saturday, the broad strategic tracks of their campaigns are becoming increasingly clear.

title: Shoreham And the 'Experts'
description: Lilco'S full-page ad in various papers the week of March 7, 1983, is just another of its cruel jokes. Look at the panel of ''experts'' whose very jobs depend on nuclear industry. Of course, those ''experts'' enjoyed telling us the Shoreham reactor is but lovely and desirable; look who paid them! WILLIAM KING, East Hampton

title: Beth Daniel Up by 2
description: Beth Daniel gambled and lost on the 18th hole today, yet emerged with a two-shot lead in the $400,000 Nabisco-Dinah Shore Invitational golf tournament.

title: VENTURES IN THE CHINA TRADE
description: George III dispatched an envoy to imperial China in 1793 with a proposal to open up trade, the Emperor Ch'ien Lung haughtily replied, ''I set no value on objects strange or ingenious, and have no use for your country's manufactures.'' The Emperor admonished the British King that ''should your vessels touch the shore, your merchants will assuredly never be permitted to land or to reside there, but will be subject to instant expulsion. In that event, your barbarian merchants will have had a long journey for nothing.''

title: DENNIS HOPPER, A SURVIVOR OF THE 60's, TRIES AGAIN
description: "Most of the people I knew in my 20's are dead,'' Dennis Hopper says, more in wonder than in sorrow. ''Three-quarters of my friends died before I was 30. I was talking to Bob Dylan once and he said, 'When we hit 40, man, we can look at each other and really talk to each other, like hey, how did we do that?' Forty-year-olds are survivors.''

title: OUTCRY ON CLOSING AREA AT KENSICO
description: THE sudden appearance of ''No Entrance'' signs on a cove of the Kensico Reservoir has brought an outcry from county fishermen. Nailed to trees on Nannyhagen Road, the signs were posted by the Bureau of Water Supply of New York City's Department of Environmental Protection at the end of February, sealing off an area of the Kensico Reservoir known as Horseshoe Bend in the town of Mount Pleasant.

title: THE DRAMA IN CUNNINGHAM'S NEW 'QUARTET'
description: Merce Cunningham has always claimed to have ''dramatic dances'' within his repertory and the latest is his magnificent ''Quartet,'' which received its New York premiere recently at the City Center. Drama to Mr. Cunningham, however, is not linked to a plot line but to an atmosphere. Not all his dances, then, could be called dramatic. In a general sense, all his works are meant to be seen as pure-dance pieces, where one movement is equivalent to another. This does not always work out in practice as it does in theory, but the theory does explain why Mr. Cunningham's choreography looks so different from anyone else's.

title: WEDDINGS IN FAMILIES OF DIVORCE
description: CATHY CHANDLER's wedding day was filled with almost everything a bride could want: the elegant decor of the Woodmere Country Club, the smell of orchids sent from the bridegroom's parents in Hawaii, a dress of white satin, more than 100 smiling faces and the man who at noon would become her husband, Charles Alexander.

title: 'MERE MAN' FULLY EQUIPPED TO RAISE HIS CHILDREN
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SAVE HARMLESS' SCHOOL FORMULA SURVIVES ANEW
description: FOR weeks the attention of legislators, lobbyists and localities has been riveted on the state budget and how to change it. Now that the budget has finally passed and the State Legislature is taking a two-week break, there is time to reflect on what the legislators did to the budget and what they want to do about the main budget issues in the future.

title: WHEN TO SIGN UP A PERFORMER
description: In the hard world of the concert artist, the role of the record company can sometimes be crucial to a career, bringing the artist to a much wider audience than the recital or concert hall can ever hold and providing additional income. But when does a record company decide to take on an artist? How early in the career? When is a performer a good enough risk to invest some money in him?

title: LESSON OF FALKLANDS: DISCIPLINE PAYS
description: The intangibles of war - intelligence, discipline and training - were key elements in Britain's victory over Argentina in the Falklands campaign. A report paying tribute to the intangibles and to British professionalism was circulated by the United States Navy Department on the first anniversary of Argentina's occupation of the islands.

title: TALENTED EXPOS, CHANGED DODGERS COULD DOMINATE
description: The following National League preview was written by Joseph Durso. The teams are listed in predicted order of finish with the Mets picked for fifth in the Eastern Division. NATIONAL LEAGUE EASTERN DIVISION

title: Border Patrol at Tijuana Catches 49,599 Aliens
description: After calling in reinforcements in March, the Border Patrol set a one-month record of 49,599 apprehensions of undocumented aliens in its busiest corridor.

title: ONE OF THREE YOUTHS ON A MAKESHIFT RAFT MISSING IN EAST RIVER
description: A Bronx teen-ager disappeared in the East River yesterday afternoon when he tried to swim 20 feet from a makeshift raft to Randalls Island, the police said.

title: COUNTY LOBBYISTS JUDGE THEIR EFFECT ON STATE BUDGET
description: ON Monday afternoon, Marcia M. Lee sat in the County Office Building in White Plains trying to determine how the state budget, passed that morning, would affect Westchester. ''It's difficult to get information,'' she said. ''A lot of our delegation members were exhausted and left to go to sleep.''

title: THE EVERYDAY LIFE OF EARLY CHRISTIANS
description: THE FIRST URBAN CHRISTIANS The Social World of the Apostle Paul. By Wayne A. Meeks. 299 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.

title: Anne C. Warner Engaged
description: The engagement of Anne Catherine Warner to Midshipman Jeffery Wilson Heavner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Billy Joe Heavner of Baltimore, has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Warner of Plainview, L.I. A June wedding is planned. Midshipman Heavner is a member of this year's class at the United States Naval Academy.

title: PRAY, WHY ME?
description: Whenever King Hussein tosses out a hint that he might join negotiations if the Israelis were to suspend settlement of the West Bank, the answer from Jerusalem is a terse: ''No preconditions.''

title: STRATFORD STRUGGLES TO SAVE SHAKESPEARE THEATER
description: THE American Shakespeare Theater ''has been our link to the outside world,'' said Edward J. Fennell, chairman of the Stratford Town Council, the other day. ''It's one of only three in the world and the only one in this country. It would just be unacceptable for us to lose it.''

title: Nancy Lynn Golden to Wed Dr. Guy T. Bernstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Golden of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Lynn Golden, to Dr. Guy Thomas Bernstein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Aaron Bernstein of Short Hills.

title: A June Wedding For Bijou Clinger
description: Representative William F. Clinger Jr., Republican from the 23d District of Pennsylanvia, and Mrs. Clinger of Warren Pa., and Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Whitla Clinger, to Gregory John Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew S. Miller of Steubenville, Ohio and Chautauqua, N.Y.

title: Leslie Yalof Sets August Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Yalof of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Sue Yalof, to H. Douglas Garfield, son of Mrs. Lawrence Garfield of Miramar, Fla., and the late Mr. Garfield.

title: THE CHURCH NOW AND THE CHURCH TO COME
description: A CHURCH TO BELIEVE IN Discipleship and the Dynamics of Freedom. By Avery Dulles. 200 pp. New York: Crossroad. $14.95. A HISTORY OF THE CHURCH IN LATIN AMERICA Colonialism to Liberation (1492-1979). By Enrique Dussel. Translated and revised by Alan Neely. 360 pp. Grand Rapids, Mich.: William B. Eerdmans Publishing Co. $17.95.

title: REPRIEVE FOR NEW HAVEN'S UNION STATION
description: THE shabby doors of the Union Station in New Haven, a once majestic gateway to the city that was boarded up 10 years ago, were thrown open last week and Federal, state and city officials streamed in to celebrate the railroad terminal's restoration, which is to be completed in about two years.

title: Miss Winter to Wed Dr. D.A. Kahn, Psychiatrist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Winter of Tenafly, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Audrey Jane Winter, to Dr. David Alan Kahn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Kahn of Great Neck, L.I.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Nature Conservancy, a national nonprofit organization that helps to preserve endangered species, has established two new preserves in Southern New Jersey to protect several rare plants and animals.

title: Argentine Rulers Flouted Again
description: Argentina's largely discredited military regime has promised to yield power to civilians next year but by then it may have little power to yield. Last week, its authority was further sapped when hundreds of thousands of wage-earners paralyzed the country for a day despite a strike ban.

title: THE POET OF THEOLOGY
description: Of all Charles Williams's books, only a handful of novels are still in print 38 years after his death, and in current critical assessments of modern literature he is given little attention. Yet he wrote many volumes of poetry, criticism, biography, theology and plays that influenced some important writers, among them T.S. Eliot, W.H. Auden, C.S. Lewis and J.R.R. Tolkien.

title: Kings 8, North Stars 5
description: Charlie Simmer and Terry Ruskowski scored two goals each to help Los Angeles snap a seven-game losing streak. But the Kings still will miss the N.H.L. playoffs for the first time in 10 years.

title: WHERE ASTRONOMERS GET A SOUTHERN EXPOSURE
description: Viewed on a dark night outside the Anglo-Australian Telescope here, the stars seem to shine with particular brightness. The air is clear and the major celestial signpost of this hemisphere, the Southern Cross, glows against the backdrop of the Milky Way. A kangaroo thumps his way through the bush, a koala bear occasionally appears on nearby eucalyptus trees. But astronomers who work at this observatory do not often peek outside the white, domed building at the animals or even the stars. They remain inside, their eyes fixed on video screens and computers detecting events from the beginning of time.

title: ELIMINATE CORPORATE TAX
description: This is the time of year when our minds tend to focus on taxes, especially on taxes we don't like. I have one candidate for extinction - the corporate income tax.

title: Death Toll Rises to 250 In Colombian Quake
description: Rescue workers recovered the bodies of 16 people in remote Andean mountain villages devastated by an earthquake, raising the death toll to 250, officials said today. There were fears the toll would go even higher.

title: ART OF THE MAMLUKS
description: The Smithsonian Institution's exhibition of Islamic art from the 13th to the 16th century makes its final stop on a tour of major American museums at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford Saturday through May 29.

title: PROSPECTS ON MEAT PRICES BRIGHTEN FOR CONSUMERS
description: The outlook for consumers searching for bargains at meat counters has brightened as supplies of beef, pork and poultry have continued to increase.

title: TWO CLASSICS RETURN TO THE STAGE
description: George Gershwin's ''Porgy and Bess'' is one of those exquisitely ambiguous creatures whose genus, species, anthropological past and evolutionary future seem always to elude us. Neither opera nor Broadway musical theater, portraying black music and black life in the South but written by a Jewish New Yorker, at once intimate and grand in its ambitions, ''Porgy and Bess'' - which officially opens Thursday and runs all this month at Radio City Music Hall - sits poised between a whole set of cultural and ethnic tensions. Its profuseness of dramatic action and its potential for display are as rich - and often as confusing - as its contradictions. Yet it is in the penetrating, even devastating, simplicity of Gershwin's music that all these problems are finally resolved.

title: Talks on a Sale
description: A report in The Orange County Register in California lists Reggie Jackson as a member of a group holding exploratory talks to purchase the N.B.A.'s Indiana Pacers and move the team to Anaheim, Calif. ''I have been approached by a group of people in Phoenix to be a minority partner,'' Jackson told the newspaper.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
EASTER PARADE
description: It began in 1958 as suburbia's answer to Manhattan's Fifth Avenue Easter Parade, and now, Garden City's Easter Antique Car Parade and Exhibition has become as much of an institution as its model. Today at 1 P.M. the vintage autos, accompanied by costumed bunnies, start wending their way down Franklin Avenue to Village Hall at 351 Stewart Avenue, where they will pause long enough for parade-goers to study them. The bunnies will distribute lollipops, and everything is free.WOMEN IN THE ARTS

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ''Here, take your old bunny!'' says Nana in THE VELVETEEN RABBIT, and four different publishers echo the Boy's nurse as they hustle new full-color editions of this tale onto the shelves in time for Easter. Margery Williams's story was first published in 1922 in London (Heinemann) and New York (Doran) with colored lithographs by William Nicholson. In the Doubleday reissue (1958) and the Avon paperback (1975), both based on the original, the color quality was so changed that one can hardly recognize the familiar illustrations. Perhaps, now that the Velveteen Rabbit is past 60, it is time for him to get a new look.

title: HALL PLANS ROUSE ATLANTIC CITY FEARS
description: A PROPOSAL to build a new convention hall next to the blighted Inlet section of this resort has alarmed some members of the state's Casino Control Commission and City Councilmen. They fear that a hall there would make it impossible to proceed with a $206 million plan to revitalize the Inlet area with new and renovated housing.

title: SOVIET REACTION UNCONSTRUCTIVE, STATE DEPT. SAYS
description: The United States, in a prompt response to remarks by Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, said today that it was disappointed by what it called an ''unconstructive initial Soviet reaction'' to President Reagan's latest arms control proposal. It said it hoped for a more flexible Soviet position when negotiations resume in Geneva next month.

title: GALLUP POLL FINDS THE IMAGE OF JESUS TO BE SOMEWHAT MURKY
description: Americans hold strong beliefs about the spiritual and ethical mission of Jesus, but they diverge on many specific questions on His nature and significance, according to a new Gallup Poll.

title: A PARADE OF PIANISTS ON DISKS
description: Chief among the attractions of the phonograph is the window it opens for us on music that, for one reason or another, is neglected in the concert hall. A case in point is a stunning new recording of variations by Liszt, Schumann and Rachmaninoff performed by the young pianist Cyprien Katsaris (Telefunken 642787). None of these pieces - Liszt's Variations on ''Weinen, Klagen, Sorgen, Zagen,'' Schumann's Exercises and Rachmaninoff's Variations on a Theme of Chopin - are part of the standard repertory. Yet, each is unarguably a substantial composition, especially Rachmaninoff's stupendous commentary on Chopin's Prelude in C Minor. Mr. Katsaris's performances, captured by Telefunken's very natural digital technology, are a happy synthesis of virtuosity and sensitive musicianship.

title: A.C. Littlejohn Jr.  And Miss Butcher Set May Wedding
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Leslie Wright Butcher of New York to Angus Chisholm Littlejohn Jr. of Silvermine, Norwalk, Conn.

title: MUSIC: CONCERT ROYAL PLAYS 'ORIGINAL' MOZART
description: Given the numbers of Mozart's works we regularly hear played by all sorts of ensembles, it is startling to think that there might be yet another way of performing them. But in Alice Tully Hall Wednesday night, Concert Royal gave what were claimed to be the first American performances on original instruments of three familiar pieces - the Bassoon Concerto in B flat (K. 191), the Flute Concerto in G (K. 313) and the Piano Concerto in G (K. 453). The remaining work on the program was a concert aria for tenor and orchestra, ''Misero! o sogno, o son desto?'' (K. 431).

title: Dola Davis Hamilton Marries Physician
description: Dola Davis Hamilton, widow of Richard M. Hamilton, was married yesterday at the Harvard University Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass., to Dr. Bertram Zarins, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Richard A. Zarins of Brooklyn. The ceremony was performed by the bridegroom's father, pastor of the Latvian Evangelical Lutheran Church of New York in Brooklyn, and Msgr.

title:
THE CAREFUL SHOPPER;
Family-Run Shop for Kosher Needs
description: At Kosher Konnection in New Rochelle takeout cooking to strict Glatt standards is supervised by the Westchester Rabbinical Council. The family-run shop caters for family, office or temple gatherings and can provide the after-the-sabbath-service kiddush refreshments with delivery possible locally. It always closes three hours before sundown Fridays and is closed Saturdays. During Passover the menu is simplified to holiday specialties, and the hours are adjusted around the religious observation.

title: POTTERY: FORM AND TECHNIQUE
description: ''REGAL VESSELS,'' on view at the Whichcraft Studio and Gallery here, were selected for their affinity to the imaginary royal environments depicted in a parallel show of ''Temple Walls and Pyramids.''

title: Flyers 6, Leafs 3
description: Dave Poulin, playing in his first N.H.L. game, scored two goals and Brian Propp got two to lead Philadelphia. Poulin, recruited from the Portland Mariners of the American Hockey League, opened the scoring on his first shift, flipping a 10-foot shot over the sprawled Toronto goalie, Mike Palmateer, at 4:36.

title: Susan Hory Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Joseph Hory of Buffalo and Hilton Head Island, S.C., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ann Hory, to Bruce David Colley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Omer Colley of North Salem, N.Y., and Southampton, Bermuda.

title: A June Wedding for Holly Halper and Mark Seigel
description: Selma Halper of Roslyn Heights, L.I., and Theodore D. Halper of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Holly Lisa Halper, to Mark Alan Seigel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Seigel of New York. The wedding is planned for June 5.

title: 2 GIRLS WHO TRIED TO KILL THEMSELVES
description: ''I WAS really very miserable for a long time, and I decided that after school ended in June, if it didn't get better, I was going to do this,'' said 15-year-old Margaret. ''So I planned for Sept. 5.''

title: Anne Donovan Cited
description: Anne Donovan, Old Dominion's 6-foot-8-inch senior center from Ridgewood, N.J., has won the first Champion award as Division I player of the year in women's college basketball. Similar awards were presented to Jackie White of California Poly-Pomona for Division II, Margie O'Brien of Clark for Division III, Kelli Litsch of Southwestern Oklahoma State for National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics colleges and Jackie Glosson of Moberly, Mo., for junior colleges. Of the other major honors for player of the year, Miss Donovan previously won the Naismith Award and is expected to be named Thursday as the winner of the Wade Trophy.

title: FEWER APPLY FOR ENTRANCE TO TOP COLLEGES
description: OFFICIALS of Yale University say they will ''travel a little more, particularly on the other side of the Hudson.'' Trinity College is expanding its alumni admissions-support program. And Wesleyan University is ''doing more in the way of communicating with prospective students.''

title: Gail Grossman to Be Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. James I. Grossman of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gail Lisa Grossman, to Lawrence Strassman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Strassman of Atlantic Beach, L.I. A June wedding is planned. The bride is attending Hofstra University and her fiance expects to receive a degree in June from the New York College of Podiatric Medicine. Dr. Grossman, a cardiologist, is an attending physician in the department of medicine at Montefiore Medical Center, and an assistant clinical professor of medicine at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, both in the Bronx, N.Y. Mr. Strassman's father is owner of Ace Auto Stores, a wholesale and retail concern in New York.

title: COLUMBIA CONSIDERS MOVING UP THE DATE FEES WOULD BE DUE
description: Columbia University next year would advance the due date of tuition and room and board charges for its 18,000 students, and would impose fees of up to $100 a semester for late payments, under a proposal to be considered by the board of trustees in June.

title: Alston Has Heart Attack
description: Walter Alston, the former Brooklyn and Los Angeles Dodger manager who was voted into baseball's Hall of Fame last month, was in critical condition today after suffering a heart attack.

title: A FLURRY OF INTEREST IN BOND REFUNDING
description: INVESTORS in bonds have had to cope with some drastic changes in theg round rules during the past three years, including the possiblity t hat the long-term bonds they purchased recently may prove to have a m uch shorter maturity.

title: PRISTINE LINENS
description: n the beginning, before there were no-iron designer sheets, even before Porthault's scalloped edges had wiggled their way onto fashionable beds, there were pure white bed linens. And they were good. So good, in some cases, that they were too good to use. So good, in others, that they never wore out. So good that today these ''antique'' linens are collectors' items, passing for works of art to eyes numbed by floral prints and machine embroidery on polyestercotton blends.

title: 250 ON L.I. SEEK ASSISTANCE OVER FEAR OF PESTICIDES IN THEIR HOMES
description: State environmental officials said yesterday that 250 Long Island residents had called them since Friday concerned that their homes might have been contaminated by toxic chemicals improperly applied by exterminators.

title: Donna Miller Engaged To Dr. Evan Schwartz
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Miller of Hewlett, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Donna Nancy Miller, to Dr. Evan Schwartz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Schwartz of New York and Candlewood Lake, Danbury, Conn. An early fall wedding is planned.

title: WHERE TO GO FOR SOME OF THE IRVING CELEBRATIONS
description: THE bicentennial of the birth of Washington Irving on April 3, 1783, will be celebrated throughout the year at his home, Sunnyside, and at many other sites in the county, as well as at many cultural institutions in New York and Washington.

title: THREE WORKSHOPS
description: The Oakwood Terrace budget committee will have its first meeting next Saturday morning, and it can be predicted with certainty that by afternoon the group will have produced a working budget. The committee and the community it represents will be created - and as quickly disbanded - purely to show how a cooperative or condominium board wrestles with the problems of communal budgeting.

title: Bradley of the Blitz Intercepts 6 Passes
description: Luther Bradley returned one of his six interceptions 93 yards for a touchdown tonight as the Chicago Blitz beat the Tampa Bay Bandits, 42-3.

title: Tax-Table Apartheid
description: In South Africa, where even taxes are separate and unequal, the Government has been talking for years about giving blacks the deductions enjoyed by white, Indian and mixed-race ''colored'' taxpayers. The change was originally due this year, but last week, complications led Finance Minister Owen Horwood to put it off until March 1984.

title: 12 Indicted in Florida In Undercover Operation
description: Agents pretending to be criminals ran an after-hours club in an operation that led to racketeering and conspiracy charges against the reputed Florida crime boss and 11 others, the Federal Bureau of Investigation says.

title: MORE STUDY OF THE EAST URGED
description: CAROL FREEMAN'S interest in Japan began a decade ago, when she was a high school student in Rye and increasing numbers of Japanese families were moving into the community. ''There was a Japanese girl on the tennis team with me at Rye High School,'' Mrs. Freeman recalled recently. ''She fascinated me. The other kids showed no interest whatsoever, but my curiosity was overwhelming.''

title: AN ART BETWEEN SPEECH AND MUSIC
description: ''Text-sound'' art, whose inventors practice a form of writing that lies somewhere between language and music, is avaliable on a number of recordings, and the time has come to ask: What does it add up to? What's worth hearing and how much of this sort of thing can one safely ignore?

title: 13 Slam Dunks Fall From High Altitude
description: All week basketball people were wondering if the 4,958-foot altitude here would affect the outcome of the Final Four games. And today Louisville indeed was affected by the altitude -the altitude of the Houston players as they soared in for 13 spectacular slam dunks in a 94-81 victory that in the second half often resembled a warm-up drill.

title: DONT'T RUSH THE THREE R'S
description: IGRIPPED my book bag tightly. It contained two sharpened pencils in a pencil case. I was on my way to first grade and felt I had arrived. After all, I had all the n ecessary intellectual accomplishments: I could count to 10 and print my name. I was a veteran of nursery school and kindergarten, having mastered the art of sharing while still making sure I got my turn at t he swing in the playground. But this was it: real school.

title: Was Inflation With Us From The Very Start?
description: Just when earthlings were getting used to the notion that the universe started in a primordial explosion of energy, some physicists are coming around to another idea: The universe may have bubbled up out of virtually nothing and then suddenly inflated to astronomical proportions.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: The 'Stop' Button For Staten Island
description: The New York State Power Authority, it turns out, doesn't have enough power or authority to build its long-planned, $2.1 billion coal- and garbage-fueled electric generating station on Staten Island. Honoring a campaign pledge, Governor Cuomo acted to block the sale of bonds to pay for the project, leading the state agency last week to ''indefinitely postpone'' it.

title:
GARDENING;
SELECTING PLANTS FOR THE GARDEN
description: WITH the spring planting season at hand, home gardeners will be flocking to the garden centers to take advantage of special plant sales. Certainly, there is nothing wrong with that. It is only natural to want to get the best price possible. A bargain is no bargain, however, if the plants purchased are not well-suited to the planting site and purpose for which they are intended. Plant characteristics and site requirements should be considered before a purchase.

title: ON THE MAGIC OF OPENING DAY
description: Last fall, the Yankees proposed to the American League that their first three home games be played in Denver because of anticipated construction problems at Yankee Stadium.

title: A RARE PORTRAIT OF THE POPE
description: Think of Pope John Paul II as an evangelist, preaching where he can. Think of him also as a modern man, a media personality, who uses television to further his evangelism. The Pontiff in both these roles is the subject of an unusual hour-long documentary, ''The Pope and His Vatican,'' on ABC at 7 o'clock tonight.

title: School Lunch Seen Near Goal
description: An Agriculture Department study shows that federally subsidized meals eaten by children at school do not reduce a family's overall grocery budget.

title: Bait Is Key to Fly Fishing
description: A fly designed to resemble a sand eel or a sand launce is probably t he most important item in the Northeast saltwater fly fisherman's k it.

title: INSTEAD, DISARM EUROPE
description: President Reagan's proposal for an interim agreement on a limited but equal number of intermediate-range missiles in Europe seems more likely to lead to a numbers game than to an agreement with the Soviet Union. While the proposal is meant to be more feasible than Mr. Reagan's original plan, the ''zero option,'' it still obscures the real issue - that while all land-based nuclear weapons in Europe, medium-range or short-range, are intended more for political and psychological than military purposes, they are destabilizing and could trigger nuclear war.

title: THE UNEASY CATHOLICISM OF GRAHAM GREENE
description: Later this month Simon & Schuster will publish ''The Other Man,'' a series of interviews with Graham Greene conducted by Marie-Francoise Allain. Much of the material contained in Greene's answers to her questions will be familiar to readers of his two autobiographical books, ''A Sort of Life'' and ''Ways of Escape'' - his despair during adolescence, his adventures with Russian roulette, the lifelong restlessness that led to his extensive travel, his introspection and his early conversion to Roman Catholicism. But the following selection reprinted, in a somewhat emended form, from ''The Other Man'' is perhaps a fuller and more lucid explanation of his uneasy relationship to the church than exists elsewhere. *

title: Reagan Punches Between Rounds Of Budget Fight
description: ''I want to get out there and tell my side of the story,'' President Reagan is said to have said to aides over Christmas. Last week, during Congress's Easter break, out there is exactly where he was, barraging the homefolks through national television and casual chats with reporters just as most senators and representatives were taking soundings among their constituents.

title: RACISM AND STOCKS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: COLLEGES DECLINING TO TIE DRAFT TO AID
description: FOR the last month, most financial-aid administrators at New Jersey colleges have been caught between a fear of violating student rights and disobeying a new Federal law that requires young men to register for the draft before receiving Federal educational funds.

title: LOW-COST FEDERAL MORTGAGES
description: IN recognition of the mobile home's evolution from transient to p ermanent housing, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban D evelopment announced recently that the same kind of long-term m ortgage insurance available for other kinds of homes will now apply t o mobile homes as well, under certain conditions.

title: ARCHEOLOGISTS NOW SAY PHILISTINES WEREN'T SO BAD AFTER ALL
description: ''Philistine'' has long been a byword for a person lacking cultural values, spiritual enlightenment and intellectual interests. Nineteenth-century essayists ridiculed the English middle class as vulgar Philistines. Matthew Arnold, the poet and critic, suggested that those who invented the nickname meant ''a strong, dogged, unenlightened opponent of the chosen people, of the children of light.'' Arnold in turn considered Philistine ''people who believe most that our greatness and welfare are proved by our being very rich, and who most give their lives and thoughts to becoming rich.''

title: Far East-Import Owner Extols Some Virtues
description: Bernard Sloan's article, ''Foreign Cars: Good Sense Breaks Down'' (Opinion Page, March 13), gives, in my opinion, a false impression of cars, in general reliable and well made. My own experiences, including those of other people I know, have been far different from those observed by Mr. Sloan and his friends.

title: LAWYERS FOR POOR FACE BUDGET WOES
description: Twenty years ago, a group of activists working on the Lower East Side opened a law office in a storefront. It was staffed mostly by young, recent law school graduates, and its clients were the poor, caught in disputes with businessmen, landlords and the government.

title: Leesa S. Fields Plans Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Fields of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leesa Shawn Fields, to Jonathan Band, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Band of Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: AGAINST GALACTIC RHETORIC
description: DOCUMENTS RELATING TO THE SENTIMENTAL AGENTS IN THE VOLYEN EMPIRE Canopus in Argos: Archives. By Doris Lessing. 179 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: NEW DRAMA EXPLORES BASEBALL SCANDAL
description: THE Chicago White Sox will always be remembered for having perpetrated the greatest betrayal of public trust in baseball history. No matter how brilliantly they play or how many games they win, fans of opposing teams will always identify them with the historical shadow of dishonored teammates.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: RONALD C. TOCCI made it official last week. The county legislator from New Rochelle, citing inadequate resources, withdrew formally from the Democratic race for County Executive. That left the field to the favorites, Anthony Veteran, the Greenburgh Town Supervisor, and former Representative Ogden R. Reid, each of whom, Mr. Tocci said, is ''adamant about forcing a primary.''

title: CLASSES DERAILED BY STRIKE
description: WHEN the Metro-North railroad strike on the New Haven line began, Adelphi University's Classroom on Wheels jumped the track. Over the last decade, Adelphi University of Garden City, L.I., has leased space on trains to teach courses in marketing management and economics to commuters interested in earning the degree of Master of Business Administration.

title: ISRAEL: VOICES OF MORAL ANGUISH
description: David Shipler's article on Israel begins with a headline that terms the war in Lebanon ''a conflict in which survival was not an issue.'' He makes no attempt to explain this presumption.

title: Correcting The Puzzle
description: I am sure you have heard this by now, but I am writing to inform you of an omission in the February 13 acrostic puzzle.

title:
DINING OUT;
WEEHAWKEN: ROOM WITH A VIEW
description: WE ARE asked at times why reviewers bother to write about a restaurant whose food preparation has little to recommend it, one that deserves only a fair rating. This is a valid question when the establishment has no other redeeming qualities either in atmosphere, service or location, and where there is little hope for improvement.

title: BUSINESSES AIDING SUMMER JOB EFFORT
description: ''OUR philosophy is to customize training to meet the needs of industry by bringing industry up front into the picture at the very beginning,'' said Lloyd D. Jones, director of the Westchester Private Industry Council. ''Industry's involvement in the development of the training gives us the stamp of approval that we're going in the right direction and the knowledge that most individuals in the program will receive a job at the end.''

title: Georges Bank Leases Blocked
description: A Federal judge in Boston last week threw cold water on the sale of drilling rights for 2.8 million acres of Georges Bank, the prime fishing grounds off the Northeast coast.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Swish Provides The Net Asset
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WANTED: A HONE ROBOT WITH SOME OLD-FASHIONED ROBOTICS
description: I AM a low-tech person in a high-tech world. Not for me were electric toothbrushes invented, or remote-controlled garage doors that flick up and down like guillotines. While other homes have become more mechanized, the state of the art in mine has stood still, with such primitive artifacts as a two-speed electric mixer (On and Off) and an oven that won't go from greasy to clean without the direct laying on of hands.

title:
OPINION;
A LACK OF DIPLOMA CUTS ACROSS ALL SOCIAL STRATA
description: LOOK around at the people who share your crowded space on a supermarket checkout line. Look at the harried young mother trying to calm an impatient toddler with a cookie. Look carefully at the woman who slaps her screaming child because she is embarrassed by the child's crying. Perhaps, in front of you, you'll see a well-dressed young businesswoman, who only has a few items in her basket for her single life style. In front of her is a fellow in an auto mechanic's uniform, impatiently waiting to pay for his food, which you notice consists of baby-food jars, a box of Pampers and a six-pack of Budweiser.

title: CONCERT: TAPINGS BY EARL HOWARD
description: The composer Earl Howard is skilled at creating sustained sonic landscapes, but is less adept at constructing musical entities capable of growth and evolution. The most interesting work on his Composers Forum-sponsored performance at Roulette Thursday evening was a 1982 composition, ''P.T. II'' for taped sound.

title: ACTION ON LANDMARKING CLEARS THE WAY FOR TALKS
description: THE Board of Estimate's recent affirmation of landmark status for L ever House probably puts to rest, at least until the 21st century, a ny realistic possibility that the building will be demolished.

title: Of Lawyers And Other Pros
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DEBATED RYE HOUSING PLAN FOR THE ELDERLY AWAITS COURT RULE
description: PROPONENTS of a housing project for the elderly in Rye have tangled with some unusual opponents over the last two years. When they wanted to tear down an old church, history-minded residents objected; when they chose a site occupied by tennis courts, the players opposed them.

title: Who's What In Nicaragua
description: As far as reporters on the scene could make out last week, the winds of war in Nicaragua were mostly wind. Little evidence was seen to support Sandinist claims that up to 2,000 ''counterrevolutionaries'' were fighting inside the country, with reinforcements massing across the border in Honduras. But Nicaraguan charges that Washington was actively planning and supporting the insurgency were backed by a Honduran directly involved in American covert activities and by two American senators and a high Administration official, according to The New York Times.

title: NEK CHAND'S GARDEN FANTASY
description: In Chandigarh, India, just a few hundred feet from the site where Le Corbusier's government buildings stand caked in a moldy patina, lies the fanciful sculpture garden of Nek Chand, the masterpiece of a self-taught artist who first assembled his constructions stealthily at night for fear that the authorities of this planned city would order them razed for nonconformity.

title: The Confusing Marx Case
description: A California jury decided last week that it wasn't clear whether Erin Fleming had used undue influence to get cash and property from Groucho Marx during his waning years.

title: Rosalind Livingston Warner Planning Fall Wedding to Richard R. Schreiber
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles G. K. Warner of Lincoln, Mass., and Delray Beach, Fla., have announced the engagment of their daughter, Rosalind Livingston Warner, to Richard Ramsdell Schreiber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Schreiber of Southampton, Pa.

title: A 'MISSED' PARK
description: To the Editor:

title: CARIBBEAN PRESS CURBS LISTED
description: Suriname, Nicaragua, Cuba and Haiti received harsh criticism in a report on freedom of the press and information that was approved last month by the Inter American Press Association.

title: A TIRED OPERETTA, DESPITE THE SWORDPLAY
description: THERE is splendor to spare and energy to burn in ''The Three Musketeers'' at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn., but there is no cohesive musical in sight - only in sound, thanks to Larry Wilcox's upbeat orchestrations. Counting the blessings of the season's final production, there are also choreography, costumes and conducting - but not a score - to sing about.

title: Tangled Ivy
description: Harvard University proposed to strip its buildings of their ivy a year ago this month, and immediately some students asked, Can there be an Ivy League school without ivy?

title: CONGRESS FACES TOUGH DECISIONS ON ITS RETURN FROM RECESS TUESDAY
description: Congress returns to work Tuesday to confront a series of tough decisions on domestic and foreign issues that it managed to avoid before the Easter recess.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ATLANTA
description: When azaleas explode in a profusion of pinks, reds and lavenders under stately pines, and dogwood trees turn expansive lawns into floral snowbanks, Atlanta becomes one of the most beautiful cities in the country. Residents get so carried away with the beauty that they celebrate by holding a Dogwood Festival. It opened yesterday and ends officially on April 10 - but the captivated citizenry lets it run on another week or so. For example, on April 13 Dogwood Festival Night at the Symphony will be observed with the Atlanta Ballet joining the orchestra to present ''Tchaikovsky in the Theater.'' Tickets ($7 to $12.75) are available at the Memorial Arts Center Box Office (404-892-2414).

title: Alcohol Program Needs More Support
description: As the Vice President for Darien of the Alcoholism Council Inc., I wish to express our appreciation for your article (''Efforts Grow to Fight Drunken Driving,'' March 13) describing, in part, our efforts toward creating an atmosphere of awareness with regard to the dangers of alcohol abuse, particularly among our young people.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN OYSTER BAY
description: OYSTER BAY is the town Theodore Roosevelt called home. Although he was born in New York City, he s pent most of his summers there, sailing, hunting and fishing along t he North Shore and raising his family at Sagamore Hill, a rambling, 2 2-room Victorian mansion.

title: OTHER TAX BREAKS IN THE REGION
description: Besides the Federal Government, the three states in the metropolitan region also provide tax incentives for homeownership. New York conforms to Federal law in terms of permitting residents to deduct such items as mortgage interest and property taxes and allowing those age 55 and over to claim the $125,000 exclusion on any gain from the sale of a house. New Jersey generally follows Federal law, and while Connecticut has no income tax, it extends special capitalgains treatment to elderly persons who sell their homes.

title: Soviet Politics and The Military
description: John Burns's article ''The Emergence of Andropov'' (Feb. 27) was in many ways informative. One would dispute, however, his assertion that the Soviet generals' support had been a major factor in helping Andropov to reach the top.

title: STATE ADDING TO ENDANGERED-SPECIES LIST
description: NEW JERSEY'S official list of 52 endangered and threatened species is being revised to include several new species, as well as others that officials say have slipped from threatened to endangered status.

title: GENERALS SAID TO HURT LEAGUE
description: Chet Simmons, the commissioner of the United States Football League, acknowledged in an interview last week that the poor performances of the New Jersey Generals and Herschel Walker have impeded the start of the new league, which is one month old today.

title: Robin Berman to Wed Jeffrey Plunkett
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Berman of Spring Valley, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Berman, to Jeffrey Dunbar Plunkett, son of Barbara Plunkett of Westport, Conn., and Sumner L. Plunkett of Patchogue, L.I.

title: Leslie A. O'Connor to Wed Howard Edelman, Lawyer
description: Leslie Anne O'Connor and howard C. Edelman plant to be married in August in New York. The future bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lester T. O'Connor of Lynbrook, L.I. Mr. Edelman is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving H. Edelman of Brooklyn.

title: THE REVIVAL OF 'ORNAMENTALISM'
description: THE course of art is never so confused that cooler heads can't discern some order in the chaos. Robert Jensen and Patricia Conway are two such heads taking on the latter part of the 20th century in all its disarray. Mr. Jensen, formerly an associate editor of the Architectural Record, is now an assistant professor of architecture at the New York Institute of Technology. Miss Conway, an associate editor for Industrial Design, is also a partner in Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, a firm of architects, interior designers and planning consultants. The two have examined not only the architecture of the last 20 years but the applied and fine arts, too, and they have observed in them a trend that hitherto has been obscured under the headings, ''pluralism'' and ''post-modernism.''

title: Who Gets the Furniture?
description: The wife of a $6 billion man could become a $3 billion divorcee as the result of a court ruling in California last week.

title: N.B.A.'S NEW CONTRACT: A STATESMANLIKE SETTLEMENT
description: IF Larry Fleisher, chief negotiator for the National Basketball Players Association, was the happiest man around after last week's handshake on a revolutionary new basketball agreement, his opposite number in the National Football League Players Association, Ed Garvey, ran him a close second.

title: Barbara Donahue To Wed a Banker
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Paul Donahue of Whitefield, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Lynn Sean Donahue of Greenwich, Conn., to Charles Riford Boyce 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Boyce of Falmouth Foreside, Me., and Highgate Springs, Vt.

title: Eleanor Labine to Wed Stockbroker on June 18
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roland Arthur Labine Jr. of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eleanor Jane Labine, to Thomas Aquinas Mancusi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Thomas Mancusi of Douglaston, Queens, and Quogue, L.I.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: WOMEN VOCALISTS The list of women who will be performing in New York's cabarets, jazz clubs and concert halls this week is an unusual gathering of top echelon talent.

title: Medical Mystery
description: After being quiescent for 15 years, thallium poisoning suddenly appeared to be a problem in January 1981. Eight confirmed cases were reported among Texas Gulf Coast residents by the University of Texas Poison Control Center, and the rare metal, banned in consumer products since 1972, was suspected of causing a dozen other illneses.

title: Equitable Agreements In Divorce
description: In ''Coping With Divorce in Later Life'' (March 6), divorce mediation is described as an alternate route to a separation or divorce wherein wife and husband do not get locked into the adversarial system. The mediation process does indeed develop productive discussion and problem-solving so that each party has a voice in decision-making.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Prices Hold

title: SIDEWALKS TRIP UP SOUTHOLD
description: SIDEWALKS are not usually a subject of concern on the rural North Fork, where less than 38 miles of sidewalks traverse the hamlets and villages. But in the village of Southold, people are tripping and falling on the uneven concrete paths that front the village's shopping area.

title: A COMEBACK FOR ROMANTIC ROSES FROM ANOTHER ERA
description: A rose garden is romantic. When I'm working with my roses it's easy to forget that I'm mucking about manure and compost and easy to imagine myself floating among the ranks of nobility. There are such roses as Comtesse de Murinais (moss), the Honorable Lady Lindsay (shrub) and Baroness Rothschild (hybrid perpetual). Weeding here, snipping there, I tend Marie Louise (damask) just as Empress Josephine did in her gardens at Malmaison.

title: JERSEY COURT ASKS JURY DUTY REFORM
description: All automatic exemptions from jury service would end under a statewide program announced by Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz of State Supreme Court.

title: Felons Should Not Lead Unions
description: Roy Williams enjoyed the presumption of innocence and therefore the presidency of the teamsters' union throughout his seven-week trial for conspiring to bribe a senator and misuse union funds. He lost the presumption when he lost his case, on all eleven counts. He should now lose his job.

title: SELECTING A CHILD'S FINANCIAL GUARDIAN
description: MANY parents of young children concentrate on building up enough a ssets to protect them in case they are orphaned. But often, parents n eglect to draw up wills because they think their estates are too s mall to warrant consulting an attorney.

title: French Official Accused Of Slander by China
description: China made a strong personal attack against Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France today, accusing him of slandering Peking and spreading mischief during his recent trip to Southeast Asia.

title: EAST HAMPTON DEBATES TRAILS VS. HOMEOWNERS' PRIVACY
description: EAST HAMPTON TOWN'S effort to advertise an unusual public system of trails and save them from development has divided the Planning Board and angered homeowners who fear a loss of privacy.

title: BOSSY'S 60TH SET N.H.L. MARK
description: Mike Bossy now has 60. Billy Carroll has one. But each of their goals was significant tonight as the Islanders scored four times in the final period for a 6-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Vietnamese Battle Thais
description: At least 100 Vietnamese troops crossed into Thailand today and fought hand-to-hand with a Thai border patrol, killing five Thai soldiers and wounding eight, the Thai Army commander in chief said.

title: Terps Win in Lacrosse
description: Jim Wilkerson scored two goals and added two assists as seventh-ranked Maryland upset No. 3 North Carolina, 11-9, in lacrosse match today. Tony Olmert added two goals for the Terps, who are 4-1. Dave Wingate and Mike Burnett each had a pair for the Tar Heels, who fell to 2-2.

title: Belgium's Spa
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORS'S HOUSE IS NO LONGER A HOME
description: LATELY, both day and night, I've taken to looking out of one of my north windows at the house next door. Like mine, it is a white twostory first of-the-century house with, on the side I can see, two tall upstairs windows with handsome shutters, a small latticed window that marks the stairway, a wide kitchen window and two small cellar windows.

title: GHETTO UPRISING TO BE MARKED
description: THE 40th anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising will be commemorated at Holocaust memorial programs throughout the state in the next several weeks.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
BIG SUMMER AUCTION IS MOVED TO NEW YORK CITY
description: New York will be the site of Auction '83, one of this year's biggest public auction sales of rare coins. The fifth in an annual series, this midsummer sale had been scheduled for San Diego in mid-August, just prior to the convention of the American Numismatic Association in that city. But the four participating auction firms decided to shift it because of unforeseen problems regarding the original location.

title: HOUSTON, NORTH CAROLINA STATE WIN AND GAIN N.C.A.A. FINAL
description: Jim Valvano, North Carolina State's excited and happy young coach, said, ''We're on Fantasy Island'' after his surprising team reached the championship game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament. The Wolfpack was never expected to get that far when this tournament began in mid-March.

title: U.S. TIES TO ANTI-SANDINISTS ARE REPORTED TO BE EXTENSIVE
description: The following article is based on reporting by Philip Taubman and Raymond Bonner and was written by Mr. Bonner. A Honduran who was directly involved in planning United States covert activities reports that the United States has been giving intelligence assistance and military advice in Honduras to forces fighting the Sandinist Government in Nicaragua.

title: Wisconsin Scores Success in Hockey
description: The University of Wisconsin's N.C.A.A. hockey championship, earned last weekend in a 6-2 decision over Harvard at Grand Forks, N.D., seemed to be business as usual. It was the Badgers' fourth national crown in 11 years.

title: A WHOLE LIFE IN 64 SQUARES
description: THE QUEEN'S GAMBIT By Walter Tevis. 243 pp. New York: Random House. $13.95.

title: College Decision
description: ''I want him to go to Pitt; my husband wants him to go to Pitt; the whole family wants him to go to Pitt,'' the mother of Marlon Ferguson was quoted as having said in The Pittsburgh Post Gazette yesterday. The trouble is her son, a 6-foot-8 inch basketball star at Center High School has signed a letter-of-intent for Duquesne and the parents, Carl and Nan Ferguson, say they won't sign it.

title: DOES MUGABE TRAIL OR LEAD HARD-LINERS?
description: THIS country is only three years into its independence and its rules of political discourse are still being written. One rule seems to hold that political leaders in power, especially Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, should not be taken literally when they threaten their enemies from a public platform.

title: MAN MEETS BOOK IN THE PERSONALS
description: ''IF you are acquainted with the work of the French historians - the analystes who go around looking at parish records and bills of lading to find out what happened in times gone by instead of looking at kings and armies -I would say that these personals have that kind of place in the sociological matrix.''

title: SPANISH DISHES, AND MEXICAN, TOO
description: AS at most Spanish restaurants, at La Paella, a small place that opened last year in Glen Cove, the portions are extremely generous and the prices relatively moderate. You will not leave hungry.

title: American Friends
description: To the Editor:

title: DESPITE HARSH TALK, NEW COLD WAR IS DISCOUNTED
description: SOVIET and American leaders are trading ugly charges, military spending is being further pumped up, each side is on the verge of deploying a new generation of nuclear missiles, and there is talk of another cold war. Yet the weight of expert opinion inside the Reagan Administration, shared by many private specialists on the Soviet Union, is that while relations between the two superpowers are very bad - Secretary of State George P. Shultz called them tense last week - they are not particularly dangerous. Ultimately, these experts say, the military buildup, while cause for concern, will lead to serious negotiations.

title: OLD VALUES GONE UNDERGROUND
description: NARCISSA AND OTHER FABLES By Louis Auchincloss. 213 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $13.95.

title: CIVIL SERVICE BILL IS ENDORSED
description: IT WAS like Oldtimers Day at the State House last Wednesday, a day that saw New Jersey's two most-recent Governors - Brendan T. Byrne and William T. Cahill -join Governor Kean in lobbying for changes in the state's Civil Service system.

title: HOLY WEEK 1983
description: This year's Holy Week was marked by an unholy row over nuclear military weapons.

title: CUOMO'S L.I. MAN
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO has established a Long Island outpost in the person of a 31-year-old Williston Park resident, Thomas P. DeJesu, who has just started work as the regional representative for the Cuomo administration.

title: DEAR CONGRESSMAN: PERUSING THE MAIL
description: THE subjects can range from Social Security to morals, from ''outof-control'' military spending to the cost of a stoplight on a suburban street corner, from an annoying transit strike to a peremptory nuclear strike. Each week, thousands of pieces of mail on all subjects imaginable - and some almost unimaginable - pour into the comfortably cluttered offices of Westchester County's Congressmen from the folks back home.

title: Patricia M. Reilly To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Patrick Reilly of Darien, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Mary Reilly, to Stuart Scott Morrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Raymond Morrison of New Orleans.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: NEW disclosures of secret operations conducted by the Office of Naval Intelligence for more than three decades, including World War II, are ''agonizing,'' says Jeffrey M. Dorwart, author of ''Conflict of Duty'' (Naval Institute Press, Annapolis, Md., 21402, $18.95).

title: CONCERT: MUSICA SACRA
description: Richard Westenburg approaches Bach's choral masterpieces in a manner that is convincingly idiosyncratic. Although Mr. Westenburg has done his musicological homework, his style has as little to do with the wispy sounds produced by too many ''Authentick'' Baroque scholars as it does with the broad Germanic Romanticism espoused by an earlier generation.

title: CONCERT: ALVIN CURRAN
description: ''Canti Illuminati,'' performed by its composer, Alvin Curran, at Roulette Wednesday night, is a minute work with epic pretensions, for piano, voice, tape and electronic equipment.

title: SAN ANTONIO MAYOR RE-ELECTED
description: Henry Cisneros, the first Hispanic Mayor of this south Texas city since the mid-19th century, won re-election tonight with a record 94 percent of the vote.

title: Marguerite M. Jenkins To Marry Psychiatrist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alan Nelson Jenkins of Warrenton, Va., and Vero Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marguerite Martin Jenkins, to Dr. Frank Grier Wakefield of Rehoboth Beach, Del., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Harold K. Wakefield.

title: Miss Young, Paul Ford Jr.  Plan to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. John Young of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Young, to Paul B. Ford Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ford of Pine Orchard, Conn., and Eustis, Fla. The wedding is to be held on May 28.

title: A Moving Moment
description: Calling it ''one of the most moving moments of my life,'' Tony Yates returned to the University of Cincinnati yesterday as the head basketball coach. Yates, who helped the Bearcats win National Collegiate Athletic Association titles in 1961 and 1962 with such other players as Tom Thacker and Ron Bonham, was named to the post by Athletic Director Mike McGee to fill the vacancy created by the dismissal of Ed Badger three weeks ago, after the Bearcats posted the worst record, 11-17, in 37 years at the school.

title: Water Energy Project Next to Yosemite Gains
description: Despite opposition in Congress, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has issued a preliminary permit for a $660 million hydroelectric project next to Yosemite National Park, Calif.

title: FRENCH LABOR TAKES WARY VIEW OF PLANS FOR AUSTERITY
description: The economic austerity the French Socialists have put into effect is not the sort of program to bring trade unionists to their feet for a joyous rendition of the ''Internationale.'' In fact, the unions have responded harshly to a plan to cut consumption by way of reducing inflation and the country's balance of trade deficit.

title: JOURNAL SQ. PLAZA
description: It has been nearly 20 years since the ''bowl'' area of Journal Square in Jersey City was cleared for urban renewal, and mayoral candidates ever since have promised to put the vacant four acres back into productive use. But the area remained a parking lot until recently, when the administration of Mayor Gerald McCann helped Joseph A. Panepinto get financing for the first phase of an expected three-building office complex to be called Journal Square Plaza.

title: BRAVURA EFFECTS
description: FRANZ LISZT Volume One. The Virtuoso Years, 1811-1847. By Alan Walker. 481 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Reagan Bends Under Pressure By the Allies
description: More to pacify the allies than to persuade the Russians to compromise, President Reagan backed away last week from his insistence on all or nothing in intermediate-range missile deployment in Europe. His proposal - sharp reductions on both sides - was rejected yesterday by Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, who said it could not lead to agreement in the deadlocked arms negotiations in Geneva. The President proposed an initial step toward his still cherished goal of total elimination of such missiles - cutting back from the 108 Pershing 2 and 464 cruise missiles the Allies plan to start deploying this year in return for similar reductions in the Soviet arsenal of 600 missiles.

title: BY AIR OR BY RAIL?
description: According to a recent Amtrak study, it is cheaper, more comfortable and quicker to go from New York to Washington by train than by air. Even though other studies dispute this, they all reflect the growing attention that travelers in the Northeast Corridor are giving to alternatives to the long-popular Eastern Air-Shuttle as it battles competition from other airlines and as rail service improves.

title: Karen Beth Klein to Marry James Andrew Hirsch
description: Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Klein of Woodbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Beth Klein, to James Andrew Hirsch, son of Dr. Stanley Hirsch of Pittsburgh and Renee Hirsch of Boston.

title: Debra Newman Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Newman of Scarsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Debra Margolit Newman, to Dean Robert Bernstein, son of Howard Bernstein of Fort Lee, N.J., and Mrs. Stanley Weston of Kings Point, L.I. A June 5 wedding is planned. Miss Newman is assistant to the vice president for financial reporting of the New Plan Realty Trust in New York, of which her father is president and chairman. Her fiance is marketing manager of the M.P. Commodities Corporation in New York.

title: Air Force Grounds Its F-15's To Examine a Key Part of Tail
description: The Air Force has grounded its 650 F-15 jet fighters for the second time in five months because of suspected defects in a key tail part.

title: Barbara Watkins Becomes a Bride
description: Barbara Sanders Watkins, daughter of Mrs. John Custer Watkins of Lebanon, Va., was married yesterday to James Herbert Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Kaufman of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. James F. McDonald performed the Methodist ceremony in the chapel of the University of Virginia in Charlottesville, Va.

title: Susan D. Bliss Is Engaged To Marry Peter M. Soule
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Mather Bliss Jr. of South Freeport, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Dwight Bliss, to Peter Martin Soule, son of Mrs. Lawrence Darr Chapman of Falmouth Foreside, Me., and the late Frank Huntington Soule.

title: MET OPERA: 'PARSIFAL' BY WAGNER
description: Both Wagner's ''Parsifal'' and the Metropolitan Opera have been with us now 100 years, and since their respective births, one has never strayed too far from the other. The Met first brought this massive and exalted work to the American stage in 1903 over the ardent protests of the Wagner family, who saw ''Parsifal'' as a sacred ceremony suitable - in its dramatic form at least - only for Bayreuth.

title: Barbara Rifkind Is Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Richard A. Rifkind of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Rifkind, to Todd Warren Boli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren R. Boli of Canton, Ohio, and Stella Maris, Long Island, Bahamas.

title: Ridership Declines
description: Does mass transit take people where they want to go? The answer, according to an analysis last week by the Census Bureau, seemed to be yes in New York City and no just about everywhere else.

title: WHAT WHEN WRONG?
description: IT seems a hundred years ago that we boarded a shiny, clean train at the New Haven station for a trip to New York City. Dressed in our best clothes and black patent leather Mary Janes, we were lifted up from the platform by a genial conductor and placed gently aboard. The New York, New Haven and Hartford chugged reliably out of the railroad yards and we held our breaths collectively as our anticipation of riding the train for the first time became a reality.

title: Rodgers Wins Race
description: Bill Rodgers, last year's winner, pulled away from Mike Clark of Fayetteville, Ark., to win a 10,000-meter road race today.

title: EMPTY-NEST ANTICS AT WHOLE THEATER
description: AS IF in anticipation of next season, which will have an emphasis on entertainment, the Whole Theater Company here is ending its first decade with a new comedy that couldn't be more commercially oriented and has a right to a prosperous afterlife as a touring and summerstock attraction.

title: Racism and Stocks
description: To the Business Editor:

title: A CORRECTION
description: An article about correctional institutions last week incorrectly used as an illustration a photograph taken at Bonnie Brae. Bonnie Brae, in Bernards Township, is a residential treatment center for children with family difficulties, adjustment disorders, learning disabilities and the like. The children who live there are not inmates.

title: Conflict of Interest
description: Richard Buonantony has a problem. He's one of the bright young pitching prospects in the Chicago Cubs farm system, had a good year with the Quad Cities Class A farm last season, hurling three shutouts on the way to a 12-4 record and striking out 103 batters in 161 innings.

title: LAUTENBERG: ON-THE-JOB TRAINING
description: FRANK R. LAUTENBERG is still running, not for the United States Senate - he won that battle against Millicent Fenwick last fall - but in it. In his 98 days in office, the 59-year-old Democrat has learned, in fact, that the real running takes place after the election.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Chester 135,000 *2*Fox Chase Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*15-year-old Cap Cod; birch-paneled *2*basement, semifinished attic; taxes $2,898. Edison $89,400 *2*15 Bodnarik Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, *2*22-year-old bilevel; screened porch, *2*heavily treed year; taxes $1,758. Livingston $95,000 *2*47 Congressional Parkway, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*30-year-old ranch; new roof and furnace, *2*hardwood floors; taxes $2,229. Allendale $100,000 *2*50 Chestnut Street, 4-bedroom, 2-bath *2*older colonial; large concrete patiom *2*year-old gas furnace; taxes $2,337. Montclair $153,000 *2*251 South Mountain Avenue 3-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*20-year-old split level; deck, *2*2 fireplaces; taxes $4,857. Raritan Township $176,000 *2*Laurelton Trail, 4-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*new passive solar home; 3.5 acres, *2*family room with woodstove, greenhouse; *2*taxes to be assessed. OTHER AREAS Merrick, L.I. $46,000 *2*1498 William Street, 4-bedroom, 1-bath, *2* 50-year-old Cape Cod; den, eat-in kitchen; *2*taxes $1,200. Larchmont, N.Y. $235,000 *2*1 Highridge Road, 5-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*32-year-old frame split level; *2*family room, patio, eat-in kitchen, *2*2-car garage; taxes $6,243. Ridgefield, Conn. $145,000 *2*59 Acre Lane, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*17-year-old raised ranch; *2*sun room, 1 acre, excellent condition; *2*taxes $2,124.

title: EVIDENCE
description: At one point during a series of hearings that ended last week with the sentencing of teamster president Roy L. Williams and three co-defendants, Federal District Judge Prentice H. Marshall, a witty man with a penchant for the ironic, seemed to be poking fun at the Government's case. He began parroting prosecutorial cliches, including a repeated reference to ''the slimy tentacles of organized crime.''

title: Compound Casino Risks
description: Doctors at Atlantic City's Medical Center report that from November 1980 through 1982, they treated 291 cardiac patients brought from casinos or buses enroute to the gaming halls. The casinos are thus providing almost 16 percent of the center's annual cardiac business.

title: IT'S AN AGE OF VULNERABILITY
description: RIGHT now I am clinging to the precipice of dreams. At 47, I am still not a realist. I have a tendency to believe that people are honest, hard work pays off and no one intentionally steps on another human being to get to the top.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE TRUANTS: Adventures Among the Intellectuals. By William Barrett. (Doubleday/Anchor, $8.95.) An insider's vivid and poignant memoir, ''The Truants'' reexamines both the leading personalities and the governing ideas of a pivotal intellectual coterie - the Partisan Review's editors and contributors - as it emerged in the years immediately before and after World War II. Our reviewer, Hilton Kramer, noted that William Barrett writes ''with an unusual degree of intimacy, intelligence and candor,'' and said the book ''abounds in brilliant portraiture.''

title: THE ROOTS OF 'STAYMAN'
description: Every serious mathematician knows about the great coincidence in the history of his subject: The independent simultaneous invention of differential calculus by Newton and Leibnitz. But very few bridge players know about a corresponding episode in the history of their game.

title: STATE HEALTH CHIEF PLEDGES TO ACT AGAINST MISCONDUCT BY PHYSICIANS
description: New York State, increasingly troubled by cases of misconduct, incompetence and drug abuse by physicians, has decided to bring charges against any hospital that fails to report such cases, according to the State Health Commissioner.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 3 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 1 THE LONESOME GODS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $14.95.) A rugged adventurer stakes his claim in 19th-century southern California. 3 6 4 THE DELTA STAR, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $15.45.) Los Angeles cops contend with their own city's underworld, some would-be Nobel Prize scientists and an elusive Soviet sub. 4 1 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The friendship of two women survives the strains of 25 years in the worlds of show business, politics and big business. 5 5 31 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 6 3 27 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 7 1 BANKER, by Dick Francis. (Putnam,

title: APPEALS PLANNED ON STAKES
description: The makeup of the field for the Kentucky Derby this year appears likely to be affected by the outcome of two appeals and possible lawsuits surrounding the outcome of the Spiral Stakes at Latonia Race Course on March 27.

title: DECORATING EGGS: A FOLK ART UPDATED
description: FOR over 1,000 years, the people of Poland have decorated eggs - the symbol of life and rebirth - at springtime. At the Port Jefferson home of Stephanie Kostecki Costanzo, the traditional Polish folk art of coloring and adorning eggs is reborn each Easter season.

title: 2 Men, Apparently Homeless, Found Dead After Fire on L.I.
description: Two men, apparently homeless, who were sleeping in a rundown, abandoned house here were found dead this morning after a fire destroyed the two-story building, according to fire officials.

title: RACE CAR RARITIES
description: Long before the Model T came off Henry Ford's assembly line in 1913, there were toy automobiles - cars to pedal about in and cars to push around. This means, of course, that today there are two kinds to collect and two quite different audiences for these toys.

title: Felice Shapiro Is Engaged to Darrell D. Friedman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Shapiro of Westbury, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Felice Shapiro, to Darrell D. Friedman, son of Mrs. Jack Friedman of San Francisco and the late Mr. Friedman.

title: CHAS CONERLY AND ASSAULT LANDING WIN
description: Chas Conerly, named for the former New York Giants' quarterback, stamped himself as a prospect for the Kentucky Derby when he led every step of the way to win the second division of the Gotham Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: FALSE IDENTITIES USED BY PROFESSOR NOW STAND AT 34
description: The number of false identities has risen from two to 34 and investigators in Pennsylvania have not yet got to the bottom of the 16 boxes of documents found in the apartment of the peripatetic professor.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''If the position of the U.S.A. stays as it is now, there can be no chance of an agreement.''

title: DEMOCRAT ASSAILED FOR SEEKING CAMPAIGN AID OUTSIDE CHICAGO
description: Representative Harold Washington, who has taken his campaign for Mayor to New York, Washington and Detroit in recent days, has returned home to face continued criticism of his trips from his Republican opponent.

title: Portugal
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am interested in going on one of the many wildlife adventure trips available today in Africa or Asia or South America. I am looking for adventure, but not outright danger, and while complete safety can never be guaranteed and is not expected, how safe are these trips? How can one find out what provisions, if any, are made for reasonable safety, and what sort of record a trip operator has? - V.A.W., New York, N.Y. Answer:China Galland - author of a book called ''Women in the Wilderness'' (Harper & Row) and a California-based guide who has led groups rafting down the Colorado River, kayaking in the Gulf of California and trekking in Nepal - offers the following questions for a prospective expedition member to ask the tour operator:

title: Weighing In For Wagner
description: A fourth 'R' is dominating the search for a successor to former Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola - race - and once again, Mayor Koch is in conflict with New York City's black and Hispanic communities. The Mayor's choice for the $85,000-a-year job is his Deputy Mayor for Policy, Robert F. Wagner Jr.; most minority leaders have rallied behind Dr. Thomas K. Minter, the Deputy Schools Chancellor for Instruction. Anthony J. Alvarado, superintendent of Community District 4 in East Harlem, is widely regarded as a longshot contender for the post.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: If It Isn't One Strike, It's Another
description: For a while last week, it seemed that N.J. Transit might get back on track following a tentative agreement with a faction of the United Transportation Union that struck its nine commuter rail lines March 1. But while those who called the walkout voted to end it, some of those who supported it said they weren't ready to settle.

title: The Hot Seat At the E.P.A.
description: Environmentalists had a few good words last week for William D. Ruckelshaus, President Reagan's nominee to be the new Environmental Protection Agency Administrator. But it was clear from the latest reports from the field that the man who first led the agency in 1970 faces an uphill struggle this time around.

title: A BROUHAHA IN YANKEE BANKING
description: LIKE many New England bankers, Richard D. Hill is given to sermonizing about banking by drawing on the woodsy poetry of Robert Frost for metaphors and similes of birch trees, spring thaws and stone walls. Lots of stone walls.

title: Pumping Irony
description: The public positions Jane Fonda has taken on women's rights don't reflect the posture of her health spa, according to three women who used to work for her.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: MARK R. SHEDD, who did not seek reappointment as Connecticut's Commissioner of Education in January, has a new job in Maine. Mr. Shedd, who had been the state's top education official for nearly nine years, will direct a new program of public policy and management to begin this fall at the University of Southern Maine in Portland Gorham. His appointment took effect Friday.

title: Morales of U.S.C. Wins 100-Meter Dash in 10.66
description: Louis Morales, a late entry in the 100-meter dash, edged his Southern California teammate, Darwin Cook, today at the Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Suns Down Knicks; Fourth Loss in Row
description: At 6 feet 10 inches, Larry Nance is called a ''small forward'' because of the position he plays on the Phoenix Suns front line. But tonight, his big numbers spelled the demise of the Knicks before 12,643 fans here at Veterans Memorial Coliseum.

title: BUSY MRS. FENWICK SAYS SHE HAS FEW REGRETS
description: IF THERE is one thing Millicent Fenwick has learned since her defeat by Frank R. Lautenberg last November, it is to read her mail the day it arrives.

title: Gayle A. Perkins Weds C.N. Atkins 2d
description: Gayle Angela Perkins, editorial director of WRC Television, an NBC-owned station in Washington, was married yesterday in Richmond to Charles Nathaniel Atkins 2d, legislative counsel to Senator David L. Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma. The ceremony was performed at St. Philip's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Allan Wentt, assisted by the Rev. Miles Mark Fisher 4th of Washington.

title: VIETNAMESE LEAVE STAMP ON LIVES OF CAMBODIANS
description: More than four years after its invasion of Cambodia, Vietnam has extended its influence deep into the daily lives of the Cambodian people.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GROMYKO'S STATEMENT ON MISSILES
description: Following are excerpts from a statement by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union at a news conference yesterday in Moscow, as distributed in translation by the official Soviet press agency Tass:

title: SEEKING BETTER TIMES
description: GEORGE BAMBERGER, who nearly quit as manager of the Mets after one s eason, is a salty and direct 57 year-old man from Staten Island who h as seen better times. He considers the numbers:

title: Miss Agnew Is Affianced
description: Mrs. Seth Marshall Agnew of Wellesley and Siasconset, Mass., has announced the engagement of her stepdaughter, Roseanna Elizabeth Agnew, to Walter Owen LaBonte Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. LaBonte of Springfield, Mass.

title: Nova Scotia Pique
description: The Bronx Civil Court judge awarded $200 to Ida Bogner for emotional anguish in a suit against General Motors, saying she had to ''languish in the boondocks'' of Nova Scotia a week while awaiting a part for her disabled 1982 car.

title: ISREAL: VOICES OF MORAL ANGUISH
description: David Shipler might have mentioned draft refusal, which occurred in Israel during the war in Lebanon. At a theater in central Tel Aviv, while the war was raging, there was a public meeting to discuss the propriety - and even the necessity - of refusal to render military service.

title: STEPS ARE MADE TO SAVE FARMS
