description: FOR the first time in three years, the State Department of Agriculture says it is ready to sign a contract with a farmer to keep his land from being sold for development.

title: A TRUE VISION OF THE TRUE WEST
description: ELIZABETH ARTHUR's most recent novel, ''Beyond the Mountain,'' is forthcoming in the fall from Harper and Row.

title: Miss Raisfeld to Wed Leonard A. Benowich
description: Marcine Raisfeld of West Hempstead, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Ruth D. Raisfeld, to Leonard A. Benowich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward B. Benowich of Tappan, N.Y.

title: A French Ferry Is Swept by Fire
description: A fire swept through a French ferry carrying 700 people today, killing one man and injuring 26 other passengers, the police said.

title: All U.S. Marines in Lebanon Will Now Carry Loaded Rifles
description: United States Marines in Beirut, after an attack on them last month and the threat of another, now all carry loaded rifles instead of just one per patrol, their commanding officer, Col James Mead, said Friday. Special to the New York Times

title: 'PROJECT STUDIO' ART TURNS AN EXHIBITION INTO A FESTIVAL
description: THE project studio is a setting in which artists usually spend months or years creating works suited to the particular environment provided for them. Such facilities, including the Clocktower and P.S. 1 in New York City, offer far more than mere work space, and are often the scene of performances and related events that expand our definitions of art.

title: Affirmative Action
description: To the Business Editor:

title: TRACKING WASHINGTON'S ENDS AND MEANS IN CENTRAL AMERICA
description: WHILE politicians and diplomats continued to argue the relative merits of electoral or negotiated solutions in Central America, the region last week took a new step toward wider warfare. The latest wave of anti-Sandinist attacks inside Nicaragua did not threaten the Government installed after the ouster of the Somoza regime in July 1979. But it suggested that just as in El Salvador, Nicaragua's troubles were moving toward prolonged military struggle rather than an early political solution.

title: A Coach's Viewpoint
description: Abe Lemons, out of basketball since being dropped as coach at the University of Texas last season, gave his perspective of college coaching from the outside to the National Association of Basketball Coaches in Albuquerque, N.M., the other day: ''When I started, we used to make very little money and have a lot of fun. Now, we make a lot of money and have no fun at all. I like it better this way.''

title: TACTICS IN THE DEBATE ON SHOREHAM
description: THE two articles in the Long Island Weekly on March 13 re the Shoreham nuclear plant (''The Fight Over Shoreham Is Also a Fight for Public Opinion'') have left the heart of the issue untouched. The blame for this failure to address the issue lies squarely with the Long Island Lighting Company management. It is the duty of a company that introduces a new technology to mount a firm, full, vigorous campaign of education and to be particularly forceful in exposing misstatements of fact that mislead the public.

title:
GARDENING;
SELECTING PLANTS FOR THE GARDEN
description: WITH the spring planting season at hand, home gardeners will be flocking to the garden centers to take advantage of special plant sales. Certainly, there is nothing wrong with that. It is only natural to want to get the best price possible. A bargain is no bargain, however, if the plants purchased are not well-suited to the planting site and purpose for which they are intended. Plant characteristics and site requirements should be considered before a purchase.

title: HOME WORSHIP FILLS A NEED
description: IF Robert W. Louth, the chairman of the Emmaus Community, a Roman Catholic congregation in Stamford, were asked directions to his church, he probably would be stuck for an answer.

title: AN AMERICAN OPERA TO TOP THE LIST
description: Twenty years ago, writing in this newspaper, Virgil Thomson sized up the American opera picture and came to some hopeful conclusions. The composer and critic, whose own works for the lyric stage had demonstrated his competence to speak on the subject, saw the development as a slow one, partly because our composers had jettisoned traditional European models but had not yet developed a native operatic tradition to guide them.

title: IF IT'S SPRING, IT'S ONION TIME
description: METEOROLOGISTS contend that the vernal equinox heralds the advent of spring. ''Nonsense,'' say New England gardeners, cognizant of the fact that there are really only three sure signs of a shift in seasons: Groundhog Day, the first robin and onion season.

title: On Time and On the Money
description: ''I'm not particularly proud of what we have done,'' Warren M. Anderson, leader of the New York State Senate, said last week. ''But I am proud of when we did it.''

title: LETTERS FROM HOME FLOOD CONGRESSMAN
description: THE subjects range from Social Security to immorality, from military spending to the cost of a traffic light on a suburban street corner, from steel-jawed animal traps to tax loopholes.

title: A Correction
description: In a Week in Review article of March 13, the Hanna Mining Company was incorrectly described. Hanna, an independent company, is a partner with W.R. Grace and Company in some coal mining ventures.

title: ONE STEP TOWARD FULL DEREGULATION
description: IN the last few years the domestic airfare marketplace has become e normously confusing. The increasingly complex structure has created c onfusion for the travelers, travel agents and airline employees. Thel ack of consistency between ticket prices and distances traveled has r aised questions about the rationality and equity of the pricing s ystem.

title: SAVING TREES AND A 1741 HOMESTEAD
description: Preserved through a deed restriction imposed by a previous owner, an original Long Island homestead has gone up for a sale on a site in North Hempstead that will soon be surrounded by 44 new homes. The homestead's original section was built in 1741 and it was the site of the first North Hempstead town meeting in 1793.

title: Jane A. Sutter Engaged to R.P. Starke
description: Jane Ann Sutter and R. Penfield Starke, who are lawyers in Washington, will be married on Aug. 27. Their engagement has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Sutter of Malverne, L.I., and Washington, Conn. Mr. Starke is a son of Ann Penfield Starke and Richard P. Starke, both of East Aurora, N.Y.

title: THE NOT-QUITE-AN-ISLE OF PURBECK
description: The Isle of Purbeck is the tail end of Dorset, a little world lapped by water: to the north by the expanses of Poole Harbour and the river Frome, to the east by the approaches to the Solent between the mainland and the Isle of Wight, to the south by the English Channel and to the west by a stream that you could, if chased by a bull, jump across, which doesn't end in the sea.

title: Reagan, in Holiday Message, Assails Hecklers of John Paul
description: President Reagan, in his regular weekly radio speech, delivered an Easter and Passover holiday message of ''hope and peace'' that was mixed with criticism of ''godless tyranny'' in Poland and ''Communist-inspired revolution'' in Central America.

title: FRON WALTZES TO TANGOS
description: The music of Johann Strauss 2d, his brothers Eduard and Josef, and their illustrious father has long been one of the mainstays of the light classical repertory, not to mention the recording indusrty. while its intoxicating potency as dance music may have faded-along with notions that a man looked best in the uniform of a Hussar officer-the music has lost none of its charm or popularity with concert audiences. It even seems to be enjoying, 100 years later, an upwards critical re-evaluation.

title: PITCHING STILL UNCERTAIN
description: YANKEE pitchers have pitched seven shutouts this spring. One was a n o-hitter. Yankee pitchers pitched three consecutive shutouts, four i n five games and five in a seven-game span. Included in that period w as a stretch in which they allowed only one run in 49 innings.

title: WESTCHESTER AIDE BACKS ROADBLOCK
description: Westchester County's top police official has told members of the Board of Legislators that every precaution was taken to assure the safety of motorists in last weekend's roadblock search for drunken drivers.

title: LINCOLN WEST SPONSOR IS CONFIDENT DESPITE SETBACK
description: A SETBACK in court and the death of the project director has delayed t he huge Lincoln West housing development planned for Manhattan's W est Side. But both the developer and city officials who have worked f or nearly three years on the billion-dollar project expressed c onfidence that it would go forward.

title: THE TAX BENEFITS OF OWNING YOUR HOME
description: THE tax advantages of home ownership are among Washington's many s acred cows: While there is periodic talk of radically revising the n ation's tax laws in this area, nothing much ever seems to come of i t. Indeed, the host of tax incentives that Congress has provided forh omeowners reflect its continued belief that Americans should be e ncouraged to invest in their own homes.

title: A CHINA WALL REMARK NIXON COULDN'T MAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: Chrysler Recalling Autos
description: The Chrysler Corporation said Thursday it was recalling 163,000 small automobiles made by Mitsubishi of Japan for replacement of steel straps that cause rust, resulting in the partial separation of the gas tank from the car. The autos involved are the 1976 Plymouth Arrow and all 1977 and some 1978 Dodge Colts and Arrows. No accidents or injuries have been reported.

title: LOAN FORMS AND DRAFT FORMS DON'T MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE
description: The Los Angeles Ballet, directed by John Clifford, has been touring on the outskirts of Manhattan occasionally for the last two years, so Tuesday's opening by the California company at the Joyce Theater is not exactly a New York debut.

title: Data BankData Bank  April 3, 1983

ANTIQUES;
OF CACHEPOTS AND POSIES
description: IN spite of wind and cold rain storms, the courageous crocus, the snowdrop and the old-fashioned double daffodil have made their element-defying appearances in most Connecticut gardens.

title: Andrea Leinwand to Marry
description: The engagement of Andrea Terri Leinwand to Jeffrey Jay Kaminsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Kaminsky of East Rockaway, L.I., has been made known by Mr. and Mrs A. David Leinwand of White Plains, parents of the future bride. An October wedding is planned. Miss Leinwand and her fiance graduated from the University of Rhode Island. She received her master's degree from Teachers College of Columbia University and is teaching at the Stephen Gaynor School in New York. Mr. Kaminsky is a broker with the Mabon-Nugent Company Inc.

title: A WAY TO CURB SCHOOL VIOLENNCE
description: NEWSPAPER articles about student assaults on high school teachers give the impression that teaching is a high-risk occupation. Yet college professors seem relatively safe.

title: June Wedding Set By Miss Slobogin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Slobogin of Rockport, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathy Slobogin, to Barry N. Spodak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Spodak of Manhasset, L.I.

title: FLORAL DISPLAYS FOR THE CUSTOM CLIENT
description: They have all had an enduring and lifelong attraction to flowers, and they have all been able to translate that passion into a profession. They are the growing group of florists who work mostly by appointment and who favor personal, even intimate communication between the florist and his client.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings 5.50 At savings institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds 9.38 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index 6-Month Savings Certificates 9.00 Maximum rate at savings institutions Money Market Funds 7.80 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Average Bank Money Market Accounts 8.31 Bank Rate Monitor national average Home Mortgage 13.59 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 16.50 Continental Illinois, Chicago 16.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 19.00

title: PERFORMING ARTS GROWING IN STATE AT A HIGH COST
description: IN RECENT years, New Jersey has changed from a cultural wasteland squeezed between New York City and Philadelphia to a state with a strong and growing artistic identity of its own. However, that change carries a huge price tag.

title: Future Events; Performances, Parties
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. On Your Toes April 5 - Highlight at opening night of the Paul Taylor Dance Company's season at City Center will be guest appearances by Suzanne Farrell and Peter Martins in ''Musette,'' a new on-point work created specially for them by Mr. Taylor. The duo will star also at postcurtain supper at O'Neal's/43d. Tickets for black-tie evening to benefit the company, $150, from 966-6959. Bus transportation from theater to restaurant is included.

title: U.S. VOICES REGRET; Excerpts from news session, page 10.
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko today described as ''unacceptable'' President Reagan's proposal of an interim agreement limiting Soviet and American medium-range missiles. He said there was ''no chance'' that it could be used as the basis for an agreement at the arms reduction talks in Geneva.

title: 10TH STATE PRESERVATION CONFERENCE HERE
description: Athree-day conference on historic preservation will be held from April 15 through 17, in the county, with Friday and Saturday meetings at the Tarrytown Hilton, a Saturday evening reception at Lyndhurst and an daylong bus tour of the county's landmark mansions on Sunday April 17.

title: POVERTY
description: Rural life in Cambodia, as seen in a visit to ricegrowing Takeo Province south of Pnom Penh, seems better than at any time since 1975, when the Communist regime of Pol Pot came to power.

title: BIRTH RATE CALLED KEY TO HOPE IN THIRD WORLD
description: If the rate of economic growth throughout the world continues to decline, particularly among less-developed countries, only those that quickly reduce birth rates will have enough food and energy, according to a report issued this week by a privately financed research organization.

title: 'Moment of Silence' In School Defended
description: Francis X. Hayes, in his comments on the Minute of Silence law (Feb. 27), was ''struck by the analogies from the pornography law.'' I was ''struck'' by his misquoting the First Amendment, saying that ''Congress shall make no law respecting the establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof.'' The correct wording is ''... an establishment of religion ... ''

title: Suffolk Home Rule And the Duke
description: In regard to a statement in the article ''Suffolk Celebrating a Banner Year - Its 300th'' (March 6) that it was ''the activism of colonists that forced the Duke of York in 1683 to grant his subjects some semblance of home rule through a Charter of Libertyes and Privileges'': Although this so-called charter set a precedent for representative assembly in New York, the Duke did not grant the charter or permit home rule.

title: Melissa A. Nathan Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Nathan of Floral Park, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melissa Amy Nathan, to Dr. Richard S. Krugman, son of Dr. Mitchel A. Krugman of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Jamaica, Queens, and Muriel F. Krugman of Florial Park. A June wedding is planned.

title: Vineyard Theater Gives 'Betly,' Donizetti Opera
description: The Opera Shop of the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street, off Second Avenue, will present ''Betly,'' a two-act comic opera by Donizetti, until April 17. It is the first fully staged New York production since 1861.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, APRIL 3, 1983
description: International

title: A TIRED OPERETTA, DESPITE SWORDPLAY
description: THERE is splendor to spare and energy to burn in ''The Three Musketeers'' at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, but there is no cohesive musical in sight - only in sound, thanks to Larry Wilcox's upbeat orchestrations. Counting the blessings of the season's final production, there are also choreography, costumes and conducting -but not a score - to sing about.

title: WHEN ARTISTS START THEIR OWN GALLERIES
description: Today, we tend to view the art gallery and the system of exhibiting and selling art it implies as an inevitable fact of artistic life. But the commercial art gallery in the form we know it is only a little more than a hundred years old. When public exhibitions first started, most new art was shown in large exhibiting societies run by artists. These were annual or biannual mixed shows in which freely invented, uncommissioned art was seen in unpremeditated profusion.

title: Jennifer Clayson Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Davis Barr Clayson of Weston, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Church Clayson, to Kent Morrison Rapp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudyard Kent Rapp of St. Louis A Junee wedding is planned.

title: LITTLE LEAGUE IS NOT WHAT IT USED TO BE
description: BASEBALL has long captured the fancy of many a mother's child, but Little League, alas, isn't what it used to be. Although fly balls are being shagged, pounds of gum are being chewed and wood (or aluminum) is again meeting horsehide in this fourth season of the decade, many child and adolescent leagues throughout the Garden State are in a pickle. The problem is that they are running out of players.

title:
DINING OUT;
MUCH MORE THAN NORTHERN ITALIAN
description: A TRANSFORMATION has taken place on a corner in Old Pleasantville. What was for years a sleazy spot specializing in cocktails or beer nuts metamorphosed two months ago into a tastefully decorated restaurant with a serious kitchen that serves well-cooked and exceptionally well-chosen fresh food.

title: EARTH MOVERS CARVING FREE-TRADE ZONE
description: AFTER years of delays and frustrating setbacks, construction will b egin soon on the first warehouse for the New Jersey Foreign Trade Z one in Mount Olive Township.

title: McGuffey Revival
description: The McGuffey Readers, first used in elementary schools in 1836, went back into use in the public schools of Bristol, Va., in 1982, and by last January officials there reported that initial wariness by teachers had evaporated.

title: IT SEEMS AN OPENING PRIMER IS STILL NEEDED
description: One would think that by now correct play in the opening would be known to some point well beyond the fourth move, but this is just not the case.

title: SUICIDES BY THE YOUNG TO INCREASE
description: SUICIDES among children are on the rise, experts say, and the reality may be even worse than statistics indicate because many deaths reported as accidental could be suicides.

title: Errant Shot Hits Handyman
description: The handyman of a Bronx apartment building was critically wounded in the head at about 3:25 P.M. yesterday while sweeping the walk in front of his building, at 1045 Woodycrest Avenue, just north of Yankee Stadium, when a gunman involved in a nearby dispute missed his intended victim, the police said. The gunman also shot his intended victim, William C. Black, 29 years old, in the thigh, a police spokesman said. The handyman, tentatively identified as Renriquez Garcia, 30, was listed in extremely critical condition at Lincoln Hospital, pending emergency surgery.

title: Mrs. King's Team in Final
description: Billie Jean King and Sharon Walsh beat Leslie Allen and Mima Jausovec of Yugoslavia, 6-7, 7-5, 6-4, today and moved into the final of the $150,000 Bridgestone women's doubles tournament.

title: JAZZ: SATHIMA BEA BENJAMIN
description: At the Jazz Forum Thursday, the singer Sathima Bea Benjamin gave a lesson in the difference between melancholy and bathos. Miss Benjamin, who appears too rarely in New York, is a South African singer who has worked with Duke Ellington.

title: A BILL TO HURT CONSUMERS
description: If Senator Robert Kasten, Republican of Wisconsin, wins, victims of faulty products will lose. Heavily. More than 300,000 Americans are permanently disabled each year as a result of product-related injuries, and more than 80,000 die. Among the victims are young women who have vaginal cancer because their mothers were given the drug diethylstilbestrol (DES) during pregnancy, middle-aged men who have lung cancer because they worked with asbestos for years, and people of all ages with severe burns resulting from exploding auto gas tanks. While compensation can't begin to make up for such tragedies, victims of defective products can at least recover monetary damages from those who made the faulty product and profited from it.

title: OUTLOOK FOR ROSLYN RENEWAL
description: FOR more than a decade the urban renewal area near the Roslyn Long Island Rail Road station has been supervised by Hector Gayle, director of the North Hempstead Town Community Development Agency. That agency distributes Federal funds in accordance with guidelines set by the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: The Greening of The Bundestag
description: Accompanied by bongo drums and a good-natured claque of pacifist, feminist and environmentalist supporters, the first Greens elected to West Germany's national legislature paraded to the Bundestag last week. The 27 members had little hope of parliamentary victories in the 498-seat house.

title: MARRIED TO ENGLAND
description: THE FIRST ELIZABETH By Carolly Erickson. Illustrated. 447 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: THERAPEUTIC RUDENESS
description: JACQUES LACAN The Death of an Intellectual Hero. By Stuart Schneiderman. 182 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $14.95.

title: FISHERMEN SPIN SOME TALL TALES
description: ''I know the best fishing spot in the Catskills,'' Dennis Greenwald said. Naturally, everybody stopped eating, drinking and talking. Not just at our table but at a few tables around us. It was like the television commercial, in which everybody freezes at the mention of the investment broker with the magic touch.

title:
GARDENING;
SELECTING PLANTS FOR THE GARDEN
description: WITH the spring planting season at hand, home gardeners will be flocking to the garden centers to take advantage of special plant sales. Certainly, there is nothing wrong with that. It is only natural to want to get the best price possible. A bargain is no bargain, however, if the plants purchased are not well-suited to the planting site and purpose for which they are intended. Plant characteristics and site requirements should be considered before a purchase.

title: SOME BRIGHT NEW TALENT COMMANDS ATTENTION
description: If part of the fascination of Martin Scorsese's fine, dark comedy ''The King of Comedy'' is the possibility that, at almost any minute, it might blow up in one's face, like a Johnny Carson doll with a time-bomb inside it, then one of the people responsible for this curious mixture of danger and lunacy certainly must be Sandra Bernhard, one of a number of new performers who are giving this season a certain amount of class.

title: DANCE: MARIA CHENG TALKS BETWEEN STEPS
description: In addition to presenting dances in the Bessie Schonberg Theater, Maria Cheng acquainted the audience with her process of making dances.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Tidal Wave of I.R.A.'s

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THERE is nothing more fleeting than time, nothing more inaccessible than the past, nothing more unrecognizable than faces you have not seen for decades. Much of my life has been spent in coming across people I dimly recall who shower me with effusive salutations and leave me mumbling, with limping enthusiasm, ''Well, I'll be jiggered if it isn't ... Er.''

title: Article on Ireland Called 'Simplistic'
description: Dr. James V. Burke's Opinion Page article about Ireland (March 13) once again raises the simplistic solution ''Brits Out.''

title: STRIKERS APPROVE JERSEY RAIL PACT AMID UNCERTAINTY
description: Striking trainmen and conductors ratified a new contract with N.J. Transit today. But a threat by a union faction to walk out at 12:01 Monday morning left it uncertain that the commuter trains would run Monday.

title: IN POP, A 1960's REVIVAL HAS ALREADY BEGUN
description: Friday and Saturday nights on Los Angeles's Sunset Boulevard, the crowds waiting in line outside the Roxy and other rock clubs have a new but eerily familiar look. Leather jackets and the other accouterments of punk fashion are still in evidence, along with the foppish elegance of the new romantics. But more and more young rock fans are sporting shirts and blouses in riotous paisley patterns, Nehru-style jackets or suits with collar-less jackets and pegged pants - fashions that were the rage in the summer of 1967, the summer of love. Similar fashions are on display outside lower Manhattan rock clubs when psychedelic-revival bands like New Jersey's Trypes or the Chesterfield Kings from upstate New York are performing. The young men who play in these bands are sporting carefully layered shag haircuts, striped bell-bottom jeans, multi-colored shirts and scarves, and they can often be seen between sets talking to young women in mini-skirts and go-go boots.

title: Formula One Races Costly
description: While a group of New Yorkers is preparing to hold a world championship Grand Prix race in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, the organizers of other North American Formula One races are finding themselves priced out of the market for dates on the calendar for the international auto racing series.

title: Waivers Sought on LeFlore
description: Ron LeFlore, the Chicago White Sox outfielder, may become a free agent again, but this time it will not be on his terms. The White Sox today requested waivers on LeFlore for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release.

title:
ANTIQUES;
OF CACHEPOTS AND POSIES
description: IN spite of wind and cold rain storms, the courageous crocus, the snowdrop and the old-fashioned double daffodil have made their element-defying appearances in most Connecticut gardens.

title: THE LEGACY OF WASHINGTON IRVING
description: SHOULD the old schoolmaster re-emerge from Sleepy Hollow, he would be recognized immediately, ''tall, but exceedingly lank, with narrow shoulders, long arms and legs, hands that dangled a mile out of his sleeves, feet that might have served for shovels and his whole frame most loosely hung together.''

title: A Correction
description: Two leading finishers in the foil division at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's fencing championships were incorrectly ranked in some copies of the sports section last Sunday. Demetrios Valsamis of New York University finished first, and Paul Schmidt of Princeton University was second.

title: Krickstein, Miss Phelps Easter Bowl Winners
description: Aaron Krickstein of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Terry Phelps of Larchmont, N.Y., won their second Olympus Easter Bowl junior tennis championships today with victories in the 18-years-and-under finals.

title: SOVIET POLITICS AND THE MILITARY
description: John Burns's article is full of relevant facts and throws much light upon the character of the man. But what especially holds my attention is the painting of Yuri Andropov on the cover, by Mark Hess.

title: Carlyle
description: To the Editor: Travelers anticipating a visit to 24 Cheyne Walk, London -home of Thomas and Jane Welsh Carlyle and ''The House Where Jenny Was Kissed'' (Travel, Feb. 20) - can turn to the works of Virginia Woolf for a fascinating and irreverent glimpse of the meaning Cheyne Walk held for its two formidable Victorian inhabitants. In ''Great Men's Houses,'' one of six essays on the London scene recently reissued by The Hogarth Press (London, 1982), Virginia Woolf takes the reader on a tour of Cheyne Walk to draw some remarkably contemporary conclusions.

title: GOVERNMENT AND INDUSTRY HAND IN HAND
description: To the Editor:

title: DNA Plant
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Nancy Lopez, the golfer who married Ray Knight, the Houston Astro third baseman, last Oct. 25, said they were expecting a child in November. Miss Lopez plans to stop playing on the pro tour in July, then return next year. ... Jeff Ruland, who averaged 24 points and 12 rebounds starting all 17 games for the Washington Bullets last month, was named N.B.A. player of the month for March.

title: CALCULATING THE BOTTOM LINE OF 'PRIVATIZATION'
description: Although the Administration appeared to backpedal last week on its announced intention to sell the four weather satellites and the land-mapping satellite, Landsat, to a private corporation, the proposal is only the latest, if one of the more dramatic, example of the pursuit of President Reagan's goal of a smaller government.

title: FITZGERALD FRENCHIFIED
description: F.SCOTT FITZGERALD A Biography. By Andre Le Vot. Translated by William Byron. 393 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $19.95.

title: Callers Can Hear Shuttle Talk
description: A special phone number is again being provided for the public to hear conversations between the astronauts on the space shuttle Challenger and ground controllers here. Calls from the United States to 900-410-6272 will cost 50 cents for the first minute and 35 cents for each additional minute. The number will be in effect from 6 A.M. Monday throughout the five-day mission.

title: THE TURN OF THE SCREW
description: The position of dissidents in the Soviet Union, already grim, has grown even worse in recent months. Political prisoners about to finish their sentences have been re-sentenced to further terms. There have been new brutalities in labor camps. And those few in the society still trying to work for human rights, peace and the right to emigrate have come under increasing pressure.

title: Cup Yachts Feel Budget Pinch
description: Winter training camps from Italy to Australia are breaking up as sailors and their yachts head for Newport R.I., for the 25th defense of the America's Cup this summer.

title: CELESTIAL SEASONINGS PINS ITS HOPES ON MORE HERBAL TEA
description: ON most weekdays, Morris J. Siegel peddles his 18 speed, $500 bicycle the five miles from his home to the Celestial Seasonings herbal tea factory, listening as he rides to lectures by Peter Drucker or Norman Vincent Peale on a Sony Walkman headset.

title: Dr. Marion Peters Marries Dr. Eric Brown, a Scientist
description: Dr. Marion Peters and Dr. Eric Brown, research scientists at the Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., were married yesterday at their home in Bethesda. The Rev. Gerald O'Collins, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Susan C. Lehing Affianced To Douglas Arthur Brown
description: The engagement of Susan Carol Lehing to Douglas Arthur Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Brown of Wyckoff, N.J., has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Lehing of Wyckoff and Sun City, Ariz., parents of the future bride.

title: PATAGONIANS CAN'T FORGET FALKLAND WAR
description: Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands one year ago today and surrendered 11 weeks later, but for people in this small seaport in Patagonia, war is still a part of their lives.

title: STALLED
description: For the third time in less than a year, the Legislature last week refused to renew New York City's principal tax incentive program for developers who renovate rundown apartment buildings. It wasn't because lawmakers questioned the tax breaks, but rather because they couldn't agree on who should get them and for what.

title: PIEDMONT AIR SKIRTS THE FARE WARS BY FLYING TO OUT-OF-THE-WAY PLACES
description: IN the midst of the recession, hard-hit Dayton, Ohio, spent $15 million for airport facilities to lure a new airline to town. It also offered an unusual concession. If things didn't work out, the carrier could scrap the 10-year lease. That would leave the city to find a new tenant - no small task at a time when major airlines are shunning many medium-sized cities.

title: Assigning a Lease
description: Question: I have lived in a rent-stabilized apartment for 25 years. I would like to know how I might insure that my niece, who has never lived with me eventually can obtain rights to live here? ... D.M.W., Manhattan. Answer: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled recently that tenants had the right to assign their leases and that the owner could not unreasonably withhold consent. While the case will be appealed, according to Gary M. Rosenberg, lawyer for the landlord in the case, you have the right to assign your lease to your niece now. In his opinion, however, you cannot make an assignment effective upon your death.

title: YOUTH PROJECT'S END CRITICIZED
description: A CORPORATE giant that last year endowed teen-agers in this Passaic County community with a two-year, $75,000 grant for an innovative project and youth center has now discontinued the project and closed the center.

title: Work and Play In the Outdoors
description: Now that spring is here, the appeal of the great outdoors waxes daily. For vacationers eager to know more of nature or to labor amid its glories, there are opportunities of more than ordinary interest.

title:
CAMERA;
HOW TO PHOTOGRAPH THE GREAT OUTDOORS
description: Mountains, wilderness areas and rural settings provide a conucopia of photographic opportunity for photographers who also enjoy backpacking, hiking and camping. But to get effective pictures that truly capture their outdoor experiences in these areas, the photographer must carefully plan what equipment and films will be taken along, and he or she must be technically prepared for the wide range of wilderness shooting situations one can expect to encounter.

title: Jayne F. Milne Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James W. Milne of Stony Creek, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Jayne Fellows Milne, to Kevin J. Swanson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Swanson of Fairmont, Minn.

title: STING BEATS ARROWS, 7-3
description: The Chicago Sting beat the New York Arrows, 7-3, in a Major Indoor Soccer League game before a crowd of 14,209 at Chicago Stadium tonight.

title: Uneven and Unfair
description: To the Business Editor:

title: SEVILLE SPICES ITS HOLY WEEK WITH REVELRY
description: Throughout southern Spain the agony of Christ's ascension to the cross is celebrated with fervor - almost with gusto - and nowhere more so than here in Seville.

title: Award to Widow Is Upheld
description: A trial judge has upheld an $873,697 jury award to a Ware widow who said the police failed to detain a drunken driver minutes before he was involved in an accident that killed him and her husband and daughter. Judge Raymond Cross rejected motions Friday by attorneys for the Town of Ware to dismiss the verdict or reduce the award granted to Debbie Irwin on Feb. 12. The lawyers said the town, which lacks liability insurance to cover the award, would probably appeal.

title: NEW AND STYLISH IN WESTPORT
description: ''WHERE do I park my horse?'' a friend asked, when we invited him to dine with us at Polo's, Westport's newest Post Road restaurant. Actually, the only horses at Polo's are on the walls in framed prints. The name hardly telegraphs the light, pleasingly sophisticated interior of what was once a fast-food restaurant. Cavernous space has been intelligently broken up into a number of softly lighted sections.

title: Agnes de Mille Tribute Is Planned for May 16
description: Agnes de Mille will be honored on May 16 at a benefit in the Shubert Theater sponsored by the Friends of the Theater Collection of the Museum of the City of New York. The program will feature performances of several of Miss de Mille's best-known works for both ballet and Broadway musicals, as well as dances by other leading choreographers.

title: Nafplion
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa M. Wren Is Affianced
description: Mrs. Thayer Pereira Draper of Wilton, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Lisa Morgan Wren, to Jonathan Blair Eckman, son of Doris Josephson Eckman of Westport, Conn., and Richard B. Eckman of New York. The wedding is planned for August. The future bride is a daughter also of the late Leo Paul Wren.

title: GRACEFUL SIMPLICITY
description: While there is little mystery to keeping cool in the approaching warm months of summer - one wears garments made of thinner fabrics, and fewer of them - staying comfortable and elegant at the same time often can be somewhat of a consternation.

title: ELISABETH SCHWARZKOPF AND THE NAZI PARTY
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: STYX ON TOUR
description: Styx usually plays in arenas, but Thursday the quintet began a four-night stand at the 2,800-seat City Center. The shows were part of a much-ballyhooed tour based on Styx's new album, ''Kilroy Was Here.''

title: Indians Lose Out On Water Rights
description: All over the Southwest, water rights are as bitterly contested today as they were a hundred years ago, though usually less violently. Last week came the latest chapter in the protracted legal fight over access to the Colorado River. Although a special master had concluded that five Indian tribes had through bureaucratic oversight been denied a fair share of water almost two decades ago, the Supreme Court ruled 5 to 3 that the allotments needn't be increased.

title: FORTRESS ISLAND OF THE MEDITERRANEAN
description: Malta has paid the price of being situated at a crossroads of history and civilization. The three-island archipelago at the center of the Mediterranean has been conquered and reconquered by every expansionist power that ever shaped history in this cradle of civilization, from the Phoenicians to the British, with Romans, Arabs, Swabians, Normans, various Italians and Sicilians and the French in between. It has suffered in wars religious and secular, never more than under some of the most concentrated bombing of World War II.

title: Eva Nutt, Editor, To Wed Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Tysen Nutt of Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eva Margaret Nutt, to Robert Edwin Nies, son of William Arthur Nies of Little Falls, N.J., and Mrs. Joseph Simmons of Southwest Harbor, Me. The wedding will take place late next month.

title: Wedding Set By Miss Blue For Summer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Fownes Blue of Garrison, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gary Bolton Blue, to Henry Barritt Peterson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Peterson of Hinsdale, Ill.

title: ONE STORY, 19 ACRES
description: When the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company closed its Pottstown, Pa., manufacturing plant in 1980 - a casualty of the switch from bias-ply to radial tires - the need for its mammoth distribution warehouse in Cranberry, N.J., was suddenly diminished, according to a company spokesman. Now, however, the single-story warehouse, whose roof covers almost 19 acres of space, or 8l2,000 square feet, has a new future as a multitenant building.

title: BACH'S ORGAN MUSIC: A LONG PROJECT REACHES COMPLETION
description: Along with the endless individual disks that flood the market, the record industry periodically addresses itself to longer-range projects. Unobtrusively, every few months, a record or an album will emerge as the latest installment in the Telefunken Bach cantata series, or the L'Oiseau-Lyre Dowland series, or the same label's Mozart symphony project (now nearing completion). And yet there is a tendency to let some of these marathons, especially those of repertory already recorded by others, come to their conclusions unnoticed.

title: SELF-IMPROVEMENT AS A RELIGION IS DANGEROUS
description: AMONG the cultural high priests who seem to thrive in our time are those who hustle the self-improvement message. You are No. 1; you can pull your own strings; you can be happy all day all your life.

title: BEYOND THE BASIC ARTICHOKE
description: A FRIEND wanted to know how to tell if an artichoke is ripe. It seemed like a peculiar question because when buying artichokes one looks for signs of freshness, an absence of browning or drying on the leaves, rather than conditions of ripeness.

title: THE ANALYST AS OUTSIDER
description: FURY ON EARTH A Biography of Wilhelm Reich. By Myron Sharaf. Illustrated. 550 pp. New York: Marek/St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

title: THE ANGUISH OF BEING NUMBER THREE
description: THE New York cabbie looked quizzical when Judd Hirsch, star of the ABC show ''Taxi,'' got in and said that he was going to NBC. ''Oh, t hat's too bad,'' the driver remarked. ''They got nothing. I never w atch them.''

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Rare View of the Pope

title: BOUNTY HUNTERS COLLECT CRITICS AS WELL AS TAXES
description: The French monarchy gave the practice the rustic rubric of ''tax farming.'' In each corner of the country, the king gave one subject the right to collect the crown's taxes. For bringing in the sheaves, the appointee kept a share of the harvest.

title: Pope Lights Candle In Easter Ceremony
description: Pope John Paul II lit a candle in a darkened St. Peter's Basilica tonight, symbolizing the Resurrection of Christ.

title: 24 Food Establishments Cited For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 24 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named three that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and three that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: Erins Isle Wins
description: Erins Isle went ahead midway through the stretch to win the $210,900 San Luis Rey Stakes by three-quarters of a length today at Santa Anita.

title: BUSY LOVE LETTERS
description: H.H.ASQUITH: LETTERS TO VENETIA STANLEY Edited by Michael and Eleanor Brock. Illustrated. 676 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $35.

title: Rites of Spring
description: Sap rises, buds unfurl, evenings lighten, the cycle of seasons begins anew. At egg-rolls and altars, Easter rites celebrate the renewability of life. Religious themes of resurrection or deliverance, marked on dates linked to the coming of spring, give Easter and Passover their special richness.

title: ART
description: For his first New York exhibition, which can be seen through April 20 at the Robert Elkon Gallery, 1063 Madison Avenue at 80th Street, the English sculptor Garth Evans has chosen to show works that look like artless twists of paper.

title: U.S. REPORT SAID TO ACCUSE SOVIET ON ARMS TREATY
description: An interagency task force is close to sending President Reagan a report that finds the Soviet Union guilty of violating the 1979 strategic arms limitation treaty with recent missile tests, White House officials said Friday.

title: SONG CYCLE: 'ODYSSEUS'
description: The composer and bass-baritone Thomas Beveridge fashioned the text of his song cycle ''Odysseus'' not from Homer, but rather from Nikos Kazantzakis's ''Odyssey, a Modern Sequel,'' in the English translation by Kimon Friar. Monday night in Symphony Space, with Martin Katz at the piano, Mr. Beveridge gave ''Odysseus'' its New York premiere performance.

title: MY MOTHER ELENI
description: This article is adapted from his book ''Eleni,'' to be published by Random House later this month. On the road to vengeance ... one discovers life. - Andre Malraux, ''Man's Fate.'' On Aug. 28, 1948, at about 12:30 P.M. on a hot, windless day, a group of women with firewood on their backs were descending a steep path above the Greek vil-lage of Lia, a cluster of gray stone houses on a mountainside just below the Albanian border. As the women came into view of the village below them, they encountered a grim procession.

title: Hamilton Breaks Record
description: Alexander Hamilton of Brooklyn posted a meet record in the two-mile relay and narrowly missed another mark in the sprint medley today at the Kearny-Adidas Scholastic Relays on the high school track here.

title: Theodore Washburne, Laura Roberts to Wed
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Donald V. Roberts of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Jane Roberts, to Theodore P. Washburne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brenton P. Washburne of Buena Park, Calif. A December wedding is planned.

title: Israel: Voices of Moral Anguish
description: David K. Shipler's reasoned article, ''Israel: Voices of Moral Anguish'' (Feb. 27), has clearly issued a universal challenge: How can a nation-state be moral in an immoral world? Each act brings on a counter act whenever and wherever ideas, power, interests and economics clash. Please continue with this theme, making this inquiry into all nation-states. Are they asking the same agonizing questions? JOYCE MOLLOV, Jamaica, N.Y.

title: OFFICE BUILDING IS SET FOR 55TH ST. AFTER AN ACCORD WITH DEVELOPER
description: After more than a year of conflict between community leaders and a real- estate developer, construction is set to begin next month on a 13-story office building on West 55th Street near Fifth Avenue.

title: IN THE PIT, LOBOGATE LIVES
description: FROM the outside, it's a sprawling dirt brown adobe hut. But inside, the street level is 45 rows above a basketball court as shiny as Indian jewelry. This is The Pit, the University of New Mexico's arena where the Final Four yesterday was reduced to tomorrow night's Title-Game Two, the 17,121-seat arena that inspired one of college basketball's most notorious scandals, the arena where the coach who dealt in forged transcripts and phony credits, Norm Ellenberger, is still hailed by many Lobo rooters as a mod version of Albuquerque's original conqueror, the Spanish explorer Coronado.

title: NEW SPACE SHUTTLE IS READY TO START A FIVE-DAY MISSION
description: After a multitude of woes with engine leaks and windblown dust contamination, the nation's newest space shuttle, the Challenger, is reported ready for its inaugural launching Monday, more than two months late but presumably in time that commitments for five shuttle missions in 1983 can be met.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE taxman cometh. And for those who still haven't figured out just how big their bite will be, help is at hand at libraries throughout the Island. Provided by volunteers trained by the Internal Revenue Service and by specially tutored accounting students from such local universities as Hofstra and Adelphi, the counseling is available primarily to those over the age of 60, but it is extended to all other taxpayers who need help.

title: Deborah R. Burck Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Burck of Framingham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Rachel Burck, to Robert Alan Amchin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Amchin of Farmingdale, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: DINA MERRILL: A STAR ON HER TOES
description: WITH her musical comedy debut in the spanking new Broadway revival of the 1936 Rodgers and Hart musical ''On Your Toes,'' the acting career of Dina Merrill has taken a new upward spin and a serious turn.

title: PRYOR STOPS KIM IN 3D ROUND
description: The fight that almost did not take place was finally stopped after 37 seconds of the third round today, much too late to save Sang Hyun Kim from taking a ferocious beating from Aaron Pryor.

title: SOHO 'LUXURY'
description: To the Editor:

title: CANCER UNIT SEEKS CONTINUITY OF CARE
description: ''WE see patients at their cure, or we see them at their death,'' Mary Spengler said. ''There is continuity of treatment and care; out of this continuity patients get to know each other, nurses get to know patients; doctors, nurses, social workers get to work as a team. The whole thing blends, and so far it has worked very well.''

title: AN END TO 'HOUSE SENSE' COURSE?
description: THE privately financed House Sense Program, which now teaches 2 5,000 public-school students respect for New York City's housing s tock and how to cope with its problems, is facing termination b ecause of a shortage of funds.

title: A FLOOD OF CONCERTS WILL FOLLOW EASTER
description: BECAUSE it is Easter, most of today's musical activity is taking place at church services. But by next weekend the concert floodgates will again be open, with many intriguing and diversified events on the calendar.

title: EQUITABLE AGREEMENTS IN DIVORCE
description: In the article ''Coping With Divorce in Later Life,'' Hugh Wilson suggests that women come together as a group and lobby politically for their interests.

title: RAIL STRIKE STIRS DEBATE ON SUBSIDIES
description: AS Metro-North passengers continued to ride buses and subways last week, peripheral strains arising from the rail strike began to show. A rift developed among County Legislators over a proposal, drafted when union and rail negotiators were not talking, to withhold statemandated county payments to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority until service resumed.

title: MAJOR DAMAGE FEARED IN PERSIAN GULF OIL SPILL
description: The largest oil spill ever to hit the Persian Gulf now threatens major economic and ecological damage to eight gulf nations, Government and industry officials said yesterday.

title: CONCERT: DIONNE WARWICK
description: NOW in her early 40's, Dionne Warwick is a pop-soul singer with a history that's almost as interesting as her husky pop-gospel alto. Like Lena Horne and other pop entertainers with careers that span more than one era, she wisely makes much of that history in her concert appearances.

title: GENERALS WIN FIRST AS WALKER GAINS 177
description: The New Jersey Generals won their first game of the season tonight, defeating the Arizona Wranglers, 35-21, as Herschel Walker gained more than 100 yards rushing for the first time. Walker scored three touchdowns in the second half, and his rushing total was 177 yards on 33 carries.

title: British Parties Back Shipbuilders Chief
description: Graham Day, hired by the British Government to steer the nation's shipbuilding industry into profitability, will be a rarity among the leaders of the country's state-owned companies when he takes over as chairman and chief executive on Sept. 1.

title: WILANDER SWEEPS PURCELL IN FINAL
description: Mats Wilander scored a 6-1, 6-2, 6-3 victory over Mel Purcell today and captured the $60,000 first prize at the Monte Carlo Open tennis tournament.

title: Catholics Attend Mass At Site of Jesus' Tomb
description: Hundreds of Catholics attended Easter mass today at the spot revered as the tomb of Jesus.

title: N.C.A.A. FINAL MATCHES BALL-CONTROL AGAINST POWER
description: The sensation stopped being scary a long time ago. When Clyde Drexler was a 6-foot-1-inch, 14-year-old who had not yet known the feeling of reaching the rim of a basketball hoop, as he molded his game in a playground behind Albert Thomas Junior High in the south side of Houston, he went into the air with two taller players in front of him. ''They both jumped,'' Drexler said, ''and it scared me.''

title: DRAMA IN AFRICA IS USED TO EDUCATE AUDIENCES
description: Lounging under parasols, breast-feeding their babies, several hundred women laugh and shout at the actors in the lively tradition of African theater. When the play ends, it is the cast's turn to shout questions at the audience.

title: RUSTING SHIP CARRIES HOPE FOR A SEAWAY
description: A rusty tramp steamer named the Righteous sailed toward the Great Lakes today after clearing the Eisenhower Lock here, the first ship to go through the St. Lawrence Seaway in 1983, the seaway's 25th year.

title: WEST EUROPE SAYS SOVIET ARMS MOVE IS NOT LAST WORD
description: Western European governments signaled to Washington this weekend their view that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's rejection of its interim proposal limiting medium-range missiles was not likely to be the Soviet leadership's last word.

title: U.S.C. WOMEN TOP LA. TECH FOR TITLE
description: The Southern California women's basketball team won the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship today in a game it seemed to have given away.

title: A GRAVEYARD BIRTHDAY PARTY FOR WASHINGTON IRVING
description: They heard that Washington Irving bought the most expensive piano made in his day - a $500 model that had a rosewood veneer. They heard that Irving, the creator of Ichabod Crane and Rip Van Winkle, passed the collection plate for many years in the church just down the road from here.

title: AMID GUANTANAMO WAR GAMES, THE PEACEFUL LIFE
description: The insistent clamor of the great bell brought the marines running from bunks, routine assignments and drill. They grabbed their weapons and ammunition and rolled in trucks to positions defending this American toehold in a Communist state.

title: Article 077393 -- No Title
description: At least 900 pounds of gold chains, valued at $6 million, were reported stolen from a Fifth Avenue wholesale jewelry company in what the police said yesterday was one of the largest thefts ever of jewelry in New York City.

title: WATER-SHY UTAH FINDS TOO MUCH IS NO ASSET
description: The toll booth at the entrance to the state park at Utah Lake near Provo now stands 20 feet offshore, and wind-driven waves break over the tops of picnic tables.

title: N.C.A.A. FINAL MATCHES BALL-CONTROL AGAINST POWER
description: Sidney Lowe and Dereck Whittenburg, North Carolina State's superb guards, ''look like they should be playing in a bar league in New York,'' according to their coach, Jim Valvano. ''They look more like a pair of linebackers than the best guards in the land.''

title: D'Arcy Retirement
description: James Busch Orthwein, the 59-year-old, St. Louis-based chairman of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, announced his retirement last week.

title: NURSING HOME DEATHS RAISE ISSUE OF MEDICAID PAY SYSTEM
description: For the third time in three years, a grand jury will be asked to bring murder indictments against a nursing home in Galveston County.

title: 1,000 Jurors Called For Radicals' Trial
description: An extraordinary jury selection is to begin today for the trial of four men and two women on charges that grew out of a Federal investigation of the bloody 1981 Brink's armored car holdup in Rockland County.

title: TO SAVE FLY FISHING'S JOYS
description: IT was altogether fitting that Joan Wulff using a fly tied by the late and legendary Theodore Gordon - made a symbolic cast to open the Catskill Fly Fishing Center here last Friday. She and her husband, Lee, are the best known and most respected fishing couple in the country, and their work on behalf of trout and Atlantic salmon has been unremitting for years.

title: Jet Carrying 145 Falls 4 Miles in Power Loss
description: A Republic Airlines jet lost power in both engines on a flight from Minneapolis to San Diego Saturday and dropped about four miles before the engines restarted, officials said today.

title: BEYOND THE LIMITS OF OUR NATURAL RESOURCES
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKING NOISE TO SAVE BIRDS, AND JETS FROM BIRDS
description: Carolyn Heywood frightens birds. It isn't that she doesn't like them. She chases them to save them from themselves - and to save airplanes. She chases horned larks, owls, geese, ducks, an occasional ibis, but mostly seagulls away from the runways of Kennedy International Airport. Her techniques include roaring auto engine noises, recorded bird squawks, pistols, shotguns and an occasional booming cannon. As an operations services supervisor with the Port Authority's bird control unit, that is what she is paid to do.

title: Commodities; Strength In Farm Futures
description: AFTER more than a year of steadily declining prices and inactivity, the farm futures markets suddenly came to life early last month in a burst of price gains, volume and open interest. The reason is that a surprisingly large number of farmers have signed up for the Government's payment-in-kind program, which is aimed primarily at reducing the huge grain surpluses and bolstering farm prices.

title: Basketball's New Force
description: SUDDENLY he is the most towering, if not the most terrifying, player in college basketball. Akeem Abdul Olajuwon has upstaged both Ralph Sampson and Patrick Ewing by the sheer strength that he projects with his presence and potential. Now there are three young centers who will dominate the National Basketball Association for the next decade and Akeem Olajuwon might be the best of the three. But he is only justifying his name.

title: Washington Watch; Fed's Control Over Margin
description: THE Federal Reserve, which is midway through a review of its 50-year old rules regulating stock-market credit, isn't saying much about the possibility that it might turn this responsibility over to somebody else - perhaps the securities business itself.

title: RAILYARD ACID SPILL CAUSES EVACUATION IN DENVER
description: More than 2,000 people were evacuated from an area near central Denver before dawn this morning after nitric acid spilled from a railroad tank car and sent a plume of deadly gas over the city.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
AIRPORT AGENTS UNCOVER HEROIN WORTH MILLIONS
description: The largest heroin seizure of the year by customs agents in the New York area - 12 pounds with a street value of $12 million - was made at Kennedy International Airport on Saturday by an inspector who thought that the garment bag of a Pakistani lawyer seemed too heavy.

title: Golden Youth
description: When 32-year-old Bobby Valentine opens the season Tuesday as the third-base coach of the New York Mets, he will be flashing signals to many of his elders, such as Rusty Staub, Dave Kingman, Tom Seaver, Mike Torrez and Ron Hodges. Valentine will be the youngest third-base coach in the major leagues, but the native of Stamford, Conn., is used to being ''the kid'' in athletic settings.

title: West Beats East
description: Darrell Walker, a guard from Arkansas, scored 17 points to lead the West to a 99-94 victory over the East in the National Association of Basketball Coaches' all-star game today. The East was led by Bill Goodwin of St. John's with 17 points and Roy Hinson of Rutgers with 13.

title: EXCLUDING JUSTICE
description: President Reagan is moving quickly before the United States Supreme Court and the Congress to overturn the exclusionary rule, which prohibits prosecutors from using illegally seized evidence to try to convict a defendant. By virtue of Supreme Court decisions interpreting the Constitution that date to 1914, illegally obtained evidence cannot be used against a defendant. If the Administration's position succeeds, the Constitution will be undermined.

title: Sabres Mischief
description: Last week the folks in the front office of the Buffalo Sabres were feeling relaxed and playful. The Sabres were assured of third place in the Adams Division of the National Hockey League and were scheduled to open the Stanley Cup playoffs this week against Montreal.

title: ARCHITECTURE: ATRIUM OF TRUMP TOWER IS A PLEASANT SURPRISE
description: IT has not been difficult to presume that Trump Tower, the 68-story glass skyscraper at the corner of Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, would be silly, pretentious and not a little vulgar. After all, what New York building has been surrounded by so much hoopla? First there were the rumors that the British royal family was contemplating purchasing a condominium apartment - perhaps the much-talked-about $10 million penthouse, said to be the world's most expensive apartment. Then the shopping mall at the building's base opened, complete with guards dressed like a comic-opera version of English beefeaters and with brass podiums for flowers that turn out to be huge versions of the initials T.T.

title: EUROPEAN MISSILES: A PROPER SOVIET CONCERN
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Catholics Celebrate
description: More than 8,000 Catholics attended an early Easter mass today in the Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception in Peking, the New China News Agency reported. The 300-year-old church was decked with flags, ribbons and flowers while prayer books, crucifixes and other religious objects were on sale nearby.

title: EAGLES ARE AGAIN GATHERING IN THE NEW YORK AREA
description: The bald eagle is beginning to return to the New York metropolitan area, conservation officials said yesterday, and the shores of the Hudson River within 50 miles of Manhattan are once again becoming popular feeding grounds for the large, graceful birds.

title: Spaghetti Franchises
description: Elsewhere in the exciting world of franchising, someone has told the management of Spaghetti World that spaghetti was going to slurp its way into being the most popular fast food of the 1980's, so said management promptly hired Mandaback & Simms, a New York agency, to help insure pasta's popularity.

title: Topics; Alterations and Improvements; Hail, Kong!
description: Remember how he swatted those planes as if they were flies? How, dying, he got that funny hurt look on his face? How he lay, heaven knows how many pounds of gorilla, supine on 34th Street? How his captor opined that it wasn't the bullets but beauty that killed the beast? How sad it was?

title: POPE SPEAKS OUT TO THE OPPRESSED
description: Pope John Paul II, in an especially grave Easter message today, aligned the Roman Catholic church with a broad range of victims of political and social afflictions of the contemporary world.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 4, 1983
description: Energy

title: U.S. WANTS TO SELL SAUDIS 1,200 TANKS
description: The number of M-1 Abrams tanks to be sold to Saudi Arabia under a long-range plan being developed by the Reagan Administration has been put at 1,200, according to Defense and Congressional officials. They say some of the tanks would be used by American troops if they were deployed there in a crisis.

title: Famous Anonymous Donor
description: Somewhere in the city, thanks to the late Arthur Godfrey, are two people who are a step closer to having their sight restored.

title: Karen Akers Sings At Carnegie Hall
description: Karen Akers's rapid rise in less than two years from success in a tiny cabaret on West 54th Street, Mickey's, followed by her Broadway debut and a Theater World award last year in ''Nine,'' reached a climax Friday evening, when she made her Carnegie Hall debut to a sold-out house.

title: BID FOR BETTER POLYESTER IMAGE
description: The polyester industry has fallen on hard times, spurred in large part by the image of the mid-1970's doubleknit suit and changing consumer tastes. Designers have ignored polyester. Retailers shunned it. And consumers made jokes about it.

title: BRIEFING
description: Dollars for Hollings

title: The U.N. Today; April 4, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Camacho Beats Perez on Decision
description: Hector Camacho gained a unanimous 10-round decision over Irleis (Cubanito) Perez today in a nationally televised bout between junior-lightweight contenders.

title: Police Suspend Arrested Officer
description: A 22-year-old probationary police officer, arrested during the weekend for drunken driving, has been suspended without pay, the police said yesterday.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Three Share Lead
description: Craig Stadler, who found the putting stroke that has eluded him all season, shot a five-under-par 67 today and moved into a three-way tie for the lead after the third round in the rain-delayed, $400,000 Greater Greensboro Open.

title: An Overlap Of Seasons
description: A YEAR ago in this space, it was predicted that the Yankees would have three managers in 1982. Bob Lemon would be followed by Gene Michael, who would then be followed by either Jeff Torborg or Joe Altobelli.

title: MASON ORNE DAMON
description: Mason Orne Damon, a partner in the Buffalo law firm of Damon & Morey who was also active in civic affairs, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Buffalo.

title: For Fleer Bubble Gum, Fights and Fast Moves
description: In the bubble gum business, says Donald D. Peck, president of the Fleer Corporation, you have to be ready for the unexpected. ''Some of the things we do are wholly unplanned,'' Mr. Peck said. ''One day it might be a coffin with bubble gum bones, and the next, Pac-Man,'' which was Fleer's best-selling licensed product. ''You have to be ready to move with the opportunity.''

title: Return to Forever At the Palladium
description: Return to Forever brought some new material and new gadgets to its reunion concerts Friday and Saturday at the Palladium. Yet it was still the same disappointing band it was seven years ago - a quartet of idle virtuosos.

title: RANGERS LOSE
description: The Rangers' season has been at times very good, at times very bad, without ever going too far in either direction. So perhaps it was appropriate that they finished with a perfectly even record: 35 victories, 35 losses and 10 ties.

title: OIL EXPERTS SEE PRICES STABILIZING
description: After months of mounting acrimony among the world's major oil producing nations and fears of a price war that would bring crude oil prices down steeply, a growing number of American oil experts now believe the international price structure has stabilized.

title: Books Of The Times
description: ANCIENT EVENINGS. By Norman Mail- er. 709 pages. Little, Brown. $19.95.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A family of Rhode Island reds sunned themselves the other day on the sidewalk outside Banny's Grocery Store, their home on Amsterdam Avenue near 87th Street. Fluffing out their plumage and pecking contentedly on lettuce leaves, they awaited the arrival of two additions, now just brown eggs in a nest in Banny's basement.

title: Lending a Helping Foot
description: A subway rider with a token that won't fit the turnstile slot can try another turnstile or make an exchange at the booth.

title: SPARROW IS PRAISED AFTER HIS FIRST START
description: ''Something had to be done,'' Coach Hubie Brown said recently as the Knicks were slumping. Having lost five of their last seven games, they were in danger of fading out of contention for a playoff spot.

title: Beware Fair Traders Crying Foul
description: The United Steelworkers feel duped. First they fought shoulder-toshoulder with U.S. Steel to block imports of finished steel from subsidized foreign producers. Next they yielded wage concessions for a promise that the savings would be reinvested in the enterprise. And now they awake to find their members' jobs threatened by the company's negotiation to buy semifinished steel from a subsidized European producer.

title: Fuel Truck Stolen In Westchester
description: Two men handcuffed a gasoline delivery driver and hijacked his tractor-trailer with 6,000 gallons of fuel from a service station in this Westchester County community early today, the police said.

title: VISIT BY ARCHBISHOP ADDS TO EASTER JOY IN NICARAGUAN TOWN
description: Easter, always a festive day in heavily Roman Catholic Central America, was especially so in this dusty town because Archbishop Miguel Obando y Bravo came to celebrate mass.

title: U.S. IS PLANNING BID TO WIN OVER EUROPE'S YOUNG
description: The Reagan Administration is devising a broad strategy to counteract what it views as growing anti-American tendencies among younger Europeans, according to Government officials.

title: Topics; Alterations and Improvements; The Naming of Ships
description: In the naming of ships it is hard to please everyone. When the Navy decided to christen a nuclear attack submarine the Corpus Christi, after the town in Texas, the city fathers were delighted; but its Catholic bishop was dismayed at what he considered a misuse of the name of the Feast of the Eucharist.

title: ANTITRUST STUDY OF U.S. BOND TRADING
description: The Justice Department is investigating possible antitrust violations by several large banks and Wall Street firms that specialize in the trading of United States Treasury securities.

title: SANDINIST AIDE ASKS U.S. FOR VISA
description: Interior Minister Tomas Borge Martinez has applied for a visa to visit the United States, American diplomats here said today. They said the decision on whether to grant the visa would be made by the State Department.

title: East Village Arts Festival
description: An art exhibition, with rock music by the group His Master's Voice, will open the second East Village Arts Festival today at the Middle Collegiate Church, 50 East Seventh Street.

title: Canadiens 4, Bruins 4
description: Guy Lafleur scored with 5:21 left to lift Montreal in the regular-season finale for both teams. Keith Acton gave LaFleur a centering pass from behind the net, and the Canadiens' right-wing beat the goalie Pete Peeters from the slot for his 27th goal.

title: A Happy Birthday Reprise
description: It was Easter when Phyllis Smith, during a jam session at the old Hickory House, was introduced to Eddie Condon, the jazz guitarist. It was 1937, and her second day in New York.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No matter how hard it rains outside, it's sunny in here!'' - Dr. Samuel D. Proctor, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem. (B1:2.)

title: SANJAY GANDHI'S WIDOW CONVENES NEW PARTY
description: The widowed daughter-in-law of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi held the first meeting of her new opposition party today and attacked what she called the failure of Mrs. Gandhi's Government to curb corruption, limit population growth or create more jobs.

title: Japan Denies Soviet Charge
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone today denied a Soviet charge that Japan is a base for nuclear weapons. ''There are no nuclear weapons or bases in Okinawa or any other part of Japan,'' Mr. Nakasone said in reply to a charge made by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, who said on Saturday that Japan is ''stuffed with nuclear weapons.''

title: Mount St. Helens's 1980 Toll Is Cut by 2 as Error Is Found
description: Now that the authorities have removed two names they say were included erroneously, the list of people presumed dead or missing after the May 18, 1980, eruption of Mount St. Helens has dropped to 57.

title: TV: BATES AND JULIE CHRISTIE IN 'SEPARATE TABLES'
description: FLOATING around the schedule of Home Box Office the last few weeks has been a very affecting production of Terence Rattigan's ''Separate Tables.'' It could have been seen on the pay cable channel at 1 A.M. today. It will next be shown Saturday afternoon at 3:30. It is very much worth chasing and catching.

title: HIGH TIME FOR NATURAL GAS DECONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMBODIA IS ARMED CAMP OF SOLDIERS AND GUERRILLAS
description: In the heartland of Cambodia and along its borders, there are now more troops, weapons and preparations for war than at any time since the Vietnamese Army swept through the country in early 1979.

title: DEVILS GET 3 EARLY, DEFEAT PENGUINS, 5-3
description: The Devils defeated the Pittsburgh Penguins, 5-3, here tonight and completed the season two rungs higher than their last-place finish a year ago as the Colorado Rockies.

title: Colombia Selling Food As Quake Relief Builds
description: Earthquake relief aid from Canada, the United States, France and other countries piled up in warehouses today while a Colombian Government agency sold food to survivors.

title: WHITNEY AT PHILIP MORRIS SET TO OPEN
description: The Whitney Museum of American Art will open a major exhibition center and sculpture court Friday on the street level of the new Philip Morris World Headquarters Building at Park Avenue and 42d Street.

title: Norstar Bancorp Continues Growth
description: Norstar Bancorp, the 11th-largest banking organization in New York State, continued its expansion efforts with the announcement that it wants to acquire a $1.64 billion bank holding company, the Security New York State Corporation.

title: GHK Refinancing Set
description: The GHK Company, a major oil and natural gas drilling concern based in Oklahoma City, announced over the weekend that it had completed a $350 million debt refinancing plan that would permit it to pay off all but its seven largest creditors today. GHK said that its largest creditors had agreed to the new long-term credit arrangements. Robert A. Hefner 3d, GHK president, added that the refinancing plan had been effected with $60 million in new loans provided by three banks, which he did not identify.

title: SEAVER IS READY FOR OPENING DAY
description: The Mets ended spring training today with 11 victories and 12 defeats, and with assurances from Tom Seaver that he would be well enough to pitch the opening game of the season Tuesday, after all.

title: Soviet Six Wins
description: Sweden's second-string national team defeated Canada's Olympic team, 5-4, and the Soviet Union's second team trounced Czechoslovakia, 7-1, in the playoff finale of the Leningrad ice-hockey tournament today. The Soviet Union finished first, followed by Sweden, Czechoslovakia, Canada and Finland.

title: Games Coaches Play
description: The many roles that a college basketball coach must play include cheerleader, strategist and harasser of referees. Sometimes these roles overlap, conflict and produce situations that even the coaches can laugh about once the game is over. Jim Valvano, the exuberant coach of North Carolina State, which plays Houston for the National Collegiate Athletic Association title tonight, had a chance to chuckle after his Wolfpack defeated Virginia in the West Regional championship game in Ogden, Utah.

title: REAGAN ARMS EFFORT: A PLAN IN PERIL
description: The phones did not ring on Capitol Hill last week. President Reagan wanted them to ring. He went on national television 10 days ago and urged his listeners to support his request for a 10 percent increase in the military budget for the fiscal year 1984. But this time the man known as the Great Communicator failed to get his message across.

title: 1,000 Sikhs Arrested in India In Advance of Punjab Protest
description: The police in the northern Indian state of Punjab have arrested more than 1,000 Sikhs in a crackdown in advance of a planned protest, the Press Trust of India reported today.

title: A ROOM FOR PRESIDENTS IS A ROOM NEGLECTED
description: Abraham Lincoln went there often. Woodrow Wilson worked there as much as three times a week. But except for occasional visits, recent Presidents have virtually ignored the one Capitol room that they could call their own: the President's Room.

title: Reagans Join Services At Church Near Ranch
description: President Reagan attended Easter services at a small church a few miles from his mountaintop ranch near Santa Barbara, and then left for the White House this afternoon after a weekend holiday of horseback riding and ranch chores.

title: Syracuse Is No.1 In Lacrosse Poll
description: The unbeaten Syracuse team replaced Johns Hopkins, also undefeated, at the top of the Division I poll of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Coaches Association, it was announced today.

title: DeLorean Investigation
description: Police in Northern Ireland are investigating what they believe may be the disappearance of $17.5 million from John Z. DeLorean's car company, the Sunday Times reported today.

title: TO CURB CON ED'S APPETITE FOR RATE HIKES
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: INDIA'S MUSIC, NORTHERN AND SOUTHERN
description: TO non-Western ears, the classical music of France, Germany, England and Italy must sound quite similar. There are shared musical techniques, a shared musical language, even cross references and influences across borders. But from deep within the tradition itself, the differences even between regions of Western Europe are significant indeed, pointing to differences in society, in religion, in climate and even in the function of the music itself.

title: COPELAN'S PROSPECTS DIMMED FOR DERBY
description: It was only 2 1/4 lengths from Current Hope's victory in the Flamingo Stakes here Saturday to El Cubanaso's ninth-place finish. A margin of less than half a second among nine horses after a mile and an eighth in 1:49 2/5 seems to leave little to choose from in a mediocre field. But the race was more definitive than it seemed, at least in accentuating the negative.

title: A DEFECTOR TELLS OF DRUG DEALING BY CUBA AGENTS
description: A Cuban defector has told Federal and New York State law enforcement officials that agents of the Cuban Government conducted narcotics trafficking in the New York metropolitan area and in Florida in 1980 and 1981.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE IS PRONOUNCED SET FOR LIFTOFF TODAY
description: Space agency officials today pronounced the nation's newest space shuttle, the Challenger, ''go'' for its inaugural flight. Liftoff is scheduled for 1:30 P.M. Monday.

title: DR. IRVING YALE
description: Dr. Irving Yale, a prominent authority on podiatry and past president of the American Podiatry Association, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Yale-New Haven (Conn.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Ansonia, Conn.

title: COLLEGE SEEKS SAVINGS BY LEASING ITS CAMPUS
description: The president of Bennington College is proposing to help solve the school's financial crisis by leasing the entire campus to a group of alumni and then paying them for use of the buildings.

title: Live TV Coverage Set By 3 Major Networks
description: The three major television networks said they would interrupt their regularly scheduled programming to provide live coverage of today's space shuttle launching from Cape Canaveral.

title: Shaeffer at Tolson
description: Tolson & Company, a small New York ad agency founded in 1976, has picked up the account of the Shaeffer Eaton division of Textron, which manufactures writing instruments and paper products. The billings, put at about $1.3 million, previously went through Doyle Dane Bernbach, the agency for the past six years.

title: ECONOMY UP IN MARCH, PURCHASING STUDY FINDS
description: The economy expanded again in March, according to a survey of the nation's purchasing managers. The study was released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: British Seamen Threaten to Strike
description: The British seamen's union threatened to strike today after the Royal Navy seized one of its own civilianmanned transports, bound for the Falkland Islands but stranded in port by a pay dispute.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In college basketball, a player saves a ball from going out of bounds by tapping it back into the court. His momentum carries him out of bounds. Is he permitted to return and pick up the loose ball without being penalized?

title: THE JACKET LASTS FOREVER
description: THEY are accustomed to spending four days a week cutting a swath through the most reputable golf courses in the country, sometimes barely noticing whether they are in Greensboro, Orlando or Tucson. But this week they will know. There is an air about the Masters that gives golfers pause, that makes them want to have all their clubs in order when they drive down Magnolia Lane to the Augusta National Golf Club in search of perhaps the most prestigious prize in golf.

title: Advertising; Travelers Are Target Of Esquire
description: ESQUIRE magazine, which will probably end this year in the black for the first time in a decade, expects to hasten that happy state with its pair of single-interest, bound-in magazines.
