First there is the Esquire Collection, a men's fashion magazine first introduced last year, that shows up in the March and September issues. And bowing in October will be another biannual, this one on travel, called The Esquire Traveler, which will also have an April issue so that summer travelers may travel as much as winter ones.

title: FOR SINGLE WOMEN, ADOPTION ISN'T EASY
description: She had been told that it would not be easy; that to be 42 years old and single was, in effect, to be ineligible to adopt a baby. But Geri Diamond had wanted a child for a long time and nothing, she said, was going to stop her this time.

title: Black Leader Is Killed By South Africa Police
description: The outspoken leader of a black community of peasant farmers trying to resist Government plans to evict them from their land was shot dead Saturday during an altercation with the police at a protest meeting.

title: NISSAN USES JAPAN'S WAYS IN TENNESSEE
description: As Marvin T. Runyon tells it, the Nissan Motor Company's plant in Smyrna, Tenn., is becoming a hothouse for nurturing Japanese management, labor-relations and manufacturing practices in the United States.

title: Salvador Police Clear A U.S. Journalist
description: The police today cleared an American journalist in their investigation of possible arms trafficking from the United States to leftist guerrillas.

title: Enough Already With Withholding
description: Ignore the Barking About the Federal Bite

title: N.J. TRANSIT TRAINS ARE RUNNING AGAIN WITH STRIKE OVER
description: After a monthlong strike, N.J. Transit resumed service early this morning with two empty trains that left the Hoboken station shortly after 12:30 A.M., one for Suffern on the Erie line and one for Dover on the Lackawanna line.

title: WHAT WE DON'T KNOW
description: It's frustrating and humbling: there is so much we don't know. A brief news story filed from Paris by New York Times correspondent E.J. Dionne Jr. is a case in point. ''French police officials said today that they had arrested a man,'' went the lead, ''for passing industrial secrets to the Soviet Union.''

title: UNTHINKING DOOMSDAY
description: No matter why he said it, President Reagan's glimpse of a future where space-based defense will rule out atomic offense touches an irresistible hope.

title: MANY TAX-FREE ISSUES DUE
description: The tax-exempt market faces a heavy supply of new short- and longterm issues this week. Beyond New York State's $4 billion note sale, various housing authorities around the country plan to sell about $1 billion of Government-guaranteed project notes Tuesday. In the long-term bond market, analysts at Salomon Brothers said this week's volume could total $2.3 billion.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: First Lady

title: 238 X-RAY SCANNERS FACE ACTION BY U.S. OVER RADIATION RISK
description: The Food and Drug Administration says it has found a defect that may pose ''a risk of injury'' in 238 sophisticated X-ray scanners around the country. It has taken action that could lead to an order to the manufacturer to repair the scanners.

title: JORDAN AND P.L.O. STILL DEADLOCKED
description: Yasir Arafat and King Hussein held a third round of private talks at the King's palace today, but made no apparent progress toward a joint approach to Middle East peace talks.

title: ST. LOUIS OIL BARGES EXPLODE AND LEAK
description: Four barges loaded with crude oil crashed into two bridges spanning the Mississippi River and two of the vessels exploded, unleashing a stream of flaming oil that torched grain barges and brush along the St. Louis waterfront.

title: DIALOGUE: OFFSPRING VS. PARENTS
description: ANDRE DUHAIME, 16 years old, can talk easily to his parents. ' 'Depending on the situation, you should be open with them as much as possible,'' he said. His sister, Amy, 17, who was sitting on the o ther side of George and Jean Duhaime, did not agree at all. ''I c an't talk to them; I talk to my friends instead,'' she said.

title: O'KOREN HITS 9 OF 10 SHOTS ON 'BEST NIGHT'
description: Michael O'Koren scored on shots from the corners, the top of the key and on drives. He made nine consecutive field goals before he missed his 10th and final shot in the closing minutes of the Nets' 107-105 loss Saturday night to the Milwaukee Bucks at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: AMERICA CAN WELL USE AN ACADEMY FOR PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: GROMYKO NEWS CONFERENCE: A 'VIRTUOSO PERFORMANCE'
description: Though the headlines today focused on Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's rejection of President Reagan's latest arms proposal, those here who watch the Kremlin were at least as intrigued by the fact that he had chosen to announce the rejection at a wide-open news conference.

title: Chamber Music Society Plays 'Vox Balaenae'
description: Wearing black masks and sitting in dim blue light, whistling and chanting into their instruments and invoking an evolutionary epic extending from the beginning of time to its oceanic end, the players of George Crumb's ''Vox Balaenae,'' or voice of the whale, set the tone for Friday night's concert of the Chamber Music Society at Alice Tully Hall.

title: NOW FUND AND UNION CLASH OVER ORGANIZING BID
description: A bitter fight is taking place over efforts by District 65 of the United Automobile Workers to organize staff members at the Legal Defense and Education Fund of the National Organization for Women.

title: Mount Etna Rubmles
description: Mount Etna rumbled and spewed out a stream of molten lava today, but vulcanologists said there was no immediate danger of a full-scale eruption. Officials barred tourists from the upper slopes of the mountain and a few chestnut trees caught fire.

title: Vie de France Chooses J.W.T. in Washington
description: The Washington office of J. Walter Thompson has been named the agency for Vie de France, based there.

title: Temporary Shelter Cuts Cost For Boston Mental Hospital
description: The Massachusetts Mental Health Center, a state hospital, cut its annual costs 14 percent by opening a dormitory to provide temporary shelter for homeless patients, a report says.

title: ROCK: TOM PETTY AT THE BYRNE ARENA
description: TOM PETTY complained that he had a cold at the Brendan Byrne Arena on Friday, but it didn't prevent him from connecting again and again with an affectionate, wildly enthusiastic audience. The word ''affectionate'' is not often appropriate for a loud, celebratory rock crowd, but Mr. Petty has a knack for writing songs that express, in a straightforward manner, his listeners' most basic attitudes and emotions - a dissatisfaction with job and hometown, a deep-seated need to believe that love really can conquer all.

title: A.A.F. and Four-A's Merge Education Units
description: Both the American Association of Advertising Agencies, whose members are the ad agencies themselves, and the American Advertising Federation, the grass-roots organization with individual as well as corporate members from all facets of the industry, have had education foundations, each reflecting the interest thrusts of the organizations.

title: CORRECTION
description: A television review on March 22 incorrectly described the extent of ABC's coverage of a battle at Suchitoto, El Salvador. ABC reported fighting there on Feb. 18 and also on March 13.

title: ANALYSTS SEE RATE WEAKNESS
description: While traders in the credit markets have been preoccupied with recent increases in short-term interest rates, many economists doubt that the trend will be extensive or sustained.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Reds vs. Atlanta Braves, at Cincinnati, 2 P.M. Joe Torre, whose Braves won the National League West last season in his first year as manager, faces the Reds in the traditional season opener.

title: Kansas Raffle Offers A Banker for the Day
description: In an attempt to prove wrong the stereotype of the bank executive as stodgy and aloof, the suburban Kansas American Bank is raffling off its president, James McCoy.

title: Bridge: Visiting New York Players Hold Off New Zealanders
description: Some 150 local observers were sitting on the edge of their seats here Saturday afternoon ready to explode with a wild cheer of victory. But the cheer was stillborn, for the victory proved elusive.

title: Brown Wins Title
description: Ricky Brown of Brentwood, Tenn., and Stephanie Rehe of Highland, Calif., won the 16's titles as the 16th annual Olympus Easter Bowl junior tennis championships ended today. Both were top-seeded.

title: CITY REACHES PINNACLE AS ARCHITECTURAL LEADER
description: In 1972, one of New York City's most celebrated architects began a speech to a gathering of his profession in Chicago by saying how grateful he was ''to have been invited from the provinces to speak in America's first city of architecture.''

title: Fire Ruins 6 Stores In New Rochelle
description: Much of a suburban shopping center was destroyed early today by a two-alarm fire that injured four firefighters, a Fire Department spokesman said.

title: Swiss Motorcyclist Dies at Le Mans
description: Michel Frutschi of Switzerland died from injuries suffered in the crash of his Honda during the 500-cc event of French Grand Prix motorcycle race today.

title: Fireball Streaks Across Southern California Sky
description: The authorities said today that they could not determine the origin of a large flaming white object that streaked across Southern California skies, prompting dozens of calls to law enforcement agencies in at least five counties.

title: THOUSANDS IN AREA TURN A SOGGY DAY INTO A BRIGHT EASTER
description: Easter began yesterday with a whistling wind and the sound of rain splashing on window panes. At a sunrise service in the Radio City Music Hall, several thousand people ignored the weather and listened to religious songs, readings and a sermon - while letting their shoes and hats dry.

title: DANCE: DUO FROM FRANCE
description: PROGRAMS of abstract modern dance aren't necessarily displays of personality as well. Yet Wednesday night's program by Yves Musard and Pierre Deloche at the Merce Cunningham Studio was nothing but such a display. It almost became a highbrow vaudeville act.

title: CORRECTION
description: An engagement announcement yesterday misstated the status of Simon H. Rifkind, a partner in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. He is not retired.

title: Sacks-Cochran Tie Cut
description: Leonard Sacks, president of Sacks & Rosen, announced Friday that the agency and Jacqueline Cochran Inc., a division of American Cynamid, have agreed to part after a seven-year relationship. The agency had two assignments, the Nina Ricci Fragrances and the Pierre Cardin Fragrances divisions. Mr. Sacks said billings were $3 million to $4 million.

title: TRIAL OVER DEATH OF RIGHTS WORKER NEARS END
description: Final arguments in the $2 million negligence suit against the Federal Bureau of Investigation were made in Federal court here Friday by lawyers for the children of Viola Liuzzo, whose murder by Klansmen 18 years ago they attribute to a paid F.B.I. informer.

title: CHOICES ON GUATEMALA
description: The unavoidable choice for the United States in Guatemala, as elsewhere in Central America, is whether it will accept radical change or keep the oligarchy in power by supporting, perhaps with United States troops, a campaign of mass annihilation. Many people in the United States fail to recognize this stark choice, living instead on false hopes of finding a middle ground between oligarchs and revolutionaries.

title: AMY ALCOTT WINS DINAH SHORE GOLF
description: Amy Alcott overcame the wind and two pressing rivals today to win the Nabisco-Dinah Shore Invitational golf tournament by two strokes.

title: Walt Alston Out Of Critical Stage
description: The condition of Walter Alston, the former Los Angeles Dodger manager who suffered a heart attack Friday, was upgraded today from critical to serious.

title: ISLANDERS PURSUE A 4th TITLE AFTER MEDIOCRE SEASON
description: THE Islanders have this feeling about the Stanley Cup. ''In a way,'' said Wayne Merrick, one of the Islanders' veteran centers, ''we think we kind of own it.''

title: CAMBODIA FIGHTING IS SAID TO SPREAD
description: Vietnamese troops in western Cambodia continued battling insurgents along the border with Thailand on Sunday, and the fighting has spread, according to Western diplomatic sources.

title: GREBEY EXPECTS TO RESIGN
description: Ray Grebey, management's chief negotiator during baseball's 50-day strike in 1981, is on his way out as the club owners' labor representative, management sources said yesterday.

title: WINFIELD SEES SOLID SEASON
description: Spring training ended today for the Yankees, and the regular season begins Tuesday night in Seattle. At this precipitous moment of the year, Dave Winfield is feeling just the way one is supposed to: optimistic.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Savings Bank has elected Robert J. Hughes executive vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Utah Governor Recovering
description: Gov. Scott M. Matheson is expected to return to the executive mansion ''in a couple days'' from the hospital where he is recovering from a mild heart attack, an aide said today. Mr. Matheson, 54 years old, was thought to be suffering from pericarditis, a viral infection of the membrane around his heart, when he checked into the hospital Friday night.

title: MORE SCHOOLGIRLS IN WEST BANK FALL SICK
description: Another wave of illness hit at least 350 Arab schoolgirls in two towns in the Israeli-occupied West Bank today, leading to demonstrations, stone-throwing and shootings.

title: Spanning the Years
description: The Brooklyn Bridge got its picture on the cover, but the Bronx was the first borough to start getting the 1983 telephone books. Delivery of 400,000 there began last week.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF
description: Philippe Entremont's evening of Debussy and Chopin at Carnegie Hall on Saturday brought together two of the piano's most skillful composers and two of music history's more isolated figures. For despite their communicative gifts, Chopin and Debussy seem to stand apart from the natural flow of music history, being neither classical, Romantic nor wildly avant-garde and yet being all three.

title: POLISH PLAN SEEN HURTING, NOT HELPING, RECOVERY
description: Poland's three-year recovery plan not only has little prospect of easing the nation's severe economic crisis, experts here believe, but will in all likelihood make things even worse.

title: PBS Project With Merrill
description: The Public Broadcasting Service, reacting quickly to a regulatory decision authorizing a new service known as teletext, has announced that it will conduct a ''demonstration project'' with the brokerage firm of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith.

title: Foreign Trade Down in 1982
description: Foreign trade of the world's industrialized nations declined for the second straight year in 1982, reflecting a worldwide recession, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

title: LAWS ON MALPRACTICE THAT HURT CONSUMERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Colonial Penn President Stresses Independence
description: Daniel F. Crough, 47, took over Friday as president and chief operating officer of the Colonial Penn Group, a Philadelphia insurer. A lawyer who joined the company 11 years ago from the Reliance Insurance Companies, Mr. Crough succeeds Herbert J. Grubb, 52, who resigned March 9. John J. MacWilliams remains chairman and chief executive.

title: Cathy Chamberlain At Red Blazer Too
description: In the mid-1970's Cathy Chamberlain, a tall blonde with a breezy Texas Guinan manner and a lusty, free-booting singing voice, was leading a jazz combo in what she called a ''rag and roll revue,'' singing and playing songs that ranged from ragtime to rock-and-roll. After a couple of years of retirement, Miss Chamberlain is now back in action with her Ace in the Hole Dixieland Band, which plays Friday evenings at Red Blazer Too, Third Avenue near 88th Street.

title: Carnesecca Voted Coach of the Year
description: Lou Carnesecca, who guided St. John's to its best season ever (28-5), was named today Division I coach of the year by the National Association of Basketball Coaches.

title: Music Noted in Brief; American Symphony Performs Mahler
description: Moshe Atzmon led the American Symphony Orchestra through the nearly two hours of Mahler's Third Symphony yesterday in Carnegie Hall. But it wasn't until the climaxes of the final movement that Mr. Atzmon gave some hint of the character and ambitions of the expansive work.

title: TURKISH TRIAL SEEN BY JOURNALISTS AS WARNING
description: The trial of a 75-year-old publisher arrested for reprinting a 22-year-old editorial is being seen by many Turkish journalists as a warning that strict controls will be enforced by the military regime even as the country moves toward elections next fall.

title: N.C.A.A. FINAL MATCHES BALL-CONTROL AGAINST POWER
description: These reports on Houston and North Carolina State, which play tonight in Albuquerque, N.M., for the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship, were prepared and written by Jack Rohan, chairman of the Department of Physical Education at Columbia University. Mr. Rohan was Columbia's basketball coach from 1961 to 1974. He played for Columbia in the 1951 national tournament and he coached Columbia in the 1968 tournament. HOUSTON

title: DISSIDENTS PUSH TRANS WORLD PLAN
description: A group of dissident investors in the Trans World Corporation is once again seeking to break up the airline holding company. The group, Odyssey Partners, disclosed yesterday that it would propose the sale of Trans World's profitable nonairline subsidiaries at the company's annual stockholders meeting scheduled for April 27.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 4, 1983
description: International

title: MANY STOCK MARKETS ABROAD REPORT GAINS IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Signs of economic recovery were a stimulus to share prices on the world's major equity markets during the first quarter. But in dollar terms, no overseas exchange performed as well as in the United States, where signals of resurgence are strongest and where the stock market continued the rally that started last August.

title: Yonkers Raceway May Be Picketed
description: The 64-night spring meeting of standardbred racing at Yonkers Raceway, which is scheduled to begin tonight, may be picketed by striking members of the track's 65-man security force and 32-man parking lot staff.

title: Cotton Investor Elected As Mayor of Dallas
description: A. Starke Taylor Jr., a wealthy cotton investor seeking his first political office, was elected Mayor Saturday after running the most expensive mayoral campaign in the city's history.

title: Segovia to Be Honored
description: Andres Segovia, the Spanish guitarist, will attend a special mass and musical tribute in honor of his 90th birthday tomorrow at 6:30 P.M. in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The public is invited, and admission is free.

title: GULFSTREAM AEROSPACE PLANS BIG-STOCK OFFERING
description: The Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, a large manufacturer of executive aircraft, will go public this week with one of the largest initial stock offerings ever to come to market. The offering, of 7 million common shares, is being handled by Shearson/American Express and is expected to raise between $119 million and $140 million at a per-share price of $17 to $20.

title: SMALL COMPANIES SCORE BEST
description: Although blue-chip issues posted impressive advances during the first quarter of 1983, the stock market's biggest percentage gainers were some of the smaller and lesser-known companies.

title: Topics; Alterations and Improvements
description: About the House

title: WHITES AGAIN ACCOST CHICAGO CANDIDATE AT CHURCH
description: The police were called to a west Chicago church today to escort Representative Harold Washington through a group of angry whites who gathered to protest a campaign appearance by the black mayoral candidate in their neighborhood.

title: FATHER IS BEING HELD
description: A 2-year-old girl and her 8-month-old twin sisters were found dead in their home in southern New Jersey early yesterday, and their father was charged with three counts of homicide, authorities in Cape May County said last night.

title: SEARCH MADE FOR PLANE OFF L.I.
description: A single-engine plane disappeared as it was making an instrument approach in fog to Republic Airport on Long Island yesterday evening and was presumed to have crashed in the Great South Bay, the Federal Aviation Administration said.

title: Market Place; Energy Issues' New Strength
description: ENERGY related issues, long out of favor with investors, surged ahead last week, while some recent strong groups gave ground in the stock market. This process provided another example of the group rotation that has helped to cushion stock prices from any jarring decline since the bull market began last August.

title: Air Florida Officer Retires
description: Eli Timoner, the founding president of Air Florida, who was sidelined by illness last year, has announced his retirement. He said that his recovery ''has been slower than I had hoped for.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Ira M. Ventry, 50, a Professor At Columbia Teachers College
description: Ira M. Ventry, a professor of the science of hearing at Columbia University's Teachers College, died of cancer on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 50 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salamon Brothers estimate for bellwether issues

title: WHO'S AFRAID OF THE I.R.S.?
description: Once upon a time, taxpayers filed ink-stained 1040 forms in fear and trembling, the inclination to cheat kept in check by a data-matching Orwellian monster they imagined on the receiving end. No longer. Americans have caught on.

title: Wadkins Takes Greensboro by 5
description: Lanny Wadkins put together a late string of three birdies in a round of five-under-par 67 today that gave him a five-stroke victory in the Greater Greensboro Open golf tournament.

title: CONTEXT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
POWER CONVERSION INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: Results for the latest periods reflect a loss of $92,282 due to a loss of material and inventory because of a power failure.

title: Denver Acid Spill Studied For Threat to Water
description: A snowstorm slowed efforts by health officials today to determine if a nitric acid spill that had seeped into the soil threatened underground water supplies.

title: 5 Hurt in Blast Near Reactor
description: An explosion at an electrical substation near the University of Missouri nuclear reactor injured five men Sunday night. Capt. Earl Burry of the campus police said the research reactor, 100 yards from the electrical substation, was never in any danger. The cause of the explosion was not known.

title: LINCOLN PLAZA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. Year-ago revenues have been restated to exclude revenue from discontinued operations.

title: Real Estate Trust
description: San Francisco Real Estate Investors said it had purchased 279,800 shares of Real Estate Investment Trust of America in open market block transactions, thus increasing its holding in the trust to 630,592 shares, or about 38.6 percent of the total outstanding. San Francisco Real Estate's $40-a-share cash tender offer for 558,000 trust shares expired on March 31, but the company said it had told the Securities and Exchange Commission it intended to continue to seek control of the trust.

title: A New Look Again For Yankee Opener
description: For the first time, the Yankees will open their season indoors, making an unusual opening-night appearance tonight in Seattle. There is, on the other hand, not much that is unusual about the lineup that will open in the Kingdome: It has a liberal sprinkling of new faces.

title: Young Playwrights
description: ''T here's a really nice graveyard on East Third Street'' in Brooklyn's Midwood section, said 20-year-old Richard Colman. When he was at Edward R. Murrow High School, he ''used to go with friends to talk'' in the graveyard, which is part of Washington Cemetery.

title: CONCERT: PAVAROTTI AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: GRAND opera is grand not only because of the spectacle -the sets displaying the wealth and power of the state, the armies arrayed for battle, the solemnity and grandeur of the church - but because in the midst of that immensity, the individual character becomes the focus of attention. It is the lover, the father, the priest, the gypsy who becomes the focus for the conflict, through which larger forces can be made intimately real.

title: WEST GERMANS PROTEST NUCLEAR MISSILES FOR 4TH DAY
description: A fourth day of demonstrations against the nuclear arms race took place around West Germany today, with tens of thousands of people participating.

title: AMBROSE E. CATES
description: Ambrose E. Cates, vice president the E.F. Hutton Trading Company, died of cancer Saturday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 67 years old, and lived in Washingtonville, N.Y.

title: A SPORTSWEAR PREVIEW: FALL ON SEVENTH AVENUE
description: Sportswear, that quintessentially American branch of fashion, is alive and flourishing in workrooms along Seventh Avenue. Though much of the fashion world is on a more serious, formal tack, collections of casual and relaxed clothes for next fall and winter are taking shape under the aegis of some of the best-known New York designers.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After tax credits of $660,000 for the quarter and $870,000 for the year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $3,159,000 for the quarter and $8,611,000 for the year.

title: BARUCH-FOSTER CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
PARAMOUNT PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $126,000 for the quarter and $91,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $132,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everything is going tickety-boo so far.'' - Paul J. Weitz, astronaut. (C5:1.)

title: HARWYN INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: HIGH COURT BARS APPEAL ON TEXACO
description: A ruling that Texaco Inc. overcharged customers about $1 billion for crude oil sold in the mid-1970's was left intact today by the Supreme Court.

title: AID AUTO STORES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss of $35,149 from discontinued operations. c-Net income including income of $14,229 from discontinued operations.

title: SUPER VALU STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
VOGART CRAFTS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
DUCKWALL-ALCO STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
SAXON OIL'S LOSS WIDER IN QUARTER
description: Reflecting the severe problems facing many of the nation's small oil and gas producers, the Saxon Oil Company reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss had widened to $41 million. It added that its auditors were ''unable to express an opinion'' on its financial condition because of unresolved problems in restructuring its huge debt.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: THE BRIEF ROAD TO STARDOM OF MATTHEW BRODERICK
description: At 19 he was out of high school and out of work, dividing his time between ''auditioning like a madman'' and playing paddle ball. He had made a deal with himself - that he would spend one year trying to become an actor, and if it didn't work out he would go to college - but his paddle-ball game was going a lot better than his acting career.

title: Letter: On Lobbying How O.M.B.'s Defunding Plan Misfired
description: To the Editor:

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Donarl Chapter 11
description: Donarl of Florida Inc., a Broadstone Group Inc. subsidiary, has filed a petition seeking protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in the Federal District Court for the Southern District of Florida. Broadstone is owned by the Arlen Realty and Development Corporation, with a 50.5 percent interest, and by USIF Real Estate, which holds the rest. Legal proceedings have been started against Donarl seeking, in part, to foreclose on a mortgage covering its principal asset, a tract known as Aventura, which it holds for residential condominium development in North Miami Beach, Fla.

title: The I's Have It
description: Kellii Rinker, a rookie on the tour of the Ladies' Professional Golf Association, is waging a campaign to have her name spelled correctly in programs and on scoreboards.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES CURBING IMPORTS FROM NATIONS DEFYING SANCTIONS
description: President Reagan today asked Congress for authorization to restrict imports from countries that sell to Communist bloc nations in violation of an American trade sanction.

title: CHICAGO: ETHNIC VOTING VS. RACIST VOTING
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE-SAVING MANEUVER FAILS
description: THE Heimlich maneuver, a first aid technique introduced nearly a decade ago, has saved the lives of thousands of people whose windpipes had become obstructed by a piece of food or other object. The technique involves an upward thrust with the rescuer's fist, placed below the rib cage but above the navel of the victim.

title: Business and the Law; The In-House Legal Staffs
description: FOR the last few years, the most dramatic change in the practice of corporate law has been the rapid growth of in-house legal departments.

title: Henry S. Sayers, Built America's Cup Yachts
description: Henry S. Sayers, the builder of every United States defender in the America's Cup yachting series since 1964, died last Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: BRUCE T. BENEPE
description: Bruce T. Benepe, the chairman of Leacock & Company, a Manhattan manufacturer of linens and other household textiles, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 61 years old.

title: CSX DOWN 26.1% IN QUARTER
description: The CSX Corporation, which owns one of the nation's largest railroads, yesterday reported first-quarter net income of $35.6 million, or 84 cents a share, down 26.1 percent from earnings of $48.2 million, or $1.16 a share, in the first quarter of last year.

title: DOME GETS DELAY ON RESCUE PACKAGE
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd., the troubled oil and gas producer that owes an estimated $6.5 billion (United States) here and abroad, said today that its principal Canadian lenders had extended for one month the deadline for accepting a federally sponsored rescue package agreed to last year.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THE G.O.P. VS. WOMEN
description: A couple of weeks ago, Muriel (Mickey) Siebert, a Republican with strong self-made credentials as a broker and public servant, made some pungent remarks about how disdainfully her political party treats women. Known for her no-nonsense language, Miss Siebert - the first woman member of the New York Stock Exchange, the founder of her own brokerage firm (Muriel Siebert & Company), the State Superintendent of Banks for five years and, last year, a loser in the Republican primary for United States Senator - unloaded on the G.O.P. at a gathering known as The Gotham Luncheon. This is the name adopted by a group of New York's moderate Republicans who meet four or five times a year to take up issues of concern to the party.

title: TV: CBS RESURRECTS 'MAN FROM U.N.C.L.E.'
description: TELEVISION recently resurrected the old ''Leave It to Beaver'' gang for a television-movie reunion. Now, in the same trivia spirit, CBS-TV is offering, tonight at 9 o'clock, ''Return of the 'Man From U.N.C.L.E.' '' Robert Vaughn and David McCallum are returning as, respectively, Napoleon Solo and Illya Kuryakin, roles they created on the series that ran from 1964 to 1968.

title: Go Slow on Park Racing
description: An organization called the New York Grand Prix wants to take over the southern end of a city park, Flushing Meadows, and turn it into an auto race track.

title: Rates Mixed in Quiet Trading; 6-Month Bill Is Unchanged
description: Interest rates were mixed in quiet trading yesterday, with little change for issues due in less than a year and slight declines for longer-term securities.

title: IRST COMMERCIAL BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: OFFICIALS HOPING FOR FASTER WORK ON MEETING HALL
description: The head of the corporation building New York City's new Convention Center said yesterday that he hoped to have a greatly expanded work force on the site by summer to help make up for long construction delays.

title: Earl Harkness, Retired As Chairman of Bank
description: Earl Harkness, retired chairman of the Greenwich Savings Bank in New York City and a former deputy state superintendent of banks, died Friday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 84 years old and also lived in Manhattan and Delray Beach, Fla.

title: PIONEER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $328,000. c-Including a tax credit of $49,000 and a loss from discontinued operations of $52,000.

title: 4 ASTRONAUTS RIDE 2D SPACE SHUTTLE INTO EARTH ORBIT
description: Four astronauts rode the new space shuttle Challenger into earth orbit Monday and deployed a large satellite that was boosted early today toward a distant point in space where it will be used for tracking and communicating with future spacecraft.

title: Du Pont Company
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said it would seek court review of a Federal Trade Commission ruling against it and the Ethyl Corporation. The F.T.C. ruled the two companies had violated the F.T.C. Act by selling lead antiknock products on a uniform delivered price basis, by giving customers advance notice of price increases and by guaranteeing that a given customer would be charged prices no higher than any other customer.

title: TWICE-BITTEN PROFITS
description: To the Editor:

title: GEORGE WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a capital gain of $92,377. c-After a capital loss of $759,258 and a tax credit of $81,000.

title: CHICAGO: ETHNIC VOTING VS. RACIST VOTING
description: To the Editor:

title: Woman Found Shot to Death
description: A 23-year-old woman was found shot to death yesterday in the apartment of a man she had been living with at 301 East 79th Street, the police reported. They withheld her name, pending notification of her family. The body was found in the apartment of Patchel Landis, a jewelry designer, and detectives were trying to determine whether the death was a homicide or a suicide.

title: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE: STUDY FAVORS ARREST
description: DESPITE the conventional psychological wisdom that domestic disputes are best resolved through mediation, a pioneering study of police tactics in domestic assault cases has concluded that the best way for the police to prevent repeated acts of violence in the home may be simply to arrest men suspected of assaulting their wives or lovers.

title: Fannie Mae Issues To Total $2 Billion
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, announced plans to sell three issues of debentures totaling $2 billion, at interest rates to be announced today.

title: U.S.-Japan Trade Talks
description: The United States Ambassador to Japan, Mike Mansfield, met with Japan's Foreign Minister, Shintaro Abe, today and said Japan should resume negotiations on increased imports of beef and oranges from the United States, Foreign Ministry officials said.

title: Bad-Tasting Alfalfa
description: Grasshoppers like some types of alfalfa better than others, scientists in Bozeman, Mont., have discovered.

title: SCEPTRE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss of $18.3 million from the writeoff of certain European exploration and the writeoff of United Stated oil and gas properties. Results for the latest year include operations of Francana Oil & Gas Ltd. since its acquisition in May 1982.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 19.
description: Results for the latest first quarter include net income of $44,000 from operations of American Heritage Industries which was recently acquired and also from a favorable tax adjustment of $240,000 arising from the completion of an I.R.S. examination of the company's tax returns for the years 1974 through 1976.

title: 20's FILM IDOL
description: Gloria Swanson, a symbol of enduring glamour who was perhaps the most glittering goddess of Hollywood's golden youth in the 1920's, died of a heart ailment yesterday in New York Hospital. She was 84 years old.

title: Two Men Imprisoned In Child Pornography
description: Two men convicted of selling pornographic films of children were sentenced to prison yesterday.

title: Iowa Gets New Coach
description: George Raveling, the Washington State basketball coach, left Albuquerque, N.M., and returned to Washington yesterday because he said ''people were harassing me all the time,'' about reports that he would become the coach at Iowa. He acknowledged he had been offered the job but said he needed ''some time by myself to think.'' By last night, Raveling was on his way to Iowa City to accept the position as the replacement for Lute Olson, who resigned last week to take over at Arizona.

title: G.M.'s European Sales
description: The General Motors Corporation projects that it will sell more than 1.1 million new cars in Europe this year, a 15 percent increase from the 955,234 sold in 1982, an industry journal, Ward's Automotive Reports, said today. G.M.'s European sales rose 18 percent last year, leading all other producers, Ward's added. G.M.'s Opel Corsa has just been introduced in West Germany and Switzerland following its debut in France, Italy and Spain. Production of the Corsa, which is made in Spain, will increase from 700 a day to 1,200 daily by September, Ward's said.

title: Seafirst Energy Loans
description: The Seafirst Corporation, which has a $1.17 billion energy loan portfolio, said a significant oil price decline would hurt the portfolio and could require additional reserves to cover possible losses.

title: VIDEOVISION INC reports earnings for year to Nov 30.
description: b-After losses on discontinued operations of $2.2 million for the latest year and $362,430 for the earlier year.

title: LANDAUER ASSOCIATES PROMOTES 4 EXECUTIVES
description: Landauer Associates, a large real estate consulting firm, has had only two leaders since it was founded in 1946 by James D. Landauer. He died in 1979, and John R. White took over.

title: THE LESSONS OUR MUSEUMS EXHIBIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Job Interviews
description: Amid tight security and behind closed doors, the Board of Education began yesterday to interview people who want to be Schools Chancellor. By the end of the day, they had spoken to six of 17 candidates, and, by all counts, the experience was a tiring one.

title: Bridge: A Pass at the Right Time Can Keep Foes in the Dark
description: Good results at the bridge table are sometimes achieved by players who bid when they should not, thus confusing the issue for the opponents. A more subtle procedure is to pass when action seems indicated. This may deprive an opponent of a clue that would help him to play the hand.

title: BBDO Sets Acquisition Of Direct Mail Agency
description: BBDO International, parent of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborne, is planning still another incursion into the world of direct marketing.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
COVINGTON TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
20 ARE REPORTED KILLED IN INDIA AS SIKH PROTESTERS BATTLE POLICE
description: At least 20 people were reportedly killed today and 180 wounded in the northern Indian state of Punjab as policemen sought to clear thousands of demonstrating Sikh nationalists from the state's roads.

title: Grenada Official Says Force Trains in Miami for Invasion
description: Grenada's Foreign Minister, Unison Whiteman, said tonight that a United States-backed counterrevolutionary force of mercenaries and exiles has been training in Miami for an attempt to topple the leftist Government in his island nation.

title: Like Accounts Shifted to Ayer
description: Just a year ago, the crowd at N.W. Ayer let out a sigh of relief after learning that their 7-Up business would not be lost to Backer & Spielvogel.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: CANADIAN GENERAL ELECTRIC CO LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
POPULAR BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Cuban Airline Apologizes To U.S. for Violations
description: Cubana Airlines has apologized to the United States for two violations of air-traffic routings over this country that led to its being barred from American air space for two weeks.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Has 3 1/2- 1/2 Lead; Smyslov Is Ahead by 3-2
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland took a commanding 3 1/2- 1/2 lead in his quarterfinal match for world championship candidates in Bad Kissingen, West Germany, with Lajos Portisch of Hungary.

title: QUEENSTAKE RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
TUESDAY, APRIL 5, 1983
description: The Economy

title: WITNESS DESCRIBES CBS MURDERS BUT IS UNABLE TO IDENTIFY KILLER
description: The sole witness to the slayings of four people atop a Hudson River garage last April described the scene in court yesterday but said he could not identify the killer.

title: DART DRUG CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $8.3 million from the sale of 50 percent of the company's interest in Crown Books East Corp. and of operating systems for Trak Auto West Corp.

title: New U.S. Envoy to Guinea
description: President Reagan has nominated James Rosenthal to replace Allen Clayton Davis as United States Ambassador to Guinea, the White House said today. Mr. Rosenthal, a native of San Francisco, is a career diplomat and has served as deputy chief of mission in both Kuala Lampur and Manila.

title: POLITICAL HIRINGS BANNED IN CHICAGO
description: A Federal judge today gave the City of Chicago and Cook County a year to eliminate politically motivated hirings, dismissals and harassment of municipal workers.

title: ARAB BANK NAMES HEAD OF NEW OFFICE
description: The Arab Bank Ltd., established in 1930 in Jerusalem, has opened an office at 520 Madison Avenue in Manhattan and has named Godfrey G. Truslow as branch manager.

title: Lincoln Rothschild, 80, Dies; Artist, Author and a Teacher
description: Lincoln Rothschild, an artist, author and teacher, died of a heart attack on March 29 at his home in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y. He was 80 years old.

title: ARRESTS OF 28 ARE ORDERED BY CITY ON BUILDING SAFETY LAW CHARGES
description: The New York City Buildings Department ordered the arrest yesterday of 28 owners or managers of commercial properties in Manhattan who it said had neglected to comply with local building-safety laws despite repeated warnings.

title: DORSET RESOURCES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results represent operations from June 16, 1981, when they commenced, to Dec. 31, 1982. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: MCO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
The U.N. Today; April 5, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Bank Unit Merger
description: The Philadelphia National Corporation said the Federal Reserve System had approved its application to merge with the National Central Financial Corporation in a stock exchange transaction.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: PERHAPS the most important fact to emerge from the recent Paris c ollections had less to do with changes in shape, of which there w ere few, than with a new buying pattern among American retailers. E ncouraged by the strength of the dollar, or the decline of the f ranc, they bought 10 to 25 percent more this time than last season.

title: New Life for Paultz
description: Ever since he began his professional career with the Nets in 1970, Billy Paultz has never missed the playoffs. In fact, his streak of 12 consecutive postseason appearances is a National Basketball Association record for active players.

title: DAHLBERG ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including income of $1,488,321 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $530,975 from discontinued operations.

title: IRE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
SAXON OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income The 1982 fourth quarter results reflected asset writedowns and other charges of about $34.3 million.

title: WATCHING EUROPE WATCH US
description: Even though the West German national elections and French local elections produced results that Americans find reasonable and reassuring, we should not be so reassured as to conclude that the Europeans again consider us keepers of the Holy Grail or that our political and economic disagreements will disappear simply because the Germans and French voted as we had hoped they would.

title: HOT DOG WARS IN JERSEY
description: ''I'm naive, I guess,'' said Robert Roller, wiping the windblown sands from his stainless steel vending cart outside the Golden Nugget casino here. ''I thought I'd just come to Atlantic City and sell a few hot dogs.''

title: REDS DEFEAT BRAVES ON SINGLE IN 8TH
description: Dave Concepcion's two-out single in the eighth inning scored Eddie Milner with the winning run and gave the Cincinnati Reds a 5-4 victory today over the Atlanta Braves in the National League season opener.

title: N.C. STATE WINS TITLE ON FINAL-SECOND DUNK
description: At the end of a night of surprises, the biggest shock of all was that the top-ranked University of Houston Cougars - the self-proclaimed dunking fraternity Phi Slama Jama - lost the national championship on a dunk in the final second.

title: Final Play Started As Desperate Shot
description: The shot that became a pass for the winning stuff by North Carolina State's Lorenzo Charles was just that - a 27-foot, last-second, desperate shot by Dereck Whittenburg. Whittenburg did not know exactly how much time remained when he let go of the ball on the long shot that fell short.

title: DESPITE OIL SLICK, IRAN SHUNS IRAQ TRUCE OFFER
description: Iraq offered today to observe a limited cease-fire with Iran to allow the clean-up of a 7,500-square-mile oil spill in the Persian Gulf. Iran rejected the offer.

title: Reston Is Smith Lecturer
description: James Reston, the columnist of The New York Times, will deliver the first Red Smith Lecture in Journalism at the University of Notre Dame on April 20.

title: WITH WALLACE IN HOSPITAL AGAIN, SOME ASK WHO IS RUNNING STATE
description: When he ran for governor last year, George C. Wallace's health was a campaign issue. He denied that it was a problem or that he was depressed and in pain.

title: PRESIDENT TO MEET WITH SENATORS ON MILITARY BUDGET IMPASSE
description: President Reagan has invited the 12 Republican members of the Senate Budget Committee to come to the White House Tuesday to discuss the deadlock on military spending.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ray Tolbert of the Detroit Pistons was fined $500, his teammate Isiah Thomas $250 and Marc Iavaroni of the Philadelphia 76ers $250 for a series of misconduct incidents in a game March 7. ... Two New York City players - Kenny Smith of Archbishop Molloy High School in Queens and Dwayne Washington of Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn - were among 25 basketball players named to the McDonald's all-America high school team.

title: Stock Prices Retreat; Dow Off 2.42
description: Stock prices fell slightly yesterday in much slower trading as fears that interest rates may rise further weakened the list. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was in the minus column throughout the session, closed off 2.42 points, to 1,127.61. In the overall market, declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outscored issues that rose by 914 to 689.

title: WHALES MAY STUN PREY WITH NOISE
description: HOW do whales catch their prey? The process has been a mystery in the case of toothed whales since marine creatures found in their stomachs show no teeth marks.

title: FIGHT OUTCOME REVERSED AFTER A REPLAY
description: Proposals to give television replays a role in the officiating of major events remain a controversial area in sports. Last Saturday, after an unimportant preliminary fight, a replay produced a historic reversal that could carry long-range implications.

title: CHALLENGER, A LIGHTER, STRONGER SPACECRAFT, MAKES ITS DEBUT
description: A VARIETY of changes and improvements over the first space shuttle have given the second one, the Challenger, a considerably larger carrying capacity. Future usefulness of the shuttles will greatly depend on how much they can lift into orbit on each mission.

title: Books Of The Times
description: AN ICE-CREAM WAR. By William Boyd. 408 pages. William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: Marathon Raises Lengthy Debate
description: Alberto Salazar or Robert de Castella may produce a ''world's best performance'' Saturday in the Rotterdam Marathon, but there is some question how it will find a place in the books.

title: 2 AMERICANS STUDY SCHOOLGIRL ILLNESS IN WEST BANK
description: Two American specialists in epidemic control today began investigating a recent wave of illness among Palestinian schoolchildren that the Israelis attribute to mass hysteria and the Arabs to poison.

title: TV: A LOOK AT THE KLAN
description: ''THE KLAN: A Legacy of Hate in America'' does not try to tell the whole history of the Ku Klux Klan; it does not attempt a complete examination of Klan activities today. Instead, it looks to the essence of the Klan, past and present, and finds a virulent, violent racism. There is nothing new in the finding, of course, just as there is nothing new in the Klan. Every decade or so, it seems to die and then be born again. The half-hour documentary, on Channel 13 at 10 P.M., is a reminder.

title: STAGE: 'YOU CAN'T TAKE IT WITH YOU'
description: AT the end of the new Broadway revival of ''You Can't Take It With You,'' the cast refuses to take a polite curtain call. Instead, the actors pair off, collapse into one another's arms and take to dancing about the stage. And it isn't polite dancing, either: as choreographed by Reed Jones, the couples leap about, still in character, with such rowdiness that you'd think they'd all been at a party rather than performing a play. Actually, the 1936 George S. Kaufman-Moss Hart screwball comedy at the Plymouth is more party than play - but, either way, you're glad to be part of the merriment.

title: VIETNAMESE FORCE IS SAID TO OVERRUN A CAMBODIAN BASE
description: Vietnamese troops reportedly enlarged their control of Cambodian areas along the Thai border today, overrunning another insurgent headquarters and sending more than 20,000 Cambodians fleeing into Thailand.

title: The Plugged Caribbean Basin
description: No region has been promised more and given less in American development help than the Caribbean. But the Reagan Administration now has a second and possibly final chance to redeem its program. If it fails to wrest the innovative trade features from Congress this year, it will crucially undercut democratic partners eager to try its free-market recipe for growth.

title: ST. LOUIS DISTRICTS SIGN BUSING PLAN
description: All but one of the 23 school districts in suburban St. Louis County agreed today to a desegregation plan that would initiate the nation's first widespread voluntary school busing between a major city and its suburbs.

title: U.S. HOT LINE TO SOVIET: LITTLE USE FOR 20 YEARS
description: Tuesday marks the 20th anniversary of the agreement to establish a communications hot line between the White House and the Kremlin.

title: PIONEER INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
description: b-Including extraordinry gains of $328,000 for the latest first quarter and $49,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: BUMPERS IS EXPECTED TO GIVE UP ATTEMPT AT PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas, surprising friends and supporters, has decided not to seek the Democratic Presidential nomination, political sources said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BANK (WASHINGTON, DC) reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: JERSEY RAIL LINES BUSTLE AGAIN AFTER END OF STRIKE
description: Commuter trains rolled again throughout northern New Jersey today, and the old railroad terminal here - shuttered by a strike since March 1 - bustled anew with passengers and life.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net loss reflects equity in losses of Biscayne Federal Savings & Loan Association of $3,023,000. Year-ago revenues reflect phase- out of housing revenue of $32,103,000 which included sale of an apartment complex and a small asset-management subsidiary.

title: JAPAN TRADEMARKS CAN PROVE ELUSIVE
description: When the McDonald's hamburger chain arrived in Japan in 1971, one of the last things company executives expected was trouble with its famous trademarks.

title: EVERY COMPUTER 'WHISPERS' ITS SECRETS
description: COMPUTERS, it turns out, will whisper their secrets to anyone sophisticated enough to hear them. Every computer ever made constantly and inadvertently emits radio waves that can be decoded with equipment designed for electronic espionage.

title: THE 'OFF-PRICE' RETAILING BOOM
description: Discounting brand-name fashions -or ''off-price'' selling, as it is known nowadays - has become such a powerful force in the retail market that some of the nation's largest and most successful department stores are opening their own discount outlets or buying existing discount chains.

title: Loral Acquisition
description: The Loral Corporation has signed a contract to acquire the Narda Microwave Corporation for stock worth $45 million, subject to the approval of Narda shareholders. Under the agreement, each Narda share will be converted to six-tenths of a share of Loral if the average price of Loral stock for a period before the consummation of the transaction is less than $50 a share.

title: JAPAN'S BESIEGED CYCLE MAKERS
description: Japan's motorcycle industry, the world's unchallenged sales leader, is finding out that it is not easy being No.1. As with Japanese steel, auto and consumer electronics products, the industry's continued success is being threatened by increasing restrictions on its exports and a sated domestic market.

title: I.R.A. Killed Wrong Man
description: The outlawed Irish Republican Army said tonight that it had killed a Protestant factory worker by mistake. It promised an investigation of the matter. The I.R.A. Provisionals issued a statement saying they deeply regretted the killing of James McCormack, 45 years old, and extended their sympathy to his family.

title: COSTA RICA TO BAR REBELS, SANDINIST SAYS
description: Nicaragua's Interior Minister reported today that Costa Rica, challenged about the presence of anti-Sandinists in its territory, had pledged to act against those who try to abuse ''the right of asylum so generously granted.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New York on Screen

title: BALDWIN-UNITED ASKING BANKS FOR HELP ON DEBT
description: A top executive of the Baldwin-United Corporation said yesterday that the big insurance company had asked its banks to postpone repayment of $700 million in short-term debt while it tries to formulate a debt-repayment plan.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIA PACKERS LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a special gain of $3.8 million on the sale of vessels and a special loss of $691,000 for a provision for closure of facilities. c-Net income.

title: CORRUPTION TRIAL ENDS WITH PLEA ON MINOR COUNT
description: Arthur B. Powers, a former State Transportation Commissioner, today interrupted his trial on corruption charges and pleaded guilty to two lesser charges of hindering prosecution.

title: HISTORIANS OF SCIENCE STILL DEBATING THE CASE OF GALILEO
description: A 350-YEAR-OLD trial, whose verdict gave rise to a philosophical debate that continues to this day, has received an exhaustive rehearing before a court of international specialists.

title: RSR CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
REAGAN'S PENSION PLAN ASSAILED BY DIPLOMATS
description: Nothing rankles a career Foreign Service officer like the spectacle of a President appointing political buddies to prestigious ambassadorial posts over people who have spent their professional lives preparing for the job.

title: Sun Banks Merger
description: Sun Banks of Florida Inc. said it had signed a preliminary agreement to acquire Sun City Center Bank for cash or stock, subject to state and regulatory agency approvals. Under the agreement Sun City holders will receive between 1.8 and 2.2 shares of Sun common, or $44 cash for each Sun City share.

title: ARAFAT PRESSES TALKS WITH JORDAN
description: Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, shuttled between the P.L.O. executive committee and Jordan's King Hussein today in an effort to agree to a joint response to President Reagan's Middle East peace initiative.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amfac Inc., San Francisco, has named John F. Mendez president of the Amfac Garden Products division.

title: Dismissed Workers Sue 2 Mormon Concerns
description: The American Civil Liberties Union today filed suit against two companies owned by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, saying that company officials dismissed five church members for failing to meet the requirements of their religion.

title: Stake in Kerr Sold by Jacobs
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, a Minneapolis investor who has made a reputation by buying troubled companies and profiting from selling their assets, has ended his interest in the Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corporation.

title: Train Wreck Spills Chemical
description: A freight train derailed and spilled a small amount of a corrosive chemical Sunday, forcing the evacuation of a church and 45 to 50 families. Fifteen cars of the Norfolk & Western Railway train left the track, spilling a small amount of acetic anhydride, a highly flammable chemical. The residents were allowed to return to their homes Sunday night after officials determined there was little danger.

title: Board to Study Norstar Offer
description: The Security New York State Corporation said its board would examine an unsolicited $94.7 million cash and stock acquisition proposal offered Friday by Norstar Bancorp.

title: THE BITTER LEGACY OF POL POT WEIGHS ON CAMBODIA
description: This country's suffering under the Pol Pot Government, which was overthrown in early 1979, is still a live memory for millions of Cambodians. But a factual, historical account of what happened is hard to find here. Four terrible years, together with the events that preceded and followed them, have been simplified, rewritten, ignored and in some cases probably falsified by Cambodia's new Government and the Vietnamese who set it up.

title: Anchor Hocking
description: The Anchor Hocking Corporation said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its glass container division to a Wesray Corporation affiliate for about $68 million.

title: THE PROPHECY OF JIM VALVANO
description: From the moment Jim Valvano watched Houston slam dunk Louisville, 94-81, in Saturday's semifinals of the national collegiate basketball tournament, the North Carolina State coach knew what his Wolfpack had to do in last night's championship game against the Phi Slama Jama fraternity.

title: WHITE SENATOR IS SLAIN BY ATTACKERS IN ZIMBABWE
description: A white Zimbabwean senator, his daughter and a British citizen who was visiting them were slain by 20 to 30 assailants who attacked their farm in Matabeland Province Sunday night, a Government spokesman said today. The spokesman identified the attackers as anti-Government rebels.

title: NEW YORK STUDY PANEL ASKS RISE IN STATE AND LOCAL PENSION COSTS
description: A New York State commission studying the pension systems for public employees proposed a change yesterday that would increase costs for state and local governments. But the change was far less than public employee unions had been seeking.

title: A PRACTICAL GOAL
description: Despite Moscow's quick and decisive rejection, President Reagan's ''interim proposal'' on intermediate-range missiles in Europe served useful purposes and vindicated those of his advisers and among the allies who persuaded him to make it.

title: Alston 'Comfortable'
description: Walter Alston, the 71-year-old former manager of the Brooklyn and Los Angeles Dodgers, remained in serious but stable condition at Deaconness Hospital in Cincinnati. Alston, who suffered a heart attack Friday, was ''comfortable and alert,'' according to a hospital spokesman.

title: CUSTOM LABORATORIES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: GRANTS GOING NONSTOP TO LITTLE MAGAZINES
description: To the Editor:

title: KUSH OPEN TO SUIT, HIGH COURT RULES
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that a former Arizona State football player was entitled to pursue a Federal civil rights suit against his former coach, Frank Kush, and two other men who were athletic officials at the university.

title: First Union Corp.
description: A $50 million issue of the First Union Corporation 11 5/8 percent notes due in 1993 goes on sale today at a price of 100, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The notes were A-1 rated by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's. First Union, based in Charlotte, N.C., is a one-bank holding company that owns that third-largest bank in North Carolina.

title: Missile Defense Called ABM Treaty Violation
description: Three men involved in negotiating the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty said today that a space-based missile defense system such as President Reagan has proposed would require amendment or abrogation of the treaty.

title: MASSIVE DISTURBANCE IN OCEAN BRINGS FAR-FLUNG HAVOC
description: EARLY last year a modest increase in air pressure began to be recorded at Easter Island in the southeast Pacific. Although little heed was paid at the time, that increase heralded a sequence of events that have dumped torrential rains on California, Florida, Ecuador and Peru, swept away some of California's most prized beaches and taken a score of lives there, destroying a dozen piers and many large kelp beds.

title: New York on Screen
description: It was a formidable bunch. Manhattan's five highest-ranking police detectives had been at 565 Fifth Avenue yesterday to investigate Saturday's $6 million gold-chain burglary.

title: SALVADOR MAYOR BELIEVED SHOT
description: Salvadoran guerrillas occupied two hamlets in the eastern province of San Vicente today and shot the mayor of a third, local government officials said.

title: ISSUES IN UNSETTLED STRIKE
description: The strike of 622 conductors and trainmen against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad began March 7, forcing 90,000 commuters from Westchester County and Connecticut to travel to Manhattan by car, bus and subway.

title: USR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,677 and $18,005, for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $36,250 for the quarter and $54,250 for the year. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $494,089 and $340,635, for the quarter and year, respectivley, and extraordinary credits of $68,800 for the quarter and $105,100 for the year. The 1981 results were restated.

title: CAPE CODDERS'S VAIN DRIVE FOR 24-HOUR MORATORIUM ON KILLING
description: One year ago, Police Officer Donald R. Moreland was on the midnight shift when he heard a newscast about a new arms technology and, as he recalls, ''I suddenly had a feeling that I was a passenger on a runaway train hurtling toward almost certain self-destruction.''

title: WISCONSIN WILL VOTE TODAY ON RADIOACTIVE DUMP ISSUE
description: Wisconsin voters, who last September approved the nation's first statewide referendum calling for a freeze on nuclear weapons, will have a chance Tuesday to support or oppose a high-level radioactive storage dump.

title: FOE OF SANDINISTS FAULTS U.S. POLICY
description: A leader of one of Nicaragua's anti-Sandinist groups today criticized the Reagan Administration's support for guerrillas who are trying to topple the Sandinist Government, saying it would lead to sharper political divisions and less likelihood that a democratic government would eventually come to power.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co.'s Canadian unit completed the previously reported sale of its pulp mill in Marathon, Ontario, to James River Corp. of Richmond and Buchanan Forest Products Ltd. of Ontario.

title: QUESTIONING OF JURORS STARTS IN THE FEDERAL BRINK'S TRIAL
description: Selection of an anonymous jury began yesterday for the trial of six defendants on Federal charges stemming from an extensive investigation of the 1981 Brink's robbery and murders in Rockland County.

title: JOSEPH K. ROBERTS
description: Joseph K. Roberts, a former director and vice president of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), died of emphysema Sunday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 78 years old and lived in Mahwah, N.J.

title: ABC's Marketing Plan For '84 Olympic Games
description: Having paid out $316.5 million in 1979 for the rights to televise the 1984 Olympic Games, the American Broadcasting Companies next had to work out an advertising rate structure that would bring it a profit.

title: A TAX THAT CAN BREAK DEVELOPMENT'S BACK
description: To the Editor:

title: COURT ISSUES MORE NARROW RULING THAN EXPECTED ON JOB BIAS SUITS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a plaintiff in an employment discrimination suit is not required to produce direct proof of intentional discrimination.

title: Toyota Unit in Canada
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it had set up a subsidiary in the Canadian province of British Columbia to produce 20,000 aluminum wheels a month, starting in the middle of 1985.

title: MEN IN THE NEWS: PAUL J. WEITZ
description: Paul Weitz, a retired Navy officer, is making his second journey into space as commander of the space shuttle Challenger on its maiden flight.

title: BRIEFING
description: Eyes on Speakes

title: Cancer Virus Confirmed
description: Researchers at Duke University Medical Center have confirmed that a virus can cause a type of blood cancer in humans, scientists here say.

title: Oiler Arrested
description: Vernon Perry Jr., a defensive back for the Houston Oilers, has been charged with possession of cocaine.

title: Market Place; How to Read Stock Ratings
description: LAST November, shortly after Greg A. Smith joined Prudential-Bache Securities as research director, the firm adopted a new rating system for stocks. ''Prior to that time,'' he recalled recently, ''the ratings simply consisted of Buy, Sell or Hold.''

title: FABRIC WHOLESALERS INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
U.S. JUDGE REFUSES TO ALTER DELOREAN BAIL AND SETS NEW TRIAL DATE
description: Government prosecutors said today that John Z. DeLorean, facing trial on cocaine conspiracy charges, gained his release from jail through ''fraud'' last year by posting property for bail that was previously encumbered.

title: Advertising; Buick Buys A 12-Page Time Insert
description: THE Buick division of General Motors, a frequent sponsor of the Academy Awards telecasts over the last few years, is augmenting that exposure this year with a major investment in print - a special 12-page section in the April 11 issue of Time magazine.

title: DE TOMASO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Charlotte Curtis; A playwright enjoys poking some fun at his own world of WASP's
description: ALBERT RAMSDELL (PETE) GURNEY JR. has been called the John Cheever of playwrights, and no wonder. He writes almost exclusively and charmingly about the special folkways of upper middle-class American WASP's, and the other night, when one of his plays, ''The Middle Ages,'' opened Off Broadway, he showed up in the quintessential WASP uniform: gray flannels, blue blazer, button-down shirt, striped silk rep tie and 25-year-old cordovan shoes.

title: Strike Is Averted, Yonkers Reopens
description: A strike of parking attendants and security workers that could have kept harness-racing fans away from the reopening of Yonkers Raceway was settled about two hours before the first post time last night. A chief issue was wages.

title: PAUL TAYLOR-PETER MARTINS PROJECT
description: Although Paul Taylor has been making dances since the early 1950's, it was not until less than two weeks ago that he ever created a work for dancers who were not members of his own company. His first piece for dancers from another troupe is ''Musette,'' the duet for Suzanne Farrell and Peter Martins of the New York City Ballet that receives its world premiere tonight as part of the the Paul Taylor Dance Company's gala at the City Center.

title: CINDY'S INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: Results for the latest year include a gain from the sale of two motor inn properties to Southside Management Corp. and a loss from the sale of ceivables to Southside Management.

title: VERIFYING WEAPONS ACCORDS
description: While world attention has focused on the talks on intermediate-range nuclear forces in Europe - most recently, on President Reagan's proposed interim agreement limiting Soviet and American medium-range missiles and the rapid Soviet rejection of it - little attention has been paid to what could be the ultimate stumbling block in negotiations: verification. In light of a recent news report of Administration concern about possible Soviet violation of the SALT II agreement, and the difficulty of monitoring the weapons involved, discussions of insuring compliance are likely to focus increasingly on the central issue: on-site inspection.

title: FRANCES S. BRUNO
description: Frances S. Bruno, who helped run the Pen and Pencil Restaurant at 205 East 45th Street for many years, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Manhattan.

title: Allen Is Warned
description: Chet Simmons, commissioner of the United States Football League, says he sent a letter to George Allen, president and coach of the Chicago Blitz, warning that he will be fined if he makes any more statements critical of league operations. Allen has said the U.S.F.L. should not be considering expansion now.

title: Clabir Acquisition
description: The Clabir Corporation, a diversified holding company based in Old Greenwich, Conn., announced it had signed a letter of intent to acquire an 80 percent interest in an unnamed offshore financial services institution for $24 million. The transaction is subject to final approval of regulatory authorities and the boards of both companies. Clabir's president, Ralph R.M. Ehrmann, said the purchase would provide the company with ''great flexibility in achieving its planned growth.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Thursday about stock trading incorrectly reported when the Dow Jones industrial average reached its current record of 1,145.90. It was March 24.

title: Genuine Risk Foal Is Dead at Birth
description: The most eagerly awaited birth in the history of American thoroughbred racing ended sadly early yesterday morning when a chestnut colt by Secretariat out of Genuine Risk was born dead at Catoctin Stud in Waterford, Va.

title: COMMUTERS AS PLAINTIFFS
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS STARTS ITS TELETEXT SERVICE
description: The CBS television network began the first national, over-the-air electronic information service today even though the required decoding equipment is still not available to consumers.

title: People
description: * Jeff Diskin has joined M. Shanken Communications Inc. as vice president of marketing and advertising sales.

title: RECTISEL/EDI CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 27.
Western Talks With Wien Parent
description: Western Airlines Inc. said that it had resumed discussions about a merger with Household International Inc., the parent company of Wien Air Alaska.

title: Braniff Extension On Reorganization
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge gave Braniff International two more weeks to submit its long-awaited reorganization plan and the airline's chief executive said it would be filed by April 18.

title: New York Tribune Publishes; Paper Replaces News World
description: The New York Tribune began publication yesterday and its circulation director, Lew Zedicoff, said it had sold most of the 100,000 copies printed.

title: ELDER-BEERMAN STORES CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 30.
New Chairman For Goodyear
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company today named Robert E. Mercer, who has been chief executive officer since Jan. 1, to the additional post of chairman.

title: The Right Wife
description: Samuel D. Gordon died in 1965 and two women, both saying they were his widow, claimed the railroad worker's death benefits. Who was the real Mrs. Gordon?

title: Jobs Conference Seeks Speaker on Union Side
description: The United Steelworkers union is boycotting a national jobs conference because the United States Steel Corporation, whose chairman will introduce President Reagan at Wednesday's session, wants to import subsidized British steel.

title: THEATER: 'VIEUX CARRE' BY WILLIAMS IS REVIVED
description: THE art and life of Tennessee Williams intertwine in ''Vieux Carre,'' given a restorative revival by Stephen Zuckerman at the WPA Theater. A failure on Broadway in 1977, this is the first of the author's neglected works to be subjected, posthumously, to re-evaluation. More should follow.

title: PLAN TO HARNESS ENERGY OF TEACHERS AND PUPILS
description: A LITTLE tinkering with the schools will not bring about the changes necessary to improve them, according to John I. Goodlad, who has spent the last seven years on a research project called ''A Study of Schooling.'' The centerpiece of his reform proposal is the reorganization of schools into four-year units, in which teams of teachers assume responsibility for the total education of the students in each unit.

title: SEAVER FACES PHILS AT SHEA
description: New York's baseball season opens today in Shea Stadium with the Mets playing the Philadelphia Phillies and a rare display of pitching history on the mound: Tom Seaver against Steve Carlton, a pair of 38-year-old stars with seven Cy Young Awards and 549 victories between them.

title: WARNER AMEX CHOOSES CHIEF FOR HOME SPORTS
description: Joe Smith is a veteran of the record industry who hopes to make the transition to cable television - and sports cable at that. Mr. Smith, 54, is former chairman of Elektra/Asylum/Nonesuch Records, a unit of Warner Communications Inc. He has been named president and chief executive officer of Home Sports Entertainment, a regional sports network operated by Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc.

title: Q&A
description: Q. If March 20 was the spring equinox, why weren't the day and night each 12 hours long? On March 20, according to The Times, the time from sunrise to sunset was 12 hours 11 minutes. Also according to The Times, the time from sunrise to sunset on March 17, three days before the equinox, was 12 hours 1 minute. How come?

title: COLUMBIA ACTS TO CUT GAS SUPPLY
description: The Columbia Gas System, one of the nation's major suppliers of natural gas, said yesterday that its pipeline unit was invoking ''force majeure'' clauses in contracts with suppliers in an attempt to cut down on burgeoning supplies of natural gas.

title: INPUT BUSINESS MACHINES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: CAREY'S BROTHER RULED IMMUNE ON TAX CHARGE
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that Martin Carey, a brother of former Gov. Hugh L. Carey, could not be tried on charges of evading $122,000 in sales taxes on gasoline sold at a chain of stations he once controlled on Long Island.

title: HOW WALKER BEWILDERED WRANGLERS
description: They are called misdirection plays. The linebackers are led to believe that the ballcarrier will go one way, but then he goes the other way.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 1:35 P.M. Tom Seaver faces Steve Carlton, another 38-year-old, in Seaver's 14th openingday start, which will tie him with Walter Johnson for the majorleague record. Seaver is 6-1 on opening days, with six no-decisions; Johnson finished at 9-5. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Mariners, at Seattle. Billy Martin begins his third tenure as the Yankee manager with plenty of hitting but with a pitching staff that raises questions, despite seven shutouts during spring training. (Television - Channel 11, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770; 10:30 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 8:35 P.M. The foundering Knicks, home with a fourgame losing streak, need a victory in their drive for one of the two open playoff positions in the Eastern Conference. (Television - MSG Cable, 8:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; about 10:15 P.M., after Ranger broadcast, tape.) Nets vs. Washington Bullets, at Landover, Md. A Net victory would benefit the Knicks, who are only a game ahead of the Bullets. (Television - Channel 9, about 10:30 P.M., after Ranger telecast, tape. Radio -WVNJ, 620; 8 P.M.) Hockey Rangers vs. Philadelphia Flyers, Patrick Division semifinal, first game, at Philadelphia. Ed Mio will be the starting goaltender in the opener of the three-of-five-game series.

title: Turkish Court Puts Off A Verdict on Publisher
description: A military court today put off until May 9 its verdict in the case of a newspaper publisher accused of inciting people to violate existing legislation through his reprinting of an editorial first published in 1961.

title: Hitachi Videotape Move
description: Hitachi Ltd. will start making videotape recorders in West Germany three months earlier than originally planned, a company official said today. Production was originally scheduled to start in January 1984.

title: PEKING AIDE PROTESTS
description: A 19-year-old Chinese tennis player who defected from her country's team during a tournament in California last July has been granted political asylum.

title: Richard Neal, Played For the Jets and Saints
description: Richard Neal, former defensive captain of the New York Jets and the New Orleans Saints, died of heart failure at the age of 35 in St. Louis Sunday.

title: Texas Housing
description: A $125 million issue of the Texas Housing Agency's 9 percent bonds due in 1995 was tentatively priced at 100 by a Goldman, Sachs & Company group.
