The bond proceeds will be deposited in certificates of deposit at local savings and loan associations, which will then extend below-market rate financing for the construction of multifamily housing projects. Because the backing of the C.D.'s by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation also applies to bondholders' investments of up to $100,000, the Texas Housing issue was rated AAA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: FLUOROCARBON CO reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
IN SELECTING WORD PROCESSORS, SPEED COUNTS, SO DON'T HURRY
description: WORD processing is supposed to make the written life a lot easier. Sometimes it does, if you and the software happen to be naturally compatible. More often it doesn't. When you use a traditional instrument of inscription, such as a ballpoint or even a fountain pen, the manner in which you, say, cross out a word is more or less up to you. You can draw a line through it from left to right, or from right to left. For that matter, you can simply crumple up the sheet with the offending error on it and gracefully arch or violently propel it into the waste receptacle. Similar options to suit your particular style or mood may or may not be available in software for word processing.

title: NEW YORK PHONE ADDS A SURCHARGE OF 1.2%
description: The New York Telephone Company said yesterday it would include a 1.2 percent surcharge in monthly bills to recover $52.3 million it must pay the state under a plan to aid the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Rise in Insurance Rates Ordered on Jersey Cars
description: Insurance Commissioner Joseph F. Murphy today ordered a $19 surcharge on all automobile insurance policies in New Jersey, an additional $14 surcharge on all policies with collision or comprehensive coverage, and a 15 percent rate increase for State Farm Insurance.

title: RALEIGH CELEBRATES
description: Celebrating the last in a dramatic series of basketball victories, thousands of North Carolina State fans overran the campus and nearby streets tonight after the Wolfpack's 54-52 victory over Houston in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's championship game.

title: FOLLOWS UP
description: The Master Eagle Gallery has two large chambers set aside for display of art just behind the prosaic office spaces of the Master Eagle Family of Companies, a commercial graphic-arts complex of concerns on the sixth floor of 40 West 25th Street (924-8277).

title: News Analysis
description: Edward I. Koch made it one of his goals when he was running for office five years ago, and it has been a goal of his ever since: gaining control of the city's public school system.

title: QUICK RANGERS FACE FLYER FORECHECKING
description: About six weeks ago, before the Patrick Division standing had settled enough to determine which teams would oppose each other in the first round of the playoffs, a Philadelphia Flyers scout said the Flyers would prefer not to meet the Rangers in the first round.

title: CANADA PERMANENT INCOME INV reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
INTERNORTH DISCUSSING PLAN TO ACQUIRE BELCO
description: Internorth Inc. and the Belco Petroleum Company announced yesterday that they were considering a deal whereby Internorth would acquire Belco for as much as $700 million.

title: SOVIET CALLS REBUFF BY GROMYKO UNEQUIVOCAL
description: The official Soviet press agency said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had been unambiguous in rejecting President Reagan's latest arms control proposal.

title: Continental Plan
description: Continental Mortgage Investors, involved since 1976 in reorganization proceedings under the Bankruptcy Act, announced it had consummated its plan of reorganization as previously approved by the Massachusetts District Court and security holders.

title: NEW 'MUST' IN COLLEGE COURSES
description: FRESHMEN now enrolled at Hamline University in St. Paul, Minn., primarily a liberal arts institution, are in the first class at the school that will have to demonstrate ''computer literacy'' to graduate.

title: INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 5.
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $191,000. c-Net income. d-Including an extraordinary credit of $937,000.

title: Markets Closed
description: Stock, commodity and foreign exchange markets were closed yesterday in Britain, West Germany, France, Australia, Hong Kong and South Africa because of the Easter Monday holiday.

title: Series on Afghanistan Starts Tonight on TV
description: A three-part series on Soviet-occupied Afghanistan begins tonight on the ''CBS Evening News'' with Dan Rather.

title: MGF OIL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income The losses for the latest quarter and year include provisions of $47 million and $55.1 million, respectively, for additional depreciation depletion and amortization.

title: Prize Bank President Hopes to Avoid Snow
description: A local bank president, the raffle prize won today by a suburban Kansas City woman, said he hoped shoveling snow would not be included in his duties as servant for a day.

title: Looking for Czar
description: The Hartford Whalers announced last month that they were looking for a ''czar,'' a team president to oversee all operations of the National Hockey League team.

title: WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, APRIL 5, 1983
description: International

title: ROYALS BEAT ORIOLES IN OPENER
description: As the Orioles, the team with the best record in baseball for the last 26 years, opened their season today with a 7-2 loss to the Kansas City Royals, their manager for most of that time, Earl Weaver, was abusing a golf ball in Miami.

title: LITTLE-KNOWN ADVISER WHO HAS MAYOR'S EAR
description: Consider two stories about Daniel Wolf and Edward I. Koch: Mayor Koch, in a dispute with clergymen over his handling of the homeless population, wanted to write a strong letter in response. Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. says he tried, and failed, to get the Mayor to remove some acerbic paragraphs from a draft copy.

title: MGM/UA HOME ENTERTAINMENT GROUP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company was a division of MGM/UA Entertainment Co. until shortly before its initial public offering on Dec. 22, 1982.

title: NUTRITION WORLD INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
SIBERIAN TREASURE HUNT HITS A VEIN OF SKEPTICISM
description: For a newcomer stepping off an Aeroflot jet into the Yakutian night, the harshness of Siberia is immediate. The 3,500-mile flight from Moscow ends after midnight, and the plane taxis across a darkened field toward pillars of vapor pouring from service vehicles' exhausts. The only illumination comes from the vehicles' parking lights and a pale lamp atop the deserted terminal.

title: What Price Market-Rigging?
description: Should the penalties for antitrust violations be reduced? William Baxter, chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division, says yes. As part of a legislative package to make the economy more competitive, he would limit triple-damage awards to victims of pricefixing.

title: Portugal Is Off On Election Campaign
description: Political activists blanketed Portuguese cities with posters and graffiti today at the start of official campaigning for the April 25 general elections.

title: SOME IN HOUSE USE ELECTION CASH ON LUXURIES
description: Surplus campaign contributions for a growing number of members of the House go for costly clothes or travel for their wives, overseas trips and lodging in fine hotels. Reports filed with the Federal Election Commission detail these expenditures, along with more traditional uses of the excess cash in campaign treasuries, such as laying it aside for a future campaign, using it in a race for the Senate or spreading it around among colleagues who need campaign help.

title: APPLE CUTS PRICES ON COMPUTER LINE
description: Apple Computer Inc., striving to retain its position as the nation's leading producer of personal computers, said today that it had cut prices of its Apple III personal computers by up to 23 percent, and that it would end production of one Apple III model.

title: Re-funding Bond Issue, By Piladelphia Priced
description: A $160 million issue of A-rated Philadelphia water and sewer refunding bonds was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 10.013 percent for 9 7/8 percent bonds due in 2006 by underwriters led by the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group.

title: Carolina Bank To Cut Prime
description: The Wachovia Bank and Trust Company said today that it would cut its prime rate to 10 percent, from 10 1/2 percent, effective Wednesday.

title: SUSPECTED DROWNING REVIVES DISPUTE BY CITY'S 2 SCUBA TEAMS
description: Competing scuba teams from the Police and Fire Departments have been showing up at some underwater rescue missions in a year-and-ahalf dispute over jurisdiction.

title: 'GREAT CHESS MOVIE' AT FILM FORUM
description: ''THE GREAT CHESS MOVIE,'' which opens today at the Film Forum, is a practically perfect documentary of its kind. It's a funny, wise, passionate, witty inquiry into chess, which is called a game, and acknowledged to be ancient, though it might be more accurately described as a way of thinking about the world and dealing with it.

title: ELWAY GETS READY TO MAKE A CHOICE
description: It was very late at night last Thanksgiving. The street was dark, but a light shone from a window on the house on Flowering Plum Road in San Jose, Calif.

title: 2 Use Bow and Arrow To Cross Berlin Wall
description: Two East Berliners used a bow and arrow to shoot a line across the Berlin Wall, then glided to the West on a pulley 35 feet above the ground while guards were not looking, the West Berlin newspaper BZ said today.

title: Richard O'Brien, Hollywood Character Actor, 65, Is Dead
description: Richard O'Brien, one of Hollywood's busiest character actors, died of cancer at his home here March 29, an Actor's Fund spokesman said. He was 65 years old.

title: WATERMAN MARINE CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
LIBERTY FABRICS OF NEW YORK INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 13.
LUNCH FOR WOMEN: FOOD AND IDEAS
description: ''IT was so stimulating that when I got home, I couldn't get to sleep,'' said Blanche Ross, a partner in Ross Associates, a speakers' bureau. ''You can let your hair down and forget male-female gamesmanship,'' said Judy Licht, a television newswoman who will be joining the Metromedia Television News network this summer. ''You don't have to project an image, there's a relaxed, freewheeling atmosphere that fills a need,'' said Alice Young, a lawyer and managing partner of the New York office of Graham & James.

title: Careers; Courses In Foreign Business
description: THE world may not be their oyster for all M.B.A. degree candidates, but most graduate schools of business are putting added stress on international courses.

title: DODGERS DEFEAT ASTROS
description: Ken Landreaux drove in six runs, and Pedro Guerrero knocked in five with a homer and a triple to lead the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 16-7 rout of the Houston Astros tonight in their National League opener.

title: CONCERT: HASKELL SMALL
description: PERHAPS the surest way for a composer to bring his music to the public is to play it himself. Haskell Small is good enough a pianist to do just that, and Monday night in Alice Tully Hall he served as soloist, accompanist and chamber player in a number of his own pieces.

title: COMPANY CHANGING RULES FOR OPERATING SOME CAT SCANNERS
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it would issue new operating instructions for 238 advanced X-ray scanners that the Government says may expose patients to unnecessary radiation.

title: City's Port Chief Resigning
description: Linda W. Seale, the city's Commissioner of Ports and Terminals for two and a half years, submitted her resignation yesterday, effective June 30. Miss Seale said she was negotiating for a job in private industry.

title: Indiana Standard Seeks U.S. Output
description: The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) believes there are ample opportunities to find oil and gas in the United States, John E. Swearingen, chairman, told analysts.

title: KNICKS WIN IN OVERTIME
description: Bernard King scored 8 points in overtime, leading the Knicks to a 110-107 victory over the Detroit Pistons last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: LASERMETRICS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. Results reflect the consolidation of the financial statements of Laser Applications Inc. of Winter Park, Fla., which became a wholly owned subsidiary in the last quarter of 1982.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: WHAT follows, according to Donald Kirschenbaum, is a recent conversation between two white-coated people traveling in a crowded elevator between the sixth and seventh floors of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: Market Place; Funeral-Tied Stocks Gain
description: SMALL ''niche'' industries often do very well for their stockholders. One example is the funeral-related business, consisting of a handful of publicly owned companies.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 25.
47 SOVIET OFFICIALS EXPELLED BY PARIS ON SPYING CHARGES
description: France expelled 47 Soviet diplomats, journalists and others today, accusing them of espionage. The Interior Ministry said their activities had centered on high technology and the armed forces.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: A Williamsburg Summit or Pageant?
description: The seven Presidents and Prime Ministers of the democratic industrial powers will gather in Williamsburg, Va., over Memorial Day weekend for the ninth annual economic summit meeting. This good idea was reduced to a pageant of posturing politicians the last two times out. President Reagan, this year's host, promises an effort to create an atmosphere for listening as well as talking, but there are disturbing signs that nothing much will come of it.

title: JOSEPH LUBIN, PHILANTHROPIST AND BUSINESSMAN, DIES AT 83
description: Joseph I. Lubin, co-founder of the Eisner & Lubin nationwide accounting firm, who gave more than $10 million to universities, died of a heart ailment Monday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: GUIDE GETS BIGGERS AS AUTHOR STAYS THIN
description: ''I HONESTLY didn't know what I was letting myself in for,'' said Egon Ronay a few days after the publication of his 1983 guide. This is the 25th anniversary of what has become an annual bible for travelers in Britain who want to find good hotels and good food in a country where it is still not easy to find either.

title: HUNGRY BANGLADESH THREATENS TO BURST ITS SEAMS
description: The village of Tingaon, south of here, looks idyllic and abundantly prosperous in the warmth of a spring afternoon. Its bamboo huts nestle atop a small, man-made mesa, built to keep them safe when monsoon rains flood the green rice fields that stretch in every direction.

title: Rally at N.C. State 'Happiest Moment'
description: Greeted by an overflow crowd of about 20,000 people in Reynolds Coliseum, the North Carolina State Wolfpack came home today to celebrate its victory over top-ranked Houston in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship game.

title: LOW-INCOME HOUSING CERTIFICATES: RENT CAPS PLUS FLEXIBILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Rioters in Brazil Protest Economic Conditions
description: The police drove back a mob attacking the governor's palace today, but rioting over unemployment and the high cost of living continued here into the night. It was the second day of violent protest.

title: NAME DROPPING
description: When Michael Mathias Prechtl, artist of Nuremberg, looks at someone he sees, along with a mere face, the elements that characterize his subject's public image as well. These unusual perspectives may be viewed among the 50 watercolors and lithographs brightening the upstairs gallery walls of Goethe House New York, 1014 Fifth Avenue, at 84th Street (744-8310).

title: Miss Potter Wins In a Tiebreaker
description: Barbara Potter, playing in her first clay-court event in four and one-half years, defeated Wendy White, 2-6, 6-2, 7-6, today in the second round of the $200,000 Family Circle Cup tennis tournament.

title: NUCLEAR WASTE SITE DECISIVELY REJECTED IN WISCONSIN VOTING
description: Voters rejected the idea of a high-level radioactive waste dump in Wisconsin today in early returns in an innovative referendum.

title: Kerr-McGee
description: The Kerr-McGee Corporation said that its earnings for the first two months of 1983 were $18 million, down from $30.5 million a year earlier, and added that the trend probably continued in March. It said 1983 first-quarter earnings would be below last year's $29.2 million, or 56 cents a share. That included a nonrecurring charge of $17 million after taxes.

title: HUNTINGTON HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
CORNING GLASS WORKS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $22.2 million from the exchange of Owens-Corning Fiberglas stock for Corning Glass Work shares.

title: LET LATINS ALONE
description: A citizen unversed in Central American affairs may nonetheless inquire what United States interest is supposed to justify the political costs of breast-beating intervention in the growing-up process of an incidental neighbor.

title: BROKER INDICTED IN TOLEDO
description: Edward P. Wolfram Jr., formerly the managing partner of Bell & Beckwith, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Toledo, Ohio, on charges that he had engaged in a scheme to defraud in violation of the Federal securities laws.

title: Memorial for Marjorie Guthrie Planned; Aided Disease Study
description: A memorial service will be held today for Marjorie Guthrie, who died March 13. Mrs. Guthrie, the wife of the folksinger Woody Guthrie, had worked since her husband's death from Huntington's disease in 1967 to aid families of Huntington's disease victims and to develop support for research.

title: Everthing Under Control
description: Tom Seaver called it ''a very emotional day,'' and he tried not to let the emotions spoil the day. He said he could feel the emotions around him and within him as he walked out of the bullpen yesterday afternoon, for his first official game as a New York Met since the old management shipped him away on June 15, 1977.

title: 1. An Amish Look
description: As soon as designers decided that women should wear hats again, fashionable women decided that what they really wanted were men's hats. That gave Peter Bradley and Larry Dupuis an idea. While shopping for their antiques store in Sag Harbor, they came upon a factory that makes hats for Amish men. So the partners decided to have the hats changed just slightly for women's heads. Thus, Tryons by Bradley/Dupuis were born. There are three broad-brimmed styles in natural straw. The farmworker's hat has a perforated crown. The others are ''go-to-meeting'' hats - one with a flat crown, one with a round crown. They are $25 each at Henri Bendel.

title: TAINTED SLUDGE TO BE REMOVED IN CONNECTICUT
description: A major Connecticut toxic-waste treatment company has agreed to begin removing a contaminated sludge pile from its plant in downtown Waterbury, officials announced yesterday.

title: Prime Computer
description: Prime Computer Inc. said it expected to report that net income for the first quarter fell about 20 percent from a year earlier, although it expected to post higher sales. In the 1982 quarter, Prime earned $10.6 million on revenues of $103.2 million. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Prime plunged $7, to $34, on volume of 2,090,000 shares.

title: Islanders Settle For No.3 in Draft
description: A year and a half ago, the Islanders traded Dave Cameron and Bob Lorimer in a deal that Bill Torrey hoped would give his team the first choice in the National Hockey League's amateur draft this June. In acquiring the first-round selection of the Colorado Rockies, Torrey was rooting for that team, which subsequently became the New Jersey Devils, to have the worst record in the league this season.

title: KINDER-CARE LEARNING CENTERS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 18.
Xerox Price Cut
description: The Xerox Corporation cut the price of its basic 820-II model personal computer, including processor, keyboard and display screen, by 26 percent, to $1,795. The 820-II with 5 1/4-inch, double-sided, double-density dual drive was reduced by 23 percent, to $2,995.

title: U.S. SPURS ALLIED TIES AT U.N.
description: The United States and the European Community, increasingly concerned about their differences at the United Nations, have begun to discuss closer cooperation, Western diplomats here said today.

title: Montero Vehicle Priced
description: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America said today that its new Montero model, a four-wheel-drive utility vehicle, would be introduced this month at $9,229.

title: REAGAN NOT MOVED BY G.O.P. CRITICISM ON 10% ARMS RISE
description: President Reagan was described today as staying with his proposal for 10 percent growth in the military budget as he met with key Senate Republicans and heard warnings that his spending goal would never make it out of their budget committee.

title: REPORTS OF ANTI-SANDINIST AID WORRY SENATORS
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, said today that many of his Senate colleagues were deeply worried about reports the Reagan Administration was actively supporting a guerrilla movement against the Government of Nicaragua.

title: Calumet Prizes In Dispute
description: A court here has been asked to decide who owns Calumet Farm's trophy collection, spanning 40 years of thoroughbred racing victories and said to be worth millions.

title: AMICOR INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $16,000 for the quarter and $116,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $111,000 for the quarter and a gain of $6,000 for the year from discontinued operations.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest periods include $1.5 million from the settlement of litigation with Mini-Technology Inc. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for compensated absences.

title: GEORGE UHE
description: George Uhe, founder of the George Uhe Company, brokers and agents in oils, spices and chemicals, died Sunday in Boca Raton, Fla., after a stroke. He was 83 years old and had retired to Boca Raton from Manhattan about five years ago.

title: Saab May Build in U.S.
description: Saab-Scania AB of Sweden is expected to decide by June 1 whether to build a bus plant in the United States, according to Automotive News. The industry publication said on Monday that the plant might be placed near the company's headquarters in Orange, Conn.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: By the middle of the week, they had created a monster on the observatory deck of the Empire State Building. It wasn't King Kong. It was a publicity campaign larger, more frightening, more inexorable. It wrapped itself around the top of the building and pounded its chest. There were buttons. There were posters. There were live television broadcasts. There was a sign that said ''King Kong World Media Headquarters.'' There were competing public-relations executives, smiling. There were quotes that had been carefully crafted.

title: ZOOS COME TO AID OF TEEN-AGER BITTEN BY VIPER STOLEN FROM CAGE IN WASHINGTON
description: A 16-year-old boy was reported to be recovering from a near-fatal snake bite today after a frantic overnight effort by doctors to gather lifesaving serum from zoos along the East Coast.

title: TV: RIGHTS OF CHILDREN IS SUBJECT OF CBS MOVIE
description: WHEN a bunch of talented people take on a subject that is sensitive and complicated, the project is at least promising. Such is the case with ''In Defense of Kids,'' a made-for-television movie on CBS-TV tonight at 9 o'clock.

title: New Computer By Honeywell
description: Honeywell Inc., the Minneapolis-based electronics company, hopes to increase its share of the computer market with a new personal computer and the software that goes with it, saidJames R. Pompa, an associate group vice president.

title: Dead Woman Is Identified
description: A 23-year-old woman found shot to death Monday in an apartment at 301 East 79th Street has been identified as Delores Lola Borden, the police said yesterday. Whether she was a victim of homicide or a suicide has not yet been determined. The police said she had been found by Patchel Landis, a 42-year-old jewelry designer, who rented the apartment and sometimes let her stay there.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: The Forgotten Farmers
description: The State and Defense departments haven't had much success in dealing with the Russians lately, and the notion in this corner is that maybe the problem should be turned over to the Department of Agriculture.

title: 2 PIANOS SERVE AS TOOLS OF DIPLOMACY
description: When Adrien F.J. Meisch, the Ambassador from Luxembourg, ends his nine-year assignment to the United States this month, the diplomatic tools of the trade that he will pack up will include not only his pin-stripe trousers but also two grand pianos.

title: CHICAGO RIVALS AIMING FOR UNDECIDED WHITES
description: Both candidates in this city's racially polarized mayoral contest made major shifts today in their television advertising campaigns in a bid to zero in on the undecided white voters expected to play a decisive role in next Tuesday's election.

title: Gilels, Soviet Pianist, Plans Carnegie Recital
description: The Soviet pianist Emil Gilels, who last played in this country in 1979, will give a recital in Carnegie Hall April 16 at 2 P.M. Mr. Gilels's engagement was arranged through contacts between Sy Rosen, the artistic director of Carnegie Hall, and Anatoly Dyushev, the cultural attache of the Soviet Embassy in Washington.

title: U.S. AIDE DEFENDS BILL BOLSTERING TRADE CURBS
description: The Reagan Administration wants tougher controls over exports of technologically advanced equipment to Western nations to prevent possible diversion to the Soviet Union, Lionel H. Olmer, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade Administration, said today.

title: Economic Scene; Structural Joblessness
description: CAN the problem of structural unemployment be solved - and without radical change in the economic system? The answer lies in whether the impact of the new technology, based on microelectronic ''brains,'' is substantively different from that of all the earlier types of machinery to which capitalist societies successfully adjusted in the past.

title: For London's Easter, A $7 Million Robbery
description: Six gunmen stole the equivalent of at least $7.5 million from a security company's London headquarters over the extended Easter weekend, making the robbery the largest cash haul in British history, the authorities said today.

title: AUTHOR WHO CHECKMATED ACADEME
description: John Milton (1608-74) of Cheapside, London, indirectly helped Walter Tevis of New York by way of Lexington, Ky., to write his latest novel, ''The Queen's Gambit.'' It's a suspense story about chess, with a young heroine who takes on the Russian world champion at high noon.

title: Warhol and the Bridge
description: Andy Warhol's colorful new poster of the Brooklyn Bridge will serve a double function - as the bridge's official 100th-birthday poster and the official poster for Artexpo.

title: Arthur Cady, Painter And Art Director, 63
description: Arthur Cady, painter of cityscapes and landscapes, died yesterday of a heart attack in Brewster, N.Y. He was 63 years old. Mr. Cady's paintings were characterized by a sharp, distant, northern light and a small-town sense of intimacy and optimism. His work conveyed a deep, almost pantheistic affection for everything he painted, for the earth and particularly the sky, and for such mainstays of rural life as country stores, gas stations and rocking chairs.

title: Q&A
description: Q. More than 50 years ago my father would make root beer at home and the children of the family loved it. None of us can recall how it was made. Can you tell me the ingredients of root beer?

title: Article 081052 -- No Title
description: The Federal Government today began the process of distributing $100 million in emergency aid to the needy and the homeless.

title: BROOK'S BUNT IS KEY TO RALLY
description: The names of pitchers were bouncing back and forth like Ping-Pong balls in the exuberance of the Mets' locker room. Seaver. Sisk. Carlton. Almost ignored in the postgame enthusiasm were the two players whose bats figured in the runs that sent the Phillies to their opening-day defeat at Shea Stadium.

title: DISUVERO OUT OF WHITNEY
description: A sculpture by Mark di Suvero that was to be one of the centerpieces of the sculpture court of the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris will not be ready for the opening this Friday. The Whitney will bring in a painting by Alfred Jensen to replace it.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR TROUPE
description: LOOKING at the sublime second movement of ''Mercuric Tidings,'' the extraordinary work Paul Taylor choreographed to Schubert recently, one was ready to forgive him anything last night.

title: Bridge:; A Book by Kantar Focuses On Some Defense Matters
description: Most experts would agree that defense is more difficult than dummy play. Yet the average player who works to improve devotes little of his attention to this vital area.

title: 'The Greatest Star of Them All'
description: In the 1950 film ''Sunset Boulevard'' an aging, out-of work actress named Norma Desmond, seeing her young self in an old movie, cried out ''They don't make faces like that anymore.''

title: DAVID PRIMIS
description: David Primis, a former sales manager of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Valley Stream, L.I. He was 73 years years old.

title: RATES FALL AS BUYING QUICKENS
description: Interest rates fell sharply yesterday after two weeks of light activity in which they hardly moved. The decline amounted to almost a quarter of a percentage point for some short-term issues and a tenth of a percentage point for longterm Treasury bonds. In the last two weeks, short-term rates had risen slightly while long-term issues were almost unchanged.

title: Lockheed Outlines Staff Reorganization
description: The Lockheed Corporation said yesterday that it would consolidate 24 different line and staff functions into four groups. Hal Hurlocker, the spokesman for the company, said in an interview that Roy A. Anderson, the chairman and chief executive officer, and L.O. Kitchen, the president and chief operating officer, had found it difficult to keep track of the operating companies,

title: G.M.'S 10-DAY SALES OFF
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that, based on the daily selling rate, its sales fell 5 percent from the 1982 level in the March 21-31 period.

title: REAGAN PLANS TO VISIT CENTER FOR COMPUTER TRAINING TODAY
description: Shortly after he arrives in Pittsburgh about noon Wednesday, President Reagan will head for Control Data Center on the city's North Side, where 135 unemployed steelworkers and other laid-off factory workers are learning to repair and install computers.

title: New Trial Asked On Groucho Marx Estate
description: Erin Fleming's attorney today requested a new trial on the Groucho Marx estate, contending that the Bank of America had hidden a diary kept by the comedian in his last years.

title: MATSUSHITA SHOWS AN ERASABLE DISK
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company yesterday demonstrated what is believed to be the first optical disk that can be erased and re-used, a development that will make optical disks more competitive with magnetic tapes and disks for information storage and retrieval.

title: Kissinger Joins Drive
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State and a lifelong soccer fan, has joined a growing campaign to obtain the 1986 World Cup competition for the United States despite last week's rejection by the World Cup's preliminary screening committee. Declaring that a United States World Cup ''would be tremendous for the sport and for the United States,'' Mr. Kissinger said that he had been in touch with international soccer officials and would testify tomorrow before a House subcommittee examining the issue. ... Tom Werblin, the Cosmos' general manager, says he is optimistic that the club will sign Franz Beckenbauer, the 37-year-old former West German star who played four sensational seasons with the team before leaving in 1980. ''If everything works out, we'll sign him,'' said Werblin, who said the Cosmos would hold a news conference today to announce Beckenbauer's status.

title: JERSEY RAIL PACT IS TURNED DOWN BY PART OF UNION
description: A faction of the United Transportation Union today rejected the contract that ended the 34-day railroad strike in New Jersey, and the leader of the group threatened a new walkout unless economic benefits were improved.

title: Sale by Petrolane
description: Petrolane Inc. of Long Beach, Calif., said it had agreed to sell its Advanced Health Systems Inc. subsidiary to the Horizon Health Corporation of Dallas for about $65 million in cash, notes and preferred stock. Advanced Health Systems encompasses all of Petrolane's health-care activities, including alcoholism treatment hospitals and the management of general, acute-care hospitals in rural areas. Horizon operates 20 specialty psychiatric and substance abuse programs in nine states.

title: Drug Deals in U.S.  Said to Aid Castro
description: A former Cuban agent testified in Manhattan yesterday that his work for the Cuban Government as a drug dealer in the United States had earned $7 million for the Castro regime, which is starved for foreign currency.

title: SUPERMARKETS ENTER THE AGE OF SPECIALTY FOODS
description: ''I MAKE my spaghetti sauce with tomatoes and meatballs,'' the butcher was telling a customer. ''But you know, if it says 'beef stock,' you've got to use those cubes.'' The conversation was unremarkable except for its location - over a meat case filled with fresh pheasants, squabs, partridges, quails and prime meat. At the Grand Union on East 86th Street.

title: Market Continues Slide; Dow Off 7.45
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday, with some of the technology issues registering the largest losses. Trading accelerated from Monday.

title: LIPTON, THOMAS J, INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
YANKEES EDGED BY MARINERS
description: Neither their new lineup nor their old complaints about umpiring helped the Yankees begin the baseball season with a victory tonight. Steve Kemp, an important part of the new lineup, rapped three hits, including a home run, and drove in two runs, but the Seattle Mariners won, 5-4, on a sacrifice fly by Al Cowens in the seventh inning.

title: RANGERS TAKE PLAYOFF OPENER
description: Beaten by the Rangers in their last two meetings of the regular season, the Flyers felt compelled to exercise some caution early in tonight's opening-round playoff game at the Spectrum here.

title: A Japanese Carryout
description: These days there are almost as many carryouts as supermarkets on street corners. But a Japanese carryout, if not unique, is certainly rare. A tiny one has opened in Greenwich Village and has some offerings that are a delightful respite from the overly mayonnaised or oily salads that so many carryouts offer.

title: German Metalworkers
description: The West German metalworkers' union and the industry's employers group urged workers today to accept a 3.2 percent pay increase for the current year. Their call followed the signing of a one-year wage accord for that amount on behalf of one million metalworkers in North Rhine-Westphalia.

title: BALDWIN POSTS LOSS IN QUARTER
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation, deep in negotiations to postpone payment of more than $700 million in short-term debt, yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $2.8 million and a net income of $66.3 million for all of 1982, down sharply from 1981.

title: CAMBODIAN-THAI BORDER BATTLES SUBSIDE
description: Fighting between Vietnamese troops and Cambodian insurgents reportedly subsided today along the Thai-Cambodian border northeast of here.

title: MGM/UA Has Profit in Period
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company yesterday reported earnings of $15.4 million, or 31 cents a share, for the fiscal second quarter, ended Feb. 28, contrasted with a loss of $5 million in the period a year earlier. Operating revenue for the entertainment conglomerate fell 16.9 percent, to $158.2 million, from $190.3 million.

title: STATE TO RESCUE STRATFORD STAGE WITH PURCHASE
description: The American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, threatened with foreclosure, was rescued today when the State of Connecticut announced that it would use $1 million of Federal money to buy the theater's property.

title: Times Microfilms Licensed to Xerox
description: The New York Times Company and the Xerox Corporation announced yesterday that they had signed an exclusive licensing agreement under which University Microfilms International, which is owned by Xerox, will take over the production and marketing of microfilms of The New York Times and The Times Index.

title: Advertising; HTH Pool Chlorinator Campaign
description: WITH much excitement, Grey Advertising recently extended an invitation to ''see something new'' that it had created for the Olin Corporation, which was added to the client list last August.

title: State Notes, Due Today, Given M.I.G.-2 Rating
description: New York State's $3.9 billion of notes, scheduled to be offered today, were assigned by Moody's Investors Service its second-highest rating, M.I.G.-2, yesterday. The rating was the same as it was for the $500 million of state notes sold in January, but was lower than the M.I.G.-1 rating assigned at last year's spring note sale.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to March 12.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $4.8 million.

title: California Bonds Drawing Buyers
description: California's $200 million of Aa-rated general obligation bonds were offered through underwriters led by the Bank of America, with yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 8 percent in 1993 and 9 percent in 1999 to 2008.

title: STAGE, 'FOOLSFIRE,' A TRIO OF HILARITY
description: THE last time that those comic marvels Bob Berky, Fred Garbo and Michael Moschen were in residence with a clown show at the Dance Theater Workshop's late-night Economy Tires Theater, they posed the title question, ''Is 60 Minutes Enough?'' It certainly wasn't. In response, the trio has returned with the full-length ''Foolsfire,'' reprising a few of the choice numbers from the earlier show and adding new airborne material. The result is helium-light and hilarious.

title: HOW $60 CHECK BECAME $30
description: Last December, without giving it much thought, Denis Caslon, a 48-year-old Manhattan schoolteacher, routinely deposited a $60 check that a Canadian friend had sent him. Almost two and a half months later, following a process that involved four different banks and two separate fees, his bank credited him with $30, or just half his original check. And thereby hangs a tale.

title: Noisy Debate
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, who defends the World Boxing Association's lightweight title May 27 against Kenny (Bang Bang) Bogner in South Africa, got in the first shot in the battle of nicknames.

title: CONNECTICUT DEFIES U.S. LAW AND BANS DOUBLE-RIG TRUCKS
description: Connecticut today banned tandem-trailer trucks in defiance of a new Federal law permitting the larger rigs to use Interstate System highways beginning Wednesday.

title: Oak Industries
description: Oak Industries said it had withdrawn an application to build and operate a satellite that would have been used for a direct-to-home broadcast satellite system.

title: MONCHIK-WEBER CORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net income

title: AMERICAN SECURITY CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-After securities losses of $412,000 for the latest first quarter and $175,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: MODERATE MOOD FOUND AT 3D WORLD MEETING
description: The Group of 77, which now comprises about 120 developing countries, began a ministerial meeting here today amid signs of an emerging mood of moderation in their demands on the industrialized world.

title: Reagan Extends Public Panel Dealing With Drunken Driving
description: President Reagan today extended the life of a public commission dealing with drunken driving and praised the group for promoting greater highway safety.

title: HERITAGE GROUP INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Feb 19.
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ''REACH out and touch someone,'' American Telephone and Telegraph urges potential callers. The advertisement reflects on the conditions of life for millions of Americans: distant, isolated, lonely.

title: Second Condor Chick Is Hatched With Help
description: The second California condor chick hatched in captivity pecked its way out of its shell at the San Diego Zoo today, five days after the first, with the help of a keeper using a tiny chisel.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Department of Housing and Urban Development sold $1 billion of housing project notes that were offered by various securities firms with yields ranging from 4.65 percent for notes due in November 1983 to 5.05 percent for those due in May 1984.

title: VETA GRANDE COMPANIES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $73,000. c-Net income including an extraor= dinary tax credit of $280,000.

title: A SWEDISH COOK WHO BROUGHT HER ART TO AMERICA
description: SWEDISH food has long been a particular favorite of mine. I love herring dishes and Swedish pea soup and pancakes and a dish called Jansson's Temptation, and I consider well-made Swedish meatballs one of the great regional specialties of the world.

title: WAGING THE PEACE RACE
description: Our negotiations, you will recall, began when satellite photography revealed that the Western bloc was bristling with some 32 million peace demonstrators, while the Soviet Union had only 27. We advised the Russians that we were as unhappy with this disproportion as they must be and said we would not regard an increase in the number of Soviet peace demonstrators as a threatening buildup for peace.

title: HOUSE PANEL TOLD OF GAPS IN ETHICS LAW
description: A Congressional subcommittee, exploring ways to close what the chairman called loopholes in Federal laws on conflicts of interest, today questioned the process used to review the personal finances of several top Reagan Administration officials before they took office.

title: 5 Killed in Crash Of Bus and Truck
description: A tractor-trailer truck collided with a bus carrying mentally retarded and handicapped adults today, killing five people and injuring 16 others on the bus, a spokesman for the Chenango County Sheriff's office said.

title: Further Changes Made At State Loan Agency
description: The chairman of the state's Mortgage Loan Enforcement and Administration Corporation, Meyer S. Frucher, resigned Monday, and the organization's executive vice president, Lawrence Volk, was dismissed yesterday, according to a spokesman for its parent agency, the State Urban Development Corporation.

title: Nets Start Slowly, Fall to Bullets, 95-89
description: Incentive plays a particularly important role this part of the season. Teams such as the Bullets are fighting to stay in the race for the playoffs. And teams like the Nets, who have already clinched a berth in postseason play, have little incentive.

title: BISHOPS' LETTER ON NUCLEAR ARMS IS REVISED TO 'MORE FLEXIBLE' VIEW
description: A committee of Roman Catholic bishops today issued a revised draft of a proposed pastoral letter opposing nuclear arms that its leader, Joseph Cardinal Bernardin, called ''more flexible'' in meeting the criticisms of Government and church leaders.

title: DIGITAL COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
People
description: * Harvey Gabor has joined MCA Advertising as senior vice president-creative director.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: HIGH-FIRED STONEWARE
description: THERE is nothing like a brick or stone oven for making bread with a thick, crisp crust and moist center. Brick helps maintain a constant oven temperature and reflects heat evenly, something electric ovens cannot duplicate. Some people try to simulate the effect of brick by laying tiles on their oven racks while baking. This can make a difference, but it doesn't quite match the real thing. The most satisfactory alternative I have found is a high-fired stoneware container called La Cloche.

title: PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: A SUPPLY-SIDER'S PREMATURE VICTORY CELEBRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Marietta Contract
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation won a $179 million Navy contract for six vertical launching systems and ancillary equipment and services, the Defense Department said.

title: David Williamson, 87, Foreign Service Officer
description: David Williamson, a former Foreign Service officer, died Monday at Easton (Md.) Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Chestertown, Md., where he had a dairy farm.

title: British Steel Strike Widens
description: A strike over layoffs at the specialty steel operations of the British Steel Corporation spread to eight plants today, involving 10,000 workers.

title: Burma Reports Rebel Toll
description: The Government says 285 rebels and 99 of its soldiers were killed in an offensive that ended Monday. It said 24 rebels were captured and 36 surrendered. It said 388 of its men were wounded.

title: Ex-Aide to Shultz Is Dean at Chicago
description: John P. Gould Jr., a former special assistant and consultant on economic affairs to George P. Shultz, was named dean of the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business yesterday, succeeding Richard Rosett. An active proponent of the Chicago approach to business education, Mr. Gould is expected to encourage the school's theoretical style while placing increasing emphasis on its link to business realities.

title: 'Tombstone' Ad Shown on Cable TV
description: Yesterday, Morgan Stanley & Company, an investment banking firm, with the help of Doremus & Company and its parent, Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, broke new ground in video commercials that may never win the approval of the vast hoards of tube watchers. It introduced ''tombstone'' advertising, probably the most boring advertising in print, to cable television.

title: Sitting Ducks Are Targets for City
description: More than three-fourths of the cars parked illegally in midtown Manhattan are occupied, the city's Transportation Commissioner said yesterday. But a ''sitter'' in your illegally parked car may no longer save you from a ticket.

title: New I.B.M. Models
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, which periodically adds to its family of computers, announced new versions of its Series-1 and System-38 computers with double the maximum internal memory capability and other enhancements. Purchase prices for the new Series-1 model range from $14,150 to $89,700, with subsystems. Prices for the System-38 range from $160,000 to $252,990, depending on capacity.

title: U.S. STUDY OF SUGAR IMPORTS SET
description: The White House said today that it had ordered a review of quotas governing imports of sugar by the United States from Central America, apparently in an attempt to put economic pressure on Nicaragua.

title: Family Hailed At White House
description: President Reagan exchanged gifts today with Rachel and Carl Rossow of Ellington, Conn., and their 14 children, 11 of whom are severely handicapped.

title: Red Carpet for Democrats
description: Choosing among cities that want to be the scene of the next Presidential nominating convention is one of those political rituals that can be a little hard on the waistline and liver of the chooser. Such facilities as a big hall, plenty of hotel rooms and good transportation are the first things a competing city trots out for party officials, but second comes hospitality, lots and lots of it.

title: Peking Sees 'Grave Incident'
description: Qi Huaiyuan, director of the Chinese Foreign Ministry's information department, accused the United States today of creating a ''grave incident'' by granting political asylum to Hu Na, the tennis player. He said the decision would hurt sports and cultural exchanges and overall relations. Mr. Qi said China would ''make stern representations to the United States side.''

title: JAPAN ACCEPTS PLAN TO AID ECONOMY
description: The Japanese Cabinet today approved a package of measures intended to stimulate the domestic economy and hasten the arrival of an anticipated recovery.

title: Red Cross Taking Over Colombia Quake Relief
description: The state governor's committee administering relief to survivors of the Popayan earthquake bowed to charges of inefficiency, profiteering and misuse of relief supplies today and announced it would let the Red Cross take over.

title: STATE'S NEW TAX ON OIL CONCERNS RENEWS DISPUTE
description: Governor Cuomo has balanced his budget with the help of a $200 million tax on oil companies. But the companies and an investment rating service are questioning whether the tax can be collected.

title: Race May Lose Star
description: Fifteen teams and 75 riders are set to begin the three-day, 225-mile inaugural Tour de America bicycle race from Virginia Beach to Washington Friday morning. But, according to race officials, Bernard Hinault, a four-time winner of the famed Tour de France, has told them that he will probably miss the event because French cycling officials have reneged on a promise to excuse him from a French race this weekend.

title: Festival Commemorates Poe's New York Sojourn
description: An Edgar Allan Poe festival, commemorating the writer's residence in New York City almost 140 years ago, begins tonight at 7 o'clock with a free reading of his poems by the New York Poetry Forum at Lehman College.

title: Southmark Plan
description: The Southmark Corporation said it had agreed to acquire the Pacific Standard Life Company for $30 million of Southmark series A preferred stock. Pacific Standard, a life insurance company, has $150 million in assets.

title: DANCE: OPENING OF LOS ANGELES BALLET
description: THE Los Angeles Ballet returned to New York last night for the first time since 1980, and its performance at the Joyce Theater, which opened a week's engagement, revealed that the company remains pleasant-looking and talented.

title: Real Estate; Arguments Rage Over Gains Tax
description: WITH its recent approval by the Legislature as part of the new state budget, the capital gains tax on real estate transactions has come full circle.

title: U.S. URGES SUPPORT FOR KING HUSSEIN
description: The Reagan Administration appealed today to Palestinian and Arab leaders to give support to King Hussein of Jordan and not to lose what it called ''this unique moment'' for reviving the Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Interpace Officers In Bid for Company
description: The Interpace Corporation, a construction materials company based in Parsippany, N.J., said yesterday that the First Boston Corporation had conveyed an offer from a new company wishing to acquire Interpace for nearly $132 million.

title: ARAFAT LEAVES JORDAN, WITH NO SIGN OF AN ACCORD
description: Three days of talks between King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, ended today with no indication that the two men had fashioned a joint strategy for a Middle East peace plan.

title: From the City, A Salute to Segovia
description: For his 90th birthday and for his 55 years of New York concerts - if not specifically for his stature as a teacher - Andres Segovia received an apple yesterday at a Gracie Mansion reception.

title: WIDE U.S. SAVINGS PROJECTED
description: The Government could save $54.7 billion over the next three years by aggressively streamlining operations through measures ranging from cutting Civil Service retirement benefits to charging fees for collecting firewood on Federal lands, a Reagan Administration study group said today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Party vs. Race in Chicago
description: Representative Harold Washington has one powerful reason to expect to be elected Chicago's first black mayor next Tuesday: by the accident of white disunity in a primary, he became the Democratic Party's candidate in a devoutly Democratic city. No Republican has won a citywide contest in Chicago in over 50 years.

title: Court Rejects Conrail Closings
description: Conrail lost a round in its campaign to close through routes over its lines to competing railroads in order to become more profitable. A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit in Chicago ruled that a Conrail study that provided the basis for thousands of route closings approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission did not provide sufficient evidence to justify the closings.

title: Pennsylvania Derailment Spills Oil in French Creek
description: A Conrail freight train derailed today, spilling about 60,000 gallons of crude oil into French Creek, creating a 20-mile oil slick that threatened wildlife in the popular fishing stream.

title: 9 TIN MEN, 200 INNINGS, 400 TIMES AT BAT
description: I CAN'T bring myself to join the ululation over how many hours America's young people spend playing video games. I was a protoaddict myself - long before the games went electronic.

title: President of McCulloch Optimistic About Future
description: Donald V. Marchese, president of the McCulloch Corporation and engineer of the leveraged buyout of McCulloch from its parent, the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, is optimistic about the future of the money-losing chain saw maker. Mr. Marchese heads a group of 13 private investors including seven McCulloch officials that completed the purchase of McCulloch last week.

title: ISLANDERS BEGIN CUP DEFENSE
description: Are these the same Islanders? Is this the team that rolled to three straight Stanley Cup championships, at times appearing to win with nonchalance?

title: Outlook Bleak For Pacers
description: There is a ''very high probability'' that the Indiana Pacers will move or fold before next season, according to their general manager, Bob Salyers. He gave that assessment today in announcing a decrease for 1983-84 in the club's ticket prices. After talking with the owner, Sam Nassi, who lives in California, Salyers said: ''Yesterday I would have said there's a possibility the team might not be here next year. Today there's a very high probability.''

title: A TICKET TO THE ROAD IN 13 LANGUAGES
description: An old complaint here holds that the capital city lacks diversity and that everything centers on a single industry, the Federal Government. But when it comes to ethnic diversity, there are now so many groups in Washington that you can hardly walk down the street without hearing a foreign language.

title: Japan Studies Beef Quotas
description: Japan's top agriculture official said today that his nation must reach a domestic consensus about expanding its quotas on beef and orange imports before resuming talks with the United States.

title: AN ON-AGAIN, OFF-AGAIN TAX CUT WON'T DO
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Ends Inquiry
description: The European Commission today officially dropped an antidumping inquiry against imports of Japanese videotape recorders following Japan's recent agreement to limit growth of its sales to Europe this year. European makers of the machines have withdrawn their complaint, lodged last December, against the Japanese imports.

title: Norway Oil Price Cut
description: Norway's state oil company, Statoil, proposed today to cut prices for its North Sea crude oil to the level recommended last week by the British National Oil Corporation.

title: The U.N. Today; April 6, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Louisiana's $131 million of Aa-rated bonds were offered at yields ranging from 5.25 percent in 1984 to 8 percent in 1993 and 8.9 percent in 2002-03 through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: Violinist Arrested On Drug Charges
description: A violinist who had played for 15 years with the Metropolitan Opera orchestra until his dismissal four months ago, was arrested yesterday in his apartment at 33 West 67th Street and charged with dealing in narcotics and possessing guns illegally.

title: Bumpers Cites Fund Lag In Decision Not to Run
description: Senator Dale Bumpers of Arkansas, citing a lack of money and organization, announced today that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for President.

title: Yankees Keep Erickson
description: The Yankees opened their season tonight with 11 pitchers on their 25-man roster. Roger Erickson, the 11th pitcher, is on the roster because the Yankees think they need his permission to send him to their Columbus farm team.

title: Vermont Castings
description: Vermont Castings, known and loved by wood stove devotees everywhere, has moved its direct marketing account to Marvin & Leonard in Boston from a three-year stay with Ogilvy & Mather Direct in New York. The budget is put in the ''multimillion-dollar'' range by the Boston agency, although Leading National Advertisers, the media-research firm, could only trace $692,200 in media advertising from the company in the first nine months of last year and no direct mail. Vermont Castings is based in Randolph, Vt.

title: HONDURAS REQUESTS A 5 NATION MEETING ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: Honduras called on the nations of Central America today to meet ''as soon as possible'' to work out a settlement to bring peace to the region.

title: Shanker Elected
description: The United Federation of Teachers has re-elected Albert Shanker to his 11th two-year term as president, the union announced yesterday. He got got 25,093 votes to 7,745 for his opponent, Shirley Burton.

title: Videotape Was Made Of Gold-Chain Thieves
description: The thieves who broke into a Fifth Avenue jewelry company's vault last weekend and stole 900 pounds of gold chains worth an estimated $6 million were videotaped by a security camera, investigators said yesterday.

title: EQUIPMENT COMPANY OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: MGM/UA ENTERTAINMENT CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes a net gain on the sale of the music publishing business of $9,901,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Fort Lauderdale Strikers of the North American Soccer League say they have asked Akeem Abdul Olajuwon, the University of Houston basketball center, to attend a three-day tryout with the team. Olajuwon, the 7-footer who led Houston to a runner-up finish in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, was a soccer goalkeeper in his native Lagos, Nigeria, before turning to basketball.

title: LINK SEEN TO RECENT SLAYING OF FRENCH AGENT
description: The decision today by the French Government to expel 47 Soviet officials has focused attention on the unsolved murder of a French counterespionnage officer on Feb. 15.

title: Meet Mrs. Walker
description: It was last summer that Cindy DeAngelis got her gold necklace with the pendant in the shape of the numerals 34.

title: Whom Did You Say Was Performing?
description: One small detail was missing from Monday night's glittering love-in between Luciano Pavarotti and Zubin Mehta, leading the New York Philharmonic. Q: From a perplexed $75-dollar-a-seat patron: ''Where are the programs?'' A: From a harassed usher: ''Not yet. Later.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The pastoral letter is skeptical to a point bordering on disbelief regarding the controlled use of nuclear weapons.

title: Celtics 117, Hawks 95
description: Larry Bird, on one of the hottest streaks of his career, scored 39 points to lead Boston. Hitting on 18 of 22 shots, mostly from long range, Bird ran his scoring spree to 139 points in four games.

title: IRAN-IRAQ ACCORD REPORTED ON OIL SPILL
description: United Nations officials said today that the Iranian and Iraqi Governments had agreed in principle to cooperate in cleaning up an oil spill from Iranian offshore wells covering an area of 7,500 square miles of the Persian Gulf.

title: 51,054 SEE METS WIN, 2-0
description: With Tom Seaver pitching, Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch watching and a paying crowd of 48,682 fans cheering, the Mets opened the season in Shea Stadium yesterday with reunions, memories and a 2-0 victory over Steve Carlton and the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: U.N. Study On Europe
description: The economic lift that lower oil prices should provide to Western Europe must be reinforced by stimulatory fiscal policies if recovery is to be sustained, United Nations researchers said today.

title: DETECTIVE SAYS HE REVISED A REPORT ON CBS KILLER
description: One of the first detectives to question the only witness to the slayings of four people at a Hudson River parking lot testified yesterday that he had changed a report about the description of the killer.

title: War by Slick in the Persian Gulf
description: Mineral water is selling in Qatar and Bahrain for more than oil as the sheikdoms of the Persian Gulf watch huge oil slicks threaten their desalination plants. A new weapon, the shore-to-shore pollution of the gulf, has been introduced into the bitter conflict between Iraq and Iran.

title: A SUPPLY-SIDER'S PREMATURE VICTORY CELEBRATION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ''I FEEL like I've somehow stepped into 'The Twilight Zone,' '' Barry Gibb of the Bee Gees said recently. ''It's been a nightmare.'' Mr. Gibb, who founded the Bee Gees with his brothers Robin and Maurice, was talking about the last several months of their lives, and particularly about being found guilty in a copyright infringement suit by a Chicago jury on Feb. 23. The jury ruled in favor of Ronald Selle, a Chicago antiques dealer and band leader who claimed that the Gibb brothers' composition ''How Deep Is Your Love,'' which was a hit single in 1977 and appeared on their best-selling soundtrack album from the film ''Saturday Night Fever,'' was pirated from his own composition ''Let It End.''

title: U.S. PLANS TO END BAN ON IMPORT OF KANGAROO HIDES AND MEAT
description: The Interior Department will propose on Friday to drop Australian kangaroos from its list of threatened species, officials of the department's Fish and Wildlife Service reported today.

title: GEOTHERMAL RESOURCES INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2,859,000 and a gain of $2.2 million from transaction fees. The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: MUFFIE BRANDON GIVES UP JOB AS REAGAN SOCIAL SECRETARY
description: Muffie Brandon, the White House social secretary for two years, has resigned to open an office here for an international public relations concern specializing in the entertainment industry.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
STARTING SUMMER'S CROP OF VEGETABLES INDOORS
description: With visions of sugar peas dancing in their heads, gardeners are preparing for the coming spring planting season. Seed catalogues have been around for weeks, and in much of the country gardeners will soon be able to sow cool-weather crops such as broccoli, cabbage, celery, lettuce and peas.

title: Russians Reported Killed, By Afghan Avalanche
description: An avalanche north of Kabul, the Afghan capital, destroyed a bridge and swept away four Soviet military outposts, killing an undetermined number of soldiers, Western diplomats and Afghan rebels said today.

title: 1,000 Men in New Delhi Strip To Briefs in Rally for Uniforms
description: More than 1,000 male Indian civil servants stripped to their briefs today and marched for two miles through the city, their clothes bundled under their arms, to back demands that the Government supply them with better uniforms.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allegheny Beverage Corp., Baltimore, has named Lynne K. Zusman vice president and general counsel.

title: DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
LIBRARY RESTORES PERIODICAL ROOM'S SPLENDOR
description: The Periodical Room of the New York Public Library - ornately paneled with huge, arched windows and marble doorways - has just been restored to its original grandeur.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Wednesday about insurance litigation incorrectly described the status of a $4 billion lawsuit brought by the General Public Utilities Corporation, holding company for the utilities that own the Three Mile Island nuclear plant, against Babcock & Wilcox, builder of the plant. It was settled out of court without determination of fault.

title: Jersey Trial Starts In Nazi Death Case
description: A retired New Jersey dental technician was charged by the Government today with having participated in the murder of 2,000 Jews after helping to herd them into a mass grave in Nazi-occupied Lithuania during World War II. The charge came as the Government opened its case to strip the technician, 67-year-old Juozas Kungys of Clifton, of his citizenship.

title: WHERE IS DETROIT'S RECOVERY?
description: Consumers, economists predicted a few months ago, would gather their shaken confidence, draw down their swollen bank balances and, with their purchases, power the economy to a robust recovery.

title: FEDERAL AGENCIES CRITICIZED ON FOOD SAFETY ENFORCEMENT
description: Two consumer groups, in separate news conferences today, charged the Reagan Administration with weakening and not enforcing regulations governing the safety of food.

title: IF THE WORLD HAS A WINE CAPITAL...
description: Wine Talk

title: STAGE: DRAMA BY ALBEE, 'MAN WHO HAD 3 ARMS'
description: EDWARD ALBEE'S ''Man Who Had Three Arms,'' at the Lyceum, isn't a play - it's a temper tantrum in two acts. A celebrated man known only as Himself - why is it always so hard for Mr. Albee to give people proper names? -stands at a lecture-hall podium, backed by potted plants and flags, and spends nearly two hours alternately insulting the audience and announcing how bitter he is.

title: CAMPAIGN FUND RAISING LED BY SOLARZ AND KEMP
description: Two Representatives from New York who had virtually no opposition for re-election last November raised more money for their campaigns than any other House candidates in the state.

title: A SUPPLY-SIDER'S PREMATURE VICTORY CELEBTATION
description: To the Editor:

title: NUTRITIONAL PROGRAM SAID TO BE REACHING ONLY 40% OF NEEDY
description: The Federal program that provides special nutrition aid to needy pregnant women, infants and children is reaching only about 40 percent of those who need the help, officials said today.

title: IF OPEC'S PACT FAILS, WE LOSE
description: In March the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reached an agreement on production quotas and prices that are intended to stabilize the oil market. The question remains whether the agreement will hold or break down and lead to free-for-all competition and a collapse of oil prices. If it breaks down, what will be the consequences?

title: PHOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes $35,000 cumulative effect on prior years for a change in accounting principle.

title: JEWS FROM ASIA AND EUROPE: A BITTERNESS GNAWS AT ISRAEL
description: After 35 years of preoccupation with the external threat from Arab armies, Israel is now awakening to new dangers from within: the perils of poverty, discrimination and ethnic tension among Jews themselves.

title: MANY-SIDED TALKS ON LATINS SOUGHT
description: A group of prominent United States and Latin American citizens say that the Reagan Administration, the Soviet Union and Cuba should hold a ''many-sided dialogue'' with the nations of Central America to find ways to end fighting there.

title: TRUMAN OPTED FOR NO 'FIRST STRIKE'
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 6, 1983
description: International

title: MORE GAS PIPELINE UNITS MOVE TO TRIM SUPPLIES
description: The nation's major natural gas pipeline companies said yesterday that they were stepping up efforts to reduce the amount of highpriced gas they must purchase under long-term contracts, signed in the 1970's when supplies were squeezed.

title: STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including gains of $649,500 for the quarter and $1,374,200 for the year on the sale of GNMA's.

title: Nicaragua's Air Force Said to Bomb Indians
description: Nicaraguan Air Force planes bombed at least one Indian village in an attack on rebels inside Nicaragua, forcing about 1,000 peasants to flee into Honduras in panic, refugees and a United Nations official said today.

title: Kin of Britons Killed in Battle Leave on Trip to the Falklands
description: Relatives of 166 British soldiers killed in the Falkland Islands left Britain today on a pilgrimage to the remote South Atlantic battleground where their husbands, fathers and sons died a year ago.

title: East-West Trade Turnabout
description: In a historic turnabout in East-West trade, the West last year recorded its first trade deficit with the Soviet bloc in two decades, according to a United Nations agency report released today.

title: Watt Bans Rock Groups From July 4 Celebration
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt has prohibited rock music bands from this year's Fourth of July celebration on the Mall in order to keep the celebration ''a family-oriented day,'' a spokesman confirmed tonight.

title: 3 Jersey Casinos Lost Money in '82
description: Three of New Jersey's nine casino hotels lost money in 1982, but the nine had a net total income for the year of $56.9 million on revenues of about $1.7 billion, state officials said today.

title: Public Relations Firm Bought by Doyle Dane
description: A major industry trend these days is the acquisition of public relations firms.

title: WASHINGTON SCENE: 2 NEW RESTAURANTS
description: GASTRONOMIC sightseeing is a relatively new game in Washington and it is one that is being played with increasing fervor. A visitor known to be interested in food is quickly bombarded with suggestions of the new, the wonderful and the in, and local restaurants now vie with the city's more traditional museums, monuments and official buildings as bona fide sights.

title: AIDES FEAR REAGAN'S PEACEFUL IMAGE IS IN PERIL
description: In a little noticed but politically significant shift of voter sentiment, Ronald Reagan appeared to have largely succeeded last year in diminishing his unwelcome image as a dangerous President capable of taking the United States into war.

title: Help Wanted
description: For Tom Bartlett, a 68-year-old doctor from Wellington, New Zealand, charity begins on the road. Bartlett, a competitive runner for 51 years, arrived in New York two days ago with the hope of running to San Francisco in order to raise money for handicapped children.

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 6, 1983
description: Markets

title: Freon Gas Kills Worker
description: A Freon gas leak aboard a submarine at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard here killed one worker Monday and injured at least seven people, officials said. The leak was aboard the Jack, which was here for overhauling. Patrick McCabe of Dover, N.H., 24 years old, was pronounced dead at Portsmouth Hospital after he inhaled Freon gas, the authorities said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: BANKER. By Dick Francis. 306 pages. Putnam. $14.95.

title: E.E.C. Price Rise Eases
description: Consumer prices in the 10-nation European Economic Community rose by seven-tenths of 1 percent in February, down from an increase of eight-tenths of 1 percent in January, the community's statistical office, Eurostat, reported today.

title: A Glimpse of 1908
description: In 1908-style knickers and knee socks, two young newsboys stood in front of Cathedral of St. James in Brooklyn on Monday shouting, in traditional singsong: ''Tab-let! Tab-let! Five cents a copy!''

title: NINE MORE ARRESTED IN DRIVE BY THE CITY BUILDINGS DEPT.
description: With the arrest of nine persons yesterday, the Buildings Department continued its crackdown against owners and managers of commercial properties that are not in compliance with safety laws.

title: LONE YOUNG MOTHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Tigers Rout Twins
description: A three-run homer by Larry Herndon in the first inning touched off a 15-hit attack that carried the Detroit Tigers to an 11-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins in their American League opener tonight.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THERE are cheeses that are destined for cooking and those that are made for the table. Cooking cheeses include grated Parmesan, cheddar, the Swiss cheese called Emmenthal and the related cheeses from the same nation, Gruyere and Appenzell. Blue cheese, in its many variations, can be used as a table or cooking cheese.

title: JAMES H. CALLAHAN
description: James H. Callahan, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Kenyon & Kenyon, died Sunday at his home in Holmdel, N.J. He was 60 years old.

title: SATELLITE CARRIED IS SPACE SHUTTLE IS SHORT OF ORBIT
description: A mysterious rocket malfunction today prevented the $100 million communications satellite launched by the space shuttle Challenger from reaching its intended orbit as it apparently tumbled temporarily out of control.

title: PUBCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss of $3.3 million for the quarter and year from discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2 million for the quarter and $8.9 million for the year.

title: Canada Sends for Help
description: Reinforcements headed to Europe yesterday to bolster the sagging Canadian national hockey team in a five-nation tournament in Leningrad.

title: REAGAN'S MIDEAST PANIC
description: Desperate to salvage some semblance of progress for his ill-advised Mideast plan, President Reagan is showing a new weakness toward the Russians and is becoming an object of scorn among Arabs.

title: A VEHICLE FOR COMBAT
description: To the Editor:

title: AN UNDERGROUND TALE OF TWO CITIES
description: For the hardened veteran of New York City's graffiti-smeared, trash-strewn subway system, a plunge into the subterranean world of the Washington, D.C., Metro system seems like a journey into a fantasy world where cleanliness is a fetish.

title: BANK CUTS CONSUMER LOAN RATES
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, New York's fourth-largest bank, cut its consumer loan rates yesterday by one to one and a half percentage points.

title: Dodgers 4, Astros 2
description: Ken Landreaux of Los Angeles continued his impressive season start with a two-run tie-breaking single in the eighth inning that beat Houston.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Many Shoverlers And a Single Spruce
description: How many trees does it take to make a grove? And how many shovelers to plant a single four-foot spruce? The accent will be on symbolism today when a ''grove'' is dedicated to Hadassah on the Metropolitan Museum's north lawn (actually part of Central Park). The New York-based Jewish National Fund, which has planted 200 million trees in Israel, has given the Parks Department $1,000 honoring the 70th anniversary of the Zionist women's organization.

title: U.N. URGES LIBYA AND CHAD TO TAKE DISPUTE TO O.A.U.
description: The Security Council called on Chad and Libya today to settle their territorial dispute through the Organization of African Unity.

title: Bomb in Argentina Explodes At English-Language School
description: A bomb exploded today at an English language school in suburban Buenos Aires, shattering windows but causing no injuries, the school's principal said.

title: NEW DATA EXPLAIN LAG IN PRODUCTIVITY
description: The Government today introduced a statistical series on productivity that shows that a drop in capital investment was not a major factor in the sharp decline in the growth rate of productivity in the 1970's.

title: PITFALLS OF A NUCLEAR ARMS 'BUILD-DOWN'
description: To the Editor:

title: Baldwin-United Misses $5 Million Debt Payment
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation failed yesterday to make a promised $5 million payment to one of its bank creditors, raising the possibility that it would not be able to work out an agreement to reschedule more than $700 million in short-term debt.

title: SOVIET FARMING SEEMS HEADED FOR SHAKE-UP
description: The new Soviet leadership under Yuri V. Andropov appears to have decided on a drastic overhaul of agriculture, traditionally one of the weak spots of the Soviet economy.

title: Mormon Church Defends Employment Policy
description: The Mormon Church's policy of hiring only worthy church members when possible complies with state and Federal laws, a Mormon spokesman said in response to a discrimination lawsuit against two church-owned businesses.

title: Mariners Defeat Yankees
description: When the Yankees signed Bob Shirley as a $2 million free agent last December, they would have been happy to have him match the pitching exploits of Ron Guidry. Shirley, in his American League debut, did precisely that tonight, but it wasn't what the Yankees had in mind.

title: SOVIET BLOC SAID TO PLAN ECONOMIC SUMMIT TALKS
description: The Soviet Union and its principal allies are preparing to hold their first economic summit meeting in 12 years, probably in May, NATO officials and other experts on the Communist bloc said today.

title: Elgin Groseclose, 83, Author and Economist
description: Elgin E. Groseclose, a novelist, economist and religious leader who most recently worked as president of the Washington City Bible Society, died of a stroke today. He was 83 years old.

title: HONG KONG TO PUT ELECTRONIC TOLL TAKERS IN STREETS
description: After grappling unsuccessfully for years with the problem of traffic chaos, the Government of this crowded British colony has decided to make motorists pay for driving on its most congested roads.

title: Mr. Scowcroft's MX Mouse
description: The President's Commission on Strategic Forces seems ready to recommend, finally, how to base the MX, that Flying Dutchman of a new American missile: in strengthened versions of the silos that now house Minuteman missiles. That solution may support Mr. Reagan's determination to ram the MX through Congress, but it makes a mockery of the case on which the MX was built.

title: I.B.M.'s New Robotics Unit
