description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a lowcost programmable robotic system that it said is designed for assembly and material-handling jobs.

title: Grundig Had Profit in Year
description: Grundig A.G. registered a profit in the year ended March 31, after two years of losses, a spokesman for the company said today.

title: BOTH NATIONAL PARTIES FEAR THE AFTERMATH OF CHICAGO CAMPAIGN
description: The Chicago mayoral election, by focusing attention on black-white tensions and on deteriorating voter loyalty, is creating problems for the national political parties that reach beyond this racially polarized city.

title: Singer's Body Identified
description: A relative has identified the body found in a motel room as that of Danny Rapp, a rock 'n' roll performer, who apparently committed suicide, the police said today. Mr. Rapp's group, Danny & The Juniors, had a hit with ''At The Hop'' in 1957. The singer's body was found Monday in Quartzsite.

title: WITHHOLD INTEREST
description: If Congress, under heavy lobbying pressure by banks and saving and loan institutions, repeals the law it enacted last year to withhold taxes from dividends and interest, honest taxpayers will foot the bill for unreported dividends and interest by paying higher taxes.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Aaron Kyle, a cornerback and one of the most consistent players on the Denver Broncos, announced his retirement. ... Billy Paultz, the center who was waived by the Houston Rockets on Monday, has signed with San Antonio. ... The White Sox have placed Jim Kern, their hardthrowing reliever, on the 21-day disabled list after he re-injured his elbow Tuesday night. ... Wilfredo Gomez, the World Boxing Council superbantamweight champion, says he does not plan to fight again in that class because he has trouble making the 122-pound limit. He says will fight as a featherweight or junior lightweight.

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 7, 1983
description: Companies

title: GRAFTON GROUP LTD reports earnings for year to Jan 31.
description: b-After a writedown on assets of $5,398,000.

title: Viper Victim Off Critical List
description: A 16-year-old snake collector, bitten by an African viper that he is suspected of stealing from the National Zoo, was taken off the critical list today but doctors said he was still seriously ill. Officials said the youth, Louis Morton of southwest Washington, remained in the intensive care unit of Children's Hospital, where he was taken late Monday after he told a bus driver he had been bitten on the shoulder by one of two Gaboon vipers he was carrying in a plastic bag. Five East Coast zoos sent emergency supplies of antitoxin to the hospital to treat him.

title: Coal Slurry Bill Advances
description: A bill to clear the way for construction of thousands of miles of coal slurry pipelines was approved today by the House Interior Committee on a 27-to-13 vote.

title: Allied Adds Bendix Officers
description: The Allied Corporation said yesterday that it had elected five officers of the Bendix Corporation to its board, in an action representing the start of the combination of the Allied and Bendix corporate staffs.

title: MILLER, HERMAN, INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Boat With 70 Haitians Arrives in Florida
description: At least 70 Haitians packed aboard a wooden sailboat with ragged sails and a tree trunk for a mast arrived here today, the authorities said.

title: A GUIDE TO STORING KEROSENE HEATERS
description: When a kerosene heater is prepared for storage in the spring, several common-sense guidelines should be followed in addition to any specific instructions provided by the manufacturer.

title: THREE GENERATIONS OF GLASS DESIGNERS
description: For centuries in Europe, the art of glass making was passed down from one generation to another in the same family. Such was the case in 19th-century America. Then, with the advent of new technology, glass making became mechanized and more removed from the hands of craftsmen. Creativity now lay principally with the glass designer, not the maker. An exception was the Littleton family.

title: PRESIDENT APPROVED POLICY OF PREVENTING 'CUBA-MODEL STATES'
description: At a meeting with his senior foreign policy advisers last April, President Reagan approved a policy with the goal of preventing a ''proliferation of Cuba-model states'' in Central America that could threaten the United States militarily and economically.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,500,000, or 41 cents a share, from the sale of the company's 20 percent interest in Mobil Tyco Solar Energy Corp. c-Includes a gain of $3,700,000, or 40 cents a share, from the exchange of the company's investment in Fisher Scientific Co. common stock for convertible preferred stock of Allied Corp.

title: CONCERT: PAUL DRESHER, GUITAR AND ELECTRONICS
description: BEAUTY and its little sister, prettiness, were once considered essential to great art: if a painting or a piece of music didn't please on its sensual surface, it was rejected out of hand. But in recent times, beauty has become suspect. In our art today we value sincerity, strength, energy and formal rigor, and surface charm and grace can seem almost antithetical to these rougher virtues.

title: GRETZKY SCORES 4 AS OILERS WIN, 6-3
description: Wayne Gretzky scored four goals, including three in the second period, to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 6-3 victory over the Winnipeg Jets in the first game of opening Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: DELAY IN VOTING ON SCHOOL CHIEF CALLED HARMFUL
description: It has been more than two months since Frank J. Macchiarola left the post of New York City Schools Chancellor, and the absence of someone to head the largest school system in the country is beginning to have an impact, according to members of the Board of Education and others.

title: KEAN, DEFYING LAW, BANS LARGER TRUCKS FROM MANY ROUTES
description: Governor Kean said yesterday that he would defy the new Federal law on tandem-trailer trucks and would allow them only on a few major roads.

title: PORT AUTHORITY ROLE AT ISSUE IN CITY'S HUNTERS POINT PLAN
description: A conflict over a multimillion-dollar renewal plan for the Queens side of the East River developed yesterday between the Port Authority and the Koch administration.

title: F.D.A. APPROVES NEW SPONGE CONTRACEPTIVE
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had approved a new nonprescription sponge contraceptive for women.

title: REAGAN'S TACTICS ON SECURITY FRONT
description: In the snarl of interlocking national security matters up before Congress, President Reagan is pursuing seemingly contradictory tactics on the related issues of the MX missile, the nuclear freeze and the Pentagon budget. Some Republicans doubt he can get away with such an intricate approach.

title: Cuomo Signs Measure On Court Nominations
description: Governor Cuomo signed a bill today that increases by two the number of candidates who may be recommended to the Governor for nomination to a vacancy on the State Court of Appeals.

title: WHITE HOUSE CONCERT FEATURES YOUNG QUARTET
description: Itzhak Perlman presided over a concert at the White House today. Among the performers was the Muir String Quartet, which is named for the American naturalist John Muir.

title: 4 LITHUANIAN BISHOPS ARRIVE IN ROME
description: Four Roman Catholic bishops arrived today from the Soviet republic of Lithuania for a visit that was viewed here as a notable advance in the relationship between the Vatican and Moscow.

title: Market Place; Bank Profits: Confusion
description: BANK holding companies will soon begin reporting 1983 first-quarter profits, and the process, according to Wall Street professionals, promises to create confusion among bank stock investors. The issue centers on a new rule adopted in March by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: BIG TRAFFIC GAINS FOR AIRLINES
description: The nation's major airlines, most of which are still losing money, experienced a big upturn in travel in March, but they are still reluctant to say a recovery is under way.

title: Dutch Seize Heroin
description: The Dutch police said today that a Pakistani heroin connection was uncovered last week with the detention of nine suspects and the seizure of 21 pounds of heroin. A police spokesman said the heroin, worth $740,000, had been smuggled into the Netherlands from Pakistan and had been found at various addresses in Amsterdam and in a storage shed at Schiphol Airport.

title: Canada's Economy Stirs
description: Canada's real gross domestic product in January rose 1.6 percent from December, the Government said today. It was down 2.8 percent from January 1982. The G.D.P. is the total value of goods and services, excluding exports.

title: NORTH AMERICAN BIOLOGICALS INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $75,000 for the quarter and $175,000 for the year.

title: EUGENE C. BISHOP
description: Eugene C. Bishop, a newspaper executive who played a significant role in California journalism, died Monday at Stanford University Hospital.

title: NASA IS CONFIDENT PLAN CAN CORRECT SATELLITE'S ORBIT
description: Space flight controllers, exuding confidence as they struggled to save the world's largest communication satellite, decided today on a sequence of jet-firing maneuvers to boost the errant craft to its desired operational orbit in 10 days to two weeks.

title: Martha Graham Chosen For Bryn Mawr Award
description: Bryn Mawr College will award Martha Graham the M. Carey Thomas Award, the college's highest honor, on April 15.

title: REGAN URGES DELAY IN LIFTING OF BANKING INDUSTRY BARRIERS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan today called on Federal bank regulators to impose a moratorium that would prevent companies outside the banking industry from getting into commercial banking and would prevent both banks and savings institutions from getting into other fields.

title: Award to Andrzej Wajda
description: The Polish dissident film producer Andrzej Wajda has been awarded a $100,000 prize by the Onassis Foundation for his ''important contribution to the cause of human dignity, freedom and social progress.'' Wajda's best known recent film was ''Man of Iron,'' which chronicles the development of the Polish Solidarity workers' movement under its leader, Lech Walesa.

title: AMERICAN SPORTS ADVISORS INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
Suspect Seized In Robbery Spree
description: A gang that preyed on fruit stands operated by Asians in the Bronx and Manhattan was broken up yesterday with the arrest of one teen-age suspect and the identification of two other gang members, the police said.

title: Nurses Threaten Strike in Brooklyn
description: More than 300 nurses will walk off their jobs at Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn this morning unless an agreement is reached on a new contract, the nurses' union said yesterday.

title: Mexico Approves Debt Plan
description: After weeks of negotiations with foreign bankers, the Mexican Government today announced a complicated plan to free up enough dollars to allow Mexican corporations to repay their foreign debts in the future.

title: SOVIET LETS ONE OF PENTECOSTALS EMIGRATE
description: A Siberian Pentecostal who was one of a group that took refuge in the United States Embassy five years ago flew to Vienna today after an unexpected Soviet decision to let her emigrate.

title: Flexi-Van Sues Former Chairman
description: The Flexi-Van Corporation, an international transportation-leasing company, said it had filed suit against its former chairman, David H. Murdock, and other shareholders, charging them with violations of securities law in what it called ''an unlawful plan'' to take control of the company.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Including investment tax credits of $9,000 for the quarter and $37,000 for the year and income of $77,000 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the quarter and $1,000 for the year and an investment tax credit of $174,000 for the quarter and year. Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 15, 1982.

title: SILVER STATE MINING CORPORATION reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: The company's fiscal year was changed to a calendar year effective Jan. 1, 1982. The results for the 1981 year reflect 12 months of operations.

title: Hill & Knowlton Hires Ex-Gov. Edward King
description: Former Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts, who failed to win the Democratic primary last year in his re-election bid, has become a senior consultant for Hill & Knowlton Inc., the big New York public relations firm that is part of the JWT Group.

title: CONGRESSMEN FIND OPTIMISM AT HOME ON ECONOMY BUT NOT FOREIGN POLICY
description: When Representative George E. Brown Jr. talked to the home builders in his southern California district a year ago, the meeting was like a funeral. But when the Democratic lawmaker met with the same group last week the gathering was a ''swinging party,'' he reported.

title: WOOD AND CERAMICS: CUSTOM LACQUER DESIGNS
description: THE bamboo bird cage is the one item that Phillip Mueller, top, does not have custom-made. But everything else, including trays and platters, vases and bowls, are custom-designed and then lacquered by the 29-year-old craftsman. Mr. Mueller got interested in the lacquering technique a few years ago and taught himself the process.

title: Stanislav V'Soske, 83, A Leader in Rug Design
description: Stanislav V'Soske, who was known as the dean of American rug design, died March 20 at his home in Santurce, P.R. Mr. V'Soske, who was 83 years old, was a co-founder of V'Soske Inc. in Manhattan 60 years ago, and the carpet business is still owned by the family.

title: Milton Bradley
description: The Milton Bradley Company said it expected to report a loss for the first quarter on sales below those of a year before.

title: SENATE TO PROCEED ON BUDGET FOR U.S.
description: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Pete V. Domenici, a New Mexico Republican, said today that the panel would vote on military spending Thursday even without an agreement with President Reagan on what the 1984 increase should be.

title: PLAYERS
description: During the winter that followed his 30th birthday, as he prepared for the prime of his career as a pitcher, Pete Vuckovich of the Milwaukee Brewers felt a strange sensation in his right arm. It felt fine.

title: 9 Underground Poles Go on Trial
description: Nine members of the Solidarity underground accused of trying to organize a factory workers' revolt against martial law went on trial today before a military court.

title: ROLE OF LAWYER IN HER CLIENT'S ESCAPE FROM PRISON MYSTIFIES FRIENDS
description: Last Thursday, Mary Evans, a 26-year-old lawyer, accompanied her client, a convict accused of murdering two fellow prisoners, to a psychologist's office in nearby Oak Ridge.

title: Islanders Capture Opener in Playoffs; Islanders 5 Capitals 2
description: The power play and the goaltending of Billy Smith, which have been so successful in past Stanley Cup playoffs for the Islanders, again were the main ingredients tonight in their 5-2 triumph over the Washington Capitals.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: RATES EBB FOR ALL MATURITIES
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined modestly yesterday, ending at their lowest levels of the day. Dealers in the Treasury market characterized investor demand for notes and bonds as modest. They said many investors were concentrating on exchanges of securities rather than net additions to their holdings.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: 4,802 See Cubs Fall By 3-0
description: Al Oliver hit two home runs, his first breaking up a pitching duel between Steve Rogers and Ferguson Jenkins in the seventh inning, and led the Montreal Expos to a 3-0 victory today over the Chicago Cubs.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CABARET: MAXINE SULLIVAN
description: MAXINE SULLIVAN says that her current engagement at Village West, through Sunday, is the first time that she has done anything longer than a one-night stand in New York since 1969. In that event, it could have been an opportunity for the singer to expand a bit, to spread out beyond the standard material that is the core of her repertory.

title: Accounts
description: * Timex Clock Co., Waterbury, Conn., to Grey Advertising.

title: GREAT WEST STEEL INDUSTRIES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: HERS
description: ANYONE who has taken a walk in Manhattan during the past year knows that the red light no longer provides even a modicum of safety for pedestrians because it no longer commands the respect of a significant proportion of drivers. But the social significance of ''rule-trashing'' - an inventive bit of slang describing a practice that is spreading throughout every area of modern life - extends far beyond its obvious dangers to potential victims. When the number of rule-breakers reaches a critical mass, social pressure - the prime enforcer of civilized behavior - works on behalf of instead of against lawlessness.

title: E.P.A. ADMITS NOT PRESSING FOR TOXIC LAGOON CLEANUP
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has acknowledged that it failed for two years to pursue information that could have forced several corporations to finance a multimillion-dollar cleanup of a vast toxic lagoon in southern New Jersey.

title: BALDWIN-UNITED CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. Share earnings are fully diluted. The company did not report primary share earnings. The results for the quarter were negatively affected by charges for income taxes and reserves for possible losses on certain investments and advances which will probably not recur in material amounts in future periods, the company said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty, Hartford, has named James S. Dailey president and chief executive officer of its Ponderosa Homes subsidiary.

title: DYED IN THE WOOL?
description: ''To start with,'' Nils B. Hult said, ''I'm a dyed-in-the-wool conservative Republican. I come from a very conservative family, Swedish, you never spent a nickel unless you had it. I was chairman of an earlier Reagan campaign here, when he was still Governor, and I was vice chairman this last time. I know him.''

title: Topics; Wings, Rings; Telepathy
description: A friend whose employer recently installed high-tech push-button phones sensed his callers were granting him new respect. One day he learned why: A caller exclaimed, ''Wow! How did you do that?''

title: Coast Thrift Unit's Zero-Coupon C.D.
description: The Homestead Savings and Loan Association, based in Burlingame, Calif., is offering $125 million of zero-coupon certificates of deposit through underwriters led by Blyth Eastman Paine Webber Inc. The offering was increased from $100 million, underwriters said.

title: 'STAR WARS' DEFENSE IS NOT THE ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: FOSTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
Pennsylvania Sale
description: Pennsylvania's $88 million of A-rated general obligation bonds were offered yesterday at yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1983 to 8.20 percent in 1993 and 9 percent in 2001-02. According to underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company, all but $14 million of the issue was sold. Underwriters said that there was ''good demand'' from investors and that relatively few of the bonds were still held by securities dealers.

title: Mellon Merger
description: The Mellon National Corporation said its merger with the Girard Company was now completed, creating the nation's 12th-largest bank holding company, with assets of more than $25 billion. Principal units are the Mellon Bank, Girard Bank, Mellon Bank International, Girard Bank (Delaware) and Mellon Financial Services.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ON BROOKLYN BRIDGE
description: The Borough, the Bridge and the City, Municipal Art Society, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street), 212-935-3960.

title: Hungarian Girl, at 16, Is Rising in Tennis
description: Several times during her match today, Kathy Rinaldi paused between points to steal a glance at Andrea Temesvari, a tall, slender blonde dressed in pink, on the adjoining court. Miss Temesvari was having great success hitting high topspin forehands that Michaela Pazderova of Czechoslovakia, who is only 5 feet 2 inches, could have used a stepstool to reach. The Pink Lady was winning easily, and Miss Rinaldi looked interested.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
DOUGLAS, KELLY, & CO reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,333,000. c-Includes a gain of $1,000,000.

title: Ouster of Professor Sought
description: George Washington University officials want Prof. Paul Arthur Crafton to resign because of accusations that he taught at two Pennsylvania colleges under false names while he was a faculty member at George Washington, a university spokesman said today. Barry Jagoda, the spokesman, said Professor Crafton was sent a letter expressing the university's concerns.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 7, 1983
description: International

title: SLATER ELECTRIC INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Ford and Chrysler Show Higher Sales
description: The Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation reported today that new car sales rose in the March 21-31 period, by 3.6 percent and 9 percent, respectively. They reported their sales a day after the General Motors Corporation, which had a 5 percent decline. For the Big Three as a group, sales fell 1 percent in the reporting period.

title: MONEY MARKET RATES AT BANKS RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts rose slightly this week, both nationwide and in the New York area, the Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: Awaiting Carter
description: In his fifth pro football game, Herschel Walker showcased his talents and led the Generals to their first victory last Sunday. However, Anthony Carter's skills remain hidden thus far for the Michigan Panthers, who play the Generals this Sunday at Giants Stadium.

title: CANADA MAY SOON CUT PRICE OF GAS SOLD TO U.S.
description: The Canadian Government, faced with a possible loss of markets, appears to have decided to cut the price of its natural gas exports to the United States by an amount roughly comparable to the price cut for oil announced last month by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Sisk Accepts Mets Relief Role
description: Doug Sisk remembers the day a piece of paper was tacked on the door of the phys ed office in junior high school in Renton, Wash. ''Those whose names do not appear on the list below have been dropped from the baseball squad,'' the notice began and his heart sank to the tiled floor. His name was not on the list.

title: THAIS READY TO ORDER NEW STRIKES ON VIETNAMESE
description: Thai military commanders said today that they were prepared to order new air strikes against 150 Vietnamese soldiers who crossed from Cambodia over the weekend and entrenched themselves in hillside positions just inside Thailand.

title: DELAY INDICATED IN REAGAN'S PLAN FOR SALVADOR AID
description: The Reagan Administration, worried about rising opposition to a $60 million military aid request for El Salvador, is seeking to delay consideration of the measure until it can muster enough votes on Capitol Hill.

title: 10,000 Policemen Battle Sao Paulo Rioters
description: The authorities called out 10,000 riot policemen today to battle rock-throwing mobs in a third day of looting and violence touched off by rising unemployment and the Government's austerity program.

title: A Song for Barnard
description: A group of students, faculty members and Barnard alumnae gathered in Barnard Hall yesterday as the Barnard Baccantae, a six-member singing group, warbled ''Barnard - A Woman's Place.''

title: REAGAN JEERED BY 4,000 PROTESTERS ON VISIT TO PITTSBURGH JOB FORUM
description: President Reagan, traveling to one of the nation's most economically depressed regions, drew an angry crowd of 4,000 protesters here today as he pledged to help retrain unemployed steelworkers for new jobs and protect the steel industry from collapsing.

title: ARCHITECTURE: A 26-STORY TOWER
description: WHEN a company with so extraordinary a record of support for the arts as Philip Morris - as well as a history of commissioning serious works of architecture - decides to build its own headquarters in Midtown Manhattan, it is no wonder that much is expected. And with the news that the building's covered public space was to become not another cold and unwelcoming plaza but a new midtown branch of the Whitney Museum, hopes went even higher.

title: Senate Labor Panel Chairman Asks Teamster Chief to Quit
description: The chairman of the Senate Labor Committee called today for the immediate resignation of Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union chief who has been sentenced to 55 years in prison for his conviction on charges of conspiring to bribe a Senator.

title: NEW FILMS AND CINEMATIC REALISM
description: AN attention to cinematic realism is one of the things elicited by the New Directors/ New Films series, which recently concluded its 1983 program and which sometimes presents films that are of much more interest sociologically or anthropologically than cinematically.

title: Pistons 107, Bullets 96
description: Ray Tolbert came off the bench to score 20 points for Detroit. Washington's second loss in 11 outings left the Bullets one game behind the Knicks and a game and a half behind Atlanta for the final playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.

title: Six Go Free in Case Of Widow's Savings
description: A judge has dismissed charges against six people accused of being part of a gang that abused a senile 74-year-old widow in her home while draining her life savings.

title: GROWING SHIPYARD PARALYSIS
description: The workers at the Harmstorf shipyard here kneel in the piercing glow of acetylene torches, creating a ship's bulkhead by welding steel ribs to curved steel plate.

title: Burlington Plans
description: Burling Northern Inc. said it expects to spend $576 million on capital projects in 1983, up from $395.9 million in 1982. The diversified transportation concern said it expects to generate most of its capital expenditure requirements internally.

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes a gain of $91,000 from the sale of investments. Transamerica Realty Investors is managed by Transamerica Realty Services Inc., a subsidiary of the Transamerica Corp.

title: HARDIER CAMELLIAS FOR COOLER CLIMES
description: TWO new hardy camellias bred from fall-blooming species may extend the cultural range of this handsome evergreen beyond the Mason-Dixon line. Although the new camellias, named Frost Prince and Frost Princess, are not yet available to the public, cuttings and scions have been released to plant breeders and nurserymen by the United States National Arboretum in Washington. Home gardeners may soon be able to buy the new plants.

title: MERCHANTS BANK OF NEW YORK reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DEVELCON ELECTRONICS reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Books Of The Times
description: THE LIFE AND DEATH OF THE PRESS BARONS. By Piers Brendon. 288 pages. Atheneum. $14.95. A SPIRIT of independence or ''will to power,'' Piers Brendon tells us a number of times, is the distinguishing trait of the ''press barons'' whose rise and fall he chronicles in his enjoyable book. Sensibly, however, he makes no great effort to support this dubious proposition or even to explain it, concentrating instead on a zestful recounting of the careers of a score of legendary newspaper editors and owners on both sides of the Atlantic and, lately, the Pacific.

title: Chrysler's Ad in Digest Is a Mammoth 40 Pages
description: If you want to see an automobile ad that is an automobile ad, check out the May issue of Reader's Digest. Chrysler has a 40-page ad for its cars there and, says Donald B. Horton, domestic promotion director, ''To our knowledge, at 40 pages, it's the biggest ad ever run by a single car manufacturer.''

title: WOLF, HOWARD B, INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $10,299 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes tax credits of $10,897 for the quarter and $99,245 for the 9 months.

title: EAST BLOC MINISTERS EXPECTED TO ENDORSE MOSCOW ON MISSILES
description: Warsaw Pact Foreign Ministers opened a two-day meeting in Prague today that was expected to give the sevennation alliance's full backing to Soviet policy on nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: SCOTT'S LIQUID GOLD INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $204,000. c-Net loss.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: AROUND THE PARK

title: Masters Permits Regular Caddies
description: Ever since the Masters started in 1934, the Augusta National Golf Club has required contestants to use only resident caddies. The system has been successful, but there have been exceptions, and there was a severe problem in the rain-delayed second round of last year's tournament, when a dozen caddies reported late to work, causing considerable inconvenience.

title: India's Army Ordered To End Assam Outbreak
description: Indian Army troops were called out today to put down new outbreaks of violence in the northeastern state of Assam that left at least nine people dead and 5,000 homeless, officials said.

title: FRIESS IS BARRED FROM EVER BEING NEW YORK JUDGE
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct yesterday announced that it had barred Alan I. Friess from ever again being a judge in New York. Mr. Friess was a Criminal Court judge for three and a half years before he resigned while misconduct charges against him were pending.

title: 'GANDHI' BOUGHT FOR TV
description: On the eve of the Academy Awards, Embassy Communications has purchased United States and Canadian cable and television rights to the Oscar-nominated epic movie ''Gandhi.''

title: Plane's 20,000-Foot Drop Explained by Airline
description: Republic Airlines said today that the failure of two pilots to follow a routine check list resulted in a DC9 jetliner's losing power and dropping more than 20,000 feet before the engines could be restarted.

title: KEY SOVIET AGENTS IDENTIFIED IN PARIS
description: The chief of Soviet intelligence operations in France and his principal aides were among the 47 Soviet officials expelled on Tuesday, an informed source said today. All were accused of espionage.

title: Samuel Griffith Dies; A General and Writer
description: Brig. Gen. Samuel Blair Griffith 2d, retired, of the Marine Corps, a decorated officer in the Pacific in World War II and an author and expert on Chinese military affairs, died March 27 in Newport, R.I. He was 76 years old and lived in Newport and Mount Vernon, Me.

title: Question on Democracy
description: Representative Mel Levine, Democrat of California, in remarks on the House floor, Feb. 25, 1983: Mr. Speaker, the Justice Department has apparently decided that three films, all produced by the Canadian Government, not exactly a hostile government, including a documentary on nuclear war that has been nominated for an Academy Award, are to be looked at as political propaganda and may not be shown in the United States without a disclaimer stating that the U.S. Government does not approve of these films.

title: RIVAL GOVERNORS BATTLE IN UNNEIGHBORLY FEUD
description: For months Gov. Rudy Perpich of Minnesota and Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota have been feuding over which state offers the better quality of life for residents and the better business climate.

title: Vending Machines, And What the Law Says
description: Hordes of blue and white USA Today vending machines, which arrived in advance of the Gannett newspaper due in the city next Monday, causing citizens and community boards to complain to the Mayor, the Consumer Affairs Department and the Department of Transportation. All discovered that there was no law regulating the machines' placement.

title: NBC Offering Split 30-Second Spots
description: TV has notified ad agencies that on an experimental basis the network will sell 30-second advertising units that can be used to promote unrelated products or services in attached 15-second spots. So far there have been no takers.

title: CREATING DECORATIVE ILLUSIONS WITH BORDERS OF WALLPAPER
description: IN the mid-18th century when wallpapered rooms became a prevailing fashion in England and France, wallpaper borders were as important a decorative element as the coverings themselves. A brilliant swag of printed paper flowers, for example, might be used to outline a ceiling below the cornices, or a pair of handblocked trompe l'oeil columns to punctuate a doorway.

title: Muppet Magazine In Cheerios Promotion
description: Muppet magazine, a quarterly from Telepictures Publications, is preparing for its third issue. And Donald E. Welsh, publisher, who formerly was with Outside magazine, is on cloud nine over a deal he has made with General Mills that he is confident will get him to the 500,000 circulation level by December.

title: Director of Disease Centers To Quit His Post but Stay On
description: Dr. William H. Foege, brought in to head the Centers for Disease Control amid controversy six years ago, announced his resignation today with a ''sense of accomplishment'' and an eagerness to tackle new tasks at the Federal agency.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said the International Trade Commission had begun an investigation of Allied's complaint that several Japanese and German companies, including Hitachi, T.D.K. Electronics and a unit of Siemens A.G., had infringed on Allied's rights to a patented technology for amorphous metal alloys.

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
ADMINISTRATION HAILS NEW DRAFT OF ARMS LETTER
description: The Reagan Administration today welcomed the latest draft of a letter by a committee of Roman Catholic bishops that opposes nuclear arms. The State Department called the letter ''an important and serious contribution to the public discussion of what is surely one of the most vital issues of our time.''

title: Car Sales Up in Japan
description: Japan's domestic sales of passenger cars, trucks and buses rose one-tenth of 1 percent in March, to a record 530,378 units.

title: The Perils of Shakespeare
description: As in a cliffhanger, the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., has been saved from bank foreclosure in the nick of time by the white-hats from Hartford.

title: BROWN SAID TO SEEK JOB AT KANSAS
description: Coach Larry Brown of the Nets has applied for the job as head basketball coach at the University of Kansas, a source close to the situation said early today.

title: AT HOME WITH A BACKYARD PLANE
description: JACK SELWITZ dropped into his pool-side lounge chair, poured himself a Coca-Cola and watched a vintage World War II fighter plane taxi toward his house. ''That's music to my ears,'' said Mr. Selwitz, as the plane roared louder and a radio receiver on the patio belched out the pilot's voice. ''When I hear an engine and smell aviation fuel it really does something to me.''

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for qtr to March 19.
description: b-Net income. The year-ago net income is restated to reflect a change to the LIFO method of valuing domestic inventories.

title: GULF AIDES DEFER OIL-SLICK PARLEY
description: Cabinet ministers from eight Persian Gulf nations that are threatened by a vast oil slick decided today to put off the formal opening of a conference on the crisis to allow more time for trying to get Iran and Iraq to suspend hostilities in the area.

title: STEVE JERKENS SETS LIGHT DERBY COURSE
description: Steve Jerkens is standing near the gap in the rail during training hours at Hialeah Race Track, waiting for some of his horses to finish their morning gallops. It is a few days after an uninspiring running of the Flamingo Stakes, when nine horses finished less than three lengths apart to confirm the mediocrity of this year's Kentucky Derby crop.

title: Forestry Executive To Join Burlington
description: David Leland, 47 years old, will join Burlington Northern Inc. as president and chief executive officer of the newly created forest and forest products group, effective tomorrow.

title: TV WILL COVER WALK IN SPACE
description: The first venture of an American astronaut outside a spacecraft in nearly a decade is scheduled to be broadcast live this afternoon on network television.

title: MUSIC: FINE ARTS QUARTET PLAYS SHOSTAKOVICH
description: THE music of Shostakovich is beginning to take its rightful place in contemporary repertory. What was thought to be banal, commonplace and crude when academic hermeticism was the rule of the day, now can be heard as powerful expressions of an important musical voice.

title: Beckenbauer Is Back
description: Franz Beckenbauer, once Europe's and then America's leading soccer player, has returned to the Cosmos, coming out of retirement from West Germany at age 37 to play one more season. He helped the Cosmos win North American Soccer League titles in 1977, 1978 and 1980.

title: TV: RATING COVERAGE OF SOVIET
description: THE press criticizes society, but who criticizes the press? In a way, everyone does, but name-calling is one thing and intelligent, informed criticism is another, and while there has always been a good deal of the first, the second has been in short supply. ''Inside Story'' begins its third season on public television tonight by criticizing, or at least intelligently examining, press coverage of the Soviet Union. The examination, on Channel 13 at 8 P.M., finds the coverage wanting.

title: SALVADORAN REBEL SLAIN IN NICARAGUA
description: One of the top leaders of El Salvador's guerrilla movement, Melida Amaya Montes, was assassinated near Managua early today, the Nicaraguan Interior Ministry said.

title: ALLCITY INSURANCE CO reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Old Master Makes Farewell at Augusta
description: Sam Snead wrote a letter to Clifford Roberts in January 1956 telling the chairman of the Masters golf tournament how much he enjoyed playing in the annual event.

title: Jersey Investigates Death of a Guard
description: A grand jury investigation was ordered today into the death of a 28-year-old New York State prison guard early Tuesday after an encounter with two Bergen County policemen in Fort Lee.

title: KNICKS LOSE IN LAST 1:36
description: Robert Parish scored two crucial baskets, blocked a shot and grabbed a key rebound in the final 96 seconds tonight, enabling the Boston Celtics to rally for a 102-98 victory over the Knicks at Boston Garden.

title: Venezuela Routs Protesters
description: The police used tear gas today to disperse demonstrators protesting the treatment of political prisoners now on a hunger strike in Venezuelan jails.

title: MICKEY LIVINGSTON
description: Thompson O. (Mickey) Livingston, the starting catcher for the Chicago Cubs in the 1945 World Series, died Sunday at a Veterans Administration hospital in Houston.

title: Jersey Eagle Egg Hatched in Lab
description: An egg from New Jersey's only known pair of wild bald eagles has been hatched in a Maryland laboratory and another egg is about to hatch, state wildlife officials reported.

title: The U.N. Today; April 7, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Pryor's Warning
description: Aaron Pryor has been promised a $1.75 million guarantee and a percentage of the net receipts - and his wife's company, Aphrodite, has been promised $500,000 - if he will defend the World Boxing Association's junior-welterweight title against Alexis Arguello again this year.

title: KOREA'S CHUN SEEKS NO EXTENDED TERM
description: To the Editor:

title: Loyal to His Coach
description: Line coaches don't have much to do with wide receivers, but during his four years as an assistant with the Pittsburgh Steelers, Rollie Dotsch, now the head coach of the Birmingham Stallions, managed to catch the eye of one - Jim Smith, a wide receiver who liked what he saw in Dotsch. ''I could see his style and the fairness he handled players with,'' said Smith.

title: Niland Arrested Again
description: John Niland, a former All-Pro lineman for the Cowboys, was arrested in Dallas for the second time in just over a month. The police said he was driving while intoxicated and had a white powder believed to be cocaine. Authorities are still awaiting a chemical analysis of a white powder seized when he was arrested March 4 after a former girlfriend accused him of stealing a suitcase containing jewelry and other property.

title: E. P. A. Plans to Clear New York Waste Sites
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced an ''action plan'' for cleaning up 26 waste sites in New York State.

title: PHYSICIANS CRITICIZE RULES ON NEWBORNS
description: NEW Federal regulations affecting the treatment of severely handicapped newborn babies came under sharp criticism yesterday at a conference of doctors, philosophers, lawyers and historians debating the ethics of caring for seriously ill infants.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: NOW is the time to check the outside of a house for winter damage. The small defects that can be easily repaired now may, if ignored, lead to much more serious and costly problems.

title: BILLINGS CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,700,000 from the sale of land. c-Net loss.

title: 1 FOR TRAVELERS PURSUING PASSPORTS
description: The room is at Fifth Avenue and 50th Street, behind the sculpture of Atlas, up the escalator and to the left. It is the New York Passport Agency office, and if you want to avoid the crowd, arrive early.

title: SEPHARDIM BEAR BURDEN OF JEWISH POVERTY IN ISRAEL
description: A casual observer scarcely notices the poverty among Jews in Israel. It exists behind a screen of moderate wellbeing. It has not scarred the urban landscapes with vandalized, burned-out neighborhoods of obvious despair, as in American cities. But it is there, a permanent and corrosive element of Israeli society.

title: MORE FIRE-RESISTANT FURNITURE
description: By doing such things as putting aluminum foil in welt cords and eliminating cotton ticking, upholstered furniture manufacturers expect that 85 percent of their products will soon resist ignition by smoldering cigarettes.

title: UPSTATE ENGINEERING CAMPUS KEEPS CLOSE TRACK OF SHUTTLE
description: ''No apology necessary, General. That's the way things go. Do the best you can down there.'' That philosophical advice was conveyed by phone to Lieut. Gen. J.A. Abrahamson, in Houston directing efforts to counter difficulties with the space shuttle's communication satellite, by George M. Low, once a top official of the space agency and now president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: INGRID, a manufacturer of plastic housewares, has introduced a group of reasonably priced workshop organizers to enable hobbyists to follow the dictum ''a place for everything and everything in its place.'' There are seven organizers made of black and gray plastic that, except for a tool tote, mount on the wall with screws.

title: The Unlayering of an Onion
description: ''Onions have seven qualities, and seven layers,'' Hanne Lauridsen said yesterday. She was planting onions in pots seven paces apart outside Con Edison's power plant, 59th Street and West End Avenue.

title: UNITED REALTY INVESTORS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $290,000, or 8 cents a share, relating to a loan repayment. Results for the latest first quarter reflect the accrual of about $140,000 of expenses incurred in connection with the company's agreement with Don Carter Realty Inc. to stand still while United Realty continues to seek a potential purchaser for the company.

title: MUSIC: LEINSDORF AND PHILADELPHIANS
description: BECAUSE Erich Leinsdorf was a rare guest of the Philadelphia Orchestra in the days of Eugene Ormandy's reign as music director (from 1958 to 1982, Mr. Leinsdorf did not conduct the ensemble at all), one felt just a little uneasy about how things might turn out in Carnegie Hall Tuesday night when the Philadelphians appeared there under Mr. Leinsdorf's direction.

title: BRIEFING
description: Options at White House

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FLORENCE KNOLL: FORM, NOT FASHION
description: ''YES, it was an exciting time,'' said Florence Knoll. ''But it was mostly hard work. We had to battle the prejudice against contemporary design.''

title: The Piersall Case
description: On Tuesday, Jimmy Piersall was dismissed as commentator for Sportsvision, the pay-TV channel started by Eddie Einhorn, the Chicago White Sox owner. Yesterday, the Sox gave the explanation that Piersall had made ''vitriolic'' attacks on the club's management, which it said were not only unprofessional, but also ''beyond the bounds of his license'' and in violation of his contract.

title: PETROTECH INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After taxes on income of $101,700 that was refunded. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: British Merchant Seamen Drop Strike Threat
description: Britain's 28,000 merchant seamen today dropped their threat of a full-scale strike over the Royal Navy's action in secretly taking over a ship from its civilian crew.

title: Japan Machine Exports
description: Export orders for Japanese industrial machinery fell by 24.3 percent in February from February 1982, reflecting the worldwide recession, the Japanese Society of Industrial Machinery Manufacturers said today.

title: New York State Notes Draw Strong Response
description: New York State's spring financing, traditionally the largest taxexempt financing in the nation, was well received yesterday and attracted about $5.8 billion of orders for the $3.9 billion of notes to be sold, according to underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: OUSTER ARBITRARY, MOSCOW COMPLAINS
description: The Soviet Union said today that the expulsion of 47 officials from France had been ''absolutely arbitrary'' and the stated reason ''obviously fabricated.''

title: STAR OF FILMS AND BROADWAY
description: Martha Sleeper, an actress who starred in motion pictures and on Broadway, died March 25 of a heart attack at her home in Beaufort, S.C., where she lived with her third husband, Col. Howard C. Stelling. She was 72 years old.

title: CIBOLA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: RAIL UNION SAYS OFFICIALS IMPEDE TALKS ON STRIKE
description: A leader of the striking conductors and trainmen on the Metro-North railroad charged yesterday that Governor Cuomo and Richard Ravitch, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, had disrupted bargaining by trying to involve the Federal Government.

title: MANY TO RECEIVE RENT REDUCTIONS UNDER FUEL LAW
description: Thousands of New York City tenants in rent-controlled apartments are entitled to rent reductions of between $5 and $40 a month this year because their landlords did not report drops in their fuel costs in 1982, city housing officials said yesterday.

title: NATIONAL SECURITY COUNCIL DOCUMENT ON POLICY IN CENTRAL AMERICA AND CUBA
description: Following is the text of a National Security Council document, ''U.S. Policy in Central America and Cuba Through F.Y. '84, Summary Paper,'' on a meeting of the National Security Planning Group in April 1982: I. Interests and Objectives

title: 2 U.S. Records Set in Swimming
description: Jeff Kostoff and Rick Carey set American records tonight, and Tracy Caulkins won a record 43d national title with her third consecutive victory in the 200-meter backstroke in the first round of finals at the Untied States Swimming short-course national championships.

title: NUCLEAR PHARMACY INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $75,900.

title: U.S. Adds 10 Homes To Missouri Buyout
description: The Federal Government said today it would buy the homes of 10 families at two dioxin-contaminated sites in Missouri but problems remained with plans to buy out the contaminated town of the Times Beach.

title: MARTIN IS YANKEE SYMBOL
description: For New York fans, the opening of the baseball season is particularly gay. After a three-year absence, there is once again the gratifying and deeply enriching spectacle of Billy Martin in a Yankee uniform kicking dirt on an umpire.

title: A Correction on Chicago
description: An editorial yesterday stated incorrectly that Harold Washington, the Democratic nominee for mayor in Chicago, had once been disbarred for five years. Mr. Washington's license to practice law was suspended indefinitely in 1969, and reinstated upon petition after five and a half years.

title: Insurance Accord
description: The Business Men's Assurance Company, a life- and health-insurance company based in Kansas City, Mo., said it had agreed to purchase 591,000 shares of its common stock from the American General Corporation for $41.75 each, or an indicated total of $24.7 million. Business Men's Assurance, which has about 5.9 million shares outstanding, said $4.9 million would be paid in cash, with the balance in eight-year notes. In addition, it said that American General had agreed not to acquire any stock or take any other action affecting control of Business Men's for 10 years.

title: FOR DEVOTEES OF QUILTING
description: Of interest to both novice and experienced quilters are classes, exhibitions and sales of quilts in the area. The Women's Fellowship of the Congregational Church in South Glastonbury, Conn., will sponsor ''A Quilt Show II'' exhibition and sale, beginning today and running through Saturday.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
Optimism on Oil Price Pushes Pound Higher
description: The British pound today rose to its highest level against major currencies in six weeks amid a growing sense that oil prices have stabilized.

title: CHINA GIVES ENVOYS A NOTE BERATING U.S. FOR ASYLUM DECISION
description: The United States Ambassador to China was handed a note tonight that strongly protested the Reagan Administration's decision to grant political asylum to a Chinese tennis player.

title: IN A POOR ECONOMY, A BRITISH COMPANY HIRES THE DISABLED
description: The dreams of Jack Reynolds and his wife are not unlike the dreams of factory workers everywhere. Mr. Reynolds, a burly printing supervisor in a factory in north London, and his wife, who works across the shop floor, often take trips to Paris for the weekend, and hope to visit New York someday.

title: Two Stars May Stay
description: Guy Lewis, the Houston coach whose team just lost the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship to North Carolina State, says two of his stars - Akeem Abdul Olajuwon and Clyde Drexler -will probably not be going to the pros prematurely. ''They've told me they are coming back and I believe them,'' said Lewis.

title: Topics; Wings, Rings; Two Birds
description: The California condor chick that hatched last week is about as attractive as its diet: diced day-old mice in warm water plus provender from vomiting vultures. Nor will its visage improve with age.

title: ART: A SCULPTURE COURT FOR MIDTOWN
description: THE Whitney Museum of Art at Philip Morris will be a blessing to anyone who likes modern art, finds himself somewhere near Grand Central Terminal, and has a little time to kill. It is an enclave of serious art in an area that has hitherto been notably short of it. It looks pretty, the initial choice of art is quite distinguished and the views -whether from outside in or from inside out - are consistently provocative.

title: New General Counsel Is Appointed by G.M.
description: Elmer W. Johnson, a member of the big Chicago law firm of Kirkland & Ellis and former general counsel for the International Harvester Company, has been named general counsel for the General Motors Corporation. He will succeed Otis M. Smith on May 1.

title: BROKERAGE PLANS TO BUY THRIFT UNIT
description: Thomson McKinnon Inc., owner of a major brokerage firm, announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy a savings and loan association in Madison, Conn. The announcement came as other major brokerage firms considered similar moves into the thrift industry.

title: BOOK ROUSES PUBLISHER
description: It is a rare event in the world of books. One of the nation's largest book publishers is threatening legal action against one of the smallest, demanding that references to itself be deleted from a forthcoming book, and insisting that the manuscript be handed over for inspection before publication.

title: U.N. Chief in Dublin for Talks On Peace Efforts in Lebanon
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, arrived in the Irish Republic today on a three-day visit to discuss United Nations peacekeeping efforts in Lebanon and problems in Ireland.

title: STUDY CITED AS SIGN OF HEALTH PERIL TO CHILDREN OF POOR IN U.S.
description: A survey by a Boston hospital that found an unexpectedly large number of children with stunted growth may be an indication of ''silent undernutrition'' among America's poor, a Harvard health specialist said today.

title: MOVEMENT IS CITED ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: During the latest round of strategic arms talks, the United States offered to limit the number of long-range bombers and airborne cruise missiles, while the Soviet Union called for a ban on deployment of all kinds of cruise missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: Penetrating the Cable Audience
description: THE key phrase in cable television circles these days appears to be ''network television audience erosion''; yesterday morning at the annual Cable Advertising Conference at the Sheraton Centre it seemed as if every speaker managed to slip it in somewhere.

title: Witness Tells Of Finding Body
description: A bartender described in court yesterday how he discovered the body of a Federal witness in lower Manhattan last April 13 while walking his dog.

title: KOCH PLANS HOUSING AS A SOLUTION TO LONG DISPUTE IN WILLIAMSBURG
description: The Koch administration, in an attempt to settle a long-running dispute between Hasidic and Hispanic residents in Brooklyn, announced a plan yesterday for the construction of hundreds of private homes and public housing apartments in the Williamsburg section.

title: L.I. Police Arrest 6 And Seize Cocaine
description: The Nassau County police said today that they had broken up a multi-million-dollar drug operation with the arrest of six people and the seizure of more than $500,000 in cocaine.

title: REAGAN SOCIAL AIDE APPOINTED
description: The White House announced today that Gahl Lee Hodges had been selected social secretary to succeed Muffie Brandon, who has submitted her resignation effective June 1.

title: U.S. EXPANDS CARE OF ATOM VETERANS
description: The Veterans Administration said today it would start giving free medical treatment to veterans who took part in open-air atomic tests and who had illnesses that might be a result of exposure to radiation.

title: EUROPEAN NUCLEAR CONTROL
description: Western Europe is host to 6,000 or 7,000 United States nuclear weapons. A basic European security aim should be to remove these weapons where this is consistent with European security, and to establish some form of European veto over their use where is it not. The proposed deployment of cruise and Pershing 2 missiles should not be acceptable to European governments without physical arrangements that would provide the host governments with negative control.

title: DMG Stake Sold
description: DMG Inc., a real estate developer and mortgage-financing concern, said Equity Group Holdings, a private concern, had recently acquired 1.39 million shares, or 19 percent, of its common stock, for an undisclosed price. Equity Group purchased the shares from an affiliate of the Pacific Holding Corporation and in market transactions, it said. DMG also said that Donald E. Benson, president of the MEI Corporation, a Milwaukee soft-drink bottler, had resigned as chairman of DMG after MEI sold its stake in the company.

title: THRIFT UNIT IN MIAMI COLLAPSES
description: The Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association of Miami was declared insolvent by Federal regulators today and closed over the objections of its chairman and principal stockholder.

title: Sign of the Times
description: In the March-April issue of InfoAAU, the newsletter published by the Amateur Athletic Union, a calendar lists this year's remaining national events in physique body building.

title: Addenda
description: * People magazine increasing its circulation rate base 7.2 percent, to 2.6 million, and its advertising rates 9.1 percent, effective with the July 18 issue.

title: WHERE FREE MARKET AND PUBLIC INTEREST COLLIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Some Top Australians Put Their Ability Into Endings
description: Most Americans and Europeans think of the land down under as the end of the world. Appropriately, Australia has some world-class bridge players who seem to specialize in unusual endings.

title: RELIGION COUNTS IN THE SOUTH BRONX REVIVAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Torturing Cambodia Yet Again
description: There are many ways to kill a nation, and all of them have been tried in Cambodia. Unimaginable slaughter, invasion, brutal occupation have followed famine and pestilence, all of it aggravated by the cynicism of big powers and the paranoia of smaller ones. And now Vietnam, having already done so much to reduce Cambodian nationhood, is striking at Cambodians in camps along the Thai border. The arc of misery widens and the flood of refugees swells to 45,000 in a week.

title: LANE WOOD INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income which is after a tax charge of $66,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $604,000 for the year.

title: STATE DEPT. AIDES SAID TO QUESTION ACTS IN NICARAGUA
description: High-ranking State Department officials raised questions in White House meetings last week about the legality of United States involvement in covert military operations against Nicaragua, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: Peru Combed for Rebels After Peasant Massacre
description: Peruvian commandos and warplanes searched the Andean foothills today for Maoist guerrillas they say massacred as many as 80 peasants on Monday.

title: Coast Utility Issue
description: The Southern California Public Power Authority's $150 million of revenue bonds were tentatively priced to yield from 7 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 9 percent in 1998, as well as 9 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2003 and 9 1/4 percent in 2017. Underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. said that strong demand for the bonds enabled them to reduce the yields for the issue by about an eighth of a percentage point from the levels proposed earlier in the week.

title: Aleksandr Scibor-Rylski, 55, Polish Film Author-Director
description: Aleksandr Scibor-Rylski, a film director who was also the author of more than 20 movies, including ''Man of Marble'' and ''Man of Iron,'' has died, the official news agency PAP said today.

title: People
description: * Joseph C. Lonsdorf promoted to executive vice president, director of client services; Benjamin S. Tully, senior vice president, to director of media services, and J. Patrick McCaffrey to senior vice president at McDonald & Little, Atlanta, a subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide Inc.

title: Violette Verdy Named Boston Ballet Director
description: Violette Verdy has been named artistic director of the Boston Ballet. E. Virginia Williams, who founded the company in 1963, brought the French ballerina to Boston in September 1980 to help her direct the company. Miss Williams will continue with the company as an artistic adviser.

title: PAPER SIEGE BY PRISONER PROVOKES IRE
description: A specter is haunting American courts: Clovis Carl Green. Founder and sole pastor of the Human Awareness Universal Life Church and jailhouse lawyer extraordinaire, he is a man the United States Court of Appeals here called ''in all likelihood the most prolific prisoner-litigant in recorded history.''

title: Q & A
description: Q. We hung some vinyl wall-covering a couple of days after the woodwork next to it had been painted with a latex paint. Some of the vinyl adhesive oozed out and got onto the freshly painted woodwork, so we washed it off with water. However, after washing that woodwork again, we find that the paint has crazed and is flaking off in places. How should these areas be treated before we repaint the woodwork?

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Mr. President, I've been looking for a job for a year, and I can't find one.'' - Ron Bricker, handing his resume to Mr. Reagan. (D27:6.)

title: Florida Women Return From Cuban Jail Term
description: Three American women arrived here from Havanna tonight after nearly a year in jail in Cuba for drug trafficking.

title: INSANITY DEFENSE BACKED BY PANEL
description: An independent commission recommended yesterday that the insanity defense in criminal cases be retained but urged that the legal burden to prove insanity be placed on the defendant.

title: U.S. AGENCY CALLS CUTS IN DISABILITY PAY IMPROPER
description: The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said today that Social Security officials had improperly cut off disability benefits for many people with ''severe mental impairments.''

title: G.M. Profit Seen
description: The General Motors Corporation expects to report a profit in the first quarter, the auto maker's executive vice president, F. Alan Smith, said here.

title: KEVLIN MICROWAVE reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
SOTHEBY'S ART STAFF MIGHT LEAVE IN TAKEOVER
description: About 95 percent of Sotheby Parke Bernet's art staff in London and on the Continent yesterday said they would consider seeking employment elsewhere if the auction house is taken over by its major stockholders, Marshall S. Cogan and Stephen S. Swid, the American cochairmen of General Felt Industries of Saddle Brook, N.J.

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FANS PROTEST WATT'S BAN ON ROCK BANDS AT CONCERT
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt's decision to ban rock music from the annual Fourth of July celebration on the Mall here has bared an apparent dispute within the Reagan Administration.

title: BL Strikers Reject Offer
description: About 5,000 striking assembly workers at the state-owned BL P.L.C. plant voted today to reject possible bonuses offered in return for a phasing-out of unofficial ''cleanup'' time.

title: Spain Appeals Coup Terms
description: Spain's Attorney General, Luis Buron, urged the nation's Supreme Court today to increase the sentences for most of those involved in the 1981 attempted coup. The prosecution is appealing eight of the 11 acquittals by military judges and says the imprisonment of 20 defendants for terms ranging from one to six years was too lenient.

title: KENYA'S LITTLE TRACK OF IRON THAT ALMOST WASN'T
description: It was built by the British to buttress an empire, and some termed the venture lunacy. Its creators were prey to man-eating lions as well as disease. And its coming, a track of iron through desert and bush, opened up lands that had not known change, exposing them to penetration by many outsiders - settlers and traders and adventurers, hunters of both beasts and fortunes.

title: WESTON SPEAKS UP, FLATLANDERS AND ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: Caracas Bank Curbs Studied
description: Venezuela's Finance Minister, Arturo Sosa, said today that the Government was considering stricter controls on banking as a result of recent setbacks suffered by some banks.

title: A WARNING ON HAZARDS OF INGESTING BATTERIES
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission and the National Capital Poison Center have issued a strong warning that miniature batteries used in watches, calculators and clocks can be swallowed and may result in internal burns and sometimes death. The report said an estimated 500 to 800 ''buttons'' or miniature disk batteries are swallowed each year.

title: Technology; Seeing Robots As Machines
description: UNIVERSITY researchers can now build robots with rudimentary hands, feet, ears, eyes and mouths. They can be programmed to perform simple services, and if they don't understand a command, they can say so.

title: JERSEY ALTERS ITS SLOGAN TO REACH THE SPENDERS
description: New Jersey announced a new slogan and promotional campaign today meant to improve the state's image and lure tourist dollars and business investment.

title: Stocks Down for a Fourth Day
description: Stock prices dropped yesterday for the fourth consecutive session as investors' apprehension over the outlook for interest rates and corporate earnings again weakened the list.

title: Sentence Is Reduced In Goody Tapes Case
description: A judge yesterday suspended a one-year prison term for a retired vice president of the Sam Goody music stores.

title: FAST FOOD OPERATORS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $120,000 for the settlement of a class action suit.

title: A SOLAR RETREAT FOR A CITY ARTIST
description: SIX years ago, Lowell Nesbitt, the well-known painter of large floral canvases, declared he had created ''town and country all in one.'' There was no need to go out of the city on weekends. He had all the green growing things and wildlife he wanted on the spot. Nothing was spared in his renovation of a dilapidated police stable in the West Village to allow this hybrid way of life.

title: Additional Shares Sought by A.M.C.
description: The American Motors Corporation said it will ask its shareholders this month to authorize the issuance of 40 million additional shares of common stock.

title: First Union in Deal For Butcher Bank
description: The First Union Corporation, a bank holding company based in Charlotte, N.C., said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Jake F. Butcher's interest in the United American Bank of Chattanooga, Tenn., and to inject new capital into the bank.

title: German Output Drops
description: West German industrial production declined by 2 percent in February from January, the Economics Ministry reported today. The production index, seasonally adjusted, stood at 101, down from 103 in January and 107 in February 1982, showing a production decline of 5.6 percent in a year.

title: Dayco Bid Denied
description: The Australian Government said it had denied a bid by the Dayco Corporation, a diversified manufacturing concern based in Dayton, Ohio, to acquire the remaining 50 percent of the stock in Cadillac Plastics Ltd. that it does not already own. Dayco applied to the Government for permission to purchase the shares from the Nylex Corporation of Australia. The Government said the proposal did not offer enough net economic benefit to warrant approval under the country's foreign investment policy.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said it had purchased 540,731 common shares of Instrumentation Laboratory Inc. under its tender offer for 1.4 million shares at $38 a share, which expired on March 22; Instrumentation has about three million shares outstanding.

title: Topics; Tall Tale, and Toll; Kinked Kong
description: Maybe it's because this April has been very cruel indeed, breeding not memory and desire but head colds and damp feet. Maybe it's because New Yorkers, always eager to distinguish themselves from the rest of the country, were looking forward to saying that their city boasted an 84-foot rubber gorilla.

title: Comings and Goings
description: LaTaunya Pollard, a three-time all-America guard who averaged 29.3 points a game for Long Beach State, won the Wade Award as the top female college basketball player. Linda Sharp of Southern California was named big-college coach of the year; Darlene May of California Poly-Pomona, won in the small-college category, and Penny Slagle of North Dakota-Williston Center was cited in the community college category. ... Rick Dempsey, the Baltimore catcher, agreed to a threeyear extension of his contract, which would have expired after this season. ... Dan Fouts, the free-agent quarterback for San Diego of the National Football League, apparently hasn't budged the Chargers in his demand for a $1 million annual salary. Now, his agent, Howard Slusher, has stepped up the pressure by disclosing that Fouts will meet with Chet Simmons, the commissioner of the United States Football League, possibly to discuss a contract with a U.S.F.L. expansion club in San Diego.

title: CANADA MALTING CO LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Grebey Leaves Post
description: As had been expected, the major league baseball owners and their chief labor negotiator, Ray Grebey, came to a formal parting of the ways yesterday.

title: DRAMA AT OXFORD
description: ''PRIVILEGED,'' which opens today at the Lincoln Plaza Theater, is a prettily precocious but overwrought undergraduate melodrama, shot entirely in and around Oxford University by students, in collaboration with the university's drama department and distinguished alumni, including John Schlesinger. It would look awfully good in a student film festival.

title: CHICAGO CAMPAIGN DAY POINTS UP THE TENSIONS
description: It began as just another day on the campaign trail: Representative Harold Washington, the Democrats' nominee for mayor, arrived at the Roll-A-Way Conveyor Company in west Chicago, stepped out into the crisp, sunny morning air, and was promptly surrounded by a gang of reporters, photographers and sound technicians who, with the help of campaign aides, formed a human wall that would surround him for much of the day.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ELAINE'S: A LITERARY DEN MARKS ITS 20th BIRTHDAY
description: When strangers who have heard about Elaine's restaurant first walk into the place, their heads swivel and their eyes begin searching. Where is she, the woman who opened a modest bistro 20 years ago this month and became den mother to half the city's literary establishment, not to mention a good percentage of visiting movie stars, directors, writers and agents?

title: CHANGING THE IMAGE OF A BANK
description: SOMEWHERE down the road of deregulation awaits an era in which bank advertisers can create and offer meaningful consumer benefits and not cosmetic ones. And more meaningful than toasters, too.

title: SENATE STUDY CALLS FOR CHANGES TO UNRAVEL THE TANGLED LEGISLATIVE PROCESS
description: A study group headed by two former Senators today recommended wide-ranging changes in Senate rules designed to make the lawmakers more efficient in their procedures and more respected by the public.

title: O'NEILL TURNS HISTORIAN TO OPPOSE INCOME TAX
description: William A. O'Neill was reading a study that had been prepared for the Governor of Connecticut. It recommended repealing the state's ''horrible'' sales tax and enacting an income tax to deal with the state's financial difficulties.

title: THE CURRENT COST OF 'PIE IN THE SKY'
description: To the Editor:

title: ASTRONAUTS WALK OUTSIDE SHUTTLE
description: Two astronauts glided, tumbled and somersaulted through the vacuum of space today in a successful test of their abilities to serve as orbital repairmen.

title: U.S. REPORTED TO SEEK OUSTER OF SALVADOR'S DEFENSE CHIEF
description: The United States is seeking the removal of El Salvador's Defense Minister, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, because of the lagging combat performance of the nation's armed forces and poor morale in the military, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: RANGERS GAIN 2-0 PLAYOFF LEAD
description: Now the Philadelphia Flyers must win three straight games from the Rangers, two of them at Madison Square Garden, or be eliminated from the Stanley Cup playoffs. The Rangers put the Flyers in that unenviable position by defeating them, 4-3, at the Spectrum tonight, for a lead of two games to none in their opening-round playoff series.

title: SENATE PANEL, 17-4, APPROVES 5% INCREASE IN ARMS BUDGET, HALF OF PRESIDENT'S REQUEST
description: A bipartisan majority of the Senate Budget Committee today approved a 5 percent increase in the military budget next year, just half the increase that President Reagan has insisted is necessary for the nation's security. The vote was 17 to 4.

title: 'OUT OF THE BLUE'
description: TRANSITIONS barely exist in Dennis Hopper's ''Out of the Blue,'' a work of affecting, if largely unexplained, intensity, and one whose collective associations are far more powerful than its story. Mr. Hopper's films, particularly this one, are more like time capsules than movies anyhow. They seem to be collections of free-floating cultural artifacts, assembled roughly but with honesty and passion. There is incoherence, too; ''Out of the Blue'' is more lucid than Mr. Hopper's ''The Last Movie'' but perhaps less direct than his ''Easy Rider.''

title: 2-GALLERY SHOWS ARE CATCHING ON
description: A NEW tradition may be entrenching itself in the art world, that of the two-gallery show. Initiated by the dealers Mary Boone and Leo Castelli, with whom most of such shared exhibitions have taken place, it goes like this: A ''hot'' artist produces so much work, or work of such a size, as to require his dealer to find more than one space - usually that of another dealer - in which to show it.

title: RED SOX GET 5 RUNS IN FIRST TO BEAT JAYS
description: Dave Stapleton capped a five-run first inning with a three-run homer, and Dwight Evans hit a two-run shot today to lead the Boston Red Sox to a 7-4 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CAPITALS TRIUMPH TO TIE SERIES, 1-1
description: The Washington Capitals beat a tentative Islanders team, 4-2, tonight at Nassau Coliseum and evened their playoff series at one game each.

title: A rebound in gem market.
description: SOME spectacular Art Deco jewelry, along with later styles, will be sold by New York's two top auction galleries over the next two weeks. Both Christie's and Sotheby Parke Bernet say their sales have some excellent offerings from private owners and that the market for colored diamonds and for rubies, sapphires and emeralds has vebounded recently after an 18-month decline.

title: SLEEP FIRST, SAVE LATER
description: In the old Boston Celtic locker room, the players knew it was a big game when they could hear Bill Russell being sick minutes before game time. Wherever Reggie Jackson plays, the tension shows in his verbal stream of consciousness before a big game.

title: Edith M. F. Pritchard Is Dead; Leader in Nursing Education
description: Edith M.F. Pritchard, a leader in nursing education, died Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 86 years old and lived in New York City.

title: Abu Dhabi Cut on Gas
description: Abu Dhabi today cut its liquefied natural gas prices by 15 percent, effective March 1, following last month's decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to reduce crude oil prices, United Arab Emirates officials said. They said all the gas was exported to Japan under long-term contracts but gave no prices.

title: WATT REVERSES BAN ON ROCK MUSIC AT CONCERT
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt was summoned to the Oval Office today to have his moralistic dictates in popular music lightly mocked and then reversed by President Reagan.

title: PRECISION FILM & VIDEO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $1,981,823, or 82 cents a share, for the quarter and year. c-Net loss.

title: U.S. CHURCHES OFFER SANCTUARY TO ALIENS FACING DEPORTATION
description: More than 40 churches around the country are giving sanctuary to illegal aliens from Central America who would face deportation to their war-torn nations if they were caught by Government agents.

title: CONTROL LASER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Reports of Harassment
description: The Fire Department's admission of women as firefighters has resulted in ''isolated incidents'' of harassment, Fire Commissioner Joseph E. Spinnato said yesterday at his City Hall swearing-in. Mr. Spinnato told Mayor Koch and several hundred others in the City Council chambers that ''mostly the incidents were verbal and sexist.''

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: JUDGE WON'T BLOCK TAKEOVER
description: The Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association reopened today in the hands of Federal regulators. A Federal judge rejected a request from the thrift's old management to regain control of the institution.

title: Court Dismisses Appeal by Dayco
description: The Dayco Corporation said that the Federal Appeals Court in New York had dismissed Dayco's appeal of a lower court decision against the company's attempt to attach certain properties of a New York agent. Dayco said it had tried to attach certain properties of the Foreign Transactions Corporation and Edith Reich.

title: NEEDIEST VETERANS WITHOUT V.A. HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: DOW JONES & CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in January 1983.

title: STAGE: NEW 'PORGY AND BESS' STARS ORIGINAL SCORE
description: WHATEVER one chooses to call it - I say grand opera - ''Porgy and Bess'' is simply the greatest score ever to have been produced by the Broadway theater. True, ''Porgy and Bess'' is not the greatest piece of musical drama Broadway has ever seen - or the most profound social comment - but when one is listening to George Gershwin at the peak of his genius, who cares?

title: HOTEL INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
MITSUI MANUFACTURERS BANK (LOS ANGELES) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
France Limiting Sports With South Africans
description: The French Government today ordered sports organizations to end all contacts with South Africa because of its apartheid policy.

title: No Clues on Lost Troops, British Tell Argentines
description: Representatives of families seeking information on more than 500 Argentine servicemen listed as missing in the Falkland war a year ago were told by Britain today that it had no secret clues to their fate.

title: BROWN RESIGNS AS NETS' COACH TO TAKE JOB AT KANSAS
