description: Saying that ''it wasn't supposed to happen this way,'' Larry Brown resigned today as coach of the Nets to accept the position of head basketball coach at the University of Kansas.

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in November 1982.

title: ZIMBABWE ATROCITIES: A SENSE OF TALES TWICE TOLD
description: Michael Auret, a white layman who is chairman of the Roman Catholic Church's Commission on Justice and Peace in Zimbabwe, could have been forgiven if he spoke of history repeating itself.

title: No Change Slated For Soap Operas
description: On a day when ABC Sports and major league baseball announced a new six-year marriage, the network also decided to maintain its love affair with daily afternoon soap-opera fans, even during next summer's coverage of the Los Angeles Olympics.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Inssues

title: CITY IS LOSING ANOTHER BATTLE IN GRAFFITI WAR
description: New York City's freshly painted white subway cars are quickly turning all shades of red, green, blue and black. Graffiti scrawlers have struck the white cars to such an extent that Transit Authority officials are now considering halting the creation of what they once envisioned as ''a great white fleet.''

title: QUEENS BOARD SUPPORTS GRAND PRIX PLAN
description: A proposal to hold a Grand Prix auto race in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens next fall has received a strong vote of support from Queens community leaders.

title: U.S. TO SPEED ARMS TO THAILAND
description: A State Department official said here today that the United States would speed up arms deliveries to Thailand in view of the tense situation on the Thai-Cambodian border.

title: MUSIC: ADELAIDE HALL AT THE COOKERY
description: SINCE 1977, Alberta Hunter, who is now 87 years old, has been an emblem of vital senior citizenship at the Cookery, whose owner, Barney Josephson, is a spirited octogenarian himself. While Miss Hunter is recuperating from an operation, Mr. Josephson has brought in another glowing representative of autumnal life, Adelaide Hall, who was 16 when she started her career in the chorus of ''Shuffle Along'' in 1921.

title: COLONEL STIRS QUESTIONS ON MX-FIRING DOCTRINE
description: An Air Force colonel's comments about the MX missile have raised new questions about whether the Reagan Administration is moving toward a doctrine of launching American missiles at first warning of a Soviet attack.

title: SWEDEN'S 'FLIGHT OF THE EAGLE'
description: FOR reasons not entirely clear, doomed polar expeditions remain almost endlessly fascinating. It may be because cold landscapes, unlike the jungles and rain forests of the tropics, do not overwhelm the past with fecundity. Instead, polar regions preserve it, sometimes for millennia, deep frozen, as a silent lesson to us all.

title: PRESSURE SEEN IN VOTE TO WITHDRAW BRIEF ON QUOTAS
description: The Justice Department persuaded the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission not to file a legal brief challenging the Reagan Administration's position in a major affirmative action case, officials say.

title: TURNER BROADCASTING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: HOW THE BANKERS LOBBY ON WITHHOLDING ISSUE
description: This week, as Congress braces for more debate on a provision that would require banks and other financial institutions to withhold 10 percent of all interest and dividends, bankers across the country are receiving their latest ''Withholding Repeal Kit'' from the American Bankers Association.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday NEW YORK POPS DEBUT

title: Sail and WGBH-TV Schedule a Joint Project
description: Meredith's Boston-based Sail magazine has an interesting deal coming up with the Public Broadcasting System, which will allow some commercial interests to get their noses into the noncommercial tent.

title: Highway Monsters and City Streets
description: Washington doesn't hear it yet, but New York and other cities do, loud and clear: the groan of huge double-trailer trucks making tight cloverleaf turns, intimidating motorists and monopolizing expressways. The Transportation Department, faithful to a rigid new law, has declared all urban interstate roads and half the country's major highways open to the tandems. States and localities, worried about safety, are up in arms.

title: 'FALSE MESSIAH,' OPERA OF TIME WHEN WORLD SEEMED DOOMED
description: In 1665, in Gaza, a 29-year-old Turkish Jew proclaimed himself the Messiah. The biblical ''end of days,'' he declared, was at hand; the Jews would soon return from exile; the paradise of Eden would be restored.

title: FILIBUSTER THREAT ON ADELMAN DROPPED
description: Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, today withdrew his threat to filibuster the nomination of Kenneth L. Adelman as Director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, saying he now felt the nomination could be defeated.

title: DANCE: TAYLOR'S 'SUNSET'
description: AS a purveyor of sentiment without sentimentality, Paul Taylor knows no peer. And so in ''Sunset,'' a quietly glorious work that had its premiere with the Paul Taylor Dance Company Wednesday night at the City Center, the choreographer takes us again not so much into a narrative mode as a narrative mood.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
YANKS WIN AFTER TWO LOSSES
description: Billy Martin figured he would keep doing it until the Yankees got it right. So he started yet another left-handed pitcher against Seattle at the Kingdome tonight, and this time Dave Righetti was successful.

title: Vietnamese Archbishop Excommunicated Again
description: The Roman Catholic Church has excommunicated for the second time a Vietnamese Archbishop for consecrating bishops without papal authority, the Vatican said today.

title: WHAT NEW YORK'S GRAND PRIX WILL DO FOR A PARK
description: To the Editor:

title: Carl D. Weinstein Dies; Cable TV Sales Official
description: Carl D. Weinstein, president of Eastman CableRep, died Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital after suffering a heart attack. He was 50 years old and lived in New York City and New Canaan, Conn.

title: Quake in Soviet Asia
description: A moderate earthquake rocked an unpopulated area of the Tadzhikistan region of the Soviet Union near the Afghan border today, the Soviet news agency Tass said. There were no reports of casualties or damage.

title: Baseball Gets Billion-Dollar TV Deal
description: Major league baseball was assured of a six-year network television package in excess of $1.1 billion yesterday when ABC Sports announced agreement for its half of the rights.

title: HAMLET
description: Another Algonquin Hotel cat named Hamlet has apparently made his exit after a run that didn't come close to his predecessor's. Hamlet I died in January 1982 at the age of 15, celebrated in book and anecdote.

title: Market Place; Energy Stock Selections
description: RELATED stocks performed like a broker's dream from the late 1970's to the end of 1980. Later, because of shrinking product demand and declining crude oil prices, these issues lagged far behind most other stocks.

title: Lloyds Consolidation
description: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. said it planned to consolidate the money market activities of its wholly owned Lloyds Bank Ltd. subsidiary with those of the parent bank because the benefits of maintaining a separate sterling dealing operation were diminishing, The subsidiary's principal operations are sterling deposits and sterling loans. The merger will be put into effect gradually, but, beginning April 11, all new pound deposits will be taken in the name of Lloyds Bank P.L.C. Existing deposits and loans with Lloyds Bank Ltd. will continue to run until maturity.

title: Boxing Computer
description: Boxers have been known to adopt any number of aliases in order to continue fighting when they may be medically unfit or otherwise under suspension in a particular state. But if Ralph Citro has his way, this a.k.a. practice may soon be eliminated.

title: Pacific Telephone Rearranging Debt
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Pacific Telephone Company have agreed on a plan to reorganize Pacific Telephone's finances.

title: FM RADIO SERVICE IS EXPANDED
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved new rules allowing FM radio stations to use their facilities to transmit data such as electronic mail and offer nationwide paging services, competing directly with phone companies and other communications concerns.

title: Newark Bishop Is Consecrated
description: The sixth Auxiliary Bishop of Newark, David Arias, was consecrated here today in the Cathedral of the Sacred Heart before more than 3,000 people.

title: Historians' Books Win 1983 Bancroft Prizes
description: This year's Bancroft Prizes, for books of exceptional merit and distinction in American history, were awarded last night to John P. Demos, for ''Entertaining Satan: Witchcraft and the Culture of Early New England'' (Oxford University Press), and to Nick Salvatore, for ''Eugene V. Debs: Citizen and Socialist'' (University of Illinois Press).

title: WALESA IS INVITED BY HARVARD TO CEREMONY BUT HE DECLINES
description: Lech Walesa, the former leader of Poland's banned Solidarity union, accepted an invitation from Harvard University last month to speak at the June commencement. But he said yesterday in Poland that he would have to turn down the offer for fear the authorities would deny him re-entry.

title: DIRECTED BERLIN AIRLIFT IN 1948
description: Lieut. Gen. William H. Tunner, retired, who directed the Berlin airlift in the 1948-1949, died Wednesday of heart disease at Walter Reed Memorial Hospital in Gloucester, Va. He was 76 years old and lived in Ware Neck, Va.

title: Bombs Kill 6 in Assam; Clashes in Other States
description: Bomb blasts left at least six dead in Assam today, the authorities reported. Meanwhile, the police opened fire to rout protesters in Tripura, and Sikh militants clashed with politicians in Punjab.

title: MANEUVERS TO RAISE SATELLITE INTO A HIGHER ORBIT DELAYED
description: Officials of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration decided today to delay for about a week the beginning of maneuvers to correct the orbit of the communications satellite that was launched by the space shuttle Challenger.

title: ROGER CHAUVERON, OWNED RESTAURANTS AT 2 EAST SIDE SITES
description: Roger Chauveron, who had operated two successful East Side restaurants, Cafe Chauveron and Cafe Chambord, died of emphysema and coronary failure Wednesday at the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, L.I. He lived in Bal Harbour, Fla., and had been visiting relatives in Westbury, L.I. He was 82 years old.

title: MIDWESTERN FUEL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Pacific Press Halting Operation
description: Pacific Press, which prints regional editions of Time, People, Sports Illustrated and other national magazines, will close operations because of increasing financial losses, laying off 500 to 600 workers, the parent company said.

title: Dow Advances 4.16, to 1,117.65
description: Stock market prices closed slightly higher yesterday, with some of the retailing issues making the best gains. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow price range throughout the session, ended up 4.16 points, at 1,117.65. In the previous four trading days, the key average tumbled almost 30 points mainly because of concern that interest rates would rise.

title: A Jewish Group in U.S.  Takes Issue With Begin
description: The Administration's efforts to persuade King Hussein to enter Middle East peace negotiations was encouraged today when a major American Jewish organization openly differed with Prime Minister Menachem Begin on the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: 2 FAMOUS TOUGH GUYS
description: TWO familiar tough guys reappear in new guises this weekend, leaving the electronic landscape strewn with broken hearts and mangled bodies. Tomorrow night at 9 on Channel 2, Mickey Spillane's Mike Hammer gets still another reincarnation in a television movie called ''Murder Me, Murder You.'' This time, the hard-as-nails private eye is played by Stacy Keach. Sunday night at 10, Channel 4 is beginning a limited weekly series based on the classic movie ''Casablanca.'' In this one, Rick, owner of the Cafe Americain in Morocco, is portrayed by David Soul.

title: NEXT SEASON AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: Carnegie Hall's 1983-84 season will include a ''French Opera Comique'' series featuring Frederica von Stade in all three performances; chamber music by groups including the English Chamber Orchestra, I Musici, Orpheus, the Cleveland and Juilliard Quartets and the Academy of St. Martin-in-the-Fields Octet in their New York debut; and a violin series featuring Isaac Stern, Pinchas Zukerman, Nathan Milstein, Shlomo Mintz, Miriam Fried, Cho-Liang Lin, Elmar Oliveira and Henryk Szeryng.

title: A PHONE'S WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: Women Suspended
description: Wyoming athletic officials ordered the women's softball team suspended from competition indefinitely following the intensification of ''internal problems'' with the team.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC (INC) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HEALTHY NEW START FOR DAVID HOLLAND
description: JUST about a year ago, David Holland, one of the finest bassists in modern jazz, was undergoing open-heart surgery, the aftermath of an infection that nearly killed him. Mr. Holland, who had been a key member of groups led by Miles Davis, Anthony Braxton and Sam Rivers, considers what happened in surgery a minor miracle.

title: BULGARIAN SCOFFS AT TIMES ARTICLE
description: A Bulgarian spokesman, responding to an article published in The New York Times on March 23, has questioned whether a Bulgarian intelligence official mentioned in the report actually exists. The official was reported to have said that the Soviet secret police wanted Pope John Paul II killed to prevent Western subversion of Poland.

title: SABRES TOP CANADIANS TO LEAD SERIES, 2-0
description: Gilles Hamel and Mal Davis scored 36 seconds apart in the second period, and Bob Sauve got his second shutout in as many nights to spark Buffalo to a 3-0 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight, giving the Sabres a 2-0 lead in their Stanley Cup playoff.

title: SCHOOLS STUDY ETHICS OF BUSINESS-AIDED RESEARCH
description: Harvard and Yale Universities are moving toward adopting rules to limit the influence that commercial interests bring to bear on laboratory studies they sponsor.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is so American. It is big. It is, if I may say, crazy.

title: Stepien Selling The Cavaliers
description: Ted Stepien, who said last month he would move the Cleveland Cavaliers to Toronto, said today he had signed a deal to sell his majority interest in the National Basketball Association team to Gordon and George Gund, whose holdings include hockey's Minnesota North Stars. The Gunds own and operate the suburban Richfield Coliseum, the Cavaliers' home court.

title: Report Names Schlichter
description: A National Football League player, said to be Art Schlichter of the Baltimore Colts, reportedly ran up $389,000 in gambling debts and then aided the F.B.I. in an investigation of four men charged with illegal gambling.

title: 5 Organizations Will Get Bulk Of $2.5 Million Godfrey Estate
description: Arthur Godfrey left the bulk of his $2.5 million estate to five organizations and gave nothing to his two former wives, according to court papers.

title: Kodak Recasts Unit's Name
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has decided to change the six-day-old name of its camera-making unit, the U.S. Equipment Division, figuring people might not want to buy USED cameras.

title: LOSS OF BEACH HOUSES BRINGS FLOOD INSURANCE UNDER SCRUTINY
description: Three years ago, Ted Gronlund, a businessman who works in Manhattan and lives on the Upper East Side, bought a second home on the beach here for $143,000.

title: 36 Are Felled by Smoke In a South Bronx Blaze
description: Thirty-six people, including a dozen children and 15 firemen, were overcome last night by choking clouds of smoke that engulfed a sixstory apartment building in the South Bronx in an electrical fire.

title: The U.N. Today; April 8, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend paid March 3.

title: AT REBEL CAMP, HANOI'S THREAT IS A FACT OF LIFE
description: Here at the military headquarters of anti-Vietnamese Cambodians loyal to Son Sann, a former Prime Minister, all the camp's residents - 8,000 civilians as well as several thousand soldiers -are aware that the settlement can be overrun at any moment.

title: TACO VIVA INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
RESCUE BID AIMS AT LITTLE MAGAZINES
description: Three years ago, the financially ailing Harper's magazine was preparing to cease publishing, when two private foundations stepped in and saved the 130-year-old literary and opinion monthly. Now, the Harper's Magazine Foundation, created in 1980 to shore up the publication, is carrying out a rescue operation of its own, this one to insure a more stable future for hundreds of small literary magazines, which otherwise might have to shut down.

title: BEYOND THE RIGHTS OF A STUDENT GOVERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Fernand Legros, Dealer in Art
description: Fernand Legros, a flamboyant millionaire art dealer who served a brief prison term for selling faked works of European modern masters to a wealthy Texas art collector in the 1960's, died of cancer Wednesday in a village in southwestern France. He was 52 years old and was buried yesterday in a private service in the village of Chassenuil-sur-Bonnieure.

title: THE FIRST NECESSITY
description: Senator Charles Percy of Illinois, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, is of the opinion that ''in the foreseeable future'' there is no chance for a Soviet-American agreement limiting medium-range missiles in Europe. Why is that?

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HEARTBURN. By Nora Ephron. 179 pages. Knopf. $11.95.

title: ARGENTINA LINKED TO RISE IN COVERT U.S. ACTIONS AGAINST SANDINISTS
description: United States involvement in covert guerrilla activities against Nicaragua increased sharply last year after Argentina largely halted its assistance to the rebels, according to Administration officials. The Argentine move was in reaction to President Reagan's support for Britain in the Falkland war, the officials said.

title: REAGAN REJECTS CUOMO BID AND STAYS OUT OF RAIL STRIKE
description: President Reagan today turned down a request by Governor Cuomo to intercede in the Metro-North railroad strike. Federal intervention in the month long dispute ''could set an unfortunate precedent,'' according to a letter that Transportation Secretary Elizabeth H. Dole wrote today to Mr. Cuomo on behalf of Mr. Reagan.

title: Funds Down $1.97 Billion
description: Assets of money market funds fell $1.97 billion for the week ended Wednesday, to $180.1 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The drop in the previous week was $2.2 billion, the same as the week before.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Going Out Guide last Monday gave an incorrect date for readings by Betty Comden and Adolph Green at the Donnell Library Center. They will take place Monday at 12:30 P.M.

title: Soldier Gets Life Term In Dome of Rock Death
description: Alan Harry Goodman, the Israeli Army recruit who shot his way into a mosque on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem last April 11 and started an Arab riot, was sentenced to life imprisonment plus 40 years today for the murder of a Moslem guard and the attempted murder of four others.

title: Youth Bitten by Viper Is Reported Recovering
description: A teen-ager suspected of stealing a deadly snake from the National Zoo is making a remarkable recovery from a bite inflicted by the African reptile, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: Second-Opinion Screening

title: STEWART & STEVENSON SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net income

title: IDAHO REPUBLICAN INDICTED IN FINANCE DISCLOSURE CASE
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted Representative George V. Hansen, Republican of Idaho, on charges of filing false financial disclosure statements.

title: SANDINIST REBEL IS REPORTED BACK IN NICARAGUA
description: Close aides of Eden Pastora Gomez, the former Sandinist commander, said here today that he had entered Nicarcgua secretly. He is organizing his supporters for a challenge to the Sandinist Government, they said.

title: FRIDAY, APRIL 8, 1983
description: International

title: 'LOSIN' IT'
description: GUESS what they're losing in ''Losin' It,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters? Here are some hints: They're losing it in a bordello, and they're losing it in Tijuana. This is the story of four fun-loving American teen-agers who head south of the border for a little excitement, traveling in a fancy red convertible. The locals don't seem to like these gringos much, pointing out, ''You come to Mexico to do things you wouldn't do in your own country.'' They have a point, though it's one that the movie doesn't work overtime to pursue.

title: RESTAURATEUR SHOT DEAD BY THE POLICE IN MIX-UP
description: A Queens restaurant owner who was spending the night in his establishment to trap intruders was shot to death by two plainclothes police officers early yesterday. The police said the officers opened fire after the owner had attacked them with a baseball bat, apparently thinking they were burglars.

title: THE NINE-YEAR EFFORT TO BUILD A JERSEY CONDOMINIUM
description: The Admiralty, a 162-apartment condominium in this small beachfront community 55 miles from New York City, is nearly a decade old. But only last August did it open for occupancy.

title: Conviction Is Reinstated For Ex-Gov. Blanton
description: A Federal appellate court today reinstated the convictions of former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee and two of his former aides in a case involving conspiracy to sell liquor licenses.

title: 25,000 ARE DRIVEN FROM HOMES BY FLOODING IN 3 SOUTHERN STATES
description: A deluge of rain swamped the Deep South yesterday, causing extensive flooding that forced the evacuation of about 25,000 people from their homes and isolated the million residents of the New Orleans area.

title: OLD AND NEW WORLDS MEET ON LOWER EAST SIDE
description: FOR the weekend explorer willing to go in search of the Jewish Lower East Side of old, there are relics of that distant past, tinted with quaintness, still to be found, some of them in working trim, some only unmarked mementoes of more stirring times. There is still a Jewish Lower East Side alive in the midst of a Hispanic Lower East Side, a Chinese Lower East Side and an Italian Lower East Side. But it is not the old ''ghetto'' where immigrants sweated in workshops, spoke Yiddish, espoused creeds that ran from Orthodox Judaism to anarchy and yearned for the day when Golden America would beam on them and waft them off to paradisiacal living in Brooklyn, the Bronx or, one should only live so long, Uptown, on Riverside Drive. Metropolitan Baedeker

title: London Index a Record
description: The Financial Times's 750 all-share index closed at a record 421.64 today, compared with the previous record 421.13 set on March 15 and yesterday's finish at 415.96. The Times's 500-share index also ended at a record level today, at 459.14, against the previous high of 455.82 of March 15, and yesterday's 451.88 finish.

title: O'Hare Bonds
description: A $175 million issue of O'Hare International Airport revenue bonds was offered yesterday by a Goldman, Sachs & Company group, with serial bonds yielding from 6 percent in 1985 to 9.3 percent in 1998. Long-term 9 1/2 percent bonds due in 2003 were offered at a price of 100 and 9 5/8 percent bonds due in 2013 at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 9.675 percent.

title: Songs of Argentina
description: The Argentine singer Mercedes Sosa, whose repertory includes political and folk songs, will perform Sunday in the auditorium of Washington Irving High School, 40 Irving Place at 16th Street. Tickets are $7 to $15, and more information is available from Taller Latinoamericano, 255-7155.

title: Charges Are Filed In Crash Fatal to 5
description: The driver of a flatbed truck involved in a five-death crash on Route 8 southeast of here has been charged with having an unapproved hitch and failing to display an emblem identifying the truck as a slow-moving vehicle.

title: RIGHTS PANEL CITES DATA DELAY
description: The chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that the Reagan Administration had provided information the panel had sought under threat of subpoena, but commission members complained of delays.

title: BALLET: PREMIERE OF 'YOUNG APOLLO'
description: DOES the world need another ballet about the god Apollo? Maybe not. But John Clifford's new ''Young Apollo,'' presented by the Los Angeles Ballet Wednesday, was worth a trip to the Joyce Theater, where the company performs again tomorrow.

title: Children Should Not Sleep in Parks
description: In the course of a year, more than 5,000 poor families in New York City have no place to live. Some get evicted, others burned out. Unlike the numerous homeless adults who refuse shelter, homeless families are desperate for clean, safe places to stay.

title: THE BENEFITS OF AGILITY
description: Robert Parish's best shot is a looping jumper that he can hit from any angle and at distances of more than 20 feet, and he used it effectively against the Knicks in Boston Wednesday night. But it was his play under the backboard, a tip-in of a second missed shot by Larry Bird, that did the big damage in the Celtics' 102-98 victory.

title: DATA TERMINAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
SEPHARDIM ARE TRANSFORMING ISRAEL'S POLITICAL MAP
description: The ethnic tensions and social and economic divisions among Israel's Jews are exerting a decisive influence on the country's politics, considerably strengthening the power base of Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: Gulfstream Goes Public
description: Shearson/American Express yesterday announced an initial public offering of 8 million shares of the Gulfstream Aerospace Company at $19 a share.

title: 10 Chicagoans Are Charged With Fraud in November Vote
description: Ten people were indicted today on charges of stealing and buying votes and other fraud in last November's general election.

title: Baldwin's Stock Falls
description: The stock of financially troubled Baldwin-United fell yesterday by $3.37, to $11.50. For the last week, the financial services company has been seeking at least a 90-day extension of payments on some $800 million in short-term debt.

title: CELEBRATING A NEW BRANCH OF THE WHITNEY
description: Leaders from the art and corporate worlds sipped cocktails and mingled last night among several large pieces of modern sculpture that included a huge ''breathing'' ice bag by Claes Oldenburg.

title: TIMBERLAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $12,000. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $153,000.

title: Mobil Names Heads Of Two Divisions
description: The Mobil Corporation yesterday moved to another stage in its management succession process, appointing new heads of two of its divisions.

title: CONGRESSMAN TELLS OF A SALVADOR THREAT
description: The president of the Salvadoran National Assembly, Roberto D'Aubuisson, sent one of his security guards to the United States last year to ''investigate'' a California Congressman after he had visited El Salvador in April, according to a confidential State Department cablegram.

title: JUDGE BLOCKS LARGER TRUCKS ON SOME GEORGIA HIGHWAYS
description: A Federal district judge today temporarily blocked the Government from enforcing its rule allowing larger trucks to travel on certain non-Interstate highways in Georgia.

title: THE REGION
description: Governor Kean signed a bill today requiring the use of safety restraints in automobiles for children under 5 years old. He also signed a measure making it a crime to have a blood-alcohol content of one-tenth of a percent or higher while driving.

title: PERSIAN GULF COUNTRIES FAIL AGAIN ON A PACT FOR COMBATING OIL SPILL
description: An emergency meeting of Persian Gulf nations whose coastlines are threatened by an oil spill ended in disarray in Kuwait tonight as efforts to obtain a temporary ceasefire in the 31-month-old war between Iraq and Iran failed.

title: CITY IS CHECKING DELIVERY TRUCKS OVER ILLEGAL FUEL
description: New York City is making spot checks of oil trucks coming into the city in an effort to trace the source of illegal fuel that it found in private apartment houses this winter.

title: ROUGH NUCLEAR EQUALITY IS CRUCIAL
description: President Reagan's recent proposal for limiting Soviet and American medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe should be seen for what it is: a variation on the original zero option proposal. The principle that forms the basis of both offers is that of equality between the two great powers in intermediate-range nuclear missiles. Whether this principle is realized at zero or at some level above zero is less important than the insistence that whatever the level, there must be a rough equality.

title: L.I. Couple Killed, By Fumes in Car
description: A Long Island couple were found dead early today, apparently accidentally overcome by carbon monoxide fumes while they were seated in a car with the motor running, authorities said.

title: Sitting Pretty
description: What do a Texas millionaire, Anthony Quinn and a former Miss America have in common? All have asked to ride in the lead car of this year's New York City Marathon and have been turned down by the New York Road Runners Club.

title: Akiba Eisenberg Dead at 74; Austrian Chief Rabbi 35 Years
description: Dr. Akiba Eisenberg, Chief Rabbi of Vienna and Austria for 35 years, died today of heart failure, Jewish community leaders announced.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for 16 wks to Feb 26.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split issued March 11, 1983.

title: BID TO CURB LENDING OVERSEAS
description: As a quid pro quo for higher American contributions to the International Monetary Fund, rules governing international lending by American banks would be tightened under a proposal that bank regulators will submit to Congress Friday.

title: BEWILDERMENT AND DISMAY VOICED BY U.S. SPORTS AND CULTURE GROUPS
description: There was mixed reaction in the United States yesterday to China's announcement that it would not take part in 10 sports events and 9 cultural exchanges scheduled for this year. Some groups expressed bewilderment and others dismay, and still others said the Chinese action did not matter.

title: COVERT ACTIONS: DEBATING WISDOM AND MORALITY
description: The latest disclosures about the Reagan Administration's covert program in Central America have raised old questions about the wisdom and morality of secret American involvement in the internal affairs of other countries.

title: Another Country
description: A t Harlem's Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture the other evening, Viola McFerren of rural Fayette County, Tenn., found herself talking to David Torres, who lives in a single-room-occupancy hotel on West 95th Street.

title: BLISS, A T, & CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
British 'Passion' is finally finding its way to Broadway
description: THE Broadway production of Peter Nichols's London hit ''Passion Play,'' which has been in the works for two years, suddenly came together this week and was rushed into rehearsal so it could open before May 15, the cutoff date for the Tony Awards. The play, which has been retitled ''Passion,'' will open on May 10 at the Longacre. The production will star Frank Langella, Bob Gunton, Cathryn Damon, E. Katherine Kerr, Roxanne Hart and Stephanie Gordon. It will be directed by Marshall W. Mason.

title: Nouvelle cuisine with classic touch
description: WHEN we last saw Michel Fitoussi, he was holding forth in the kitchen of the Palace, the East Side restaurant always more noted for the price than the quality of its food. But in January he moved to 24 Fifth Avenue, the graceful Art Nouveau restaurant at Ninth Street, taking along his wire whisks and saucepans, his ways with whitechocolate mousse and caramel sauce, and the razor-sharp knives with which he shreds the green leaves of leeks that bind tiny vegetables into tiny bundles.

title: Denver Mayor Suspends Three Top Policemen
description: Mayor William McNichols announced today that he had suspended three of Denver's top police officers without pay amid charges they knew of a scheme to skim money from bingo games.

title: News Analysis
description: When Yasir Arafat's armor-plated Mercedes rolled up to the front door of King Hussein's palace for the two men's first round of talks last Saturday, the car door swung open, the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman stepped out and, for one brief moment, nobody was there to greet him. King Hussein then rushed out of the palace, flipping off his glasses as if he had been reading a newspaper and his wife had asked him to see who was at the door.

title: G.P.U. Settles Suit On Nuclear Mishap
description: The General Public Utilities Corporation said yesterday that it had settled a stockholder class action suit brought in connection with the Three Mile Island nuclear accident in 1979.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA HAS INVINCIBLE ATTITUDE
description: Even the clay under her feet doesn't worry her anymore. Some of the women here were hoping that the artificial clay surface, perhaps more than anything they might accomplish with racquets, would help bring an end to Martina Navratilova's winning streak and the air of invincibility that surrounds her. All of which she finds amusing.

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $328,000. c-After a loss of $21,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Jan Troell calm about Oscar bid
description: THE Swedish director Jan Troell will be flying to California for the Academy Awards presentations because his ''Flight of the Eagle'' (reviewed on page C8) has won a nomination as best foreign-language picture.

title: WARSAW PACT JOGS NATO ON A TREATY
description: Foreign ministers of the Warsaw Pact countries concluded a two-day meeting in Prague today with a communique urging the North Atlantic alliance to look constructively at the offer of a nonaggression treaty made in January.

title: SYMPHONY: MAHLER'S 2D
description: MAHLER's ''Resurrection'' Symphony is a 90-minute, five-movement search for the mystery of life that employs two vocal soloists, chorus and orchestra. Because of its grand scope and apocalyptic tone, it is generally the only work played on a program and that was how it was last night at Carnegie Hall where Gilbert E. Kaplan led the American Symphony Orchestra through the Mahler. In fact, however, no other work could have been on the program simply because Mr. Kaplan's entire repertory consists of just this one symphony.

title: Value Line Plans First Public Sale
description: Value Line Inc., the nation's largest investment advisory service, filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of 1.9 million shares of common stock.

title: Homeless Picket Legal Aid Society
description: Homeless families and welfare-rights advocates picketed the offices of the Legal Aid Society at 11 Park Place yesterday to protest a class-action suit the society filed last week against the city and the state on behalf of the homeless.

title: ATTAINABLE SPACE-BASED DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss Bank Losses
description: The Union Bank of Switzerland's chairman, Robert Holzach, said today that the bank lost less than $600,000 in the collapse of Italy's Banco Ambrosiano last year.

title: CONGRESSMAN FAULTS SUPPORT BY THE U.S. FOR ANTI-SANDINISTS
description: Representative Wyche Fowler Jr., chairman of a House subcommittee that oversees the covert operations of the Central Intelligence Agency, said today that United States support of anti-Government forces in Nicaragua did not fully comply with the law.

title: POP-JAZZ: CLEO LAINE, SINGER
description: FEW singers are more naturally gifted than Cleo Laine, the English pop-jazz contralto who celebrated the 10th anniversary of her Carnegie Hall debut Wednesday evening. Miss Laine's rich smoky alto, with its sensual, almost overripe vibrato and phenomenal upper register, remains an amazingly flexible instrument.

title: COAST TRAINER IS STILL GOING STRONG AT 77
description: Buster Millerick winds up and feigns pitching a fastball toward the manure pit with a bottle of thick red fluid.

title: Alas For Plausibility
description: President Reagan is worried about perceptions of the U.S. in Europe, especially the signs of anti-Americanism in the ''successor generation'' to people who lived through World War II and its aftermath.

title: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $491,000 for the quarter and $1,903,000 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $337,000 from the repurchase of debentures.

title: Abbott's Profit Gains by 17.9%
description: Abbott Laboratories, a worldwide manufacturer of health-care products, announced yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1983 increased 17.9 percent, to $75.2 million, or 62 cents a share, from $63.8 million, or 52 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

title: Palmer, on 68, Trails 3 by Shot
description: Arnie's Army mustered at the first tee of Augusta National Golf Club today and headed out behind its aging but popular leader on a thrilling, 6,905-yard march that had the troops dreaming of a fifth Masters victory.

title: CHARITIES THE ADMINISTRATION DOESN'T LIKE
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRYSLER PLANS TO BUY VW PLANT NEAR DETROIT
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would buy Volkswagen of America's mothballed automobile assembly plant north of Detroit and use it to build a new front-wheel-drive car.

title: B.A.T. Profits Advance
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C. said today that it had 1982 pretax profits of 856 million, up from 684 million a year earlier, on turnover of 11.51 billion, up from 9.27 billion. The pound is worth $1.51 in United States currency. B.A.T. said retailing turnover and trading profits in 1982 were helped by the acquisition of Marshall Field in the United States.

title: Argentina Loan Delay
description: Argentina's continued arrears in external debt service payments and lack of central bank guidelines for refinancing $1.5 billion of swaps are holding up the granting of a new $1.5 billion loan by creditor banks, banking sources said today. The five-year loan, to help Argentina with payments on its $38.7 billion external debt, was originally due to be signed by the end of March, but the sources said it was now unlikely to be agreed on before the end of April.

title: Westchester Files Stouffer's Appeal
description: The Westchester District Attorney has asked a state appellate court to reinstate the murder convictions of Luis Marin in the deaths of 26 people during a fire at the Stouffer's Inn in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Caution Issued on Effect Of Caffeine on Heartbeat
description: The caffeine contained in just two cups of coffee, tea or cola can cause changes in the human heartbeat that may be dangerous for some people, a doctor says.

title: WHY SEGAL IS DOING HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL
description: ''A little over a year ago,'' the sculptor George Segal said the other day, ''I got a letter from Mayor Diane Feinstein of San Francisco's Committee for a Memorial to the Six Million Victims of the Holocaust, asking me to submit a drawing or a maquette. I didn't want to do it because I knew I would be steeped in death for months on end.''

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
KING KONG, AT 50, LACKS GET UP AND GO
description: Invariably, these big apes that come to New York and hang on the top of the Empire State Building making spectacles of themselves run into trouble. It happened to King Kong in 1933, and it's happening again to a 3,000-pound model being tethered to the top of the building in commemoration of the film's 50th anniversary.

title: Swan and Allen Pitch 4-Hitter Mets 6 Phillies 2
description: The revival of the Mets, or whatever it is, continued at Shea Stadium yesterday when they made it two straight over the Philadelphia Phillies with a 6-2 victory on a four-hitter by Craig Swan and Neil Allen.

title: ART: GEORG BASELITZ AND HIS UPSIDE-DOWNS
description: IT would be difficult to be in touch with new painting and not know by now that for quite some years the image in the paintings of Georg Baselitz has been painted upside down. The reason for this is that Baselitz likes us to perceive the paint as paint, in the first place, and only then to take in the subject matter. Perception is sequential, in other words, though sometimes it is hard to say which of the two operations comes first.

title: ROLL-CALL ON BUDGET BY PANEL IN SENATE
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate Budget Committee today approved an increase of 5 percent in military spending in the 1984 fiscal year: FOR THE 5% FIGURE - 17 Republicans - 8 Armstrong, Colo.

title: Braniff and Union Agree on Contract
description: The president of the Braniff International Corporation, Howard D. Putnam, said the company had negotiated a labor contract with the International Association of Machinists that would allow the bankrupt airline to reopen its key maintenance base.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 8, 1983
description: International

title: AFFORDING DEFENSE AND MORE
description: Though the United States is engaged in a debate about defense and domestic spending priorities that may be crucial for our survival, the most basic and obvious facts relevant to that debate are never put on the table.

title: Bridge: New Yorkers Rally to Beat Opponents in New Zealand
description: The Precision team of touring New York experts had a scare here Wednesday night when they trailed the Wellington team by 25 international match points after three deals. But the experience of the visitors eventually prevailed, and they won by 26 points.

title: U.S. Officials Say Flu Season Is Continuing to Wind Down
description: Federal health researchers believe the 1982-83 flu season is continuing to wind down, although people are still dying from flu and its complications.

title: Surprise Visitor
description: There was the Rangers' Scot Kleinendorst, all 6 feet 3 inches and 205 pounds of him, holding a skate at arm's length and suppressing an urge to say, ''Eek!''

title: CITY'S RETAIL SALES UP 12.1% IN MONTH
description: March retail sales in New York City rose 12.1 percent over 1982, the biggest monthly gain since a 19.1 percent surge in April 1981, a spot-check of the area's seven largest retailers showed yesterday.

title: British Columbia To Vote on May 5
description: Premier Bill Bennett today called a provincial general election for May 5, saying investment uncertainty could be cleared only by a provincial government with a ''strong and enduring mandate.''

title: FARE RISE AND AID SAVE 6 BUS ROUTES
description: Increases in fares and a state subsidy will save Greyhound bus service for 37 upstate communities, Governor Cuomo announced today.

title: SKIPPER'S INC reports earnings for qtr to March 20.
Economic Scene; Protectionism Vs. Free Trade
description: IN Pittsburgh, where the jobless rate is over 16 percent, President Reagan has just run into one of the biggest demonstrations of his Presidency. One of the thousands of demonstrators standing in the rain outside the hotel where he spoke was a 52-year-old unemployed steelworker named Joseph Rice, who had been out of work for a year. ''We were all counting on this Administration to do something,'' he said, ''but it's obvious they don't care.'' Mr. Rice said strong tariffs were needed to keep out steel imports.

title: STANDARD MICROSYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
TREASURY RATES UP SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates for Treasury issues rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday, reversing some of the declines that occurred in the previous two days.

title: Finance Aides Asked to Meet
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, seeking better coordination of international economic policies, said today that he had invited trade and finance ministers of the six other leading industrial countries to meetings in Paris May 10-11.

title: Eisenreich Out Again
description: He's tried everything from medication to self hypnosis, but nothing seems to work for Jim Eisenreich. Yesterday, following a recurrence of the nervous condition that kept him out of the Minnesota Twins' lineup for most of the 1982 season, the 23-year-old slugging center fielder was placed on the 15-day disabled list, prompting speculation that his major league career may be at an end. Minnesota took the action after Eisenreich, who had been a spring training standout with a .400 batting average, asked to be excused from the home game yesterday against Detroit.

title: FOR V.L.I., SUCCESS AT LAST
description: It was an occasion that Bruce W. Vorhauer had anticipated for more than seven years. The times when few financial supporters stood at his side, and many creditors called, were finally behind him.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORGANIZATION reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: Results have been translated at the rate of one pound sterling equals $1.6175.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split on Jan. 31, 1983.

title: F.C.C. Commissioner Leaving Agency in May
description: Anne P. Jones, a Boston lawyer who has worked in various Federal regulatory roles over the last 15 years, surprised her colleagues yesterday by announcing her resignation from the Federal Communications Commission, effective May 31. She has been a commissioner since 1979. Previously she had worked at the Securities and Exchange Commission, and later as general counsel at the Federal Home Loan Bank Board.

title: Topics; Tall Tale, and Toll; Wrong Kong
description: Why does it always have to be the authorities who exact the tolls? It's happening again, this time in Hong Kong, which has begun an experiment called electronic road pricing on heavily used thoroughfares. One kind of electronic device will be fitted to every car and will exchange signals with another type, to be embedded in the pavement at busy locations.

title: TRUST COMPANY OF GEORGIA reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
The Art of Being James Watt
description: The Secretary of the Interior is in the news again, this time because he sought to ban rock groups like the Beach Boys and the Grass Roots from the Fourth of July celebration on the Washington Mall. The bands attract ''the wrong element,'' Mr. Watt explained - young people taking drugs and drinking.

title: Tribune Co. Plan On Stock Cleared
description: Shareholders of the closely held Tribune Company have approved charter amendments that would allow the offering of up to 50 million shares of common stock to the public, Stanton R. Cook, president, said.

title: RABIES ALERT ON RACCOONS
description: As if Washington area residents did not already have enough to worry about, what with zoo vipers on the loose and rock-and-roll on trial, now they must be on the lookout for raccoons spreading what is believed to be the worst rabies epidemic in the nation.

title: BOOK FAIR OF THE OLD, FINE AND RARE
description: Of the thousands of first editions, old-master drawings, prints, maps, atlases, manuscripts, autographs and incunabula (books printed before 1501) from all over the world included in the New York Antiquarian Book Fair at the Seventh Regiment Armory, which opened last night and continues today and tomorrow, perhaps the most poignant piece of Americana is a tantalizing antebellum poster (from David Bauman, bookseller) put up by a master seeking a runaway slave. It reads in part:

title: Supermarkets General Appoints a New Chief
description: Directors of the Supermarkets General Corporation, the nation's 10th-largest food chain, yesterday elected Leonard Lieberman chief executive officer, succeeding Herbert Brody. The 54-year-old Mr. Lieberman has been president since 1982 and will also retain that post.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: EVEN if King Kong hadn't attempted to scale the heights of the E mpire State Building once more, the city would still have been a wash in 30's nostalgia this week. Consider the parties.

title: Prudential Realty Issues New Mortgage Security
description: Prudential Realty Securities Inc. introduced a new kind of mortgage-backed security yesterday with a $300.2 million issue of zero-coupon bonds due annually from 1984 to 1997.

title: THE RISE OF OIL'S SPOT MARKET
description: In a boxy brick building in Wayne, Pa., that might be mistaken for a post office, just down the road from the immaculate 19th-century homes that checker Philadelphia's western suburbs, Gerard F. Cerchio said the other day that he was sitting at ''the center of the universe.''

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including tax credits of $149,000 for the quarter and $298,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $313,000 for the quarter and $612,000 for the 6 months.

title: Trash Sites Picked In Westchester
description: Committees of the Westchester County Board of Legislators tonight chose two sites for county garbage compacting stations, over objections by officials and residents of White Plains and Briarcliff Manor.

title: ABC Net Outlook
description: The American Broadcasting Companies will report that first quarter earnings fell about 35 cents a share from the period a year before, Frederick S. Pierce, ABC president, told security analysts.

title: Harrison A. Mitnick, 55, Dies; Hearst Corp. Vice President
description: Harrison A. Mitnick, vice president, treasurer and chief financial officer of the Hearst Corporation, died Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Music for the 'Middle Brow'
description: ''It's the first time we've had an orchestra for the middle-brow soul,'' Skitch Henderson said, explaining his new New York Pops orchestra, which is to debut tonight at Carnegie Hall. Dapper in white tie and goatee, he will conduct the 100-member group in popular classics by Victor Herbert, Irving Berlin, Leonard Bernstein and the Beatles.

title: 'BLACK MAGIC' OF JOHNNY JOHNSTON IS BACK
description: JOHNNY JOHNSTON is somewhat surprised to find himself singing at Michael's Pub. He thought he had left show business behind in 1971. By then, in a career that had spread over four decades, he had hit the top in popular music. He had been a band singer in the big-band era with Art Kassel and his Castles in the Air. He was part of the legendary Chicago radio world that produced Fibber McGee and Molly, Jim and Don Ameche, Mercedes McCambridge and Fran Allison, when he sang on ''The Breakfast Club'' 15 times a week in the late 1930's.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 12.
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in March 1983.

title: A Gift for Liberty
description: The children of Bridgeport Conn. -24,200 in public and parochial schools - have collected $3,587 to help restore the Statue of Liberty. Yesterday, 50 of them came to visit the statue and present a check at the Park Avenue offices of the Statue of Liberty-Ellis Island Centennial Commission.

title: BISCAYNE SAVINGS ATTRACTING BIDDERS
description: Some major banks and savings institutions said today that they were interested in bidding for Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan of Miami, which was declared insolvent this week and taken over by Federal regulators.

title: New Jobless Claims Increase
description: First-time claims for unemployment benefits rose in the week ended March 26 after two consecutive weeks of decline, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

title:
PATENTS;
Phone Ring Detector Has a Visual Display
description: A new telephone ringing detector for the deaf, which has a visual display, was patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. Richard G. Sparber of Wheaton, Ill., obtained patent 4,379,210.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split declared in December.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: Lawrence Butcher is a slight, soft-spoken man who lives in Queens and once sold hardware for a living. Nevertheless, the mere sight of him can cause grown men to drive recklessly down Lexington Avenue, to pull away from the curb as though demons were after them, to drop a hot dog with extra sauerkraut onto the counter of a fast-food wagon and say over and over, like a mantra, ''Oh man, oh man, give me a break.''

title: Drilling Off in Canada
description: Oil and gas drilling in western Canada is being reduced sharply this year from the low level of 1982. Industry officials and analysts have attributed the slowdown, in part, to a huge natural gas surplus, a small domestic oil surplus and the end last December of a drilling subsidy program by the government of Alberta. Canada's oil pricing and taxing policies and the world oil glut are also factors, they say.

title: Wallace Leaves Hospital
description: Gov. George C. Wallace today left a hospital here where he had spent almost three weeks for treatment to reduce pain. Mr. Wallace has been in virtually constant pain since he was shot while campaigning for the Presidential nomination in 1972. The wound left him paralyzed from the waist down.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SCHLICHTER ADMITS HEAVY BETTING LOSSES
description: Art Schlichter, the backup quarterback for the Baltimore Colts, lost almost $400,000 betting on basketball games this year and then, when the gamblers pressed him for payment, helped Federal authorities build a case against them, according to Schlichter and Federal court documents.

title: MOSCOW PUTS OUT A BOOKLET IN ITS ANTIMISSILE CAMPAIGN
description: The Soviet Union brought out a 95-page booklet today as part of its campaign against the deployment of new American medium-range missiles in Europe.

title: 6 PEOPLE KILLED AS SMALL PLANE CRASHES UPSTATE
description: All six people aboard a singleengine plane were killed today when it crashed into a hill shortly after takeoff, skidded 150 yards and burned, officials said.

title: The Bridge China Didn't Burn
description: The decision to grant political asylum to Hu Na, the Chinese tennis player, is not illegal, immoral or an attempt to interfere in China's internal affairs. It underlines instead an inescapable difficulty in any program of exchanges between a closed and an open society.

title: WASHINGTON UTILITY FACES DEBT DEFAULT
description: The chairman of the Washington Public Power Supply System executive board said today that the supply system may find itself in default on the $7 billion debt on two terminated nuclear power plants by the end of the month.

title: Miss Navratilova Averts Loss
description: She took a deep breath and slowly exhaled, all the time shaking her head in disbelief. Martina Navratilova heard the crowd applauding as she walked off the court today, but she figured it wasn't for her as much as for Andrea Temesvari and the fact that the Hungarian teen-ager had taken her to the brink of defeat. When it comes to playing Miss Navratilova nowadays, close apparently counts.

title: 107,997 Seized at Border
description: The Border Patrol apprehended 107,997 aliens trying to cross the southern border of the United States illegally in March, the most for any month ever, a spokesman for the Immigration and Naturalization Service said today.

title: MICROBIOLOGICAL SCIENCES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in March.

title: SPLIT EXISTS ON U.S. BANK LOANS ABROAD
description: Legislators said today that proposals by bank regulators to monitor lending abroad by American banks do not go far enough.

title: Films of Sybil Shearer
description: Rare films of Sybil Shearer, the maverick American choreographer and performer, will be shown at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, April 28 at 4 and 6 P.M. The program is free. Tickets may be obtained one hour before performance time in the library lobby. Information: 870-1630.

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-After currency adjustment charges of $1,074,000 for the quarter and $1,932,000 for the 6 months. c-After currency adjustment charges of $932,000 for the quarter and $997,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: Bronx Girl Is Charged In Blaze Fatal to Baby
description: A 15-year-old Bronx girl who was said to be angry with her parents for making her go to school was charged yesterday with setting a fire that killed an 18-month-old baby, the authorities said.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 27.
description: b-Including tax credits of $2.5 million for the quarter and $5 million for the year. c-Including tax credits of $2.8 million for the quarter and $5.6 million for the year.

title: A MOMENT'S SILENCE THE A.C.L.U. WON'T BROOK
description: T o the Editor:

title: HILLER AVIATION reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.

PATENTS;
John DeLorean Wins Patent for Car Door
description: John Z. DeLorean, who has been released on $5 million bail pending trial on cocaine conspiracy charges, was granted a patent this week for means of mounting a vehicle's door.

title: Dow Advances 7.06 After a Late Rally; Off by 5.32 For the Week
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, buoyed in part by favorable retail sales reports on Thursday. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved in a narrow range until the last hour of trading, closed up 7.06, to 1,124.71. At 3 P.M., the average was ahead only 1.45 points. Analysts attributed the late upswing mostly to bargain hunting and short covering.

title: U.S. TELLS HUSSEIN IT'S READY TO PRESS BEGIN ON OUTPOSTS
description: The Reagan Administration promised King Hussein of Jordan today that if he agreed to join the Middle East peace negotiations, the United States would seek to bring about a halt in the building of Israeli settlements in the West Bank.

title: INSULATION-FOAM BAN NULLIFIED
description: A Federal appeals court on Thursday overturned a Federal ban on the sale of urea formaldehyde insulation.

title: Prosecutors Study L.I. Contamination
description: The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation said yesterday that it had referred 11 cases involving the suspected contamination of Long Island homes by exterminators to the District Attorneys of Nassau and Suffolk Counties for investigation.

title: History of Black Dance At Brooklyn Academy
description: Three hundred years of black dance history will be celebrated in Dance Black America at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from April 21 to 24.

title: DAVIS LONGS FOR BIG GAIN
description: Anthony Davis sat at a picnic table outside a building that was once part of La Marina Elementary School and is now the training center for the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League. He was squinting into the sunset, discussing his decision to resume a career in football at the age of 30 and after a four year absence, when two small boys wandered by and asked if Davis played for the Express.

title: CHOICE FOR SCHOOLS CHIEF DELAYED
description: Under growing criticism for the way it has been going about selecting a new chancellor of the New York City public school system, the Board of Education delayed making the appointment yesterday. The expectation of some board officials and most city politicians was that Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr., Mayor Koch's choice, would be named today.

title: SCHULMAN, A, INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
ILL-CONCEIVED DEFENSE OF A P.L.O. CENTER
description: To the Editor:

title: CENSORSHIP RAISED IN BOOK DISPUTE
description: A transcontinental argument between an author and a publisher has raised questions about the reasons why the publisher rejected a 1979 book and whether it is now trying to censor an account of that decision.

title: Riding Too High on the 'Hog'
description: ''I'm not concerned about the Japanese,'' said Vaughn Beals, the president of Harley-Davidson, two years ago. ''There's nothing magic in what they do.'' Lately, the sobered chief executive of the only American-owned manufacturer of motorcycles has been telling a different story.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 24.
Rail Talks Are Set To Reopen Today
description: Officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority are to resume negotiations this morning with the union representing striking conductors and trainmen on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.

title: Dome's Chief Retires
description: John P. Gallagher retired yesterday as chief executive officer of Dome Petroleum Ltd., but will retain his position as chairman of the board.

title: AUGUSTA, GA., AN ALWAYS-COLORFUL CITY OF GARDENS, TURNS ALL GREEN FOR GOLF
description: A bouquet of pastels covers the gently rolling hills of this city of gardens: pink, fuchsia, lavender, mauve, apricot.

title: RAND INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for year to Feb 27.
description: The year-earlier results were restated to reflect 1-for-3 reverse stock split paid in November.

title: Korean Bank Gets Loan
description: The Korea Exchange Bank of South Korea today signed a $500 million loan agreement with an international consortium of more than 50 banks.

title: Winners in the Crime Wars
description: For a while, it looked as though 1983 would be another year of stalemate for legislation to improve New York criminal justice. But now, remarkably, the warring mayors, prosecutors and legislators are talking both peace and progress.

title: MORE ON JOYS OF DINING PAST
description: Next to actually eating food, what devout gastronomes seem to enjoy most is talking about it, planning menus and remembering meals past. After a personal reminiscence two weeks ago, in which I wrote about some favorite New York restaurants that no longer exist, letters came in from readers who either elaborated on the places mentioned or added some memories of their own.

title: Rain Postpones Masters
description: The second round of the Masters tournament was postponed today by heavy rain that made the Augusta National Golf Club course unplayable. The revised plan calls for playing the second round Saturday and two rounds, or 36 holes, Sunday.

title: WASHINGTON SCIENTIFIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 13.
description: b-Net income.

title: The 17 1/2 cent Token Fallout
description: Remember how New York said last November that it was going to get tough with subway riders who used Connecticut's 17 1/2-cent turnpike tokens to beat the 75-cent fare? Of 37 infractions in Manhattan, here is what's happened:

title: Freestyle Mark For Miss Thomas
description: Tammy Thomas, a senior at the University of Kansas, broke her American record in the women's 50-yard freestyle trials today, then beat Dara Torres, the defending champion, in the final to take her second national short-course swimming title.

title: VISUAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $777,000 from prepayment penalty on borrowing. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 28.

title: TOXIC CLEANUP DELAY LAID TO 2 EX-AIDES
description: Recently departed leaders of the Environmental Protection Agency deliberately slowed and limited the program of cleaning up dangerous toxic wastes, two senior agency officials testified today.

title: A LEADER OF '43 WARSAW UPRISING ASKS BOYCOTT OF POLISH OBSERVANCE
description: The deputy commander of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising of 1943, when Jews fought Nazis for three weeks, has called for a boycott of a Government-sponsored observance of the event's 40th anniversary.

title: ARAFAT PUTS OFF RETURN TO AMMAN
description: Yasir Arafat chose not to return to Amman today to complete his talks with King Hussein because of substantial differences that remain between the two men over how to respond to President Reagan's Middle East peace proposal, P.L.O. officials said.

title: MINNESOTA FABRICS INC reports earnings for year to Jan 29.
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding give effect to a 3-for-2 stock split on July 30, 1982.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The money is there and we're going to spend it, and we're not going to spend it on a party.'' - Mayor Koch. (1:5.)

title: Richard Blow, Artist; Revived Florentine Mosaic Technique
description: Richard Blow, a painter known for his revival of intarsia - a Florentine mosaic technique - died of a stroke in New York Tuesday.

title: DIOXIN USE ON ARKANSAS RICE RAISES CONCERN ABOUT HEALTH
description: The agricultural miracle that permits this small town in Arkansas County to call itself the rice capital of the world is about to begin again with spring planting. But the chemicals that make the miracle possible may also pose a health threat to the region's residents, according to doctors and scientists.

title: Mistrial Ruled in a Rape Case After Publicity Over Sentence
description: A judge declared a mistrial today in the case of five young men charged in the rape of a former beauty queen because he said he could not find enough people who had not heard of the case.

title: STAGE: 'DELICATE BALANCE' IS REVIVED IN PRINCETON
description: Coinciding with the arrival on Broadway of Edward Albee's new play, ''The Man Who Had Three Arms,'' there is a revival of ''A Delicate Balance'' at the McCarter Theater Company, and it reminds one of an earlier, more sanguine stage of the author's career.

title: STERLING CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of March 31.
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: RANGER SUCCESS AIDED BY LACK OF ANGER
description: Hockey being a rough and sometimes violent game, it is not common to associate it with turning the other cheek. Essentially, though, that's what the Rangers did Thursday night in Philadelphia, and by turning away from provocation and concentrating on the game itself, they managed to beat the Flyers for the second straight time.

title: MIDEAST: WRONG TARGET OF AMERICAN PRESSURE
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERSTATE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MONENCO LIMITED reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
U.S.F.L. TO ADD TEAMS
description: In spite of plummeting attendance at their games and only moderate television ratings, the owners of the United States Football League have voted unanimously to add at least four teams next season to the current 12.

title: Ford Conducts Seminar on Civics
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford today delivered a civics lecture at Rutgers University covering topics from foreign policy and the economy to Congress and the press.

title: BASIC FACT FOR BUYERS OF AUTOS
description: According to a new book about cars, a sporty C orvette is 1,700 times more likely to be stolen than a subcompact P lymouth Horizon. If you buy a Ford Mustang, you will have to pay a s urcharge for insurance, but if you buy a similar-size compact Dodge 4 00, you will actually get a discount because it has a better loss r ecord with insurance companies.

title: SOGGY NEW ORLEANS BAILS OUT
description: By 11 o'clock Thursday morning Graciela Oster, eight months pregnant, feared that the moment was at hand, just as the flood waters were rising. So she and her family headed for Southern Baptist Hospital in New Orleans, 20 miles from their home in Chalmette.

title: CAMBODIAN REBEL ACCUSES VIETNAMESE OF MASSACRING CIVILIANS
description: Son Sann, the former Cambodian Prime Minister, charged today that Vietnamese troops had massacred ''several hundreds'' of civilians, including women and children, in overrunning a rebel camp Monday on the Cambodian side of the border with Thailand.

title: Jerry Brainard, 35, Organist; Formed Badinage Ensemble
description: Jerry Brainard, an organist and harpsichordist who was the artistic director of the early-music ensemble Badinage, died last Saturday. He was 35 years old.

title: AMERICAN PLAN CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: MUSICAL: 'FROM BROOKS'
description: To complain about ''From Brooks With Love,'' a musical that opened Wednesday night in the Harold Clurman Theater about the folk who work at a quality clothing store, is like kicking an amiable, frisky, tail-wagging puppy that is good-naturedly chewing at your trousers.

title:
PATENTS;
'Briefcase' Piano With Full-Sized Keys
description: A New Yorker has invented what he calls a briefcase piano.

title: ILLEGALLY AIDING LATINS
description: Two members of the Senate Intelligence Committee, Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Patrick J. Leahy, have publicly suggested that the Reagan Administration may be violating a December 1982 law forbidding the United States to support any attempt to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government. But Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, America's chief delegate to the United Nations, has pleaded not guilty, claiming ''absolutely that no law is being broken.'' Is the Administration breaking the law?

title: REITMANS (CANADA) LTD reports earnings for year to Jan 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated for an accounting adjustment related to vacation pay.

title: Your Money; I.R.A. Moves Still Possible
description: WITH less than a week to go before the deadline for opening individual retirement accounts for 1982, many sponsors of these plans are planning to keep their offices open late to attract additional customers. And for most of those who have still not done so, it makes sense to make a contribution to an I.R.A. before the April 15 cutoff date.

title: Seeking a Fight
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho has emerged as one of the country's hottest young boxers, and Sam Glass of Tiffany Promotions says he is prepared to offer Camacho $250,000 to fight another unbeaten New York junior lightweight, Tony Santana.

title: Appeal Filed on Oil Leases
description: The Federal Government and 11 oil companies asked the Federal District Court here today to lift an injunction that prohibits the leasing of more tracts for oil exploration in the George's Bank fishing grounds. The lease sale, scheduled March 28, was halted a day before on a suit brought by Attorney General Francis X. Bellotti of Massachsetts and the Conservation Law Foundation.

title: Citibank, Iran Settle Claims
description: Citicorp's Citibank unit has received $125 million from Iran in settlement of disputed loans dating from the 1979-80 hostage taking, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Bridge: A Far-Away Community Opens Well-Equipped Club
description: This pleasant town of some 50,000 inhabitants, center of a sheep-farming area, has two claims to fame. It is farther South than any other urban center in the British Commonwealth and it has the biggest and best-equipped bridge club of any place of comparable size.

title: A STATE BUDGET'S BLOW TO MENTAL-HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
F.A.A. MOVES TO GIVE PILOTS BETTER LANDING DATA
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, acting on recommendations growing out of a World Airways accident on an icy runway in Boston last year, says it will take new steps to assure that pilots receive timely data on braking conditions.

title: SESSION ON A-PLANT ACCIDENTS STRESSES PSYCHOLOGICAL HARM
description: The likelihood that a nuclear power plant would ever release enough radiation to kill anyone is extremely small, but accidents in which radiation is released can cause significant psychological damage to the public, according to doctors, government officials and nuclear engineers speaking at a two-day symposium.

title: Bullets 107, Celtics 99
description: Ricky Sobers scored 27 points, and Greg Ballard scored 10 of his 14 in the fourth quarter for the Bullets, who won for the 10th time in 12 games.

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for qtr to March 20.
The Talk of Jersey City
description: Paul Agner, vice president of Metropolitan Tele-Tronics of Manhattan, was shopping around for new office space recently and called the Jersey City Mayor's Office. ''I couldn't believe it,'' he said. ''They called me back within 20 minutes. And it wasn't just one guy -I got five calls.'' They were from Thomas Kelly, executive director of the Jersey City Economic Development Corporation; Harry Melendez, director of the Mayor's Job Club; William Colon, director of the Jersey City Corporation for Employment and Training; Mark Munley, director of the Department of Housing and Economic Development, and Thomas Golodik, the Mayor's press secretary.

title: BILL URGED TO PREVENT CLUBS FROM LIMITING MEMBERSHIP
description: A law to prevent private clubs from banning women and minority groups was proposed yesterday by Mayor Koch, City Council President Carol Bellamy and a majority of the City Council.

title: Terry Cummings Ailing
description: A heart ailment diagnosed as ''rapid rhythm disturbances'' has forced Terry Cummings, the San Diego Clippers' star rookie from De Paul, to skip the remainder of the season, which ends April 17. The irregular heart beat was discovered Tuesday night during a game in which Cummings wore a monitoring device.

title: LAZARE KAPLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net loss.

title: TOMLINSON OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3.4 million for the quarter and 6 months from an adverse legal decision.

title: SNAG SEEN ON BRITISH STEEL PLAN
description: As the United States Steel Corporation and the British Steel Corporation continued their work on a plan to ship Scottish steel production to a Pennsylvania mill, a British Steel spokesman indicated yesterday that his company was seeking to free the Scottish plant from Government subsidies.

title: Jail Terms for 4 In Drugging Case
description: Four men charged with trying to help their betting chances by tranquilizing harness-racing horses were sentenced yesterday in Federal court here to jail terms. They were convicted Feb. 24 on charges of criminal racketeering.

title: ARNOLD PALMER, RAIN AND REALITY
description: During his four-under-par 68 in Thursday's opening round, Arnold Palmer was walking onto the 16th green when thunder clapped. From the huge gallery following the fourtime Masters champion, a voice called, ''Even He's applauding you, Arnie.'' But yesterday when a steady downpour postponed the second round until today, He put Arnold Palmer on hold. He also put Arnold Palmer on alert that 36 holes tomorrow (or Monday or Tuesday) might be necessary to complete the 72-hole tournament. Perhaps that means that He's not rooting for Arnold Palmer or perhaps He just decided to give Arnold Palmer a day of rest.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Dec. 10, 1982,and an equity offering of 600,000 shares by the company on Dec. 21, 1982.

title: New Trial Denied In F.A.L.N. Case
description: A Federal judge yesterday denied a motion for a new trial by five advocates of Puerto Rican independence who were convicted of criminal contempt of court.

title: Befogging The Taxpayer
description: It's not easy to make sense out of the cost overruns and time delays that have been suddenly discovered at the construction site of the city's new Convention Center. And one fundamental reason for the heavy fog and confusion that have descended is that, as with most grand-sized government projects, the public officials who conceived the center didn't let the public in on the true costs and the potential for delays and overruns.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: Former JWT Executive Files Suit Over Ouster
description: Marie Luisi, the former J. Walter Thompson Company executive who was dismissed following accusations of a computer manipulation that led to a write-off of $30 million, filed a multimillion-dollar damage suit yesterday against five top JWT executives.

title: NETS' PLAYERS CITE PRESSURES ON BROWN
description: Buck Williams, the Nets player who was closest to Larry Brown, said tonight that the pressures of coaching in the National Basketball Association may have been a key factor in Brown's resignation Thursday.

title: Peru Massacre Survivors Blame Leftist Guerrillas
description: Survivors of a massacre of more than 50 peasants last Sunday say leftists killed randomly and brutally for two hours.

title: Mets-Cards Rained Out
description: The Mets' game with the St. Louis Cardinals at Shea Stadium last night, the first game of a scheduled four-game series, was rained out. No makeup date has been announced.

title: PRUDENTIAL SEEKS BANK IN GEORGIA
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the nation's largest life insurance company and owner of Prudential-Bache Securities, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a small commercial bank in Georgia.

title: A TEXAS ORCHESTRA BEGINS CHINA TOUR
description: The Fort Worth Chamber Orchestra began a 21-day tour of China today, a day after the Government canceled 19 sports and cultural exchange events to protest Washington's decision to grant political asylum to a Chinese tennis star. The Fort Worth group's tour was not canceled because it was considered an unofficial visit.

title: Daughter Charged In Mother's Death
description: An 18-year-old Queens woman and her 25-year-old boyfriend were arrested yesterday and charged with murdering the woman's mother during a burglary at the victim's home in Bayside.

title: SPEAKERS AT A SYMPOSIUM DEFEND THE WORK OF MARGARET MEAD
description: Anthropologists from universities around the country gathered at Barnard College yesterday to assess the work of Dr. Margaret Mead as a result of a widely publicized attack on her research that was published this month by Harvard University Press.

title: James Bond Revised
description: ICEBREAKER. By John Gardner. 301 pages. G.P. Putnam's Sons. $10.95.
