When Ian Fleming died and there was talk of finding someone else to continue the James Bond series, it didn't seem to me that this would be very hard to do. The Bond books were amusing and reasonably inventive, but not inimitable. They had good details, a flashy threat, a pretty girl or two, a villain with delusions of grandeur and Bond himself, a smooth practitioner of elementary irony.

title: RULES TO AID HANDICAPPED INFANTS FACE COURT TEST
description: A Federal district judge heard an impassioned argument here today on the legality of Federal rules that require doctors and hospitals to provide food and medical care to infants with severe birth defects.

title: Mugabe Urges Death For Aiding Dissidents
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe told 5,000 cheering supporters today that Government soldiers were entitled to kill anyone caught aiding anti-Government forces.

title: CAROLINA FREIGHT CARRIERS CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to March 26.
Cleveland Crime Figures Get Life Terms on Drug Charges
description: A reputed leader of the Cleveland Mafia and three of his lieutenants, all convicted of operating a narcotics network, were sentenced Thursday to life in prison without parole. A fifth defendant received a sentence of 42 years.

title: The Talk of Port-au-Prince
description: For the thousands of people accustomed to eating, sleeping and peddling their wares along this capital's alleys and roads, Boulevard Jean Jacques Dessalines was once a choice spot.

title: Dance Series Scheduled
description: Collaborations between choreographers and visual artists will be performed in ''Dance Environments,'' a dance series to be presented by the Institute for Art and Urban Resources from April 23 to May 22 at P.S. 1, at 46-01 21st Street, Long Island City.

title: I CAN'T GO TO WARSAW
description: The Polish Government's appeal to join it in Warsaw in mid-April to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto is the latest of many invitations to return to Poland that I have received since I fled nearly 60 years ago. Like the others, this invitation raises a host of troubling questions.

title: Dartmouth Names Successor To Editor of Alumni Magazine
description: An employee of another university has been named editor of Dartmouth College's Alumni Magazine after the last editor was dismissed.

title: U.S. IS AIRLIFTING MISSILES TO THAILAND IN FACE OF VIETNAMESE THREAT
description: The State Department announced today that the United States would start an immediate airlift of ground-to-air missiles, howitzers and other weapons to Thailand to help the Government reinforce its border against any intrusion by Vietnamese troops from Cambodia.

title: SHELL, ESSO ACCEPT $30 BRITISH OIL
description: The British National Oil Corporation's $30-a-barrel pricing proposal was accepted by two major buyers yesterday, the Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Esso Petroleum Company, a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation.

title: Eastern Job Cuts
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. said it would reduce its systemwide work force by 1,600, to 37,600, by May 1.

title: APPLE GETS PRESIDENT FROM PEPSI
description: Apple Computer Inc., in a move that is expected to help its marketing efforts, yesterday named the president of Pepsico Inc.'s Pepsi-Cola Company subsidiary, John Sculley, to be its new president and chief executive officer.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Headline
description: Federal Reserve Wednesday, April 6, 1983 All data in millions of dollars LatestPreviousYear WeekWeek Ago

title: Hyatt Proposes Braniff Deal
description: The Hyatt International Corporation hotel chain has proposed a deal that could put part of Braniff Airways' idle fleet of jets back in the skies under the grounded airline's name, officials said.

title: First Chicago Reports Record Net in Quarter
description: The First Chicago Corporation, the nation's 11th-largest banking company, said yesterday its first-quarter earnings rose to a record $43.47 million from $33.17 million in the 1982 period.

title: RAINCOATS: LIGHT AND SLEEK
description: Until recently, the idea of a plastic raincoat conjured up a shapeless affair that made a woman look as though she were wrapped in cellophane. The coat came from the umbrella department and cost about $10. It was hardly stylish, but it was practical: unlike many cotton raincoats, it could withstand a real downpour, was lightweight and packed easily.

title: Cowboys Hire Security Chief
description: The Dallas Cowboys will be the National Football League's first team to have a full-time security director, and one of his chief duties will be to investigate drug use among players.

title: HARDWICKE COMPANIES INC reports earnings for year to Oct 3.
DISTRICT TRUST reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
AID FOR SOUTHERN BANK
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which pumped a $25 million loan into the United Southern Bank on Thursday, said today that it would take additional steps to keep the bank from failing.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TO GIVE RECOGNITION TO CONSCIENTIOUS OBJECTORS
description: South Africa's Parliament has enacted legislation that recognizes for the first time the status of conscientious objectors to military service.

title: SANDINISTS LOSE GROUND AMONG MIDDLE CLASS
description: Economic hardships, outside political pressures and a campaign by anti-Sandinist guerrillas in northern and central Nicaragua appear to have widened a gap between the Government and important segments of the middle class.

title: TV: A REALISTIC SERIES ON OLDER PEOPLE
description: Older people do not have it easy on television. On news programs, they are either comic-happy or pitiful-sad, dancing the hora in a nursing home, say, or cowering in a locked apartment, worried about crime in the street. Moreover, there is not much in the way of television programming that is specifically directed to older people, especially programming that the not-so-old might like, too. A singular exception is the weekly series ''The Prime of Your Life.'' It will be seen tonight on WNBC-TV at 7 o'clock.

title: Glamour and Hope
description: Seven hundred very tall, very thin, very good-looking people are adding glamour to the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel this weekend, aspiring models attending the 23d annual convention of the Modeling Association of America.

title: Horowitz Will Perform At Metropolitan May 15
description: The pianist Vladimir Horowitz will appear at the Metropolitan Opera May 15 at 8:30 P.M. The program will consist of Beethoven's Sonata in A (Op. 101); Schumann's ''Carnaval'' and Chopin's Polonaise-Fantaisie (Op. 61), Three Etudes and the Polonaise in A-flat (Op. 53).

title: A Sub-3:30 Mile
description: Mike Boit of Kenya ran what was believed to be the fastest mile ever Saturday, when he was timed in 3 minutes 28.36 seconds in Auckland, New Zealand. That's fast enough to break easily Sebastian Coe's world record of 3:47.33.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. He is the Ambassador from Luxembourg and a gifted pianist.

title:
Patents;
System Brightens Signs
description: AN electroluminescent display system to brighten signs and aviation instruments was patented this week by Robert W. Lester, president of the Static Systems Corporation, a New York research and development company. It can also be used in photocopying machines to eliminate the need for printers.

title: SURPLUS RANGING TO $300 MILLION FORECAST FOR CITY
description: State officials said yesterday that New York City would have a budget surplus of between $158 million and $300 million this fiscal year.

title: Tennis Rivalry Gets More Heated
description: The complex legal battle between World Championship Tennis and the sport's establishment took another turn this week with word that the International Tennis Federation had agreed to pay the legal fees of the Association of Tennis Professionals in the W.C.T.'s antitrust suit.

title: AIDES SAY REAGAN SEEKS COMPROMISE ON ARMS SPENDING
description: President Reagan, seeking to recover from a severe setback in the Senate on his military budget, authorized staff aides today to try to salvage a compromise with the Budget Committee, White House officials reported.

title: LOS ANGELES BALLET: THREE PREMIERES
description: For the third program in its Manhattan debut season, the Los Angeles Ballet included three New York premieres Thursday night in the Joyce Theater, where the company performs through tomorrow night.

title: ALLIANCE FOR CITY SCHOOLS MOUNTS 'GO PUBLIC' DRIVE
description: A campaign to persuade more of the city's families to send their children to public rather than private schools is about to be undertaken by an alliance of civic, business and educational organizations.

title: RATING VALUE LINE'S PROSPECTS
description: For years, Value Line has been judging the fortunes of companies. Now the company that operates the big investment advisory service will be coming in for some judgments of its own from analysts and investors. For Arnold E. Bernhard, the 81-year-old founder, has decided to sell 19 percent of his company to the public.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 9, 1983
description: Companies

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $100 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve System reported yesterday that the basic measure of the nation's money supply declined by $100 million in the week that ended March 30.

title: Fear in Accademe
description: Heads of English departments of nine universities in the city got together for the first time ever yesterday and discovered they shared a fear of the rapidly encroaching word processor.

title: U.S. Cup Bid Still Alive
description: The United States is still under consideration to be the host of the 1986 World Cup, according to Werner Fricker, the executive vice president of the United States Soccer Federation.

title: CBT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JACKPOT ENTERPRISES reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
MOVIELAB INC reports earnings for year to Jan 1.
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,682,000 for the latest year and $628,000 for the previous year.

title: People Express In British Bid
description: The People Express airline asked Britain's Civil Aviation Authority today to allow it to fly passengers across the Atlantic for as little as $149.

title: WINFIELD'S LONG HOMERS AMAZE MARTIN
description: Roy Smalley, the Yankee shortstop, was impressed, even though he saw similar displays last season: ''He went through streaks like this last year where he hit the ball so hard he wasn't human. I've never seen anyone hit the ball so hard.''

title: COOKE MARKS 175 YEARS OF DIOCESE IN NEW YORK
description: Terence Cardinal Cooke visited St. Peter's Church, the oldest Roman Catholic parish in New York State, yesterday and celebrated the 175th anniversary of the founding of the Diocese of New York.

title: ROADBLOCK TO NEW NURSING-HOME BEDS
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 9, 1983
description: International

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HIDEAWAY

title: JUDY'S INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: Kraft Foods in Shift
description: Kraft Foods, the British subsidiary of Dart & Kraft Inc., said today that it was shifting cheese production from England to West Germany and Belgium in a move that will cost 930 jobs. Kraft said it would keep 220 workers at its plant in Kirby, England.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Col. William J. Walsh on March 22 misidentified him. He served with the Selective Service Administration but was never Chancellor of the New York State Board of Regents.

title: MUSIC: NEW YORK POPS, WITH SKITCH HENDERSON
description: Arthur Fiedler made the Boston Pops an American institution, and John Williams seems to be carrying on that torch with some sureness. For a while, Andre Kostelanetz led a New York Philharmonic equivalent, but that seems to have transformed itself after his death into a shifting sequence of different spring-festival ideas.

title: EXPLORERS DESCRIBE PERILS OF POLAR TRAVEL
description: British explorers who circled the globe for the first time on a route that took them over both the North and South Poles say they were halted a number of times by deep, unexpected crevasses as they descended a forbidding glacier in the Antarctic.

title: OVERTIME JUMPER WINS FOR KNICKS
description: Bernard King's 20-foot spinning jump shot from the corner with two seconds left in overtime gave the Knicks a 102-100 victory over the San Antonio Spurs last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: REJECTED BY COLLEGE?
description: ''It is with very real regret ...'' These words, when followed by a few conciliatory sentences and stuffed into a thin white envelope bearing the return address of a college admissions office, can do more to shatter a 17-year-old's selfconfidence than an acne attack on the night of the senior prom.

title: ARGUS CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Fines for Fighting
description: Clemon Johnson of the Philadelphia 76ers and Reggie Theus of the Chicago Bulls were fined $1,000 and $500, respectively, for fighting durng a game March 29. The fines were in addition to the automatic $250 fines they drew for being ejected.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a computer typesetting error, the ''Hers'' column in The Home Section on March 31 incorrectly stated the fee paid Judy Stiver of Lansing, Mich., for her agreement to bear a child by artificial insemination for Alexander Malahoff of Queens. It was $10,000.

title: DISQUIETING CALM AFTER THE STORM
description: With charges of wrongdoing at the Environmental Protection Agency dominating the news, President Reagan told the nation Feb. 16 that he had ordered the Justice Department to investigate ''every charge that is made.''

title:
PATENTS;
Inventors Exposition Is Set for May 9 to 13
description: The seventh annual International Inventors Exposition is to be held at the New York Statler Hotel from May 9 through May 13. In making the announcement, Harold L. Kleiman, president of the sponsor company, said that a much larger group of independent inventors from this country and abroad was expected to display models or prototypes of their inventions than at previous expositions.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
ASTRONAUTS PACK UP IN PREPARATION FOR A RETURN TO EARTH TODAY
description: The Challenger's astronauts cleaned up their spaceship and packed up their gear today and were set for their return to earth Saturday afternoon, bringing to a close the first flight of the nation's newest space shuttle.

title: Judge Firm on Prison For Teamsters' Chief
description: Federal District Judge Prentice H. Marshall today refused to reverse his order that Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president, report to a Federal prison hospital April 15.

title: WINTER, JACK, INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
Secure From Our Posterity
description: Mr. B.L. of Chattanooga writes that he wants to have his photograph made, but can't decide what to do about his head. He wants the photograph so his posterity, a century or two hence, will know what he looked like, but he does not want to leave them a picture that will make him look ''old-fashioned.''

title: KARCHER, CARL, ENTERPRISES reports earnings for 12 wks to Jan 28.
Letter: On Collecting Revenue Let's Try a Unified Oil Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE SENATOR TO BE CHOSEN IN QUEENS
description: A special State Senate election Tuesday will mark the latest shift in political musical chairs in central and northern Queens. Assemblyman Leonard P. Stavisky, the 57-year-old Democratic-Liberal candidate, is the heavy favorite to succeed Gary L. Ackerman, who won a special election for the House of Representatives last month. Mr. Ackerman succeeded Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, who died in January.

title: WESTFIELD MINERALS LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
WASHINGTON FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (DC) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-There are no comparative year- ago share earnings because Washington Federal converted to a stock sociation on Nov. 17, 1982.

title: Elusive Top Prize
description: Anne Donovan, Old Dominion's 6-foot-8-inch senior center from Ridgewood, N.J., has taken many prizes as a top college basketball player during her career, among them, in recent weeks, the Naismith and Champion awards.

title: Ex-Boston Aide Is Convicted Of Mail Fraud in Pension Plot
description: A Federal jury today convicted William P. McNeill, a former Boston budget director, of 10 counts of mail fraud, finding that he had used the mails in a plot to obtain a $36,900 disability pension from the city.

title: Dome Petroleum May Sell Assets
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. is considering a plan to sell more assets to reduce its debt, a company spokesman said. This could involve selling a substantial portion of its interest in Dome Mines Ltd., he added.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. ACTS TO SPEED CURBS ON ASBESTOS
description: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration said today it would begin hearings this summer to speed up introduction of stricter standards for asbestos exposure.

title: GLOBAL NATURAL RESOURCES PROPERTIES PLC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-After nonrecurring expenses of $10.7 million relating to the 1982 proxy contest in the company's consolidation of U. S. operations into a single headquarters and non-cash charges of $13.5 million to reduce the book value of nonproducing leases to reflect declining economic conditions in the industry. c-Net income. Results include operations of McFarlane Oil Co. since its acquisition on Sept. 3, 1982.

title: CARDINAL URGES CHICAGOANS NOT TO VOTE ON RACIAL BASIS TUESDAY
description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago has urged voters not to use race as a basis for their vote in the mayoral election here Tuesday.

title: HIGHLAND CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of March 31.
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Exxon Lifts Price
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. announced that it had increased its wholesale prices by 2 percent in New York State, effective yesterday, and said the increase reflected the cost of New York's new 2 percent gross receipts tax, which is applicable to the state's 18 largest oil companies. Exxon, a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, said the price increase applies to all petroleum products with the exception of fuel oil exempted by a residential use certificate. The new tax was signed into law on March 28, retroactive to Jan. 1, 1983.

title: MIDDLEMEN VS. LANDLORDS AND TENANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CONTINENTAL PLASTICS & CHEMICALS reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
description: b-Net loss. c-After nonrecurring charges of $192,663.

title: MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SECURITIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Owens to Set Up $250 Million Credit
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. is setting up a $250 million international line of credit to give it more strength and room to maneuver during hard times.

title: MARKETING FOODS WITH LOWER SALT
description: The Campbell Soup Company has brought out seven low-sodium soups. Kellogg has put low-sodium Rice Krispies and Corn Flakes into its product line. Libby's introduced an entire 12-product line of no-salt vegetables. And the White Rock Company is now brewing a low-salt beer.

title: American Ballet School To Give 3 Performances
description: The School of American Ballet, affiliated with the New York City Ballet, will present its 18th annual workshop performances April 30 at 8 P.M. and on May 2 at 4 and 7 P.M. in the Juilliard Theater. They will be dedicated to the memory of Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts from 1969 to 1977.

title: LTV Spending Plans
description: The LTV Corporation said in its annual report released today that it plans to cut capital expenditures to $240 million in 1983 from 1982's $290 million.

title: Hawks 138, Bulls 101
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 34 points and Dan Roundfield had 11 assists, both career highs, for Atlanta.

title: BRIEFING
description: Domenici's Temptation

title: 17 Hospitalized In Bronx Fire
description: Seventeen people, including 12 children, remained hospitalized yesterday, suffering from smoke inhalation after dense smoke from a fire filled their Bronx apartment house Thursday night.

title: Soviet Orders 2 Britons To Leave the Country
description: The Soviet Union ordered the expulsion of two Britons today, a week after London expelled two Soviet diplomats and a Soviet correspondent.

title: 2 Jersey Banks Are Near Merger
description: The Horizon Bancorp of Morristown, N.J., announced that it had signed an agreement in principle to acquire the Northern National Corporation, a bank holding company in Moorestown, N.J., for about $80 million in cash, common stock and preferred stock.

title: Beach Boys Make Light Of Temporary Ban
description: Riding a wave of public support that included the backing of President Reagan and his wife, the Beach Boys said today they wanted to put their temporary ban from a capital celebration behind them and continue singing ''about good vibrations.''

title: SISTER WAS 'TERRIFIED' OVER SAFETY, BROTHER SAYS IN CBS SLAYING TRIAL
description: A brother of Margaret Barbera, a witness who was murdered before she could testify in a Federal fraud case, told a jury yesterday that his sister had been ''terrified'' for her safety in the last three months of her life.

title: Russell on Target
description: David Russell of St. John's and Rodney McCray of Louisville were the top scorers in a college all-star basketball game last night at Syracuse.

title: FIDELITY OF OKLAHOMA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOME CONSTRUCTION UPTURN SEEN AS SPOTTY AND FRAGILE
description: More than 100,000 unemployed construction workers have found jobs since home mortgage interest rates began to decline last fall and the housing industry began a modest turnaround. But six months after it began, the housing industry's recovery is still not cutting very deeply into the high levels of unemployment found in the construction trades for more than three years.

title: Possible Toxins Found In South Carolina Wells
description: About 50 tons of chemicals suspected of causing cancer seeped into the ground water beneath the Government's Savannah River Plant over two decades, but state health officials said today that there was no immediate danger.

title: MASTERS ENERGY CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Includes a $2,277,000 writedown of the company's oil and gas properties. c-Net income

title: Comings and Goings
description: Farley Weiss, a tennis player who transferred from Arizona State to the University of Pennsylvania, won a temporary court order permitting him to play for Penn. A formal hearing will be held April 20 in Federal District Court in Philadelphia to argue the validity of the intercollegiate rule that prohibits transfer students from competition within a year after their transfer. ... Coach Scotty Robertson of the Detroit Pistons, whose three-year contract expires at the end of this season, is facing an uncertain future. He said General Manager Jack McCloskey wanted to wait until after April 17 to talk contract and that ''it's beyond my control.''

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.

title: FOR SERIOUS COLLECTORS: THE BEST, AT A PRICE
description: One of the first things serious collectors of Chinese ceramics discover is that no matter where they travel, there are shops to be explored and kiln-baked rarities to be uncovered. Such prizes represent a considerable investment, but the more knowledgable the collector, the greater the challenge to find treasures dating from antiquity through the early 20th century. Although an international list of sources would fill a sizable telephone book, collectors find that the most prominent dealers are based in three cities - London, Hong Kong and New York. London Most Chinese ceramics merchants specialize either in wares made for use by the Chinese or for export. But a few carry both. At the top of the list is Eskenazi Limited, at 166 Piccadilly, where the Chinese ceramics range from 2000 B.C. through the 17th century, and are from $2,000 to $500,000. Giuseppe Eskenazi, one of the world's top dealers in Oriental wares, recently acquired from Herbert Hoover 3d of Pasadena four choice Ming porcelains - two bowls, a vase and a box with cover - all of which had been collected by his grandfather, President Hoover. A blue and white early 15th-century palace bowl, awash with figures of women and children playing in a palace garden, is one of the most extraordinary of such bowls to reach the market in recent years. The price -about $250,000. The vase, a narrow-necked design from the late 16th century, decorated with scenes of scholars in a garden, is almost identical to one in the National Palace Museum in Taiwan.

title: THE ATTRACTION OF ADDITIONS
description: Though yield is the first factor to consider in searching for a good I.R.A. at banks, credit unions or savings and loan associations, taxpayers should consider other factors.

title: IN HOT PURSUIT OF HIGH YIELDS
description: Most I.R.A. money is flowing into accounts at banks, savings and loan associations, and credit unions. And much of it is going to institutions offering yields of 9.5 percent or less.

title: PARENT-SUPPORT LAW LANGUISHING IN INDIANA
description: An Indiana law requiring people to help support their indigent parents has not been enforced since the Medicaid program began in 1965, state and local officials say.

title: Plane Forced to Land On Westchester Road
description: A small plane carrying three people apparently ran out of fuel and made an emergency landing tonight on a Westchester County parkway, sideswiping a car and slightly injuring the driver, authorities said.

title: THE PRIVATE LABEL
description: As stores strive to re-create a sense of individual identity, many retailers are turning to private-label clothes.

title: LOBSTER TRAWLING IRKS L.I. FISHERMAN
description: FOR centuries, commercial fishermen along the shores of Long Island and Connecticut have shared the productive fishing grounds of Long Island Sound. But when Connecticut's State Department of Environmental Protection introduced a proposal last month aimed at resolving a highly controversial dispute among fishermen, the proposal and the dispute erupted into Long Island waters and onto the Island's multimillion-dollar commercial fishing industry.

title: PIANO RECITAL: BYRON JANIS
description: Byron Janis's piano recital in Avery Fisher Hall Wednesday night was given as a benefit, and it was perhaps for this reason that he devised a program consisting chiefly of familiar short pieces. After opening with Haydn's Sonata in C (Hob. 50), he moved on to groups of works by Brahms, Chopin, Liszt and Schumann, the latter being represented by the ''Fantasiestkucke'' (Op. 12).

title: NEW GUIDES FOR THE POCKET
description: It may be the only tourist in the world who owns a street guide to Libourne, France. Libourne is a bustling little city 20 miles from Bordeaux. I had to meet a chap there a few years back and lost my way. Anyone else would ask a passer-by or a policeman. Not me. I headed for the first bookstore and bought a guidebook, which I have never used again. It sits on a shelf with my guides to Rabat, Morocco; Ajaccio, Corsica; Lahore, Pakistan, and the best restaurants in France run by women.

title: No Headline
description: The day after Franklin D. Roosevelt won re-election in 1944, his Vice President, Harry S. Truman, telegraphed him: ''I am very happy over the overwhelming endorsement you received. Isolationism is dead.''

title:
GARDENING;
EARLY SPRING PLANTINGS FLIRT WITH FROST
description: DOES the early bird always catch the worm? Let me cite an example, then you be the judge. It was the first Friday in April, a warm sunny day. A customer walked into a garden center and, after searching about for a time, asked for tomato plants, there being none on display. The proprietor explained that the frost-free date, the average date beyond which there was a 90 percent certainty that there would be no further killing frost, was still two weeks away. Tomatoes, being tropical in origin and subject to damage from the slightest frost, would not be available for several weeks.

title: Columbia Beats M.I.T.
description: Columbia University's varsity heavyweight rowing team christened a new eight-oared shell before its race with Massachusetts Institute of Technology yesterday, then made its maiden voyage on the Harlem River a victorious one by winning the annual Alumni Cup race for the fourth consecutive year.

title: BOOKS ARE SOLD AT PARTIES IN HOMES
description: ON a recent evening, a group of women gathered at a handsome suburban home in Weston. The hostess, Barbara Provato, met her guests at the front door, greeted the ones she knew, and introduced herself to those she had not met. The eight women, mostly in their 30's, had been invited to view a new line of products: not Tupperware, not cosmetics or lingerie or any of the more than 200 items that are currently being sold through home parties, but books - books for young children.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Playing It Again

title: An Equitable Approach For School Aid
description: Since the release of the Governor's 1983-84 Executive Budget, the subject of state aid to school districts and revision of the state's school aid formula has perhaps been the most debated and criticized component of the budget proposals.

title:
OPINION;
SOMETHING FUNNY HAPPENED ON THE WAY TO 1040
description: THE payment of taxes has never been any more popular in America than elsewhere, and for many years the suspicion has spread that many people fail to pay the proper amount of personal income tax. Such opinions have surfaced not only in the last few years when Uncle Sam has been demanding higher and higher taxes. Protests of the same nature were registered more than 100 years ago -back when the first income tax was imposed, in Civil War days.

title: Kong Nearly Reclaims Stronghold Atop Tower
description: This time, he almost did it. But for the second time in three days, King Kong was frustrated in his bid to reclaim his stronghold high atop the Empire State Building.

title: COUNTY BEST SELLERS OFFER TAX ADVICE
description: HER name is hardly a household word, but Barbara E. Weltman is one of America's best-selling authors. More than one million readers are engrossed in the work she prepared in a small office nestled above an ice cream parlor in Larchmont. The 332-page paperback contains no sex or violence, scant plot and virtually no dialogue. It will never become a mini-series.

title: ROAD TO DISASTER
description: The most fateful foreign-policy choice since Vietnam now confronts this country. Unlike Vietnam, the American public is on notice of what is happening before it is too late. Will our political system work this time to avoid disaster?

title: Drifter Who Inherited Fortune Dies of Tuberculosis on Coast
description: A penniless drifter who inherited $250,000 and a half-interest in a $1.5 million trust after he was found in a Detroit flophouse has died without getting much chance to enjoy the money.

title: WAGNER IS NAMED HEAD OF SCHOOLS IN 6-1 VOTE BY BOARD OF EDUCATION
description: The New York City Board of Education yesterday selected Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. to serve as the 14th chief administrator of the country's largest public school system.

title: Miss McNamara, William E. Burch To Marry in June
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. McNamara of Goshen, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Anne McNamara, to William Elliott Burch, son of J. Elliott Burch of Garden City, L.I., and the late Phyllis Burch.

title: Income Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: IT'S TIME ONCE MORE TO TEST THE WATERS
description: GOVERNOR KEAN'S first term is far from its halfway mark, but ''testing the waters'' already has become the newest political ''in'' phrase. In fact, the New Jersey Election Law Enforcement Commission has scheduled a public hearing for May 11 to examine its proposed changes in the state's campaign contribution and expenditure regulations. The changes would allow ''testing the water'' bank accounts by potential opponents of Mr. Kean, should he decide to run for a second term in 1985.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: IT was only a few weeks ago that Supervisor Anthony Veteran of Greenburgh seemed to be an overwhelming favorite against former United States Representative Ogden R. Reid to win the nomination for County Executive at this week's Democratic Party convention. He is still the favorite, but both sides agree the race is closer.

title: Diane Marie Rhodes to Wed
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Diane Marie Rhodes, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin B. Rhodes of Pound Ridge, N.Y., to Michael Gerard Warner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Warner of Silver Lake, Staten Island. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Future Events; Spring Frolics
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. For the Record April 14 - Lukas Foss, Ned Rorem and John Corigliano Jr. are among the ''serious'' composers who have written pop songs to be sung by Marni Nixon at the annual benefit for Composers Recordings Inc. (CRI.) At the Center for Inter-American Relations, Park Avenue at 68th Street, from 5 to 8 P.M., the event includes a tribute to the Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music in recognition of its 20 years of support to contemporary music. Cocktails and hors d'oeuvres will be served. Tickets, $60 from 212-873-1250, $75 at the door.

title:
DINING OUT;
SOPHISTICATION ON THE OTHER SIDE
description: STRETCHING into longer, warmer days, the season invites our investigations a little farther afield. The Tappan Zee Bridge makes short work of expanding the choices for dinner, a convenience for those in the county who live near the western border. And Theresa's, just three miles south of Nyack, by Route 9W or by Piermont Avenue, is worth serious consideration.

title: ASTRONAUTS RIDE 2D SPACE SHUTTLE TO SMOOTH LANDING
description: The space shuttle Challenger, bucking 18-knot headwinds, glided to a smooth landing here today for the successful conclusion of its first flight.

title: Carole L. Anderson Married to John M.L. Sweet
description: Carole Lewis Anderson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ashley Anderson of East Stroudsburg, Pa., was married yesterday to John Mason Lee Sweet, son of Rebecca Lee Sweet of Pittsburgh and the late Richard Anthony Sweet. The Rev. Robert S. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University.

title: Sandra Doolittle a Bride
description: The marriage of Sandra H. Doolittle to Leonard S. Mandor took place yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

title: LOST GLORIES OF DUCKPIN BOWLING
description: FRANK IAIZZI recalls that as a youth he was in the thick of duckpin bowling in Stamford, setting up - and dodging -pins at the Old Elks Hall on West Park Place.

title: Barbara Tassinari to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Silvio J. Tassinari of Nissequogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Lynne Tassinari, to Dr. Richard H. Haug, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Haug of St. James, L.I. The wedding is planned for Dec. 3. The future bride is an intensive care nurse at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Dr. Haug is a second-year resident in oral and maxillofacial surgery at the Mount Sinai Hospital in New York.

title: ONE FAMILY'S SQUARE-FOOR APPROACH TO A CAREFREE HARVEST
description: By planting their raised-bed vegetable garden ''on the square,'' Robert and Veeta Kleehammer will save space. They estimate their crops will take up only 20 percent of the space usually allotted to a conventional row garden. Their two four-foot squares will receive full sun in the backyard of their Long Island home.

title: NEW YORK AGENCIES GIVEN INVESTMENT ADVICE
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has released a series of investment guidelines for New York's 47 public authorities in an attempt to limit the risk to the millions of dollars these agencies handle.

title: HARTFORD SHOW IN ITS 17TH YEAR
description: THE 17th Annual Connecticut Spring Antiques Show, which opens Friday at the State Armory in Hartford, focuses on early American furnishings and will include about 100 dealers.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: THE RICH VISIONS OF CYNTHIA OZICK
description: At first glance, the novelist and short-story writer Cynthia Ozick, in her all-purpose, blue-pleated skirt, man-tailored shirt and bulky red ski sweater, has a slightly disorganized air. Yet her distracted manner veils a quiet determination to say exactly what she thinks; there is a look of conviction in the dark eyes behind the thick glasses. Cynthia Ozick always makes her point - never loses it, in fact.

title: NURSING EDUCATION IS DEBATED
description: AS THEY marked the 80th anniversary of the state's Nursing Practice Act last week -the statute was the first in the country to set licensing standards for nurses - nursing leaders in New Jersey predicted that their profession would play an ever-larger role in a changing health-care system.

title: WHY MEMBERS DON'T RUN
description: ABOUT a year ago, after a heated controversy over a program for gifted and talented children, Charles Archbald realized that he did not want to serve a second term on the Highland Park Board of Education. He also realized, he said, that the strain of serving was affecting his health.

title: RUTGERS SERIES MAKES TV DEBUT
description: ACADEMICIANS and television programmers long have thought that, by harnessing the intellectual resources of universities, they could let viewers in on the kinds of oral exchanges that had always been limited largely to graduate students.

title:
GARDENING;
EARLY SPRING PLANTINGS FLIRT WITH FROST
description: DOES the early bird always catch the worm? Let me cite an example, then you be the judge. It was the first Friday in April, a warm sunny day. A customer walked into a garden center and, after searching about for a time, asked for tomato plants, there being none on display. The proprietor explained that the frost-free date, the average date beyond which there was a 90 percent certainty that there would be no further killing frost, was still two weeks away. Tomatoes, being tropical in origin and subject to damage from the slightest frost, would not be available for several weeks.

title: LOEHMANN'S: AN EMPIRE BUILT BY ONE WOMAN
description: Nothing wearable, it appeared, was safe from resale so long as Momma -Frieda Loehmann - was around. At least George J. Greenberg says so. And he is the chairman, president and chief executive officer of Loehmann's, the chain of off-price women's clothing stores. To make his point he tells a story about the late Mrs. Loehmann, who created the clothing chain with a tough, unorthodox, cash-only bargaining technique and an unerring eye for the styles that would transcend the fickle seasons of fashion.

title: CATHOLIC LIVES
description: SEMINARY A Search. By Paul Hendrickson. 330 pp. New York: Summit Books. $14.95. NUN A Memoir. By Mary Gilligan Wong. 390 pp. San Diego and New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $15.95.

title: JEWISH-FOLKLORE CONFERENCE TO BE HELD
description: AT THE age of 82, Abraham Crystal of Bridgeton, a retired egg farmer, carves wooden keepsakes in what was once his chicken coop. For his family, he has made chess sets with the Star of David on the king's head and graggers, traditional noisemakers for the Purim celebration. For a Christian neighbor who eased his entry into farming long ago, Mr. Crystal has decorated a set of wooden keys with crosses.

title: LONDON
description: Scholars have categorized ''All's Well That Ends Well'' as one of the Bard's ''problem plays,'' as puzzling as ''Measure for Measure'' and ''Troilus and Cressida'' yet less stimulating than either, and over the centuries actors and directors have remained faithfully aloof. ''A nasty play,'' wrote the eminent critic Sir Arthur Quiller-Couch, who edited ''All's Well'' in the definitive New Cambridge edition. Indeed, the first recorded performance of ''All's Well'' took place 125 years after its author's death, and major revivals since then can be counted on, well, a hand and a half.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
THE FLOWERS THAT BLOOM
description: Spring has sprung, and in case anyone has any doubts about it, two of the Island's leading garden spots are emerging this week in all their seasonal finery. Although it doesn't open officially until April 30, Old Westbury Gardens begins a series of Sunday garden walks today from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Admission is $3, or $1 for children, and the gardens are on Old Westbury Road in Old Westbury.

title: CONCERT: SKITCH HENDERSON AND NEW YORK POPS
description: Arthur Fiedler made the Boston Pops an American institution, and John Williams seems to be carrying on that torch with some sureness. For a while, Andre Kostelanetz led a New York Philharmonic equivalent, but that seems to have transformed itself after his death into a shifting sequence of different spring-festival ideas.

title: COMPETING WITH THE PAST
description: WESTBURY MANOR in Westbury, a stately establishment with magnificent grounds that was owned by the late Carl Hoppl, one of the Island's most famous restaurateurs, changed hands in the late 70's. It is again under new management and reopened earlier this year with the promise of having been restored to its former grandeur, as in the days of the legendary Mr. Hoppl.

title: UPSURGE IN GAMBLING AROUSES CONCERN
description: THE Island's big gambler is not a stogie-smoking sharpie in a pinstriped suit. He is more apt to wear blue jeans and carry his father's OTB charge account code in his pocket.

title: Army-Navy Club to Elect
description: Brig. Gen. James D. Hittle, former Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Manpower and Reserve, was nominated as president of the Army and Navy Club and is expected to be elected at the club's annual meeting Monday. Mr. Hittle, a former Marine Corps general who was senior vice president for government affairs at Pan American World Airways until 1973, is now a business consultant here. He will replace Gen. John A. Kjellstrom.

title: What sort of country would this ''withdrawn'' America be?
description: Would it be at peace with itself? Or would we instead be back in a guiltridden 1940-type situation, with certain political forces trying to ''creep'' outward again but others trying to hold the line under cover of some false but attractive explanation.

title: Bishops Rethink The Unthinkable
description: The Administration won big points last week in a running argument with Roman Catholic churchmen about the morality of its nuclear policies. A committee of bishops softened earlier support for a halt in production and deployment of nuclear arms, calling instead for a weapons ''curb.''

title: CONNECTICUT SENATE PASSES A RIGHT-TO-DIE BILL
description: Legislation allowing terminally ill patients to order the removal of life-support systems was approved this week by Connecticut's State Senate.

title: PANEL SAYS VANDALS COST STATE U. $600,000 A YEAR
description: Vandals, often acting under the influence of alcohol or because of a lack of respect for property, cause more than $600,000 in damage a year on the State University's campuses, according to a legislative panel.

title: R.L. FRIGO, EXECUTIVE, WEDS KATHLEEN LaHIFF
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Manhattan yesterday Kathleen LaHiff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael LaHiff of New York, became the bride of Robert L. Frigo, a widower and son of Adeline Frigo of Torrington, Conn., and the late Stefano Frigo. The Rev. Gerard DiSenso performed the ceremony.

title: WATSON'S HIT GIVES BRAVES A 6-5 VICTORY
description: The pinch-hitter Bob Watson's one-out single to left field in the bottom of the ninth inning scored Glenn Hubbard with the winning run to give the Atlanta Braves a 6-5 victory over the San Diego Padres today.

title: DEMOCRATS EVERYWHERE MAY CATCH FALLOUT FROM CHICAGO
description: In the heavily Democratic Lincoln Park neighborhood one day last week, Bernard E. Epton, the Republican mayoral candidate, dropped by the Seminary Restaurant, a hangout for Democratic politicians. Outside a crowd of white men, including many city employees who got their jobs through the Democratic patronage machine, were chanting ''Ep-ton! Ep-ton!'' and taunting black passersby. ''I'm voting for the white guy,'' a member of the crowd responded when asked whether he was a Democrat or a Republican. Then, in the next breath, he pleaded not to have his name published.

title: Soviet Picks New Chief For Its Missile Ministry
description: The Soviet Union has appointed a new head of the Ministry of General Machine Building, believed by Western intelligence specialists to be a cover name for the assembly of missiles, booster rockets and space vehicles.

title: Brink's Jury To Be Nameless
description: A judge began questioning potential jurors last week in the Federal trial stemming from the investigation of the 1981 Brink's armored car robbery and murders. But one thing he didn't ask them was their names.

title: FEE BATTLE GROWS BEYOND THE CAMPUS
description: A NEW battle has broken out in an ideological war that has been going on at many colleges since the 1970's, and a number of those involved believe that more is at stake this time than campus issues.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ARNOLD OF THE DUCKS Written and illustrated by Mordicai Gerstein. Unpaged. New York: Harper & Row. $10.50. (Ages 5 to 9)

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WOLF ROLAND By Julia Cunningham. 108 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $9.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: MISSILES AIRLIFTED FROM U.S. ARRIVE IN THAILAND
description: The first United States arms shipment to be rushed to Thailand to help counter the latest Vietnamese military threat arrived in Bangkok today.

title: ART CENTERS STRUGGLE TO KEEP THEIR AUDIENCES AND BOOKS
description: THE four cultural centers named by a statewide panel analyzing the future of the arts in New Jersey are trying, with varying degrees of success and desperation, to fulfill their mandate to become regional strongholds of artistic expression.

title: ART
description: By the end of May it may well seem to New Yorkers that there can hardly be a living soul left in London, so great is the press of people who are coming over for one aspect or another of ''Britain Salutes New York.''

title: A HAVEN FOR THE HOMELESS EXTENDS ITS EFFORTS
description: CONCERNED about growing numbers of homeless people in Yonkers, three churches that established an emergency winter shelter system in February announced last week that they would extend the program indefinitely. The sponsors of the all-volunteer program, which feeds and provides beds for 25 to 50 people each night, had planned to close the operation Friday.

title: HOW FAR YOUR DOLLAR CAN GO
description: The dollar is king again, and traveling to Europe is cheaper than it ever was, right? Not exactly. In fact, if your memory goes back to the time before Jimmy Carter's inauguration or to the Watergate period, not at all. Had you gone to Paris in 1972, you could have rented a single room at the Ritz for about $42, had the Tour d'Argent's duck for just under $12, and enjoyed a cup of coffee at the Cafe de la Paix for 69 cents.

title: TERMITE CHEMICALS DRAWING SCRUTINY
description: LONG ISLAND's sandy soil and the construction methods used on many homes here have made Nassau and Suffolk Counties unusually vulnerable to termites and, according to environmental officials, to the kind of pesticide misapplication that they say led to the contamination of at least eight houses in the last 16 months.

title: No Headline
description: The Republicans certainly are floundering in confusion over what they stand for, trying now to be ''practical'' rather than ideological. In other words, they have abandoned principle in pursuit of popularity.

title: The Case Against a New Isolation
description: It was gratifying to read Prof. Earl C. Ravenal's article "The Case for Withdrawal of Our Forces" (March 6). It is heartening to read a reasoned piece that makes recommendations based upon an understanding of some key facts, notably that the budget is not ''just throwing money away,'' that it is based upon a strategy of deterrence and forward defense, and that effective budget proposals cannot be made without reference to strategy.

title: LEARNING THE LANGUAGE
description: It is doubtful whether any sport or recreation has a greater worldwide appeal than bridge. In the 1980 world championships in Valkenberg, the Netherlands, 58 countries assembled, and this is apparently a record for any specific sport or recreation.

title: Primary Residence
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: HARRY S. TRUMAN, the 33d President of the United States, will be the focus of a three day conference at Hofstra University Thursday through Saturday. The conference, entitled ''Harry S. Truman: The Man From Independence,'' will be attended by scholars from across the country as well as representatives of six foreign countries.

title: Grand National to Corbiere
description: Corbiere, a 13-to-1 entry, outran a field of 40 other horses today to win what many fear could be the final running of the celebrated Grand National steeplechase.

title: Recent Sales
description: Aberdeen $83,500 *2*63 Idlewild Lane, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*19-year-old ranch; new carpeting, raised *2*hearth fireplace; taxes $2,168. Chester $165,000 *2*East Fox Chase Road, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*6-year-old colonial; central vacuum *2*system, 2 acres; taxes $3,760. East Brunswick $118,000 *2*48 Pine Ridge Drive, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 4-year-old *2*colonial; central air-conditioning, redwood deck; *2*taxes $3,123. Murray Hill $140,700 *2*85 Glenside Road, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*15-year-old-ranch; new driveway, *2*security system; taxes $2,414. Plainfield $130,500 *2*3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 39-year-old colonial; *2*wet bar, plaster walls, full basement; *2*taxes $3,098. Vernon $66,000 *2*Lisa Drive, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 4-year-old *2*bilevel; lake community, patio, deck; *2*taxes $1,100. OTHER AREAS Greenwich, Conn. $153,000 *2*184 Putnam Park, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*30-year-old town-house co-op; monthly charges Buchanan, N.Y. $67,500 *2*150 Albany Post Road, 2-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*53-year-old colonial; enclosed porches, *2*3-car detached garage; taxes $834. Stony Brook, L.I. $80,000 *2*24 Bucknell Lane, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*16-year-old colonial; dining room, *2*den, 2-car garage; taxes $2,300.

title: TEACHERS LEARN TO TEACH HOLOCAUST
description: WHEN Beverly Mandell, a sixth-grade teacher in Farmingdale, told some of her colleagues that she had registered for a course in teaching the Holocaust, the reaction was immediate - and negative.

title: Miss Cohen Sweeps
description: Tiffany Cohen completed her sweep of four freestyle events tonight with an American record for 1,650 yards in the final session of the 1983 United States swimming short-course championships.

title: GRADING THE SCHOOLS
description: More elementary school students are mastering the basic skills of reading, writing and arithmetic, but high school performance, especially by the brightest students, has deteriorated in recent years, educational researchers say. Data from local, state and national testing programs show that the gains have been concentrated among minority students, those from poor families and those who were the weakest academically.

title: PROSPECTS
description: More New Taxes?

title: HOLLYWOOD'S OFF BROADWAY
description: MIDNIGHT MOVIES By J. Hoberman and Jonathan Rosenbaum. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Harper & Row. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $8.95.SCURRILOUS, gory, inane and often technically inept, the midnight movie is an industry unto itself, with its peculiar directors, actors, distribution procedures, even a dedicated audience that routinely heads for its show at a time of night when most moviegoers are heading for bed. What is a midnight movie?

title: COAST GOVERNOR CREATES STIR BY BLOCKING A PAROLE
description: Gov. George Deukmejian has created a manyfaceted controversy by using a little-known law to stop the parole of a prisoner who has served 15 years for murder and rape.

title: L.I. 'ANNIE' EQUALS BRADWAY'S
description: ON April 21, ''Annie'' will celebrate a birthday. It was on that day six years ago that the overture began, the curtain went up and a little red-haired orphan sang her way into American musical stage history.

title: A FOREIGN POLICY FOR THE DEMOCRATS
description: Harry McPherson, a Washington lawyer, was Special Counsel to President Johnson. Richard Holbrooke, vice president of Public Strategies, a Washington-based consulting firm, was Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs during the Carter Administration.

title: BUSINESS AND ACADEMIA MELD AT PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON University's 1,600-acre Forrestal Center has been called a corporate Walden Pond, a place where the worlds of business and academia merge in a natural setting to seek progress through research. Since it opened seven years ago, it has also engendered some of the region's most innovative building designs.

title: U.S. 1
description: To the Editor:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WHY ARE THEY STARVING THEMSELVES? Understanding Anorexia Nervosa and Bulimia. By Elaine Landau. New York: Julian Messner. $9.29. (Ages 12 and Up)

title: THE NEW DEAL: THREE FOES AND A FRIEND
description: Franklin Delano Roosevelt had his harsh critics as well as his fervent supporters. However, during the first three months of his Administration, when New Deal legislation to end the Depression raced through Congress in an atmosphere of national crisis, most criticism was muted.

title: TRAINER RELYING ON QUALITY
description: It is the day before the Santa Anita Derby and D. Wayne Lukas is exactly where he expected to be six months ago, where he has been for the last three springs. He is in the middle of the Kentucky Derby picture, using the Santa Anita Derby as a springboard for another trip to Churchill Downs.

title: Cutoffs for Mentally Ill Bring Moratorium Plea
description: Senator John Heinz, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Aging, has called for a moratorium on cutoffs of disability benefits for the mentally ill. He said the cutoffs were turning into a ''nightmare'' for schizophrenics and other sick people who were ill-equipped to fight a bureaucracy.

title: STRATFORD THEATER STILL HAS PROBLEMS
description: ALTHOUGH the state's rescue of the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford from mortgage foreclosure last week prevented the immediate demise of the 28-year-old stage, the theater's board still has to worry about more than $800,000 in other debts, as well as operating costs for future productions.

title: TOXIC CLEANUP PLAN ASSAILED AS FLAWED
description: ASTATE geologist who resigned his job in protest last week has charged that plans by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to clean up the Price Landfill here, and to relocate Atlantic City's water supply because of possible contamination, could be faulty and ultimately waste millions of dollars.

title: REWARDS IN FIGHT ON ANTI-SEMITISM
description: ''SOMEHOW the human race is afflicted with all kinds of isms,'' said Kenneth J. Bialkin, ''and relations among groups have always been subject to tensions. Anti-Semitism is perhaps the oldest and in some ways the most virulent, and it would be utopian to visualize its termination.

title: MANAGUA COUNTS A LOT ON A MOBILIZED MILITIA
description: The rundown neighborhood of San Judas, normally alive with activity, was cloaked in sorrow and anger last week after news arrived that two local militiamen recently sent to fight insurgents in the north had been killed in action.

title: A BLACKSMITH'S ART
description: ''The Art of the Blacksmith,'' a six-day series of lectures and demonstrations offered by the Yale University Art Gallery Tuesday through next Sunday, puts a fair distance between ironworkers as artists and the image created by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow of the ''mighty'' village smithy with ''large and sinewy hands.''

title: East Bloc Plans A Summit Too
description: Soviet Leader Yuri V. Andropov has had a well-founded worry over economic performance since he assumed power in November. Last week, he was reported to have extended these concerns to the entire Soviet bloc by agreeing to the first meeting in 12 years of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance.

title: Hitchcock
description: To the Editor:

title: Bennington's Mutual Aid Idea
description: Bennington College, a well-regarded liberal arts college in Vermont, is expensive to attend, with tuition, room and board costs reaching $13,510 in September. It is also in debt.

title: Group Medical Practice Answers Many Needs
description: What a pity that Dr. Sanford A. Kaplan spoils an interesting article about medical malpractice insurance and litigation (''Malpractice Costs Are Peril to Health,'' Opinion Page, March 27) with a totally gratuitous slur on group practice, which he seems to rank even lower than clinics and Medicaid mills. To suggest that only the cost of medical insurance might convince a doctor to opt for anything other than private practice and to say that ''... clearly the nature of medicine practiced in these group settings is markedly depersonalized ... without the availability, individual attention or personal commitment the physician working alone offers'' is incredible and ridiculous, at least from this patient's view.

title: Nets Win; Taub Angry at Brown's Move
description: Joe Taub, the president of the Nets, unleashed an emotional verbal attack tonight on the team's former coach, Larry Brown, saying that he ''had no choice'' but to do what he did - demand Brown's resignation.

title: COLLEGE RADIO STATION OFFERS A POPULAR ALTERNATIVE
description: ONE afternoon last summer, the host on radio station WPKN-FM in Bridgeport began what was nominally a jazz show. First he played a series of singles by James Brown, the soul singer. Then he read a selection of newspaper editorials about the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. Only then was it on to Duke Ellington.

title: 6 ARAB NATIONS HOPE OIL SPILL BRINGS TRUCE IN GULF
description: Six Arab oil-producing countries threatened by a continuing oil spill in the Persian Gulf are trying to use the problem to force a cease-fire in the Iraq-Iran war, which they have long regarded as a major security threat to the region.

title: Signs of Mutiny Among Reagan's Good Soldiers
description: Three years ago, Ronald Reagan ran the Republican Party to the White House and a G.O.P. majority to the Senate on a ticket of defense and taxes: more of the former, to rearm America, and less of the latter, to revitalize the economy. His Congressional compatriots have been uneasy on the ramparts for some time now. Last week they turned their cannon on the citadel.

title: ADOPTEE'S SEARCH FOR HER HERITAGE
description: ''ADOPTEES have four real parents; let's stop pretending that two don't exist,'' suggests Katrina Maxtone-Graham, author of the newly published book, ''An Adopted Woman'' (Remi Books, $15.95).

title:
ART;
A MODEST SHOW IN TRENTON
description: WITH blockbuster exhibitions the mode of the day, an art show that takes pains to downplay both its subject matter and historical import has a good chance of gripping our attention and fancy. Such a modest approach is taken by ''19th-Century Painters of the Delaware Valley,'' an exhibition on view at the State Museum through April 24.

title: John Woods Wed To Elizabeth Duff
description: Elizabeth Anne Duff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Fritts Duff of Chattanooga, Tenn., was married there yesterday to John Maynard Woods, son of Margery Maynard Woods of New Canaan, Conn., and John E. Woods of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Ben Hayden performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: A Year After Crisis Landing, Air Hero Almost Does Encore
description: Capt. Fred Wilson of the Idaho Air National Guard was called a hero on April 8, 1982, when he landed an RF-4 Phantom Jet from the back seat after a bird crashed through the windshield, knocking the pilot unconscious. Captain Wilson is a weapons officer and not a certified pilot.

title: Jersey Trains Moving Again
description: There were welcoming signs and free rides for Monday morning commuters as the 34-day strike against N.J. Transit ended last week. But the good cheer - and the renewed service - might be shortlived.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN DUBLIN
description: A substantial proportion of tourists coming to Dublin visit Trinity College. It is well that they should, for however foreign this great seat of learning might once have been to nationalistic Irish feelings and aspirations - it was founded by the English Queen Elizabeth I in 1591 for the stated purpose of promoting the Protestant Reformation in Catholic Ireland - it has become an impressive, integral part of the Dublin scene, tangible and intangible. Its mighty Palladian facade dominates College Green, and in its buildings, courts and quadrangles are many intimations of the Irish capital's standing as a city of great antiquity, vast cultural wealth and considerable achievement.

title: Fleeing China
description: Two Chinese on cultural missions to the United States defected last year and asked this country to let them live here. One was Hu Na, the 19-year-old star tennis player who sought political asylum in July and received it last week amid widely publicized protests by China.

title:
STAMPS;
A TRIBUTE TO THE MAN WHO DISCOVERED OXYGEN
description: A new 20-cent commemorative will be issued by the United States this Tuesday to mark the 250th anniversary of the birth of Joseph Priestley, a man of the cloth who also discovered oxygen. He was a scientist and a man devoted to freedom.

title: WHY SOME ART RETAINS ITS EMOTIONAL IMPACT
description: Mortal men and women may come and go, talking of Michelangelo, but art traditionally is supposed to last. When what once engaged us stops doing so, we have the choice of suspecting the art or suspecting ourselves. For example, much of the photography that seemed innovative and important at the beginning of the 1970's no longer has the impact it once did. This is certainly true of Conceptual art that uses photography, which, from the perspective of today, seems to have run short of ideas - the deja pensee atmosphere of Douglas Huebler's recent show at the Leo Castelli Gallery on Greene Street being a case in point. And it is true of a more traditional sort of photography that nevertheless sought to overturn the conventions of what could and could not be photographed.

title: DANCE
description: Our current esthetic eclecticism has led choreographers to create works to all sorts of music. One choreographer who refuses to set up sonic barriers is Kenneth Rinker, whose Kenneth Rinker Dance Company offers two new works Friday through next Sunday nights at the Dalton School.

title: Weight of the Law
description: Police Chief George Aylward laid down the law last Jan. 1 to 20 overweight officers in Middletown, Conn.: ''Make weight'' by April 1 or face suspension without pay.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: MARXISM AND BEYOND By Sidney Hook. 225 pp. Totowa, N.J.: Rowman & Littlefield. $19.95.With these essays, for the most part articles and reviews published over the past 10 years, Sidney Hook plunges us back into the great political debates of the 20th century.

title: BLAIR EXPECTS TO MAKE AN IMPACT ON NETS
description: Not a Saturday evening would pass in the tiny town of Whitesburg, Ky,. when William H. Blair and his oldest son - Big Bill and Little Bill, they were called - did not pull up their chairs and listen with reverence to the successes of Adolph Rupp, the state's patriarch of college basketball.

title: U.S. AND CANADIANS TO REVIEW RELATIONS
description: When Allan J. MacEachen, Canada's Foreign Minister, begins two days of talks with Secretary of State George P. Shultz in Washington on Monday, the mood will be much balmier than when the two leaders first agreed seven months ago to hold quarterly reviews of the relationship between the two countries.

title: A MARY KNOLL FILM WEIGHED FOR OSCAR
description: A FILM produced by the Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers of Ossining depicting nuclear-disarmament efforts in the United States has been nominated for an Oscar in the documentary-film category by the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences. The winner will be announced tomorrow evening during the televised awards presentation.

title: Bruce Terry Engaged To Mary McCausland
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. McCausland of Great Neck, L.I., and Tennanah Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Catherine McCausland, to Bruce W. Terry, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Terry of River Vale, N.J., and Tennanah Lake.

title: Patty Davis, M.J. Raynes Plan to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Davis of Cherry Hill, Colo., and Palm Springs, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Ann Davis, to Martin J. Raynes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius B. Raynes of New York.

title: How Americans Enjoy Wildlife
description: LIKE the 42.1 million Americans 16 years old and older who drop a leisurely line now and again and then sit back to await a strike, and like the 17.4 million sportsmen who spend hours sitting in duck blinds or trudging through the woods in quest of a clear shot, the folks at the United States Fish and Wildlife Service apparently work at a deliberate pace.

title: A BASKETBALL VICTORY OVER LOGIC AND PREDICTABILITY
description: THOSE who didn't give North Carolina State a prayer against Houston in the National Collegiate Athletic Association final were ignorant of Santayana's dictum that those who ignore history might suffer the consequences of its repetition. On reconsideration, that global analogy might be a bit too gaudy. One had only to remember the influence of New York City on Atlantic Coast teams to realize that North Carolina State was not necessarily doomed last Monday night.

title: RAIN AGAIN FORCES DELAY IN MASTERS
description: Arnold Palmer, the gallery favorite, was one of six golfers still on the Augusta National Golf Club course when the second round of the 47th Masters Tournament was suspended by darkness today, and his chances suddenly took a turn for the better.

title: TALKS TO RESUME IN ALBANY OVER DELAYING BOTTLE DEPOSIT LAW
description: When the state's lawmakers return here Tuesday after the Passover and Easter recess, negotiations will resume over whether to delay the implementation of the state's bottle refund law, which requires a 5-cent deposit on beer and soft-drink containers. The law is to take effect July 1.

title: VOCAL MUSIC
description: The human voice will provide much of this week's music in concert. One event looks back to a great singer of the past.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: IF the level of educational attainment means anything, Connecticut residents are getting smarter. The latest analysis of data from the 1980 census, issued last week by the Connecticut Census Data Center, a unit of the State Office of Policy and Management, showed that 70.3 percent of state residents over age 25 had four years of high school or more, compared with 56 percent in 1970.

title: 4 COLLEGES OPPOSE PLAN BY PRETORIA
description: A Government plan to alter its policy determining how many black students can attend South Africa's four English-language white universities has come under criticism from the universities involved.

title: REAGAN SAYS HE WILL VETO ANY REPEAL OF TAX CUT
description: President Reagan today repeated his promise to veto any bill passed by Congress that would repeal the third year of the income tax cuts he won two years ago.

title: PEKING'S FARM POLICIES BEGINNING TO PAY OFF
description: Liu Si is rich. He earned 17,500 yuan - over $8,800 - last year and expects to do even better this year. Mr. Liu, 51 years old, lives on Dali Commune at the northern fringe of the Pearl River delta in Guangdong Province. He made his money, which by Chinese standards is equivalent to an American six-figure income, by raising 7,500 plump ducks for export to the dining tables of Hong Kong.

title: Finding an Exit
description: Things may be getting a little less crowded at the American Embassy in Moscow.

title: Morals and Music
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt started the fireworks early when he said last week that the Beach Boys and other rock groups would not be invited to perform at the official Independence Day celebration in Washington.

title: PHILHARMONIC: UNITY DESPITE VARIETY
description: Zubin Mehta's program for the New York Philharmonic Thursday may have looked like a grab bag - modernistic unpleasantness at the beginning, allowing for people to come comfortably late, followed by a Romantic war-horse concerto and finally by two luxuriant Debussy standards.

title: Turbo Called Thunderbird
description: JACKIE STEWART was eating and talking in a Manhattan restaurant. ''This is going to sound a little ... well, heavy, coming from me,'' he said. ''After all, I am involved with the company. But that T-Bird is fast.''

title: Mercedes M. Cue Wed To Jean-Francois Noel
description: Mercedes Montserrat Cue, daughter of Mercedes Gispert de Cue of Mexico City and the late Lorenzo Cue, was married yesterday in New York to Jean-Francois Noel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Noel of Brussels. The Rev. Stephen M. Rodgers performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: Physician to Wed Laura Jane Berlin
description: Eve Corwin of Flushing, Queens, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Laura Jane Berlin, to Dr. Alfred Gerson Gladstone, son of Madge Gladstone of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Herman Gladstone. The wedding is planned for June 12.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: A Boost From Dear Abby

title: Solzhenitsyn Backer Is Reported Seized
description: Sergei Khodorovich, who administered the exiled Russian writer Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's dissident aid fund, has been detained by the K.G.B., dissident sources said today.

title: TOWN VOTE MAY SETTLE FATE OF TOUGH GUN LAW
description: The fate of the strictest pistol ordinance in the country may rest on the outcome of an election to fill three seats on the Morton Grove Village Board next Tuesday.

title: WHERE TO GO TO SEEK HELP
description: For immediate help, the Yellow Pages list emergency numbers for local hospitals or mental-health services. The following state, regional and private facilities treat adolescents (and, in some cases, younger children) with depression/suicide problems:

title: Lawyers Marcy Wachtel and Gary Horowitz Wed
description: Marcy Wachtel, daughter of June Rosner of New York and Dr. Daniel Wachtel of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gary Horowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Horowitz of Spring Valley, N.Y. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at the Pierre Hotel.

title: REAGAN'S ARTS CHAIRMAN BRINGS SUBTLE CHANGES TO THE ENDOWMENT
description: The National Endowment for the Arts spends less than two-tenths of one percent of the Federal budget, and it accounts for less than 5 percent of all spending on the arts in the United States. But in the art world, it exerts an influence out of proportion to its budget.

title: Miss Pittman Weds Timothy W. Clark
description: Christina Marie Pittman, daughter of Betty Joan Pittman of Kent, Wash., and James William Pittman of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Timothy Warner Clark, son of Mr. and Mrs. Cameron Clark Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., and Ocean Reef, Fla. The Rev. Stanley Houston performed the ceremony at the Greenfield Hill Congregational Church in Fairfield.

title: Miss Harlow Weds Dr. Michael Irwin
description: Frederica Todd Harlow, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Gordon Harlow of Savannah, Ga., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Dr. Michael Henry Knox Irwin, son of Mrs. William Knox Irwin of Hove, Sussex, England, and the late Dr. Irwin. The Rev. Andrew Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

title: Gulf Oil Spill: War Comes First
description: War is an ecological disaster. But the lesson from the Persian Gulf last week was that an ecological disaster can be terribly amplified by war.

title: HOW WE LIVE NOW
description: U/S A Statistical Portrait of The American People. Edited by Andrew Hacker. With the Assistance of Lorrie Millman.300 pp. New York: Viking. Cloth, $25. Penguin Books. Paper, $8.95.STATISTICAL ABSTRACT OF THE UNITED STATES: 1982-83 National Data Book and Guide to Sources. 103d Edition. U.S. Department of Commerce. Bureau of the Census. 1,008 pp. Washington, D.C.: U.S. Government Printing Office. Cloth, $15. Paper, $11.By CHRISTOPHER JENCKS

title: A MIDWESTERN INNOCENT ABROAD
description: In ''The Legend of Joseph,'' which Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes presented in 1914 with a commissioned score by Richard Strauss and Mikhail Fokine's choreography, the Biblical hero, Joseph, is saved from a fate worse than death and then death itself by an angel. Potiphar's wife, who is responsible for Joseph's punishment and whose amatory impulses caused the mess in the first place, then proceeds to strangle herself with a pearl necklace.

title: EMPTY SCHOOLS POSE DILEMMA
description: AS the town prepares to close another school in June, officials in Fairfield are laying the groundwork to solicit purchase proposals for the two oldest of its six vacant school sites.

title: Dubious Distinction
description: As Representative George V. Hansen, Republican of Idaho, railed against ''Federal intrusion into all our lives'' last week, it was easy to see how that might be on his mind. Government investigators had taken a peek at some of his financial dealings and persuaded a grand jury to make him the first person indicted under the Ethics in Government Act of 1978. He was charged with failing to disclose nearly $250,000 in personal loans and a business profit of $87,475 between 1978 and 1981. Mr. Hansen, who faces up to 20 years in prison, called the charges a ''political outrage.''

title: Lava of Hawaii Volcano Threatens Housing Area
description: A four-mile-long river of lava flowed down the slopes of Kilauea Volcano toward the sea early today, burying two houses and forcing the evacuation of 100 people from a remote subdivision.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The mezzo-soprano Barbara Martin won the 1982 Concert Artists Guild Award and was also a prize winner in the 1979 Rockefeller Foundation American Music Competition for vocalists. At Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night, accompanied by the thoughtful and responsive pianist Margo Garrett, Miss Martin presented one of the most exciting debut concerts of the year. She offered music ranging from Monteverdi to Mozart to Mahler and beyond, singing in English, French, Italian, German and even Hungarian with impeccable diction and sure musicianship.

title: 90% JOBLESS RATE GRINDS WEST VIRGINIA COAL TOWN
description: The street lights have been turned off here since last summer, but even earlier a deep gloom shrouded most of the homes scattered along the narrow valley that encloses this mining town of 3,500 people.

title: A Program of Elderly Helping the Elderly
description: In January, the Retired Senior Volunteer Program (R.S.V.P.) in Westchester began a repair service for senior citizens similar to the Eastchester program described in the March 13 article (''About Westchester'').

title: Horner Beats the Boss
description: Bob Horner, the Atlanta Braves third baseman, stepped on the scales Friday and beat his boss, the owner Ted Turner, for almost $7,692.

title: Haven From The Wars
description: Hundreds of illegal aliens attending church today won't have to travel very far - they are among thousands being sheltered or otherwise aided by churches around the country and across the theological spectrum. Such borderline civil disobedience flies in the face of the Refugee Act of 1980, but immigration officials acknowledged last week that they intend to do little about it.

title: THE COMING SHOWDOWN ON CENTRAL AMERICA
description: THE Reagan Administration and Congress, like two heavyweights measuring one another in the early rounds of a fight, have so far traded jabs over Central America policy but managed to avoid a damaging brawl. As lawmakers returned to work last week after the Easter recess, it was clear that their accumulated doubts were leading to a more intense conflict in which Congress was prepared not only to challenge Administration policy but to use the power of the purse to change it.

title: An 8-to-1 'No' To Nuclear Waste
description: In 1982, Congress gave President Reagan five years to select the first of five national dump sites for highly radioactive nuclear waste. Voters in Wisconsin last week became the first to declare that they don't want their state considered for the honor.

title: FOR P.L.O., A 1ST-CLASS TRIP TO NOWHERE?
description: At the end of a news conference by the Palestine Liberation Organization last week, reporters cornered its top military commander, Khalil al-Wazir, and pounded him with questions about why the P.L.O. would not give Jordan a mandate at least to explore what could be gained from the Reagan peace initiative. Growing increasingly exasperated, the commander finally shot back, ''What is in it for the P.L.O.?''

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Weaver
description: Mr. and Mrs. L. Davis Weaver of Birmingham, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Stafford Weaver, to Jonathan David Gelberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Gelberg of Roslyn Heights, L.I.

title: THREE FRANCS BOUGHT ME A BOWL OF BORSCHT
description: From time to time The Book Review has invited both new and established writers to comment on various aspects of their craft: their imaginative and autobiographical sources, their practices of composition, the origin of their sense of vocation. These essays are intended to provide a forum for writers to consider the rewards and perils of their craft.

title: THEATER:'CHAMPEEEN!' CELEBRATES BESSIE SMITH
description: As Melvin Van Peebles sees it, between the times of Jack Johnson and Joe Louis there was a freeze-out on great black hopes. In his new musical, ''Champeeen!'' at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, he imagines Bessie Smith as, figuratively, filling the gap as an emblematic figure. He names her world champion of blues and awards her a reign that straddles several decades of American history.

title: HONG KONG: ROOMS WITH A VIEW
description: It has been said that the sight of Hong Kong harbor at night is sufficient reason to travel. Dozens of tiny lights play against a deep blue sky.
