Victoria Peak looms high in the distance, and everything is magically reflected in the waters that separate Hong Kong Island from the Kowloon Peninsula.

title: Salazar 5th; de Castella Wins
description: Alberto Salazar learned a valuable pre-Olympic lesson today, finishing fifth in the slowest time of his career as Robert de Castella of Australia won the first meeting between the world's two fastest marathoners.

title: MEDICARE PROPOSALS SAID TO BURDEN THOSE MOST ILL
description: The Congressional Budget Office has warned that proposals to increase charges for Medicare services to the elderly would impose the heaviest burdens on sick people who are hospitalized for long periods and already pay large amounts for physicians' services.

title: Janice M. Berger to Marry Jeffrey Landau on May 29
description: The engagement of Janice Marla Berger to Jeffrey Mark Landau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Landau of New York, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Berger, parents of the future bride. The ceremony will be performed on May 29 at Hampshire House.

title: U.S. OPENS INQUIRY ON BAYONNE POLICE
description: THE Department of Justice has notified Mayor Dennis P. Collins that his request for a Federal investigation into charges of corruption in the Police Department has been granted and that ''the Newark Strike Force'' of the department's Criminal Division is looking into the matter.

title: LINCOLN TUNNEL TUBE, POUNDED BY TRAFFIC, IS BEING RESURFACED
description: THE thunderous metallic clanking that assails the ears as cars, trucks and buses go through the center tube of the Lincoln Tunnel is the only public indication that workmen are repaving the roadway in the first tunnel rehabilitation of its kind.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
BANK-BUYING BINGE GETS A YELLOW LIGHT
description: The Reagan Administration, eager to bring order out of the regulatory chaos in the financial industry, proposed a ''moratorium'' on the purchase of banks by nonbanks. Treasury Secretary Regan urged state governments and Federal regulators to hold off, at least for the rest of this year, on allowing companies to use a loophole-turned-chasm in the Glass-Steagall Act as a way into the banking business. He said this would give Congress time to decide for itself just who should be able to buy a bank. It might also settle the tiff between the Comptroller of the Currency, who has been quick to approve bank purchases, and the go-slow Federal Reserve. Mr. Regan's moratorium would exclude brokerage firms, which, he said, would still be allowed to buy S.& L.'s.

title: MEXICAN ASSAILED OVER LEADERSHIP
description: Having moved quickly to tackle the acute economic crisis it inherited last December, Mexico's new Government is now being criticized for failing to exert strong political leadership.

title: Cameron Crone Marries Brent R. Bilger
description: Cameron Crone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Seth Crone of Charleston, S.C., was married yesterday to Brent Ross Bilger, son of Mrs. Richard Muth Bilger of Timonium, Md., and the late Mr. Bilger.

title: ON ARMS AND ARMS CONTROL, SERIOUS NEW WARNING SIGNALS
description: In White House lingo, President Reagan and his aides got a heavy dose of ''reality therapy'' last week, administered by their Republican allies in Congress. In perhaps the sharpest legislative setback of his Presidency, Mr. Reagan found the Senate Budget Committee unmoved by his claim that anything less than his proposed 10 percent increase in military spending (after inflation) for 1984 would bring ''joy to the Kremlin.'' The committee gave him half of the increase.

title: TODAY
description: A FEW weeks ago, along with millions of other solid citizens, I received my 1040 Federal income tax forms, a package awaited each year with the gusto of a condemned prisoner who must build his own scaffold.

title: Vietnam Steps Up War Next Door
description: Vietnam, which for four years has been trying to extend its writ to all corners of Cambodia, last week stepped up its annual dry season offensive against some of the estimated 45,000 anti-regime guerrillas. The attacks brought world attention back to the Sovietsupported 180,000 Vietnamese troops in Cambodia - a key obstacle to normalization of Chinese-Soviet relations.

title: FAIR REPRESENTATION: LET NASSAU LOOK AT SUFFOLK AND LEARN
description: A RECENT controversy in Suffolk County has once again brought to the forefront the failure of the Nassau County system of government. That controversy was over a resolution passed by the Suffolk County Legislature to abolish special elections for the Legislature whenever a vacancy should occur.

title: Smiley Lives?
description: To the Editor:

title: TENNIS ANYONE? TRY MULTISPORTS
description: WHEN one visits a club to play indoor tennis today, it is not unusual to be surrounded by people playing racquetball and squash, or splashing un a swimming pool. Some may be doing aerobic dancing or exercising in a Nautilus fitness room. The club may even have a roller rink, with skates for rent.

title: PSYCHIC INSECURITY AND QUARTER-POINT SPREADS
description: I know people who spend all their time ''putting their money to work.'' They run from bank to bank - putting money in, taking it out - all to earn higher interest. Their days are consumed with following rates as investors' days are filled with following stocks and bettors' with horses.

title: WORLD SPECULATION MOUNTS ON WHO WILL NEXT HEAD THE FED
description: Early last week, Paul A. Volcker had lunch at the Sheraton-Carlton Hotel in Washington with a small group of reporters. Among many things, Mr. Volcker remarked that interest rates were higher than they should be. Such is the Federal Reserve chairman's influence that in no time this view, purportely expressed on ''background,'' that is, not for attribution, was widely disseminated and Mr. Volcker identified. Prices in the $1 trillion Government securities market moved upward significantly and rates of interest dropped.

title: WHAT'S NEW WITH THE I.R.A.'S
description: With the April 15 tax deadline only days away, thousands of Americans are scrambling to the nearest bank or savings and loan to open Individual Retirement Accounts.

title: PROTESTS PUT ASIDE, GREEKS JOIN U.S. IN PARTY
description: There had been threats of another protest march on the small United States naval communications base here to demand that the Americans go home. But in the end, Americans and Greeks employed on the base joined in celebrating Greece's Independence Day with warm speeches, good food and wine and vigorous dancing.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: BAYONNE
description: ON a mild spring day, as the late afternoon sun slanted through the Bayonne Bridge and lit the waters of the Kill Van Kull, Robert E. Parks, who was born and raised in Bayonne, leaned back in his lounge chair and tipped the brim of his baseball cap down over his eyes.

title: BUILDERS AGAIN PROMOTING THEIR 'PRODUCT'
description: PEOPLE seeking homes in the metropolitan area this spring will see a return to an emphasis by builders on their ''product'' - the house itself -as they try to win customers in a competitive market.

title: MONDALE WINS MASSACHUSETTS BALLOT DESPITE LABOR'S NEUTRAL VOTES
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale finished first in the straw poll at the Massachusetts Democratic Convention today, despite losing some votes in a move by union members to express a neutral position.

title: AN OPERA DIVA TURNS TV FILMMAKER
description: When Nazi soldiers began rounding up the Jews of Venice in 1943, they brought to an end a long era of relative tranquillity for the city's Jews, an era begun more than 400 years earlier, in 1516, with a bargain struck between the Jewish elders and the Doge of Venice. By the terms of that agreement, Jews were restricted to a single walled-in island within the city. The island, called the Geto, had been the location of an ancient cannonball factory (geto was the Venetian word for foundry) and eventually its name came to be used universally for forcibly segregated neighborhoods.

title: New York Times Magazine April 10, 1983
description: William Safire 14 On Language Kemp Follower Russell Baker 20 Sunday Observer In the Majors Andrew H. Malcolm 24 Chicago! On the eve of a mayoral election, America's second city faces racial, economic and social challenges. Richard Holbrooke 30 A Foreign Policy for the Democrats and Harry McPherson After the country's swings to the left and the right in response to the debacles in Vietnam and Iran, the time is ripe, say two former Government officials, for Democrats to initiate a move back to the ''responsible center.''

title: WATERMAN, 81, GETS A PLACE IN HISTORY
description: OLIVER LaPLACE, a latter-day Huckleberry Finn, grew up in the first years of the 20th century on the banks of the Connecticut River in Essex, swimming, fishing, hunting and boating, even as Samuel L. Clemens was penning his final works just up the river in Hartford.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: HOW TO CHOOSE AN ESCORTED TOUR
description: To many travelers, the ultimate tour of Europe - or any other part of the world, for that matter - is one on which you don't have to worry about anything.

title: HIGH-TECH STOCKS: A REAL PUZZLER
description: Right before your eyes,'' says a Prudential-Bache ad on hightechnology stocks, ''our industrial society has been changing to an information society.''

title: Data Bank April 10, 1983
ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THEIR stories sound like the stuff of fiction - long-lost children, painstaking searches, tearful reunions. Were they imaginary, the tales that these women tell would be dismissed as melodrama.

title: AMERICAN MARRIAGES
description: BLUE RISE By Rebecca Hill. 296 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $14.95. JOE THE ENGINEER By Chuck Wachtel. 216 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $11.95.

title: KNICKS' KING AT HIS BEST UNDER PRESSURE
description: Bernard King's personality undergoes a sharp change almost from the time he puts on his Knick uniform. By the time he reaches the basketball court, his facial expressions have taken on those of an angry man.

title: Index; International
description: Peking's farm policies beginning to pay off 1 Shultz and Canadian to open two days of talks Monday 3 Diaspora of a Dominican Jewish town 3 Around the World 5 Six Arab countries hope to use oil spill to end Iran-Iraq war 6 Greeks join Americans in celebrating holiday at a U.S. base 7 Third world economic conference mutes the polemics 8 Mexican President faces growing criticism 9 A South African education plan is criticized 11 U.S. arms shipment arrives in Thailand 13 Soviet scientists call U.S. missile plan a delusion 14 U.S. law splits a Brooklyn man from his wife 17 Government/Politics Chicago Democrats hit the street to help G.O.P. candidate 22 California Governor creates a stir by blocking a parole 23 Mondale tops Massachusetts Democrats' straw vote 24 Mondale leads Glenn in national Gallup Poll 24 Reagan repeats threat to veto any bill repealing tax cuts 25 Town election may decide fate of tough antigun law 27 Report says Medicare proposals would hurt the sickest 28 Parent-support law languishing in Indiana 29 Religion Women ministers feel responsibility of dual role 30 General Around the Nation 22 West Virginia coal town faces 90% jobless rate 22 Hinckley judge favors retaining insanity defense 26 Volunteers tend Central Park for fun and spriritual profit 37 Razing of historic mansion causes upstate dispute 38 Two Jersey refuse haulers convicted of conspiracy 40 Industry/Labor Jobless are critical of Sacramento's strict welfare program 31 Negotiations resume in the Metro-North rail strike 32 Arts/Entertainment A mezzo-soprano and a flutist are among debut recitalists 56 Skitch Henderson and the New York Pops 56 Three works by choreographer Paul Taylor at City Center 56 Dance: Kei Takei's ''Light, Part 18'' 56 New York Philharmonic plays varied program 57 ''Champeeen!'' celebrates Bessie Smith 57 Style Loehmann's: An empire built by one woman 58 Features/Notes Man in the News: Robert F. Wagner Jr., new schools chief 34

title:
CAMERA;
TO ADD INTEREST, TRY FOR THE CANDID LOOK
description: Harvey L. Bilker is a freelance writer and photojournalist.

title: Susan Heuck Marries Dr. Peter Sutton Allen
description: Susan Arnold Heuck, an editorial researcher for the National Geographic Society in Washington, was married yesterday in Cincinnati to Dr. Peter Sutton Allen, a professor of anthropology at Rhode Island College. The Rev. John Ainslie Morrison, an Episcopal priest and a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at Hyde Park Community United Methodist Church.

title: BALDWIN
description: I'D always thought a lot more went on behind the counter of Frank and Joyce Marino's dry cleaning store than I could ever understand, because my clothes went in there like Goodwill rejects and came out better than new. And I never understood how people who cleaned clothes could greet customers with smiles like a row of sparkling pearl buttons, even if business is business.

title: KOCH'S TROUBLE-SHOOTER: ROBERT FERDINAND WAGNER JR
description: Not long into his career at City Hall, Mayor Koch began to assign some of the most onerous tasks in town to one member of his inner circle, with the full expectation that these problems - from closing hospitals to rounding up support for a large housing project - would be solved. Somehow, they were. The trouble-shooter was one of Mr. Koch's three Deputy Mayors, Robert F. Wagner Jr.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Film View column in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday gave an erroneous television credit for the actress Bess Armstrong. She starred in ''On Our Own.''

title: South Carolina Sheriff Accused of Misconduct
description: Sheriff Theodore McFarlin has been indicted again on 22 counts of official misconduct, stemming from a two-month investigation of alleged irregularities at the Williamsburg County jail.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: READ ANY GOOD TEXTS LATELY?
description: For almost 20 years a growing number of literary academics have been talking about books in a way that has had virtually no impact on the world outside their domain. Of course, people who pride themselves on keeping abreast of such things were made uncomfortable by the suspicion that there were important new ideas in the air that they didn't quite understand, or worse, didn't even dare pretend to understand without risking exposure. But, to judge from academics' inability to explain themselves to the uninitiated in the course of a dinner party, book review or movie line, these ideas seemed too difficult to grasp without going to a lot of effort - effort that, in difficult times, might be better spent boning up on supply-side economics, the nature of neo-liberalism or the Boom in Latin American literature.

title: Stanislaw Lem
description: To the Editor:

title: WARMING ONESELF UP ON NOT-SO-WARM SPRING DAYS
description: DISHES with a spicy tang are a perfect foil for the kind of unpredictable blustery spring weather we have been having lately. The recipes given here are both inexpensive and easy to prepare. They are excellent for simple, small dinners and can be made the night before and heated up just before being served. In fact, the flavor is heightened when the dishes have been refrigerated overnight.

title: Margaret Quinn Is Married
description: Margaret Therese Quinn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Quinn of Keansburg, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert James Iaia, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Hugo Iaia of Vero Beach, Fla. Municipal Court Judge Peter Shebell of Neptune Township, N.J., performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's sister, Patricia Gilmartin, in Belmar, N.J. Mrs. Iaia is an executive secretary at the St. Regis Paper Company in New York. Her husband is a compensation planning administrator with the International Business Machines Corporation in White Plains.

title: 32 Food Outlets Cited by City As Violators of Sanitary Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 32 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. The department also named one that was allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations.

title: Sports of the Times; Those New Masters Caddies
description: IN the rain yesterday, they still wore the green caps and the white coveralls with the names of their golfers on the backs in green lettering. But the caddies at the Masters have a different look. For the first time in the 47 tournaments, some Masters caddies are white. For the first time, the Masters golfers have been allowed to use caddies of their choice rather than being required to hire one of the black Augusta National caddies.

title: FROM 1975 TO NOW, HOW'S NEW YORK CITY DOING?
description: * In the 1970 and 1980 census, Hispanic respondents were in some cases also counted as blacks and whites.

title: A PALISADES MANOR HOUSE
description: Back in 1740, Abraham D. Haring, a farmer and descendant of one of the first families on New Jersey's Palisades, built himself a manor house in what is now the village of Rockleigh in Bergen County. A succession of prominent families occupied the rambling Dutch Colonial manor house until 1920 when Rose Haven, a private girls' school, was founded there.

title: Miss FitzGerald To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred FitzGerald of Apalachicola, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela A. FitzGerald, to Fred C. Luedke, son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Luedke of Westport, Conn.

title: IT'S CALLED RUSHVILLE, BUT TIMES ARE SLOW
description: The symptoms were difficult to see at first - a vacant storefront here and there, a few weeds growing between jagged cracks in the sidewalk. Midwestern farm towns have always suffered from some decay and neglect, but usually just around the edges. Today, more and more rural communities suffer not only the effects of unemployment but also the impact of declining farm prices. The two have brought hard times to Main Street.

title: A FINAL OPINION THAT'S SURPRISINGLY FAR FROM FINAL
description: THE Supreme Court, after laboring for five months on what was expected to be one of the more important civil rights cases of the term, last week brought forth a cryptic five-page opinion that resolved very little and raised one obvious question.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
NEW VERSION OF ORIGINAL HOLOCAUST MEDALLION
description: The horror of the Holocaust was so enormous in scope that people have trouble fully comprehending its magnitude. A newly issued ''Holocaust Remembrance Art Medallion'' conveys that horror poignantly in terms that are perhaps the most effective: not through the massiveness of six million deaths, but rather through depicting the pain of one small group of victims.

title: SOME DETOURS IN PURSUIT OF PORCELAIN
description: Last-minute check before I hurry to the airport. Suits. Shirts. Ties. Shoes. Socks. Underwear. Toilet articles. Foam rubber. Foam rubber?

title: DEMOCRATS IN CHICAGO PUT CAMPAIGN TECHNIQUES TO WORK FOR THE REPUBLICAN
description: Bernard E. Epton has never heard of Jim Malia, Billy Kent and Susan Horvitz. But if he wins Tuesday's election here and becomes Chicago's first Republican Mayor in 52 years, he will owe that stunning upset to them and thousands of other Democrats who are, as they say here, working the streets for their man.

title: The G.O.P. in Search of Itself
description: President Reagan's political adviser Edward Rollins pinpoints the problem with his man and his party in his attitudes that (1) the course must not be changed in the name of realism; (2) if the course is changed the President will be viewed as weak-willed and (3) ''You can't run on the basis of compromise'' (''The G.O.P. - A Party in Search of Itself,'' by Steven V. Roberts, March 6).

title: IT'S A BIG WEEK FOR WUORINEN
description: It is a genuinely unusual occurrence for a living American composer to have five different compositions, two of which are world premieres, performed by five different organizations in a period of six days in New York. Yet that is precisely what is happening to Charles Wuorinen between April 14 and April 19.

title:
DINING OUT;
WASHINGTON DID NOT SLEEP HERE
description: THE OLD MILL INN in Bernardsville is one of the few pre-Revolutionary War inns in New Jersey that does not claim that George Washington slept there. The reason, according to the legend on the menu, is that the building was not a hostelry then, but a granary.

title: Miss MacDonald Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Catherine Mary MacDonald to Christopher Andrew Barth, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Barth of Laurel Hollow, L.I., has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. MacDonald of Huntington, L.I., parents of the future bride.

title: SUNDAY, APRIL 10, 1983
description: International

title: And Bear in Mind
description: Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: CHRONICLE OF A DEATH FORETOLD, by Gabriel Garcia Marquez. (Alfred A. Knopf, $10.95.) A metaphysical murder mystery by the author of ''One Hundred Years of Solitude.''

title: 'NEEDS T.L.C. AND ALL THAT
description: THE present conjunction of lower inflation rate and better weather conditions has brought back an old and favorite American pastime: making plans for the future. Some people plan trips to exotic places; others, the purchase of a new home. A chosen few dare to dream of both.

title: Barbara Cowan Weds a C.P.A.
description: Barbara Baker Cowan of Key Biscayne, Fla., widow of Gregory M. Cowan, was married yesterday to Peter B. Humphrey of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Humphrey Jr. of Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Edwin H. Cromey performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Tuxedo Park, N.Y., where the couple will live.

title: No Headline
description: The strategy Professor Ravenal propounds is deliberately obscure. He provides hypothetical cases in which United States forces would not be used but does not tell us where and when they would be.

title: Metro-North Strike Raises a Question
description: With respect to the Metro-North strike, I cannot imagine why these employees who are now part of the M.T.A. would be compensated differently than other M.T.A. employees.

title: CHUGGING ALONG AT THE MET
description: Not many grizzled observers would characterize the Metropolitan Opera's 1982-83 season, which comes to an end this week, as a particularly glorious one in its history. There were a few memorable highs and more than a few equally unforgettable lows, some of which in each category will be enlarged upon as we go along. However, the season on the whole chugged along in that businesslike, cautious way that the current administration apparently chose as its artistic style some years ago. Sometimes it seemed as if the company were concerned chiefly with plans for arriving at its centennial season, 1983-84, in sound financial and administrative condition. If that was the goal, it has been reached. On the brink of turning 100, the Metropolitan lives, sort of.

title: CITY-OWNED HOUSING UNITS INCREASE
description: THE number of housing units taken over and managed by New York City i n property-tax foreclosures will increase by 30 percent over last y ear's total in the next four months as the city completes the p rocess of foreclosing on delinquent properties in Brooklyn.

title: Miss Hickey Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Hickey of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Magee Hickey, to S. Richolson Salembier, son of Harold P. Salembier of Oyster Bay and East Hampton, L.I., and the late Mary Lathrop Salembier.

title: RANGERS WIN, 9-3, TO SWEEP FLYERS
description: The end will come for the Islanders -some day. ''We know we may lose a money game one of these years,'' said Bob Bourne, the Islanders' veteran left wing. ''But we're just not ready to do it now. We're simply not ready to lose.''

title: ZUBIN MEHTA WILL APPEAR IN A FILM ABOUT ZOROASTER
description: As music director of the New York and Israel Philharmonics, Zubin Mehta is a central figure in Western music. Yet like more and more such stars of our musical firmament, he comes from a non-Western culture - one need only consider Seiji Ozawa, Yo-Yo Ma, the Tokyo Quartet, the Chung family and many, many more.

title: Overenergized CAT Scanners
description: In response to complaints that 238 of its computerized X-ray scanning machines are defective, Technicare Corporation last week said it had found a way to circumvent the defect - not with a replacement part or computer program, but with new operating instructions. The Food and Drug Administration, which brought the complaints, has not commented on the proposed fix.

title: Oil Slick Closes Capital Road
description: A damaged tank truck spewed 4,000 gallons of heating oil on a major highway in this Washington suburb today, threatening the local water supply and prompting the Maryland state police to close part of Highway 50. The truck's tank ruptured near the District of Columbia border.

title: Eliza Shanley Married To V. James Carone Jr.
description: Eliza Ann Shanley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Joseph Shanley of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, was married at St. Luke's Episcopal Church there yesterday to V. James Carone Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent James Carone of Hamden, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Venerable M. Joseph Farley, Archdeacon of Queens and rector of the church.

title: 'PLAYS'S THE THING' NOT QUITE THE THING
description: ''THE play's the thing,'' Hamlet pronounced - and forever more the phrase entered the mainstream of critical cliches. In 1926, Ferenc Molnar used it as a telling title for a boulevard comedy that tells us little more and entertains us a good deal less. Reversing reality, Molnar's play is not the thing, nowhere near.

title: MAYORS CHEER-AND COUNT THE GATE
description: Fernando Valenzuela, Ron Guidry and Steve Carlton didn't enjoy it very much, because they were either beaten or gone early. But to the people who worry about money in the nation's big-league cities, the opening of the baseball season last week suggested that help was on the way.

title: OFFICIALS SAY MX STUDY MAY LEAD TO A NEW ARMS-CONTROL STRATEGY
description: Senior Government officials said today that a forthcoming report to President Reagan on the MX missile would, if accepted, move the Administration toward a new approach on strategic arms reductions.

title: NURSES BATTLING AN OLD STEROTYPE
description: THE white-garbed physician's handmaiden who answered telephones, picked up charts and said, ''Yes, Doctor,'' is a thing of the past, nursing leaders say, but getting rid of that old stereotype is a challenge. The modern nurse's role can be illustrated by sketches of four of the 100,000 licensed nurses in New Jersey:

title: 2 REPORTED IN LEAD IN CONTEST FOR HEAD OF SUFFOLK COLLEGE
description: JOHN C. GALLAGHER, the Chief Deputy Suffolk County Executive, and Robert T. Kreiling, acting president of Suffolk County Community College, are considered by Suffolk politicians to be the leading contenders for the community college presidency in a competition with clear political overtones.

title: Rider in Poor Shape
description: Doctors in Toronto have not decided yet whether Colin Bain needs surgery.

title: AIRPORT NOISE ISSUE: BOTH SIDES PREPEARE FOR RETURN TO COURT
description: MORE than 17 months have elapsed since county officials, on Oct. 1, 1981, imposed a flight curfew at the Westchester County Airport, prohibiting takeoffs and landings between midnight and 7 A.M. and setting fines and possible jail sentences for violators. County officials say they have yet to fine or jail anyone, although they report that there have been ''15 or 16'' unauthorized landings during the curfew hours since then.

title: Deborah Singer Is Future Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Singer of Merrick, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Ann Singer, to Edward M. Soffen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Soffen of Philadelphia.

title: Soviet Scientists Call Missile Defense Plan By U.S. an Illusion
description: Soviet scientists said today that President Reagan's plan for an effective defense against nuclear attack was an illusion.

title: NICARAGUAN WARNS HONDURAS ON RAIDS
description: The Defense Minister of Nicaragua warned today that if his country continued to be attacked from Honduran territory, revolutionaries in Honduras might launch attacks against Honduran armed forces.

title: Miss Nolan Is Married
description: Katherine Anne Nolan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Nolan of Summit, N.J., was married there yesterday to Mark Ignatius Curran, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Curran of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Sea Girt, N.J. Msgr. Anthony F. Bogdziewicz performed the ceremony at St. Teresa of Avila Roman Catholic Church.

title: After Hardball, Resuming Tennis
description: Hardly anyone in China plays tennis, except on table tops, but the few who do are not to be trifled with. That was quite clear last week after political asylum for a 19-year-old tennis player sank Chinese-American relations to a new low. The United States granted refuge to Hu Na, who broke away from the visiting Chinese team in California last summer. China promptly canceled 19 sports and cultural exchanges, including the film ''Star Wars,'' the Juilliard Quartet and a visit by the world champion Chinese women's volleyball team, saying Washington had affronted its sovereignty and ''hurt the feelings of the Chinese people.''

title: CRITICAL DOUBLE FEATURE
description: THE ALTERING EYE Contemporary International Cinema. By Robert Phillip Kolker. Illustrated. 428 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95. SOMETHING TO DECLARE Twelve Years of Films from Abroad. By John Simon. 442 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/Crown. $19.95.

title: John V. Holten Is Wed to Lisann Jacobs
description: At St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Buffalo yesterday, Lisann Jane Jacobs, a senior at Wellesley College, was married to John Victor Holten, an assistant treasurer with the Nordic American Banking Corporation in New York. The ceremony was performed by the Very Rev. James M. Demske, president of Canisius College.

title: INTERNATIONAL SITUATIONS
description: NORTHERN EXPOSURE By Michael Kilian. 323 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $14.95. THE CANARIS FRAGMENTS By Walter Winward. 285 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $14.95. THE BODY By Richard Ben Sapir. 347 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $16.95.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: BEYOND THE VEIL The Adventures of an American Doctor in Saudi Arabia. By Seymour Gray. 353 pp. New York: A Cornelia & Michael Bessie Book/Harper & Row.

title: EX-IOWA JUDGE HEADS PACE LAW SCHOOL
description: SINCE 1976, when Pace University opened its School of Law in White Plains, women have been well represented in the student body. Today they constitute 49 percent of the full-time students and 43 percent of part-timers. Many are pursuing careers after raising a family.

title: Convicted of False Complaint
description: A Fairfax Circuit Court judge has found a 30-year-old woman guilty of falsely complaining to the police last fall that contaminated eye drops had damaged her eyes. Debra D. Hill of Reston, Va., was convicted Friday of the misdemeanor offense of giving a false and misleading report of a crime. She is to be sentenced later.

title: NEGOTIATORS MEET ON METRO-NORTH RAIL STRIKE
description: Negotiations between the union and management to end the 34-day-old strike against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad resumed yesterday. Both sides said they were prepared to talk until a settlement was reached.

title: DANCE: 'LIGHT' BY KEI TAKEI
description: ''Light'' trudges on. ''Light'' is the collective title for the cycle of dances that Kei Takei has been choreographing since 1969. Moving Earth, Miss Takei's company, offered the premiere of ''Light, Part 18 (Wheat Field)'' Thursday night in the Performing Garage, and there is no end to the cycle in sight.

title: Olson Vaults 18-8 1/4, For Relays Record
description: Billy Olson shattered the Texas Relays pole-vault record today but failed in three attempts at the world outdoor record.

title: HOUSING FOR ELDERLY HEADS PRIORITY LIST
description: IN 1980, when Suffolk County evaluated the needs of its elderly people and formulated a three-year plan to meet them, housing was ranked fifth on a list of priority needs for those over the age of 65. Now, three years and several reassessments later, housing has moved up to No. 1 on the list, because of the rapidly increasing elderly population and the county's inability to make up Federal cutbacks in housing money.

title: Joy S. Johnson to Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur William Johnson of Potomac, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joy Sanborn Johnson, to Jonathan Boyd Spear of Washington. He is a son of the late Clara Ciullo Kaufmann and the late Wilfred S. Spear of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: P.L.O. AIDES SAY THEY HAVE NO CONFIDENCE IN PLEDGE ON OUTPOSTS
description: Two Palestine Liberation Organization officials said today that they had no confidence in a United states pledge to put pressure on Israel to halt Jewish settlements in the West Bank if King Hussein enters the Middle East peace talks.

title: N.H.L. Playoffs; Canadiens Ousted
description: Tony McKegney tapped in a rebound with 4 minutes 10 seconds left and Mike Ramsey added an empty-net goal tonight to give the Buffalo Sabres a 4-2 victory that eliminated the Montreal Canadiens from the National Hockey League Adams Division semifinal series in three consecutive games.

title: NORMAN MAILER'S EGYPTIAN NOVEL
description: ANCIENT EVENINGS By Norman Mailer.709 pp. Boston:Little, Brown & Co.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: BERGEN COUNTY residents called for jury duty will find their time for service reduced from a month to a week, beginning May 2, under a new system worked out by Assignment Judge Arthur Simpson Jr., who introduced similar changes when he served in Camden County two years ago.

title: Wine Cruises Feature Tours And Tastings
description: On the high seas, the days of ''Yo, ho, ho and a bottle of rum'' have given way to the era of the wine cruise. In European waters, for example, there is the 15-night Wine Lovers' Cruise aboard the Vistafjord, featuring shipboard wine experts, wine tastings and tours of vineyards in France, Portugal and Spain.

title: UNIVERSITIES DIG IN OVER LINKING COSTS WITH TUITION
description: Although Governor Cuomo's state budget managed to avert the largescale layoffs that he had predicted for the City and State Universities, it was still necessary to recommend tuition increases of $150 and $300 for the respective school systems. Last week, the chancellors of both institutions were considering the increases, which are likely to be approved in May by each university's trustees. But while the raises themselves have sparked little debate, there has been a considerable stir about proposed methods of determining them in the future.

title: A June Wedding For Phyllis Jacob
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Rowland Jacob of Greenwich, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Phyllis Ellen Jacob, to William Wraith 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wraith 3d of Portola Valley, Calif.

title: 3 Students Arrested in Korea
description: Three South Korean students have been arrested on charges of leading an anti-Government demonstration, the police said today. The three, seniors at Ewha Women's University in Seoul, were accused of violating a law banning unlicensed assembly after purportedly instigating other students to join a brief protest on Thursday.

title: THE WEALTH AND AURA OF MORGAN
description: A spotless, light beige carpet stretches like a sea of tranquillity across the executive floor of the Morgan Bank. The walls are paneled in genuine, not-too-highly-polished oak. The baseboards are of green marble. Huge oil portraits of Morgan's past chairmen peer across the chamber from gilt frames. An antique grandfather clock, with wood inlay, quietly ticks away the hours.

title: REISSUES OF MODERN JAZZ BEECOME A MAJOR TREND
description: Walking into the jazz department of a large record store these days can be like taking a trip 25 years back in time. One recognizes the covers of favored albums from the 1950's and early 1960's by musicians like Sonny Rollins, Miles Davis, Freddie Hubbard, Lee Morgan and Jackie McLean, albums that have been out of print for years. But these albums are brand new. They are reissues of some of the classic albums of modern jazz, using the original covers and back liners, and, of course, the original music. Only the shiny plastic shrinkwrap around the albums and the narrow paper sleeves wrapped around some of them betray their recent manufacture.

title: FAMILY SECRETS
description: MOTHER BOUND Autobiography in Search of a Father. By Jill Johnston. Illustrated. 164 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.RAISED by her mother and grandmother, Jill Johnston grew to college age believing that her mother was the widow of a dashing and prominent Englishman. She was disabused of this notion when her mother sent her the obituary of this man, who, though indeed dashing, had just then died; the revised version of the family saga transformed the mother into an erstwhile divorcee. Having in effect lost her father twice, Miss Johnston subsequently discovered that there had been no marriage. The mother was neither widow nor ex-wife. The daughter was illegitimate. And she found herself having a secret too: She did not believe she was really a girl.

title: FRENCH NAZI HUNTER SAYS C.I.A. 'PROTECTED' BARBIE
description: A French lawyer who with hsi wife tracked down Klaus Barbie in Bolivia in 1971 says he believes that American intelligence authorities "protected" him for five years after World War II, then sent him to Bolivia in 1951 "to cut relations with him."

title:
CAREFUL SHOPPER;
A look at Bargains and a Waterfall
description: Regional shopping centers increasingly attract organizations planning fund-raising events - just one full bus can mean 46 times $25 or $30 with much less effort than planning entertainment and cooking a dinner. Cohoes Specialty Stores charges $230 for a full bus or $5 for each reservation with a minimum of 40, and provides the vehicle for a one-stop pickup, but on occasion has arranged a second stop en route, say on the trip from Boston to Cohoes, a mill town a bit north of Albany and across the Hudson River from Troy. Driving time from White Plains to Cohoes is less than three hours.

title: DEFENSE SATELLITES: KEY TO NUCLEAR DISARMAMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: RANKS OF MISSILE PROTESTERS HAVE WIDENED AND DEEPENED
description: After considerable Easter marching, a little obstruction of business at military bases, and enough television air time in Europe to give antinuclear demonstrations the inuring familiarity of holiday traffic jams, what next?

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: IN THE MAJORS
description: I went to rent a car. There was a man ahead of me. ''Do you have a major credit card?'' the clerk asked him. The question chilled me. A major credit card?

title: Carol A. Mattson To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Mattson of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Anne Mattson, to Bruce E. Heylmun, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Heylmun of Pottstown, Pa.

title: CREATIVE DESIGNS
description: ''I like the challenge of designing for pieces of property that most of my competitors would not bother with,'' said Steven J. Calvanico, a Staten Island designer and builder specializing in residential projects for tiny, odd-shaped lots.

title: G.M. Diesels
description: To the Business Editor:

title: An Updated Form Of Contraception
description: For centuries women have used sponges as contraceptives and as tampons. Last week the Food and Drug Administration approved a modern version of this ancient birth control method, a device to be sold without a prescription, under the brand name Today, for about $1.

title: HOW TWO EAGLETS WERE HATCHED
description: IT WAS human carelessness - in DDT spraying for mosquito control - that kept New Jersey's only known pair of breeding bald eagles from bearing young for seven years. And it was human concern and persistence that helped the birds become parents again.

title: A May Wedding For Miss Newton
description: Susana Newton of Charlotte, N.C., and Nicholas Newton of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alexandra Elizabeth Newton, to David M. Carmen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald P. Carmen of Washington and Manchester, N.H. The wedding will take place next month.

title: WAITING LISTS ARE LONG FOR ORGAN TRANSPLANTS
description: WHILE her friends were out eating pizza and going on dates, 16-year-old Tracy Bossidy was spending her Saturday nights hooked up to a hemodialysis unit. She wasn't allowed pizza or soda, she was constantly tired, and her concerns were far weightier than those of the typical teen-ager.

title: Eastern's Pilots Accept Concessions on Wages
description: Pilots for Eastern Airlines accepted $30 million in wage concessions today, one day after the airline announced the layoff of 1,600 workers to offset the cost of a new contract with its largest union.

title: Robin Whitney Wed to W.N. Hubbard
description: Robin Davies Whitney, daughter of Barbara La Rochelle Davies and William Benjamin Davies, both of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to William Norris Hubbard, son of Mrs. Albert Harding Davis of Darien, Conn., and the late William Norris Hubbard of Darien. The Rev. Roger L. Foote performed the ceremony at the Christ Episcopal Church in Ponte Vedra, Fla.

title: A Correction
description: In The Week in Review of April 3, total employment in the United States in March was understated. It is 100,767,000.

title: RUBINSTEIN WINNER NAMED
description: Jeffrey Kahane, 26 years old, of Los Angeles, won the fourth Arthur Rubinstein International Piano Competition here Thursday night.

title: Affirmative Action
description: To the Business Editor:

title: NASSAU BUDGET-WATCHERS BEGIN TO SEE RED
description: In Nassau County, one of America's wealthiest suburbs, nearly everybody talks about taxes, and often in very nasty terms. But nobody does much about them, except to pay more and more each year. Most residents want to keep their schools good, their streets clean and their neighborhoods safe.

title: SHAKESPEARE'S CHALLENGE BRILLIANTLY MET
description: ''The Shakespeare Plays,'' the ambitious BBC/Time-Life Television project that is producing all 37 of the Elizabethan playwright's dramatic works, is currently concluding its fifth year with the fourpart history cycle that spans the 63 bloody years consumed by the ''War of the Roses.'' The story begins with the funeral of Henry V and ends with the grisly death of Richard III in 1485. The plays are the three parts of ''King Henry VI,'' which for some reason have been relegated by WNET/Channel 13 to an out-of-the-way 1 P.M. slot over six Sunday afternoons, and ''King Richard III,'' which will be shown in its entirety on Monday, May 2, at 8 P.M.

title: SOME REMEDIES HAVE UNWANTED SIDE EFFECTS
description: When Congress passed the budget act in 1974, it was envisioned as an instrument for restoring fiscal authority to the legislative branch. By setting its own priorities, Congress would become ''a more respected institution and a more effective partner in Government'' with the executive branch, argued former Representative Al Ullman, the Oregon Democrat who was chairman of the Ways and Means committee at the time.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FRANCE IN THE 1980s By John Ardagh. 672 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $7.95.''The Definitive Book'' is the immodest but understandable claim on the cover of John Ardagh's ''France in the 1980s.'' At first glance, this fat Penguin appears to offer more than you would ever want to know about contemporary France. The more you read, however, the more you are drawn into it.

title: When Hair Turns Thin
description: Deborah Blumenthal's article ''When Hair Turns Thin'' (March 13) was accurate and informative. However, the article failed to mention two new prospects for the treatment of hair loss.

title: POLICE SEARCHES QUESTIONED
description: AGRAND JURY investigation into the death of a motorist who was stopped by two Bergen County Police Department officers last week is expected to raise questions about official and unofficial methods used during automobile stops and subsequent searches.

title: PREVENTING YOUTHFUL SUICIDES
description: ''I HAD been reading a magazine article about suicide, saying, 'Thank goodness, this couldn't happen to us,' '' recalled a Union County man.

title: TITLE'S IMPACT IS SINKING IN AT N.C. STATE
description: WHAT a night! Oh, what a night! Jim Valvano ''Coach V'' to his North Carolina State players - was standing now in the lobby of his hotel in Albuquerque, N.M., his tie askew, talking with Jim Pomerantz, the assistant sports information director of North Carolina State. This was Monday night, about an hour after one of the most stunning and delicious moments of Valvano's life.

title: A WINNING SYSTEM
description: Yasser Seirawan has for the last year been making a killing with the Averbakh system, 5 B-K2 and 6 B-N5, against the King's Indian Defense. The United States co-champion from Seattle scored a crushing victory over the Russian grandmaster Yuri Balashov in the Toluca, Mexico, Interzonal Tournament and won a later game in the same event from Amador Rodriguez, a Cuban grandmaster, both with the Averbakh attack.

title: Colombia Denies It Sold Food To Survivors of Earthquake
description: Colombia has denied that a Government agency was selling food to survivors of an earthquake that struck the mountain city of Popayan in southern Colombia, killing at least 240 people.

title: France Eases Curbs On Foreign Travel
description: The Government has eased its new foreign-currency restrictions so that many French tourists will be able to take package vacations abroad this summer after all.

title: Environment Post: A Recommendation
description: When I became aware that Harold Berger was seeking government service, I wrote a letter to Governor Mario Cuomo recommending him. In part, I said: ''I have known Harold for the past 25 years and say without hesitancy, if there is one single human being I have met in the political arena on whom I would rely to do a job for me with intelligence, competence and dedication, it is Harold Berger.''

title: NICKLAUS FAMILIAR WITH BACK TROUBLE
description: Jack Nicklaus, in severe pain from back spasms, withdrew from the Masters today moments before the 43-yearold, five-time champion was about to tee off in the second round. He shot a one-over-par 73 in Thursday's opening round.

title: MOUNT SINAI NAMES A CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The Mount Sinai Medical Center has announced the appointment of Dr. James F. Glenn as president and chief executive officer. The appointment, effective June 1, came after a 15-month nationwide search, and was the first to merge the positions of president and chief executive officer.

title: Police Charge 3d Suspect, 17, In Slaying of a Queens Woman
description: A 17-year-old Bronx youth was charged yesterday morning in the slaying of a Queens woman whose daughter has already been charged in the crime.

title: THE POTTER'S ART
description: The Rookwood Pottery Company of Cincinnati enjoyed astounding critical and commercial success both here and abroad at the turn of the century, all of which has been documented in recent years in several exhibitions and books. Now, we are treated to another comprehensive review of the ceramics producer's modern period - ''Rookwood Pottery the Later Years: 1915-1950,'' a show of more than 140 examples on view through May 14 at the Jordan-Volpe Gallery, 457 West Broadway.

title: Atomic Storage
description: Underground salt beds in New Mexico, 25 miles southeast of Carlsbad, were tentatively chosen by the Federal Department of Energy in January 1981 as the nation's first permanent site for wastes from the manufacture of nuclear weapons. Studies on the suitability of the site were planned.

title: Poorer, Hungrier
description: In April 1979, a team of touring physicians who in 1967 had found widespread hunger in the nation's backwoods and urban slums announced that Federal feeding programs had eliminated most of the gross malnutrition in America. What would they find today on a similar tour of the country, four years later?

title: ADVICE TO THREE WORLDS
description: THE VOICE OF THE POOR Essays in Economic and Political Persuasion. By John Kenneth Galbraith. 88 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $8.95. JOHN KENNETH GALBRAITH, who served as American Ambassador to India during the Kennedy Administration, returned to that steamy land in the spring of 1982 to deliver the Rajaji Lectures, honoring the memory of Chakravarti Rajagopalachari, who served as Governor General of India between the achievement of independence in 1948 and the establishment of the Republic in 1950. In his preface to ''The Voice of the Poor,'' a collection of those lectures, Mr. Galbraith confesses his love for India; a common problem at the State Department is what to do about the excessive regard of ambassadors for the countries to which they are accredited.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I gave everybody a last vote at 30 seconds to see if they didn't want to go around one more time and all I got was blank looks. Nobody wanted to do that.'' - Paul J. Weitz, commander of the space shuttle Challenger. (30:4.)

title: BLOOD AND GUTS, EASTERN DIVISION
description: THE ANGKOR MASSACRE By Loup Durand. Translated by Helen R. Lane. 476 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $16.95. BLACK HEART By Eric Van Lustbader. 544 pp. New York: M. Evans & Co. $16.95.

title: MISS LOPEZ TAKES 2-SHOT LEAD ON 209
description: Nancy Lopez, last year's winner, shot a three-under-par 69 today to give her a two-shot lead after three rounds of the $200,000 J&B Scotch pro-am golf tournament.

title: Susanne Schafer Weds C.J. Bierbauer
description: Susanne Marie Schafer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin C. Schafer of Omaha, was married yesterday to Charles Johann Bierbauer of Washington, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Bierbauer of Allentown, Pa. District Court Judge Daniel F. O'Flaherty of Alexandria, Va., performed the ceremony at the Carlyle House, a historic site in Alexandria.

title: Nudging Israel To Lure Hussein
description: The Reagan Administration last week tried a new tack to persuade King Hussein of Jordan to join in negotiations about the Israelioccupied West Bank and Gaza - with or without approval of the Palestine Liberation Organization. Washington hinted it would consider sanctions to freeze the Israeli settlements, which Hussein fears are irreversibly shrinking the prospects for Arab self-determination in the occupied territories.

title:
ANTIQUES;
CAST-IRON GEMS FROM NEW JERSEY'S PAST
description: IRON firebacks, fireplace liners, a Franklin stove and some stove plates from the mid-1700's and early 1800's take up just two small walls in the new Decorative Arts wing at the State Museum here.

title: Colombian Novelist Returns
description: Gabriel Garcia Marquez, the Colombian Nobel Prize winner, ended two years of exile tonight when he returned to Colombia. The novelist, who fled to Mexico in 1981 charging that the Colombian Government was persecuting him for his left-ing connections, was welcomed back by Foreign Minister Rodrigo Lloreda Caicedo.

title: OLD WAYS COLOR NEW MOVIES
description: It's not only a man's world, but a very young man's world, one usually without adults and one in which women, even young ones, are bit parts. In ''The Outsiders,'' Francis Ford Coppola's screen version of S.E. Hinton's ''young-adult'' novel, the only parents on view are dumb-show figures, a pair of battling, screaming silhouettes seen against a tacky window shade.

title: At Johns Hopkins, Lacrosse Is No.1
description: One hundred years ago, Johns Hopkins University played its first lacrosse match. The team lost, 4-0, to the Druids Club of Baltimore. Since then the Blue Jays have compiled a lacrosse record unequaled by any other college. It includes 38 national championships, 605 victories, 71 winning seasons (only 13 losing ones), 125 first-team all-America players, teams that represented the United States at the 1928 and 1932 Olympic Games, and 40 of the 147 members of the Lacrosse Hall of Fame.

title: MAKING A PAYMENT ON THE PAST
description: A CURIOUS set of variables took me back to the old neighborhood, the center of my adolescence. I was in the living room with my family, absorbed in our traditional Friday evening Monopoly game, and when the telephone rang, it was ignored, since I was safely signed out to my partner. The Hippocratic Oath was the furthest verse from my mind, a house call even further.

title: Columbia Glacier
description: To the Editor: I should like to make a correction in the article ''Cruise Log: The New Trends'' (Travel, March 6).

title: 2 JERSEY GARBAGE HAULERS CONVICTED OF CONSPIRACY
description: Two refuse haulers and their companies were convicted last week of conspiring to monopolize commercial trash collections in northern and central New Jersey.

title: TORAH TO BE DEDICATED TODAY
description: A CZECHOSLOVAK Torah, on permanent loan to Congregation Beth El of Fairfield, will be dedicated as part of a memorial to Holocaust victims today.

title: Kyrill S. Schabert, 74, Dead; Ex-Head of Pantheon Books
description: Kyrill S. Schabert, one of the founders of Pantheon Books, died of heart failure Thursday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: CAR STEREO ADVANCES RAPIDLY
description: No sooner does the sap start running in the maples than I, too, get symptoms of spring fever. The snow may still be a foot deep or the mud unfathomable at my house in the Berkshires, but that first whiff of a softer air brings on a rash of wanderlust and thoughts of updating my car stereo.

title: U.S. VISA LAW PUTS A COUPLE IN A QUANDARY
description: On a hot day in London in 1971 Steven Arluck, a 19-year-old from Brooklyn, was cooling his feet in a fountain at Trafalgar Square. He noticed a woman doing the same, and they began to talk.

title: ALUMNI GEARING UP FOR ALMA MATERS
description: LATER this week, high school seniors will begin receiving college acceptance notices - and in the days that follow they will receive telephone calls from local representatives of those colleges. Essentially congratulatory, the calls are also a way for alumni to encourage attendance at their alma maters.

title: MAX VON SYDOW, ACTOR WITHOUT A COUNTRY
description: In the soft gray light of Malibu's Getty Museum, the Swedish actor Max von Sydow bends intently over delicate ink and chalk drawings, Holbein's portraits from the court of Henry VIII. ''These are good faces,'' he says, slowly looking around at the drawings. ''They're very accurate, and they're all great characters. Look how amused he is. That lower lip. And what was she thinking? I believe she must have been trying to impress Holbein. See? You recognize them all.'' His own face opens momentarily into a warm, almost shy grin.

title: IDEAS ABOUT PRISONS
description: Robert P. Patterson Jr., former president of the New York State Bar Association, has said he believes in ''a flexible and practical plan that incorporates a range of available measures which would keep additional prison construction to the minimum necessary, and release state moneys for other needed and useful purposes.''

title: Indians Defeat Orioles by 8-4
description: George Vukovich hit a grand slam, and Julio Franco had a home run in a six-run eighth inning today that led the Cleveland Indians to an 8-4 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in a home opener before a crowd of 52,150.

title: Apartment-Swapping
description: Question: My wife and I are separated but not legally divorced. She lives with our daughter in a one-bedroom apartment for which she has just signed a three-year lease, while I live in a two-bedroom apartment with the lease in my name. Can we swap apartments without having to sign a new lease? ... M.S. Queens.

title: FIELDING'S 35-YEAR TOUR OF EUROPE
description: ''The wings on our feet are awfully tattered from hard use and so now we're going to take them off and have them dry cleaned,'' said Temple Fielding, speaking for himself and Nancy, his wife and traveling partner of almost 41 years.

title: CANDOR, CHINESE STYLE
description: When I mention that I have been to China a common reaction is: ''I don't suppose you could see anything the Government didn't want you to see? A guide always with you wherever you went?''

title: INDIAN AGREEMENT IS VETOED
description: HOPES that a century-old Indian land dispute might be over were dimmed last week by President Reagan. The President on Tuesday vetoed a bill that would have returned to the Mashantucket Pequot Indians of Ledyard 800 acres they claim was illegally taken from them in 1855.

title: BACK-OFFICE CONFERENCE
description: How can New York City promote its outer boroughs as attractive locations for the back-office operations of companies that find prime Manhattan office space too expensive for clerical and computer work? What are companies seeking in their search for back office space? And what can the city do to compete more successfully with the suburban communities to which many back office jobs are being relocated?

title: AN APPEAL FOR UNITY
description: The news has been dominated in recent days by angry people: vicious racial charges in the election for Mayor in Chicago; demonstrations against the President of the United States in Pittsburgh; hostile and even personal slurs between Moscow and Washington -ironically in the name of ''peace.''

title: A SURVEY OF PROGRESS IN COUNTY DISTRICTS
description: HARDWARE: How are schools acquiring computers? A telephone survey of 40 school districts in the county showed that a majority were purchasing computers with district funds. Other computers are being obtained with a combination of Federal funds, state aid, Parent-Teacher Association gifts, private donations and corporate loans.

title: Donna J. Evans, Dietician, Marries D.I. Lichtenstein
description: Donna Joyce Evans, a renal dietician at St. John's Episcopal Hospital at the Marjorie Basser Dialysis Center in Lawrence, L.I., and David Ira Lichtenstein, who expects to receive a medical degree next month from the Universidad del Nordeste in Tampico, Mexico, were married yesterday. Rabbi Allan Blaine performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: TOP-NOTCH QUALTIY AT YALE COMPETITION
description: THE standard was consistently high at the annual Yale University concerto competion at Woolsey Hall a few weeks ago, and it was only a slight extra edge of professionalism that tipped the scales in favor of the three prize winners - who get solo appearances with the Yale Philharmonia next season.

title: PRECIOUS THINGS WE THREW AWAY
description: ''HOW about this?'' I asked, holding up a tall, white mug decorated with the British seal. ''I remember that!'' My sister's voice came from inside the bedroom closet. ''Bundles for Britain, 1943. Give it to Goodwill....on second thought, put it in my pile. And what shall we do with all these hats? Think they'll ever come back?''

title: CHILDREN OF SURVIVORS: LINK BETWEEN PAST AND FUTURE
description: THERE were nearly 100 people in the huge lecture hall. A few sat in groups of two or three, but most were scattered in single seats. I wondered if this was an attempt by those present to emphasize their individuality.

title: LESSONS FOR ALL
description: For a decade, the Preservation League of New York State has been teaching the means and virtues of preserving old buildings. Continuing in that mission, the league will be teaching again at its 10th statewide convention from Friday to Sunday at the Tarrytown Hilton in Tarrytown.

title: Era of Bigger Trucks Runs Into State Resistance
description: A new Federal law allowed tandem-trailer trucks the right of way on over 180,000 miles of the nation's highways last week, but its implementation encountered a bumpy ride as several states vigorously opposed the legislation.

title: WILLIAM H. DUNKAK
description: William H. Dunkak, a retired partner and director of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, died of a heart attack last Monday at his home in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: FOR STOREFRONT SCHOOL, NEW STABILITY
description: The school day begins noisily at the Children's Storefront in East Harlem as the 5- and 6-year-olds race up the steps of the small frame house. Waiting on the stairway is Ned O'Gorman - headmaster, poet and teacher.

title: A BOY OF DESTINY
description: A PRODIGAL CHILD By David Storey. 319 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $14.95THIS is a thoughtful, serious novel about aspiration and the artistic temperament. Its hero, Bryan Morley, the ''prodigal child'' of the title, feels from early childhood that he is marked out for something special. He has the not uncommon fantasy that he is not even his parents' child and that everything that happens to him is a test, part of the magical plan for his special destiny.

title: FUNDS, BROKERS, ET AL.
description: Banks and savings and loans are the most popular places for I.R.A.'s, but many investors open I.R.A.'s with mutual funds, money market funds or stockbrokers.

title: Rise in Tuition Voted For U. of Connecticut
description: The University of Connecticut's trustees have approved a 20 percent tuition increase for the next academic year, signaling a possible rise of $98 a year for most students at the state university's four campuses.

title: Taming of Tina
description: As the Central Park Zoo emptied its cages last January in preparation for rebuilding, it had little trouble disposing of most residents. They were either lent or given to other zoos.

title: HOW HARD IT IS TO HOLD ONE'S TONGUE
description: I WATCH television sometimes, safe within my home. With spouse, dog and I snugly seated on the couch facing our television set, we are, for the moment, the picture of the young Connecticut family. There is nothing particularly unusual about this.

title: Law Catches Up With Landlords
description: The roof fell in last week on more than a score of commercial landlords in Manhattan accused of failing to comply with New York City building safety laws. They were arrested in a roundup that Robert Esnard, the new Buildings Commissioner, hoped would show property owners and managers ''that we mean business.''

title: VOLUNTEERS HELP NEGLECTED CHILDREN IN COURT CASES
description: AFTER three years in operation, officials of the Children in Placement program here say it is accomplishing what it was created to do - reduce the number of instances in which a Juvenile Court judge is forced to take a child away from his parents because of child neglect.

title: Reporter Guilty of Fraud
description: A newspaper reporter was convicted Friday of charges of impersonating a law-enforcement officer to gain entry to a maximum security prison in southern Virginia to interview an inmate on death row. Judge Robert T. Vaughan of Mecklenburg County General District Court imposed a $500 fine on David Roman of Manassas, bureau chief for The Potomac News. The judge also imposed a six-month suspended jail sentence on Mr. Roman.

title: Mailbox; Pros in Training
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: ANNE RUSSELL GRACES 'MAME'
description: ''MAME'' has been enjoying a deservedly successful run at Glen Cove's Northstage Theater-Restaurant with Fran Warren in the title role. Now Anne Russell has taken over the lead from Miss Warren, bringing an added charm into this already charming musical.

title: A ROAD PROJECT UPSETS RESIDENTS OF WINDSOR
description: AT first glance, Pine Lane Extension, a rustic backwater in Windsor,C onn., looks much like any other pleasant neighborhood-in-the-making.R esidents can be seen tending newly planted saplings in their y etto-be-seeded front yards and at intervals along the way, c arpenters hammer at half-finished timber frames for houses that sello n average for $62,000.

title: HINCKLEY JUDGE WOULD KEEP INSANITY DEFENSE
description: In a rare public comment, the judge who presided at the trial of John W. Hinckley Jr. said Friday that the insanity defense should be retained.

title: LEADERS FAR APART ON NEXT FISCAL STEP
description: IT took three weeks of cajoling and persuading to prod the General Assembly into taking the first small step toward solving Connecticut's fiscal problem. The next step promises to be far more difficult.

title: A RETURN TO THE CITY OF URBS
description: ONCE, in another life, she had been an inhabitant of Urbs, that great agglomeration of concrete, steel and glass that testifies so eloquently to human inventiveness and genius.

title: SOUTH AMERICA'S 'ORCHESTRA' OF WATER
description: The water comes tumbling over the precipices - an awesome and powerful spectacle, higher and wider than North America's Niagara Falls, wider than Africa's Victoria Falls. They are the Iguassu Falls, roaring in the semitropical jungle on the border of Argentina and Brazil, on the Iguassu River.

title: Ex-Senators Urge Major Reform of Senate Rules
description: The United States Senate could become a much more efficient legislative machine under rule-change proposals submitted last week - unless the new rules become captives of the old.

title: AMFAC AT A TROPICAL CROSSROAD
description: HONOLULU HIGH in the lush, misty mountains above Amfac Inc.'s 1,300-acre Kaanapali Beach Resort on Maui, the view is of sweeping lime-green sugar cane fields, golf courses and a beach dotted with gleaming hotels and condominiums. It was here that Charles G. Bluhdorn talked of building a home during a visit nearly 10 years ago. ''He was just enchanted with Kaanapali,'' recalls Henry A. Walker Jr., Amfac's chief executive and chairman.

title: WESLEYAN STUDENTS DISCOVER JOY OF DANCE
description: ON one end of the campus at Wesleyan University, far away from classroom discussions devoted to computers, the stock market and DNA, strange sounds filter out of a dance studio.

title: Progress on Cancer Hailed
description: President Reagan, citing progress being made in finding ways to prevent, diagnose and treat cancer, has designated April as Cancer Control Month.

title: A TRIBUTE TO A SPECIAL TIME
description: THEATRICALLY, nostalgia has traveled the route from tiresome trend to serious sickness. It is being done to death. To see it reborn and thriving anew, go to the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport. The name of the entertainment there is ''Stage Door Canteen'' aptly subtitled ''A Musical Experience.''

title: NEW SKYSCRAPERS AND UNFULFILLED PROMISES
description: Not for half a century have as many skyscrapers with the pretense of architectural significance come to completion as now. There was a boom in construction in the 1950's, and a bigger one in the late 60's, but these periods were essentially without architectural aspirations, save for a few exceptional works. Now, however, the situation on the skyline is different. Every building seems to want to be architecture, though perhaps that word should be written Architecture, so desperate seem all of these buildings, from the best of them to the worst, to prove their value as objects of design.

title: ELIOT FELD PREFERS TO MAKE DANCES FOR OTHERS NOW
description: ''Idon't feel like a dancer anymore,'' sighs Eliot Feld, who before creating his own dance company, distinguished himself in such ballets as ''Billy the Kid'' and ''Fancy Free'' while a soloist with American Ballet Theater. Still boyish-looking even as his hair is graying, the dancer-choreographer was relaxing for a moment during preparations for his troupe's six-week season at the Joyce Theater, opening this Tuesday and continuing through May 22.

title: EMPLOYEES REMODEL POST OFFICE IN FAIRFIELD
description: THE 48-year-old main post office in the center of Fairfield Town has a new look. In just three months, the building's rather dull interior was transformed.

title: WALKER EXPECTED TO LEAD OFFENSE AGAIN
description: When they play the Michigan Panthers at Giants Stadium today, the New Jersey Generals will use the same offensive strategy that enabled them to gain 494 yards, a season's high for the United States Football League, and win their first game a week ago against the Arizona Wranglers.

title: 10 YEARS IN THE LIFE OF A GALLERY
description: AMERICA HOUSE GALLERY here is proclaiming its 10th anniversary with a show spotlighting the growth and development of American crafts during its decade of existence.

title: COMPUTER LITERACY: NEW GOAL IN SCHOOLS
description: ONE day last August, when the weather was perfect for golf or the beach, six teachers from the Tarrytown school district sat hunched over computers in the business office of Sleepy Hollow High School. What brought them back to school early was a workshop designed to introduce the participants -most of whom were members of the district's Computer Committee - to their 25 new microcomputers.

title: U.S. SAID TO PLAN A MILITARY BASE IN HONDURAS TO TRAIN SALVADORANS
description: The United States is planning to set up a military base in Honduras for the training of Salvadoran soldiers, according to two Reagan Administration officials.

title: Judith H. LeSage To Marry in May
description: Judith Hussey LeSage, a project assistant with Interphase Modular Systems Inc. in New York, and Edward Anthony Grassi, a stockbroker with Legg Mason Wood Walker in Baltimore, plan to be married May 7.

title: CONSUMER RATES
STUDY SEES LABOR SHORTAGES AHEAD FOR CITIES
description: A new study suggests that New York City and perhaps many other cities in the nation may experience labor shortages before the century is out.

title: IN PARIS, MAPS FOR KINGS AND OTHER TRAVELERS
description: Planning a hiking vacation in the French Alps? Want to know the fastest highway between Paris and the Cote d'Azur? Don't want to miss the sights or local festivals along your French holiday route? Start out with an excursion to 107 Rue la Boetie, just off the Champs-Elysees.

title: PASTA AND SEAFOOD IN GREENWICH
description: A RESTAURANT named after the delightful seaside resort of Porto Fino in northern Italy promises to offer more than the ubiquitous tomato sauce that is the mainstay of so many Italian restaurants in Fairfield County. In that respect, Porto Fino in Greenwich does not disappoint. Its small menu runs the gamut of the map of Italy, with a few non Italian specialties as well.

title: SELLING COLLEGE IN A BUYER'S MARKET
description: The acceptance letter, printed on heavy white bond under Boston University's impressive red seal, comes right to the point: ''It is my pleasure to inform you that the Board of Admissions has voted to offer you a place in the Class of 1987 at Boston University.'' This week highschool seniors across the country will be receiving the last of such letters, or ones with more dismaying news, from Boston University and other colleges and universities. In a recent switch of roles, however, it is the admissions officers who now are nervously awaiting the final outcome of the selection process.

title: A JAUNDICED PUBLIC EYE
description: THE CONFIDENCE GAP Business, Labor, and Government in the Public Mind. By Seymour Martin Lipset and William Schneider. 438 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95. THIS is no bait and switch book: A confidence gap is stalked through 10 of 12 chapters that document two decades of decline in the positive feelings Americans have toward big government, big business, big labor and a host of other important institutions and their leaders. Seymour Martin Lipset, of Stanford University and the Hoover Institution there, with William Schneider, of the Hoover Institution and the American Enterprise Institute, have exhausted virtually every major poll as far back as polls go, and they have even tried to pierce the attitudinal fog of the era before the 1930's by surveying relevant impressionistic studies of that time.

title: A-Test Veterans Getting a Break On Health Care
description: The Government announced last week that it was expanding its guidelines on free medical care for veterans who participated in open-air atomic tests between 1945 and 1962. Anyone whose diseases today might have resulted from radiation exposure then will receive free treatment.

title: 9 Sailors Left in Last Leg of World Race
description: Nine sailors in the BOC Challenge, the first organized singlehanded race round the world, are expected to leave Rio de Janeiro today on the final 5,300-mile leg home to Newport, R.I.

title: OPPOSITION DEVELOPS TO ENDING FIRE RESEARCH
description: Opposition is developing in Congress to the Reagan Administration's proposal to eliminate funds for the Government's fire research program.

title: A.T.&T. IS PLANNING A NEW FOUNDATION
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to establish a foundation that could become one of the country's largest corporatesponsored philanthropies, officials of the company said.

title: THE JOY OF THE UNEXPECTED
description: You'd think the mountain would be enough. In Patrick Meyers's admirable ''K2'' the huge overlay of ice-fall upon ice-fall that spills from an unseen top of the world into an equally unseen valley far below takes up more chilly sky-blue space than the entire proscenium of the Brooks Atkinson can show us. The very fact that the Atkinson's curtain goes all the way up as the evening begins creates its own stir of excitement, almost before we've been able to take in the full, ravaged splendor of designer Ming Cho Lee's pitted pillar of crystal. We are so accustomed to curtains that welcome us by crawling halfway up the arch and then halting, with the emptiness above cut off by an artificial ceiling, that the curtain's failure to stop midway is startling. Every inch of its rise thereafter adds to the special theatrical exhilaration that marks the occasion - almost as though we'd gone on inhaling long past what the doctor thought we could do. At the same time we are increasingly awed by the remoteness, the glaring indifference, the glittering silence of a peak only glancingly brushed by the sun.

title: Mary P. Hughes To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. John J. Hughes of Millbrook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Patricia Hughes, to James Bradford Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Clinton Barnes of Short Hills, N.J. The wedding is planned for Oct. 1.

title: NEWARK ARCHDIOCESE EXPECTS TO PAY OFF ITS DEBT BY 1984
description: The Archdiocese of Newark, which almost defaulted on loans of more than $22 million four years ago, will pay off its debts by the end of this year, Archbishop Peter L. Gerety has announced.

title: Lori Sue Abrams Engaged To Alan Barry Greenfield
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Abrams of Roslyn, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Sue Abrams, to Alan Barry Greenfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Greenfield, also of Roslyn.

title: Martha Bradstreet Jacobsen Engaged To William Austin Durkin 3d, Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Jacobsen of Madison, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Bradstreet Jacobsen, to William Austin Durkin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Durkin Jr., of Greenwich, Conn. A September wedding is planned.

title: KEMP FOLLOWER
description: When my colleagues at the Washington bureau of The Times bring a political figure in for lunch, they ask me along because they know I like to pick up snippets of the latest lingo. Recently, Republican Representative Jack Kemp, whose supply-side theories are looking much better with the economic recovery, was the guest target, and the pickings were delicious. (The economist Herbert Stein coined both supply-sider and Kemp follower.)

title: STRICTER FIRE RULES
description: IT will never be a best seller, but a recently issued 500-page soft-cover book may nevertheless have a lasting effect on the lives of Long Island residents. Its title is ''New York State Uniform Fire Prevention and Building Code,'' and it outlines stricter standards for new construction and safety provisions in older buildings.

title: LOOKING TO WESTPORT FOR INSPIRATION
description: SOME artists travel great distances in search of inspiration. Not Nancy Ketchman. She finds plenty of material within a few blocks of her home in Westport. Eight of the 10 works in ''Ambiguity,'' a onewoman show of paintings and pastel drawings at the Pindar Gallery in New York through next Sunday, depict such familiar sights as Main Street, Caccamo Lane and the Webb House.

title: JAZZ
description: Milt Hinton, the jazz bassist who is widely known as ''The Judge'' (because ''he sentences everyone to 30 days at listening to good music'') and whose reputation as a photographer is approaching his renown as a musician, will be honored with a musical tribute Sunday afternoon at 5 at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th Street and Fifth Avenue, one of the series of ''Heavenly Jazz'' concerts.

title: Chilean Exile Returns To Visit Ill Father
description: Andres Zaldivar, a Christian Democratic leader who has been living in exile in Spain, returned to Chile today to visit his ill father and was quickly hustled away from Santiago's airport by a police escort.

title: REPLIES TO 'TOMORROW, A JOB': CHOICES OR NO CHOICE AT ALL
description: ON behalf of her less privileged sisters, who have no choice but to work outside of the home, the following is offered as a counterpoint to Marilyn Levinson's murmuring of all the reasons why she can't look for a job (''Tomorrow, a Job,'' Opinion Page).

title: ART VIEW
description: A particularly welcome event in the current season is the return of the sculptor Mark di Suvero, whose last New York exhibition was in 1975. His recent work can be seen at the Oil & Steel Gallery, 157 Chambers Street, through May 7. The Oil & Steel Gallery has one of the more spectacular locations for a dealer's gallery in Manhattan. It is at the far western end of Chambers Street, at a point where the island seems to run out of island and there is nothing much to the west of us but flat white sand, the Hudson River and the Jersey shore. If you are at all high up, the light has an almost preternatural brilliance. Even with the shades down, it has the texture of sparkling crystal. Both heat and cold are magnified, likewise. So this is a place in which perceptions are heightened and we expect a great deal of the art.

title: HAPPY ON BASELINE, TRACY AUSTIN STICKS TO HER GAME
description: FROM all appearances nothing has changed. Tracy Austin still moves daintily about a tennis court as if she were wearing her finest shoes and trying to avoid the puddles on a rainy day.
