Her hair is brushed back off her face and tied in a ponytail with a pastel colored ribbon. Her home is anywhere along the baseline.

title: Computer Crime
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Question: I would like to center my vacation around horseback riding; I have taken horseback-riding trips in Wales, Hungary and Yugoslavia, and I know vacations of this sort are available in Ireland. Can you help me find other horse-oriented vacations, preferably with Englishstyle riding, in the United States or Europe? - N.N., New York, N.Y.

title: OSINING GIRLS TO PLAY SOCCER IN EUROPE
description: ''DON'T stay there. It is important to be a moving target. Get that ball going as quickly as possible!'' With these words 35 girls, mostly 14 and 15 years old, sprang into action. Quickly and adeptly they kicked a soccer ball around with their feet, heeding the instruction of their coach. They were showing off about four years of practice and playing in one of the world's most skillful and fast-moving sports - a sport that until recently had been largely a male domain.

title: WORKS IN WOODS BESTIR THE SENSES
description: IT must be the best-smelling exhibition ever assembled, ''Carved Wood Sculpture,'' and that alone makes the trip to Thorpe Intermedia, in Sparkill, worthwhile. But the show happens also to be very good - one of the best to date at this gallery, which is in the Dominican Convent on Route 340 in Rockland County.

title: Reagan Scuttles Pequot Deal
description: It took more than a century for the Mashantucket Pequot Indians to settle their land dispute with Connecticut, but only moments last week for President Reagan to unsettle it. He vetoed $900,000 Congress had unanimously appropriated for the purchase of 800 acres of privately owned land in the northeastern part of the state, saying Washington was paying too much and Connecticut too little.

title: QUEENS FEELS ZONING PRESSURES
description: AFTER more than 250 years, this will probably be the last spring thec rocuses will bloom on the front lawn of the pre-Revolutionary War house at 71-09 Juniper Valley Road in Middle Village, Queens.

title: DANGER SIGNALS TO WATCH FOR
description: Most teen-agers and younger children who attempt suicide give some kind of a signal that something is wrong. The following symptoms could mean that he or she is in danger:

title: GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE, U.S. COLLEGE STYLE
description: To the Editor:

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: DUCK hunters have been violating a three-year-old state regulation that forbids using potentially poisonous lead shot, according to Dr. Douglas Roscoe, pathologist for the Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife, an arm of the state's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: BY JOHN B. FORBES
description: FOR the last two decades, the Long Island Lacrosse Club has dominated club lacrosse in the North. But that supremacy may end this year, if a band of 32 young men and their supporters have their way.

title: Ann Margaret Dorigan Marries Dr. R.T. Wall 3d
description: Ann Margaret Dorigan and Dr. Russell T. Wall 3d were married yesterday at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Georgetown, Washington. The Rev. J. Roger Lucey, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Coast Dentist Is Sought In Deaths of 3 Patients
description: An arrest warrant has been issued for a 37-year-old dentist, charging him with murder in the deaths of three patients.

title: FICTION
description: THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 1 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 3 1 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills, loose among a set. 4 2 2 THE LONESOME GODS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $14.95.) A rugged adventurer stakes his claim in 19th-century southern California. 5 3 5 THE DELTA STAR, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $15.45.) Los Angeles cops contend with their own city's underworld, some would-be Nobel Prize scientists and an elusive Soviet sub. 6 4 2 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The friendship of two women survives the strains of 25 years in the worlds of show business, politics and big business. 7 11 22 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 8 7 2 BANKER, by Dick Francis.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BY THE LIGHT OF THE SILVERY MOON Written and illustrated by Nola Langner. Unpaged. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $9.50.

title: Female Prison Guards Found To Be as Effective as Males
description: There is no substantial difference in job performance between male and female guards in men's prisons, but women have more trouble being accepted by their male counterparts than by inmates, according to a state prison study.

title: TOKYO DEVELOPERS BET ON GOOFY AND SUSHI
description: IN 1962, Chiharu Kawasaki, the first president of a two-year-old development company called Oriental Land, visited Disneyland and told Roy Disney, Walt Disney's brother and a Disney official, that one day he wanted to bring Disneyland to Japan.

title: IT'S TIME TO MOVE ON
description: THERE must be something to working alongside the New Jersey Turnpike that makes a coach think about getting out. Is it the fumes from the gasoline distilleries or the exhaust from the trucks that make men think about college campuses somewhere else in America?

title: Which Doctors Are Dangerous?
description: In ''The Verdict,'' Paul Newman plays a lawyer who wins a case that reveals how a hospital staff participated in covering up a doctor's malpractice. At one point the jurors ask the judge if the law allows them to award the victim's relatives more than requested.

title: ADOLESCENT VICTIMS OF THEIR ELDERS' FAILURE
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
THE STILL LIFE THAT STIRS THE IMAGINATION
description: STILL LIFE themes can be wonderful foils for make-believe and the imagination. Things might be combined to suggest the exotic, or they might be isolated to generate an intense, emotional concentration. Moreover, the gifted artist will often make us feel that objects have powers far beyond the inanimate, as we see quite nicely in a current exhibition at the Isis Gallery in Port Washington.

title: CENTRAL PARK'S VOLUNTEERS TRADE LABOR FOR LEARNING
description: Tools were chosen because they were ''cute.'' Worms that had been raked out of their holes were told they were stupid for failing to get back in them quickly enough. And some low-lying tree branches were mistaken for roots.

title: COLD COMFORT IN ROME
description: Seneca, the stern tutor of Emperor Nero, scolded the Roman society ladies for their addiction to the luxury of ''drinking snow'' not only in summer but even in winter. It was surely more of an extravagance to get the stuff for the refrigeration of beverages in large leather bags from the highest peaks of the Alps during the hot months than to shovel snow and ice off the mountains near the imperial city in the chilly season. However, the stoic statesman philosopher found it outrageous that thewives and daughters of Rome's super-rich should even think of cold drinks in winter, when others were shivering.

title: INJECTING LIFE INTO BASEBALL
description: THE baseball season is now in swing, and many devotees are looking forward to another year with the boys of summer. But the time-honored game needs a shot in the arm to make it more interesting to sports fans accustomed to the fast-paced action of football, basketball and hockey.

title: THE LONG LAST NIGHT IN THE RING FOR BENNY LEONARD
description: BENNY LEONARD walked briskly past me as I greeted him in the lobby of St. Nicholas Arena. He sort of mumbled ''hi ya, kid,'' making clear that he didn't want to continue the conversation. A stop would almost surely draw a crowd of greeters and friends and hold him up to possible reprimand from the New York State Boxing Commission, whose rules dictate that a referee not converse with anyone on the night he officiates.

title: SCHOOL VOTE DRAWS FEW CANDIDATES
description: VOTERS in the state's 549 school districts will go to the polls Tuesday to decide on proposed budgets and elect board members. The people they elect will have to deal with myriad pressing problems, including insufficient state funds, declining enrollments and the subsquent need to close schools and reduce teaching staffs, a shortage of science and mathematics teachers, the need to revise curriculums to prepare students for emerging high-tech industries, continuing rounds of labor negotiations and a lack of parental interest.

title: DEFENSE SATELLITES: KEY TO NUCLEAR DISARMAMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: NO MORE PATCHES ON THE STATE'S TAX QUILT
description: THE more things change, the more they remain the same. This, in a nutshell, is a picture of Connecticut's current fiscal dilemma. To understand how we have arrived at this juncture, we must look back to 1969, when the state faced a $150 million deficit in the current period and a staggering shortfall for the following budget period. Sounds familiar doesn't it?

title: Afternoon Tea
description: To the Editor:

title: IF CHILDREN MUST PAY FOR CARE OF PARENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 More Held in Slaying of 13
description: Two men were ordered held on $100,000 bail after being arrested in connection with the destruction of evidence in the slaying of 13 people on Feb. 19 in a private Chinatown gambling club. Judge Philip Killien of the Seattle District Court ordered Kwan Fung Mak, 31 years old, and Sonny Kwan, 18, held until a decision on charges is made by the King County prosecutor's office. One of the men is the brother of Kwan Fai Mak, 22, who has been charged along with two others in the robbery and slayings at the Wah Mee club.

title: Japan Deports Chinese After U.S. Bars Asylum
description: Japan has deported a Chinese interpreter because the United States rejected her plea for political asylum, Japanese newspapers reported today.

title: L.I. TEEN-AGER KILLED AND SECOND HURT IN CAIRO FALL
description: A high school basketball player from Long Island was killed and a teammate was seriously injured yesterday when they plunged down an elevator shaft in a hotel in Cairo.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: OCEAN COUNTY has found some of its roots. Fittingly enough, the person who unearthed them is the County Historian, Pauline S. Miller of Toms River.

title: YANKS BEATEN, 7-4, BY BLUE JAY HOMER OFF GOSSAGE IN 8TH
description: The Yankees will lose many more games this season, but they hope none of the future defeats will hurt as much as the game they lost to Toronto today.

title: Miss Bowling Has Nuptials
description: Nancy Jo Bowling, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Chandler Bowling of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Stephen Allyn Gramps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Allyn Gramps of Stratford, Calif. The Rev. Walter Taylor performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church.

title: REPAY U.S. JAPANESE?
description: Forty years after the event, the Japanese-American lobby is pressing to have the Government provide additional large-scale damage-claim payments -a lump sum possibly running into billions of dollars - to American citizens or resident aliens of Japanese descent who were evacuated from the West Coast and temporarily relocated during World War II, or their surviving next of kin. If we bow to this lobby, we will perpetrate injustice.

title: A TRIBUTE TO SCHOOL BOARDS
description: COMMUNITIES throughout New Jersey will be the scene Tuesday of elections that virtually no one in the state knows about or will vote in.

title: THINGS PAST, THINGS TO COME
description: Listrac has little of the celebrity accorded its Brodeaux-producing neighbors. But now, thanks in part to the efforts of a group of American investors and those of the Baron Edmond de Rothschild, this small village in the Medoc region of France is again back on the wine-making map.

title: AIDE SAYS N.R.C. OVERESTIMATED RADIATION DANGER IN AN ACCIDENT
description: A high-ranking staff member of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission says his agency overestimated the maximum radiation that could be released in a serious nuclear accident. This, he testified last week, led to overstated predictions of the risk posed by a catastrophe at a nuclear power plant.

title: OLYMPIC VISAS ASSURED
description: The State Department has assured the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee that foreign athletes and officials traveling to the 1984 Summer Olympic Games will be allowed into the country without visa problems.

title: WESTERN COMPLAINTS
description: THE HUMAN CYCLE, By Colin M. Turnbull. 283 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Opinion; THE ROAD TO PROSPERITY ISN'T PAVED WITH CHIPS
description: ATLANTIC CITY'S gambling casinos are posting record wins, and the state's Lottery Commission reports unprecedented sales. All together, money channeled into the state coffers from legalized gaming this year will contribute nearly 7 percent of New Jersey's $6.2 billion budget.

title: SEEKING TO CONQUER 18th- CENTURY FARCE
description: AS a young man studying under the fabled Max Reinhardt, John Reich learned that as a director he must think of himself as an electric wire plugged into an outlet.

title: RAZING OF 1774 HOME CAUSES DISPUTE UPSTATE
description: In 1774, Peter R. Livingston built a brick house called the Hermitage here on the vast Livingston Manor in Columbia County that was owned and named for his family. Last month, the building was razed by its present owner, Margaret Rockefeller, despite efforts of some historical preservationists to save it.

title: BORROWING TO IMPROVE YOUR HOUSE
description: HOMEOWNERS afflicted by spring fever often develop a yearning to add on a family room, patio or swimming pool, or to rip out the old kitchen and put in a new one. This spring, those homeowners are in luck: a canvass of major lending institutions in the metropolitan area indicates that the cost of financing improvements is edging down.

title: Headliners; The Defense Didn't Rest
description: Authorities in Tennessee recently found it difficult to overrule a lawyer's objection to her client's incarceration - the attorney, Mary Evans, made her point with a gun.

title: Kin of British Dead Start Falkland Tour
description: Widows, children and parents of the 255 Britons killed in the Falkland war with Argentina last year began a four-day tour of battlefields and war graves today.

title: THE FOREIGN INTRIGUE OF COUSCOUS
description: Sentimental reasons aside, the North African dish known as couscous is, to my mind, the most intriguing of all ''foreign'' foods. It is also true that it was the first alien, which is to say non-American, dish that ever passed my lips, an experience that occurred more than four decades ago when I was stationed in Morocco during World War II. I decided then, with a limited basis for comparison, that it was one of the world's grandest creations. Nothing has changed my mind.

title: PRINCETON: AN ABSTRUSE ALBEE
description: IN ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'', Edward Albee's most commercially and critically successful - and still most potent -play, the author was grappling with the ultimate contemporary, an insoluable problem: Having arrived at awareness - enlightment, if you will - how does one handle it?

title: All's Well That Upends Well
description: Everything went swell for the space shuttle Challenger on its maiden voyage, completed yesterday, except for its $100 million cargo. While astronauts frolicked into the void, the giant communications satellite they deployed soon after arrival in orbit swung around the Earth on a severely warped path.

title:
GARDENING;
EARLY SPRING PLANTINGS FLIRT WITH FROST
description: DOES the early bird always catch the worm? Let me cite an example, then you be the judge. It was the first Friday in April, a warm sunny day. A customer walked into a garden center and, after searching about for a time, asked for tomato plants, there being none on display. The proprietor explained that the frost-free date, the average date beyond which there was a 90 percent certainty that there would be no further killing frost, was still two weeks away. Tomatoes, being tropical in origin and subject to damage from the slightest frost, would not be available for several weeks.

title: EXPO ON HEALTH OFFERS TESTING
description: NEWBERRY LOCKLEAR of Enfield turned 60 years old last week and he still drives his 18-wheeler six days a week. But if he had not made a fateful decision two years ago, things might be very different today for him and his wife, Barbara.

title: Gas Solutions
description: To the Business Editor:

title: RECOLLECTIONS FROM THE HILL
description: THE New Deal, maligned and misunderstood, created one of the most d ramatic periods in American history. I was privileged to be sworn ina s a freshman member of the House of Representatives just five days a fter the first inauguration of Franklin Delano Roosevelt. I am, in f act, the only active member of Congress who participated in that s eries of legislative and social reforms that lifted America off its k nees.

title: CRIME
description: Assassins. They come in all forms in espionage and mystery fiction. Some, unemotional and objective, kill as a business. Some are sadists who get a sexual thrill when they torture and kill, some little more than uneducated beasts. Some have style and savoir-faire. Some do it for God and Country. Some do it for the enemy.

title: WOMEN MINISTERS ARE FEELING DUAL ROLE
description: The Rev. Carol Matteson Cox feels a dual responsibility as she steps into the pulpit of Fordham United Methodist Church in the Bronx each Sunday. Like all members of the clergy, she hopes her words will comfort and inspire her parishioners. But as one of the rapidly growing number of ministers who are women, she also knows that her work is shaping the way lay people view such ministers.

title: DIGITAL DISKS TAP MUSIC OF THE BALLET
description: Since Tchaikovsky's day, many composers have written some of their best music for dance. Stravinsky, Ravel, Prokofiev, Copland and Bernstein spring first to mind, but others, like Britten, have also composed important ballets. Recent recordings include not only works representative of these composers, but also the first complete digital versions of Tchaikovsky's three ballets.

title: ESPIONAGE, TOO, HAS RULES OF THE ROAD
description: When the French Government expelled 47 Soviet citizens as spies last week, the world was treated to yet another large spectacle of the diplomacy of espionage.

title: THIRD WORLD ECONOMIC TALKS TAKE ON SOFTER TONE
description: The Group of 77 ended a weeklong meeting here today with resolutions that played down third world demands for a restructured world economic system that in the past have bitterly divided developing and industrial countries.

title:
GARDENING;
EARLY SPRING PLANTINGS FLIRT WITH FROST
description: DOES the early bird always catch the worm? Let me cite an example, then you be the judge. It was the first Friday in April, a warm sunny day. A customer walked into a garden center and, after searching about for a time, asked for tomato plants, there being none on display. The proprietor explained that the frost-free date, the average date beyond which there was a 90 percent certainty that there would be no further killing frost, was still two weeks away. Tomatoes, being tropical in origin and subject to damage from the slightest frost, would not be available for several weeks.

title: 292 RECEIVE FELLOWSHIPS FROM GUGGENHEIM FUND
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has announced fellowship awards totaling $5,540,000 to 292 scholars, scientists and artists chosen from among 3,571 applicants in the foundation's 59th annual competition.

title: Controls Protested
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO
description: They come in high off the lake, leaving only a vague trail of aerial soot to mark their silent passage. They are nothing but dots then. And no one looks. The powerful wing lights burst on first, even by day. The gear comes down next, giving the lights some legs but still no sound as another, another and yet another pair of beams swings in behind, separated by 7,000 feet. These shiny apparitions hang there, somehow coming lower, slowly, without seeming to move. About two miles out they take form, broad-winged aluminum hawks swooping home in the prairie sky from distant points, quietly. The speed seems to grow. The altitude falls quickly. The lead form plunges straight ahead, faster and faster. At 160 miles an hour, it flashes over a hotel roof. A powerline. Trees. At once the air is filled with thunder. And it is quickly gone.

title: POOR CRITICIZE SACRAMENTO WELFARE PROGRAM
description: In the heart of Sacramento's skid row an atmosphere of institutional boredom permeates a sparsely furnished hall where men and women try to pass the time watching television, shooting pool and playing chess.

title: Mary Morris, Lawyer, Weds Dr. J.R. Zech Jr.
description: Mary Frances Ann Morris, daughter of Mrs. Walter Michael Morris of Bement, Ill., and the late Mr. Morris, was married yesterday to Dr. John Raymond Zech Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Zech of Darien, Conn. The Rev. Joseph Marzolf performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Champaign, Ill.

title: DIASPORA OF A DOMINICAN JEWISH TOWN
description: Late last month, at what was once the Viennese Coffee House, the Jews of Sosua celebrated Passover. People who first heard the story of the Israelites in Egypt around dinner tables in Budapest, Breslau or Vienna held their annual seder under a thatched Caribbean roof, to the accompaniment of chirping crickets and the distant murmurs of Dominican music.

title: CUSTODY MEDIATION IS TESTED
description: WHEN George and Debra W. decided on a legal separation after eight years of marriage, they still had two powerful remaining connections: Joel and Benjamin, their sons.

title: DANCE: 3 WORKS BY THE PAUL TAYLOR COMPANY
description: Paul Taylor can serve up feasts of gorgeous all-out dancing, but his satanic instincts seem always on the ready. Both worlds were on view Thursday at the City Center, in three works performed to the hilt by the Paul Taylor Dance Company.

title: Catholic Schools Report Gains
description: The percentage of minority students in Roman Catholic schools has nearly doubled in the last 12 years while the percentage of non-Catholics has increased fourfold, the National Catholic Educational Association says.

title: A Slippery Rug For Salvador's Defense Chief
description: As Salvadoran rebels last week launched what they called a campaign to destroy the economy, the Reagan Administration was complaining that Defense Minister Jose Guillermo Garcia, the man most blamed for allowing the attacks, ''had to go.'' Therein lies a major Administration dilemma in Central America: General Garcia holds the kind of moderate political positions Washington is trying to encourage. He has supported agrarian reform and his help was essential in getting a moderate, Alvaro Magana, into the presidency. And as the American Embassy in San Salvador argued, it is not as if there's an outstanding candidate to take his job.

title: COLONIAL ENDINGS
description: Mr. Jabi and Mr. Smythe by Samuel Charters. 190 pp. New York: Marion Boyars. $12.95."MR. JABI AND MR. SMYTHE" is a first novel by Samuel Charters, who has published several volumes of peotry but is best known for histories of jazz and particularly the blues, which he has traced to their sources in Africa. In fact, "Mr. Jabi and Mr. Smythe" grew out of his growing cannon of fiction about the end of colonialism, it is a novel somehow at odds with a category that more often than not draws fromt he distrubed experience of hte writer's own life and is impelled by a respairing vision of the future. Mr. Charteis, though he lives in England, was born in America; he keeps his distance from his subject. Despite the richness of detail he brings to the novel, his evocation of the dust, the heat, the sparseness of the untamed country that is its setting and indeed his familiarity with the simple formalities tha govern village life, "Mr. Jabi and Mr. Smythe" describes a world he has merely traveled through rather than one he feels or has felt deeply.

title: Memorial Garden for Clark
description: A memorial garden will be planted this spring in Dr. Barney B. Clark's hometown to honor the first recipient of a permanent artificial heart, city officials say. Dr. Clark, 62 years old, died March 23 at the University of Utah Medical Center after living 112 days with the artificial heart. The dentist was born and reared in Provo but lived most of his life in the Seattle area.

title: Ex-Liquor Board; Investigator Found Guilty of Taking Bribes
description: A former investigator for New York City's Alcoholic Beverage Control Board has been found guilty of four counts of accepting bribes and one count of attempted extortion.

title: LOTTERY AIDE SEEKS TIME FOR REBUTTAL
description: ATTORNEYS for Reese Palley, the embattled chairman of the New Jersey Lottery Commission, say that he cannot respond to conflict-ofinterest charges filed by the state's Executive Commission on Ethical Standards because a response might hurt him if he becomes a target of a parallel grand jury investigation now under way.

title: Kuhn Not Optimistic
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, whose term is scheduled to end in August, says he does not think the new $1 billion television contract signed with NBC and ABC will help him keep his job. Speaking on ABC's ''Sportsbeat'' program, he said of the contract: ''I think it's a very good deal, and I think it's going to be good for our clubs, but frankly I don't think it's going to have much effect on my situation.''

title: MUSIC: NEVILLE DICKIE, PIANIST, AT HANRATTY'S
description: Neville Dickie, a burly, broad-shouldered English pianist whose specialties are stride piano, ragtime and boogie-woogie, has moved into Hanratty's, Second Avenue at 91st Street, where he will play through April 23, making what amounts to his American debut.

title: THE TELLING DEBATE OVER WHAT SHOULD BE SECRET
description: When President Reagan recently signed a directive ''safeguarding national security information,'' White House officials expected critics to complain about the increased reliance on polygraphs as a tool for investigating news ''leaks.'' Few of them expected the furor over another provision, requiring ''prepublication review'' of manuscripts written by employees and former employees with access to highly classified information.

title: Who Declares Secret Wars?
description: Why won't the Reagan Administration debate, openly and seriously, the legality of an American-sponsored secret war in Nicaragua?

title: THE 'HUNDRED DAYS' OF F.D.R.
description: EXACTLY half a century ago, the Republic plunged into the Hundred Days - that time of tumultuous c hange when a flood of legislation swept away venerable market p ractices and gave the American economic system a new contour.

title: BATTLING FOR A SMALLER GAF
description: AT the GAF Corporation, the mere mention of Samuel J. Heyman is e nough to make executives seethe. In top offices, Mr. Heyman is seen a s public enemy No.1 - and not without some justification. A lawyer, r eal estate developer and investor, the 44-year-old Mr. Heyman is w aging a bitter proxy battle against GAF's management, which he v iews as incompetent and wants to kick out.

title: WHAT'S SEXUAL EQUALITY IN A PENSION?
description: DOES it constitute illegal sex discrimination if an employer requires women to contribute more to their pensions than men because some of them will live longer than most of their male colleagues? Is it also discrimination when men and women contribute equal amounts to their pensions, but women collect smaller monthly annuity payments in retirement because of their longer life expectancy?

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: MISS AUSTIN WINS CHANCE TO HALT MISS NAVRATILOVA
description: Tracy Austin's exuberance could not be dampened by the light rain that fell most of today, or having had to finish one match and immediately begin another. Having to play again meant she was winning, and the feeling was one she has not experienced too often this year.

title: Upper Harlem Council From Grass Roots
description: The article, ''Resilient Commuters Cope and Adapt'' (March 13) incorrectly referred to the Metro-North Commuter Council as the successor to the Upper Harlem Line Commuter Council.

title: WHEN YOU DON'T HEAR THE DOORBELL, IMPROVE THE SYSTEM
description: ALTHOUGH one centrally located doorbell or door chime is usually adequate for the average house, in many homes there are occasions when a person is working in the basement or out in the garage and will not hear the doorbell or chime ringing when someone is at the front or back door.

title: Twice Burned
description: A budding herpitologist got a crash course in snake handling last week when he was bitten by a stolen Gaboon viper.

title: Porcelain
description: To the Editor:

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: BEFORE THE REVOLUTION: A View of Russia Under the Last Tsar. By Kyril Fitzlyon and Tatiana Browning. (The Overlook Press, $8.95.) Raymond A. Sokolov's 1979 review suggested that readers ignore Kyril Fitzlyon's text (a ''thinly veiled apology for a despotic way of life'' with overtones of anti-Semitism) and concentrate on the extraordinarily eloquent photographs collected by Tatiana Browning, which cover all aspects of Russian life from 1894 to 1917 and ''accumulate into a portrait of an incredibly diverse and backward empire ... on the verge of immense and ineluctable change.'' Above: two boys from a cadet school out picking mushrooms. TAR BABY. By Toni Morrison. (NAL/Signet, $3.95.) The central characters in Toni Morrison's fourth and most ambitious novel include a wealthy white candy manufacturer now living out his days on a Caribbean island, the former beauty queen who is his wife, and the black couple who serve them as cook and butler. Our reviewer, John Irving, commended the book's subtle but powerful presentation of the tension between blacks and whites but said that ''Tar Baby'' rises above social realism: Miss Morrison mythologizes her characters and, with the good novelist's sense of detail, makes her mythic people live.

title: Gym Title to Nebraska
description: Scott Johnson scored 58.70 in six events today to lead Nebraska to its fifth consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association gymnastics championship.

title: THE PAST SEEN IN A WORLD OF MAPS
description: For eccentric charm and historic patina few purchasable antiques rival early maps. Even if you cannot tell Mercator's projection from anyone else's, you can appreciate these oddly distorted but touchingly sincere portraits of the earth as viewed from another age. Once-imagined islands, extinct peoples and lost cities from the New World to Chinese Tartary reappear in vividly colored engravings, embellished with trumpeting cherubs and snorting sea monsters.

title: SHUTTLE WON'T SOON CARRY ITS OWN FINANCIAL WEIGHT
description: If engineering is the craft of making things work, then the space shuttle is one of the profession's great achievements. But last week's voyage of the new shuttle Challenger was the latest reminder that engineering should also be the art of working frugally.

title: Mondale Leads Glenn In Nationwide Survey
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale retains a strong lead over Senator John Glenn of Ohio as the choice of Democrats for their 1984 Presidential nomination, according to a nationwide Gallup Poll.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Many-Splendored Baseball Books

title: CARDINALS HAND METS FIRST DEFEAT, 5-0
description: Five St. Louis hits in the seventh innings were turned into as many runs and the Mets lost, 5-0, yesterday at Shea Stadium for their first defeat in three games.

title: SUMMER PLACES AROUND THE WORLD
description: Suggestions for holidaymakers from all parts of the globe: Foreign correspondents of The New York Times were asked to select a favorite vacation spot in their part of the world. Here are 14 of their choices, ranging from some of the familiar pleasures of Europe to the more exotic outposts of Asia and Africa. The delights of Rome in August (despite the trash and traffic) and an unlikely oasis of luxury (with a French accent) in Cameroon are merely the beginning.

title: Lemons Back at Old Job
description: Speculation that Abe Lemons might return as basketball coach at Oklahoma City University ended yesterday when he took the job, replacing Lonnie Nichols, who was dismissed after a 4-22 season. Lemons served as assistant athletic director at Texas last season, after having been dismissed as the Longhorn coach.

title: Nicaraguan Insurgents Claim 16 Government Troops Killed
description: Nicaraguan rebels fighting to overthrow the Sandinist Government said today that they killed 16 soldiers in the province of Nueva Segovia, on the border with Honduras.

title: REPLIES TO 'TOMORROW, A JOB': CHOICES OR NO CHOICE AT ALL
description: SO you think you want to go to work? So did I. At a 10-minute training session for my first job, I was told: ''Stand in front of the display, look pretty, and let the product speak for itself.''

title: Dr. Jane Cagan Marries
description: Dr. Jane Lynn Cagan, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Charity Hospital in New Orleans, and Bruce A. Miller, an estate tax attorney with the Internal Revenue Service in New Orleans, were married yesterday. Rabbi Murray Blackman performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai in New Orleans. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Cagan of Whitestone, Queens. Mr. Miller is the son of Julie G. Miller of New Orleans and the late Harold Miller of New York.

title: LATIN PLAN FOR A PEACE PARLEY EXCLUDING U.S. IS POSTPONED
description: A projected meeting of Latin American nations to discuss the widening conflict in Central America has been postponed indefinitely, according to diplomats here.

title: Laser Scientist Calls Reagan Plan Impractical
description: An expert on lasers and missiles says that President Reagan's proposal for space-based laser defenses against missiles may be a waste of money, but that Mr. Reagan is on the right track in wanting to share its secrets with the Soviet Union if it is ever built.

title: What's in a Baseball?
description: The argument about rabbit baseballs has popped up again. This time it is involved in an antitrust suit over who has the right to sell baseballs labeled ''official'' for the two major leagues. In 1976-77 the Rawlings Sporting Goods Company outbid three other manufacturers for an exclusive 10-year contract to sell balls to all 26 clubs. As the result of its right to label its product ''official,'' Rawlings also dominates the market in all levels of baseball, from Little League through college ball. Altogether, the sale of about 1 million dozen balls is at issue.

title: PARTIAL FAILURES BY SIX REACTORS CITED IN INQUIRY
description: An investigation by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission into the reliability of automatic shutdown systems has found that six reactors around the country have experienced partial failures but did not report them.

title: BRUINS WIN AND CLINCH SERIES
description: Luc Dufour scored on a breakaway at 12 minutes 2 seconds of the final period, enabling the Boston Bruins to clinch the Adams Division playoff series with a 2-1 victory over the Quebec Nordiques tonight.

title: PRIVATE CLUBS: BUSINESS IN THE 'LIVING ROOM'
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTI-P.L.O. FACTION SAYS IT KILLED PALESTINIAN
description: The Revolutionary Council of the Fatah, a Palestinian faction opposed to the Palestine Liberation Organization, issued a statement here today taking responsibility for the slaying of a Palestinian moderate in Portugal.

title: EPTON WITHDRAWS FROM TV PROGRAM
description: Bernard E. Epton, the Republican mayoral candidate, backed out of a scheduled appearance on NBC News's ''Meet The Press'' today because of his objections to one of the program's panelists.

title: THOMSON MCKINNON VENTURE
description: Thomson McKinnon Inc., though among the nation's 20 largest brokerage concerns, makes little noise on Wall Street. Competitors and analysts most often describe the company as reserved and conservative - ''the traditional wire house,'' said one.

title: NOVICE RIDER TAKES A TURN IN A TANDEM
description: The 65-foot-long double-trailer trucking rig made a graceful U-turn on a two-lane road here. ''A routine maneuver you couldn't do with a single trailer,'' proclaimed the driver, James H. Shores, who is 50 years old and whose accident-free lifetime mileage log is equal to 40 circumferences of the earth.

title: GO-IT-ALONE QUEBECOIS FIND ALLIES IN THE WALLOONS
description: The political leaders of Quebec, who often try to advance their hopes for independence by acting as if they constitute a sovereign and national government, scored a victory in their minidiplomacy this month.

title: MUSIC: ROSEN AT CARNEGIE
description: A SMALL audience on a wet afternoon heard two exceptional hours of piano music played by Charles Rosen at Carnegie Hall on Sunday. It was a symmetrical kind of program, with Elliott Carter's ''Night Fantasies'' standing at its center and music by Chopin and Schumann placed around it.

title: Nakasone's Party Defeated in 2 Races
description: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party was stung by two major defeats in gubernatorial races but cemented its control over the nation's local governments in elections Sunday.

title: MISS NAVRATILOVA 3-SET VICTOR IN FINAL
description: For the time being, the talk will have to remain just talk. Despite rumblings that Martina Navratilova could be beaten here on the claylike surface that is supposedly her weakest, she continued her mastery of the tennis tour by winning the final of the Family Circle Magazine Cup from Tracy Austin today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Diagnostics Corp., Newport Beach, Calif., has named William B. Adams president, succeeding Ronald H. Coelyn, who resigned.

title: RANGERS TURN BACK RED SOX
description: The Rangers, after trailing by seven runs, scored a 9-7 victory today over the Boston Red Sox. It was the fifth victory in six games for Texas. With the game tied at 7-7, the Rangers' Buddy Bell led off the eighth with a single off Bob Stanley and moved to second on Jim Sundberg's grounder. Stanley walked George Wright intentionally, but Bill Stein, a pinch-hitter, lined a two-out single for the go-ahead run. Mickey Rivers followed with a single that scored Wright.

title: POWER TO THE INVENTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Postings in yesterday's Real Estate section misstated the starting time of a conference tomorrow on back-office space in New York City. The conference begins at 6 P.M.

title: METHOD USED TO TAKE POLL
description: The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Feb. 7 through 12 with 1,503 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball

title: Sheryl Lynn Farber Wed To Robert Lee Magaziner
description: At Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I., yesterday Sheryl Lynn Farber and Robert Lee Magaziner, graduates of Union College, were married by Rabbis Robert Kirzner and David Wice.

title: Build on the Port Authority's Success
description: When a private business finds itself capable of making large amounts of money, it maximizes its income and pays out any surpluses to its owners. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has no owners in the conventional sense, but the two states that originated it, and their local governments, have been wondering how they can best put the well-managed authority's money-making potential to work for the port area.

title: Nontraditional Offering
description: Traditionally enough, Sunday's offering went to the altar to the strains of ''Praise God from whom all blessings flow.'' But, amid the money and pledge envelopes, the collection plates held a surprising number of subway tokens.

title: BRAZILIAN CONDEMNS LIBERALIZATION FOES
description: The riots over unemployment that convulsed Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest city, last week were denounced tonight by President Joao Baptista Figueiredo as the work of enemies of the country's political liberalization.

title: Irving Bicentennial Show
description: ''The Sage of Sunnyside: A Washington Irving Bicentennial Celebration, 1783-1983'' can be seen through May 1 at the New-York Historcial Society, 170 Central Park West, at 76th Street.

title: SYNTHETIC FUELS PLANT SEES LOSS
description: The country's leading synthetic fuels plant is projecting losses for its first decade of $773 million, raising the possibility that more Government aid will be needed to keep it going.

title: Photographs of Chinatown
description: New York's Chinatown, its people, streets and work places, forms the subject of an exhibition by Paul Calhoun and Robert Glick, photographers and researchers for the New York Chinatown History Project, which can be seen until April 17 at the Louis Abrons Arts for Living Center of the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street.

title: Schlichter's Father Appeals for Him
description: The father of Art Schlichter, the Baltimore Colt quarterback, asked sympathy for his son who reportedly gambled away $389,000, then turned to the Federal Bureau of Investication when he could not repay loans.

title: THEATER: IN MCBRIDE'S 'ELBA,' THE EXILES ARE THE ELDERLY COUPLE
description: IN Vaughn McBride's ''Elba,'' the new play at the Manhattan Theater Club, it's not Napoleon who's in exile but a pair of elderly Americans. Mr. McBride's hero and heroine, Don (James Whitmore) and Flo (Audra Lindley), have returned to their deserted old ranch house in Elba, Idaho, shortly after escaping by laundry truck from a nursing home where their middle-aged children had sent them to die. Though two of their three daughters soon follow them, hoping to coerce Don and Flo back to their final resting place, the fugitive couple won't give up their freedom without a fight.

title: KNICKS BEATEN BY 76ERS
description: The Knicks' playoff hopes ran into one of Andrew Toney's best shooting performances of the season today, and it hurt.

title: Washington Watch; New Patterns On Gas Prices
description: WITH the Senate Energy Committee expected to sit down this week to try to reach agreement on natural gas legislation, the Administration seems to have lost some crucial support for its bill leading to full price decontrol in 1986.

title: Below the Rim
description: Comparisons with men's college basketball are beside the point: the women's game can stand on its own. Aside from providing an excellent show, the recent national tournament of women's college basketball seemed to show that the sport had acquired an audience and had a future. Although their game is not as physical as the men's, the women can shoot, handle the ball and play defense. They have exciting players like Cheryl Miller of Southern California and Kim Mulkey of Louisiana Tech.

title: Bridge: New Yorkers Finish Tour Of New Zealand Unbeaten
description: The Precision team of New York experts headed by Kathie Wei ended its tour of New Zealand here Sunday night with an unbeaten record that had seemed in danger twice during the day.

title: CUOMO ASSAILS EFFORTS TO THWART NEW TAXES
description: Governor Cuomo criticized major oil companies and the real estate industry yesterday for ''arrogance'' for announcing plans to resist new state taxes imposed on them last month.

title: GLEMP MASS MARKS UPRISING IN GHETTO
description: Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, officiated today at a mass honoring the Jewish fighters of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising.

title: WARNING: DANGER IN SPACE
description: A small group of people, including some top experts on space war, just finished a conference near here on the military use of space.

title: Lynn E. Harrison Weds
description: Lynn Ellen Harrison, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Harrison of Douglaston, Queens, was married there yesterday to Louis Richard Cappelli, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luca A. Cappelli of Yonkers. The Rev. John H. Meyer performed the ceremony at the Community Dutch Reform Church. The bride is a producer at Compton Advertising in New York. Mr. Cappelli is executive vice president of the Saturn Construction Corporation in White Plains.

title: A HANDFUL OF NEW CORPORATE ISSUES
description: Although last week's hefty supply of new corporate bonds was readily absorbed by investors, the success of those financings does not seem to have attracted more corporate borrowers.

title: VIETNAM'S TROOPS SAID TO THROW GRENADES AT CAMBODIAN CIVILIANS
description: Vietnamese soldiers herded Cambodian civilians into bunkers last week and threw hand grenades at them, according to Cambodians who said they had been victims or witnesses of such attacks.

title: SPECIAL RELATIONSHIP OF WOMEN AND THEIR MENTORS
description: Nancy W. Collins is a businesswoman who has had three mentors. Without them, she says, she would never be where she is today: assistant to the president of the Palo Alto Medical Foundation, a 550-employee medical center in California.

title: Needham, Harper Gets C & C Cola Account
description: Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, has become agency for C & C Cola as Shasta Beverages, owner of C & C for a year, consolidates all of its products at one agency.

title: Frazier Beats Broad On Close Decision
description: Marvis Frazier, told by his father to ''go out there and take back your name,'' made a heavyweight name for himself today by upsetting James Broad in a 10-round bout between undefeated prospects.

title: Brenda Wilkin Marries Barry Fallis, Developer
description: The marriage of Brenda L. Wilkin, acting director for the national new leadership division of Israel Bonds, to Barry E. Fallis, president of Britton Development Ltd., a New York real-estate development company, took place in Manhattan yesterday. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman performed the ceremony at a private town house.

title: Hot Dogs, Hot Snakes; Bad Business
description: Are Atlantic City's casinos good for business? They sure are if you're a hot dog vendor. Hungry tourists down about $3 million worth of frankfurters a year, and a vendor with a good spot near a casino entrance can do $1,000 worth of business a day.

title: The U.N. Today; April 11, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: STRANGER'S STARE: BALEFUL OR BECKONING?
description: They were strangers on a train, two travelers who found themselves sitting across the car from each other. By chance, their eyes met. But instead of quickly looking away, they held each other's gaze. The glance became a fixed mutual stare, as the seconds ticked by. What happened then?

title: Newspaper Says E.P.A.  Concealed Forest Report
description: The Environmental Protection Agency suppressed for a year a study that indicated phosphate mining in the Osceola National Forest would cause irreparable damage, a newspaper reported today.

title: Remembering Warsaw
description: Beneath Temple Emanu-El's jewel-blue window facing Fifth Avenue, a gallery banner promised, ''We shall never forget our six million Jewish martyrs.'' Candles blazed at the altar opposite, where Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch joined Holocaust survivors and Jewish leaders yesterday to commemorate the 40th anniversary of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Gambling, and Losing, on Defense
description: Castigating the Russians' ''evil empire'' and fantasizing about a futuristic antimissile system have so far failed to win for Mr. Reagan the centerpiece of his defense policy - a 10 percent real increase in military spending.

title: U.S. STILL FAVORS LATIN PEACE TALKS
description: A State Department spokesman said today that the United States still believed that talks among nations in the Central American region ''offer the best possibility to resolve the problems of the area.''

title: GENERALS LOSE 5TH TIME, 21-6
description: Botched opportunities, turnovers and general malfeasance again afflicted the New Jersey Generals today as they lost their fifth game of six. The Michigan Panthers won, 21-6, at Giants Stadium in relentless rain before the Generals' smallest crowd in three home games - 17,648.

title: Amelia W. Trippe, Banker, Wed to Thomas G. Brophy
description: Amelia Whitfield Trippe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Richard Trippe of Montclair, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas Gerald Brophy, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Brophy of Rumson, N.J.

title: FLYER BRAWN OFFSET BY RANGERS' SKILL
description: The Rangers had just completed their most astonishing playoff conquest since they upset the Islanders in the Stanley Cup semifinals in 1979, yet their locker room was not bubbling with glee.

title: SCHOOL ALL-STAR GAMES GIVE MANY ASSISTS
description: IT was early in the week, but inside the Omni, where the 25 members of the McDonald's All-America Basketball Team were scrimmaging in preparation for Saturday's all-star game, there was the feeling of a prayer meeting. A congregation of 65 coaches, scattered throughout the arena, legs crossed, arms folded in the reddish-orange spectator's seats, watched as player after player executed a maneuver.

title: Sonics 102, Blazers 93
description: Gus Williams scored 28 points and helped launch a second-half surge that lifted Seattle to the victory over struggling Portland.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN'S REMARKS ON MIDEAST
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's remarks on the Middle East today and an exchange with reporters:

title: 10,000 Seek 46 Jobs At a Buffalo Plant
description: About 10,000 job seekers showed up this weekend at the Anaconda American Brass plant here to apply for openings for 26 skilled craftsmen and 20 production workers, company officials said.

title: ISRAELIS REACT WITH CALM TO HUSSEIN DECISION
description: Israeli officials reacted with calm and nonchalance today to the news that King Hussein had abandoned his talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization and would not enter negotiations with Israel on the future of the occupied West Bank.

title: Cat Food Mislabeled as Tuna
description: Cat food was accidentally put in cans sold to supermarkets as Chicken of the Sea tuna, and the Ralston Purina Company has pulled the suspect product from store shelves. Company spokesmen said that 150 cans, mislabeled in the San Diego plant, were shipped only to markets here and in Boise, Idaho, and that it was possible some had been purchased by consumers.

title: LAST MINUTE PUSH FOR I.R.A.'S
description: With only five days remaining before the deadline for filing Federal personal income tax returns, financial institutions in New York City and around the country are reporting a last-minute surge in depositors opening Individual Retirement Accounts to qualify for a deduction on 1982 taxes.

title: Meryl Ilene Stone and Dr. Reed Stone Are Married
description: At Temple Beth Sholom in Fair Lawn, N.J., yesterday Meryl Ilene Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Stone of West Brighton, S.I., was married to Dr. Reed Stone, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Stone of Brooklyn. The families are not related.

title: Iran Offers to Cooperate In Containing Oil Slick
description: Iran said today it was ready to cooperate with efforts to contain a huge oil slick caused by leaking Iranian wells in the Persian Gulf.

title: MASTERPIECE OF A HOME FOR A BUILDING MUSEUM
description: One of this city's architectural masterpieces, the century-old Pension Building, is being transformed into a national museum of architecture, with the refurbished structure itself billed as the star exhibit.

title: GOLD-MINING BOOM IN SOVIET FORECAST
description: The Soviet Union is on the brink of a major gold mining expansion that could result in its overtaking South Africa as the world's leading gold producer in the 1990's, significantly increasing its hard currency earnings, according to a new study presented at an economic conference here of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Rolls Cuts Thousands From Car Prices
description: Citing increasing pressure against the weakened British pound, Rolls-Royce Motors Ltd. yesterday announced what may be the biggest price cut on any consumer product in history, slicing $18,000 from its least expensive model and making similar cuts on its full line of cars sold in the United States.

title: Guilty as Not Charged
description: The State Commission on Judicial Conduct had little choice but to rule that Alan Friess, the Manhattan judge who did so many bizarre things in only three and a half years on the Criminal Court bench, should be removed permanently from judicial office. But the commission needlessly found him guilty of a separate, uncharged offense: stubborn insistence on defending himself.

title: HELEN STERN RICHARDS
description: Helen Stern Richards, a Broadway publicity agent and manager, died Saturday of complications following lung surgery at New York Hospital.

title: SAYS P.L.O. BROKE AN ACCORD; PALESTINIAN MODERATE SLAIN; Text of the statement, page A12
description: Jordan said today that it had failed to reach an agreement with the Palestine Liberation Organization and would not enter American-sponsored peace talks on the basis of a plan proposed by President Reagan.

title: WEAK YEN HURTS TRADE TIES
description: Over the past year and a half, the behavior of the yen in the foreign exchange markets has confounded the experts. At the end of 1981, leading economic research organizations and banks, inside and outside Japan, forecast that the yen would strengthen in 1982, to about 205 yen to the American dollar.

title: THEATER: NEW MUSICAL ABOUT COLETTE
description: FOR more than 12 years, Tom Jones and Harvey Schmidt, who wrote ''The Fantasticks,'' ''110 in the Shade'' and ''I Do! I Do!'' have been trying to build a musical around the life of Colette, the French author who wrote, among other things, ''Gigi.''

title: Directors of Dome To Seek New Chief
description: When John P. Gallagher, a founder of Canada's giant Dome Petroleum Ltd., announced last Friday that he was quitting as chief executive officer, it came as no surprise to officials of the financially troubled company; the move had been expected for months.

title: Jury Reconvening In N.F.L. Case
description: A jury resumes deliberations Monday in the damage phase of the antitrust suit successfully brought by the Los Angeles Coliseum and the Los Angeles Raiders against the National Football League.

title: Train Crash in Hungary
description: The Pushkin express train crashed into a stationary freight train near Cegled, 40 miles southeast of Budapest, killing the express train's engineer and injuring five people.

title: STOUFFER APPEAL AWAITED CALMLY BY FREED WAITER
description: Soon after Luis Marin was convicted last year of arson and 26 counts of murder in the Stouffer's Inn fire, and then set free by a Westchester judge, he got a job at a garden supply store in Larchmont.

title: SANTA ANITA DERBY WON BY 7-2 MARFA
description: Barry Beal and Bob French Jr. once dreamed of seeing their green and white dotted silks carried to victory in the Santa Anita Derby and the Kentucky Derby by the brilliant filly Landaluce. They stopped dreaming, and stopped going to the races altogether, when Landaluce died of a viral infection last November.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A player on Team A in a National Basketball Association game throws a long pass to a teammate near the basket. While the ball is in flight, the buzzer sounds, ending the period. The teammate catches the ball in midair and dunks it into the basket. Does the field goal count?

title: Truman's Racial Ideas Changed, Letters Show
description: Harry S. Truman gained a reputation for advancements in civil rights as President, but racial slurs are scattered through letters he wrote as a young man.

title: Mets Send Rajsich to Minors
description: A dismal, drippy day washed out the scheduled doubleheader with the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday and gave the management of the Mets a chance to do a little house-cleaning.

title: Slow Dance Into Retirement
description: On Saturday she was at the Roseland ballroom for her regular weekend treat. But this week 86-year-old Ellen Mitchell will no longer be in her 32d-floor office - her desk piled with stock market reference books, computer cards and daily quotation sheets.

title: Advertising; Agencies Add TV Production
description: THE announcement in late March that Lorimar, the big West Coast production company, had acquired the Kenyon & Eckhardt advertising agency, and all the attendant discussions of the benefits of such a marriage, must have been of special interest to dwellers within Benton & Bowles.

title: GRADING THE SCHOOLS
description: Most Americans seem willing to pay higher taxes to improve the public schools, according to a New York Times national poll. By large majorities, the poll showed, the public says it believes that the schools need more emphasis on science and mathematics, on developing job skills and on basic reading, writing and arithmetic. The poll of 1,503 adults found that, to get that those improvements, 81 percent said they were prepared to pay higher taxes and 51 percent said they would pay as much as $200 more a year. Younger, wealthier and more educated people, and those with children in school, were most likely to say they would pay $200 more.

title: NEW YORK AREA SOAKED ON 6TH WEEKEND IN ROW
description: For the sixth weekend in a row, the New York metropolitan area got rain. And the rain yesterday was a heavy, soaking rain that made umbrellas more of a psychological than a practical aid, that turned front lawns into swamps, basements into pools and subway stations into dripping caves.

title: CHINA ASSAILS REAGAN ON DEFECTOR
description: China attacked President Reagan personally today for the decision to grant political asylum to the tennis player Hu Na.

title: SAYS P.L.O. BROKE AN ACCORD; PALESTINIAN MODERATE SLAIN
description: President Reagan said today that Jordan's apparent refusal to join any Middle East negotiations was ''an impediment'' in the search for a Middle East peace. But he said he remained ''very hopeful'' that progress could still be achieved on the basis of his seven-month old initiative.

title: WHEN A NATIONAL BANK WANTS TO BE MORE
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Is Said to Name New Envoy to the U.S.
description: The Cabinet today nominated Meir Rosenne, a veteran diplomat now serving as Ambassador to France, to be Israel's next Ambassador to Washington, Israeli officials reported.

title: Firefighter Killed In Yonkers Blaze
description: A blaze swept through a six-story apartment building today, killing one firefighter and injuring 25 people. Fire departments from four nearby communities helped city crews fight the blaze in heavy rain at the 150-unit building.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE OTHER MAN. Conversations with Graham Greene. By Marie-Fran,coise Allain. Translated from the French by Guido Waldman. 176 pages. Simon and Schuster. $13.95. ASKED why he continues to write, Graham Greene gives a reply that makes him sound very much like one of his own afflicted heroes: ''A neurosis brought on by habit rather than by despair, an irresistible urge to pinch the abscess which grows periodically in order to squeeze out all the pus.'' He goes on to point out that he has been ''a bad husband and a fickle lover,'' that he ''can't remember ever having been at peace with myself, except for brief spells,'' that he has ''inherited some bad genes.'' He is loath to probe too deeply into the workings of his unconscious, worrying that such probing might somehow damage the magic of creativity; and he so dislikes reviewing his past that he keeps his old books locked up in a cupboard instead of displayed in a bookcase. Indeed, the portrait of Mr. Greene that emerges from this series of interviews - cautious, weary, and blessed with a prankster's sense of humor - is very similar to the one left in the wake of his novels.

title: A Boston Agency Tries To Lure New Yorkers
description: Oh how easy it is to buy a fellow's loyalty. Remember Wilson A. Seibert Jr., who was nice enough to be known as Bill in the old days as senior vice president responsible for the creative product worldwide of the giant J. Walter Thompson Company? He was based in New York and was one of your better Big Apple polishers, a real friend of Gotham.

title: 3,500 FLEE FLOODS NEAR NEW ORLEANS
description: Residents of low-lying areas near this New Orleans suburb packed sandbags and cleared out belongings today as the Pearl River, engorged by days of rain, crept past record flood levels.

title: Hot Dogs, Hot Snakes; The Power of Plastic
description: People who used to brownbag their lunch are now apt to plasticsack it. We plasticsack books, too, and used kitty litter, and, should a sudden downpour surprise us, we plasticsack our feet.

title: TOWARD '84 AND AWAY FROM REAGAN
description: Last Thursday morning, many of the 19 Republican Senators who are up for re-election next year met for breakfast with a delegation of senior White House officials and exchanged ideas and perspectives about the impending campaign.

title: MILITARY COMPUTER-PROGRAM SUCCESS
description: Computer scientists at New York University have produced the first successful version of a key program needed by the Defense Department to develop a standard computer language for the military.

title: LESTER CRYSTAL, THE MAN WHO'S CHANGING 'THE MacNEIL-LEHRER REPORT'
description: ''Bringing in a new producer'' can be televisionese for ''We're going to try to rescue this dog.'' Lester M. Crystal, a former president of NBC News, has been brought in to take over ''The MacNeil-Lehrer Report.'' But ''MacNeil-Lehrer'' is doing very well. It is the most-watched regular evening show on public television. It needs no rescue.

title: Ex-Rowe Price Officer Heads Rockefeller & Co.
description: The Rockefellers have a new source of investment advice. He is Thomas C. Barry, 39, former president and director of T. Rowe Price's New Horizons Fund, and recently named president and chief executive officer of Rockefeller & Company.

title: TV: A CAPITALIST-WORKER 'SIEGFRIED'
description: TONIGHT is Academy Awards time, and the annual pageant being carried on Channel 7 at 9 will undoubtedly register the blockbuster ratings to which it has become accustomed. Recognizing their helplessness in the face of seemingly irresistible glitter, the competing channels traditionally resort to throwaways. It is significant, then, that public television, in its increasingly curious wisdom, has chosen to use the evening to offer the next installment of Richard Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle.

title: TV: PRIVATE LIVES vs. A PUBLIC PRESS
description: CBS NEWS makes a brave attempt to define the indefinable tonight. In its second ''Eye on the Media'' seminar, it gathers together some bright, feisty people, seats them at conference tables and sets loose a Harvard law professor to stir them up. The seminar is called ''Private Lives, Public Press,'' and the participants discuss the individual's right to privacy, which is sometimes opposed to journalism's right - or at least, wish - to know. In theory, a line must be drawn someplace; in practice, hardly anyone knows where. The program may be seen on Channel 2 at 10.

title: FLOYD AND STADLER LEAD IN MASTERS
description: Four of golf's longest hitters, Ray Floyd, Craig Stadler, Seve Ballesteros and Tom Watson, each of whom has won a Masters tournament, moved their heavy artillery into position for Monday's final-round shootout in the 47th Masters.

title: HISPANIC VOTE SEEN AS A KEY IN CHICAGO MAYORAL RACE
description: With blacks and whites sharply divided largely along racial lines, the city's Hispanic vote has taken on added significance as the hotly contested mayoral campaign enters the home stretch.

title: N.J. TRANSIT'S RIDERS SLOW IN RETURNING TO TRAINS
description: A week after the end of the 34-day strike against N.J. Transit's nine rail lines, the number of riders has not returned to prestrike levels, a spokesman for the New Jersey agency said yesterday.

title: A BUDGET INCREASE FOR CITY'S SCHOOLS IS SEEN BY WAGNER
description: The Board of Education will get as much as $150 million more than expected for the next school year, Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. said yesterday.

title: INDIAN LAND CONFLICT REKINDLED IN CONNECTICUT
description: It has been more than three centuries since the Pequot Indians so dominated this region that the first white colonists named the river here the Pequot and their settlement Pequot Town.

title: OPERA: 'FALSE MESSIAH' BY BRUCE ADOLPHE AT Y
description: BRUCE ADOLPHE'S ''False Messiah'' - which was given for the first time Saturday night at the 92d Street Y -recounts an episode in Jewish history as bizarre as it was prophetic. Mr. Adolphe's opera centers on a Turkish rabbi living in the middle of the 17th century and describes his rise and fall and the world he turned nearly upside down.

title: WAGNER'S JOB TO BE SPLIT BY THE 2 OTHER DEPUTIES
description: Mayor Koch, who started out his mayoralty with seven deputy mayors -so many that he could not find City Hall office space for all of them - says he will cut back to two with the departure of Robert F. Wagner Jr., who was selected Saturday as Schools Chancellor.

title: Jess Neely, Coached Football for 40 Years
description: Jess Neely, who compiled 207 victories in 40 years of college-football coaching, died Saturday night. He was 85 years old.

title: SPORTSWEAR MAKES CITY A WORLD FASHION LEADER
description: Fashion traffic between New York and Europe used to be strictly one way. Retailers, designers, manufacturers and private customers from the United States would cross the Atlantic to buy clothes in Paris, and to a lesser extent London or Rome. They would then copy them, sell them or wear them.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: *Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rate chart.

title: GENERIC ADS ON TV PROMOTING LAWYERS
description: Thanks to television advertising, Norton Frickey has become a household name in Denver. And if Mr. Frickey's ads work as well in New York as they do in Denver and 90 other cities across the country, Herbert Nason and Israel Cohen will soon be household names here.

title: Index; International
description: Go-it-alone Quebecois find allies in the Walloons A2 Brazilian says foes of liberalization were behind riots A3 U.S. sees Latin talks as best route to peace A3 Around the World A4 Glemp leads mass honoring Jewish fighters of Warsaw Ghetto A6 China accuses Vietnam of stepping up raids across border A8 Anti-P.L.O. faction says it killed Palestinian in Portugal A11 Text of Jordan statement on refusing to join peace plan A12 Government/Politics A trucker demonstrates a double- trailer rig A14 New York Legislature to face key issues as it reconvenes B1 Washington Talk Congress: Heavy weather for Republicans facing re-election A16 A museum whose building is the star of the collection A16 The Calendar A16 Briefing A16 Energy Investigation cites partial failures of six nuclear reactors B2 General Around the Nation A14 United States and Britain compared at forum in Boston A18 New York City area endures sixth straight sodden weekend B1 Colleges finding financial benefit in campus video-game arcades B1 Gov. Cuomo denounces oil companies and real estate interests B2 Sportswear puts New York on the world fashion map B3 N.J. Transit riders slow in returning to trains after strike B3 Defendant is relaxed as appeal is made in Stouffer's fire B3 SportsMonday Baseball: How the Yankees' payroll breaks down C1

title: 'Agonizing With Arnie'
description: WHEN he awoke about 6 o'clock yesterday, Arnold Palmer was only four strokes out of the Masters lead. But at 8:30 he had to go out to the 18th tee to finish his second round, which had been halted Saturday by darkness. After a good drive, he put a 3 iron into the left bunker. Bogey. With a 74 for 142, he suddenly had dropped five strokes out of the lead. Soon he returned to his rented home but he didn't drink two quarts of water with breakfast as he usually does.

title: REP. PHILLIP BURTON, DEMOCRATIC LIBERAL, DIES ON VISIT TO CALIFORNIA
description: Representative Phillip Burton, an important figure among Democratic liberals in the House of Representatives, died here early today a few hours after being stricken in his hotel room on a visit to his Congressional district. He was 56 years old.

title: Chrysler Trims Finance Rate
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it is offering rebates or 9.8 percent financing on certain 1982 and 1983 models to replace the 11.9 percent financing promotion that expired today.

title: COLLEGES FINDING VIDEO GAMES A MIXED, BUT PROFITABLE, BLESSING
description: An 18-year-old computer-science major at Queens College grimaced as her last Pac-Man was gobbled up by ghosts. Around her, other video games warbled, gurgled and beeped.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN COMPARED AT BOSTON FORUM
description: Just as Americans have taken to ''the intensely English nonsense'' of Monty Python, one in four adults in England watches ''Dallas'' every week, a prominent British historian said at a symposium at Boston University this weekend.

title: Gant Captures Darlington Race
description: Harry Gant charged past Darrell Waltrip with two laps remaining today in the TranSouth 500 at Darlington International Raceway and held on to post a Nascar Grand National victory.

title: Commodities; Success Of C.B.O.E.  100 Option
description: IN its first four weeks of trading the C.B.O.E. 100 option has not only become the most active of all stock index options, but it has also helped buoy the index options futures markets on other exchanges.

title: SENATE SET TO RESUME TAX FIGHT
description: The Senate is expected later this week to tackle again the delicate issue of withholding on interest and dividends. But even if the Senate votes to repeal the tax measure - as is widely expected - Congressional leaders are predicting that victory may still be elusive, and that the question may not be resolved for several more months.

title: BRIEFING
description: Memos in the night

title: TEXT OF JORDAN'S STATEMENT ON ITS REFUSAL TO JOIN THE REAGAN PEACE INITIATIVE
description: Following, in official translation, is the text of a statement today by the Jordanian press agency on King Hussein's refusal to join President Reagan's peace initiative:

title: Susan Feder Wed To Todd Gordon
description: Susan Feder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Feder of White Plains, was married yesterday to Todd Gordon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin Gordon of New York. Rabbi Emily Korzenik performed the ceremony at the Manor, a mansion on the campus of Elizabeth Seton College in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: GAF GETS $140 MILLION BID FOR UNIT
description: The GAF Corporation, adding a surprise development to the proxy battle initiated by an investor, Samuel J. Heyman, announced yesterday that it had received a proposal, worth about $140 million, for the purchase of its ailing building materials group.

title: RENEWED NEGOTIATIONS FAIL TO END METRO-NORTH STRIKE
description: Negotiations to settle the strike against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad were broken off late last night, after representatives of the union and management had held their longest face-to-face bargaining since the strike began five weeks ago.

title: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION AT WORK FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT PRICE GLORY? A $72.5 MILLION PAYROLL
description: EVERY player in baseball, Bobby Murcer remarked the other day, should have the opportunity to play for the Yankees. Some players might willingly pass up the opportunity, thank you anyway, but for the most part, Murcer's fellow major leaguers would embrace his idea. The Yankees, after all, pay the best money in baseball, and money has become as integral a part of the game as the home run and the slider.

title: LEGISLATURE DUE TO ACT ON ROADS AND JOBLESS PAY
description: The State Legislature, which will reconvene in Albany tomorrow, faces a wide range of issues that were put off last month during the passage of a budget - from the rebuilding of roads and bridges to proposals to raise unemployment benefits and reorganize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: China Accuses Vietnamese Of Increasing Border Attacks
description: China accused Vietnam today of increasing incursions and provocations along their common border and warned the Hanoi Government it would suffer ''grave consequences'' if the incidents continued.

title: INFANTICIDE IN CHINA
description: According to news reports in China's dailies, during the last two years large numbers of female infants have been butchered, drowned or left to die, and numbers of women have suffered gross maltreatment as a result of nationwide implementation of the Government's population-control policy. This shocking situation, which the Government must take immediate steps to stop, deserves to be brought to the attention of the United Nations.

title: FORTIA SHARPENING ITS IMAGE
description: In 1981, Fortia AB made a name for itself as the first Swedish company to issue shares in the United States. This year, the rapidly growing pharmaceutical and biotechnology company decided that, unfortunately, it was the wrong name.

title: U.S. FISCAL POLICY WATCHED
description: When Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, testifies before the House Banking Committee tomorrow, he is likely to repeat often-made statements that monetary policy alone cannot guide the economy to a sustained noninflationary recovery. Rather, the Government's decisions on spending and taxation - its fiscal policy - must also be directed to the same goals.

title: SHUTTLE'S 'CLEAN' SHAPE BUOYS NASA HOPES FOR JUNE FLIGHT
description: The space shuttle Challenger withstood its five-day maiden flight in such ''clean'' condition that project officials today expressed confidence that the spaceship should be ready for its next mission in June.

title: OZYMONDIAS O'NEILL
description: I met a traveller from an antique land Who said: 'Two vast and trunkless legs of stone Stand in the desert. Near them, on the sand, Half sunk, a shattered visage lies ...

title: James Scott Lief Wed To Cathy Lynn Berson
description: The marriage of Cathy Lynn Berson, an associate in the option department of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., to James Scott Lief, a stockbroker on the American Stock Exchange, took place yesterday at the Helmsley Palace Hotel. Rabbi Lennard Thal performed the ceremony.

title: Celtics 115, Pistons 113
description: Boston's Tiny Archibald, coming off the bench after missing nearly seven games because of an injury to his left hand, scored 14 points and helped thwart a Detroit second-half comeback. Bucks 121, Bulls 91

title: A 'PROTECTIVE ORDER' THAT ALL BUT PROTECTS
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: THE ASIAN AMERICAN AND LYRIC ENSEMBLES
description: ELEANOR S. YUNG'S dances bear the influence of her training in Chinese dance, classical ballet and American modern dance. In her signature work, ''Passage'' - an intricate, minimalist piece performed by Miss Yung's Asian American Dance Theater on Saturday afternoon at the Theater of the Riverside Church - the choreographer achieves a mesmerizing blend. Her ''Crystal Rainbow'' hinted at layers of memory in the mind, perhaps, of an Asian emigrant. Too often, however, the dances were listless, despite their intelligence and craft.

title: Big Day For Cycling
description: A COMPANY of invaders, many of them elite troops airlifted from Europe, rolled into Washington yesterday and captivated a waiting crowd just behind the White House.

title: DOUBLE-TRAILER TRUCKING PLAN STIRS AN OUTCRY IN SOME UNEXPECTED QUARTERS
description: Several Southern and Western states have surprised Administration officials by opposing a plan to allow large double-trailer trucking rigs on 181,000 miles of Federal highways.

title: Market Place; When the Dow Faces a Test
description: AT 1 P.M. Friday some money managers skipped lunch to stare at their stock quotation machines with worried frowns. The Dow Jones industrial average had slipped to 1,114.07, and the word on Wall Street was that, if this indicator closed below 1,110, stock prices would tumble. No crash, certainly, but a pretty bad crack, maybe.

title: Wife Says Mate Has Herpes And Sues Him for $100,000
description: A 31-year-old woman who says her husband gave her herpes is suing him for $100,000.

title: Whitey's Tale
description: Prices are back to normal at Michael Fishenfeld's candy and smoke shop in Greenwich Village. But Whitey, the cat, isn't, quite, despite more than $400 worth of ministrations.

title: Japan Critical Of Cycle Tariff
description: Japan has charged that a recent move by the United States to protect the last remaining American motorcycle maker from Japanese imports by raising tariffs was in violation of international trade rules.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: MESSAGES FOR SEXUAL HARASSERS
description: A NEW form of the ''Dear John'' letter is making the rounds. It is said to be the latest weapon in the battle against sexual harassment in the workplace, on college campuses, wherever it exists. Nowhere int he letter does the term ''sexual harassment'' appear, but the m essage is clear.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 11, 1983
description: The Economy

title: FROM THE DRUG DEALERS, TO THEIR NEMESIS
description: To the Editor:

title: New Products Show Up At A Brisk Pace
description: New product introductions continued to boom in March, according to the Dancer Fitzgerald Sample New Product News, which reports that there were 151 introductions in March compared with 104 in March 1982, a gain of 45.2 percent.

title: Otto J. Teegen, 83, Architect Of Major New York Projects
description: Otto John Teegen, a former architect for the State University of New York and designer of several major projects in New York City, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HELLENIC NIGHTS

title: Miss Lopez Is Winner
description: Nancy Lopez scrambled to a twoover-par 74 today, but it was good enough for her to win the $200,000 J&B Scotch Pro-Am for the second consecutive year.

title: SUPPORTING PARENTS
description: When I was a child, my mother often said something that baffled me: ''When I'm old, I don't want to be a burden on my children.'' That's odd, I thought. If my mother takes care of me now, shouldn't I take care of her when she's old?

title: PUERTO RICAN WRITERS GATHER
