description: The jury deliberating damages in the Raiders' and the Los Angeles Coliseum's antitrust case against the National Football League recessed today after failing to reach a decision in its third session. It will reconvene Wednesday.

title: N.F.L. Free Agents Stay Put
description: By the end of the 1982 National Football League season, 252 players had declared themselves free agents. Since then, 22 have re-signed with their old clubs, and 7 have retired. The only players who have changed teams are the 13 who signed with the United States Football League.

title: Bridge: Playing With a Champion Can Be Somewhat Trying
description: Many players feel that they would relish the experience of playing, just once, against a world champion. But if it came about, they might find the experience unnerving, both psychologically and technically.

title: CANANDAIGUA WINE CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
CBS Advances 13% in Quarter
description: CBS Inc. yesterday reported first-quarter net income of $17.8 million, or 60 cents a share, up 13 percent from $15.7 million, or 56 cents, a year ago. Revenues of $1.04 billion were up 6 percent from $979.4 million.

title: BREWERS BEAT BLUE JAYS ON MOLITOR HIT, 6-5
description: Paul Molitor hit a double in the eighth inning to score what proved to be the winning run as the Milwaukee Brewers scored a 6-5 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays today. Cecil Cooper and Robin Yount each drove in two runs for the Brewers.

title: Hollinshead Appointed
description: Byron Hollinshead, former president of Oxford University Press, has been named president of the American Heritage Publishing Company, which publishes books and American Heritage magazine. He replaces Paul E. Hale, who resigned.

title: RETAIL SALES WERE UP 0.3% IN MARCH
description: Sales at the retail level rose threetenths of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today. Though modest, the gain was the first since November and a strong improvement over February's revised 1.2 percent decline.

title: Drop in Treasury Rates Halts; Bullish Signs Are Ignored
description: The decline in interest rates of government securities of the last few days came to a halt yesterday, despite public indications by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that there was a deceleration in the growth of the money supply during March.

title: Man Gets 12 Years In Plot to Steal Art
description: A Florida man was sentenced to 12 years in prison today for his part in a foiled plot to steal 10 Impressionist paintings from the Hill-Stead Museum in Farmington last July and hold them for ransom, officials said.

title: CURTISS-WRIGHT CANADIAN LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $63.5 million from the sale of timber in Northern California. c-Including pretax income of $26.7 million from the sale of tax benefits.

title: Cuba Seeks Credit Conversion
description: Cuba is seeking to convert more than $200 million in interbank credit lines into short-term loans, and will discuss proposals to convert the debt on Friday with a bank steering committee led by Credit Lyonnais, banking sources said today.

title: APPLIED DATA RESEARCH INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.D.C. CHIEF STEERING AGENCY INTO NEW AREA
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation is undergoing a marked change of direction that has resulted in the most tumultuous transition of the Cuomo administration.

title: Article 096106 -- No Title
description: Prize money for the United States Open tennis championships was increased yesterday to $2,001,000, one-third more than last year's purse.

title: Baby Weighs In At Over 16 Pounds
description: A newborn baby boy who weighed in at 16 pounds, 6 ounces doesn't fit into his bassinet or his baby clothes, but he is healthy and ready to go home, his mother said today.

title: Control Data Pact
description: The Control Data Corporation of Santa Clara, Calif., said the Sperry Corporation had signed an accord to buy a 13 percent stake in Control Data's majority-owned subsidiary, Magnetic Peripherals Inc., for an undisclosed amount. Control Data said that, under the agreement, an unspecified number of employees at Sperry's information-storage systems operations in Santa Clara would become employees of Magnetic Peripherals.

title: CHINESE DISHES, AMERICAN STYLE
description: SEVERAL years ago, shortly after San Yan Wong, a recent arrival from Hong Kong, opened his Hunan Garden Restaurant on Mott Street in Chinatown, a customer came in, sat down and ordered chow mein. Mr. Wong, who is also his own head chef, remembers that he whipped up a platterful of stir-fried soft noodles covered with shredded pork, sliced bamboo shoots and bok choy, fresh water chestnuts, snow peas and Chinese black mushrooms, and sent the dish out of the kitchen. Minutes later he was called to the customer's table.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: And Now, Turkey Ham

title: Dow Advances 3.49, Closing at 1,145.32
description: Stock prices finished moderately higher yesterday after Monday's surge, with much of the interest again centered on International Business Machines, which closed at a record high for the second consecutive day.

title: NETS LOSE AS RALLY FALLS SHORT
description: The memories of what has been a very successful season for the Nets are fading fast. Tonight, they were defeated by the Boston Celtics, 99-93, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in a woeful outing. And instead of displaying eagerness to begin the playoffs - as would befit a team with a 48-31 record - they showed only tension.

title: Oil Concerns Offer Bearing Sea Bids
description: Oil companies offered $427.3 million for Federal oil and gas leases on 97 tracts in the Bering Sea.

title: WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INSIDER TRADING AND OPTIONS
description: Insider trading in options has become a sticky problem for the traders and regulators of the nation's options exchanges.

title: Another Try For Kong Today
description: The workmen who have been trying for a week to inflate a 3,000-pound vinyl-coated nylon balloon model of King Kong high on the Empire State Building plan to make another attempt this morning.

title: Music of Chaucer Era With Hilliard Ensemble
description: The medieval satirical poem, the ''Roman de Fauvel,'' was often set to music; a few glimpses of those settings were offered Sunday afternoon by the Hilliard Ensemble in Corpus Christi Church in a program titled ''The Flowering of Music in the Age of Chaucer.''

title: SAGA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page A1 yesterday misidentified the member of the Presidential Commission on Strategic Forces shown at the left. He was James R. Schlesinger, former Secretary of Defense.

title: For Hometown Readers, A Source on the Move
description: Hotaling's News Agency, New York's umbilical cord to hometowns and foreign cultures, is closing its store at 1 Times Square after 75 years. A sign reads, ''A partire da maggio 1o 1983 Saremo al No. 142 West 42ma Strada.''

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE FORTIES. By Edmund Wilson. Edited with an introduction by Leon Edel. Illustrated. 369 pages. Farrar, Straus and Giroux. $17.95. A WRITER has to be either brave or vain to publish his notebooks, for nowhere else is he so vulnerable or exposed. Even the best authors can be surprisingly silly or naive before they think themselves over and edit their work. We have records of the earliest versions of published poems - including ''The Wasteland'' - to show us what an enormous difference there is between a first draft and a final one. In fiction, we can compare ''Stephen Hero'' with ''A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man.''

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: DANCE: GALA, PAUL TAYLOR AND GUEST
description: IT worked. A great ballet dancer and a troupe of great modern dancers crossed a bridge before they came to it last night and the result was fabulously successful.

title: Addenda
description: * People magazine increasing its circulation rate base 7.2 percent, to 2.6 million, from 2.4 million, and its national advertising rates 9.1 percent, effective with the July 18 issue.

title: SUN CHEMICAL HIRES EX-THIOKOL PRESIDENT
description: The Sun Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it had named Robert E. Davis president and chief operating officer. He resigned similar posts in February at Morton Thiokol Inc. of Chicago.

title: SEAVER IS STRONG, BUT METS LOSE IN 10
description: Tom Seaver pitched seven innings of fivehit ball today in his second strong performance in a week for the Mets. But this time the Philadelphia Phillies tied the score in the ninth inning off the rookie Doug Sisk, and won in the 10th off Neil Allen, 4-3.

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 27.
PURCELL CO INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $1,129,000 for the quarter and year. c-Includes an extraordinary gain of $6,232,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Atari Unit in Japan
description: Atari Inc. said it would start selling video game players and cartridges in Japan next month. Atari, a unit of Warner Communications Inc., said its Japanese subsidiary, Atari International Nippon Inc., would start selling a video game player and 25 cartridges on May 10. The player will sell for about $104, while the cartridges will range in price from $18 to $29.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN devising recipes, one thing always seems to lead to another. When I wrote recently about a less-than-an-hour preparation for that great Louisiana specialty, jambalaya, I was asked shortly afterward by a neighbor to come up with a quick method for preparing another Creole specialty, gumbo.

title: 2 Reasons for Women to Celebrate
description: To celebrate the 67th anniversary of women's entry into Congress, and, more immediate, to raise money for electing women in 1984, the Manhattan Women's Political Caucus threw a party at Polly Bergen's stylish, art-filled Park Avenue apartment the other night. Not surprisingly, 30 percent of the 230 guests were men -some politicians courting the women's vote and others courting politicians who are women.

title: STERCHI BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE woman's nails, painted scarlet, were longer than the first joint of her fingers. They looked more like weapons than cosmetic adornments and said a lot about the kinds of activities she necessarily had to avoid to preserve her manicure. Closer examination revealed that they were glued-on artificial nails, which some dermatologists say are dangerous. But even if used without medical consequences, these nails can certainly preclude activities like washing dishes, chopping onions, weeding gardens, typing and unknotting children's shoelaces.

title: TAXING OF CULTURAL INSTITUTIONS IS CONTESTED BY MISS BELLAMY
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy yesterday challenged Mayor Koch over his policy to collect property taxes from many cultural and scientific institutions that are exempt.

title: BRANCH CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FILM STAR IN U.S. AND MEXICO
description: Dolores Del Rio, an actress of remarkable beauty who became a film star in Hollywood and in her native Mexico, died Monday at her home in Newport Beach, Calif. She was 77 years old and had been in failing health.

title: Barclays Files For Shelf Issue
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. said today that it had filed a shelf registration statement with the United States Securities and Exchange Commission covering the issue of $500 million of debt securities or loan stock over the next two years.

title: BANCOHIO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
UPSTATE BOARD IS REOPENING SCHOOL CLOSED AFTER ILLNESS
description: The Board of Education here, which closed a school two months ago after 250 students and teachers became sick, voted Monday night to reopen it despite uncertainty over what had caused the illnesses.

title: HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $1,521,000, or 4 cents a share, from property transactions.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REPRISE

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Market Place; Investing in Texas Banks
description: WITH popular stock averages nudging record highs, what overlooked areas remain for profit-making possibilities? Charles H. Lott, president of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Inc., picks a Texas bank stock - Interfirst Corporation - that recently came under a cloud. It is, on the surface, not an investment for the faint-hearted.

title: VOLCKER CALLS RATES TOO HIGH
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that long-term interest rates were too high for a sustained economic recovery.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Rapp & Collins In European Move
description: Rapp & Collins, a 14-year-old direct marketing agency with some $40 million in billings, will be establishing a European beachhead in London, as a first step.

title: TOP OFFICERS SHIFT AT CORNING GLASS
description: The Corning Glass Works yesterday announced a major realignment of its management and a shift of the posts of chairman and chief executive officer from one Houghton brother to another.

title: TESTIMONY LINKS DEFENDANT IN CBS MURDERS TO PIER LOT
description: A prosecution witness in the murder trial of Donald Nash - recalling a ''brief encounter'' near a silver-colored van with a stocky man who had a ''lazy'' eye and wore a plaid green jacket - gave testimony yesterday that placed Mr. Nash in a parking lot near the Hudson River the week before four people were slain there one year ago.

title: BANCAL TRI-STATE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including nonrecurring net gains of $1.7 million in the latest first quarter and $1.5 million in the year-ago first quarter.

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $887,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Choosing Sides In the U.S.F.L.
description: Local television viewers searched in vain last Sunday for Herschel Walker and the New Jersey Generals. They found a United States Football League game between the Boston Breakers and the Oakland Invaders, but not the Generals' contest against the Michigan Panthers at Giants Stadium.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIRST UNION CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Cyclist Convicted In Trooper Attack
description: Glen Turner, a Pagans motorcycle-gang member, was convicted today of attempting to murder State Trooper John Jacobs, who was shot in the face and is now partly blind.

title: AMES TO LEAVE PHILHARMONIC
description: Amyas Ames will retire as chairman of the board of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra. Mr. Ames, who has been associated with the Philharmonic for almost 30 years, said yesterday that he would leave his post following the choice of a successor, expected at a board meeting on May 4. He became a member of the board in 1955 and the orchestra's president in 1963.

title: CHRISTINA STEAD, NOVELIST, WAS 80
description: Christina Stead, an Australian-born novelist and short-story writer, died in a hospital March 31 in Sydney at the age of 80. Her best known book is ''The Man Who Loved Children,'' published in 1940 and hailed as a ''modern masterpiece'' when it was reissued in 1965.

title: Noles Admits Problem
description: Dickie Noles, the Chicago Cubs pitcher who was charged with assaulting a police officer after an altercation at a Cincinnati bar Saturday night, said he would enter an alcohol-abuse program in Chicago and stay with it until he had beaten his drinking problem.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Larry Brown who replaced Ted Owens as the basketball coach at Kansas, has decided to retain the assistants Jo Jo White and Bob Hill. ... The Los Angeles Lakers have signed Billy Ray Bates to replace James Worthy, who broke his left leg on Sunday. Bates, a 6-4 guard, has not played since Dec.1, when he was cut by Washington. Worthy underwent successful surgery yesterday.

title: Butcher Plans Sale Of Banks
description: C.H. Butcher Jr., brother of Jake Butcher, the flamboyant Tennessee banker-politician whose United American Bank of Knoxville collapsed more than six weeks ago, said today that he would sell his controlling interest in all 21 of his banks in Tennessee and Kentucky.

title: CUOMO PLANS EFFORT TO SUPPLANT RONAN IN PORT AGENCY POST
description: Governor Cuomo said today that he would seek to replace Dr. William J. Ronan, who was a top aide to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller and a former head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, as a member of the board of the Port Authority.

title: A Long Wait, But Well Worth It
description: By 11 A.M. they were lining up to hear Betty Comden and Adolph Green ''read from favorite works'' at the Donnell Library Center's 278-seat theater Monday at 12:30. Even before the people on lunch hours arrived, the crowd was New Yorky - not young but not like a Broadway matinee either.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
SOUTHEAST NATIONAL BANCSHARES OF PENNSYLVANIA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NEW ORLEANS BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
One-Act Play for the Aged
description: ''Tiffany, Edison, Mackaye and Company,'' a one-act farce by Howard Planzer, will be presented April 28 at 1:30 P.M. at the Jewish Association for Services for the Aged, 40 West 68th Street. The play is set in 1885 and uses as its comic device a supposed collaboration among Thomas Alva Edison, Louis Comfort Tiffany and the theater impresario Steele Mackaye.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SCRIPPS-HOWARD BROADCASTING reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,387,000, or 13 cents a share, from the sale of a radio station and certain common stock investments.

title: HALE RESOURCES reports earnings for year to Nov 30.
ISLANDERS - RANGERS: LOW - KEY VIEW
description: There are the uninitiated, like Paul Boutilier, who don't understand the meaning. ''I guess it's like any other series,'' the Islanders' rookie defenseman said today. ''After one period it'll be like any other game in the playoffs. I guess that's what it's like, but I don't know, the guys don't talk about it that much.''

title: John H. Morris Is Dead; Was Ex-Police Official
description: John H. Morris, a former New York City Deputy Police Commissioner, died of Parkinson's disease Sunday at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Pleasantville, N.Y.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Schoolboy Runs 100 Meters in 9.8
description: Michael Taylor, a senior at Green Oaks High School, became the first high school athlete to break 10 seconds in the 100-meter dash, covering the distance in 9.8 seconds Monday.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: IT's curious the way New Yorkers remember their mayors. Jimmy Walker, old-timers will tell you, was the playboy Mayor who wrote songs. Fiorello LaGuardia was the Mayor with the fire engines and the funny papers. William O'Dwyer was the Mayor who lost his heart to a model named Sloan Simpson.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
MELLON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Careers; Managing Brokerage Houses
description: A SALESMAN for a brokerage firm may have the most visible job there. Y et there are many layers of management in any financial services f irm for new college graduates to consider.

title: STAVISKY WINS RACE FOR STATE SENATE
description: Leonard P. Stavisky, an 18-year veteran of the State Assembly, won a seat in the State Senate yesterday in a special election in central and northern Queens, taking 87 percent of the votes cast.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Giora Feidman Surveys Klezmer Folk Music
description: The clarinetist Giora Feidman combines an extraordinarily fluid musicianship with the instincts of a stand-up comic. His Sunday evening performance in the Abraham Goodman House was titled ''Music of the Jewish Soul,'' and it was a delightful survey of Klezmer music.

title: PARKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net income.

title: OLIVIER TO ATTEND FILM GROUP TRIBUTE TO HIM
description: Laurence Olivier has decided to attend the Film Society of Lincoln Center's tribute to him April 25 in Avery Fisher Hall. The evening will be a celebration of the 75-year-old actor's distinguished film career, which began in 1931.

title: NEW BELL LASER DEVICE INCREASES DATA CAPACITY
description: Bell Laboratories introduced yesterday a laser semiconductor that can dramatically increase the amount and accuracy of information that can be transmitted by fiber optic communications systems.

title: SONOMA VINEYARDS reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income includes a tax credit of $572,000.

title: Carl Morton, 39, Ex-Pitcher; Was Rookie of Year in 1970
description: Carl Morton, a former pitcher who was named rookie of the year in the National League in 1970, collapsed after jogging today and died of a heart attack.

title: 4 Feared Drowned In Jersey Sinking
description: Four people were believed drowned today when a clamming boat sank 30 miles southeast of here, Coast Guard officials said.

title: BOMBARDIER INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: THOMPSON MEDICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in Nov.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''While there may be bumps along the way, we will not be deterred from our long-term objective, which is a broad-based settlement.'' - President Reagan on Mideast peace plan. (A1:5.)

title: AMERICAN SAVINGS & LOAN ASSOCIATION (MIAMI, FLA) ( reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Economic Scene; Is Free Trade Useful Myth?
description: ALBERT BRESSAND, deputy director of the French Institute of International Relations, asserts in the current issue of Foreign Affairs that the age of free trade as an organizing principle is over because the model on which it was based no longer resembles the real world. He argues that the international economy can no longer be seen as ''the intersection of national economies'' but must be regarded as a ''world economy'' of increasing complexity and interdependence, calling for a new analytical framework and new global industrial policies.

title: ''NIGHT, MOTHER' AFFECTS ITS 2 STARS
description: '' 'Night, Mother'' has been described as a ''shattering evening'' in the theater, an experience that leaves many audiences stunned and weeping. Yet the two actresses who perform it have found, to their astonishment, that Marsha Norman's play has exorcised some personal demons. The experience has even been ''exhilarating,'' they say, although it takes an emotional toll.

title: Cuba Beats U.S.  In Boxing by 6-1
description: Cedric Rose of West Dallas won a split decision from Urtiminio Ramos in the 139-pound class Monday night, giving the United States its only victory in a dual meet against the Cuban boxing team.

title: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid May 21, 1982 and a 5-for-4 stock split paid Feb. 25, 1983.

title: Fight TV at Shea Barred
description: The city refused permission yesterday for Shea Stadium to be used as the major New York site for the closed-circuit telecast of the Davey Moore-Roberto Duran and Ray Mancini-Ken Bogner world championship fights on May 27. The fights are to be held in Bophuthatswana, the tribal homeland created by the South African Government.

title: Q&A
description: Q. A ham of excellent quality and a large quantity of puff pastry have been in my freezer for two years. The freezer is rarly opened and both items are properly, solidly wrapped. Do you think that at this late date it would be safe to eat them?

title: PITCHER WHO RETIRED TELLS OF THE PRESSURE
description: Kevin Saucier, whose pitching control suddenly deserted him last year when he was with the Detroit Tigers, said today that concern for his mental health prompted him to give up his nine-year professional baseball career.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CENTRAL PARK TO GET SECURITY BASE
description: The Parks Department force that patrols Central Park will have a central headquarters for the first time, officials announced yesterday. The new headquarters will be open 24 hours a day, they said, and will significantly improve security.

title: SCOTT, WALKER, & CO reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
description: b-Net loss.

title: WIEBOLDT STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 29.
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income. The year results include gains from the sale of real estate of $1,198,000, or 43 cents a share, for 1983 and $4,403,000, or $1.59 a share, for 1982.

title: STATE GETS WRIT
description: Talks between N.J. Transit and a faction of the United Transportation Union broke off today, and a Federal judge tonight barred a threatened strike by the group.

title: Allen Is Impatient
description: George Allen, the Chicago Blitz coach who is rapidly emerging as the leading critic of his club's own United States Football League, has a new complaint about the U.S.F.L.: the games are too long.

title: ROADWAY SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 13, 1983
description: International

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANK OF NEW JERSEY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $712,000.

title: REFINERS' STOCKS GROW
description: Prices of copper futures, a key economic indicator, fell an average of one-half cent a pound yesterday as several bearish factors combined to make speculators convert their recent paper profits into cash.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See Accompanying notes for special items

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Stock Exchange has elected to its board of governors Frank C. Carlucci 3d, president and chief operating officer of Sears World Trade Inc.; Charles L. Schultze, senior fellow at the Brookings institution; Richard H. Jenrette, chairman and chief executive officer of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette; William Silver, general partner at Weiskopf, Silver & Co., and Thomas W. Strauss, managing director of Salomon Brothers.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: HERE'S another installment in our occasional series of record roundups, this one devoted to jazz albums. No ratings are given; these are all worthwhile albums. But there has been a flood of jazz releases recently, from recession-damaged companies that find them cheaper to make and thus a more attractive proposition than rock.

title: MERCANTILE TEXAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After provisions for possible loan losses of $9,938,000 for the latest first quarter and $6,783,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: 500-Game Check
description: No, that isn't a new helmet Butch Goring of the Islanders is wearing on the road these days. The 33-year-old center is playing his 14th season in the National Hockey League, all with the same battered helmet for away games.

title: Undecided on Elway
description: The Baltimore Colts may wait until the last minute before deciding whether to draft John Elway, the Stanford quarterback, or to trade their rights to him. That was the word from Baltimore after Colts officials were asked about reports that they planned to trade their backup quarterback, Art Schlichter, to Cincinnati to make way for Elway. With Schlichter's status still under review by National Football League investigators looking into his gambling activities, the Colts are taking a wait-and-see attitude.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in Metropolitan Report yesterday on the demolition of Baker Field incorrectly gave the scheduled completion date for the replacement football field and stands. It is September 1984.

title: FLORIDA NATIONAL BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2,254,000 from divestiture of certain banking assets in settlement with Southeast Banking Corp.

title: Gulf Credit Cards
description: Units of the Gulf Oil Corporation and the J.C. Penney Company have signed an agreement providing for Gulf credit cards to be serviced by the big retail chain's nationwide electronic communications and credit authorization system. Gulf said it expected that more than 3,000 terminals would be installed in its service stations. It said Gulf stations handle more than 100 million credit card transactions yearly for five million Gulf credit card holders who charge more than $2 billion.

title: ECONO-THERM ENERGY SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net income.

title: HOW TO READ AND EAT AT THE SAME TIME
description: READING a book while dining alone would seem to be the answer to two of life's most vexing difficulties. No one has enough time to read - with some 40,000 books published every year, even Evelyn Wood has to strain to keep up - and everyone gets tired of breaking the monotony of dining alone by counting the escargots on the restaurant's peeling wallpaper. Yet, like many of the world's good things, reading in a restaurant is teeming with peril for the unwary, and should never be attempted without serious and careful preparation.

title: STUDENT DESIGNS AT PARSONS SHOW
description: AT most schools, graduation means diplomas, speeches and proms. At the Parsons School of Design, there's an extra added attraction for the fashion students: the chance to put on a show of clothing they themselves designed and made. And the chance for their work to be seen by a prospective employer.

title: Coach Leaves Utah
description: Jerry Pimm, who compiled a 173-86 record and led the Utah basketball team to five postseason tournaments in his nine seasons as head coach, has resigned to take over as head coach at California-Santa Barbara, a school that has not had a winning season in seven years. Pimm, who is being replaced by his assistant, Lynn Archibald, is replacing Ed DeLacy, who was dismissed after Santa Barbara wound up the 1982-83 season with a 7-20 record.

title: STAKE IN FLEXI-VAN RAISED BY MURDOCK
description: David H. Murdock disclosed yesterday that he and the four companies he controls had sharply increased their stake in the Flexi-Van Corporation.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Mellon Net Up; CCB Tie Is Set
description: The Mellon National Corporation reported today a first-quarter net income of $38.6 million and announced that it would merge with CCB Bankcorp Inc., the parent company of Central Counties Bank.

title: San Diego State Saves 3 Sports
description: Three athletic teams that faced elimination at San Diego State because of budget problems there have been given new life.

title: Peete's Thoughts
description: Of the 49 golfers who completed the 72 holes of the Masters tournament Monday in Augusta, Ga., Calvin Peete finished last at 309. After opening rounds of 70 and 72 that put him among the leaders, he soared on the last two days to 87 (the worst competitive score of his career) and 80.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to include the accounts of a bank acquired in April 1982.

title: New Job for Holub
description: A lot of schools have counselors to keep an eye on the academic progress of student-athletes, but these are frequently athletic department functionaries who are looked on with suspicion by the faculty.

title: LIBERTY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HUFFY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 25.
description: b-Net income.

title: G.E., INTERNATIONAL PAPER RISE
description: The General Electric Company, the diversified high-technology concern and the country's leading producer of electrical products, said yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1983 increased 12.7 percent, while sales rose 1.3 percent.

title: HARRIS BANKCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Young Architects' Show
description: Twelve winners of the Architectural League's Second Young Architects Competition will take part in a three-day slide presentation of their works, beginning May 3, at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue, between 50th and 51st Streets.

title: WINE TALK
description: A READER writes: ''I have always wanted to invest in a case of wine which could be used for celebrations over the years. From what I have been reading, it seems that the '82 Bordeaux would be a perfect choice.'' She continues: ''Frankly, I don't know much about wines, do have an unsophisticated palate and have never spent a lot on wine.'' Then she adds some questions:

title: MESSAGE OF 'THE VERDICT' DEBATED IN COURTHOUSE
description: It is only a movie, judges and lawyers are swift to point out, but somehow this movie has wended its way into the courthouse and the psyche of those whose livelihood centers on the third branch of government.

title: M.T.A. AND UNION FAULTED BY CUOMO FOR RAIL IMPASSE
description: Governor Cuomo said today that negotiatons to end the strike against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad were ''at impasse,'' and he blamed the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the union for failing to reach a contract.

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 13, 1983
description: The Economy

title: UNITED STATES HOME INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid April 15.

title: FIDELITY UNION BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includng a tax credit of $842,000.

title: HMG PROPERTY INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: A STRATEGY FOR MULTICOURSE MEALS FROM A WOK
description: EVEN though woks are not yet two-to-every-household like television sets, the American kitchen that doesn't include at least one of these Oriental wonders is increasingly rare. Stir-frying may even be the wave of our culinary future: given only a few more years, crisp-tender vegetables and meats with their juices still in them may well replace our diet of cooked-to-death foods.

title: LANDMARK STATUS GIVEN TO WOOLWORTH BUILDING
description: The Woolworth Building, the dazzling 70-year-old ''Cathedral of Commerce'' whose Gothic-style spire still punctuates the lower Manhattan skyline, was granted landmark status yesterday.

title: Bankers Meet With Reagan
description: A group of bankers met with President Reagan this afternoon to press for repeal of withholding of taxes on interest and dividends, but they came away virtually empty-handed.

title: FAR WEST UNIT BIDS FOR BEKINS
description: The Far West Financial Corporation, a savings and loan holding company, said today that one of its units and a major shareholder of the Bekins Company had offered to buy Bekins, a household moving concern, for $77.2 million in cash.

title: OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $2,356,000 from the early retirement of debt. c-Net loss.

title: UST CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
1. Fashions From Orient
description: Shibui is the Japanese word for understated elegance. It is also the name of a new shop in SoHo whose wares differ from most of the Japanese fashions around town in one important way: They are moderately priced. But the styles are mainly those oversize shapeless tops, baggy pants and loose dresses in drab grays and black. Shibui has cotton pants for $36 that are full around the hips and low in the crotch; oversize white cotton shirts from $34; double T-shirts for $50 with the undershirt showing through holes in the outer one; plus skirts and culottes starting at about $68. A good selection of less extreme styles includes a two-piece knitted silk dress ($188) with a horizontally striped overblouse and plaid pleated skirt, and a linen suit ($232) with a soft-collared jacket and a handkerchief-hem skirt. Shibui is at 68 Thompson Street, between Spring and Broome Streets. Hours are 12 to 7 Tuesday through Friday; 12 to 6 Saturday and Sunday.

title: RAW-MILK CHEESE: WHEN IS IT LEGAL?
description: TO certain cheese lovers, especially those who are familiar with varieties sold in Europe, nothing equals the flavor of those made with raw, or unpasteurized, milk. Pasteurizing milk can change the complexion and taste of cheeses made from it, and some contend they lose something in the process. Several years ago it was virtually impossible to find fresh raw-milk cheeses in the United States, particularly such soft-ripening types as Brie and Camembert, because state and Federal laws banned their sale here.

title: HIPOTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 5.
description: b-Net income.

title: Mother's Suicide Follows Infanticide
description: A 31-year-old mother yesterday drowned her 2-week-old baby boy in a bathtub and then committed suicide by jumping from the fifth-floor dining room of her parents' Riverside Drive apartment, the police said.

title: GOLD COIN SALES GO PRIVATE
description: The Treasury Department has decided to use a private dealer to sell its gold medallions in the hope that the dealer will do a better job than the Postal Service.

title: WESTCHESTER DEMOCRATS PICK REID AS DESIGNEE FOR COUNTY EXECUTIVE
description: Ogden R. Reid's return to politics received a major boost tonight when the six-term former Congressman from Westchester County scored an upset victory to become the Democratic Party's designee for the County Executive race in November.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HAWKS GAIN IN DOWNING 76ers
description: Dominique Wilkins scored 26 points, including 2 that put Atlanta ahead for good late in the fourth quarter, as the Hawks defeated the Philadelphia 76ers, 102-97, tonight.

title: New York Cancels Its Drought Watch
description: New York City, citing heavy rainfall during March and April, yesterday canceled a drought watch that had been in effect since Nov. 30.

title: RHODES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
Advertising; Country Living's New Shop
description: LANSDOWNE ADVERTISING has won the Country Living magazine account because, as far as the publisher is concerned, it has shown it can communicate the magazine's success to the rest of Madison Avenue in an advertising campaign.

title: Dreyfus Changes New Bank's Name
description: The Dreyfus Corporation, a financial services organization, said it had changed the name of a New Jersey bank that it acquired.

title: ATLANTIC BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOLLYWOOD'S TOP AWARDS AND WINNERS
description: Following is a complete list of winners of the 55th annual Academy Awards Monday night: Best Picture: ''Gandhi.'' Best actor: Ben Kingsley, ''Gandhi.''

title: Joseph Fuchs Performs On Violin at Carnegie
description: Joseph Fuchs's concert in Carnegie Hall Sunday evening marked another step along his estimable and seemingly endless career as a violinist. Mr. Fuchs, who has been playing and teaching longer than most of us can remember, assured us Sunday that he still has much to give.

title: CAPITAL BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RECORD 55,579 SEE YANKEES DROP HOME OPENER, 13-2
description: Never have so many seen the Yankees play so badly on opening day at Yankee Stadium. A record opening-day crowd of 55,579, titillated by the third coming of Billy Martin, watched the Yankees suffer a record openingday loss to the Detroit Tigers, 13-2, yesterday. Never in 58 other such Stadium openers had the Yankees lost by such a large margin.

title: TV: PRESIDENTIAL MUSIC
description: IN some brief concluding remarks for tonight's ''In Performance at the White House,'' on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock, President Reagan observes that ''chamber music is probably the most democratic of the arts'' - pause -''small 'd.' '' The President's involvement with music is also remarkably democratic, small ''d.'' After the concert on public television, taped last Wednesday, he is scheduled to appear on the ''Salute to the 25th Anniversary of the Country Music Association,'' which will begin on CBS-TV at 9 P.M., featuring the top country-and-western stars performing in Washington's Constitution Hall.

title: MARINE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest first quarter include the effect of the merger with Warren National Bank which was consummated on June 30, 1982.

title: MANVILLE IS ACCUSED ON LAWYER
description: Lawyers for thousands of workers with asbestos-related diseases charged yesterday that one of the lawyers working on ''legislative services'' for the Manville Corporation is simultaneously working as special counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Courts, which is responsible for pending legislation reforming the bankruptcy system.

title: GROSS TELECASTING INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
New President At Uniworld
description: Douglass L. Alligood, one of the better-known black advertising executives, has left his position as director of corporate advertising for the RCA Corporation to become president and chief operating officer of the Uniworld Group, specialists in advertising to the black community.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press published Monday, about President Reagan's proposal for an antiballistic missile system, incorrectly described the academic affiliation of Dr. Charles Townes. He is on the faculty of the University of California at Berkeley.

title: BRITISH READY FESTIVE SALUTE
description: If excuse is needed, the excuse for ''Britain Salutes New York'' - the festival of art, drama, music, dance, film and literature that opens today -is the Treaty of Paris, which ended the Revolutionary War two centuries ago.

title: NCNB CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest first quarter include a gain equal to 17 cents a share from the sale of 8 branches. Year-ago results reflect a nonrecurring charge of $1,550,000 for the writedown of certain assets acquired through foreclosure. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Bancshares of North Carolina Inc.

title: DANCE: THE ELIOT FELD BALLET OPENS AT THE JOYCE THEATER
description: THE audience greeted the Feld Ballet with great warmth when the company opened its six-week spring season at the Joyce Theater last night. With the Feld dancers back at their home theater, it seemed they'd never been away. It could have been an evening spent with family, in fact, with the prerogatives of familiar cheers and grumbles.

title: EXOTIC EDIBLES IN A CHIC BOUTIQUE SETTING
description: NOT many Korean greengrocers in New York regularly carry three or four kinds of exotic fresh mushrooms, imported and from California. And not many of them were selling magnificent bunches of lavendertipped white asparagus from Mexico last week.

title: FRENCH POTS FOR JAM
description: TO generations of French children the squat, wide glasses with rounded rims pictured here hold the same magical allure that icecream trucks had to American children of an earlier age: both presaged something sweet to eat.

title: WESTLANDS DIVERSIFIED BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Operating loss. c-Net loss. Year-ago results have been adjusted to reflect recording of deferred loan fees in December 1982.

title: A Rocky Opener for Billy
description: In Denver, the temperature was 31 degrees with light snow falling from foggy skies, and a winter storm warning was in effect. In the Bronx, it was 55 degrees and overcast, which meant the Yankees would be able to hold their latest Billy Martin Oldie-But-Goodie Revival, right on schedule.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

description: Governor Cuomo has stepped into the strike against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad with a series of statements in the last two weeks, but exactly what the Governor is trying to accomplish is not clear, even to the participants in the negotiations.

title: B.& M. Creditors Approve Sale Plan
description: Creditors of the bankrupt Boston & Maine Railroad have approved a plan under which it would be acquired by Timothy Mellon's Guilford Transportation Industries of Durham, Conn., according to the railroad's reorganization trustee, Benjamin Lacy. He said the next step was certification of the vote by creditors in United States District Court.

title: A TOP ANGOLAN IS SAID TO MEET SHULTZ IN U.S.
description: The highest-ranking Angolan official to visit Washington held an unpublicized meeting this afternoon with Secretary of State George P. Shultz to discuss South Africa's occupation of South-West Africa and the presence of Cuban troops in Angola, Administration officials said.

title: Advertising; Sunshine Biscuits Goes to TV
description: WITH the usually placid cookie business in a ferment, Sunshine Biscuits, which says it is in the top three, is taking to television advertising to reinforce its position.

title: Toxic Chemicals Stored Illegally
description: More than 1,000 drums, many containing highly toxic and volatile chemicals, have been found illegally stored in a warehouse in an industrial section of Newark, and fire officials yesterday ordered the building sealed pending further investigation.

title: 2 L.I. CONTRACTORS ACCUSED OF BID-RIGGING SCHEME
description: Two Long Island contracting companies and four of their officials were charged yesterday with conspiring to rig bids on millions of dollars in road repair contracts awarded by New York State.

title: COURT ASSAILS U.S. ON HAITIAN POLICY
description: A sharply worded Federal appeals court ruling assails the Government's policies in treatment of Haitians seeking refuge in this country.

title: REFORM WORLD FINANCE
description: The immediate danger of a financial default in the major Latin American countries is evidently fading. A collapse of the international system has been avoided for the moment. But avoiding disaster only buys time. We must consider the longer-term lessons of the crisis and insure that it does not happen again.

DEAL SEEN ON POWER BOND DEBT
description: Government and utility officials in the Northwest have reached ''substantial agreement in principle'' on a plan to avoid default on the $7 billion debt for two abandoned nuclear power projects, according to the Governor of Washington.

title: Petro-Canada Plan
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 13 (Reuters) - Canada's Energy, Mines and Resources Ministry said it had signed exploration agreements with Petro-Canada Exploration Inc. for the drilling of 10 wells off the Newfoundland shore, calling for an investment of about $500 million. Petro-Canada is operator for a group that includes Gulf Canada Ltd., Canterra Energy Ltd., Ranchmen's Resources (1976) Ltd., Total Petroleum, Suncor Inc., Agip Canada Ltd. and the Amerada Minerals Corporation of Canada.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
4 Plead Not Guilty In Schlichter Case
description: Four Maryland men charged with gambling in a case involving the Baltimore Colt quarterback Art Schlichter pleaded not guilty today in United States District Court.

title: STAGE: THREE SHORT PLAYS, THEATER TOUR
description: ''ABOUT HEAVEN AND EARTH,'' an evening of three unevenly matched one-act plays at the Negro Ensemble Company, reminds us of Douglas Turner Ward's talent and sense of humor as playwright and actor. The plays, all of them directed by Mr. Ward, are at Theater Four.

title: TELEDYNE CANADA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: MANAGEMENT'S RANKS GROW
description: The unusual sight of corporate managers being laid off during the recession has helped feed the notion that the ranks of managers are being thinned. But national data do not bear this out. Instead, despite two back-to-back recessions and a widely held belief that management had become swollen and top-heavy, its ranks have continued to grow.

title: NATIONALE-NEDERLANDEN NV reports earnings for year to Dec 31.

title: Uniworld Group Gets A Burger King Account
description: Waiting but a day after the announcement of its new president, Douglass L. Alligood, the Uniworld Group, specialists in advertising to the black consumer market, now announces a new client - Burger King.

title: Q&A
description: Q. My country house has electric cables that go underground to outbuildings and a tree light. These cables are not encased in rigid conduit, and the electrician contends that they leak current into the ground and are wasting energy. He cites black zigzag lines on the white cable as evidence. Can this be true?

title: SENATE PREPARING FOR ADELMAN VOTE
description: The Senate today completed its second day of debate on the nomination of Kenneth L. Adelman to be the nation's chief arms control official and prepared for what is expected to be a close vote on the issue Thursday afternoon.

title: RAIDERS TO SHARE $49.2 MILLION FOR N.F.L. DAMAGES
description: A jury today awarded $16.41 million in antitrust damages to the Raiders and the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum Commission in their suit against the National Football League. The suit involved the league's efforts to block the transfer of the Raiders from Oakland to Los Angeles more than four years ago.

title: BIG 3 CAR SALES UP 32.2% IN EARLY APRIL
description: On the strength of a 55.2 percent increase in car sales by the General Motors Corporation, the Big Three automobile manufacturers today reported a 32.2 percent jump in sales in the April 1-10 period. It was the largest increase since mid-December, when sales rose 38.3 percent.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period.

title: 'BRITAIN SALUTES NEW YORK' AT METROPOLITAN MUSEUM
description: YANKS and Britons toasted each other last night at a party at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that celebrated the opening of a $3.5 million arts festival called ''Britain Salutes New York.''

description: The Ford Motor Company earned a profit producing automobiles and trucks in North America in the first quarter of this year, Philip Caldwell, the chairman of Ford, said today.

description: The springtime weather tells Howard Jacobson it is a good time to walk. But Jacobson hears that message even in blizzards.

description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Battle of the Boxes
description: When six of USA Today's blue and white vending machines were placed alongside Central Park Tuesday, Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern decided to do something.

title: Ayala Is Guilty In Rape Trial
description: Tony Ayala Jr. was found guilty today of having raped a 30-year-old woman in her West Paterson apartment last New Year's Day.

title: Naval Assault on Think Tanks
description: The Center for Naval Analyses is a think tank that has been operated for the Navy since 1967 by the University of Rochester, in New York State. The arrangement, similar to that with other study centers that advise the Defense Department, provides for truly objective analysis of difficult military problems. But in the Reagan Administration that purpose is yielding to another: the Secretary of the Navy, John Lehman, wants a protege, Francis West, installed as the center's president.

title: THE OUT-OF-WORK LINE
description: Another stint down at the Detroit branch of the Michigan Employment Security Commission. It doesn't matter when you arrive. The line begins a step inside the door and weaves snake-like from side wall to side wall. A security guard keeps the line in shape, shepherding newcomers with stricken faces to the rear.

title: YANKEES FALL TO TIGERS
description: Dave Winfield punched Dave Rozema after the Detroit pitcher fired a pitch over his head last night, but the Tigers inflicted greater damage on Rich Gossage and defeated the Yankees, 7-5.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: WHY A FILM 'K2' WOULDN'T HAVE THE SAME THRILL
description: HAVING been mightily impressed with Patrick Meyers's ''K2'' myself, I'm not at all surprised to find theatergoers coming away from the Brooks Atkinson decidedly awestruck. I hear them chattering about actor-climber Jeffrey DeMunn's sudden, spectacular drop from a high crag into what seems a bottomless crevasse. I hear them marveling that designer Ming Cho Lee's mountain of ice can be freely dug into by spiked toes, sending a glittering surface spray over the pockmarked ledge on which two climbers rest. It's all a pretty heady business for a standard Broadway house, and there's no reason audiences shouldn't revel in it as they might in a first-rate fireworks display.

description: West Germany's Constitutional Court issued an injunction today halting a national census that civil libertarians said could lead to the infringement of individual rights.

description: Favorable economic news and the growing conviction that interest rates will continue to drop sent the stock market up sharply yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average soaring 11.32 points, to close at a record 1,156.64.

title: FLEXI-VAN BOARD YIELDS TO MURDOCK
description: The Flexi-Van Corporation's board of directors gave in to David H. Murdock yesterday, restoring his title as chairman and thereby ending a two-week struggle for control of the company.

title: JERSEY REVOKES LICENSE OF DOCTOR ACCUSED OF FRAUD IN CANCER CASE
description: The state revoked the medical license of Dr. Donald R. Cole tonight after concluding that his conduct in New York in treating cancer patients was fraudulent and ''tantamount to quackery.''

title: RANGERS AT A GLANCE
description: Forwards 8 ROBBIE FTOREK: Center, 5 feet 10 inches, 155 pounds, 31 years old; 12 goals, 19 assists in season. Leading scorer in 1982 playoffs. 9 ROB McCLANAHAN: Left wing, 5-10, 180, age 25; 22 goals, 26 assists. One of league's fastest skaters, learned to break around defenses. 10 RON DUGUAY: Center-right wing, 6-2, 210, age 25; 19 goals, 25 assists. His most disappointing season. Lost scoring touch almost completely, but size makes him valuable near net for tipping shots, screening. Centering fourth line. Good speed, penalty-killer. 12 DON MALONEY: Left wing, 6-1, 190, age 24; 29 goals, 40 assists. Missed Philadelphia series with knee injury. Second to Ftorek in playoff scoring last season, with 10 points in 11 games. 14 MIKE ALLISON: Center, 6-0, 200, age 22, 11 goals, 9 assists. Season interrupted twice by knee injuries. Has replaced injured Mike Rogers as center for Don Maloney and Ed Johnstone, Rangers' No. 2 line. 15 ANDERS HEDBERG: Right wing, 5-11, 175, age 32, 25 goals, 34 assists. His 4 goals and 4 assists in Flyer series tied with Edmonton's Wayne Gretzky for playoff scoring lead to date. Thriving on No.1 line with McClanahan and Mark Pavelich. 17 ED JOHNSTONE: Right wing, 5-9, 175, age 29, 15 goals, 21 assists. Midseason injuries cost him 28 games. He and Don Maloney make workhorse bookends on No. 2 line centered by Allison.

title: SHAD ASKS STIFF PENALTY FOR INSIDER VIOLATIONS
description: John S.R. Shad, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today urged approval of a bill that would allow assessment of triple damages for insider trading violations.

title: 21 Now the Age To Get Into Casino
description: Governor Kean signed a bill today raising the minimum age for admittance to a gambling casino to 21, to match a recent change in the drinking age. The law is effective immediately.

title: U.S. Use of Herbicide Curtailed in California
description: A Federal appeals court today virtually prohibited the United States Forest Service from using the herbicide 2,4-D on its lands in California.

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PAUL ROBESON HONORED
description: The 85th anniversary of the birth of Paul Robeson was observed in Carnegie Hall Tuesday by 2,600 people who spent the evening reliving the sweet and bitter years of the late singer-actor-activist's life. Some brought their children to share in the memories.

title: SAFETY-KLEEN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a charge of $150,000 for stock appreciation rights. c-Includes a credit of $525,000 for stock appreciation rights.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday incorrectly reported the roles of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and Chemical Bank in the rescheduling of Baldwin-United Corporation debt. Chemical Bank is acting as agent for creditors of Baldwin-United and the D.H. Baldwin Company, a Baldwin subsidiary. Manufacturers Hanover is agent for creditors of Balunit Inc., another Baldwin subsidiary.

title: Tornado Kills 54 In South China
description: A tornado killed 54 people and seriously injured 163 when it raged through two south China communes Monday, the New China News Agency said today.

title: Dr. Cecil J. Watson, 82, Dies; Expert on Disorders of Liver
description: Dr. Cecil J. Watson, an expert on liver disorders and former head of the University of Minnesota School of Medicine, died Monday after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND CORP reports earnings for As of March 31.
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: PHILS BEAT METS WITH 5 IN 9TH
description: In their best display of hitting in nearly a year, the Mets whacked out 17 hits against the Philadelphia Phillies tonight. But in their worst display of pitching in memory, they wasted a four-run lead and lost the game, 10-9, on a home run by Bo Diaz with the bases loaded and two out in the ninth inning.

description: Baseball

description: To the Editor:

title: Institute Is Now Urging Artificial Heart Grant
description: The National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute, which two years ago refused to support research for the artificial heart that was to prolong Dr. Barney B. Clark's life, is now urging the University of Utah to apply for a grant for future implants.

title: AN EX-SOVIET SPY IDENTIFIES 8 HE SAYS HELPED HIM IN JAPAN
description: A Soviet spy who defected to the United States in 1979 has identified eight Japanese, including three well-known Socialist politicians, who he says acted as his contacts in the 1970's when he worked in Tokyo.

title: HEADED DEPARTMENT STORE CHAIN
description: Morton D. May, a collector of primitive art who was the third member of his family to head the May Department Stores Company, one of the largest retail chains in the United States, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at Jewish Hospital in St. Louis. He was 69 years old.

title: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
VIDEOVISION INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $94,883. c-Net loss after a loss of $233,845 from discontinued operations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We strive for unity. I guarantee you a total outreach to every area of this city.''

title: JOHN NEEDHAM, 65, OF SALVATION ARMY
description: John D. Needham, national commander of the Salvation Army, died of cancer yesterday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 65 years old and lived in Cedar Grove, N.J.

title: MAKE HOCKEY, NOT WAR
description: A terrible injustice was committed last Sunday night in Washington, according to a Washington Capital radio announcer who was heard in a car barreling north on the interstate.

title: CHALLENGE OF PICKING STATE GIFTS
description: What does one give a Sultan who has everything? Or, for that matter, what does one give a President of the United States who can only pat a gift admiringly before sending it off to the Office of Protocol for disposition as ''public property?''

title: Turpin Won't Turn Pro
description: Melvin Turpin, the University of Kentucky's junior basketball center, has decided not to turn pro after all. ''I'm going to stay for my fourth year,'' he announced at an awards dinner Tuesday night. It was also announced that Kentucky's coach, Joe B. Hall, would get an extension - its length as yet undetermined - on his contract, which has two years to run.

title: 20 YEARS OF LIST ART POSTERS MARKED
description: At Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts last night, the spotlight was on the visual arts. More than 400 artists, gallery owners and Lincoln Center officials and supporters gathered to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the art-poster program endowed by the Albert A. List Foundation.

title: REAGAN'S DILEMMA PITS SUCCESS AGAINST PURITY
description: As illustrated by the sea of troubles now confronting President Reagan, the central dilemma of his third year in office turns on the choice that many politicians believe will define his Administration for the voters in 1984: whether to go for political purity or political success.

title: Ellis Island Revisted, With Eban as Guide
description: The city gleamed like a promise yesterday from Ellis Island, where Channel 13 gave a picnic to celebrate resumption of filming on ''Heritage: Civilization and the Jews,'' its 10-part series narrated by Abba Eban.

title: FOR THE PARSONS WINNER: 7th AVE. DOORS ARE OPEN
description: THE day after the Parsons School of Design's annual Fashion Critics Award Show, which was held Tuesday night at the New York Hilton, David Pfendler, who won three Golden Thimble Awards plus the Student Designer of the Year Award, was doing what all fashion designers like to do best -selling his clothes. However, he was offering them not at retail but on the fifth floor of his alma mater, along with other senior classmates who had presented their creations.

title: STAGE: ROYAL SHAKESPEARE COMPANY'S 'ALL's WELL'
description: UNTIL the climactic scene, in which the gold of dawn at last peeks through, the light in the Royal Shakespeare Company's ''All's Well That Ends Well'' comes in shades of gray. That's how it should be. This comedy is indeed the problem play everyone has always said it is. Call ''All's Well'' what you will - a romance studded with nasty thorns, a cynical satire, a jumble - it is often cloudy. But gray, in Shakespeare's hands, becomes silver, and this play, stepchild of the canon though it may be, is still a mirror, however cracked, held up to the world. It reflects the intensity of life from the oddest of angles.

title: KNICKS DOWN NETS, GAIN IN PLAYOFF RACE
description: Hubie Brown searched for a winning combination for three periods last night. The coach of the Knicks found it in the final quarter in the second-unit front line of Louis Orr, Marvin Webster and Sly Williams and the unusual backcourt of Ernie Grunfeld and Paul Westphal.

description: * Cahners Publishing Company, Boston, the major United States publishing arm of Reed International, London, has acquired the assets of Fischer Medical Publications.

title: British Warships Arrive In Gibraltar Amid Protest
description: Sixteen Royal Navy warships steamed into port today in this disputed British colony, enraging the Spanish Government.

description: Ten years ago today I set up shop in this space, promising only ''another point of view'' but vaguely looking forward to an amalgam of reporting and opinionating called ''investigative commentary.''

title: Interest Rates Off Moderately; Budget Steps Are Awaited
description: Interest rates declined modestly yesterday as government securities dealers said that modest investor demand was enough to raise prices slightly.

Internorth, Belco in Deal
description: Internorth Inc., a natural gas transmission and distribution company, and the Belco Petroleum Corporation, an international oil and gas producer, have executed an agreement for Internorth to acquire Belco for about $735 million, the companies announced today.

title: M.A.C. Bond Sale Of $118.3 Million
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York plans to sell $118.3 million of bonds due 1984-98 on April 18. The interest rate for the bonds will be determined by competitive bidding among various securities firms, rather than through negotiations with a previously selected group of firms.

title: CBS Explains Baseball Rejection
description: Recent contract negotiations gave television rights to major league baseball for the next six years to NBC and ABC. The cost has been estimated at $1.1 billion.

title: 'Macon' Film Postponed
description: ''Eddie Macon's Run,'' a movie starring John Schneider and Kirk Douglas, has postponed its opening date at local theaters to April 29. The film, directed by Jeff Kanew, dramatizes the pursuit of a falsely convicted man who has escaped from a Texas prison.

title: Not Guilty Plea Entered, By Dentist in 3 Deaths
description: A 38-year-old dentist charged with murdering three patients with anesthetics surrendered Tuesday and pleaded not guilty in a court appearance.

title: News Anaylsis
description: The margin of 40,000 votes that gave the Chicago mayoral race to Representative Harold Washington also spared the national Democratic Party from a damaging loss of prestige and, for the time being, tamped down black-white conflict within the party.

title: ISLANDERS PREPARED FOR RANGERS AGAIN
description: The Rangers are here on a roll. The Islanders are here on their laurels, clinging to their three Stanley Cups as if they were silver security blankets.

title: Debt Restructure For South Texas
description: South Texas Drilling and Exploration Inc., Houston, announced that it had signed a debt restructuring agreement with its major creditors allowing a deferral until April 1984 of the principal and interest payments due on the company's $25 million principal amount of debt.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atari Inc., a unit of Warner Communications, said it had signed a long-term agreement with Williams Electronics Inc., Chicago, giving Atari first refusal rights for home video and computer games based on Williams's coin-operated amusement games; terms were not disclosed.

title: Westinghouse, Teledyne Off
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, citing a decline in shipments of products to industrial customers, said yesterday that net income in the first quarter dropped 19.4 percent, while sales slipped 2.1 percent.

title: BRIEFING
description: Kohl's Television Woes

title: JURORS HEAR TAPE AT MURDER TRIAL
description: A tape recording that a prosecutor said a construction foreman unwittingly made of his own murder was played for jurors today as the man on trial for the bludgeon killing buried his face in his hands.

title: PRESSURE GROWING ON SALVADOR AIDE
description: The commander of the Salvadoran Air Force said today that unless the country's Defense Minister resigned by Friday his service would disregard the minister's authority.

title: A 'RETURN TO CLASSICISM' IN DISPLAY OF ROOMS
description: CARL LEVINE, senior vice president of Bloomingdale's, said ''the return to classicism'' was the major theme in the store's fifthfloor spring model rooms, which open today. ''In this informal world, there's a seeping in of formality in the home,'' Mr. Levine said of the vignettes, which were opulent as usual.

title: Peachtext 5000
description: Peachtree Software Inc. of Atlanta, a subsidiary of Management Science America Inc., introduced Peachtext 5000 for the small computer market. Priced at $395, the software package combines word processing, financial planning and data-base management for personal computers such as those offered by the International Business Machines Corporation and Texas Instruments. The package is comparable to separate programs that would cost about $1,195, according to Ben Dyer, Peachtree president.

title: Fantasy Campers
description: Fantasies are wonderful to achieve, especially if you can afford them. The latest fantasy craze allows men in their 30's and older to live out their dreams of playing baseball and spend a week learning from former major leaguers.

title: More Stubborn Than Smart on Adelman
description: However the Senate votes today on Kenneth Adelman, the loser will be President Reagan. If it approves Mr. Adelman as head of the arms control agency, the President's authority will have been sapped by the closeness and rancor of the confirmation vote.

title: Braniff Directors, Creditors Meet
description: Directors and unsecured creditors of the Braniff International Corporation met late into tonight in an attempt to reach agreement on a proposal by the Hyatt Corporation to save the airline.

title: RUBBERMAID INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

description: Mayor-elect Harold Washington today joined Mayor Jane M. Byrne, the son of Richard J. Daley, the brother of the unsuccessful Republican mayoral candidate, Bernard E. Epton, and city religious leaders at a luncheon to urge civic unity after the bitter municipal election.

title: CATERPILLAR TRACTOR CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
