title: Article 099624 -- No Title
description: The Senate Budget Committee tonight finished an initial round of drafting a 1984 Government budget that would spend $851 billion, or $8 billion more than President Reagan proposed, an increase of less than 1 percent.

title: FOUNDATION HEADS EXPRESS OPTIMISM
description: Leaders of American foundations displayed a new confidence about their role in attacking social ills at a three-day conference here this week. But, at the same time, they acknowledged uneasiness because of forthcoming Congressional scrutiny of their operations.

title: FLEET FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DNA SYMPOSIUM HEARS OF GAINS IN DIAGNOSIS OF HEREDITARY DISEASE
description: Scientists from around the world who gathered for a symposium marking the 30th anniversary of the discovery of the structure of DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid, were told today that a new technique growing out of that discovery might soon be widely used for prenatal diagnosis of many hereditary diseases.

title: HERS
description: fem*i*nism. n. 1. the doctrine advocating social and political rights of women equal to those of men; 2. (sometimes cap.) an organized movement for the attainment of such rights for women. The Random House Dictionary of the English Language

title: ISLANDERS AT A GLANCE
description: Forwards 9 CLARK GILLIES: Left wing, 6 feet 3 inches, 214 pounds, 29 years old, 21 goals, 20 assists in season. Resumed skating yesterday, nearly a week after surgery for torn knee ligaments, and hopes to play by end of next week. 11 WAYNE MERRICK: Center, 6-1, 198, age 30, 4 goals, 12 assists. Used sparingly this season on fourth line. Good on face-offs. 12 DUANE SUTTER: Right wing, 6-1, 189, age 23, 13 goals, 19 assists. Very physical, enthusiastically works along boards and in corners. Strong shot. 14 BOB BOURNE: Left wing, 6-3, 202, age 29, 20 goals, 42 assists. One of few Islanders to improve on overall points from last year, but goal-scoring was down slightly. Scored twice in first period of Game 3 against Washington, killing Capitals' momentum in series. 17 GREG GILBERT: Left wing, 6-1, 194, age 21, 8 goals, 11 assists. Rookie who spent over half the season, 45 games, with the club. 19 BRYAN TROTTIER: Center, 5-11, 198, age 26, 34 goals, 55 assists, 89 points. Perhaps the best two-way center in the game, a strong checker who has career totals of 312 goals, 537 assists in 620 regular-season games. Has scored 29 points in each of the last three playoff seasons. Strong, durable skater. 20 MATS HALLIN: Right wing-left wing, 6-2, 202, age 25, 7 goals, 7 assists. Played half season and showed versatility. 21 BRENT SUTTER: Center, 5-11, 175 pounds, age 20, 21 goals, 19 assists.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
IN BROOKLYN HEIGHTS THE ELEGANT ART OF PRESERVATION
description: IF preservation in Brooklyn Heights begins in the home, the dominant image here is not the single, splendid house, but one of streets flanked by rows of brownstones. These are buildings that are enormously cooperative in establishing a protective feeling, a human scale, great architectural variety within an overall continuity, and a certain 19th-century social decorum. The sum total of these preserved houses is a preserved neighborhood organization of small lots, intimate streets and private yards - and the very humane living patterns this helps establish.

title: THURSDAY, APRIL 14, 1983; Markets
description: Markets

title: CELANESE CANADA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: WESTINGHOUSE CANADA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BAKER, FENTRESS & CO reports earnings for As of March 31.
FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The New York Power Authority announced yesterday that it will sell, on May 24, $550 million of new revenue bonds that will be used to refund $610 million of outstanding 9 1/2 percent series C general purpose bonds. Underwriters for the financing will be led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: FOOD STAMP PROPOSAL WOULD HURT POOREST FAMILIES, A STUDY REPORTS
description: A study issued today by the Congressional Budget Office said the Reagan Administration's latest proposals for the food stamp program would reduce benefits for many of the poorest families.

title: CAMBODIANS TELL OF HORROR
description: It is still impossible to say how many civilians died this month at O Smach, a Cambodian refugee and guerrilla camp that was shelled and overrun by Vietnamese troops. It is also not known with certainty how they died.

title: BLUEPRINT FOR LOWERING NATURAL GAS PRICES
description: To the Editor:

title: BEN S. CASTLEMAN SR.
description: Ben S. Castleman Sr., the northern Kentucky restaurateur who was the breeder of the champion race horse Seattle Slew, died Tuesday in Lexington, Ky.

title: HAYES-DANA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: CAPITOL TO GET MUSEUM TO HONOR NAZIS' VICTIMS
description: In a ceremony on the Capitol steps, Vice President Bush and the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., today presented a symbolic key for a Holocaust museum honoring Jewish and other victims of Nazi German tyranny.

title: PANEL INCREASES GRANTS FOR ISRAEL
description: A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee has quietly increased the amount of military and economic grants for Israel by $365 million over the amount requested by the Reagan Administration for the 1984 fiscal year, committee members said today.

title: MOST WEST BANK ARABS BLAMING U.S. FOR IMPASSE
description: Leading Palestinians living under Israeli occupation are blaming a variety of parties for the breakdown in talks between King Hussein of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization. Some are still hoping for a renewal of the Jordanian-P.L.O. dialogue on entering American-sponsored negotiations with Israel over the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: The U.N. Today; April 14, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strengthening of the Role of the Or- ganization - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Athletes Found Poor in Reading
description: Most football and basketball players at Iowa State University read below the 10th-grade level and a few can be classified as functionally illiterate, according to the athletic department's academic counselor.

title: IN HARTFORD, IT'S THE BEST AND THE WORST OF TIMES
description: On almost every weekday since she was dismissed from a diesel engine factory here 15 months ago, Flora Hogg has walked through this city looking for work.

title: TV: 'WE, THE ACCUSED' SERIES BEGINS
description: PUBLIC television's ''Mystery!'' bounces back from its periodic doldrums tonight at o 9 o'clock with a five-part series called ''We, the Accused.'' Adapted for the BBC by Julia Jones, the story is based on a novel by Ernest Raymond, a well-known writer in the 1930's.

title: BACKUP BUYER FOR GAF UNIT
description: The GAF Corporation, involved in a bitter proxy battle with dissident shareholders, announced yesterday that it had a backup buyer for its building products business in case the Southwestern General Corporation fails to go through with a deal to buy 80 percent of the operation.

title: FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GAF CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $1,026,000. c-Including a tax credit of $1,053,000, an extraordinary tax credit of $1,057,000 and income from discontinued operations of $5,303,000. Year-ago results include income of $5.4 million from the sale of tax credits.

title: W.R.G. Named Agency For Supercuts Shops
description: Wells, Rich, Greene, always ready to take on a new creative challenge, has just become agency for Supercuts, a San Franciscobased chain of franchised hair-cutting shops.

title: G.M. Recalling 16,000 Workers
description: The General Motors Corporation announced the recall of 16,000 workers from indefinite layoff at four assembly plants and their accompanying component plants, beginning in May, as a result of planned production increases.

title: Put Legal Back Into Legal Services
description: The Comptroller General says it's legal to pay $221 a day to the directors of the Legal Services Corporation even though none of those appointed by President Reagan has yet been confirmed by the Senate. Though that's technically right, the moral and political wrong continues and Congress should fix it.

title: IN CEDAR RAPIDS, IOWA, FACTORY WORK LAGS BEHIND GROWTH IN SERVICE JOBS
description: Prosperity in this little city is like a good friend who went away in 1979, and as the nation struggles to come out of its recession people here are beginning to wonder if their friend will be as kind to everyone as he was before he left.

title: PUPILS SHOW GAINS IN EASY ARITHMETIC
description: After a decline in the 1970's, American students are doing better at simple arithmetic but still have trouble using those skills to solve problems, according to a Government survey released yesterday.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a pre-tax gain of $12,700,000 from the sale of cable television systems. c-Includes a pre-tax gain of $26,000,000 from the revision of the previously recorded estimated future cost of the company's discontinued offshore power systems project.

title: GAB Business Services Getting New President
description: John P. Holloway has been named president of GAB Business Services Inc., which provides the insurance industry with claims-adjustment services. This is a business that does well in catastrophe; lately the pace has picked up as floods and other disasters have struck parts of the nation.

title: Giants Trade Jeter For Draft Choices
description: Gary Jeter, a starting defensive end for the Giants for three years until his knee was injured early last season, was traded yesterday to the Los Angeles Rams for at least two choices in the college draft April 26.

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for As of March 31.
description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: Greenville, N.C., to Strike 'Colored' From Memorial
description: A Vietnam veteran has persuaded Pitt County officials to remove the designation ''colored'' from a monument listing those killed in the nation's wars.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago results have been restated to reflect pooling of interest methods.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $51,000,000 from the cumulative effect of accounting changes.

title: EUROPEAN AMERICAN BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Military Analysis
description: Iran, which began an offensive against Iraq on Sunday, has shown ''little imagination'' in its attacks so far, according to a report from a Western military observer in Iraq.

title: FIRST BANCORP OF OHIO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FOR DURABLE FINISH ON STRIPPED OAK
description: Oak's popularity has been renewed in recent years, and one will hear of an avid collector with an addiction to it in every shape and form. Such a collector's home literally groans under the sheer weight, from hallway hatstand to converted sewing machine, Victrola, icebox, bed and crib.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Saucier Switches Controls
description: The end, and the beginning, took place a week ago at Parker Field in Richmond, Va. The Richmond Braves, the top farm club of the Atlanta Braves and Kevin Saucier's new team, were about to have the first workout since leaving their West Palm Beach, Fla., training camp. At the point of the baseball season when he had not lost a game that counted, when there is normally the most reason for hope, Kevin Saucier felt the most hopeless.

title: A Switch to Pitt
description: Curtis Aiken, the high-scoring high school guard from Buffalo who had previously announced plans to attend Kansas, decided instead on Pittsburgh yesterday, the first day on which basketball recruits were permitted to sign national letters of intent. The decision was made after the Jayhawks' new coach, Larry Brown, had flown to Buffalo with his top assistants in an effort to get Aiken to keep an oral commitment he had made to Kansas.

title: 3 More Lippizaners Die
description: Herpes virus has killed three more Lippizaner foals, bringing to 39 the number of horses that have died in the two-month-old outbreak.

title: BRITISH SEEK VETO ON USE OF MISSILES
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is coming under increasing pressure to seek surer British control over American cruise missiles to be based in this country, and she is likely to raise the issue with President Reagan when they meet in Williamsburg, Va., next month, according to ranking members of the Conservative Party.

title: Kissinger Named
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger accepted yesterday an invitation from the United States Soccer Federation to serve as chairman of the country's 1986 World Cup Organizing Committee. He will work closely with Werner Fricker, the federation's executive vice president, in efforts to bring the 1986 World Cup to the United States.

title: Q and A
description: How many New Yorkers does it take to broil a steak?

title: WALTER E. HOUGHTON
description: Dr. Walter E. Houghton, professor emeritus of English literature at Wellesley College and a Victorian scholar, died of viral pneumonia Monday at Wellesley Hospital in Newton, Mass.

title: PENTAGON SEEKING MORE IN RESEARCH
description: The Defense Department proposes to spend $10 billion over the next five years for research on defensive arms, including lasers, that would be intended to defeat nuclear missile attacks, according to a confidential Pentagon memorandum.

title: WILLIAM A. DURBIN
description: William A. Durbin, a former chairman of the Hill and Knowlton public relations company, died at his home Tuesday in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: JUROR SELECTION BY JUDGES GETS JURIST'S SUPPORT
description: New York State's Chief Judge said today that judges should pick juries and that there was no need to test the idea, as some legislators and Governor Cuomo have suggested.

title: RIEGEL TEXTILE CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: Results for the latest quarter include pre-tax capital gains of $2,012,000, or 38 cents a share.

title: TOWN'S PISTOL BAN SUPPORTED
description: The nation's strictest pistol ordinance got a vote of support Tuesday as residents here rejected four Village Board candidates who said they would try to rescind the measure if elected.

title: MONEY FUND RATES AT BANKS DECLINE
description: The interest rates on money market deposit accounts offered by banks declined slightly this week in New York and throughout the nation, the Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.

title: DEKALB AGRESEARCH INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $2.4 million.

title: KING RADIO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WAGNER ELECTION FOR SCHOOLS POST IS MADE OFFICIAL
description: The New York City Board of Education officially designated Robert F. Wagner Jr. as Chancellor of the public school system last night at a two-and-a-half-hour meeting marked by frequent outbursts, demonstrations and charges of racism from the predominantly black audience.

title: Tankers in Search of Cargo
description: The owners of tankers built with Federal subsidies for international trade want to reimburse the American taxpayer and gain the right to compete for domestic shipping. The Transportation Department wants to accept the deal to reduce Federal deficits and also to increase competition in the transport of Alaskan oil. But the influential owners of the domestic tanker fleet are bitterly opposed. They are also determined to test the mettle of Elizabeth Dole, the new Secretary of Transportation. She should hold firm.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, APRIL 14, 1983
description: International ''An apparent violation of the law'' has been committed by the Reagan Administration in providing covert aid to Nicaraguan insurgents, according to Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachusetts. Mr. Boland, who is chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, convened the panel to consider appropriate action. (Page A1, Column 6.) The highest-ranking Angolan official to visit Washington held an unpublicized meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said the two officials discussed possible ways to resolve the problems of South African occupation of South-West Africa and the presence of Cuban troops in Angola. (A1:5.)

title: Pope Commemorates Warsaw Ghetto Uprising
description: Pope John Paul II commemorated the 40th anniversary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising today as ''a desperate cry for the right to life, for life and for the salvation of the dignity of man.''

title: CANRAD-HANOVIA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Required Reading; Tribute to Burton
description: Excerpts of remarks made on the floor of the House by Representative Les AuCoin, Democrat of Oregon, in tribute to Representative Phillip Burton, Democrat of California, who died Sunday in San Francisco, April 11, 1983:

title: Missing B52 Found; All 7 Aboard Dead
description: The wreckage of a B-52 bomber missing on a training flight since Monday was found today in southern Utah, an Air Force official said.

title: ADOLESCENTS' SEX: THE ENTICEMENTS AROUND THEM
description: To the Editor:

title: HARLAND, JOHN H, CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AMERICAN BOOK AWARDS ANNOUNCED
description: Alice Walker has won the American Book Award for fiction for ''The Color Purple,'' her novel about a poor Southern black woman's struggle for independence. Fox Butterfield, who in 1979 became the first correspondent of The New York Times in 30 years to be based in Peking, won the general nonfiction award for his book ''China: Alive in the Bitter Sea.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mary Decker Tabb was spending a precautionary few days at a hospital in Portand, Ore., after being shaken up in a car accident on Monday. ... Dickie Noles, the Chicago Cub pitcher who was arrested after a barroom brawl last Saturday, was placed on the 21-day disabled list while he undergoes rehabilitation for alcohol abuse. ... The jockey Larry Saumell, in whose car traces of cocaine and marijuana were found last month, has been suspended from racing for 90 days and placed on probation for a year by the Thoroughbred Racing Association. Deborah Reeson, an exercise rider who was with Saumell at the time of the search by the Thoroughred Racing Protective Bureau, received the same punishment. Both have agreed to enter a drug rehabilitation program, with the understanding that their suspensions would be lifted when treatment is completed. ... The actor Lee Majors has bought an interest in the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League.

title: NAPLES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (FLA) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid April 1, 1983 and a 10 percent stock dividend paid March 29, 1982.

title: SYKES DATATRONICS INC reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
ALTOS COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
L. H. Wright, Law Professor And Expert on Income Taxes
description: Lafayette Hart Wright, professor of law at the University of Michigan and a consultant on United States income taxes and European tax procedures, died Tuesday while undergoing treatment for lung cancer at the Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore. He was 65 years old and lived in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: U.S. SHOWS BIAS AGAINST REGION, 3 GOVERNORS SAY
description: The Governors of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, sharing a dais for the first time, pushed partisan differences aside last night to complain that the Northeast was the victim of discrimination in Federal policy.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: STAINED GLASS SHOW
description: A Spring of Stained Glass, Glassmasters Guild, 621 Avenue of the Americas (19th Street), 212-924-2868.

title: ARENS, ATTACKING U.S., CITES NEED FOR ISRAELI WEAPONS INDEPENDENCE
description: Defense Minister Moshe Arens said today that President Reagan's decision to withhold F-16 fighter planes from Israel had provoked a decision in the defense establishment here to reduce Israeli dependence on American weapons and to build up the domestic arms industry.

title: Clinch River Funds Seen
description: Private investors may be willing to put more than $1 billion into the controversial Clinch River Breeder Reactor project, but only if they are assured the plant actually will be built, Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel said today.

title: BARRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
LORNA PUMROY O'BRIEN
description: Lorna Pumroy O'Brien, who was active for many years with the Visiting Nurse Service and other charitable organizations in New York City, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HANDLING PROBLEMS OF A SOGGY SPRING
description: WILL April showers bring May flowers? Most certainly, but the ground will have to dry first. Although record rainfall has done little damage to the plants, six rainy weekends in a row depressed gardeners' spirits.

title: REGULAR LIVES FOR MANY RETARDED
description: Men and women who once could have expected to spend their lives in institutions for the mentally retarded have been earning wages and learning skills instead.

title: NEW WRITERS
description: Those who ponder the eternal question about where the new playwrights are may do well to visit the Circle Repertory Company, 99 Seventh Avenue South, at Sheridan Square (924-7100), and catch the second annual Young Playwrights Festival, which will run through May 1.

title: STUART HALL CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
GROUP OPPOSES BILL FOR SPORTS HUNTING IN ALASKA PARKLAND
description: The Alaska Coalition, which is regrouping to fight legislation that would open national parks in Alaska to sports hunting, said today that the proposal was a threat to the entire park system.

title: Wanting Children
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: ASTHMA DRUG MOVE CALLED HAZARDOUS
description: Leading experts and professional groups are challenging the Food and Drug Administration's approval of the nonprescription use of an inhaler drug for asthma.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IT-YOURSELFERS who once limited themselves to simple repairs or small improvements have increasingly moved on to more ambitious projects such as remodeling a bathroom or kitchen, jobs that have steadily been climbing in cost when done professionally.

title: Horace J. Bryant Dead; Commissioner in Jersey
description: Horace J. Bryant, the first black to become a Cabinet member in New Jersey, died yesterday at a convalescent home near Atlantic City. He was 73 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: ST. JUDE MEDICAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INVENTORIES UP 0.1% IN FEBRUARY
description: Business inventories rose one-tenth of 1 percent in February, the first monthly rise since September, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: THUNANDER CORP reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
KEY HOUSE MEMBER FEARS U.S. BREAKS LAW ON NICARAGUA
description: The chairman of the House Intelligence Committee said today that the Administration apparently has violated the law by providing covert aid to Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Caterpillar Posts Loss
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company, the nation's largest maker of earth-moving machinery and equipment, yesterday reported a firstquarter loss of $172 million, compared with a profit of $42 million, or 48 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: NEW COMMITTEE OPPOSES TAXING OF ARTS GROUPS
description: Cyrus R. Vance, the former Secretary of State, and Martin E. Segal, chairman of the board of Lincoln Center, have formed a committee that will seek to persuade Mayor Koch to alter his policy of collecting real-estate taxes from cultural and arts institutions that are now exempt.

title: KILLERS AND CYNICS
description: Dr. Issam Sartawi, the P.L.O. diplomat, knew he was risking his life when he spoke out for peace with Israel. And he knew who the likely killers were: the Abu Nidal gang. When I saw him in Paris last year, he told me how the gang had murdered other P.L.O. moderates as well as, in his words, ''carrying out a series of atrocious acts against Jews in Europe.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT ON CITY TAX BREAKS FOR NONPROFIT GROUPS
description: Following are excerpts from a report to Mayor Koch by the City Task Force on the Exemption of Nonprofit Organizations From Real Property Tax, headed by Frederick A.O. Schwarz Jr., the city's Corporation Counsel:

title: 1982 U.S. Gold Coins Start Selling, Slowly
description: Gold dealers reported widespread public interest in the Treasury's 1982 gold medallions that went on sale for the first time yesterday. But they conceded that sales were far below those of the South African Krugerrand, Canadian Maple Leaf, Mexican Peso and other popular bullion coins.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
DECORATIVE MOLDINGS
description: ORNAMENTAL ceiling medallions and cornice moldings can create elegance and distinction. Their texture, shadow and highlights soften the break between ceiling and wall and add interest when placed around a door or fireplace.

title: Resume to President Brings Man a Job
description: Ronald D. Bricker, the 39-year-old unemployed steelworker who dashed up to President Reagan last week and handed him his resume, got a job today.

title: Intermountain
description: Intermountain Health Care Hospitals Inc., a consortium of Utahbased hospitals, has sold $127 million of revenue re-funding bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The bonds, which are expected to carry an Aa rating, were tentatively priced to yield from 5.5 percent in 1985 to 9.1 percent in 1998 and 9 3/8 percent in 2012. In addition, 5 percent bonds due in 2015 were tentatively priced at 59.545 to yield 8.8 percent to maturity.

title: Robert Milano Due For Post at Center
description: Robert J. Milano will be named today to the board of the corporation building the Convention Center, a spokesman for the State Urban Development Corporation confirmed yesterday.

title: BONANZA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Technology; Slides From Computers
description: THE use of computers to instantly draw charts and graphs has been expanding rapidly. But turning those charts into slides for business presentations has been hard and costly. That could change if the Polaroid Corporation succeeds with a new device it will introduce in May.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Panel Clears Funds For Synthetic Fuels
description: The United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation today made its first monetary award, assigning funds to a North Carolina project, and also signed a promised $120 million letter of intent for a California proposal, a spokesman said.

title: ANTIQUES SHOW AND TOUR
description: The Brooklyn Heights house tour will be held on May 14 from 1 to 4 P.M. The antiques show will start on Thursday night, May 12, with a preview reception from 6:30 to 9 P.M., and will run through Saturday. House tour tickets are available, on an advance sale basis only, for $15, and include admission to the antiques show and tea in the church garden.

title: Associate Director Leaving Budget Office
description: Lawrence A. Kudlow, associate director of the Office of Management and Budget and one of the Administration's key economic strategists, said yesterday that he would resign later this spring to go into investment management and financial consulting.

title: WALESA DETAINED 5 HOURS BY POLICE
description: The police held Lech Walesa in custody for five hours today, questioning him about his secret meeting with five fugitive leaders of the underground Solidarity movement.

title: CONSUMER ADVICE ON TAPE IS POPULAR
description: IN the 15 months since the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs established Tel-Consumer/Tel-Law, the department has received more than 14,000 calls from New Yorkers for the tape-recorded consumer information service. The most popular consumer tapes, the department says, concern problems of the home.

title: FEDERAL FARM SUPPORT WITH THE SKY AS THE LIMIT
description: To the Editor:

title: BANCOKLAHOMA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Anonymous Jury Set in Brink's Case
description: An anonymous jury of five men and seven women was tentatively completed yesterday for a trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan involving the Brink's case and other crimes.

title: No Argument
description: The customer was tall enough to intimidate most folks. But three of the men in the Memphis pawn shop had guns, so when they ordered Keith Lee to lie on the floor during their robbery Tuesday, the 6-foot-9-inch all-America forward from Memphis State obliged.

title: PROFESSIONAL CARE OF LAWNS INCREASES
description: WITH leaves of grass creeping upward and the whine of neighbors' lawn mowers not far away, homeowners in ever greater numbers are turning to large chain- or franchise-operated lawn services that promise to take the work and the worry out of maintaining a patch of green.

title: IKE LOVELADY INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
INTERNATIONAL MULTIFOODS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THE DANCE: NEW WORKS HIGHLIGHTED
description: THERE was a time when young dancers just wanted to dance. Now, it appears, they also want to choreograph. Two members of major companies who obviously fall into this category are Daniel Duell of the New York City Ballet and David Parsons of the Paul Taylor Dance Company.

title: Celebrating Tet
description: Tet began yesterday for Southeast Asians, and about 200 Cambodians, Laotians, Burmese and Thais sardined themselves into a tiny room that serves as a temple in the International Zen Center of New York, on East 31st Street.

title: MORGAN'S NET INCOME CLIMBS 37%
description: J.P. Morgan & Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose to $117.8 million, an increase of 37 percent over the $86 million earned in the first quarter of 1982. On a per-share basis, net income rose to $2.76, from $2.09. The company's primary subsidiary is the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank.

title: Gala Benefit to Open American Ballet Season
description: American Ballet Theater will open its 11-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House on May 2 with a gala benefit.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net income.

title: 32-Team Field
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament continues to grow. Bobby Knight, Indiana's outspoken coach, says it should move in the opposite direction.

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Playoff Extension Off for This Year
description: Representatives of major league baseball's players and club owners agreed yesterday that the owners' idea to expand the league championship series to seven games was dead for this season.

title: SIDEWALK GOODS OF DISCOUNTERS SEIZED IN RAIDS
description: A new crackdown on illegal peddling began yesterday with the police and other enforcement agents seizing goods displayed in front of discount stores along 14th and 34th Streets.

title: CERTAINTEED CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: ROWAN COS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ARAFAT IS SAID TO EXPECT RENEWED TALKS
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, expects interrupted talks between the P.L.O. and Jordan on a Middle East peace initiative to resume, Scandinavian politicians who met him here reported today.

title: BANKS DIFFER ON WITHHOLDING REPEAL
description: President Reagan picked up some support today from several leading bankers in his fight against the Congressional attempt to repeal the withholding of taxes on interest and dividends.

title: Bolivia and U.S. Report Plans For Step-Up in Drive on Drugs
description: Bolivia will step up its drive against drug-trafficking, according to a joint statement today by the visiting United States Attorney General, William French Smith, and the Bolivian Foreign Minister, Mario Velarde.

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NEW RURAL AMERICA NEEDS NO SUBSIDIES
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY WORK PLAN TO FIGHT WELFARE RISE
description: New York City's welfare rolls have increased for the first time in seven years, Mayor Koch said yesterday. To help cope with the rise, he announced a program to put to work some recipients of Aid to Families With Dependent Children.

title: Exxon Says It Will Pay New State Receipts Tax
description: The Exxon Corporation has said it will pay a new state tax on the gross receipts of oil companies, despite its doubts over the legality of the measure. At least one other company, Mobil, has threatened not to pay the tax.

title: LAIDLAW INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 14, 1983.

title: VICTOR'S BACKERS SEE SHIFT IN POWER
description: It was midnight at Representative Harold Washington's campaign headquarters at Donnelley Hall. The air was charged with tension, excitement and expectation as many of the nearly 20,000 people in the exhibition hall crowded around a handful of television sets to watch the latest election returns.

title: ALASKA GOVERNOR CONVENES AN INQUIRY ON HIMSELF

title: REID EXPECTS A TOUGH BATTLE FOR EXECUTIVE IN WESTCHESTER
description: Ogden R. Reid, a former six-term Representative who scored an upset victory Tuesday night as the Democratic nominating convention's choice for Westchester County Executive, began preparations today for what he said would be a ''tough and serious'' campaign.

title: CONCERT: MISS BEHRENS AND BOSTON SYMPHONY
description: OURS is an age of specialists, in singing as in most other fields of art and commerce. So a soprano who wants to spread her talents prodigally around the vocal landscape, such as Hildegard Behrens, can bring us up short. Miss Behrens, it would seem, aims at being a soprano of the versatile type that vocal historians say once roamed the earth in sizable numbers but is now virtually extinct. This season, for instance, Miss Behrens sang Sieglinde, a robust but lyric role, in the Metropolitan Opera's ''Walkure,'' and the heavy, fiercely difficult solo part in Schoenberg's ''Erwartung'' at the New York Philharmonic.

title: FIRST OF AMERICA BANK reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
A LESSON IN ADVISING AND CONSENTING
description: The Senate is scheduled to vote Thursday on the nomination of Kenneth L. Adelman to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. The vote is expected to be close, but critics of the nomination feel they have accomplished an important purpose no matter how the final tally comes out.

title: NASSAU DECLINES TO SUE MARGIOTTA OVER KICKBACKS
description: Nassau County leaders have decided not to exercise the county's right to sue Joseph M. Margiotta, the chairman of the Nassau Republican Committee, to recover $700,000 in kickbacks he was convicted of collecting and distributing to party loyalists.

title: Market Place; Taking a Look At Health Care
description: THE Government's program to curb health care costs, putting limits on what Medicaid and Medicare will pay for 467 different ailments, is set to begin next Oct. 1.

title: FILIBUSTER BLOCKS SENATE IN ALBANY
description: For the first time in memory, the New York State Senate has been stopped dead by a filibuster. Today, for the second consecutive day, the 60 members of the New York State Senate met without considering a single bill. Republicans raged at Democrats, accusing them of ''putting on a sophomoric show.'' Democrats railed at Republicans, charging them with ''genetic arrogance.'' The filibuster was staged by the Democratic minority to protest what members said was unfair treatment at the hands of the Republican majority.

title: Keeping Pace
description: As reports circulated that a group led by Reggie Jackson was on the verge of closing a deal to buy the Indiana Pacers and move them to Anaheim, Calif., Mayor William Hudnut of Indianapolis flew to New York yesterday on behalf of a group of rival investors who hope to keep the team in Indianapolis. Mayor Hudnut conferred with Larry O'Brien, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, who said the meeting had been informative.

title: Grading the Schools
description: Lisa Shelton had a dream. The 18-year-old senior at Booker T. Washington High School here thought she might want to be a computer engineer. One day, in their apartment in a public housing project, she confided this dream to her mother. According to Miss Shelton, her mother responded, ''Oh, you can't be no engineer, you know that, girl.'' And that settled that. Then, one day at school, Miss Shelton met Jerry Hill. He suggested that she reject such negative talk, that she set her goals to become anything she wanted and not let others make her decisions. Ordinarily, Miss Shelton and her classmates might have dismissed such talk as coming from an idealistic teacher unfamiliar with the real world. Businesses Aid Experiment

title: FROM BRITAIN, ADELAIDE HALL AND HER CABARET ACT
description: LIFE has not been a song for Adelaide Hall. It has been a countermelody. During Miss Hall's singing career, which began 62 years ago in the black musical ''Shuffle Along'' and is continuing now at the Cookery, where she is appearing this weekend and all next week, through April 23, she has been known primarily for two tunes - ''I Can't Give You Anything but Love'' and ''Creole Love Call.'' She gained her lifelong identification with both songs within seven months, between October 1927 and May 1928, although she never actually sang either of them in that period. In both cases she created a countermelody.

It wants to be about love and style and dancing and ambition, about how, as one character puts it, ''when you give up your dream, you die.'' All those things that ''Saturday Night Fever'' was about, in other words.

title: AMONG CLASSICAL LANGUAGES, GREEK IS A HAS-BEEN
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW LIFE FOR THE 42D STREET LIBRARY
description: Public libraries have traditionally been refuges, places to which people go not only to work and to learn, but also to escape from the pressures and tensions of the city. For most of the last generation, the New York Public Library's great central building at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street has functioned well enough for its primary purpose - research - but poorly indeed for its secondary one. It had become so physically uncared-for a place that it could not signify escape from anything, except perhaps the tranquillity and dignity of its original architecture. The presence of blocked-off windows, of marble galleries filled with filing cabinets, of ornately carved ceilings punctured by fluorescent lighting, all gave a sense of scholarship as drudgery, as duty and not as pleasure.

title: SURPRISES ARE NO SURPRISE ON OFF OFF BROADWAY
description: BY definition, Off Off Broadway is a floating festival of diverse theatrical events, offering something for every taste. This weekend in particular, the scene is alive with promising entertainments. The emphasis is very much on spectacle, but in typical, experimental fashion, the spectacle can be an extravagant musical drawn from the Biblical plagues, Shakespeare transplanted to ancient China or a trio of inspired tomfools. And to even the score, there are new plays by very young dramatists and a restorative revival of a drama by Tennessee Williams. Two prolific theaters are showcasing a range of work by favorite sons and daughters. In the vast expanse of La Mama Annex is a musical called ''The Plagues,'' written by Eve Merriam and Tom O'Horgan, and directed by Mr. O'Horgan. In residence on other La Mama stages are Paul Zimet's Talking Band, doing an ensemble play with music titled ''Hot Lunch Apostles,'' and Harris Yulin, a Broadway star, playing the title buncombe artist in Richard Ploetz's ''Barnum's Last Life.'' At the nearby Theater for the New City, 162 Second Avenue, at 10th Street, Leonard Melfi, a graduate of both La Mama and Theater for the New City, is showcasing a new epic musical, ''Rosetti's Apologies,'' while on another New City stage, Stuart Sherman is demonstrating his one-man, world-in-a-suitcase art with a performance piece called ''13 Spectacle'' (tickets for both $4; information: 254-1109).

title: Coach Under Fire
description: Tom Meyer, basketball coach at the University of Illinois-Chicago Circle and son of Coach Ray Meyer of DePaul, said, ''My basketball players at a secret meeting last March 30 demanded that I resign or they would refuse to play for me.'' Meyer had left a meeting of the players, Athletic Director Bill Rohtzheim and Vice Chancellor Richard Ward. The parties had been negotiating a settlement to what many of the players referred to as an ''impossible situation.''

title: STAGE: 'LE BOURGEOIS,' COMEDY AFTER MOLIERE
description: CHARLES LUDLAM'S new farce, ''Le Bourgeois Avant-Garde,'' bills itself as ''a comedy after Moliere,'' and that's about the only line of the evening that's not a joke. Mr. Ludlam - director, author-inpermanent-residence and star of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company at One Sheridan Square - has indeed rewritten ''Le Bourgeois Gentilhomme,'' transposing it to the present day. By turns viciously funny, tasteless, slapdash and rude, this play is Mr. Ludlam's brightest prank since he assaulted analysands in ''Reverse Psychology'' three seasons ago.

title: STATUS OF NEW YORK TENANTS' RIGHTS TO SUBLET IS HAZY
description: A recent decision in a New York sublet case seems to have added to the confusion over who the courts believe should have the right to control the choice of new occupants when tenants move out of rental apartments.

title: EGYPTIANS ARE DISAPPOINTED BY THE JORDANIAN-P.L.O. RIFT
description: While publicly saying that the current setback is only temporary, Egyptian officials are privately disappointed that King Hussein of Jordan has abandoned plans for a joint approach with the Palestine Liberation Organization aimed at talks with Israel.

title: THE CALM HEAD OF HUBIE BROWN
description: Must be positive, must be upbeat, Hubert Jude Brown, coach of the Knicks, told himself last Sunday. How to convince his players of this, however, might be a chore. This was after the 76ers defeated the Knicks by 16 points, 113-97, and Hubie Brown had to keep his team from wallowing in disappointment.

title: A Declaration joins 'Salute'
description: THE London-based New York auction houses are participating in the ''Britain Salutes New York'' festival with sales of some extraordinary historical material relating to the American Revolution and to British history. These include a previously unknown copy of the Declaration of Independence, a rare group of 18 documents relating to the Treaty of Paris of 1783 that ended the Revolution and silver vessels that once belonged to British royalty. All of these go on view tomorrow and will be up for bidding over the next 11 days.

description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today delayed restarting the Salem 1 nuclear plant in South Jersey until questions about the quality of the management at the plant were resolved.

title: A RULE EXCLUDING JUSTICE
description: Consider this scenario: Federal inspectors discover that a nuclear power plant is emitting dangerous levels of radiation. But a judge prohibits the Government from closing the plant because the inspectors, in the course of their investigation, allegedly violated the plant owner's rights. The plant, meanwhile, is allowed to continue threatening the health and safety of the community.

title: McGraw to Retire As Chief Executive
description: Harold W. McGraw Jr., 65 years old and ''on active duty with McGraw-Hill for the past 36,'' announced yesterday that he will retire as chief executive officer of the big New York publisher on April 26. He will be succeeded by Joseph L. Dionne, 49, McGraw-Hill's president since 1981.

title: Lifeboats for Brazil
description: The riots in Brazil's largest city, Sao Paulo, are at least as important as other hemisphere conflicts. Brazil isn't a domino, it's half a continent. Its stability has been shaken by three years of economic decline, crushing foreign debts and an inflation rate of 10 percent a month. All this coincides with tense effort to move from dictatorship to democracy.

title: NEW YORK ADOPTS A BRITISH ACCENT FOR ARTS FESTIVAL
description: A stranger in New York these days might well be forgiven for doubting that the War of Independence was ever fought, never mind won. The city is awash, and will be for several months, in British displays, exhibitions, accents and titles. Whether more is better is a moot point but if indeed it is the British have won the national promotion sweepstakes hands down.

title: CRITICS TELL OF 'BARRIERS' FROM A 2D CITY AREA CODE
description: Residents of Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, testifying yesterday at an often-raucous public hearing, complained that the New York Telephone Company's plan to change their area code would harm community morale, disrupt businesses and lead to higher phone bills.

title: 'SPIELBERG'S 'DUEL,' FOUR-WHEEL COMBAT
description: STEVEN SPIELBERG first made his mark with a film about a diabolical truck, a subject that would seem to have only limited possibilities. In fact, Mr. Spielberg's 1971 television film ''Duel'' took advantage of the very narrowness of its premise, building excitement from the most minimal ingredients and the simplest of situations. The theatrical version of ''Duel'' at the Manhattan Twin theater may contain a few extra close-ups of its leading man's nose, but otherwise it works as well on the wide screen as it did on the small one. Even without benefit of hindsight, ''Duel'' looks like the work of an unusually talented young director.

title: Layoffs in Netherlands
description: The Hoogovens Group plans to lay off 1,000 more workers at its plant here, a union spokesman said today. The plant now employs 13,000 people full time and 5,500 part time.

title: ART: ONE MAN'S BIENNIAL ASSEMBLES 102 ARTISTS
description: IT takes a certain chutzpah to assemble a grab bag of works by 102 artists more or less on the current scene and to come up with a viable show. But Nicolas A. Moufarrege, an artist and art writer from Lebanon via Paris who now lives in this country, has managed to bring it off. His ''Intoxication,'' at the Monique Knowlton Gallery, 153 Mercer Street (through May 7), is a kind of one man's Whitney Biennial with a strictly New York flavor. Its huge local cast includes stars, bit players and even amateurs, ranging from a 5-yearold who paints like, well, a 5-year-old, to the sophisticated Italian imports Enzo Cucchi and Francesco Clemente.

title: POLICE, USING A SINGLE FINGERPRINT, ARREST SUSPECT IN WALDORF MURDER

title: SCULPTURE: MEL KENDRICK
description: A YOUNG sculptor who originally comes from Boston, Mel Kendrick makes some of his contemporaries look as if they were just pumping iron, esthetically speaking. Where they aspire to the grandiose in noble and industrial materials, he works concisely, small and for the most part in wood. Few of the pieces in the artist's show at John Weber, 142 Greene Street, are more than three feet tall and all are mounted at eye level on metal stands. They are, moreover, more closely related to Cubism and tribal art than to later-20th-century movements. Earlier in his short career, though, Mr. Kendrick was practicing a romantic kind of Constructivism, and he is also appearing in a group show called ''New Biomorphism and Automatism'' at the Hamilton Gallery, 20 West 57th Street.

CONSTABLE'S ENGLAND
description: WHO better than John Constable could inaugurate ''Britain Salutes New York,'' the free-form festival of British art, music, theater, dance, literature, movies, photography and video, which opened this week and will continue through much of the summer? ''Constable's England,'' opening tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is in that context about as well timed as an exhibition can be. More than anyone else, John Constable (1776-1837) is Mr. English Landscape. (His chief rival in that regard, J.M.W. Turner, had a pan-European activity that puts him in a less local category.) Constable was reared in an English landscape. He made his name with an English landscape. In times of stress, he even said his prayers in front of one of his English landscapes. In fact, he did everything a man can do with an English landscape except eat it.

title: OLD FRIENDS, NEW START
description: WITH the regular season coming to a close, commercial television is getting increasingly clogged with reruns. And as it happens, two of the more interesting programming developments this weekend can be found on cable television - pay cable, at that - which is moving gingerly into the traditional television area of the regular series. Tonight at 8 o'clock, Showtime presents the first of seven new episodes that are resurrecting ''The Paper Chase,'' the failed but acclaimed CBS-TV series. Tomorrow night at 10, Home Box Office will offer ''Philip Marlowe, Private Eye,'' a five-part weekly series based on the mystery stories of Raymond Chandler. If these projects attract attention and subscribers, obviously much more of the same will be on the way.

And Still The MX
description: The Scowcroft commission makes much sense in its recommendations for a switch to arms control limitations on warheads rather than on launchers, and for development of a smaller, single-warhead missile as the best way to achieve a survivable force of land-based ICBM's. But the commission is not so persuasive in linking these proposals to its plan for deploying 100 MX missiles in existing Minuteman silos.

He had been coach since 1977. His team won the national cross-country title last year.

title: Toledo Edison Co.

Underwriters at the Merrill Lynch White Weld Capital Markets Group said the 1.2 million shares of preferred stock were all sold but for ''tag ends'' at a price of $27 1/2 a share with a dividend of $3.47 a share.

title: POP JAZZ
description: A MUSICIAN'S tone is his signature - especially in jazz, where players declare allegiances and antipathies, conscious or unconscious, by developing an individual voice. Because the modern jazz revolutions have been spearheaded by saxophonists - the alto players Charlie Parker and Ornette Coleman, the tenor players Lester Young, Sonny Rollins and John Coltrane - it is especially tempting to characterize saxophone players by their models, as Coltrane-style players, or heirs to Coleman.

title: SOVIET GAIETY
description: THE Soviet gaiety to be found in Pyotr Todorovsky's ''Waiting for Gavrilov'' is so atypical you may start to think it's April in Paris. Actually, it's springtime in Odessa, where a buoyant young woman and her buoyant friends and family rush to City Hall. They're on their way to a wedding - hers -except that the bridegroom doesn't arrive. So the family skips the wedding feast and goes home. And the would-be bride wanders blithely through the park near City Hall, having all sorts of wholesome, life-affirming encounters with the strangers she meets there.

title: HYATT CHIEF QUITS CONTINENTAL AMID BRANIFF TALKS
description: Jay A. Pritzker, chairman of the Hyatt Corporation, has resigned from the board of Continental Air Lines, the carrier said today. The move, apparently to avoid a conflict of interest, came as Mr. Pritzker offered a ''revised and improved'' proposal to revive Braniff International, according Irma Jensen, a Braniff representative.

title: A Vote Against Knight
description: The New York City Council unanimously passed a resolution yesterday asking the United States Olympic Committee to remove Bobby Knight of Indiana University as head coach of this country's basketball team at the Games in Los Angeles next year.

title: HOW FLOOD AND A BLOWN FUSE CUT OFF NEW ORLEANS
description: A flooded basement and the failure of a $2 fuse in a generator crippled the long-distance telecommunications system of this city for 10 hours last week and severed its link with a nuclear attack warning system.

title: Friday; BLUES BOSS AT NEW SCHOOL
description: Big Joe Turner, known to his fans as the ''boss of the blues,'' started out more than five decades ago, worked with Count Basie, Duke Elllington and Benny Goodman, and influenced generations of singers. In the 1950's, he anticipated rock-and-roll with his hits ''Shake, Rattle and Roll'' and ''Honey Hush.'' Tonight from 6 to 7:30 he will be singing at the New School, 66 West 12th Street, with his longtime pianist Ernest Hayes. Tickets, at $6, will be available a half-hour before the performance. Information: 741-5690. REBIRTH AT LYNDHURST

FOR DISARMING EUROPE
description: For three years, on both sides of the Atlantic, there have been conferences and church meetings and marches and agonizing over the fate of the Earth. Well, are we serious or not? Somewhere, at some time, some people have got to decide that they will say no. We in the European peace movement have decided that the place is Europe and the time is now and that the people will have to be us. Europe is the noman's-land between the superpowers where at last the nuclear arms race might be stopped.

title: Bid for Rockingham
description: Max Hugel, a former Central Intelligence Agency official, and the owners of the Seabrook greyhound race track signed an option to buy the burned-out Rockingham Park racing track, a lawyer for the prospective buyers said. The 30-day option on the $12.5 million track cost Mr. Hugel and the Seabrook dog track owners $50,000, according to Joseph Millimet, the lawyer. Mr. Millimet declined to discuss what the group, the Rockingham Venture, planned to do with the 260-acre Salem track, which has been idle since a July 1980 fire.

title: Grand Slam Brings Joy And Gloom
description: For batters, the thought of a two-out grand slam in the ninth inning that lifts the home team to victory is a pleasant daydream. For pitchers, it is a nightmare. Wednesday night in Philadelphia, the double-edged fantasy came alive for Bo Diaz of the Phillies and Neil Allen of the Mets in a 10-9 victory for Philadelphia.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN UP SHARPLY

title: Crafts on the Park
description: The Central Park South Outdoor Art Exhibit, in its eighth year, sets up along the north sidewalk of Central Park South at the Avenue of the Americas tomorrow and Sunday. More than 150 participants will show paintings, drawings, sculpture, prints, etchings, silkscreens, photographs and crafts. Hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Other dates this year are May 7 and 8; May 28 to 30; June 4 and 5; July 23 and 24; Aug. 20 and 21; Sept. 24 and 25 and Oct. 8 to 10.

title: A Strike Stuck Between Two Laws
description: Is Governor Cuomo tilting toward the union in New York's Metro-North rail strike? Although a statement earlier this week suggests that, he contends he was misinterpreted when he said he was disappointed in the position of both sides. The episode makes clear how dangerous even unintentional ambiguity has become.

title: ON ABUSING CHILDREN
description: ''ABUSE,'' which opens today at the Cinema 3, is a frail little movie that pretends to be a serious study of child abuse. In reality it's an unintentionally funny, lyrical, homosexual romance about an all-too-convincingly amateur New York film maker, a man in his mid-30's, and the 14-year-old boy who steals his heart.

title: GENE GAINS BUOY HOPES ON CANCER
description: Scientists reaffirmed today that they might at last have the tools to solve the complex mystery of the biology of cancer. This was by no means a promise that such a complicated problem would be solved soon, but it was an expression of the optimism raised by the power of the new techniques known collectively as recombinant DNA technology, or gene-splicing.

title: There Is a Better Way to Tax
description: Six years have passed since Jimmy Carter called the income tax a disgrace, more than two years since Ronald Reagan promised to free us from its disincentives to thrift and initiative. Yet April 15 remains a day for bitter jokes like the one on the right.

title: Heller Sale Plan
description: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation is considering the possiblity of full liquidation, if the sale of its finance subsidiaries to The Fuji Bank Ltd. is completed as planned, it said in its annual report. The report said that Heller is also considering reinvestment of the proceeds in new assets, and partial liquidation.

title: DR. FREDERICK THOMPSON, 75, DEVELOPER OF AN ARTIFICIAL HIP
description: Dr. Frederick Roeck Thompson, an orthopedic surgeon who led in the development more than 30 years ago of an artificial hip replacement procedure, died Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital of complications following recent surgery. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ELWAY RULES OUT COLTS, OILERS
description: The agent for John Elway, the Stanford University quarterback who is expected to be the first selection in the National Football League college draft in 11 days, has told the Baltimore Colts and the Houston Oilers that Elway would prefer to play for a West Coast team.

title: LABORERS ASSAIL HIRING CHANGES FOR CITY CENTER
description: The state's Urban Development Corporation has made changes in an ambitious minority hiring program at the city's new convention center, and yesterday scores of black and Hispanic laborers who said they wanted construction jobs protested the moves.

title: Israeli Trade Show
description: Colleen Dewhurst will read from Golda Meir's prose at ''Opportunities in Israel,'' a trade and cultural show of the American Zionist Federation at the Minskoff Cultural Center, 164 East 68th Street, Sunday at 2:30 P.M. The fair, which runs from noon to 6 P.M., will feature booths on Israeli government, banking and industry and exhibits of high technology and other merchandise. Representatives of 50 Jewish organizations will distribute material on programs they run in Israel. Admission is free, and baby-sitting services will be available.

title: An Antiscalping Bill
description: Governor Kean of New Jersey signed into law a statute banning the scalping of tickets to events held in public facilities, such as the Meadowlands sports complex, where the signing took place.

title: DESPITE REAGAN CUTS, MANY ARE TAXED MORE
description: Despite President Reagan's tax cuts, the total tax burden on Americans is still going up. Lower Federal income tax rates have been more than offset by higher Social Security taxes and by higher levies by states and localities.

title: STUDY ON U.S. PERSONNEL COSTS CALLED SHAM BY CONGRESSMAN
description: The chairman of the House Post Office Committee said today that a report by a Reagan Administration study group on how to reduce the cost of government was filled with ''statistical error, misrepresentation and disregard for fact'' and was ''a sham on the American people.''

title: CAT Scans Are Urged
description: The ''best thing'' the New York Legislature could do for fighters would be to make CAT scans of the brain mandatory, a leading neurosurgeon told a State Senate hearing on boxing safety yesterday.

title: Doorman Slain on East Side; Suspect Arrested by Police
description: A Manhattan man was arrested yesterday and was charged with murdering the doorman of an East Side apartment building and attempting to kill a porter.

title: Allan D. Dowling Dead at 79; Poet, Publisher and Producer
description: Allan D. Dowling, poet, author, publisher, librettist and film producer, died in London on Wednesday. He was 79 years old. Mr. Dowling, who was born in New York City on July 4, 1903, first published his poetry at the age of 17.

title: E.P.A. EVACUATING TRAILER SITE NEAR ASBESTOS MINE
description: The Environmental Protection Agency announced Thursday night that it was temporarily evacuating families living in an Arizona trailer park. The action came three years after the agency's staff warned that asbestos contamination presented a serious health hazard for residents of the park.

title: Rodgers Fights a Cold
description: Bill Rodgers, a four-time winner of the Boston Marathon, says that a persistent head cold may keep him out of the 87th marathon on Monday. ''If it's Monday morning and I feel like I do today,'' he said yesterday, ''I probably won't run.'' But the 35-year-old Rodgers said that he was still planning to compete and hoped that the cold he's had since last Sunday will clear up by race time.

title: SIX BOYS HELD IN RAPE OF GIRL, 12
description: Six boys between the ages of 13 and 15 raped a 12-year-old girl in the backyard of a tenement, the Passaic police said today.

title: Ravitch Loses Bid On Zoning Change
description: Richard Ravitch, head of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has lost his fight to get special zoning approval to build a caretaker's house at his home on Blue Heron Lake.

title: Your Money; Underpaying Tax Is Riskier
description: THE 1982 tax law, known formally as the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act, was the biggest revenue-raising bill ever passed by Congress. And one of the ways in which the Government expects to raise more funds is by a new penalty for ''substantial understatement'' of taxes.

title: Meyer's Son Dropped
description: Tom Meyer was relieved temporarily of his duties as basketball coach at the University of Illinois-Chicago Circle and will be reassigned.

description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has removed C.H. Butcher Jr. as head of the troubled Southern Industrial Banking Corporation, citing violations of state lending laws.

title: Oh, That Bucolic Damp
description: It started to rain when we left town for the country, and when we got to the country it continued to rain. The house where we stayed had a tin roof, and it rained very loudly all evening on the tin roof.

title: May Day Tremors in Poland
description: What's new and significant in Poland is the link now established between Lech Walesa and the leaders of the Solidarity underground. They have jointly called for anti-Government protest on May Day, just a month before the scheduled visit of the Pope.

title: BRENNER: WORKING CLOTHES
description: In the mid 1950's Eleanor Brenner began designing clothes for women who wore small sizes because her major client, Henri Bendel, was specializing in styles for the small-boned customer. A few years later, she branched out, designing everything from sweaters to evening dresses for women of all sizes, for all occasions. She called her business Brenner Couture, and her husband, Richard, who had been a merchandise manager at Bloomingdale's, helped her run the company.

title: Solo Trek to North Pole Fails
description: The British adventurer David Hempleman-Adams's attempt to become the first man to walk alone to the North Pole has failed. The crew at his base camp decided to abandon the trek because the 26-year-old mountaineer from Bristol had been plagued by cracked ribs and bad weather.

Sub Launches Cruise Missile
description: A Tomahawk cruise missile launched Thursday from a submerged submarine off San Clemente Island successfully flew a 400-mile course before hitting its intended target on the test range at Tonopah, Nev., a Navy spokesman said. It was the 99th successful launching of a cruise missile since 1976 and the 19th to be completed from a submerged submarine, said a spokesman for the Joint Cruise Missile Project.

title: A Helping Hand
description: When you need money, who better to ask but a friend? So last November, when the strike of National Football League players was in the 50th of its eventual 57 days, the N.F.L. Players Association asked the Major League Baseball Players Association for a $25,000, interest-free, one-year loan. The money did not arrive until January because the baseball players' board of directors did not meet until then.

title: Priest Leaves Jail In Harassing Case
description: A Roman Catholic priest charged with harassing Terence Cardinal Cooke was released on his own recognizance yesterday after eight days in jail.

DOW ADVANCES 6.09, TO 1,171.34
description: The stock market posted its seventh consecutive advance yesterday, fueled by favorable economic and inflation developments, with the three major market indicators again closing at new highs.

title: NEW ALVIN AILEY DANCE SHAKES PARIS
description: Alvin Ailey did not set out to shake up the world of the Opera, the stately Second Empire-style building here that usually provides a home for the most classical of classical dance.

title: Firefighter Hurt in Blaze Dies
description: A 37-year-old firefighter who ran into a burning building here Wednesday believing that people were trapped inside died Friday of injuries suffered in the blaze, authorities said.

title: SALVADOR AIDE SAYS CRISIS IS OVER
description: The chief aide to El Salvador's Provisional President said today that the threatened standoff between the Defense Minister and the commander of the air force had been ''resolved satisfactorily'' and that further details would be announced this weekend.

title: CONCERT: MOTET CHOIR
description: The New York Motet Choir hit upon a good idea in planning the benefit concert for itself that was given at St. Joseph's Church in Greenwich Village Wednesday night. Titled ''Gertrude Stein: Words and Music,'' it consisted almost entirely of vocal works incorporating texts by the idiosyncratic American writer who lived most of her life in France. The exception was an instrumental piece, a little piano sonata that Virgil Thomson composed for her in 1930.

title: Article 103734 -- No Title
description: A television repairman who picks his lottery tickets by extracting numbers from a coffee can has won $4.8 million in the Pick-6 Lotto game, becoming the biggest winner in the 12-year history of the New Jersey Lottery.

title: MONROE R. SHEINBERG
description: Monroe R. Sheinberg, a former director of the New York regional office and the national fact-finding department of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, died of cancer Thursday at Sibley Hospital in Washington. He was 72 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: DANCE: FELD'S 'REAL MCCOY'
description: ''The Real McCoy,'' a compact, incisive escapist fantasy that Eliot Feld created in 1974, was revived Thursday night by the Feld Ballet. This was the first time the work was seen at the Joyce Theater, where Mr. Feld's company has made its home since last June, and it contained a few changes. It had, for example, two new leads - Cheryl Jones and Jamie Cohen in Mr. Feld's original role as the dreamer with visions of himself as Fred Astaire. Rouben Ter-Arutunian's rainbowdesign backcloth has given way to a plain cyclorama but the hero still carries a collapsible top hat and the heroine vamps in the same Jean Harlow dress on the same mobile couch.

description: Owners of patents are being offered insurance to cover legal fees and expenses incurred if they sue someone for infringement of a patent.

title: SOVIET SHOWING UNUSUAL ANGER OVER PARIS ACTION
description: The Kremlin, in what was considered here to be part of its response to the expulsion of 47 of its officials from Paris, has chosen the unusual measure of starting a campaign of letters from surprised and indignant citizens.

title: 16 Killed at Ugandan Funeral
description: A Ugandan special forces policeman went berserk and shot and killed 16 people at the funeral of a colleague before committing suicide, the police said today.

title: ON SCHLICHTER AND GAMBLING
description: Fred Zechman, now head football coach at New Mexico State, was Art Schlichter's coach at Miami Trace High School in southern Ohio and the quarterback coach when Schlichter was the star for Ohio State.

title: VILLAINY DISPATCHED IN EL PASO

description: In homage to the heyday of 5-and-10-cent stores, a city crane this week sidled up to the former S.H. Kress store on Fifth Avenue, near West 39th Street, and stripped the facade of its glories - six black marble Art Deco panels and six limestone crests carved with a classic Greek honeysuckle motif.

According to one of Ferguson's suitors, Coach Terry O'Connor of Fairfield University in Connecticut, recruiters from Pitt have gone over the line in their efforts to woo Ferguson.

title: NASSAU TRUST CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FLEXI-VAN'S LURE FOR MURDOCK
description: David H. Murdock has won control of the Flexi-Van Corporation at an opportune time. The company, which leases cargo containers, chassis and highway trailers around the world, is just coming out of a slump prompted by a two-year decline in world trade. It has been slimmed down and made more efficient, analysts say, so that any increase in business will quickly translate into profits. And it has a healthy cash flow and a low debt for its industry.

description: The area around Indian Point is not prepared for a possible accident at the nuclear reactors there, and the safety of the 288,000 people living within 10 miles of the plants cannot be assured, a Federal agency said in a report issued yesterday.

description: Mayor Koch, who had planned last December to lay off as many as 6,600 workers before June 1984 to balance the city's next budget, said yesterday that virtually no layoffs would be necessary.

title: Animals Will Be Animals
description: I'm not yet sure what it all means, but the Health Department reported this week that humans have been biting humans in New York City at an unusual clip. While, on the one hand, the police tell us the homicide rate has gone down slightly, we learn, on the other, that New Yorkers are apparently growling and snarling more often and sinking teeth into their neighbors' flesh.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The sign on the wall said, ''Make checks and money orders payable to Internal Revenue Service.'' That was the bottom line. There were lots of lines before the bottom one, however. They included the lines for information, the lines for assistance, the line on which to print full name (first, middle, last), the line for Form 4868, which is the form for a filing extension and the deadline, which was midnight.

description: As the Senate took up the issue of withholding taxes on interest and dividends today, Senator Robert W. Kasten Jr., the leader of the repeal effort, said that he was seeking ways to make his proposal more acceptable to the White House.

title: CLOTHING PLANT AILMENTS STIR PROTEST
description: A group of workers, union officials, priests and nuns are raising a protest against disorders of the arms and hands that they say are caused by high production rates and poor job designs for workers at the Hanes Corporation's hosiery and underwear plants, mostly in the South.

title: WHAT A SCHOOL WAS
description: When I entered elementary school in 1913, I spoke only Yiddish. I was, in today's educational parlance, mono-lingual. And not surprisingly. My parents spoke no English. My recently arrived ''greenhorn'' relatives spoke no English. Neither did most of my friends.

title: CONCERT: GIDON KREMER PERFORMS WITH PHILHARMONIC
description: There are a number of legitimate, credible ways to play the Brahms Violin Concerto, ranging from the robust, somber Germanic style to the more restrained, banked-fires manner of the Franco-Belgian school. But no matter how plausible such categories may seem, every important soloist puts an individual stamp on this score. Certainly, the approach taken yesterday afternoon by Gidon Kremer with the New York Philharmonic would not fit into any pigeonhole without a great deal of squeezing and pushing.

title: TRANSSEXUAL CONVICT WINS
description: A convicted bank robber who is undergoing a sex change has won an injunction to prevent her from being confined with men in any penitentiary. Federal District Judge Raul Ramirez suggested Thursday that 25-year-old Ann Marie Mostyn, who was born a man, be placed in ''administrative segregation in a hospital setting.''

description: The chief of the transit police reported yesterday that there had been a reduction in felony crime on the subways during the first three months of this year.

Dimpled Look
description: Though Bernie Cohen enjoys playing polo, he was unhappy with the wood and plastic balls the game required. So he invented a dimpled polo ball that looks like a giant golf ball.

title: Left in the Dark On Opening Night
description: Thursday was opening night at Vernon Downs, a harness racing track 18 miles west of Utica, N.Y. As the eighth race was ending, high winds knocked down a huge tree miles away, and the tree fell on the 13,200-volt Niagara-Mohawk power line that served the track, severing the line.

title: Discovering the Answer to Deficits
description: When Congress approved President Reagan's three-year tax cut in 1981, it could not have imagined that in 1983, even before the third-year cut took effect, it would be voting on tax increases. The pain of doing anything so unpopular has stalemated the Senate Budget Committee, but slowly and unmistakably it's dawning on Washington that the budget won't be brought under control unless it is done.

title: U.S. INTEREST IN OMAN
description: Since Oman is the only Persian Gulf state openly committed to an American military presence in the region, the Administration should consider how America can defend the Gulf without detriment to Oman's domestic stability, which has received relatively little attention, and to our long-term strategic goals.

title: News Analysis
description: Negotiation is the soul of the budget process in Congress. In past years budget negotiations have been complex, prolonged and productive. But this year some key players have refused to come to the bargaining table, giving rise to fears that both the budget and the budget process are in jeopardy.

HOW TO LIMIT FIELDS IS A MAJOR PROBLEM
description: A race with more than 20 horses is too crowded to be safe or fair. But with so many horses being bred and so much prize money being offered nowadays, major races are increasingly being decided before the gate opens, when the decision is made concerning who gets to run for the big prizes.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: ACCORDING to the National Home Care Council, a substantial segment of the population is not aware o f the diverse array of services available to those seeking a lternatives to long-term hospitalization or institutionalization. M oreover, the council says, even fewer consumers and health-care p rofessionals know what to look for and what to avoid in the search f or home care.

title: The Unconventional Convention Center
description: The furor about overruns and delay in building the New York City Convention Center suggests that there's something scandalous going on. There is, but it's not careless construction practices or bad planning. It's the misconceptions conveyed by public officials, including Edward Regan, the state Comptroller, and Richard Kahan, the former chairman of the Urban Development Corporation.

title: New Claims by Jobless Decline
description: First-time claims for unemployment benefits fell 11,000 in the week that ended April 2, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

title: MONEY GROWTH RATE EASES
description: A key measure of the nation's money supply rose by $18.8 billion in March, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday. The increase, which was considerably smaller than February's $40.2 billion gain, was sufficient, analysts said, to ease the Fed's task in meeting its targets for money supply growth and encouraging lower interest rates.

title: KOHL ASSURES REAGAN ON U.S. MISSILES
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl assured President Reagan today that West Germany would proceed with deployment of American medium-range nuclear missiles on its soil this year barring an agreement with the Soviet Union to eliminate the missiles.

Japan Urges Trade Ads
description: Japan's top trade official urged Japanese businesses today to place advertisements in newspapers in the United States to refute claims that Government steering gives Japan's manufacturers an unfair trade advantage. Sadanori Yamanaka, International Trade and Industry Minister, told reporters that the Federation of Economic Organizations and other business groups must stand up against American criticism of Japan's industrial policy. Mr. Yamanaka said Motorola recently placed advertisements in the United States accusing the Japanese Government of helping specific export industries achieve rapid growth.

title: SOMETIMES A TV CHARACTER STEPS-OUT AND STAYS OUT
description: Some years ago on ''All My Children,'' the ABC-TV soap opera, a character named Bobby Martin went upstairs to polish his skis, and he hasn't been seen or heard from since. Writers on the show's staff admit that eventually it became more complicated to explain his disappearance than simply to forget it.

title: WHERE TO GET PRENATAL HELP
description: SPINA BIFIDA is one of more than 150 birth defects that now can be diagnosed in the womb. If the fetal spine is open, there is an abnormal amount of alpha feto-protein, a component of fetal spinal fluid, in the amniotic fluid. During amniocentesis, a sample of amniotic fluid is withdrawn so that alpha feto-protein levels can be measured.

title: AMHERST'S ABUNDANCE OF HALLOWED HALLS
description: One college is enough to breathe life into even the sleepiest hamlet. Five guarantee an abundance of extracurricular life, which is why the area around Amherst, Mass., is a popular destination for visitors, even those who are well past college age.

title: AN AMERICAN SOUND
description: RED AND HOT The Fate of Jazz in the Soviet Union 1917-1980. By S. Frederick Starr. Illustrated. 368 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $16.95.

title: AN APRIL BONANZA OF CHORAL MUSIC
description: ORCHESTRAL and chamber concerts proliferate the year round, but most choirs are made up of amateur singers, so it takes longer to prepare the music. Usually these ensembles start work on their new programs after Christmas, which means that come April they are raring to go. Lovers of choral music will find a bonanza between now and the end of the month.

title: NEW ATTACKS ON BIRTH DEFECTS BRINGING HOPE
description: AGGRESSIVE new techniques are giving children with spina bifida - a crippling birth defect - a chance to lead more-normal lives. A generation ago, 80 percent of such children died; many who did not were institutionalized with severe mental and physical handicaps.

title: 2 Die in Smokestack Falls
