description: Two foundry workers died Friday after one fell into a furnace smokestack while trying to retrieve a ladder and the second man fell in trying to rescue the first, the authorities said. More than 30 firefighters and rescue workers suffered smoke inhalation and heat exhaustion in seven hours of struggling to retrieve the two from the two-story smokestack.

title: Lost Wages Lawsuit
description: Jack Rudnay, a retired center, has filed a $690,000 law suit against the Kansas City Chiefs, the National Football League and its players association to recover wages that he said he lost during the 57-day strike last season.

title: HEMLOCK HEAD PREPARES CAMP
description: ''I'VE seen pictures of Camp Hemlock 50 or so years ago, with campers wearing very short hair and funny-looking outfits,'' Barbara Davis said. ''In those days, boys and girls had structured, stereotyped activities. Boys did pioneering and campfire building, and girls did arts and crafts.''

title: AN ARTICHOKE TO GROW IN THE SUN
description: Those who are considering growing a vegetable that is both ornamental and easy to cultivate might try Jerusalem artichoke. It's easier than growing potatoes. Probably the only labor involved is in planting the tubers plus a little time to cultivate until the plants start growing. Once settled in the garden, the plants take care of themselves through summer to fall when they are ready for harvesting.

title: SHRINKING HOMES
description: When young Americans fantasize about the future, they still dream about a one-family house of their own. But the reality, according to recently compiled statistics of the Federal Departments of Commerce and Housing and Urban Development, is receding fast.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART

title: THERE'S A KNACK TO REPLACING BRICKS LOOSENED BY WINTER
description: ONE pesky home repair job that often needs doing at this time of year is the replacement of one or more loose bricks on the corner of a wall or brick stoop. This condition is usually discovered when a homeowner starts looking around the outside of the house in the early spring.

title: Seeking a President For Suffolk College
description: Rumors of a de facto appointment to the presidency of Suffolk County Community College, based on partisan politics, have been rampant since the announcement of the retirement of its founding president, Dr. Albert M. Ammerman, last fall. It is indeed unfortunate that the Long Island Weekly has joined in further politicizing the atmosphere surrounding the search for the next president (''2 Reported in Lead in Contest for Head of Suffolk College,'' Politics column, April 10).

title: Debra Wassman To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Robert Wassman of New York and Brant Lake, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Irene Wassman, to Jonathan Trumbull Lanman Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Jonathan T. Lanman of Bethesda, Md. A May 29 wedding is planned in Larchmont.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: TODAY marks the end of ''Days of Remembrance'' in Connecticut, a week of memorial ceremonies recalling the slaughter of millions of Jews by the Nazis in the 1930's and 1940's. Governor O'Neill began the special observance during ceremonies at the State Capitol a week ago Friday.

title: IS REALISM REALLY AN ILLUSION?
description: THE Summit Art Center exhibition, ''American Realism 1930's/1980's,'' is a workmanlike production that comes with a useful catalogue. But there's something not quite right about it, and what this is remains unclear.

title: Latin American Intellectuals
description: It was refreshing to read an article that finally makes it clear that to be against American policies in Latin America does not mean one is pro-Communist, but rather pro-Latin America (''Revolution and the Intellectual in Latin America,'' by Alan Riding, March 13).

title: METS LOSE 6TH IN ROW, 6-2
description: The Mets ended one of their worst weeks in memory tonight with more misery, both on and off the field. They lost to the St. Louis Cardinals, 6-2, for their sixth consecutive defeat and the Cardinals' sixth consecutive victory. And Neil Allen and Mark Bradley were fined close to $500 apiece after they broke curfew and nearly became embroiled in a brawl in an afterhours club in East St. Louis, Ill., at 2 o'clock in the morning.

title: WHERE SALMON IS KING
description: British Columbians are a little too inclined to take salmon for granted. They forget that in most parts of the world the delicately flavored fish is a great luxury because in this west coast Canadian province salmon is a way of life.

title:
DINING OUT;
DELICACIES NORTH OF THE BORDER
description: ONCE in a blue moon, we happen upon a restaurant so special that we hate to finish reviewing it. Raoul's, which is just across the New York State line in Nyack, is such a place.

title: ISTANBUL'S CARAVAN STOPS
description: Until the dissolution of the Ottoman Empire after World War I, and the subsequent move of the Turkish capital to Ankara, Istanbul was the seat of Ottoman power. Built on the remnants of Constantinople and Byzantium, it was as grand a city as it was powerful, for the sultans fully intended it to be a majestic capital and commissioned the finest architects to make it so.

title: More Prisons, More Prisoners
description: New Jersey may not be able to build those jails fast enough, but it won't be for lack of trying. Last week the state got its prison expansion program started with an $80 million appropriation to begin to relieve the up-against-the-wall conditions.

title: Need for Capital
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Kathleen K. Schutte Is Wed to Richard W. Kelley
description: Kathleen Kelly Schutte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis H. Schutte of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Richard William Kelley, son of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Kelley of Tenafly, N.J. The Rev. Joseph Martin performed the ceremony in St. Theresa's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Miss McKittrick To Wed July 17
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sterling McKittrick Jr. of Morristown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Victoria McKittrick, to Mark Oliva, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Oliva Jr. of Gates Mills, Ohio.

title: Trial Questions Reliability of Product Tests
description: From lipstick to herbicides, toxicology studies are the foundation of Government safety rules for chemicals in the marketplace. The possibility of fraudulent research, raised last week as a Federal trial of Industrial Bio-Test Laboratory began in Chicago, shakes the enormously complex regulatory system to its roots.

title: CHANTILLY: ARCHIVE OF TASTE
description: Horse races and black lace, porcelain and whipped cream: Chantilly has many claims to fame, so it is perhaps not surprising that its crowning asset should be the least known of all. Ask a Parisian about Chantilly, and he will tell you about its forest, probably the finest in France, adding that there is also a castle. In fact, some of the best examples of French 16th-, 18th- and 19th-century architecture, one of the most beautiful parks anywhere and a fine collection of paintings and medieval miniatures are all to be found in this imposing and well-preserved estate.

title: 'FREE AND CLEAR' IS PONDEROUS STUFF
description: BEWARE of a play that ends with this exchange: ''I didn't mean anything I said.'' ''Neither did I.'' Why then, one wonders, has the audience been subjected to it at all?

title: ENSEMBLE PLAYING IN HOMES
description: AN old idea has been given new expression through the efforts of Performers of Westchester, an organization that presents chamber music by subscription in private homes. The spring season begins this afternoon at 3 o'clock in Mount Kisco.

title: British Laborites Assail Expulsion of Russian
description: British opposition Members of Parliament today denounced the retaliatory expulsion of a Soviet diplomat from Britain, saying it could undermine Western nuclear arms control initiatives.

title: CALCULATING THE COST OF GOVERNMENT BY COMPUTER
description: This Friday, as every Friday, a small White House computer will print a summary report of issues confronting the Reagan Administration. Versions of the slim volume go to the President, senior White House assistants and members of the Cabinet.

title: THE DAYS OF STALIN'S DEATH
description: Harrison E. Salisbury was The Times's correspondent in Moscow from 1949 to 1954. This article is adapted from his memoirs, ''A Journey for Our Times,'' to be published by Harper & Row in May.

title: A THEATRICAL APPROACH TO A SHADE GARDEN
description: shady site, when your heart longs for a sun-drenched, old-fashioned English perennial garden, can be depressing. No matter that your friends extoll the garden's ease of maintenance or that your husband beams with pleasure at his weedfree lawn. If color is what you want, then no fleeting shade-loving wild flower can ever completely satisfy.

title: BEST SOLUTION TO A $20 BILLION TAX-CHEATING PROBLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: Upper Volta
description: To the Editor:

title: Vice-Presidential Stepping Stones
description: In his otherwise informative article about the Democratic Presidential hopefuls, Martin Tolchin revives one of the oldest halftruths of American Presidential politics. I refer to his statement that ''the Vice Presidency has proved to be a good stepping stone for the top job'' (''Here Come the Democrats,'' March 13).

title: THE PAINTER WHO INVENTED ENGLISHNESS
description: VAN DYCK By Christopher Brown. Illustrated. 240 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: Cornell University Press. $48.50.

title: CRIME
description: The locale is Chicago and the subject is arson in Ronald E. Gettel's first novel, TWICE BURNED (Walker, $12.95). This is a graphically written study of a professional arsonist who takes an artist's pride in his creations. One of his creative visions centers on burning down a sizable section of Chicago. He also happens to be a psychotic killer who takes it as a personal affront when his professional skills and character are impugned.

title: Oberammergau - A Birthday
description: Under ordinary circumstances, the famed Passion Play at Oberammergau in Germany is staged every 10 years, at the turn of the decade. But next year, 75 performances have been scheduled to mark the 350th anniversary of the play, whose performance fulfills a vow made by villagers in the 17th century after they had been spared the ravages of the plague that had swept through neighboring communities.

title: July Nuptials for Betsy West
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Phelps West of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Harwichport, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Kearney West, to James Thornton Sneath, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Scott Sneath of Riverside, Conn.

title: MASSACHUSETTS SETS RAISES
description: --Gov. Michael S. Dukakis and other Massachusetts officials signed a three-year contract with the state's largest public employee union yesterday, providing a 4 percent raise June 26 and a 19 percent increase over the life of the agreement.

title: AN EVIDENCE RULE IN THE PATH OF JUSTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: MX PAPER: APPEALING, BUT MOSTLY APPALLING
description: Last week the Scowcroft commission published what is at once one of the best and worst state papers of the nuclear age. Unfortunately, it seems possible that the best parts will be less appealing to President Reagan than the worst. It is obvious from the elaborate White House orchestration that the report has been constructed with built-in Presidential approval and that at its core it is a selling job for the wrong missiles in the wrong place -100 MX missiles in Minuteman silos. This solution has been repeatedly reviewed and rejected both by Congress and by the executive branch over the last 10 years.

title: Fire in French Printing Office
description: A fire that police and fire officials said was probably caused by arson raged for more than four hours in the basement of the National Printing Office, destroying more than 1,000 tons of paper before some 200 firefighters could bring it under control today, fire officials said. There were no serious injuries, but several people suffered from smoke inhalation, the fire officials said.

title: ON THE TRAIL OF U.F.O.'S
description: THE date: March 24, 1983. The time: about 9 P.M. Gloria Scalzo of Ossining was driving north on the Taconic State Parkway near Route 133 in the town of New Castle when she said something caught her eye.

title: GROWTH OF 7 ARTISTS EXAMINED
description: A HANDSOME and impressive exhibition is on view through May 8 at The Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson, in the Municipal Building there. The show, featuring the work of seven respected artists, focuses on the evolution of their work over the last decade. The artists all work in diverse media, often combining materials and always exhibiting an eagerness to experiment with techniques and forms.

title: J.N. D'Agostino, Kitty McBride Set Wedding in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dana McBride of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Robin McBride, to Joseph Nicholas D'Agostino, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen I. D'Agostino of Lookout Mountain, Tenn. A June wedding is planned.

title: COURT TOLD OF 'LAUNDRY' FOR MILLIONS IN DRUG FUNDS
description: A major conspiracy trial in Manhattan has focused on charges that a Colombian businessman and several associates ''laundered'' many millions of dollars in cash from narcotics trafficking.

title: Gift-Tax Law
description: To The Editor:

title: DEFECTS IN EMERGENCY EQUIPMENT DELAY FUELING OF SHOREHAM PLANT
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has announced a two-month delay in loading fuel at its nearly complete Shoreham nuclear reactor, following unusual problems with the plant's emergency diesel generators.

title: A SMALL DREAM
description: It's owner is Lucy Mackall, a young entrepreneur who has struck gold twice within the past few years: first with her franchised ''Have a Heart'' boutiques and again with what turned out to be the ''pet rock'' of the 1980-81 season - shoelaces festooned with hearts, shamrocks and polka dots that proved irresistible to the sneaker set.

title: Grace C. Carroll To Wed in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. John M. Carroll of Chestnut Hill, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Grace Coulson Carroll, to James Dwight Dana Jr., son of Mrs. Horace L. Shepard of New Canaan, Conn., and Mr. Dana of New York and East Hampton, L.I.

title: SOUTHPORT SHOW IS ECLECTIC
description: COMPLETE with added attractions, the 19th-annual Southport-Westport Antiques Show again will be produced at the Fairfield County Hunt Club next Friday through Sunday. In addition to an ecletic show including formal and country furniture and folk art, the Westport weekend features an appraisal clinic and a house tour.

title: BATTLE LINES DRAWN ON RIGHT-TO-KNOW
description: POWERFUL business interests in the state joined forces last week to defeat a bill that would require employers to label hazardous chemicals in the workplace and to disclose health and safety risks to both workers and people in surrounding communities.

title:
DINING OUT;
FOR CHINA'S CUISINE OF CUISINES
description: THE county has been lucky in attracting an increasing number of restaurants that offer the regional cooking of China. Their specialties do much to enrich the county's dinner hour. And now Hong Kong Pavilion has opened in New Rochelle with a menu devoted almost entirely to Cantonese food that is in sum very good and in parts excellent. Although it is difficult to compare dishes from one region with those of another, Hong Kong Pavilion at this moment has perhaps the best Chinese food in the county, preparations that bear out the Chinese saying: For good food, go to Canton. The restaurant's special dishes can be had elsewhere only in Manhattan's Chinatown, and although they might cost a little less there, they won't be better or fresher than those this restaurant puts on its tables.

title: Meg Fidler, an Executive, Is the Bride of Leon Sigal
description: Meg Fidler, creative director of Clark Direct Marketing, a New York advertising agency, was married yesterday to Leon Sigal, a visiting scholar at the Brookings Institution in Washington and an associate professor of government at Wesleyan University. Rabbi Robert Rothman performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons restaurant.

title: THE DANCE: AMBIGUITIES OF URBAN LIFE
description: City dwellers always grouse about noise, dirt, tension and litter. Yet, provided a community is not totally falling apart, one can often detect a note of pride in these gripes, for they imply that, if nothing else, cities are exciting and that anyone who survives in them must have a lot of nerve.

title: Sports of The Times; National Pastime Is Pure Fantasy
description: ACCORDING to a recent survey, nearly half the people watching a baseball game entertain at least a passing fancy that they can hit as well as Dave Winfield or pitch as well as Tom Seaver.

title: CHURCHES TRY SOLAR DEVICES FOR HEAT
description: For centuries, the solid, Byzantine domes of Greek Orthodox churches have stood as symbols of the heavens. But a clear solar bubble, unlike any other Byzantine dome in the world, is rising over a new church in West Nyack, N.Y.

title: PATHMARK AND ITS SUPERSTORES
description: NEXT FALL the largest supermarket ever built in Manhattan will open on the edge of Chinatown. At 42,600 square feet, it will be four times the size of the average D'Agostino's, Gristede's, A.& P. and Sloan's grocery stores that now dot the borough.

title: BRASS HAT IN HAND
description: The Pentagon reminds me of Fred Allen, who was possibly the funniest wit of midcentury America. It was Fred Allen who said you could take all the integrity in Hollywood, put it in the navel of a flea and still have room left over for an agent's heart and a caraway seed.

title: HEART TEAM DRAWING LESSONS FROM DR. CLARK'S EXPERIENCE
description: A 48-year-old New York City man suffered complications from a severe heart attack while vacationing here last year. He was told his only hope was the Utah artificial heart.

title: Man Lost Off U.S. Navy Ship
description: A civilian crewman of the United States naval tanker Mistillion was reported missing at sea today. A Seventh Fleet spokesman at Subic Bay, north of Manila, said the man disappeared as the ship was sailing near the northern Japanese island of Hokkaido.

title: ISLAMIC ART THEFT IN JERUSALEM
description: Thieves broke into the Islamic Museum Friday night and stole ancient watches and clocks, rare books and paintings valued at more than $4 million in what the Israeli police today described as the city's biggest theft.

title: Nancy S. Cramer To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. N. Ken Cramer of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Sue Cramer, to Todd J. Mason, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor M. Mason of Marion, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: TRANSFER-STATIONS DISPUTE GAINS FORCE
description: THE battle over where to place two proposed garbage-transfer stations intensified last week, even as taxpayers began to shoulder the financial burden of building them.

title: SEAFOOD DONE SIMPLY AND NICELY
description: AMONG the restaurants that specialize in fish and seafood on the Island, relatively few of them do it well, which is why the Atrium in Seaford, a newcomer in this category, is such a welcome addition.

title: PIANO CONCERT: SETA KARAKASHIAN
description: The best moments in the pianist Seta Karakashian's Abraham Goodman House concert Monday night came with her sturdy and authoritative performances of Janacek's ''Three Moravian Dances'' and ''Sonata in Two Movements'' (1905).

title: Barbara Finamore Wed to S.M. Young
description: Barbara Anne Finamore, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy P. Finamore of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Stephen Markley Young, son of Col. Mason James Young Jr., U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Young, of Newport News, Va. The Rev. Donald Roberts performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of New Rochelle.

title: PACEMAKER USERS MARK AN ANNIVERSARY
description: MANY people see nuclear power as a threat to life, but the nine men and women who returned to Beth Israel Medical Center here last week look at it as the key to life.

title: COSMOS TURN AGAIN TO BECKENBAUER
description: The return of Franz Beckenbauer will strengthen the Cosmos on the field and perhaps put more people in the stands. Coach Julio Mazzei, who no longer holds the position on an interim basis, as he did last season when the team won the league championship, said the Cosmos got Beckenbauer back more for his ability to play rather than his appeal to the fans.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Around the end of July we plan to spend a week driving between San Francisco and Los Angeles. Will there be any special events or festivals we should look for at that time? - J.M., Newark, Del.

title: Sheryl Ann Judd Weds Joseph Edward Toplyn
description: Sherryl Ann Judd, daughter of Mrs. Arthur T. Dickerson of Dunellon, Fla., and Gordon S. Judd of Corvallis, Ore., was married yesterday to Joseph Edward Toplyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Toplyn of Boston. The Rev. William D. Roberts performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: End of the Fiction Doldrums?

title: Bonn Says Citizen Who Died In East Germany Was Beaten
description: The Government said today that a West German who died during questioning at a border crossing point inside East Germany last Sunday had suffered several blows to the head.

title: Linda B. Howard to Wed David Agnew
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman A. Howard of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Linda Burd Howard, to Dr. David Chalmers Agnew, son of William Agnew of Everett, Pa., and Naples, Fla., and the late Adelaide Hartman Agnew.

title: 9-10 MAULDIN WINS BOLD RULER BY A NECK
description: The main attractions were washed out of the Bold Ruler Stakes yesterday, but the four horses who remained to slog through the slop at Aqueduct put on a rousing show of their own. Maudlin, the 9-10 favorite, held off Top Avenger to win by a neck in a race in which the bettors picked the exact order of finish.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: MY cousin Shirley never played golf on Long Island or belonged to a country club. But now she is a retiree in Florida, and she wears cute golf shorts and a cute sun visor and owns cute socks to cover her golf woods.

title: Less for the Truly Needy
description: The Reagan Administration has a standing response to charges that reductions in social spending enacted in the last two years hurt the truly needy. It is, the cuts are not cuts; they are reductions in the rate of increases.

title: A NEW LIFE FOR AN OLD CHURCH
description: AFTER a century of service as a spiritual center for immigrants, St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Newark's West Ward is being transformed into a modern office complex where neighborhood residents will come, not to pray for their souls, but to care for their bodies.

title: SYRIA DEMANDS ISRAELIS LEAVE LEBANON FIRST
description: The Syrian Government newspaper said today that talks on a pullout of Syrian forces from Lebanon could not begin before all Israeli troops had left the country.

title: RISING COSTS ON SALVADOR'S SECOND FRONT
description: Radio Venceremos, the guerrilla radio station in El Salvador, sparked up its program last week with some live theater about the troubles of the country's defense minister. The sitcomlike banter, however, was only a brief interlude in broadcasts that dealt primarily with the leftist opposition's plan to launch major new attacks against the Salvadoran economy. ''We will deepen the war against the economy to include all the national territory,'' the rebel disc jockey boasted.

title: THE TEMPTATION OF SWOLLEN HOME EQUITY
description: WHEN the house was bought 20 years ago, the owner's only equity was h is 10 percent down payment. But in the next two decades, the market v alue of the house jumped from $50,000 to $200,000, and he paid off m ost of the mortgage. As a result, his equity has risen nearly f ortyfold, from $5,000 at the time of purchase to $190,000 today.

title: Daryl Froelich Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Froelich of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Daryl Dee Froelich, to Michael Jeffrey Moss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Moss, also of Scarsdale. The wedding is to be June 19.

title: Debra Ann Friedman Marries Charles C. Schoenau
description: Debra Ann Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard W. Friedman of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Charles C. Schoenau. Rabbis Sheldon Zimmerman and Lynne Landsberg of the Central Synagogue in New York performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: NEW JERSEY suddenly looks different and more remarkable than ever after reading ''In Suspect Terrain'' (Farrar, Straus, Giroux, New York, $12.95) by John McPhee.

title: THE ROYAL BALLET CHARTS A NEW COURSE
description: The Royal Ballet arrives at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday trailing a lustrous past. It is a past peopled by Dame Ninette de Valois, the indomitable founder of the 52-year-old company, Sir Frederick Ashton, the self-effacing architect of the English ballet, and stars of the magnitude of Dame Margot Fonteyn and Rudolf Nureyev, her galvanic Russian partner. The aura clings of a small band of plucky adventurers, dancing ''The Sleeping Beauty'' and ''Miracle in the Gorbals'' through the adversities of the war years to forge what was to become the lyric classicism and vivid theater of the English style.

title: HAWKS MAKE PLAYOFFS
description: Mike Glenn, a reserve guard, connected on eight of nine field-goal attempts in the final quarter tonight and led Atlanta to a 96-79 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks that put the Hawks in the playoffs.

title: Heart Surgeon's Dark Moments
description: While the travails of Dr. Barney B. Clark were widely reported during the 112 days he lived as the first human with a permanent artificial heart, the man who implanted it, Dr. William C. DeVries, suffered anguish of his own in private. Dr. DeVries disclosed in recent interviews that after the surgery he received ''hate mail'' from people who said he had countered the will of God. Further, someone sabotaged his car in a manner that might have caused a fatal accident. Even without those distractions, Dr. DeVries said that throughout the ordeal he was ''worried to death.''

title: A $150 Million Windfall Follows Wagner to School
description: From the victor comes the spoils. That seemed to be the case last week when, a day after his selection as New York City Schools Chancellor, Robert F. Wagner Jr. said the Board of Education's budget would be as much as $150 million larger than anticipated just three months ago.

title: THOSE UNACCOUNTABLE AGENCIES COUNT FOR A LOT
description: From his office on the 57th floor of the World Trade Center, Governor Cuomo looks out on a world he played little part in shaping but would nevertheless like to control. All around him are tangible symbols of a complicated network of agencies, authorities and commissions with the power to get things done - and a relationship to the Governor that is not always clear.

title: AN AMERICAN DECORATOR EMERITUS
description: These days, home for Billy Baldwin is two tiny rooms stacked upon each other in a two-story house on Nantucket. At the time of his retirement a few years ago, he was considered America's leading decorator. Today, as decorator emeritus to a profession that has quadrupled in size since he started to practice in the 1920's, he lives the quiet life. Quiet for him might seen quite hectic to others: There is a daily round of drinks, lunches and dinners with friends from all over the world who come to visit.

title: Reagan Vows to Veto Changes in Tax Laws
description: President Reagan, in his weekly radio broadcast today, again said he would veto any bill to repeal a law requiring a partial withholding of Federal taxes from interest and dividend income.

title: James Lawrence Murphy, 66, Active in Eisenhower's Races
description: James Lawrence Murphy, a San Francisco investment broker who was an early supporter of Dwight D. Eisenhower when he first ran for President and was national chairman of the Citizens for Eisenhower in both campaigns, died of cancer Friday at Presbyterian Hospital in San Francisco. He was 66 years old.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Taxing the Elderly Rich

title: DANCE: PAUL TAYLOR'S 'DUST' REVIVED
description: Paul Taylor is a master of the unexpected. Call a dance ''Dust'' and, it would seem, the dance would be bleak, dark and dire. Mr. Taylor's ''Dust,'' a 1977 work revived Thursday at City Center by the Paul Taylor Dance Company, is dark all right. And the thick black knotted rope that hangs from the flies has an aura of death about it. But ''Dust'' is probably the most antic dance anyone has ever choreographed about infirmity - a cartoon that coaxes laughter as much as dread and pity.

title: The Cultural Zero?
description: To the Editor:

title: JONI GOTTLIEB TO MARRY PAUL JABLANSKY IN JULY
description: Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence H. Gottlieb of East Rockaway, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Joni Dale Gottlieg, to Paul Eric Jablansky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Jablansky of Silver Spring, Md. A July wedding is planned.

title: TURKEY OPENS WAY FOR NEW PARTIES
description: President Kenan Evren pressed a campaign this week against Turkey's old political parties as the ruling National Security Council prepared to announce a new law setting guidelines for elections and the creation of new political groups.

title: OFFICIAL'S OUSTER DISTURBS COAST ENVIRONMENTALISTS
description: The dismissal of a state health official has increased environmentalists' concern about Gov. George Deukmejian's commitment to solving the state's toxic waste problems.

title: Prost Gets Pole Position
description: Alain Prost of France was more than two seconds faster than the field in his turbo-charged Renault today as he took the pole position for Sunday's Formula One French Grand Prix.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, APRIL 17, 1983
description: International

title: ON PARK AVE., SOMETHING FOR EVERYBODY
description: JULIAN PERLMAN bought his seven-room co-op apartment at 815 Park A venue for $165 a share instead of the $320 he thought he would be p aying. Edward C. Ross and his partners are making more than $1 m illion on a building they owned for a split second. The original o wners got their $7 million asking price and one of the principals isg oing to retain her table-tennis room.

title: LEWIS HINE'S LAST LEGACY
description: A science teacher turned photographer, Lewis W. Hine expected to see human will transcend and transform the industrial landscape of the early 20th century. Time and again, whether his subject was a group of grimy child laborers at a coal mine or a woman in a canning factory, plain insistent human strength and dignity were powerfully evident in the eyes and in the carriage of the shoulders.

title: AN 'ACTION' CENTER IS FOCUS OF DISPUTE
description: FOR some people in North Amityville, it comes as no surprise that the property on which a local community service center now stands may be sold and the center moved elsewhere. They contend that the Town of Babylon, which encompasses North Amityville and has the power to move the center, rarely represents their community's needs anyway.

title: TELL IT TO THE MARINE
description: ''I thought they taught English at the Naval Academy,'' writes Charles Maechling Jr. of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington. He attached a clipping quoting a letter written by Gen. Robert Barrow, Commandant of the Marine Corps, to the Secretary of Defense, and widely disseminated by the Pentagon.

title: THE EXPERT BEHIND THE BOOK
description: ''In April 1970 I got a call from Nicholas Katzenbach, who asked if I and Charles River Associates would be interested in doing a study of the computer industry, with an eye toward providing expert testimony,'' said Franklin M. Fisher. Neither man could have known that both were about to embark on a 12-year episode.

title: Military Analysis
description: Syria's expansion of ground, armored and air forces and the installation of SA-5 missile sites manned by Soviet soldiers raise two questions for United States and other intelligence services.

title: Soviet Team Wins, 3-0, In Hockey Tournament
description: The Soviet Union, favored to win its 19th title, defeated East Germany by 3-0 on the opening day of the world hockey championships today.

title: PUBLIC SCHOOLS ARE REACHING A TURNING POINT
description: THIS year public education will receive two report cards that cannot be ignored. The reports will be issued by the Federal Commission on Excellence in Education (due later this month) and the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching (due this fall).

title: FORT BENNING GIVES TRAINING TO REDUCE CHILD ABUSE CASES
description: A program requiring Fort Benning soldiers to learn how to detect and report child abuse has produced ''astounding'' results in three years, officials say.

title: CENTRAL AMERICANS NEED A JEAN MONNET
description: To the Editor:

title: STRESS TEST FOR A WEAPONS SYSTEM: POLITICAL SURVIVAL
description: The Navy's new F-18 Hornet is a classic survivor in the battles of Washington, proof of the political and bureaucratic principle: ''A weapons program put into motion tends to stay in motion.''

title: WHAT DETERMINES SIZE OF A REFUND IN OVERASSESSMENT?
description: WHEN the Nassau County Board of Supervisors agreed recently to refund some $520,000 in county taxes to the owners of the Chalet, a 140-unit apartment building in Roslyn, it was accepted by county officials as almost a routine matter. Since 1977, about $40 million has been refunded to thousands of commercial property owners in Nassau because of overassessment, and about 8,000 other appeals are awaiting decisions on similar reductions, according to spokesmen for the county.

title:
CAMERA;
WIDE-ANGLE LENS FOR BROADER PERSPECTIVE
description: Peggy Sealfon is East Coast editor of Petersen's PhotoGraphic magazine.

title: QUAKERS LEADING TAX PROTEST AGAINST SUPPORT FOR MILITARY
description: Quakers are leading a growing movement that subjects members to a painful dilemma: to obey the law or to follow their pacifist beliefs by refusing to pay taxes that go to the military.

title: SOVIET STILL SEEKS BONN ENERGY DEAL
description: Soviet officials plan to revive discussions of a proposal for West Germany to deliver synthetic fuel plants to the Soviet Union in return for energy supplies, an authoritative energy newsletter said today.

title: DANCE IS RETURNING TO SYMPHONY HALL
description: THE art of dance is finding its way back to Symphony Hall here, and the Philadelphia Ballet will perform Wednesday morning as part of a new series for student audiences.

title: BETTER BUSINESS BUREAU OFFICE HANDLES UP TO 800 CALLS A DAY
description: The phones ring incessantly in the main office of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York on Park Avenue South. On the busiest days, as many as 800 people call in with inquiries, according to bureau officials.

title: OXFORD'S MAY FETE
description: Oxford is bounded by two rivers, the Thames and the Cherwell, which meet at the corner of Christ Church Meadow, so that, if you enter the city from any side except the north, you will do so by crossing a river bridge. If you enter from the London side you will cross the Cherwell at Magdalen Bridge, finding yourself immediately at the foot of Magdalen Tower, the tallest and stateliest of Oxford's older buildings.

title: Martha Glover Is the Bride Of Dennis Perry in Florida
description: Martha Somes Glover, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ebner Glover of Boca Raton, Fla., was married there yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joan of Arc to Dennis Walter Perry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Perry of Needham, Mass.

title: A HOME BUYER'S FINANCING PRIMER
description: Home-buying in the 1980's, the Federal Trade Commission acknowledges, involves new rules and new strategies. What with rollercoaster interest rates and fluctuating purchase prices, prospective home-buyers these days must have more than just a casual familiarity with the array of mortgage financing plans available before venturing into today's money marketplace.

title: WHEN IT'S A MOVIE, NOT A FILM
description: IN the 1974 Broadway musical ''Mack and Mabel,'' a song called ''When Movies Were Movies'' summed up the movie maker Mack Sennett's credo: ''No one pretended that what we were doing was art.''

title: Lisa C. Symons to Be Bride Of Jeremiah Burke in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Symons of Bluemont, Va., formerly of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Carole Symons, to Jeremiah Peter Burke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Burke of Clifton Park, N.Y. The wedding is to held June 4.

title: FLEMISH INN AIMS HIGH
description: In a tiny West Flanders farming village, surrounded by flat fields of wheat and sugar beets and within sight of an 18th-century windmill, an unexpectedly elegant six-room hotel with restaurant offers amenities more likely at the Ritz in Paris than in the Belgian countryside.

title: REMOVING BARRIERS TO CHILDREN
description: In the competition to find an apartment in New York City, one group is apparently the most likely to lose: families with children. This is particularly the case when that family is headed by a single parent, most often a woman.

title: CITING GAINS, BLACKS PREDICT GROWING ROLE IN POLITICS
description: DAVID FORD, chairman of Mount Vernon's Democratic Party, was obviously glad the question had been asked. ''How many blacks do we have in city government,'' he said, adjusting his hands to count the positions on his fingers, only to discover that the number exceeded 10. ''The Chief of Police is black, the Commissioner of Veteran Affairs, the Buildings Commissioner and the City Assessor. The deputy commissioners in the Comptroller's office and the department of recreation are black. The City Clerk is black, the Executive Director of the Youth Board.

title: QUANTITY, QUALITY AT MODEST PRICES
description: EVERY now and then, when you think you cannot swallow another gummy stuffed clam, over-syruped duckling a l'orange or pudding mix masquerading as chocolate mousse, you chance upon a restaurant that makes dining out a welcome and worthwhile experience.

title: THEATER: P.T. BARNUM, HIS AUTOBIOGRAPHIES
description: ''Barnum's Last Life,'' is a curious one-act play by Richard Ploetz that is playing at La Mama. It is a drama about P.T. Barnum, the greatest showman of his times, and about his many autobiographies - in which he confused fact with fiction, memories of what happened with what he wished had happened.

title: Sky Smuggling
description: Narcotics smuggling by private aircraft had become so prevalent in the tip of Florida by April 1982 that the Federal Aviation Administration ordered all pilots flying south of Jacksonville to file flight plans and to make regular position reports.

title: RADIOACTIVITY STIRS MIDDLESEX DISPUTE
description: TWO months ago, Leighton Scretchings, his wife and two preteen-age children moved here from New York and began adjusting to suburban life in Birch Run, a new housing development in a nook of Piscataway Township near Middlesex Borough.

title: A SHOW BY THOSE WHO DON'T SHOW
description: THE Barron Art Center, a historic brownstone building in this Middlesex County township, is the setting for ''Fine Crafts,'' an exhibition and sale of work by 17 New Jersey craft artists.

title: Economist Weds Atsuko Imamura
description: Atsuko Imamura of Philadelphia was married there yesterday to Forrest Landis MacKellar, son of Mr. and Mrs. Forrest B. MacKellar of Frederick, Md. The Rev. Norman Kerr of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Philadelphia performed the ceremony at the Art Alliance Club.

title: AID FOR COLLEGIANS NOT A 'FREE RIDE'
description: WHEN Curtis Aiken, the 5-foot-10-inch all-America guard from Bennett High School in Buffalo, announced his decision to attend the University of Pittsburgh last week, he effectively ended a recruiting chase that had begun in earnest nearly eight months ago. At around the same time Aiken made his decision Wednesday, Kenny Smith, the 6-1 guard from Archbishop Molloy in Queens, announced that he would attend the University of North Carolina.

title: Hammer Hangs Over Sotheby's
description: Sotheby Park Bernet last week got a $100 million bid for a venerable object of the art world - the British auction house itself. The offer was not welcomed.

title: Boat Sinks Off Jersey; All 18 Aboard Rescued
description: Coast Guard helicopters plucked 18 people from a sinking fishing boat and surrounding waters in a battle with rain and 8-to-12-foot waves today.

title: MUSIC: ELIOT FISK OFFERS LATIN GUITAR PROGRAM
description: By this time, the classical guitar has an enormous repertory of interesting compositions, many of them from Latin countries. And so Eliot Fisk's recital of modern Latin guitar music Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y, co-sponsored by the Center for Inter-American Relations, had a good base on which to build.

title: NATURE BOXED AS AN ATRIUM
description: More than a few of the low-rise business complexes that now dot the suburban landscape are deemed office parks by those who design and construct them. But an office building now rising on a wooded 16-acre site in Montvale, N.J., can lay true claim to that description.

title: THE NOBLE HEARTLAND OF FRANCE
description: The Ile de France has everything. It has great cathedrals, great country houses, great forests, great hotels, great food and drink and some very good boating. It has small towns by the dozen that have kept a distinctive identity in spite of everything that our century has done to destroy them. It has been the favorite of poets (Nerval and Mallarme), composers (Offenbach, Debussy and Ravel), painters (Corot, Delacroix, Pissarro and Monet) and photographers (Nadar and Atget).

title: WRITER'S GUILT AND THE LURE OF A WORD PROCESSOR
description: AS a novelist, I began to find myself contemplating the purchase of a word processor with the same ambivalence with which I might consider a second piece of Amaretto cheesecake. Of course I wanted it. The questions were: Is it good for me? Do I need this?

title: No Headline
description: The Outspoken President of Yale A. Bartlett Giamatti's comment that Yale's mission is ''not to make one technically or professionally proficient, but to instill some sense of the love of learning for its own sake ...'' could have come straight from the English theologian John Henry Newman's ''Idea of a University Defined'' (''The Outspoken President of Yale,'' by William E. Geist, March 6).

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:; GREENWICH
description: FAR beyond its borders, the name Greenwich connotes not only material success but a particular kind - old money. It can seem like something out of a New Yorker cartoon. ''Greenwich is a lot of good land, well guarded - the affluent s ociety,'' said Beth Henry, a sculptor who has lived in the town for 2 4 years.

title: FAST FOOD AND FLAMBOYANCE, TO GO
description: LEAVING his hillside estate at six o'clock one morning last week, Harold G. Fulmer 3d drove his stately Stutz Blackhawk the three miles to a McDonald's restaurant. He ordered scrambled eggs, alerted the manager to a straw that littered the parking lot and sat down to eat and talk with the manager about fishing. Then he walked back to the Stutz, settled his 6-foot 4-inch, 250-pound frame in the seat and headed to a 7:30 charity meeting. By 9, he was in his office, signing paychecks.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: MARTHA DUBOWSKI is 64 years old, with a serene-looking face and pale hair. She and her husband, Leo, were born in Yonkers and have lived there all their lives, within a tight circle of family, friends and neighbors.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE

title: HOW THE U.S. FLUBBED THE I.B.M. CASE
description: Folded, Spindled, and Mutilated: Economic Analysis and U.S. v. IBM, by Franklin M. Fisher, John J. McGowan and Joen E. Greenwood. The MIT Press, Cambridge, Mass. 464 pages, $25.

title: CURVES IN, CURVES OUT
description: AMERICAN BEAUTY By Lois W. Banner. Illustrated. 369 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: Susan Jean Papst To Wed in Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas L. Papst of Columbus, Ga., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jean Papst, to David Parker Bowman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Bowman of Southbury, Conn. The wedding is scheduled for spring.

title: PARED-DOWN LUXURY
description: This one-room apartment is a compendium of space-stretching ideas. The home of Paul Siskin, a partner in the interior-design firm Barrett/Siskin, the apartment is a 20-foot-by-25-foot room in a Manhattan brownstone. It needs to be versatile because it functions as a living room, dining room, bedroom and occasional work room.

title: SOUPS FROM A PASTEL PALETTE
description: WHEN the weather is bitter, few dishes can provide the total satisfaction of a steaming bowl of hearty soup. And when the temperature begins to climb, a refreshing cold soup smoothed with cream or sharpened with lemon will revive a flagging appetite. Springtime falls between both extremes but soup is as suited to this season as to any other.

title: PLAYGROUNDS FROM GRASS ROOTS
description: A SURPRISING thing is happening with the community-built playgrounds that have increasingly become part of the Long Island landscape. Bob Leathers, the Ithaca, N.Y., architect who designed many of the Island's volunteer-built playgrounds, has observed that the structures are being used in so many unexpected ways - and by so many different age groups - that, in the latest playgrounds, he is incorporating entirely new design elements that reflect this actual usage.

title: LIMITS PROPOSED ON LOBSTER HARVEST IN LONG ISLAND SOUND
description: A DISPUTE among fishermen over the productive lobster grounds of Long Island Sound has led to proposals in both the Connecticut and New York legislatures to limit the number of lobsters that may be taken by trawlers.

title: SHOPPERS AT THE GALERIA POLLED TO SHAPE ADVERTISING
description: THERE is a growing interest in what the county's consumers think - not about world affairs, especially, but about new products. And that interest is drawing a steady parade of corporate clients, advertising agencies and research suppliers to The Galleria shopping complex in White Plains.

title: Correction
description: In a letter from Dr. Gabriel S. Zatlin (Travel, April 3), the address was erroneously printed as Stony Brook, L.I., instead of Hoboken, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: It is difficult to fathom why, in the headline, Cardinal Lustiger was described as ''a most special Cardinal'' when the nub of what he has to say is ''traditionalist, unbending but in the language of modern intellectual seduction.'' Sounds like just another hard-working apostle.

title: Hispanic Literature
description: To the Editor:

title: SIX MORE YEARS?
description: The Reagan Administration feels it has won a ''great victory'' in the Senate confirmation of Kenneth L. Adelman as the new director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency. And the President says, ''We are not doing anything to try and overthrow the Government of Nicaragua.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
HACKENSACK: PLUS CA CHANGE...
description: ALMOST a dozen shops selling antiques and collectibles in the Anderson Street shopping section here look about the same as they did five years ago. One can expect to return in 10 years and probably still find them little changed.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: PARENTS NEGOTIATE WITH YOUTH
description: ADOLESCENT problems have been approached in many ways, but one negotiation technique, known as Toughlove, has attracted a growing following since it was introduced in the county a year ago.

title: Music Lover of Means
description: Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman arrived in Washington last week with his hand extended in friendship - or so it would seem from the size of the check that was in it.

title: REAGAN AIDES SPLIT ON MEDICAL CARE FOR UNEMPLOYED
description: The Reagan Administration is divided by a dispute over what type of medical assistance, if any, to provide to jobless workers, according to officials in the executive branch and Congress.

title: SPRING SONG OF A BLITHE SPIRIT: STAN THE BIRD
description: THE encounter began on a steely day in March of last year. I first saw the cardinal with his feathers puffed out against the cold winds, looking like a round, red Christmas ornament on the bush just outside the window. As a spring, a summer and an autumn were imbued with his sound and color and flight, I wondered: Would he stay through the winter?

title: No Headline
description: It was surprising to see no mention of Brazil, subcontinental in size and population, and a country that has produced not only the undisputed giant of 19th-century Latin American letters, Machado de Assiz, but also an unprecedented number of 20th-century masters, including the novelists Guimaraes Rosa, Clarice Lispector, Jorge Amado and Marcio Souza, as well as extraordinary poets like Carlos Drummond de Andrade and Joao Cabral del Melo Neto.

title: Index; International
description: Sandinists hunt rebels in rugged border region 3 Thailand elects new House of Representatives tomorrow 6 Around the World 7 Little is left of the Warsaw ghetto 40 years after uprising 9 Islamic Museum in Jerusalem is robbed 12 Pollution is dulling luster of the Taj Mahal 13 Slain black South African leader proclaimed a hero at funeral 15 Soviet said to offer Bonn a $16.5 billion energy deal 17 Turkey preparing to allow new political parties to emerge 19 Government/Politics In leftist Santa Monica, Calif., voters turn to the right 22 Probation had been sought in House drug case 24 Coast environmentalists con- cerned about Deukmejian 25 Quakers leading tax protest against support for military 26 New York City is host to 90 con- sulates 31 Political figures drew conces- sions from both sides in strike 32 ''Laundering'' of $150 million from drugs charged at trial 35 Role of casino agency in urban renewal is debated 36 Assembly votes to extend J-51 tax abatement program 39 General Expensive empty space haunts Veterans Administration 21 Around the Nation 22 Teacher remains in prison in ali- mony protest 23 Fort Benning teaches soldiers to spot and report child abuse 29 Arts/Entertainment Two pianists, baritone among debut recitalists 26 Dario Fo's comedy ''About Face'' opens at the Yale Rep 26 ''Barnum's Last Life'' plays at La Mama 26 Style Volunteers provide meals for needy 26 Sports Back at Alabama, Perkins begins a new era 27 Martin angry at umpiring 27 Islanders dominating series with Rangers 27 Rangers are altering lineup 27 Wilcox comes within one out of perfect game 27 Dave Anderson on hockey's Sut- ter brothers 28 George Vecsey on the fantasy of the national pastime 29 Orioles defeat Indians, 2-0 29 North American Soccer League preview 30 Cosmos look again to Becken- bauer 30 Moody a bright spot amid Gener- als' gloom 30 News Analysis Drew Middleton examines ques- tions posed by Syrian buildup 12

title: NEW ROUND OF PLANETARY MISSIONS URGED
description: In an effort to chart an economy-class program of unmanned planetary exploration, a committee of leading American scientists proposed yesterday that small, no-frills spacecraft fly four missions between now and the end of the century.

title: A NEW BICENTENNIAL
description: The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx is doing its share to celebrate the bicentennial of the peace treaty that ended the American Revolutionary War against Great Britain in 1783.

title: REPLACEMENTS NEAR FOR THE RENT BOARD
description: REPLACEMENTS for four lame-duck members of the nine-member Rent Guidelines Board, which sets rent levels for 65,000 county apartments, are expected to be made before the board begins its deliberations in June on next year's rent levels.

title: LIBRARY IN DISPUTE
description: ALTHOUGH modifications of the eight-month-old policy restricting access to Princeton University's Harvey S. Firestone Library went into effect April 1, opponents of restriction are pushing for more changes.

title: SCHOOLS FIGHT PAPER WORK
description: TO NEW JERSEY educators, more paper work used to mean more money. Now they are learning that less such work means thousands of dollars saved and more time for improving education.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The pianist Ronald Sadoff, who gave his debut recital on April 9 in Carnegie Recital Hall, played with a sure understanding of the structural requirements of the music. This made for a convincing program, but it would have been still more effective had Mr. Sadoff more rigorously carried through on his interpretive ideas.

title: CHANGE RINGING: AN ANCIENT ART
description: THE sound is different from music. It is more like a melodic message - a conversation among the bells. There is a similarity to bird song in the lack of tune, the clarity and effect of tone and a kind of expectation and joy. It is a practice that is ancient and ceremonial and related to air and sunlight and self-expression.

title: RANKS BREAK OVER DEFENSE BUT PRESIDENT HANGS TOUGH
description: THIS was the week Congress went to the mat with the President over foreign and defense policy. From military spending, to arms control, to Central American policy, the two branches of government grappled with each other. In part, it seemed that Democrats sensed that President Reagan might be vulnerable politically on international issues. But also it seemed that a number of legislators, Democrats and Republicans alike, simply disagreed with where Mr. Reagan was leading the country.

title: MUGABE WIDENS STATE CONTROL
description: The Zimbabwe Government plans to extend its participation in the economy, now dominated by the minority white community, according to Prime Minister Robert Mugabe.

title:
GARDENING;
THE WHAT AND WHEN OF SPRING PLANTING
description: AN old rule of thumb among gardeners says that certain things can be planted as soon as the soil can be worked in the spring. Included are hardy perennials, such as shasta daisies and columbines; biennials, such as pansies, sweet williams and digitalis, and perennial vegetables, such as rhubarb and asparagus.

title: BUT DOES THE P.L.O. WANT A STATE?
description: To the Editor:

title: TROUBLE ON THE MECCA LOT
description: TWO, By Richard Grenier. 346 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $14.95.

title: THE LITTLE GUY WILL GET HURT
description: THE deregulation-at-any-price buffs are at it again. Having u nshackled the airlines and busted up the telephone company, they aren ow turning their attention to the United States Postal Service.

title: Auto Shipping
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWARK NEEDS A TOWER TO BRING IN THE TOURISTS
description: FROM: STANLEY B. WINTERS TO: BOARD OF DIRECTORS, RENAISSANCE NEWARK INC.

title: FRONT-OFFICE SHIFTS
description: GOVERNOR KEAN had a difficult time last week convincing reporters that there wasn't more to the job shakeup in his front office - a remarkably simple one in which everyone comes up smiling - than what he outlined at a news conference.

title: E. J. Acton, Literary Agent, Weds Rose Ellen Sedgwick
description: Rose Ellen Sedgwick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kerr Sedgwick of Syracuse, Ind., was married yesterday to Edward John Acton, son of Mrs. Edward J. Acton of North Andover, Mass., and the late Dr. Acton. State Supreme Court Justice Lawrence E. Kahn of Albany performed the ceremony at the New York home of Francis Greenburger, a friend of the couple.

title:
ART;
A LITTLE-KNOWN MASTERPIECE HIGHLIGHTS YALE SHOW
description: THE Yale University Art Gallery recently placed on view 22 important paintings from the 18th and early 19th centuries. Most of them are French, but one is a small, and until now little-known masterpiece by the American artist Thomas Eakins.

title: Miss Davies, A Paralegal, Has Nuptials
description: Helen Deborah Davies, daughter of Yvonne Davies of Chiddingfold, England, and Jack Davies of Horsham, England, was married yesterday to Alden MacPherson Richards, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Ames Richards Jr. of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Richard E. Mayberry performed the ceremony at St. Francis Episcopal Church in Stamford.

title: WASHINGTON DROPS IN ON 'THE LAST DOMINO'
description: Three senior Reagan Administration officials are due to arrive here today to monitor the state of United States-Mexican relations in the midst of this country's worst economic crisis in more than 40 years. Yet, as in every previous high-level bilateral meeting over the last two years, public attention will center on the chaos in Central America.

title: Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: MARTIN IS ANGERED BY UMPIRE'S ACTION
description: Billy Martin's ''war'' on umpires was rained out yesterday. Martin, who was ejected by Vic Voltaggio in the first inning of Friday night's game against Toronto, said after the 6-5 loss: ''He wants to declare war, he's got it.

title: Miss Kidwell Marries Charles Miller Jr.
description: Kristen Emilie Kidwell, daughter of Doris B. Kidwell of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Dr. Allyn P. Kidwell of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Lockett Miller Jr., son of Comdr. Charles L. Miller, U.S.N. retired, and Mrs. Miller, of Annapolis, Md.

title: JOHN SAYLES: A MAN FOR ALL MEDIA
description: Steve Lawson, literary manager of the Williamstown Theater Festival, writes frequently about the arts and for television.

title: MANCHESTER TEACHER HONORED AS BEST
description: INSTEAD of fulfilling his duties as chairman of the English Department at Manchester High School last week, Dr. Leroy E. Hay spent three days in Washington D.C. He spoke about his educational theories on Voice of America broadcasts, attended a number of dinners, luncheons and presentations before political leaders, and received an award from Nancy Reagan at a ceremony at the White House.

title: SEEKING A SPOT FOR FIREWORKS
description: PEOPLE in Riverhead haven't got much of a bang out of fireworks lately. For years, the Town Board has declined to incur the expense of Fourth of July fireworks displays on a town beach.

title: Walesa and the Regime Play Cat and Mouse
description: For an organization that ''does not exist'' and a ''private citizen'' who no longer leads it, Lech Walesa and the Solidarity union captured a considerable share of the Polish Governmment's attention last week. In moves as delicate as setting a time bomb, Mr. Walesa all but endorsed a Solidarity call for anti-Government May Day protests and police all but arrested him for meeting with underground leaders of the banned group.

title: CIRCUITS SCALED TO SIZE
description: Miniaturization is a key word in electronics today, and the same principle that shrank a roomful of equipment into a pocket calculator in a few short years now makes possible incredibly high performance in home-entertainment, information and computing products designed to fit into compact spaces.

title: NEW REPRESENTATIVES ENJOY THE JOB
description: TO describe their first 100 days in Congress, Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of New Britain, and Bruce A. Morrison, Democrat of New Haven, keep coming back to the words ''time'' and ''paper.''

title: SOUTHERN AUTHOR GIVEN LANGSTON HUGHES HONOR
description: Margaret Walker Alexander, a poet, novelist and educator who has influenced many young black poets and writers, was honored at the eighth annual Langston Hughes Festival at City College last week.

title: Moody a Bulwark of Generals
description: The Generals try again today. They play the Washington Federals at Giants Stadium in a game that will be televised here on Channel 7, and in contention is last place in the United States Football League. The Generals and the Federals share the bottom spot in the standing, each with one victory in six games.

title: MAINLY THE MATTERS OF EVERYDAY LIFE
description: LETTERS, By Sylvia Townsend Warner. Edited by William Maxwell. 311 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $26. COLLECTED POEMS By Sylvia Townsend Warner. Edited, with an introduction, by Claire Harman. 290 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $26.

title: FILMMAKERS TAKE A HARD LOOK AT ISRAEL
description: Israeli cinema is coming of age. Buoyed by the success of serious, highly personal films written by directors, companies that once bankrolled only the frothy comedies known as burekas are now financing artistic films.

title: Letters; Narrow Focus
description: To the Editor:

title: Ellen Claire Brown Is Engaged to William K. Hoeg
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edward Allan Brown of Larchmont, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Claire Brown, to William Kenneth Hoeg, son of Dr. and Mrs. Dwight C. Hoeg of Duluth, Minn. A June 18 wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: John Vinocur's portrait of Cardinal Lustiger revealed him to be not only a most special Cardinal, but also a most special man. Few people can create in their own lives links between the past and the present, the present and the future, but many can recognize such a link when created by someone like Cardinal Lustiger. His personal history - having lived through the greatest age of ''ideologies which kill realism and create messiahs'' - makes his words that much more powerful and instructive. KRISTEN ANTELMAN, New York City

title: BEHIND THE SCENE WITH ED WILLIAMS
description: Phil Gailey is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times. The first time Edward Bennett Williams invited President Reagan to be his guest at the opening game of his baseball team, the Baltimore Orioles, was in 1981. Mr. Reagan failed to attend because a few days before the game he was wounded in an assassination attempt.

title: MEYER IS FAVORITE IN BOSTON MARATHON
description: The memory still lingers, like an old wound. But this time, Greg Meyer says he has entered the Boston Marathon on his terms: hungry, more experienced, better prepared and perhaps finally accepted.

title:
GARDENING;
THE WHAT AND WHEN OF SPRING PLANTING
description: AN old rule of thumb among gardeners says that certain things can be planted as soon as the soil can be worked in the spring. Included are hardy perennials, such as shasta daisies and columbines; biennials, such as pansies, sweet williams and digitalis, and perennial vegetables, such as rhubarb and asparagus.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: What Attracts the College Crowd

title: Missile Developer Is Selected
description: The Air Force has selected the General Dynamics Corporation to develop an advanced version of the cruise missile that is believed to incorporate radar-evading technology.

title: PIANO RECITAL: GREGORY ALLEN
description: Gregory Allen's recital at the 92d Street Y Tuesday night was that of a pianist whose digital skills allowed him to negotiate a variety of demanding compositions with ease. He encountered no unconquerable technical obstacles anywhere in a program comprising Beethoven's Sonata in D (Op.10, No.3), two Mazurkas and the Barcarolle of Chopin, Scriabin's Sonata No. 7 and a Rachmaninoff group consisting of a Prelude and three Etudes-Tableaux.

title: HOPE AGAINST HOPE
description: Years ago I heard an Israeli warn against ''the immorality of pessimism.'' He was saying that it is wrong to give up in a struggle for human values, however grim the odds. His warning has come back to me with the news from the Middle East in these last days.

title: Bonn's Promise Is Not Eager
description: Amid all his troubles over defense and arms control policies, President Reagan was able to draw a bit of comfort from a visit by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany last week. Mr. Kohl assured the President that Bonn would proceed, as promised, with deployment of American medium-range missiles later this year barring an agreement with the Soviet Union to eliminate them.

title: FASHION PREVIEW
description: What a difference a year makes. At this time in 1982, American designers and manufacturers - set to introduce their fall collections, the most important of the year -were facing a treacherous future. Store sales were down, even on expensive merchandise, and the general state of the economy promised little hope of change. As one line of defense against dwindling or stagnant receipts, many ''name'' talents and manufacturers launched into decidedly different design directions. A general silhouette that was curvy or sharply angular resulted, a ''high style'' look more suggestive of Europe than the rather classic, casual shapes that had become the American norm. Applauded by some, just as loudly bemoaned by others, this long-distance influence was evident throughout the year, fluctuating in forcefulness from design house to design house and from season to season - just like the sales figures.

title: N.J. HOUSING WOES ARE ALL OVER THE MAP
description: In 1975, the New Jersey Supreme Court tried to mandate housing opportunities in the suburbs. Its landmark order, known as the Mount Laurel decision, ruled that poor people had a constitutional right to decent housing outside of crowded cities and outlawed exclusionary zoning ordinances, such as estate-size minimum building lots, that led to housing only the well-to-do could afford.

title: THE BRIDE OF FRANKENSTEIN
description: ELSA LANCHESTER HERSELF By Elsa Lanchester. Illustrated. 327 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $17.95.

title: KNICKS CELEBRATE PLAYOFF SPOT
description: Dave DeBusschere had been through the excitement that accompanied the Knicks' 1970 and 1973 championships. He had been through hundreds of key games and memorable moments.

title: PAINTING IS ONCE AGAIN PROVOCATIVE
description: ''Whatever happened to painting?,'' people used to say. This was when the hot new thing in art was a spiral jetty in the Great Salt Lake, a circle of sticks or stones in the high mountains of Peru, a tube or two of fluorescent light above the tracks in Grand Central Station or a heap of felt that lay on the floor like a gun dog winded by the chase.

title:
MUSIC;
CONTEST WINNERS ARE GIVEN RECITALS
description: COMPETITIONS for instrumentalists have proliferated in recent years, but there always seems room for more. In 1981, the American Jewish Congress and the Pepsi Cola Company jointly established an annual Young Musicians competition. Geared to soloists 17 to 26 years old, the New York-based program provides winners with engagements in the metropolitan area.

title: Ann Diamond Is Married To Dr. Steven M. Stoller
description: Ann Diamond, a New York public-relations consultant, was married yesterday to Dr. Steven Marc Stoller. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at Temple Rodeph Sholom.

title: A CASE FOR PUTTING OUR GARBAGE ON A PEDESTAL, NOT IN THE CAN
description: GARBAGE is getting a bad name, and I don't think it deserves it. My own village, like so many others, has let loose a community outcry against the proposal to have a garbage transfer station located within noseshot. Posters are plastered around town raising the specter of stench. The seeds of paranoia are being planted by those folks who have chosen to play to our innate fear of filth.

title: 2 DEBATE CASINO AGENCY ROLE IN OVERSEEING URBAN RENEWAL
description: The chairman of the New Jersey Casino Control Commission and a former acting chairman have expressed sharp disagreement over whether the commission should take on the role of supervising urban renewal here.

title: TEACHER LINGERS IN PRISON IN ALIMONY PROTEST
description: Paul W. Lataille, who believes the Rhode Island divorce laws are unfair to men, has gone to jail rather than pay the $15,000 in savings, legal fees and alimony that his wife was awarded in a divorce judgment.

title:
GARDENING;
THE WHAT AND WHEN OF SPRING PLANTING
description: AN old rule of thumb among gardeners says that certain things can be planted as soon as the soil can be worked in the spring. Included are hardy perennials, such as shasta daisies and columbines; biennials, such as pansies, sweet williams and digitalis, and perennial vegetables, such as rhubarb and asparagus.

title: CHURCHES INCREASING SERVICES TO NEEDY IN TIME OF HARDSHIP
description: The Rev. William James does not call it a bread line or a soup kitchen. The 80 people who come to Metropolitan United Methodist Church at 126th Street and Madison Avenue for a meal each day sit down at what the Harlem pastor has named a ''Welcome Table.''

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: THE United Way of Westchester released contribution totals for its 1982 campaign last week, capping a yearlong effort that Ralph Gregory, the drive's executive director, charaterized as ''a remarkable achievement in these uncertain times.'' Passing the 1981 total by more than $1 million, the drive marked the first time in the 17-year history of the Westchester and Putnam campaign that a $1 million increase was realized in the space of one year. Increased contributions from the corporate sector and several outstanding community drives helped push the total to $9,103,888 for the year.

title: Water Heat a Key To Trout Fishing
description: VARYING water temperatures affect a fish's rate of feeding and the way it goes about it, something many anglers forget in the rush to learn new techniques or to try out new lures and flies.

title: Miss Frank Plans August Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Louis Frank Jr. of Short Hills, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristi Frank, to Arnim Sanchez Holzer, son of Adela Lafora Holzer of New York and Peter A. Holzer of Locust, N.J.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1 THE THORN BIRDS, by Colleen McCullough. (Avon, $3.95.) The saga of a 19th-century Australian family: basis of the television miniseries.

title: LIKE OTTO PREMINGER'S JOAN OF ARC
description: SYBILLE By Marion Meade. 444 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $17.95.

title: OFF-LIMITS STATUS DISTURBS PEMBERTON
description: IN A small corner of this 64-square-mile community bordering Fort Dix lies a hamlet that has few visitors today. And, according to military and local police officials, that is as it should be.

title: REVEALING HEROINE
description: GOING THROUGH THE MOTIONS, By Katherine Govier. 256 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $12.95.

title: TEST ON STREET LANGUAGE SAYS IT'S NOT GRANT IN THAT TOMB
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. employees scored C's and D's on an examination dealing with street language that was written by some high school students who were dismayed by the company's own standardized tests.

title: Patricia Kearton Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Kearton of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Lynn Kearton, to Laurence George Payson 2d, son of Mrs. Charles H. Sanford of Southport, Conn., and William S. Payson of Stamford, Conn. A June 18 wedding is planned.

title:
TV VIEW;
CABLE DISPLAYS A GROWING EAGERNESS TO TITILLATE
description: Only a few years ago, the dividing line was quite clear: movies, watched in the semidarkness of a cramped theater, could be ''adult,'' a label that covers anything from strong language to hardcore pornography. Television, on the other hand, was the family medium and therefore subject to innumerable restrictions. Most theatrical-release movies had to be carefully edited before being presented on the ''home screen.'' Then, along came cable television and the dividing line just about completely disappeared. The set in your living room or bedroom has remained the same, but the available product has gone through startling changes.

title: SCHOOLS PANEL BIDS STATE ADOPT NEW REGULATIONS
description: A COMMITTEE appointed by the state's Commissioner of Education to determine the ''essential criteria'' and monitoring procedures that school districts must follow to comply with the 1975 Public School Education Act has recommended that the ''Thorough and Efficient'' regulatory system be scrapped for a vastly simplified, more-focused version.

title: PART TIME HOME
description: Although it is dramatic and sophisticated, this apartment is also a one-room studio that faces on the wall of an adjacent building. All of this is fine with its occupants, the architect Dale Booher and his landscape-gardener wife, Lisa Stamm.

title: U.S. Envoy Objects To Guatemala Tribunals
description: The United States Ambassador to Guatemala has objected to the country's secret military tribunals, which have sentenced a string of guerrillas to death by firing squad.

title: Courting John Elway, in Yankee Style
description: The trappings of the New York Yankees surrounded John Elway yesterday. It was his first visit to the offices of the team that is attempting to show him that it is better to start his fulltime professional career as a minor-league outfielder with the Yankees than as a National Football League quarterback.

title: FOR WARSAW, FEW FLOWERS AT THE GHETTO
description: Warsaw is a city so battered by the war that there is a pocket guidebook, more than an inch thick, with the street addresses of where atrocities took place.

title: CHANGED FOR THE BETTER
description: In an effort to keep the kettle boiling, audio manufacturers churn out new products at a rate that seems alarming to sober-minded bystanders. Before marketing overtook engineering as the prime determinant of the industry, hi-fi components had a typical product cycle of about five years, meaning that a particular model remained in production for that length of time before being replaced.

title: US AND THEM, BUT NOT INVARIABLY
description: I WORK part time in a blue jean store in the Hamptons. It's a great b lue jean store. We sell only Levis and I love the product. I'm good at my job. I can analyze a body the minute it walks in thed oor. I know right away if it's a 505 or a 20505 or a 719. I know w hich jeans give and which jeans shrink. In a matter of seconds I canf it man, woman or child into a full-cut tapered leg, a tapered-fit s traight leg or a low-rise boot-jean, prewashed or unwashed.

title: SANTIAGO'S SOARING SHRINE
description: During the 1960's and 1970's, I spent a lot of time exploring the medieval churches and cathedrals of central and southern France, and I soon came to expect to find, in some corner or other, a sculptured relief of a scallop shell, the symbol of St. James the Apostle. The shells were there, a bit of reading revealed, because the buildings had served in the 11th and 12th centuries as hostels for the million or more pilgrims who each year walked from France - and from Britain, Germany and Scandinavia - to the great shrine at Santiago de Compostela in northwestern Spain, where the saint's bones were said to have been unearthed in the ninth century.

title: Richmond Riding a New Road
description: Two years ago, Tim Richmond's career as an Indy car driver was stalled. A series of crashes after winning the Rookie-of-the-Year award at Indy had put him on the sideline. Now, after a struggle to prove himself, he has established himself as one of the most successful new drivers on the Winston Cup stock car circuit.

title: Tax Bites Bite Koch
description: It's been a while since City Council President Carol Bellamy was able to publicly rattle Mayor Koch, her favorite political nemesis. But she got to him last week after blowing the whistle on an embarrassing tax report he had kept under wraps since October.

title: THEATER: DARIO FO'S 'ABOUT FACE'
description: In his irreverent political farces, Dario Fo poses what-if questions and then hypothesizes answers to the point of hilarity. His new comedy, ''About Face,'' in its English-language premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater, ponders the murder of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro of Italy and then fantasizes about the possible kidnapping of Giovanni Agnelli. As owner of Fiat and other enterprises, he is the richest industrialist in Italy.

title: ORATORIO: 'PLAGUES FOR OUR TIME'
description: Our jittery post-industrial society doesn't lack for fear of rampant infection. And this sense of being under siege by a thousand potential perils, from nuclear radiation to herpes, is the basis of Tom O'Horgan's and Eve Merriam's satirical oratorio ''Plagues for Our Time.'' An hourlong work for unaccompanied 20-voice chorus and percussion, ''Plagues for Our Time'' amusingly implies that the unpleasant banalities of everyday -everything from meaningless work to presweetened food and spray cans -are plagues that we have brought upon ourselves.

title: Women And Chess
description: To the Editor:

title: Talk Isn't Cheap In Argentina
description: Ever since they lost the Falkland war, Argentina's generals have squabbled publicly and privately over who was at fault. The nasty spectacle turned somewhat bizarre last week as the Argentine army arrested its former leader for publicly blaming those he led.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Ladies Auxiliary at Overlook Hospital in Summit is brimming with pride over the latest acclaim given to its fund-raising cookbook, ''Cooking Is Our Bag.'' Good Housekeeping magazine features the 256-page work in this month's ''Cookbook Corner.''

title: WILLIAMS CENTER TEETERS ON BRINK
description: THE William Carlos Williams Center for the Performing Arts in Rutherford has been teetering for months on the brink of default of a $3 million bank loan. Last Thursday, despite a campaign to raise funds, it fell over the edge when its sponsors failed to make a $62,000 monthly payment.

title: DINING: FOUR COUNTRY INNS
description: At its best, dining in the Ile de France means a relaxed meal in a comfortable country auberge where the chef takes his work seriously. Here are four worth sampling while touring the region around Paris, listed in order of personal preference. Prices are for a meal for one: appetizer, main course, cheese or dessert and coffee, and half a bottle of a $15 wine, tax and tip. In all cases, reserve, particularly for Sunday lunch. Saint-Germain-en-Laye Cazaudehore, 1 Avenue President Kennedy, 78100 Saint-Germain-en-Laye (telephone: 451-93-80). Closed Monday. No credit cards. About $28 a person. The bright, flowered terrace of Cazaudehore, on the edge of the Saint Germain forest in the historic little town of Saint-Germain-en-Laye, is ideal for a leisurely Sunday lunch. Energetic travelers many want to walk from the train station - it's a vigorous, 30-minute wander along the edge of the forest full of song birds and wildflowers. In addition to the terrace - one of the region's prettiest outdoor dining spots - there is a rustically elegant, wellappointed dining room, where the service is accommodating and professional.
