Cazaudehore offers a few specialties of the Basque region, including piperade, a hearty blend of scrambled eggs mixed with peppers, country ham and hot chipolata sausages, but the cuisine here is generally classic and correct. Good dishes to sample are a mixed salad tossed with apples and walnuts and a superb poached salmon set on a bed of spinach. The cheese tray is thoughtfully selected and offers fine, fresh cheeses from thoughout France.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: SUPERINTENDING THE STATE'S BANKS
description: ''WELL,'' said Vincent S. Tese, ''I thought about John Stuart Mill's essays, 'On Liberty,' and our duties to the state, and I felt that it probably was the right thing to give a certain amount of one's time to public service.''

title: MOBILE MEDICAL UNITS FACE CUTS
description: AN EMERGENCY medical program that has been credited with saving many lives in the state is now fighting for its own life. New Jersey's Mobile Intensive Care Unit (M.I.C.U.) system, which provides on-the-scene treatment for victims of heart attacks, accidents or other medical crises, is facing loss of funds as a result of a change in hospital reimbursement policy by the Health Care Financing Administration of the Federal Department of

title: SALEM PLANTS GET CONTROL SIMULATOR
description: A SIMULATED control room for the nearby Salem nuclear-power plants will be put into service here in September, but the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, while commending the $8 million project, said that it might not get to the heart of part of the plants' problem, specifically that of Salem I.

title: BOOK SALE TO AID THEATER
description: SOME 8,000 rare and out-of-print books will be put on sale today in Litchfield at prices ranging from $2 to $5,000. In addition to calling attention to the hundred or so specialized booksellers in Connecticut, the sale will aid the renovation of an art-deco theater in Torrington.

title: JERUSALEM: ISRAELIS ASSERT THE PLAN NEVER HAD ANY CHANCE
description: ISRAELI officials had to bite their tongues last week to keep from saying, ''We told you so.'' All their assessments of Arab intransigence and American naivete were, they felt, bolstered demonstratively by the failure of Jordan's King Hussein to get the agreement of the Palestine Liberation Organization to his talking with Israel about the future of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Reagan plan, calling for the eventual transfer of the territories to Palestinian rule in association with Jordan, was withering away, just as Prime Minister Menachem Begin had predicted it would.

title: ANTIQUES VIEW
description: The exquisite, gem-studded fantasies of Peter Carl Faberge, Russian jeweler to the Romanovs, have been collected by five generations of British royalty and admired internationally since they first appeared at the turn of the century.

title: NEW TALENT TO BE HEARD
description: COMPETITIONS may have their problems and pitfalls, yet unquestionably they provide important career stepping stones for the emerging artist. As it happens, quite a few musicians in the winner's circle at recent auditions are performing in the county this week - so there is a chance to combine good listening with the joy of discovery.

title: SAN FRANCISCO POLITICS IS SOMETHING ELSE
description: This city's rarely dull political scene has produced yet another oddity -next week's recall election, an attempt to unseat Mayor Dianne Feinstein that stems from her support for guncontrol legislation.

title: THE TENANT AS CO-OP CUSTOMER
description: A cooperative owner named Sheldon Einhorn is happy to be taking a back seat these days in the affairs of an apartment building called the Cromwell at 69-60 108th Street in the Forest Hills section of Queens. But he won't soon forget the events of last summer. ''It was a wild time,'' he said.

title: CAN THE PINELANDS BE PROTECTED IF THE MASTER PLAN IS IGNORED?
description: WILL New Jersey's plan to ''enhance, protect and preserve'' the 1.1-million-acre Pine Barrens succeed? As developments are approved and conformance by local and county governments to the state's Comprehensive Management Plan is certified, environmentalists are asking that question with increasing concern.

title: Pastor Magruder
description: After doing seven months of prison penance for his role in the Watergate coverup, Jeb Stuart Magruder became a student at the Princeton Theological Seminary, then quit to become an industry executive and finally quit that to return and finish his Master of Divinity course at the seminary. In May 1982 he was invited to become associate pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of Burlingame, Calif., 17 miles south of San Francisco.

title: Future Events; Festivals, Flowers, Fun
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Gershwin Gala April 18 - After a performance of the vintage musical ''Rosalie,'' by George Gershwin and Sigmund Romberg, at Town Hall at 8 P.M., merrymakers can trot across the street to join Maureen O'Sullivan, who will serve as host at a party at the Century Cafe, 132 West 43d Street, to benefit the New Amsterdam Theater Company. The party will include Dina Merrill and Cliff Robertson from the play's cast, more Gershwin tunes by the pianist Steve Ross and the singer Paula Laurence and the New York City Gay Men's Chorus Chamber Choir. The theater company is dedicated to the preservation and performance of old musicals. Tickets to the show and party, which include a bar, canapes and snacks, are $35; show only, $16.50; party only, $20. From 586-1586.

title: A SPOTLIGHT ON LOCAL COMPOSERS
description: WHEN you think of an enclave of composers, you probably think of Vienna in the 1800's or maybe Paris around the turn-of-the-century. You might not think of Connecticut in 1983. Yet Connecticut these days is alive with melodic creativity; from the more traditional strains of Robert Dix's symphonies to Chinary Ung's Cambodian-inspired instrumentations to Vaclav Nelhybel's ''Graffiti Pompeiani'' - five movements for seven solo singers, inspired by ancient wall inscriptions.

title: On Air Fares
description: To the Business Editor:

title: 'ALWAYS AVAILABLE' MAYOR CALLS IT A DAY
description: TO spend 30 years as a mayor, trustee and committeeman in Rockville Centre is to have everyone around know the most personal details of your life.

title: BACK OFFICES IN THE OUTER BOROUGHS
description: NEW YORK CITY'S fledgling campaign to attract significant corporate b ack-office operations to its outer boroughs was subjected to a s earching, sometimes skeptical scrutiny last week at a forum in M anhattan.

title: Nicaragua Reports Releasing Three Fishermen From U.S.
description: The Sandinist authorities said today that they had freed three United States sport fishermen seized Friday in two rented boats off Nicaragua's Caribbean coast.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: PERRY B. DURYEA, the former State Assembly Speaker, has announced plans to construct 200 luxury condominium units and 23 middle income housing units at the former New York Ocean Sciences Laboratory in Montauk. A marine research facility is also envisaged for the site.

title: Court Voids the 'Baby Doe' Rule
description: It seems hard to imagine anything more heartbreaking than giving birth to a severely handicapped child, unless it is not having a say in how it should, or shouldn't, be treated. Last week, a Federal judge eased the dilemma, if not the pain, by striking down the Reagan Administration's recent effort to regulate the issue -the ''Baby Doe'' rule - as a ''hasty, ill-considered'' intrusion into ''one of the most difficult and sensitive medical and ethical problems.''

title: Catherine R. Gambino and Andrew Garroni Marry
description: Catherine R. Gambino, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S. Raymond Gambino of New York and Englewood Cliffs, N.J., was married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral to Andrew W. Garroni, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Garroni, also of Englewood Cliffs. The Rev. Anthony Dalla Villa performed the ceremony.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC

title: Rights Panel Loses Patience
description: After sharp complaints last month by the usually mild-mannered chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights, several Government agencies produced documents sought by the panel. Early last week, the commission voted to issue subpoenas to two footdraggers, the Departments of Labor and Education; by the end of the week, the hard line appeared to have paid off.

title: A SPY IN THE HOUSE OF LOVE
description: IT was the weekend before St. Valentine's Day. Love had come, temporarily, to Sacramento, Calif., at $65 a head. In an epidemic of Gold Rush fever, approximately 400 romance readers, writers and publishers descended on the Red Lion Motor Inn on Interstate 80 for the so-called ''West Coast Rom/ Con II'' - three solid days of romance explication, with lots of ''boom or bust excitement.'' The meeting was sponsored by Affaire de Coeur magazine.

title: Henrietta Barlow and Roger Fridholm Are Wed
description: Henrietta Barlow, who heads the Barlow Development Company, a national media development and production concern in Detroit, was married yesterday in Washington to Roger Fridholm, president and chief operating officer of the Stroh Brewery Company, also in Detroit. The ceremony was performed at the National Cathedral (SS.

title: READING AND WRITING
description: What accounts for the hostility that American novelists display toward American business -and so toward America, whose business, as they say, is business? Variations on that question are much on the minds of conservative intellectuals these days. A few weeks ago The Committee for the Free World, an ideological spinoff of Commentary magazine, held a weekend conference at the Plaza Hotel that was devoted to attacking what Joseph Epstein, editor of the American Scholar, called the left-wing cliches being floated by the likes of Norman Mailer, E.L. Doctorow, Robert Coover and Robert Stone.

title: Stars Beat Invaders
description: Kelvin Bryant broke off runs of 45 and 37 yards late in the first half as Philadelphia built a 10-0 lead, and the Stars went on to a 17-7 United States Football League victory over the Oakland Invaders today.

title: SUPERPOWER PEACE THROUGH AGRICULTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: For too many years, I have observed my alma mater to move in lockstep with the liberal fashion of the times.

title: FACE RACE TO ATTRACT TECHNOLOGY
description: EXECUTIVES from high-technology companies throughout the state are being asked over lunch, cocktails, and at business meetings this month what they think about doing business in Connecticut. Their answers, being sought by members of the Governor's High-Technology Council, will help state officials develop strategies to attract new high-tech companies and encourage existing firms to stay and expand.

title: Plane Crashes in the Sudan
description: A Liberian airliner crashed into a house soon after takeoff today from Khartoum, the capital of the Sudan, killing 14 people. The Middle East News Agency said the plane's captain parachuted to safety.

title: Data Bank  April 17, 1983
AWASH IN NOSTALGIA FOR A CLASS REUNION
description: LAST fall the mail brought a letter that began, ''Dear Classmate - Plans are afoot for a high school reunion next spring.'' High school reunion! Turn back the hands of time. Graduation night was the last occasion most of us had seen one another. Along with the letter was a list of the class, all 123 of us, accompanied by a plea to supply whatever current addresses and married names we knew.

title: HE'S AN ELECTRONIC HOCKEY SCOUT
description: ELIMINATION of the Vancouver Canucks during the first round of National Hockey League playoffs hasn't discourged one of the team's most fervent fans, 17-year-old Jay Grossman. Not only a fan, but also a scout of sorts for the team during the last two years, he has been called a key man in the Canadian team's defense by none other than the Canucks coach, Roger Neilson.

title: Vanishing Teeth
description: George Washington's uppers and lowers - an ivory and gold set of false teeth - disappeared from a locked storeroom in the nation's capital in June 1981, and in May 1982 the case was half solved: The lowers were returned anonymously to the room.

title: Levittown Has Second Thoughts
description: Levittown was enveloped in a time warp last week. Twenty-nine years after the Long Island community decided to fluoridate its drinking water, residents decided to abandon the cavity-fighting chemical in the name of ''pure'' water.

title: Elizabeth Sulimirski to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Witold S. Sulimirski of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Maria Sulimirski, to Donald Powell Blakeslee Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Blakeslee, also of Bronxville.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 5 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 2 2 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga.

title: JAPANESE VICTORIAN
description: Set in mountains sometimes washed in gray, like the atmospheric ink paintings they have inspired, the Fujiya Hotel is named for its view of Mount Fuji. It is typically poetic of the Japanese to have named a hotel after something so dreamlike as a view, but the Fujiya is otherwise less than typically Japanese.

title: John Taylor Johnston Coe Will Wed Gay Katherine Larkin in September
description: The engagement of Gay Katherine Larkin to John Taylor Johnston Coe has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester P. Larkin Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Coe 3d of Lawrence, L.I., and Johannesburg.

title: Ann Marie Marriott to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent J. Marriott of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Marie Marriott, to Brent Doyal Ballard, son of Mrs. William F. Cody of Pepper Pike, Ohio, and Dr. Lester A. Ballard Jr., of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. A July wedding is planned. Miss Marriott's father is executive vice president, international operations, of the Continental Can Company in Stamford, Conn., and a vice president of the Continental Group. Dr. Ballard, a gynecologist, is chairman of the department of gynecology at the Cleveland Clinic Foundation.

title: LIFETIME EMPLOYMENT, U.S. STYLE
description: WHEN the recession deepened in 1981, several top executives at the Materials Resource Corporation began to fear their chairman was making a mistake. Like many suppliers of the semiconductor industry, the ceramics and equipment manufacturer based in Orangeburg, N.Y., faced slumping sales. Employees stood idle. Layoffs seemed likely.

title:
ART;
CELEBRATING POWER AND ORIGINALITY
description: WHEN specific ethnic identifications are attached to an experience in the arts, we often pause to wonder whether we are being asked to see the work in a special way. However, in the case of ''Celebrating Contemporary American Black Artists,'' a sizable exhibition at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island, the director-curator, Eleanor Flomenhaft, has taken great care to point out that her goal is to contribute to an understanding of the diversity in the nation's art by showing this diversity to be clearly present in one representative segment of the art community.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: NEW JERSEY'S only known pair of bald eagles may be purging themselves of the DDT that has impeded their reproduction since 1976. Stanley Wiemeyer, a research biologist at the Patuxent Wildlife Center in Laurel, Md., an arm of the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service, said last week that measurements of the eggshells of the two recently hatched eaglets showed improvement over last year.

title: Jennifer Lubrano Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. David G. Lubrano of Hingham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Lynne Lubrano to Mark Gardner Clayton, son of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Clayton, also of Hingham. The wedding is planned for Sept. 17.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We very much want to get our riders back, and as quickly as possible. People will definitely get something for nothing, which they probably deserve after all they've been through in the strike.'' - Peter Stangl, president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. (1:2.)

title: Michigan Regents Bob and Weave
description: University investment portfolios have been targets of campus protest for years, especially since Vietnam-era arguments about industrial support for unpopular military ventures. Debate over financial links to South Africa has been just as bitter, with the University of Michigan the latest scene of contention between those who believe American-owned business helps apartheid and those who think it mitigates a racist system.

title: ROLE OF MILITARY IS KEY ISSUE IN THAI ELECTION
description: Thailand is scheduled to elect a new House of Representatives on Monday in a nationwide general election in which the central issue has been the military's role in politics.

title: Pact Reached in Strike By Kingsbrook Nurses
description: Representatives of striking nurses and the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn have reached a tentative agreement to end an eight-day walkout, a union spokesman said yesterday.

title: Q & A
description: Can A Lease Be Willed? Question: If a close relative in a rent-controlled Manhattan apartment wills her apartment lease to me, what is the possiblity of my inheriting it at its current rent rate? Will the apartment rent jump to market value? ...A.L., Manhattan.

title: 49 Food Outlets Cited by City As Violators of Sanitary Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 49 food outlets last week for violations of the health code. In addition, the department named two restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and one that was closed for having failed to do so. VIOLATIONS China Sur Restaurant, 15 Ave. B Cafe Jean Claude, 1312 Madison Ave. My Daddy's Pizza, 50 Trinity Pl. Ciccio's Restaurant, 1 Walker St. Yolanta's Restaurant, 119 First Ave. Gay Robin, 1502 First Ave. Maya Palace, 60 Second Ave. Jamboree, 1047 Second Ave. Allen's Restaurant, 1315 Second Ave. Camelback & Central Restaurant, 1403 Second Ave. Theo's Coffee Shop, 359 Fifth Ave. Jimmy Ray's, 729 Eighth Ave. Wilson's Bar, 360 W. 23d St. Louis Luncheonette, 452 W. 36th St. Kaplan's Deli, 71 W. 47th St. Imperial Dragon West, 45 W. 55th St. India Pavilion, 156 W. 56th St. City Island Seafood, 500 City Island Ave., Bronx. Half Crown Pub, 1751 Crosby Ave., Bronx. Arizona Fried Chicken, 2268 Grand Concourse, Bronx. Venice Bar & Grill, 984 Morris Park Ave., Bronx. Popeye's Kitchen, 3949 White Plains Rd., Bronx. Wo Far Kitchen, 300 W. 231st St., Bronx. Bedford Restaurant, 184 Bedford Ave., Brooklyn. Murphy's Tavern, 156 Calyer St., Brooklyn.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Explosion of Emotion

title: Elizabeth C. Ross to Wed George M. Sachs in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Ira Franklin Ross of South Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Constance Ross, to George Morrison Sachs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Maxwell Sachs of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: RAIL UNION TAKES ARBITRATION STEP
description: Leaders of the striking trainmen's union yesterday took one of two steps needed to ratify a decision to arbitrate their six-week-old dispute with the Metro-North Commuter Railroad. The president of the railroad said trains would roll tomorrow morning if the process was completed today.

title: ARE CONDUCTORS NECESSARY?
description: The other evening, when I should have been totally absorbed in watching an amateur conductor lead the American Symphony Orchestra through Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony, my mind kept wandering. The man at the podium was Gilbert E. Kaplan, a wealthy devotee of Mahler who pays orchestras to let him conduct the one work in his repertory, the ''Resurrection.'' The American Symphony, a cooperative organization controlled by the musicians themselves, had invited Mr. Kaplan to conduct this concert, a benefit for the orchestra to which the public was invited. Mr. Kaplan is a 40-ish businessman who founded a magazine called Institutional Investor. Perhaps the struggling American Symphony wanted to tap him for muchneeded financial advice as well as musical contributions. That, at least, would help explain the decision to turn over the orchestra and Mahler to him for a public outing.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ''NEW YORK Loves New Jersey'' may not be the new slogan of either state, but it's the theme of a dinner Tuesday night at the Tamcrest County Club in Alpine.

title: SENATE G.O.P. MODERATES MAY CHART AN INDEPENDENT COURSE
description: During a Senate Budget Committee meeting last week, Senator Lawton Chiles of Florida, the ranking Democrat, proposed increasing taxes by $30 billion in fiscal year 1984. Senator Mark Andrews, a North Dakota Republican, crossed over and voted with a solid block of Democrats for the proposal.

title: Most Economic Signs Point to Sound Recovery
description: After months of equivocal signals, the week's economic indicators came as a double-barreled shot of confidence. Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, summed up. ''Inflation is down and real output is growing at a very good pace; it is just the kind of recovery we were hoping for.''

title: 'NEW MOON' RISES IN MILLBURN
description: ''STOUT-HEARTED MEN,'' ''Softly, as in a Morning Sunrise,'' ''One Kiss,'' ''Wanting You,'' ''Lover Come Back to Me.'' It sounds like the Hit Parade of 1928 - a cornucopia of operetta standards, not to mention ''Marianne,'' which is perhaps the most delectable number in this lot.

title: Tragedy Shows Peril in Offshore Racing
description: The Rev. Paul S. Tipton, S.J., rose early on the morning of the Lightship Race to study the weather. Besides being the president of Spring Hill College in Mobile, Ala., Father Tipton races a 40-foot sloop called Holy Smoke with a crew of students.

title: DANCE: GROUP DESIGNS BY IRENE FEIGENHEIMER
description: It's not often that one longs for messy choreography. Yet some dances are so neat, tidy and finicky that one wishes their choreographers would loosen up and let passion guide them. Should a bit of a mess result, that may not be a calamity because there are times when lively disorder is better than placidity.

title: Manchester, Brighton In English Cup Final
description: Manchester United and Brighton, from opposite ends of the English League First Division soccer standing, won their semifinal matches today and advanced to the English Cup final May 21 at Wembley Stadium.

title: AIDE URGED PENTAGON TO CONSIDER WEAPONS MADE BY FORMER CLIENT
description: Richard N. Perle, an Assistant Secretary of Defense, recommended that the Army consider buying weapons from an Israeli company a year after he accepted a $50,000 consulting fee from the company's owners, according to Mr. Perle and an attorney for the weapons dealer.

title: ZOELLER'S 65 FOR 204 GAINS LEAD BY SHOT
description: Fuzzy Zoeller came from six shots off the pace with a six-under-par 65 and moved into a one-stroke lead today in the third round of the $350,000 Sea Pines Heritage Classic.

title: GOOD LAW OR A GOOD LAUGH? ASSEMBLY BILLS CAN BE BOTH
description: IT is not all just the big issues such as taxes and budgets at the State Capitol these days. The General Assembly's hopper of bills for consideration this session has filled to the brim with a lot of ideas for state laws. Many of the bills, of course, do deal with important issues such as the state's fiscal problems, education, health, environment, transportation and the like. But a few would appear to fall into a less weighty category.

title: Sunny's Halo Triumphs In the Arkansas Derby
description: Sunny's Halo, despite breaking from the No. 13 post position and giving away 3 to 11 pounds, scored a front-running, 4-length victory today in the $293,900 Arkansas Derby at Oaklawn Park today.

title: PEELING AWAY JAPAN'S TRADE BARRIERS
description: IT is Japan's peculiar legacy that, for several centuries, the island nation lived in virtual isolation from the outside world. Contact was allowed in a few places, like the Western port of Nagasaki, the mythic home of Madame Butterfly. But from the time the pilgrims landed in the New World until the American Civil War raged, the Japanese cherished their insularity. A visit to the outside world during this era was a crime punishable by death for a Japanese.

title: Susan Patel to Marry R.M. Furlaud Jr.
description: The engagement of Susan Patel to Richard Mortimer Furlaud Jr., son of Mr. Furlaud and Elspeth Banks Furlaud, both of New York, has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Jamshed R. Patel of Summit, N.J., parents of the future bride. A September wedding is planned.

title: To Help Hockey
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NANCY LIEBERMAN'S REVIVE-A-LEAGUE CAMPAIGN
description: IT'S funny, but I still get the same feeling every April. The college basketball season is over and the professional sports are beginning their playoff drive. The newspaper, television and radio sports reports are jammed with the progress of National Basketball Association teams jockeying for position in the playoffs and how the National Hockey League is faring in its Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: MARTINA ARROYO IS BACK AFTER A FIVE-YEAR ABSENCE
description: When, after an absence of five years, the American soprano Martina Arroyo appears in recital at Carnegie Hall this evening, concertgoers will reacquaint themselves with an operatic voice that New York critics once deemed to be among the most glorious in the world.

title:
DANCE VIEW;
SOME BALLETS MADE FOR LOS ANGELES
description: Aprogress report on the Los Angeles Ballet, first seen here in 1980, was made easy this month when the 10-year-old company founded by John Clifford breezed into town for a few performances at the Joyce Theater. Mr. Clifford's case is an interesting one in that he has chosen a path that differs markedly from that of other past or present house choreographers in the New York City Ballet. Like most choreographers whose work was first presented by the City Ballet, he was also a dancer in the company. But unlike many, he chose to leave the City Ballet early in his career.

title: TWO GOOD SINGERS IN SEARCH OF POPULARITY
description: Kate Bush and Marianne Faithfull might seem at first glance to make an unlikely pairing. True, both are English, both are women and both are rock singers. But Miss Faithfull is a formerly angelic ingenue from the 60's who now sings straightforward rock with a husky, weathered voice, while Miss Bush is still an ingenue in her early 20's who makes an almost impossibly ornate, giddily overproduced modern-day art-rock.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE SILVER COW, A Welsh Tale. Retold by Susan Cooper. Illustrated by Warwick Hutton. Unpaged. New York: Atheneum/Margaret K. McElderry. $11.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: SOUTHOLD PONDERS MORATORIUM
description: WHILE Southold Town is trying to protect its shrinking farmlands by revising the town's master plan, it is also trying to decide how best to discourage real-estate developers from carving up the open space until then.

title: THE PIED-A-TERRE
description: Many people who are fortunate enough to have small apartments in the city are choosing to hold onto them, rather than give them up, when they move on to the suburbs. The transformation from apartment to pied-a-terre often results not only in practical city headquarters, but in attractive designs that use space in inventive ways. But a spot to rest one's head was not the only prerequisite given to Doug Frank, a young interior designer, when he was asked by two clients to redesign two such tiny studio apartments.

title: Charity Begins at Home?
description: Sir Richard Attenborough got Academy Awards last week for producing and directing the film ''Gandhi,'' and then got what-for when he decided to attend the film's segregated premiere in South Africa.

title: NAZI-HUNTER SEES RESPONSIBILITY TO GO ON
description: born Nazi-hunter who tracked down Klaus Barbie in Bolivia, told an audience in the county last week that ''most'' of the 76,000 French Jews deported to death camps during World War II ''would have been saved if France had refused to help the Nazis.''

title: GOING HOLLYWOOD
description: DAYS WITHOUT WEATHER, by Cecil Brown, 250 pp New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

title: AN AMERICAN SOUND
description: ALL AMERICAN MUSIC Composition in the Late Twentieth Century. By John Rockwell. 286 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: ISLANDERS DOMINATING THE SERIES
description: Duane Sutter, like most of his Islander teammates, knows what to expect tonight at Madison Square Garden. ''The fans there don't like the Islanders,'' he said, almost amused by the thought. ''They throw stuff, they yell things at us. But we get a kick out of that. Deep down, it gets our blood boiling.

title: WELFARE RULES CHANGING TO MEET U.S. CRITERIA
description: New York and Connecticut welfare officials said this week that they expected to avoid any loss of Federal funds by fully complying with new welfare rules within a few months.

title: Barbara Ingram Wed To Thornley A. Hart
description: Barbara Purnell Ingram, daughter of Mrs. Barron Proctor Lambert of Stevenson, Md., and the late Charles Lindley Ingram, was married yesterday to Thornley Anthony Hart, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thornley William Hart of New York and Cedarhurst, L.I. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. E.Melville Taylor at the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Sacred Heart in Mount Washington, Md.

title: POLL FINDS REAGAN GAINS ON ECONOMY
description: Public approval of President Reagan's handling of the economy has rebounded slightly, halting a decline in confidence that began two years ago, according to The New York Times/ CBS News Poll.

title: Sandra Stark, Consultant, Weds James Mersfelder
description: Sandra Lee Stark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Stark of Teaneck, N.J., and Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to James L. Mersfelder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester A. Mersfelder of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. Harold N. Gainer, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: UNORTHODOX CERAMICS
description: THE exhibition of selections from the Daniel Jacobs collection of contemporary ceramics, currently on view at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, largely features nonfunctional pieces, or rather, pieces whose primary function is esthetic. Mr. Jacobs began collecting such works on a trip to Britain, where many of the old distinctions between art and craft have been successfully challenged.

title: PESSIMISM IS MATCHING DECLINE IN ECONOMY IN FRANCE
description: France has entered a sensitive and difficult period of deepening economic problems, disagreement over how they should be solved and recurring talk of the possibility of social unrest.

title: CONCERT: MUSICA CAMERIT PLAYS WITH VOCAL ENSEMBLE
description: Musica Camerit is a recently formed chamber ensemble directed by the pianist Samuel Sanders, and featuring Masao Kawasaki, violist, Stephen Kates, cellist, and the flutist Carol Wincenc. Tuesday night in the Abraham Goodman House, they were joined by the soprano Lucy Shelton and a vocal ensemble under the direction of Joel Revzen.

title: Stearns's Condition Is Causing Confusion
description: At the end of a week of misplays and maddening losses on the field, the Mets were confronted today with a misplay and maddening loss off the field: John Stearns was back on the disabled list, only four days after he had come off it.

title: Teamster Boss Gives It All Up
description: Teamsters' union president Roy L. Williams last week gave up his kingdom for remaining free on bail while he appeals his conviction of conspiring to bribe former Senator Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada. But under the plea bargain, proposed three weeks ago by Federal prosecutors, he retains the trappings if not the power of his office until 5:00 P. M. Wednesday.

title: WHY WE WATCH THE ACADEMY AWARDS
description: It's like taking an extremely slow Seventh Avenue Local to heaven. It's a very long ride, and overcrowded, and the arrival -by which time one is exhausted - is always a bit of an anticlimax. Yet one simply cannot afford to miss it. It is, of course, the annual Oscar awards ceremony of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences - and the 55th presentation, last Monday night, was everything one could have wished it to be, including dignified.

title: Death of Black Musician Brings Rights Conviction
description: A 21-year-old white man who was acquitted of murder two years ago in the beating death of a black jazz saxophonist was convicted Friday of violating the musician's civil rights.

title: NEW HAVEN MAYOR PLANS AN ART CENTER
description: AN X-rated film was the only show playing last week in what will become the Shubert Square Entertainment District. But city officials hope to replace the Crown Theater, the downtown movie house that plays ''adult films,'' with a community stage for New Haven's hundreds of artists.

title: POLLUTION IS DULLING MAJESTY OF TAJ MAHAL
description: As it has for three-and-a-third centuries, the Taj Mahal still dazzles visitors with the shifting moods one might hope for in one of the world's most famous monuments to love.

title: BIG SOUND, SMALL SYSTEMS
description: My first view of New York City filled me with alarm. It was the only city I had ever seen where most buildings were taller than they were wide, and it made me profoundly uneasy. I had been accustomed to the horizontal sprawl of Vienna and Paris, and only many years later did I come to realize that high-rise buildings were destined to become the predominant mode of urban habitation. It is cheaper to stack up people in layers than to spread them out on the ground.

title: WASHINGTON WILL LEAD BUT WILL CHICAGO FOLLOW?
description: In the predawn hours of Wednesday morning, after the votes had been counted, Milton Stewart was at work in a downtown parking lot when he spotted a familiar face. ''What did I tell you,'' he said, smiling broadly, ''We did it.''

title: REAGAN RIGHTS POLICY CALLED WEAK IN 4 LATIN NATIONS
description: Contacts have declined between United States embassies and opposition leaders in the military-run countries in the southern part of South America since President Reagan took office, according to American diplomats and opposition leaders in those countries.

title: Melisande Stone Marries Maurice J. Clos-Versailles
description: Melisande Grace Stone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emerson Stone of Greenwich, Conn., was married at Christ Episcopal Church there yesterday to Maurice Jean Clos-Versailles of Greenwich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmond Clos-Versailles of Lembeye, France.

title: Fight at Campbell
description: To the Business Editor:

title: IN 'PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF SANTA MONICA,' VOTERS TURN TO THE RIGHT
description: This seaside city, which turned so far to the left politically in the last four years that critics dubbed it ''the People's Republic of Santa Monica,'' has taken a turn back to the right at its municipal elections.

title: IN DEFENSE OF BUSING
description: Lee A Daniels is a reporter on the Metropolitan staff of The Times.

title: THOSE SUTTER BROTHERS
description: HOCKEY has always been a game for brothers - the Richards, the Espositos, the Hulls, the Mahovliches, the Bentleys, the Plagers, the Potvins, the Maloneys, the Patricks, the Cooks, just to name a few. But in another season or so, there will be six Sutter brothers, yes, six, in the National Hockey League; already there are four. And as far as the Rangers are concerned in their Stanley Cup playoff with the Islanders that resumes in Madison Square Garden tonight, two Sutters are too many.

title: THE ADVISER'S ADVICE
description: POWER AND PRINCIPLE, Memoirs of the National Security Adviser, 1977-1981. By Zbigniew Brzezinski. Illustrated. 587 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.50.

title: NEW HERO IS CREATED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The slain leader of a rural black community that has been resisting the Government's attempts to force it to surrender land it has owned for three generations was canonized today as a hero by black nationalist groups that turned his funeral into a political protest.

title: NEW DISKS FOR CHILDREN OF ALL AGES
description: A sampling of what's new in children's recordings has turned up some winners along with the inevitable assortment of losers and uninspired items appealing, like their counterparts for adults, to the lowest possible common denominator. Few age levels are overlooked. I have yet to come across any records for 1-year-olds, but there is ''Music for 2's and 3's'' (CMS 693; cassette CMSX 4693) an album of ''game and activity songs'' featuring the soothing, serene voice of Jenny Michaels backed by a guitar and a rhythm band. All pleasant and instructive enough, no doubt, if you're 1 or 3.

title: HOW REID FORGED VICTORY AT CONVENTION
description: WESTCHESTER'S Democrats made their choice last week - Ogden R. Reid over Anthony Veteran, as candidate for the post of County Executive - and the narrow margin, 56 percent of the vote at a nominating convention, did not reflect the powerful impact of Mr. Reid's victory.

title: VOLUTEERS WITH A PERSONAL TOUCH
description: At exactly 6:30 last Thursday morning, Carol Roaman, Bob Gordon and Marilyn Fisher went down the steps of the East 55th Street entrance of Central Synagogue, through the empty auditorium and into the kitchen to begin preparing vegetable soup and coffee for 80 guests. By 7 o'clock, the three had been joined by an assembly line of a dozen other well-dressed men and women making cheese sandwiches and slicing oranges.

title: The Jordan Door Slams Shut
description: President Reagan wants to believe that King Hussein's resounding ''no'' to negotiations with Israel only means ''not yet.'' He wants to believe that the P.L.O.'s rejection of his approach to peace was engineered by a few radicals and might yet be undone. But it is hard to imagine that Middle East politics can soon create a better climate for the compromise Mr. Reagan was trying to sell. More likely, another chapter in the Arab-Israeli conflict is now closed, with fateful consequences all around.

title: Sean Crombie Connor Weds Anne Wheeler
description: Anne Kathleen Wheeler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Charles Wheeler of Tulsa, Okla., was married in New York yesterday to Sean Crombie Connor, son of Alice Connor Bassett of Christiansted, V.I., and the late John Powers Connor. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony at All Souls Unitarian Church.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN GENEVA
description: In this cosmopolitan city on the largest Alpine lake, which prides itself on functioning with the precision of a Swiss watch movement, the ironic attraction this spring is a display of weird and completely useless machines. Helvetian efficiency is confronted with the absurd in a retrospective exhibition of 150 works created between 1954 and 1981 by Jean Tinguely. The artist, born in Fribourg in 1922 and well known in New York, has long challenged his country's cult of the utilitarian with his assemblages that combine cogwheels, levers and dynamos with rags, animal bones, clothes hangers and rusty steel helmets.

title: BACK HOME IN ALABAMA, PERKINS BEGINS A NEW ERA
description: ON occasion, a football player would have an opportunity to visit him in his office, to sink into the comfortable gray sofa that made it feel as if he were looking up at ''Coach,'' as Paul (Bear) Bryant was called. And the player would listen attentively to the old stories and homespun Fordyce philosophy that maybe his older brother or daddy had first heard back when the Bear was more of a grizzly than a grandfather type. Everyone remembered the visits to the office, and the sofa, and the man looking down from behind the desk.

title: INDIANS AND ORIOLES SPLIT TWO
description: Julio Franco, a replacement for the injured Toby Harrah, hit a three-run double in the fourth inning and the Cleveland Indians went on to defeat the Baltimore Orioles, 7-4, and divide a doubleheader today.

title: GARVEY SETS A LEAGUE RECORD
description: Steve Garvey set a National League record tonight when he played in his 1,118th consecutive game. Garvey, a first baseman, played 12 full seasons here before signing as a free agent with the Padres last winter after a somewhat bitter contract dispute with the Dodgers. Tonight he singled and doubled as the Padres lost, 8-5, to the Dodgers.

title: Kathleen Flynn Is Engaged
description: Mrs. Gerald F. Flynn of Yonkers, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Kathleen Mary Flynn, to Bruce Vernon Bordelon of New York and Norfolk, Conn., son of Mrs. Al R. Bordelon of Baton Rouge, La., and the late Mr. Bordelon.

title:
GARDENING;
THE WHAT AND WHEN OF SPRING PLANTING
description: AN old rule of thumb among gardeners says that certain things can be planted as soon as the soil can be worked in the spring. Included are hardy perennials, such as shasta daisies and columbines; biennials, such as pansies, sweet williams and digitalis, and perennial vegetables, such as rhubarb and asparagus.

title: Iraq Invites Khomeini To Conference on War
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq today invited Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader, to an Islamic conference here on the Iran-Iraq war.

title: KEEPING THE LEAD WHEN PLAYING A MATCH
description: One strategy of how to play a match with a fixed number of games is to seize the lead and head cautiously for draws the rest of the way. This view is popular with those who have never been in a match.

title: Robertson Angered
description: Shana Robertson has lost her basketball scholarship at the University of Arizona, and her father is upset at the school. Her father is Oscar Robertson, the former National Basketball Association star, and he says that he plans to ''dig and dig and dig'' until he has found ''what they're trying to cover up.''

title: Remains of 100 People Found in Colombia Cave
description: The skeletal remains of 100 people believed killed by smugglers during illicit marijuana operations have been found in a remote cave in northern Colombia, the authorities said today.

title: SHOREHAM GETTING CONGRESSIONAL SCRUTINY
description: THE Long Island Lighting Company's Shoreham nuclear power plant, often the subject of rancorous discussions at the state and local levels of government, is coming under Congressional scrutiny.

title: THE GRASS-ROOTS VOTE IS FOR RAIL TRANSIT
description: To the Editor:

title: Tibet
description: To the Editor:

title: WITH POLITICIANS PRODDING, BOTH SIDES IN STRIKE SOFTENED STANDS
description: Under intense and mounting pressures, each side did something it had been reluctant to do to settle the six-week-old strike against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, according to participants in the dispute and the actions to resolve it.

title: Insulation Ban Is Upheld
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court has upheld the State Health Department's decision to ban the use of ureaformaldehyde insulation. The court on Tuesday overturned a lower court's decision that the Commissioner of Public Health acted illegally in November 1979 by ordering the ban on the sale, distribution and use of the blown-in insulation, which had been used in 1,260 homes in the state.

title: Bomb Explodes in Texas In Extortion Attempt
description: A small bomb exploded Friday at an Exxon gas station as a police officer waited in a nearby phone booth for instructions from an extortionist.

title: HIGH STYLE IN LIMITED SPACE
description: One time-honored theory of decorating holds that small spaces should be furnished simply, a theory that was ignored by the designer of this one-bedroom apartment in a former brownstone. Instead of being pared down, in fact, it is furnished in a manner usually associated with vast apartments or sprawling houses. Most of the walls are glazed, and there is a profusion of bibelots, paintings, prints, stacks of books, flowers and plants. The upholstered furniture has plump down cushions and pillows, and every chair has a table nearby. The whole has an artless quality, but a great deal of thought has gone into this apartment to make it work.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: HOW TO BOOK PASSAGE ON A FREIGHTER
description: With the advent of containerization, those ''slow boats to China,'' as the world's freighters were once romantically known, are carrying fewer passengers and more cargo these days, but it is still possible to hop aboard one - if you have enough time and patience and know where to start.

title: 'STORY' STOCKS COME BACK INTO VOGUE
description: LAST September, when Shearson/American Express recommended Monolithic Memories, a maker of programmable s ilicon chips, the shares were trading at 14. They have since soared t o 32. Now Shearson is thumping the drum for Data I/O, which makes p rogramming equipment for those chips. ''If investors liked M onolithic Memories, they'll love Data I/O,'' predicts John Connolly,S hearson's research director.

title: A NEW MEANING FOR LUXURY
description: That they are smaller would seem the most obvious observation that could be made about the way places to live are made today. Yet it seems worth saying anyway, for there is a tendency to forget just how far down on the list of priorities space has fallen. We have given up, almost entirely, on the building of large houses and apartments -they are created occasionally under very special circumstances, but they are almost never made as part of routine residential construction.

title: EUROPE'S JOBLESSNESS BEGETS GENERATION OF DESPAIR
description: As the rain-soaked day slips into dusk, young women gather behind the wet plate-glass windows of a Government-sponsored youth center in downtown Amsterdam.

title: FLOOD AID AVAILABLE
description: AS HUNDREDS of homeowners pumped out flooded basements early in the week and cleaned up damage caused by last weekend's rainfall, hardware store operators, plumbers and insurance agents faced stormrelated questions.

title: Mary Joyce Scully Wed to Lawrence Fuller Bissell
description: Mary Joyce Scully, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Joyce Scully of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Lawrence Fuller Bissell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sumner Fuller Bissell of West Suffield, Conn. The Rev. Francis V. Boyle performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE WALT WHITMAN OF EATS
description: THIRD HELPINGS, By Calvin Trillin. 184 pp. New Haven and New York: Ticknor & Fields. $12.95.

title: Ways to Keep Theater Alive
description: I have been following the events regarding the financial problems of the American Shakespeare Theater with great sadness. As a teenager growing up in Fairfield, I found fulfillment of many theatrical dreams at this landmark in Stratford.

title: Greece to Try Hijacker Over Turkey's Protest
description: A leftist Turkish hijacker arrested early this morning will be tried in Greece and not extradited to Turkey, as demanded by the Ankara Government, the Greek Government spokesman said today.

title: Court Asked to Overturn Verdict on Marx Estate
description: Erin Fleming's attorney has asked the judge who presided at the Groucho Marx estate trial to throw out a jury's verdict against Miss Fleming, the comedian's longtime companion, in part because, he said, the jury failed to understand the meaning of love.

title: ISLANDERS DOMINATING SERIES
description: The Ranger-Islander playoff series has been a replay of the Rangers' opening series against the Philadelphia Flyers in reverse. Everything that the Rangers did in the three-game sweep of the Flyers the Islanders are doing to the Rangers. They have swept the first two games, the third is at Madison Square Garden tonight and the fourth, if necessary, is at the Garden tomorrow night.

title: Fighting Food With Food
description: Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina may be a Republican conservative, but his commitment to free-market principles doesn't extend to the farm. He and his Senate Agriculture Committee have produced a flag-waving bill that would at once create three ugly effects:

title: Truck Explosion Kills Man
description: A truck carrying military rockets and fuel exploded on a desert stretch of Interstate 10 on Friday, killing one man and injuring another, the State Department of Public Safety reported. Both men were in the truck.

title: NINE WAYS TO EXPAND SPACE
description: Sally Clark and Lois Perschetz are co-authors of ''Making Space: How to Get the Space You Need Out of the Space You Have,'' to be published in November by Clarkson N. Potter.

title: GOODMAN VARIETY
description: Benny Goodman, classical and swing musician, will give a concert in both modes at 8 P.M. Friday in Woolsey Hall on the Yale campus to benefit the Yale School of Music Scholarship Fund. The 74-year-old clarinetist received an honorary degree from the university last year.

title: Slight Progress Is Seen In Pittsburgh Jail Siege
description: Negotiations to free two hostages held at the maximum-security Western Penitentiary by two inmates progressed today with the exchange of some sandwiches for a four-page handwritten list of demands.

title: THE CHICAGO MACHINE IS A JUNK HEAP
description: The Mayor of Chicago is a black man. The City Council, forever and a day a pool of trained seals, is now an assemblage of independents, black and white, along with the seals, who are at the moment in a catatonic state.

title: ECHOES OF A ROYAL HUNT
description: Twenty-eight miles north of Paris lies the small cathedral town of Senlis, nestled, like the tantalizing center of a Faberge Easter egg, at the juncture of three lofty beech forests -Halatte, Chantilly and Ermenonville.

title: League of Angels
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Home Truths
description: Sushi, Disney

title: August Wedding Planned for Laura Merrill Garber
description: The engagement of Laura Merrill Garber to Steven Mandell has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Victor Garber of Watchung, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Burton Mandell of Cranford, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: MAKING SPORTS WORK FOR THE YOUNG ATHLETE
description: ALONG with the first robin, the yellow forsythias and other early heralds of spring comes one of the most familiar calls of the season - the cry of ''Play Ball.'' For many hundreds of youngsters, even more significant than the return of the Yankees and Mets, that call means Little League season, and in parks and playgrounds throughout the area, eager young ballplayers are preparing to try out for teams in their local leagues.

title: Lea of Expos Stops Astros on a 1-Hitter
description: Charlie Lea allowed only one hit, a pinch-hit single by Terry Puhl with two out in the eighth inning, as the Montreal Expos defeated the Houston Astros today, 2-0. Andre Dawson hit a towering home run.

title: Unbeaten Syracuse at Peak
description: ''Before this year we were Davids,'' said Roy Simmons Jr., the coach of the undefeated Syracuse lacrosse team. ''We were on the back burner, sneaking up on people. But this year we're Goliaths.''

title: Information On Rail Service
description: PHONE NUMBERS: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad advised people to call one of three telephone numbers for information on train schedules.

title: MISS BASSETT, 15, GAINS FINAL
description: Carling Bassett, the 15-yearold rookie pro from Canada, gained the final with Chris Evert Lloyd today in the $250,000 Lipton Women's Tennis Association championships.

title: A Suggestion For Steinbrenner
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 26 INMATES TEST 'HONOR DORM' AT BEDFORD HILLS
description: IT is about 8 P.M. on a midweek evening here. Beverly is in her room, which she has decorated in warm shades of red and rose, chatting with her friend, Grace Morris. Down the hall, Glenda Cooper sits cross-legged on her flowered bedspread, crocheting a child's toy animal.

title: PROBATION HAD BEEN SOUGHT IN HOUSE-LINKED DRUG CASE
description: Attorneys for the House Ethics Committee have recommended that a former Congressional employee be placed on probation, rather than be sentenced to prison, because his continued cooperation was ''important to the committee's ongoing investigation'' into drug use on Capitol Hill.

title: CONSUMER RATES
EUROPE GEARS UP FOR WORLD CLASS TECHNOLOGY
description: When President Francois Mitterrand kicked 47 Soviet diplomats, journalists and others out of France on espionage charges this month, his Interior Ministry cited ''a systematic search on French territory for technological and scientific information, particularly in the military area.'' With Western Europe acting lately as if it had forgotten how to make the wheel, some governments might find this affair an encouraging sign that France, at least, has technology worth stealing.

title: Rideau Waterway
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THE MUSICAL FRONT IN HOUSTON
description: Houston's musical life is very much in the news this week. Saturday night, as part of the ''Carnegie Hall Presents'' series, the Houston Symphony makes its first visit to New York in seven years. The concert is part of a seven-day East Coast tour and comes during a fund drive by the orchestra which hopes to bring in $13 million.

title: CONCERT: STYLES SAMPLER BY NEW MUSIC CONSORT
description: The New Music Consort's Thursday night program in Carnegie Recital Hall offered a challenging, if rather limited, survey of some current compositional styles.

title: JUNE Wedding Set By Miss Cameron And M. M. Irving
description: Catherine Hooker Cameron and Juan Mayer Cameron, both of Washington, have announced the engagement of their daugher, Elizabeth Cameron, to Macculloch Miller Irving, son of Flora Miller Biddle of New York and Michael Henry Irving of Rowayton, Conn. A June 4 wedding is planned.

title: CORRIE TEN BOOM
description: Corrie Ten Boom, a Dutch woman whose book on her experience in a Nazi concentration camp was the basis for the film ''The Hiding Place,'' died Friday night at her home in Placentia, Calif., according to her adopted son Do Van Nguyen. She was 91 years old.

title: Miss Haack Wed to R.S. Pierrepont 3d
description: Priscilla Elizabeth Haack, who is with the corporate bond department at Shearson/American Express in New York, was married in Wayne, N.J., yesterday to Rutherford Stuyvesant Pierrepont 3d, a vice president of Triumph Resources, a venture capital exploration company in New York. The Rev. Richard Hess performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. David's Episcopal Church.

title: 7TH RAINY WEEKEND IN CITY SETS RECORDS FOR THE DAY AND MONTH
description: The rains came again yesterday to the metropolitan area, setting a record for the date in New York City and making it the wettest April since the city began keeping statistics.

title: Another Barrier Falls in Virginia
description: Charles S. Robb, the Democratic Governor of Virginia, has rankled many of the Old Dominion's once-dominant conservatives by appointing people who are not white and male to agencies and commissions. Last week, in perhaps his most dramatic break with tradition, Mr. Robb named the first black justice to the Virginia Supreme Court.

title: EXPENSIVE EMPTY SPACE HAUNTS U.S. AGENCY
description: After spending more than $700,000 to renovate part of an office building near the Capitol, the Veterans Administration has left the space vacant for more than a year because agency officials cannot agree on how it should be used.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
DO SAT'S MEASURE THE RIGHT THINGS?
description: TO THE OFFICE OF ADMISSIONS:

title: TWO FUGITIVE SOLIDARITY OFFICIALS SEIZED IN POLAND
description: The Polish authorities reported today the arrest of two fugitive officials of the outlawed Solidarity union, along with more than 20 Solidarity supporters, and the seizure of radio transmitters and printing presses.

title: INSIDE THE DIVIDED MIND
description: Ellen Hale is a medical reporter with the Gannett News Service in Washington.THE searing pain roused Marianna from sleep. She switched on the bedside light and saw dark red streaks of blood covering her sheets. She counted the fine lines of 30 razor cuts on her arms and legs before she carefully climbed out of bed. On her dresser was a note, written in childish scrawl: WARNING TO MARIANNA The lies must stop. Put a stop to the child or I'll kill. -THE RIPPER It was a death threat. But it was also a suicide attempt -for Marianna, the Child and the Ripper all inhabit the same body. The Ripper, a violent male personality given to fits of rage, felt angry and threatened because the Child, a youngster of 4, had told their therapist the deeply hidden secrets the Ripper had guarded for so many years. His vicious attack was intended to make sure the Child stopped tattling. Never mind that he, the Child and Marianna all share the same body; they do not share the same pain. To the Ripper, they are different people, and he does not realize that death to the Child means death to him, too. Marianna (the names of all patients in this article have been changed to protect their privacy) described this incident to a psychiatrist to whom she also showed the note from the Ripper. She suffers from a syndrome called ''multiple-personality disorder,'' which, until recently, has received little attention from psychiatric researchers.

title: Judiah Higgins Weds Miss Morse, Attorney
description: Barbara Ann Morse, daughter of Rita Morse of Dallas and the late Harold J. Morse, was married yesterday in New York to Judiah Higgins, son of Alice Smith Higgins of Miami and the late Jonathan Higgins. The ceremony was performed at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Bea Blair and the Rev. John Fisher of Harrington Park, N.J.

title: Diana Shaw Plans To Marry in May
description: Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Shaw of Pasadena, Calif., and Manomet, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diana Shaw, to Sean MacDonald McLin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Travis McLin of Tacoma, Wash. A May 28 wedding in Manomet is planned.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: BRITTLE POWER: Energy Strategy for National Security. By Amory B. Lovins and L. Hunter Lovins. (Brick House, $8.95.) Based on a study the authors did for the civil-defense arm of the Pentagon, ''Brittle Power'' characterizes America's energy system as extremely vulnerable to accident or sabotage, and offers a plan for replacing it with a cheaper one that will be resistant to major failures. Amory B. Lovins, a physicist, and his wife, L. Hunter Lovins, a lawyer and political scientist, were also the authors of ''Soft Energy Paths: Toward a Durable Peace.''

title: Gordon and Bruce Wasley, Sisters, Plan Marriages for June and August
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S.W. Wasley of New York and Old Black Point, Niantic, Conn., have announced the engagements of their daughter, Gordon Hall Wasley, to Francis Reed Austin Jr. and of her sister, Ellen Bruce Wasley, to Robert Gray Atkins.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
LIBRARY WEEK
description: When it's National Library Week - and it is this week - the local repositories of suburban culture do more than just ask, "Have you read a good book lately?" They go all out to show taxpayers just where their money is going. This week there will be a veritable outpouring of special events, and with few exceptions they are free.

title: WORKING THE WATER
description: DISTANT WATER, The Fate of the North Atlantic Fisherman.By William W. Warner. Illustrated. 338 pp. Boston: Atlantic/Little, Brown. $17.95.

title: CONCERT: NEW SOUNDS
description: The unusually appealing - if sadly underattended - new-music concert Monday night in Cooper Union with the group Musical Elements had an outer frame of Stravinsky's ''Ragtime'' of 1918, which both began and ended the evening. Within that first frame was another, in the form of two scores by Oriental composers who work with Western forces - Toru Takemitsu and Isang Yun. And within that frame came three varied contemporary works by American-based composers, Bernard Rands, John Thow and Gian Carlo Menotti.

title: Hunt for Parents
description: A newspaper said Mary Ann Walker was ''one of the luckiest babies in the world'' when she was adopted in March 1936 by James J. Walker, New York's dapper former Mayor, and his wife, the actress Betty Compton. Last year, nearly a half century later, Miss Walker, did not feel so fortunate.

title: WILL TEAM AMERICA ADD NEW INTEREST IN PRO SOCCER?
description: INTEREST in the North American Soccer League has waned considerably during the last two seasons, but the creation of Team America and the return of Franz Beckenbauer to the Cosmos may slow the downtrend in this 17th season, which begins Friday.

title: WILLIAMS, STILL FIGHTING, STUDIES REBUFF
description: FORMER Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. is continuing his efforts to reverse his Abscam conviction after having lost a major appeal. Unless he wins a reversal, the 63-year-old Bedminister Democrat faces a three-year prison sentence for his Federal conviction on bribery charges based on the extraordinary Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: Miss Porter Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lindsay Porter of New York and Old Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lindsay Anne Porter, to Stephen Kemper Diehl, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kemper Diehl of San Antonio. The wedding is to be June 4.

title: Miss Ball Is Married
description: Margaret Ralston Ball, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Burnham Ball Jr. of Perrysburg, Ohio, and Robbinston, Me., was married yesterday to John Budlong Ottman Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ottman of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. C. Eugene Pearson performed the ceremony at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church in Perrysburg.

title: It's The One Seeking $1 Million in Earnings
description: It's The One attempts to become the 36th horse in thoroughbred history to pass the $1 million mark in earnings when he takes on six rivals in Sunday's $108,500 San Bernardino Handicap at Santa Anita.

title: Copy Now, Pay Later
description: Academia paid for an extracurricular lesson last week. New York University and eight of its professors settled out of court with nine major book publishers who had accused them of breaking copyright laws by photocopying books and other materials for classroom use.

title: REVIVAL PLANNED FOR RAIL LINE
description: HE HAS, he says, ''never been much for mowing lawns.'' So G. Roger Clements sought to do something a bit more creative in his Fairfield backyard. He purchased, for restoration, a vintage railroad car, with parlor and dining sections, brass sinks and bronze faucets, and named it the ''Sasqua,'' after an Indian tribe that once inhabited the area.

title: P.T. Glynn Jr. Is Wed To Mary Alison Kelly
description: At the Greenbush Presbyterian Church in Blauvelt, N.Y., yesterday Mary Alison Kelly was married to Philip Thomas Glynn Jr. by the Rev. Robert Garner.

title: TROOPERS GETTING NEW GUNS
description: CONNECTICUT has long enjoyed an international reputation as home to some of the world's biggest arms manufacturers, such as Colt in Hartford and Winchester in New Haven. But when the Connecticut State Police decided to strap on some new weapons last week, they settled on a handgun made by an Italian company.

title: A SLIVER FIGHTS FOR LIFE
description: In what may be the first request for a variance of the so-called sliver law, passed recently by the city to curb the growth of tall, narrow buildings that tower over their neighbors, a Manhattan developer is seeking permission to put up an 11-story nonconforming mixed-use penthouse building on a 25- by 75-foot piece of property at the corner of First Avenue and East 68th Street.

title:
STAMPS;
THE U.N. HERALDS ITS WORLD FOOD PROGRAM
description: The United Nations is issuing four engraved stamps with one common design this Friday to commemorate its World Food Program. The program has finally become operational this year after a long period of gestation.

title: KODALY'S CENTENARY PUTS HIS MUSIC IN PERSPECTIVE
description: This past December, the centenary of Zoltan Kodaly's birth passed with a few performances and one or two critical nods, but with none of the fanfare and sustained musical exploration that marked the 1981 centenary of his friend and compatriot, Bela Bartok. The reason, it seems, is that Kodaly is perceived as the lesser of two inextricably linked composers who, together, represent the Hungarian national style of the early 20th century. In this country, in fact, Kodaly's name is more strongly associated with the unique approach to music education he pioneered, and with his ethnomusicological studies of Hungarian folksong, than with the sizable body of music he composed.

title: Gas Regulation
description: To the Business Editor:

title: STAGE: 'PASSING FANCIES'
description: ''PASSING FANCIES,'' the new play currently being presented by Theater Three in Port Jefferson, is a wonderful idea that is so impressed with itself it forgets to become a play. This comic drama by Winston Clark and Bill Van Horn purports to show us the thoughts and memories that swirl around the characters. While the characters speak to one another, they vocalize, to the audience, what they are really feeling.

title: Heavy Shelling Marks Debate on Central America
description: On one of Central America's hottest political battlefields, the United States Congress, Administration forces found themselves again on the defensive last week. A serious casualty was a supplemental request for $50 million in military aid to El Salvador, voted down by a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee which also reduced the ordinary military aid package for fiscal year 1984 from $86.3 million to $50 million. Another major blow was the adoption by the same subcommittee of a proposal to prohibit American aid to Nicaraguan rebels unless specifically requested of and approved by Congress in a joint resolution.

title: WHY IT SELDOM PAYS TO RUN FOR THE BORDER
description: Extradition law being what it is, it seems that a person sought for a crime in one state has little chance of gaining sanctuary in another unless he can find a sympathetic governor or Indian tribe.

title: Advice for Coaches
description: Basketball coaching does not foster security, ''so a young coach should do whatever he has to do to keep his job.''

title: A AMERICAN SAMPLER
description: A large number of essays have been written in recent months about the so-called renaissance in American cooking. We tend to dismiss most of them as illogical. As we have said before, the United States is still a nation of strangers where regional cooking is concerned. Most Northerners have never developed a passionate hunger for crawfish bisque and crawfish etoffee, any more than Southerners have for pastrami on rye or lox and bagels. Northerners can no more understand the Southern craving for biscuits and country ham with red-eye gravy than a Southerner like myself can comprehend the New Englander's enthusiasm for red-flannel hash.

title: Frank Wheaton Sr., 102, Dies; Major Manufacturer of Glass
description: Frank Hayes Wheaton Sr., chairman of the board of Wheaton Industries, the largest family-owned glass manufacturer in the United States, died Friday at his home in Millville, N.J. He was 102 years old.

title: THE RENAISSANCE OF ALFRED DOBLIN
description: A PEOPLE BETRAYED November 1918: A German Revolution. By Alfred Doblin. Translated by John E. Woods. 642 pp. New York: Fromm International Publishing. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: PREMIERE FOR 1841 DONIZETTI OPERA
description: ALTHOUGH they had been working on their roles individually for weeks, this was the first meeting of the cast of ''Maria Padilla,'' the 142-year-old Donizetti opera that will have its East Coast American premiere on Saturday at the State University at Stony Brook. Excitement - and apprehension - ran high in the Manhattan studio of the production's vocal coach.

title: The Shoreham Debate: Another Opinion
description: Herbert Jaffe's opinion on the Shoreham debate (''Tactics in the Debate on Shoreham,'' Opinion Page, April 3) is a natural one for a director of the Association of Investors in New York Utilities. He represents people who have invested in a poorly run company that has run into very bad luck and that is trying to sell a product very few Long Islanders believe in -''safe'' nuclear power.

title: DEVELOPERS UPSET WITH FLORIDA LAW ON COASTLINE CONSTRUCTION
description: When Jacques Lallouz began building two luxury oceanfront homes last year in nearby Golden Beach, he did not expect to draw the attention of the Cabinet, the state's executive governing body.

title: THE G.E. - UTAH LESSON
description: AFTER nine years and more than $200 billion in acquisitions, America's latest merger wave is finally faltering, yet not without i ts great ironies. At the January 1983 shareholders' meeting of the Allied C orporation, the chairman, Edward L. Hennessy Jr., assailed the B endix-Martin Marietta debacle of last summer. ''The whole thing was a pretty sorry spectacle for American business,'' he lamented. W hatever his intellectual or moral concerns, however, Mr. Hennessy h ad exploited the situation by outmaneuvering Harry Gray, his old b oss at United Technologies to acquire Bendix. And what was Mr. H ennessy's rationale? By acquiring Bendix ''Allied could bring about a merger that would help us accomplish several of our most important s trategic goals,'' he said.

title: ART SHOULD MEAN AS WELL AS BE
description: OVERLAY Contemporary Art and the Art of Prehistory. By Lucy R. Lippard. Illustrated. 266 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. Cloth, $30. Paper, $16.95.

title: CARVING A WORK CORNER
description: Until recently, the business of living and the business of earning were as segregated as possible in the lives of most people. Living over the store was generally considered a regrettable condition and, if homework was part of an adult's routine, his home ''study'' tried to disguise that fact.

title: WHAT IS THE SOUND OF BROADWAY? HANS SPIALEK KNOWS
description: Anyone who looks into the orchestra pit at the Virginia between acts of ''On Your Toes'' is in for a surprise. They have just heard what sounds like a full-tilt Rimsky-Korsakov Russian ballet, complete with swirling string crescendos, on the heels of what sounds like a big band in ''It's Got to Be Love.''

title: JAZZ PIANIST IN LINCROFT
description: Marian McPartland, the jazz pianist, is a rarity in that she has earned a lofty place in a field dominated by men - and American men at that. Miss McPartland, who was born in Slough, England, got her start in jazz during World War II, performing with the U.S.O. in Europe after first entertaining troops while working for the organization's British equivalent.

title: Margiotta Dispute Far From Settled
description: Nassau Republican boss Joseph M. Margiotta's debt to society, county leaders decided last week, shouldn't include the $700,000 in kickbacks he was convicted of collecting and distributing to the party faithful. The G.O.P.-led Board of Supervisors and County Executive Francis T. Purcell, a Margiotta supporter, reached that conclusion after legal advisers said litigation to recover the money would be both costly and chancy.

title: Charlotte A.Corcoran Marries Peter C. Maier
description: Charlotte Ann Corcoran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Corcoran of Wilton, Conn., was married yesterday to Peter Cheney Maier, son of Mr. and Mrs. J. David Maier of Milford, Conn.

title: DOES THE HOLOCAUST LIE BEYOND THE REACH OF ART?
description: Ihave recently seen yet another film about what we so improperly call the Holocaust. I wonder what the viewer will retain from it. The impossibility for certain men and women to free themselves of their nightmares? The need and uselessness of running away from one's self? The urge to make contact with someone else, a stranger, and share with him one's ghosts before vanishing forever in the mist and the abyss?

title: LUXURY IN LIMITED SPACES
description: Where does luxury come in the small scheme of things? One answer comes from Billy Baldwin, considered by many to be the dean of American decorating. ''The trouble with a lot of people is that they tend to misinterpret the true meaning of luxury and confuse it with grandeur,'' he said. ''Lately, I have been thinking how comfort is perhaps the ultimate luxury. Luxurious things don't have to be costly, but they should have the quality to please and delight you.''

title: LEGAL AID SOCIETY TO HONOR LAWYER
description: Helen Lehman Buttenwieser, a lawyer with a long career of public service, will be honored Tuesday by the Legal Aid Society with the presentation of its sixth annual Servant of Justice Award.

title: HOW TO WIN AN AUDIENCE
description: The second thing to be said about Ellis Rabb's new revival of the Kaufman-Hart ''You Can't Take It With You'' is that, come the time for curtain calls, the audience has been honestly seduced into singing ''Goodnight, Sweetheart'' along with the actors, who are holding hands and swaying in grinning rhythm. The play and the people in it are just so downright likable, that's all. And the first thing to be said about the current production is that it isn't a patch on the earlier revival staged by the same Mr. Rabb for the A.P.A. in 1965.

title: CONCERT: PROTEST SONGS
description: The sellout audience that filled Avery Fisher Hall Wednesday evening to hear Ronnie Gilbert and Holly Near was, to a great extent, a reunion of followers of and participants in the protest-song movement of the 1950's and 60's. The hall echoed with exclamatory greetings before the concert and at the intermission, and the audience had an irresistible urge to join in many of the songs as soon as the opening notes were struck.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: JFK, The Presidency of John F. Kennedy. By Herbert S. Parmet. 407 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $19.95.

title: Trask Wins in Bowling
description: Art Trask tossed nine consecutive strikes and defeated Earl Anthony, 275-202, today to capture the $120,000 PBA Fair Lanes Open. The 34-year-old Trask, a 10-year veteran of the pro bowling circuit, won his fourth career event and earned $18,000.

title: BANK MONEY FUNDS---STILL A GOOD IDEA?
description: NOW that the initial hoopla over bank money market accounts has s ubsided, are the accounts still a good deal? The answer is a q ualified yes, especially for those who like the safety of the new f ederally insured accounts and do not plan to write many checks a gainst their funds. But it is vitally important to read the fine p rint before you plunk down money because people with active a ccounts have been chagrined to discover they sometimes receive less i nterest than advertised because they ran afoul of little-publicized b ank rules. Service fees for low-balance accounts, charges for extra c hecks and higher-than-normal fees for overdraft privileges can also s lash the return far below advertised levels.

title: SANDINISTS ON THE BORDER TELL OF AN EBB IN CLASHES
description: From this fortified village in northern Nicaragua and from more than a dozen others like it, Sandinist soldiers regularly set out on foot patrols, some of them lasting for weeks, in search of insurgent bands.

title: BEIRUT: STILL UNANSWERED: WHO SPEAKS FOR THE P.L.O.?
description: IN the wake of the failed negotiations between Jordan's King Hussein and Palestine Liberation Organization chairman Yasir Arafat, the diplomatic situation in the Middle East appears to have entered a new period of stagnation.

title: WHO GAINS WHEN HOUSING PROSPERS
description: A cool day, with nagging winds and clouds scudding across the sky - a truck from an engineering firm called Russell & Lockett drove up to a parcel of land at 29 Cannonball Drive in the Glen Arden subdivision in this central Jersey community (population: 25,500). Engineers lugged out some wooden stakes and sledge hammers and got busy staking out the precise spot where a house would rise.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Aberdeen $89,000 *2*42 Andover Lane, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*19-year-old ranch; central air-conditioning, *2*wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $2,398. Dover $83,000 *2*50 Reservoir Drive, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*40-year-old colonial; patio, large yeard, *2*two-car garage; taxes $1,888. Hillsdale $64,000 *2*255 St. Nicholas Avenue, 2-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*85-year-old bungalow; new gas furnace, *2*heated porch; taxes $1,278. Parsippany $206,000 *2*44 High Ridge Road, 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*8-year-old colonial; sun room, *2*40-foot deck; taxes $3,426. Short HIlls $250,000 *2*74 Kean Road, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old *2*ranch; new kitchen, pool; taxes $5,455. Westfield $115,000 *2*711 Coleman Place, 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*56-year-old colonial; new kitchen, beamed *2*ceiling in living room; taxes $2,626. OTHER AREAS Woodbury, L.I. $215,000 *2*1 Maple Way, 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 18-year-old *2*ranch; finished basement, central air-conditioning, *2*pool; taxes $5,385. South Salem, N.Y. $96,000 *2*Bountonville Road, 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 6-year-old *2*stucco ranch, screened porch, wraparound deck; *2*taxes $2,750. Fairfield, Conn. $120,000 *2*55 Orchard Hill Drive, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*34-year-old colonial; excellent condition, *2*screened porch; taxes $1,593.

title: WINNING PRIZES IN TAIWAN, AND NOW L.I.
description: AT the age of 7, a scant 11 years ago, Alvina Chiu entered her first piano competition in her native Taiwan. She wanted to be declared the best elementary school pianist in the nation. She didn't win that year, or the next, or the next. But finally, at 10, already a seasoned performer, she walked off with the title.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Los Angeles Lakers signed Steve Mix, the veteran forward who was released last week by the Milwaukee Bucks, and reactivated Bob McAdoo, who has not played since injuring a toe Feb. 16. To make room, the Lakers released Billy Ray Bates and placed another guard, Eddie Jordan, on the injured list. . . . Thomas (Satch) Sanders, the former Celtic, asked a Boston court to let him continue operation of his restaurant and lounge as he arranged for financial reorganization. . . . Among those on hand for a benefit concert that raised $200,000 for Tony Conigliaro Friday night at Symphony Hall in Boston were Ted Williams, Willie Mays and Joe DiMaggio.

title: WASHINGTON: AGAINST THE ODDS, THE PRESIDENT REMAINS HOPEFUL
description: THE Reagan Administration was doing its best last week to mask its disappointment over the seeming collapse of its Middle East initiative. ''The plan I outlined on September 1 last year is still on the table,'' President Reagan said. ''While there may be bumps along the way, we will not be deterred from our long-term objective, which is a broad-based settlement.''

title: TURKS ASK FOR HELP IN FIGHTING ARMENIAN ATTACKS
