description: Turkey has called on Western governments for help in preventing attacks on Turkish diplomats by radical Armenian groups.

title: A Most Special Cardinal
description: As a Ph.D. candidate at Princeton University, working on a dissertation on the history of the Roman Catholic Church in the latter half of the 17th century, I found John Vinocur's article on Jean-Marie Cardinal Lustiger eloquent and deeply moving (''A Most Special Cardinal,'' March 20). I, too, belong to an ethnic minority within the Roman Church.

title: Steelers Sign Gary
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers signed to a multiyear contract Keith Gary, the defensive end from Oklahoma who was the Steelers' first-round draft choice in 1981 before he signed with Montreal of the Canadian Football League. . . . David Overstreet, another former Sooner who played the last two seasons in Canada, is negotiating with the Dolphins, who drafted him in the first round two years ago.

title: A CITY ON A MONUMENT BINGE
description: BARCELONA

title: ASSEMBLY PASSES J-51 HOUSING PROGRAM EXTENSION
description: The New York State Assembly this week approved a much-debated bill to allow New York City to continue granting tax incentives to developers who rehabilitate deteriorating multifamily housing. The Assembly bill has the support of Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch.

title: LEARNING TO SAY GOODBYE
description: TONIGHT, 10 years after his death, I buried my father. It was a simple burial a beloved photo shredded and discarded, a tattered teddy bear shoved into a closet. There was no sadness, no tears shed this time - there was enough of that 10 years ago. This time was different. There was rage - a burning, red-hot fury and, at the end, a sense of acceptance and relief.

title: Meadowlands Revenues Dropped Sharply in '82
description: The Meadowlands sports complex suffered a sharp drop in revenue last year, partly because of the strike by National Football League players.

title: LET THE POSTAL SERVICE COMPETE FAIRLY
description: EMPLOYING more people than I.B.M., Exxon and Prudential combined, and with revenues nearly e qual to those of United Airlines, American Express, and J.C. P enney, the United States Postal Service now constitutes the G overnment's largest commercial enterprise. It is one of three G overnment operations - along with the Internal Revenue Service and S ocial Security - that routinely and directly affects the public. Andl ike the other two, the cost of the Postal Service is forever rising.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: NEW YORK IS HOST TO 90 CONSULATES
description: Arriving in New York by plane to assume new duties as Italy's consul general, Giulio C. di Lorenzo for the first time in many years saw the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge arched across the harbor's entrance.

title: HARPER'S CUTS ITS LOSSES AND PLANS NEW DRIVE
description: After a year of austerity, officials at Harper's magazine say they have cut their losses dramatically. A new president of the foundation that is overseeing the 133-year-old monthly took over last week and is talking about initiating a ''literary crusade.''

title: PARENTS ON BRINK OF CHILD ABUSE GET CRISIS AID
description: Her daughter is blind and her son, who is 3 years old and hyperactive, stuffed the cat down the toilet and once set a small fire. The breaking point for Julie Trostel, a young single mother living in Brooklyn, came the day she was notified her electricity would be shut off and her son poured red ink all over the furniture.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHY

title: GERMANS GET EDGY OVER 'LAW AND ORDER'
description: West German Christian Democrats, after a landslide victory in last month's general elections, have met a groundswell of resistance to what is widely perceived as their overzealous defense of law and order.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on page 25 of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies a cast member of the ''Laverne & Shirley'' television series. She is Cindy Williams.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MARKETING PLANS FOR TREASURY'S GOLD 'MEDALLIONS'
description: A new attempt is under way to the United States Treasury's gold ''medallions,'' whose limited success to date has caused them to be regarded in some quarters as the precious metal equivalent of the Susan B. Anthony dollar. J. Aron & Company of New York, one of the largest precious metals dealers in the world, announced plans last week for a multimillion-dollar promotion and advertising campaign aimed at making the Treasury medals competitive with South Africa's Krugerrand.

title: Chicago Opens A New Chapter
description: After a campaign that frequently appealed to the seamy side of democracy, Representative Harold Washington was elected mayor of Chicago last week.

title: Leslie Horn Is to Marry S.R. Finlow
description: Mr. and Mrs. Garfield H. Horn of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Hollingsworth Horn, to Simon Robert Finlow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Finlow of Oswald Kirk, Yorkshire, England.

title: A Bid for Liberty From a Basement
description: Pentecostals are deeply religious people whose highest experience is to speak with the gift of tongues. Last week six Soviet Pentecostals ended almost five years of refuge in the basement of the United States embassy in Moscow in the hope that the authorities had understood their message and would allow them to find freedom abroad.

title: AMONG THE AZALEAS AND THE CROCUSES, THE GARDENERS GLOW
description: THE long, not-so-cold winter is over. You know it is, not by the crocuses blooming, the birds singing or the calendar.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
CHARTING THE EFFECTS OF A REVOLUTION
description: Less than three decades separate the photographs of London taken by Alvin Langdon Coburn in 1909 from those taken by Bill Brandt during the 1930's. But during that short span of time the first great revolution in the history of modern photography occurred. Stylistically it was not as great as the revolution in painting that separates the work of Bouguereau and Gerome from that of Picasso and Matisse. But in other ways it was perhaps even greater, and it certainly shows up in the photographs by Coburn and Brandt on view at the International Center of Photography, Fifth Avenue at 94th Street, through May 8.

title: An Emergency Room Reopens in Mobile
description: The emergency room at the University of South Alabama Medical Center is open this weekend for the first weekend in two months.

title: TIPS ON GUESSING THE QUEEN
description: It is said of Arthur Balfour, a thoughtful man who was Britain's Prime Minister early in this century, that he once arrived at a dinner party and spent twenty minutes in the lobby pondering. It seems he was trying to think of a logical reason for ascending the double staircase by the left route rather than the right or vice versa. Conscious of his conservative heritage as a scion of the Cecil family that had helped lead England since the days of the first Elizabeth, he probably decided to go to the right.

title: 7% CUT SEEN IN SOME GAS PRICES
description: The Consolidated Edison, Brooklyn Union Gas and Long Island Lighting Companies will be able to cut their natural-gas prices to residential customers by as much as 7 percent beginning next October, according to the New York State Public Service Commission.

title: GENERALS GAIN SECOND VICTORY BY 23-22
description: The New Jersey Generals won at Giants Stadium today, 23-22, but the celebration was muted. When the game was over, their coach, Chuck Fairbanks, made a comment about winning: ''You take them any way you can get them.''

title: Advertising; Gold Coin At B.& B.; Block Shifts
description: THERE was a flurry of activity Friday as the agency world came alive briefly before taking the weekend off. Benton & Bowles struck gold. Block Drug played musical chairs. American Health magazine, after a year of handling its own advertising, found its first ad agency. Having realized it wasn't selling many of its gold medallions by distributing them though the Postal Service with no advertising, the Treasury Department has signed a contract with J. Aron & Company, a precious metals subsidiary of Goldman, Sachs & Company, to buy and then market gold struck by the Bureau of the Mint under the American Arts Gold Medallion Act of 1978. Now Benton & Bowles has been named to sell the one-ounce and half-ounce goodies that are in competition with South Africa's Krugerrand and Canada's Maple Leaf, as well as other countries' gold.

title: ALAIN PROST TAKES FRENCH GRAND PRIX
description: Alain Prost of France won the French Grand Prix today, the third event of the Formula One season.

title: SUN-TIMES BID WEIGHED BY CHICAGO RUNNER-UP
description: Bernard E. Epton, who last week narrowly lost the race to become this city's first Republican mayor in half a century, is attempting to form a consortium to buy The Chicago Sun-Times, a public relations spokesman for Field Enterprises said today.

title: Candiss L. Cowan Is Married to David B. Newman
description: Candiss L. Cowan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin S. Cowan of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Metropolis Country Club in White Plains to David B. Newman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Newman of Jamaica, Queens. Rabbi Israel Mowshowitz performed the ceremony.

title: News Analysis
description: The slaying of Kathleen J. Williams at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last Sept. 22 touched off one of New York City's most extensive police investigations.

title: A Polyglot Campaign
description: Catherine Fitzgerald Volpe of Woodside, Queens, is touching many ethnic bases in her bid for election to the District 30 school board in the northwest part of the borough. Community School Board elections will be held May 3.

title: CONCERT: ORCHESTRA FROM TORONTO
description: ANDREW DAVIS conducted some music of his own at the Toronto Symphony's concert in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night. His ''La Serenissima'' offered seven scenes of Venice, each evoked in a collage of Monteverdian melody, church bells and snippets from outdoor cafe orchestras. Mr. Davis creates orchestral sound images that are precise and highly imaginative, and these qualities, plus the composer's clever feel for drama, make ''La Serenissima'' a very effective piece.

title: TV: VEXING NEWS TO POLITICS ADDICTS
description: ON Sunday mornings, network television news does something like a reprise, catching up, annotating, doing the things it presumably wished it had done, but didn't have the time or compulsion to do, during the week. For the most part, the vehicle for this is the interview, with politicians and officials caught live and in the flesh, testing themselves against reporters. For years, Sunday mornings have provided some of the best in network television news.

title: FOR BUSINESSES, RAIL STRIKE WAS MOSTLY A BOTHER
description: Most metropolitan area businessmen affected by the Metro-North strike say it was neither a boom nor a bust for them - just a bother. Some businesses, especially hotels, profited during the strike's early days, but by last week most of them were back to normal. Even some businesses that gained from the strike looked forward to its end.

title: Randi Kanuk Is Married To L. Van V. Dauler Jr.
description: The marriage of Randi Kanuk to L. Van V. Dauler Jr. took place yesterday at the Plaza Hotel. New York County Surrogate Marie M. Lambert performed the ceremony.

title: Students Were Willing, But the Computer Wasn't
description: In the computer lab at La Guardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens, contestants huddled over their programming books yesterday, whispering strategies. Occasionally, the computer terminals emitted beeps, but mostly they said, in computer parlance, that they weren't working.

title: 3 Die as Fishing Boat Sinks
description: A 57-foot fishing boat ran into a rock and sank in the Necker Islands south of Sitka, killing three men and injuring three, the Coast Guard said today. The Sitka-registered ship Aloha sent a distress call Saturday night saying she had struck the rock in rainy and foggy weather.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Exxon Corp. announced that following Allan C. Hamilton's retirement as vice president and treasurer, Edgar A. Robinson would replace him, Ulyesse J. LeGrange would become senior vice president and Archie L. Monroe would become the vice president and controller; Lee R. Raymond also will be the new president and director of Esso Inter-America.

title: WITHOUT THAT BLOC
description: During his recent courtship by President Reagan, King Hussein of Jordan granted more than 20 interviews to Karen Elliot House, correspondent of The Wall Street Journal. Her Pulitzerworthy articles give a running diary of the King's thoughts as he was importuned by the Americans.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: The Midas Touch in the Persian Gulf
description: Residents of Kuwait got a bad fright Tuesday morning. Their newspapers ran pictures of a dark ominous shape approaching the shoreline. The dreaded giant oil slick from the damaged offshore oil well in the Persian Gulf had finally arrived.

title: JOSEPH A. McNICHOLAS
description: Bishop Joseph A. McNicholas, the leader of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Springfield, died of a heart attack today at the age of 60.

title: 24 Reported Dead, 70 Injured In Fire in South Korean Disco
description: Flames swept through a two-story disco club filled with people early today in the southeastern city of Taegu, killing 24 and injuring about 70, the police reported.

title: Evans Tie Barred
description: The Evans Products Company said its lenders had declined to approve the proposed combination of Evans and the Sharon Steel Corporation. The deal was subject to consent by creditors of the two companies.

title: Article 107051 -- No Title
description: Steve Garvey, greeted with thunderous ovations during his first return to Dodger Stadium since leaving the team, set a National League record Saturday night by playing in his 1,118th consecutive game and celebrated it by expressing his appreciation for Dodger fans today in a $15,000 newspaper advertisement.

title: BRITAIN'S GUESSING GAME: DATE OF THE ELECTION
description: Most Britons, exulting in the belated arrival of tulips and daffodils in parks and gardens, spent the last week fighting off spring fever. But in Westminster and on Fleet Street, two small but influential corners of London, the virus of the moment is different: the politicians, civil servants and journalists there have come down with a severe case of election fever.

title: VIDEO IS DRAWING PUBLISHERS
description: That Cosmopolitan Girl has appeared on cable television, discussing affairs of the heart. On the same channel, the Newsweek Woman examines affairs of state. Next month, the Essence Woman makes her debut - exploring black affairs as well as offering health and beauty tips.

title: SOLTI RENEWS HIS INVOLVEMENT WITH 'RHEINGOLD'
description: Nearly a quarter of a century ago, Sir Georg Solti's recording of Wagner's ''Das Rheingold'' served as a prelude not only to the ''Ring'' itself but to the growth of the Hungarian conductor's international career. He went on to conduct Covent Garden for 10 years, and later became musical director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra; he is now one of a few international conducting ''stars.'' That 1959 recording with the Vienna Philharmonic was also a landmark, beginning the first complete commercial recording of ''Der Ring des Nibelungen,'' produced by John Culshaw for Decca Records and its London label.

title: U.S. Trust-Chile Plan
description: The United States Trust Corporation said that it and Banco de Chile had agreed in principle for U.S. Trust to reacquire 449,700 of its shares owned by Chile's central bank for about $35 each, or about $15.7 million. Daniel P. Davison, chairman and chief executive officer of U.S. Trust, said in a statement that the shares represented about 10 percent of his corporation's common, adding that the deal was subject to the approval of U.S. Trust's board as well as various regulatory agencies.

title: ACCORD NEARS ON SPECIAL SALVADOR ENVOY
description: The chairman of a key Congressional committee said today that he was close to an agreement with the State Department on a plan to name a special envoy to El Salvador. The envoy, the legislator said, would press for open elections later this year and independent investigation of the widely criticized system of criminal justice there.

title: Zoeller Wins by 2 In Heritage Classic
description: Fuzzy Zoeller, given breathing room when Jim Nelford made a double-bogey on the 16th hole, scored a two-stroke victory today in the Sea Pines-Heritage Classic.

title: A New Statistic
description: Baseball probably has more statistics junkies than any other American sport. This season a new statistic has made its debut in the daily box score - the game-winning run batted in. The category is not new, but this year is the first time it is included in the daily box score.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: U.S. ALLOWS ISRAEL TO PURCHASE PARTS FOR NEW FIGHTER
description: The Reagan Administration informed Israel today that it could buy American-designed components for a new fighter aircraft to be built in Israel, State Department officials said.

title: EARNINGS A KEY FOR FIELD IN DERBY
description: Running a horse in the Kentucky Derby, like running for public office, used to be something that anyone able to scrape up the filing fees could dream about. But just as an overflowing campaign chest has become a virtual prerequisite for entering politics, a Kentucky Derby starter probably has to have earned a six-figure salary in the last year.

title: The U.N. Today; April 18, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strengthening of the Role of the Or- ganization - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 2 CHICAGO EXCHANGES DISCUSS LINK
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange are close to an agreement to give their members access to each other's markets. The move has important implications for the present structures of both the commodities and securities industries.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS, 7-6
description: The Rangers could not have cut it much closer and still come away with a victory last night. And Mike Bossy couldn't have come much closer to cutting that victory out of their hands and forcing overtime.

title: IMPACT OF TAX INCENTIVES IN OUTER BOROUGHS CITED
description: Standing on the new roof of his six-story apartment building at 832 Ocean Avenue, in a part of Brooklyn in which many buildings are deteriorating, Martin J. Schwartz pointed out where he had spent $350,000 to renovate his building.

title: BAMBERGER WARNS METS AND 3 ARE FINED
description: Some cold blasts and fines struck the Mets today, starting with a freakish snowstorm that postponed the final game of their series against the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Iranians Might Attend War Talks in Baghdad
description: The Iranian Prime Minister, Mir Hussein Moussavi, was quoted as saying today that Iran would be willing to send a delegation to attend an Islamic conference in Baghdad on the Iran-Iraq war if the Iraqis met certain conditions.

title: POLISH POLICE BAR MARCH ON UPRISING
description: Hundreds of Polish policemen, gathering around the spot from which 400,000 Jews were sent to Nazi death camps in World War II, today blocked an unofficial march called to mark the 1943 Warsaw Ghetto uprising.

title: The Eyes of Texas
description: Something special awaits the professional golfers who compete next month in the Byron Nelson Golf Classic, which is moving from Dallas to a new venue, Las Colinas Sports Club at Irving, Tex.

title: STATE MAY OVERHAUL TRADITIONAL METHOD OF TEACHING HISTORY
description: New York State is considering a major revamping of the social studies curriculum for secondary schools to put greater emphasis on sociological, political and economic issues rather than following the traditional chronological approach to history.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: In a National Hockey League game, a player for Team B is penalized for two minutes at 10:45 into a period. At 11:15, a player for Team A is also sent off for two minutes, leaving each team with four skaters. At 12:15, with 30 seconds left for Team B's penalty, Team A scores. What happens to the Team B player in the penalty box?

title: ALBANY LEADERS EXPAND CONTROL OVER CAMPAIGNS
description: New York's legislative leaders have gradually taken control from the state party committees of much of the campaign spending in races for the State Senate and Assembly.

title: Dome Petroleum, Home Oil Project
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. announced that it and Hiram Walker Resources Ltd.'s Home Oil Company unit had reached an agreement with the Canadian Government for a $113 million oil exploration program off the coast of Nova Scotia over the next two and a half years.

title: PRITZKER SAID TO SEEK BRANIFF BACKING ON DEAL
description: Jay A. Pritzker, the chairman of the Hyatt Corporation, will meet with officials of Braniff International today in Dallas to ask them to approve his offer to revive the airline and to get their authority to negotiate directly with secured creditors, a source close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: With General Micawber to Managua
description: President Reagan has finally dropped one shoe by conceding American involvement in a covert war against the leftist rulers of Nicaragua. It is perfectly legal, Mr. Reagan insists, though Congress has yet to endorse that view. And in the opinion of his United Nations Ambassador, Jeane Kirkpatrick, the American cause is eminently moral - an assertion that should not be glibly dismissed.

title: Blacks Call for Banning Rebel Flag at Mississippi
description: The Black Student Union, charging that racism is condoned at the University of Mississippi, has issued a list of demands that include banning the Confederate flag at campus functions.

title: Gretzky: 4 Goals, 3 Assists
description: Wayne Gretzky established a Stanley Cup single-game point record tonight, getting four goals and three assists for 7 points as the Edmonton Oilers routed the Calgary Flames, 10-2, and took a 3-0 lead in their National Hockey League playoff series.

title: QUIRKS IN THE NEW WITHHOLDING LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 SOUTH AFRICANS SPUR 'BLACK CONSCIOUSNESS' GROUP
description: Two former inmates of Robben Island, the Alcatraz-style prison in the middle of Cape Town's Table Bay, are seeking to spur a revival of the ''black consciousness'' movement that was led by Steve Biko before his death in the custody of the security police more than five years ago.

title: REBOUND IN APPLIANCES HELPS FEW EX-WORKERS
description: The Magic Chef Company has opened two new assembly lines at its plant here, a sign, as welcome as the flowering dogwoods, of the long-awaited upturn in the home appliance industry.

title: A SOUTH AFRICAN DEATH
description: If the death of Saul Mkhize, a black South African farmer serves any purpose, it will be to focus the attention of white South Africans on the removal of Africans from their property to distant places. It should compel Americans and concerned white South Africans to question the need for, if not the justness of, such a policy.

title: Transit Police Officer Is Shot By a Suspected Fare Beater
description: A Transit Authority police officer was shot and wounded twice yesterday by one of four men the officer and his partner had stopped on a Brooklyn subway platform for fare beating, the Transit Authority police said.

title: Drs. Alan David Egelman And Carola Friedman Wed
description: Dr. Carola Phoebe Friedman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. A. Frederick Friedman of Norwell, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Alan David Egelman, son of Mrs. Israel H. Egelman of Malverne, L.I., and the late Dr. Egelman. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: TRADITION OF DEUTSCHE BANK
description: When Deutsche Bank's management board gathers weekly to debate the merits of a loan to Hungary or to review steel industry prospects, there is no stenographer. Instead, one of the 13 executives, usually the junior, keeps the minutes of the meeting.

title: Dianne Bean Married To Nathan L. Pritzker
description: Patricia Dianne Bean, daughter of Mrs. John W. Anderson of New York and J. Wayne Bean of Islamorada, Fla., was married yesterday to Nathan Lee Pritzker, son of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Pritzker of East Providence, R.I., and Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi David Eichhorn performed the ceremony at the Whisperwood Clubhouse in Orlando, Fla.

title: STAGE: YOUTHFUL WRITERS
description: THE second annual Young Playwrights Festival is an event that makes one feel hopeful about both the American theater and American young people. Co-produced by the Foundation of the Dramatists Guild and the Circle Repertory Company, the Festival stages the best plays of those submitted by hundreds of applicants, 18 and younger, nationwide. The plays all testify to the persistence of literate theatrical imaginations in a new, video-reared generation. And the productions they've received are not perfunctory, condescending, lipservice exercises: some of the most gifted adults in the New York theater, under the leadership of Gerald Chapman, have banded together to mount these plays at a high level few established writers have known this season.

title: Surrender Discussed In Prison Hostage Case
description: Officials at the Western Penitentiary worked on a surrender agreement today to end a four-day standoff with two armed inmates holding two hostages.

title: West German Group Plans Antinuclear Rallies
description: The antinuclear West German Peace Movement, at a one-day meeting here today, called for hundreds of thousands to demonstrate this fall against NATO rearmament plans.

title: Officer of Grand Met Aided by Irish Liqueur
description: The market for Scotch whisky may be soft in the United States but Anthony J. Tennant says not to worry. His International Distillers and Vintners has been selling another drink that keeps the money rolling back to the parent company, Grand Metropolitan of Britain.

title: UNDER WAGNER'S INFLUENCE
description: Afflicted with crippling self-criticism from early in his career, Nicolai Rimsky-Korsakov (1844-1908) had his life altered when he encountered Wagner's ''Ring of the Nibelung'' performed by a touring German company in St. Petersburg in 1889. From then on, his creative energies were renewed and he concentrated almost exclusively on opera and vocal music.

title: RIDDLERS' PLEASURE INCLUDES A TREASURE
description: ''It's starting out a bit confused but I guess that's normal for New York,'' Bruce Nagel said in Central Park yesterday, waiting for his automatic pants-pressing machine.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Winner Over Miss Bassett
description: Chris Evert Lloyd continued her reign on her home court by defeating Carling Bassett in the $250,000 Lipton Women's Tennis Association championship today.

title: STEEL REVIVAL FOR SMALL TOWN
description: Western Pennsylvania is speckled with the yellow of daffodils and forsythia, hopeful signs among hills that are still brown from winter and often covered with coal and steel industry waste.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: * Rate depicted in Long- or Short-Term Rates chart.

title: QUIRKS IN THE NEW WITHHOLDING LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: Illinois Woman Awaiting Autopsy Revives in Time
description: A young woman awaiting autopsy startled a police detective by reviving on a morgue examining table. ''I'm telling you, I've seen dead people a hundred times in my life,'' Detective Gary Wright said.

title: ISRAEL WEEPS FOR WAR DEAD AT GRAVES OLD AND NEW
description: At 11 A.M. today, when sirens began to wail in honor of the Israeli soldiers who have died in all of the country's wars, the busy corner of King George and Hillel Streets in downtown Jerusalem fell silent.

title: Fire at Presbyterian Hospital
description: A two-alarm fire on the third floor of the Presbyterian Hospital Center for Women and Children in upper Manhattan burned out of control for 31 minutes last night but resulted in no injuries, the Fire Department said. Twenty-eight children were removed from the 12th floor as a safety precaution, according to Richard Zucker, director of the hospital's public interest department. The fire, which began at 11:07 P.M. in the X-ray area, caused extensive damage to wiring and equipment, Mr. Zucker said.

title: TV Workshop Adds Magazine
description: The Children's Television Workshop, already the publisher of three successful magazines for youngsters, is now going to join the developing crush in the computer magazine field. Its planned publication, Enter, will be the first it has had that will accept advertising.

title: Habib Meets Lebanese After a Jerusalem Visit
description: Philip C. Habib, the special United States envoy to the Middle East, held talks tonight with Lebanese officials soon after his arrival in Beirut from Jerusalem, the Beirut radio said.

title: A NEW ARREST IS REPORTED IN CRACKDOWN BY MANILA
description: The founder of an opposition political party in the Philippines has been detained by military authorities on suspicion of aiding subversives, it was reported tonight.

title: CONCERT: EMIL GILELS
description: EMIL GILELS was not scheduled to appear in the United States this season, but the Soviet pianist turned up in recital at Carnegie Hall on Saturday afternoon for his first appearance there since 1979. The official explanation from Carnegie was cryptic, alluding to ''the spirit of cooperation that has made possible the return of this great artist to the United States and to Carnegie Hall.'' All very tantalizing. Did the K.G.B. make a secret deal with the C.I.A.?

title: North Stars 5 Black Hawks 1
description: Craig Hartsburg, the Minnesota defenseman and captain, scored a goal and assisted on another in the final period as the North Stars got their first victory in the Norris Division final series.

title: 7 Authors Assail U.S.  Over Nicaragua Policy
description: Seven internationally acclaimed authors, including the American novelist William Styron, today accused President Reagan of waging an ''immoral, dangerous and inhuman'' war against Nicaragua.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day last Tuesday with an article about industrial flight from the North was incorrectly captioned. The data showed the net migration to or from states and regions during 1980-82.

title: JOBLESS VOTED MORE HEAVILY IN '82 THAN IN '78 CONGRESSIONAL RACES
description: A sharply higher proportion of the nation's unemployed, traditionally discounted as nonvoters, went to the polls in 1982, according to a Census Bureau study released today.

title: Market Place; Wall Street's Success Story
description: WHEN the stock market closed Friday, it appeared as if Hollywood had written the script. All the major market indicators finished at record highs, once again defying forecasts that prices were poised for a tumble after climbing so high so fast.

title: Hitachi's Mild, Quiet Penalties
description: Nine months after the United States Justice Department charged that Hitachi Ltd. had stolen computer secrets from the International Business Machines Corporation, the Japanese computer maker appears to have meted out its own punishment to the corporate officials deemed responsible.

title: CHICAGO MAYORAL ELECTION GETS MUCH ATTENTION IN FOREIGN PRESS
description: Harold Washington's election as Chicago's first black mayor drew wide international press coverage and many commentators around the world cited his victory as a sign of racial progress in the United States.

title: HOW DOGWOODS AND LOCATION HELPED PRUDENTIAL BUY A BANK
description: Sandwiched between a Ford assembly plant and the railroad tracks, Hapeville, Ga., (population 7,000) does not appear to be on the beaten path.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''From the mid-1970s and continuing into the present day, viewers have become increasingly evaluative, judgmental and critical of the programming offered to them by the three commercial television networks.'' -John Bowen, communications consultant. (A1:5.)

title: THE FORCES IS DIGNITY
description: The temptation in going to see the film ''Gandhi'' was to look for contrasts with Mao Tse-tung, the impact of the prophet of nonviolence and the revolutionary who preached that ''power comes from the barrel of the gun.''

title: MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1983
description: International

title: IMPULSE: THE URGE TO CLEAN
description: THERE'S a little bit of Felix Unger in all of us. You remember Felix, the neater half of ''The Odd Couple,'' the one who would throw himself under a falling cigarette ash to protect an innocent carpet. The question is: How little? In other words: How much dirt and disorder can you stand, and where will you stand it, before a still, small voice inside you whispers ''Yech!'' and you start cleaning?

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SHOPPER'S GUIDE

title: Sweeping Down the Avenue
description: Nearly 100 copywriters, account executives, creative directors, marketing experts and computer operators swept down Lower Fifth Avenue yesterday and along the side streets. They pushed brooms and filled trash bags, with two shiny new trash carts and a hired truck as tactical support.

title: Letter: On Multifamily Housing Dealing With Those Illegal Three's
description: To the Editor:

title: Knicks Finish Fifth; Face Nets in Playoff
description: The Knicks completed what Coach Hubie Brown termed an ''incredible second-half season'' today with a victory that earned them the fifth spot in the Eastern Conference and an openinground playoff meeting with the New Jersey Nets.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in some copies of Metropolitan Report on Friday about the slaying of a Queens tavern owner incorrectly described the parole status of the murder suspect, Charles Dingle. Mr. Dingle had twice been denied parole but was released from prison last August after serving two-thirds of a five-year sentence for robbery.

title: Arrows to Face Blast in Playoffs
description: The New York Arrows finished the Major Indoor Soccer League's regular season by suffering their first loss ever to the Cleveland Force, 6-2, Saturday night, but have qualified for the playoffs that begin this week.

title: Gus Mauch Is Dead at 81; Trainer for Yanks and Mets
description: Gus Mauch, longtime trainer of the New York Yankees during the Casey Stengel era and later of the New York Mets' 1969 World Series champions, died Saturday night of congestive heart failure.

title: BOTH SIDES RATIFY AGREEMENT ENDING RAILROAD WALKOUT
description: Striking trainmen and the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to accept binding arbitration, ending a 42-day walkout against the Metro-North Commuter Railroad.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'The Senate Piece'

title: F.A.A. TAKES ACTION ON SAFETY DEVICES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration, keeping to a tight schedule, has taken initial steps to procure 18 airborne anticollision devices that will be evaluated in everyday airline operations and on other special flights starting in December 1984.

title: Caterpillar Talks to Resume
description: Negotiators for the Caterpillar Tractor Company and the United Automobile Workers will resume talks here Monday on what the company called its final offer to end a 199-day strike, a union spokesman said today.

title: SALEM 2 DUST CHECKS CLEAR 65
description: About 65 employees at the Salem 2 Nuclear Generating Station were exposed to radioactive dust stirred up during repairs to a reactor coolant pump, officials said today, but they said tests had indicated that the exposure posed no serious health threat.

title: SEMINARS ON 'THE MIDDLE YEARS OF LIFE'
description: ''In the middle of the journey of our life I came to myself within a dark wood where the straight way was lost. Ah, how hard a thing it is to tell of that wood, savage and harsh and dense, the thought of which renews my fear!'' - Dante Alighieri, ''The Inferno.'' By GLENN COLLINS

title: SHAKERS SUING TO BAR STADIUM NEAR GRAVES
description: The last eight Shakers in the United States filed suit in State Supreme Court in Albany today to bar construction of a new baseball stadium here that they said would desecrate the grave of the founder of their religion, Mother Ann Lee.

title: Dr. Melinda Stern and Dr. Lon M. Dubey Married
description: Dr. Melinda Stern, assistant professor of pediatrics at the Albert Einstein School of Medicine, and Dr. Lon M. Dubey, chief resident in pediatrics at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, were married yesterday at the Hampshire House. Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge: Claims Can Be Confusing At Any Level of the Game
description: Claims by declarer and concessions by a defender represent an area of confusion for players at every level. A slightly defective claim caused a dispute in the recent Vanderbilt Knockout Team final in Honolulu, and cost one player's team 12 international match points. In claiming, he had failed to specify that in certain circumstances he would make a ducking play.

title: OPERA: RIMSKY-KORSAKOV'S 'LEGEND,' IN BOSTON
description: Every season, it seems, Sarah Caldwell and her Opera Company of Boston attempt one exotic blockbuster - a work so unusual, and so seemingly beyond their normally circumspect forces, that one has to wonder at their audacity. Sometimes, as with last season's fatally flawed distortion of Bernd Alois Zimmermann's ''Soldaten,'' they fail. At other times, as with yesterday afternoon's new production of Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Legend of the Invisible City of Kitezh and the Maiden Fevronia,'' they succeed.

title: THE BLOCK FARM: A CABINET MEMBER'S ROOTS
description: It's a good bet that not many of America's future farmers dream of growing up to be Secretary of Agriculture, but there are plenty who strive in other ways to be like Secretary John R. Block.

title: KEEPING WATER CLEAN
description: William Ruckelshaus, President Reagan's choice to become the nation's No. 1 pollution fighter, will inherit an Environmental Protection Agency rocked by scandal and mismanagement. Mr. Ruckelshaus must soon confront policies proposed earlier by the Administration that would undermine America's pollution-control programs.

title: SMART LEOTARDS AND TIGHTS FOR EXERCISE IN STUDIOS
description: There's no doubt about it: Americans are physical-fitness happy. Joggers seem to be becoming as numerous as walkers on city streets. Exercise studios, offering techniques that vary from aerobic dancing through yoga, are springing up like weeds. Office workers spend their lunch hours stretching and leaping, or get up at dawn to do 50 laps in swimming pools.

title: Auto Recalls This Year Nearly Match '82 Total
description: Nearly as many recalls of domestic autos have been ordered in the first three months of 1983 as in all of 1982, Federal statistics show.

title: COMPANIES' DIVIDEND TAX PLANS
description: While many banks say that withholding 10 percent from customers' interest payments will cause them a plethora of problems, most companies expect only minimal adjustments in withholding taxes from stockholders' dividends.

title: THE JOYS OF ORIENTEERING
description: COLD rain driven by gusts of wind that sometimes exceeded 20 miles an hour slashed across the hills, meadows, woodlands and swamps of 4,172 acre Ward Pound Ridge Reservation Saturday, but the 400 or so who had gathered there to take part in one of the nation's major orienteering events didn't seem to mind.

title: 'MOMENT OF SILENCE' DEFENDER GOES FULL CIRCLE
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVERTISING
description: The monthly report from the National Advertising division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus for March makes the advertising crowd look pretty good. In 6 of the 10 cases that were closed, the advertisers were able to support their advertising claims.

title: WOUNDS OF WAR IN 1783 RECALLED AT SYMPOSIUM
description: The morning of Nov. 25, 1783, when the last of the British troops in the 13 colonies departed from New York, they did so ''sullenly and reluctantly.''

title: BROWN TELLS WHY HE LEFT JOB
description: One of the most popular stories circulating around New York and New Jersey these days goes something like this: When Larry Brown goes to heaven, his opinion of the place is likely to be similar to his apparent view of life on earth. ''This place is nice,'' he'll say with all sincerity, ''but ...''

title: Playoff Spot To Nuggets
description: The Denver Nuggets gained the final berth in the National Basketball Associaton's Western Conference playoffs tonight with a 125-116 victory over the Kansas City Kings.

title: TAMPAX PREPARING FOR NEW MARKETS
description: After 47 years of specializing in a single product, Tampax Inc., the originator of the tampon, is preparing to move into new markets. Beginning with new products for the $1 billion feminine hygiene market, Tampax intends to become a consumer company through aggressive marketing and acquisition.

title: BUDGET AND SINUS WOES FOR DOMINICI
description: Senator Pete V. Domenici's sinuses are bothering him again and he would like to quit smoking, for good, but this does not look like the week to try. Indeed, this may not even be the year to try.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article April 9 on the role of the Roman Catholic Church in the Chicago mayoral election incorrectly identified The Chicago Catholic. It is a weekly newspaper, with the largest circulation of any diocesan paper in the nation.

title: Information on Rail Service
description: PHONE NUMBERS: The Metro-North Commuter Railroad has three telephone numbers for information on train schedules. The number for Connecticut passengers is (800) 223-6052; for commuters in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties, it is (800) 522-5624.

title: Shareholder Fights Florida Bank Plan
description: It has been a few years since M. Lee Pearce has made house calls. The one-time family physician who came to Miami from Philadelphia in 1955 to set up his medical practice has since made millions and now owns a private hospital management company.

title: Miss Ehrenkranz Marries in Miami
description: Wendy Faith Ehrenkranz, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. N. Joel Ehrenkranz of Coral Gables, Fla., was married in Miami yesterday to Robert Lawrence Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Goodman of Livingston, N.J. Rabbi Herbert Baumgard performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Am.

title: Mr. Koch Regrets . . .
description: Mayor Koch has sent his regrets to the Legislative Correspondents' Association in Albany for its annual dinner and political show on May 21. Members say the show will take its digs at his unsuccessful campaign for Governor, but then so did the Inner Circle's show by reporters from the City Hall pressroom and other political writers.

title: Rangers Triumph In 14th
description: Larry Biittner scored on Glenn Hoffman's wild relay throw to the plate with two out in the top of the 14th inning today, breaking up a pitching duel and lifting the Texas Rangers to a 1-0 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: OSHA TAKING SLOWER ROUTE ON PERILOUS-SUBSTANCE RULES
description: Citing a lack of personnel, time and money, a Federal official responsible for protecting workers from hazardous substances is relying on the regular rule-making process on such matters rather than faster ''emergency'' action.

title: Dr. Jennifer Ianthe Downey Is Married
description: Dr. Jennifer Ianthe Downey, daughter of Mrs. Dorothy Downey of Santa Clara, Calif., and the late Dr. Lyle Downey, was married yesterday to Dr. John Milton Hutson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hutson of Decatur, Ala. The Rev. Randolph L. Jones, director of the department of pastoral care at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, performed the Methodist ceremony in the choir loft of St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: Yesterdays Heroes
description: Ed Kiersh and Harvey Wang grew up on Brooklyn sandlots, avid baseball fans. Recently they went searching for yesterday's baseball heroes.

title: LEBANESE DENY ACCORD ON TROOP PULLOUT IS NEAR
description: A senior Lebanese official has disputed recent Israeli statements suggesting that Lebanon and Israel have nearly completed an agreement on a troop withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: A PUBLIC 'PRIVATE LIVES' FOR TAYLOR-BURTON FANS
description: When Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton last came to Boston almost 20 years ago, they flew into an airport on wings of scandal, newly married after a romance that broke both their previous marriages and captured the attention of the world. Mr. Burton was coming to play Hamlet before taking it to New York, and a cast member recalls the crowd of 3,000 that had found its way to the airport. It broke onto the landing field and chased the Burtons in their private plane into a hangar.

title: John Elway Leaning Toward Football
description: JOHN ELWAY, the quarterback outfielder from Stanford, is pretending to be running an option play with a football in his right hand, a baseball bat in his left hand. But judging by his tendencies toward football, he will be a rookie quarterback in the National Football League, not an outfielder in the Yankees' farm system.

title: 'GOAL THAT WASN'T' EMBITTERS ISLANDERS
description: Mike Bossy, who had put the puck in the net, had his own description. ''It was a goal that wasn't,'' he said, speaking of the play that nearly pulled the Islanders into a 7-7 tie with the Rangers last night with seven seconds to play. ''I put it in; it's obvious the puck wasn't dead, or I wouldn't have been able to put it in the net.''

title: ECONOMIC TALKS HELD WITH ALLIES
description: The United States and its major allies are embarking on unusually intense negotiations in getting ready for their economic summit meeting in late May.

title: Mark R. Kroll Is Wed To Dr. Susan Tierman
description: Dr. Susan Nadine Tierman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Tierman of Fort Lee, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Mark Richard Kroll, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kroll of Baltimore. Rabbi Robert Summers of the Conservative Synagogue of Fifth Avenue performed the ceremony at the Explorers Club.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 18, 1983
description: Metropolitan

title: THOMAS M. GRAHAM
description: Thomas Malcolm Graham, a Manhattan real-estate developer who specialized in properties in Greenwich Village, died Saturday of complications after surgery at the Palm Beach Gardens Hospital in North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Securities Industry Gets New Computer Monthly
description: If you considered the outpouring of publications that followed the success of video a flood, how then do you describe what is happening around computers?

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: CBN Picks Foote, Cone
description: Foote, Cone & Belding/New York on Thursday was named the agency for the CBN Cable network of Virginia Beach, which is a subsidiary of the Christian Broadcasting Network. Previously in-house, the account is now expected to bill around $4 million. CBN Cable has the potential of reaching 20 million cable-subscriber households, putting it among the top three in cable.

title: Deborah Lieberman Weds Neurologist
description: Deborah Lieberman, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. George B. Lieberman of Southampton, L.I., was married there yesterday at the home of her parents to Dr. David Reid Cornblath, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Cornblath of St. Louis and San Diego. The bride's father performed the ceremony.

title: PENTAGON AIDE DEFENDS ACTION AIDING EX-CLIENT
description: Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard N. Perle today defended his intervention in an Army procurement matter last year on behalf of Israeli arms manufacturers who had employed him shortly before he entered the Pentagon.

title: WINFIELD'S HOMER BEATS JAYS, 7-5
description: The Yankees crammed assorted wild happenings into a game yesterday, emerging with a 7-5 victory over Toronto at the Stadium. They delighted a crowd of 50,200 with several breathtaking plays and gave out thousands of free T-shirts.

title: A Problem Solver
description: This tale came in the form of a letter from Elaine Koehl of Ponte Vedra, Fla., home of golf's Tournament Players Championship. Mrs. Koehl writes:

title: Washington Watch; Congress Slow On Rivlin Post
description: THE wheels of Congress roll slowly. It has been seven months since Alice M. Rivlin, the director of the Congressional Budget Office, announced she was leaving this year. But Congress - specifically the House and Senate budget committees - has barely moved to seek, much less choose, a new director.

title: Salvador Prelate Asks Punishment for Killers
description: Archbishop Arturo Rivera Damas demanded today that the murderers of thousands of Salvadorans killed in the nation's civil strife be brought to justice.

title: TAKEOVER REFORM A TENDER TOPIC
description: The subject was reforming corporate takeover rules, and for some of the participants who crowded into a 28th-floor conference room at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company last Friday, it was clearly a tender topic.

title: Man Serves 16 Months Fighting 6-Month Term
description: A man who spent 10 months in jail to appeal a six-month trespassing sentence he had already served says he did not mind ''because I'm innocent and I was fighting for what was right.''

title: MORE CONFIDENCE ON RATE FALL
description: The credit markets grew more confident last week that interest rates were likely to decline this year. After a few days of inactivity, the credit markets closed with a flurry as investors were eager buyers of new corporate issues, while prices rose modestly for Treasury issues.

title: METRO-NORTH'S ESCAPE FROM THE TAYLOR LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTION IN BOSTON: WHAT COURSE FOR MARATHON
description: THE biggest decision for members of the Boston Athletic Association during their annual meetings, so the story goes, was usually whether to order shrimp or roast beef at meal time. That will not be the case later this month when the members meet again to decide the future of the Boston Marathon.

title: Joseph Margiotta's Damages
description: Is there a county government anywhere that would pass up a chance to collect damages from a politician who has been convicted of bilking its treasury? The answer is yes. The county is Nassau, New York, and the felon is Joseph Margiotta, who still reigns on Long Island as chairman of the county's Republican Party.

title: ROCKNE GRANDSONS FEEL HELD BACK BY THEIR NAME
description: FOOTBALL is very important in East Carbon, Utah. So when Gregg Wakefield, the principal of East Carbon High School, picked up his phone two years ago and was asked by the school superintendent how he would like to have Knute Rockne as his football coach, the principal replied flatly, ''Don't kid with me.''

title: AN ASSAULT ON STATE SOVEREIGNTY OVER RETIREMENT AGE
description: To the Editor:

title: Creamer Expansion
description: In 1976, Creamer Inc. got half of the San Giorgio-Skinner account away from the W.B. Doner agency in Baltimore.

title: METRO-NORTH PLANS AUTOMATIC FARE SETUP
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that he hoped a ruling by the arbitration panel in the Metro-North Commuter Railroad dispute would enable the authority to introduce an automatic fare collection system on the railroad.

title: Nets Win by 112-99
description: There had been enough intrigue around the Nets this season to supply a year of scripts for an afternoon drama. There were injured starters and unhappy substitutes in every game. Not to mention the sudden trades and the even more sudden resignation of the coach, Larry Brown.

title: LIST OF TREASURY FINANCINGS IS LIGHT
description: While the schedule of Treasury financings remains light, the volume of new corporate and tax-exempt issues continues to be heavy. In the corporate market, published calendars of new issues are misleading, as demonstrated last week, when only a handful of new issues was scheduled though more than $1 billion of fixed-rate notes and bonds were ultimatly sold by 10 companies.

title: MRS. WAITZ TIES MARATHON MARK
description: Grete Waitz of Norway equaled the women's world's best time in the London Marathon today, dashing past the Parliament tower to cross Westminster Bridge and the finish line in 2 hours 25 minutes 29 seconds.

title: HEAD OF CHARTER PANEL SEES END OF AT-LARGE POSTS LIKELY
description: The head of New York City's Charter Revision Commission indicated yesterday that it was increasingly likely that the panel would decide to abolish the 10 at-large seats on the City Council.

title: STUDY FOR TV INDUSTRY SAYS VIEWERS ARE WATCHING LESS
description: Television viewers are becoming increasingly dissatisfied with the programs they see and are spending less time watching than they once did, according to a new study commissioned by the industry's major trade association.

title: Orioles 6, Indians 1
description: The Orioles took first place from the Indians in the Eastern Division.

title: PEKING SAYS FIGHTING WITH HANOI HAS SPREAD TO SECOND BORDER AREA
description: China said today that it had intensified its shelling of Vietnamese border positions and that the clashes, which began Saturday, had spread to a second border region. The fighting appeared to be the worst military clash between the Communist neighbors in nearly two years.

title: BURTON'S WIDOW AMONG 4 CONSIDERING RACE FOR CONGRESS SEAT
description: Three scarred veterans of the San Francisco political wars are considering campaigns to succeed the late Phillip Burton, who for 18 years held one of the city's two Congressional seats.

title: Books Of The Times
description: AUTHOR FROM A SAVAGE PEOPLE. By Bette Pesetsky. 197 pages. Knopf.

title: Reagan Aides Respond To Rights Commission
description: The Reagan Administration on Friday narrowly avoided two subpoenas from the United States Civil Rights Commission demanding rights enforcement information from the Education and Labor Departments.

title: A Rejection Of 'Rumors'
description: IN the old days, Dave DeBusschere could have worked off his anger with a whack of an elbow or a flick of the hip. Now that he is director of basketball operations of the Knicks, he has to use words instead.

title: OLD BROWN ARMY BOOTS WILL SOON MARCH AGAIN
description: Long wars ago, before the evil empire was proclaimed and the Pentagon's generals were planning for laser guns and particle beams, infantry boots were brown.

title: JUDGE ORDERS CLEANUP TO RESUME AT TOXIC WASTE SITE IN MICHIGAN
description: A judge has ordered cleanup operations at Michigan's worst toxic waste dump to resume, rejecting the state's request for a delay.

title: RYAN NOW 7 SHORT OF STRIKEOUT MARK
description: Nolan Ryan of the Houston Astros could become baseball's career strikeout leader on Friday night when he is scheduled to pitch in the Astrodome against the Philadelphia Phillies. Yesterday, making his first start of the season, he fanned seven batters in six innings to run his career strikeout total to 3,501, only seven short of the record 3,508 registered by Walter Johnson from 1907 through 1927.

title: Tax Interest Rate Cut
description: The Internal Revenue Service has announced that the interest rate paid by taxpayers for underpayment of taxes will be 11 percent, down from 16 percent, beginning July 1.

title: UPHILL BATTLE FOR A ROOF OVER EVERYONE'S HEAD
description: To the Editor:

title: Beirut Attack on French Post
description: Attackers threw an explosive charge at a French Army post in West Beirut tonight, damaging a wall but causing no injuries. A French military spokesman said. the incident occurred near the Shatila refugee camp, scene of a massacre of Palestinian refugees last September. French troops immediately set up roadblocks in several parts of West Beirut in a hunt for the attackers.

title: LISBON'S SOCIALIST LEADER SEEN AS ELECTION FAVORITE
description: Campaigning has begun for Portugal's general elections April 25, and for Mario Soares, at 58 years old the grandmaster and survivor of Portuguese politics, the struggle to become Prime Minister seems all but won.

title: PUBLIC SERVANTS PONDER HOW TO IMPROVE IMAGE
description: Every day they send out tax notices, issue dog licenses and make sure the buses run on time, but, most of all, they worry about their public image.

title: Relief Arrives in Tahiti After Hurricane Strikes
description: Food, batteries and chemicals for purifying water arrived over the weekend to help Tahitians cope with the devastation caused by Hurricane Veena, which killed one person, injured 26 and left 25,000 homeless.

title: PENN CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The operations of Edgington Oil Co., a subsidiary, are not included in Penn Central's results because of the previously announced agreement for the sale of the subsidiary effective Jan. 1, 1983, the company said.

title: Interest Rates Drop Slightly; Gains Seen In Economy
description: Short-and long-term interest rates declined slightly yesterday, with all of the drop coming in afternoon trading. Government securities dealers said that investor activity was very light, and less than in the last few sessions when buying interest was strong for corporate and Treasury issues.

title: Brazil Seeks Israeli Missiles
description: Brazil wants to manufacture Israel's Gabriel missile under licence and is negotiating a deal with the Israeli Government, a Navy Ministry spokesman said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Rare Disclosure

title: FEDERAL NATIONAL MORTGAGE ASSN (FNMA) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. The share earnings figure is fully diluted.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The revenue figure for the latest quarter includes $21,800,000 which is subject to refund in connection with a pending retail rate case.

title: BRANIFF FILES PLAN WITH COURT
description: Braniff International left the door open yesterday for further negotiations to revive part of the airline while meeting a court deadline to submit a plan of reorganization.

title: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income. The year-ago results have been reclassified for discontinued operations. The year-ago results include the operations of Service Machine Group since its acquisition effective April 30, 1981.

title: 2 Ex-Officials of Detroit Charged in Supplier Loan
description: Two former city officials and a businessman were indicted by the Wayne County grand jury today on charges of conspiring to lend $1 million in public money, without having the legal authority to do so, to a company supplying diesel fuel for city buses.

title: STOICISM FORTIFIES BORDER PATROLMAN
description: After seven years as a Border Patrol officer, Capt. Mike Underdown takes a stoic view of his job, a daily game of hide-andseek in which he is ultimately always the loser.

title: CRIME VICTIMS TELL THEIR PAINFUL TALES TO REAGAN
description: Six victims of crime met President Reagan today and, amid the pastoral security of the Rose Garden, exchanged harrowing firsthand tales of an American experience lying beyond the iron gates of the White House.

title: FACTORY USE UP FOR 4th MONTH
description: Factory use rose for a fourth consecutive month in March, hitting the highest level since last summer, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Salvador Rebels Seize Post
description: Left-wing rebels overran a 120-man army post on the slopes of Chichontepec volcano today, killing 6 soldiers, wounding 8 and capturing 80, military sources reported. The sources said the army also abandoned three smaller outposts on the mountain 35 miles east of San Salvador during rebel attacks Sunday.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Chicago White Sox yesterday extended the contract of Manager Tony LaRussa through next season. He is currently in the second year of a two-year contract. . . . Andre (Moose) Dupont, the muscular defenseman on the Philadelphia Flyers' Stanley Clup championship teams of the mid 1970's, has retired. The 33-year-old Dupont, who played his final three seasons with Quebec, ended his 14-year career with 59 goals, 185 points and 1,986 penalties.

title: SHULTZ URGES THE MEXICANS TO PROMISE PEACE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, seeking to ease tensions with Mexico over United States policy in Central America, urged the Mexican Government today to promote peace in the region but warned that Nicaraguan arms supplies to guerrilla forces were creating turmoil there.

title: Satellite Plaudits
description: A planned trip to the White House to meet with President Reagan was foiled because it violated National Collegiate Athletic Association rules, so the North Carolina State basketball players had to settle for the next best thing. The Wolfpack team, which won the national championship two weeks ago, received congratulations from the President via satellite transmission from the White House to a Raleigh television station. ''I wanted to give my personal congratulations to Coach Jim Valvano and all of you ... for your heart-stopping victory over Houston,'' said Mr. Reagan, who was joined in Washington by Valvano and the two Republican senators from North Carolina, Jesse Helms and John East.

title: A Safety Is Seen As a 4-Point Play
description: Dave Jacobs, the heady 155-pound Syracuse alumnus who has been doing all the kicking for the New Jersey Generals, came up with a rarity in pro football on Sunday, the 4-point play.

title: NEW CHOICE IN SALVADOR: A NEGOTIATOR
description: Gen. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, the man likely to be El Salvador's next Minister of Defense, is known in Government circles as an excellent administrator who enjoys the role of mediator.

title: REAGAN CALLS BOMBING COWARDLY
description: President Reagan denounced ''the vicious terrorist bombing'' of the United States Embassy in Beirut today as ''a cowardly act.'' He vowed that the United States would not be deterred from its efforts to bring peace to the Middle East and the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.

title: FLAME INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $393,000 for the quarter and $659,000 for the 6 months.

title: CONNECTICUT ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MIRV AND THE WINDOW
description: The basic assumptions of arms control may be permanently altered by the report of the Scowcroft commission - a document that surely gave President Reagan more than he bargained for when he appointed its authors. For example:

title: MICROSONICS CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net loss The share earnings figures for the year-ago periods give retroactive effect to the required return of 900,000 common shares issued in connection with the initial merger of Microsonics.

title: PICCADILLY CAFETERIAS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Mugabe Renews Threat To Ban Nkomo Party
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe traveled to this opposition stronghold under heavy military guard today to mark Zimbabwe's three years of black rule. He renewed his threat to outlaw the opposition Zimbabwe African People's Union if violence continued in the region.

title: MOTOROLA NET FALLS
description: The GTE Corporation, which like other telephone companies has been experiencing only modest growth in the last year, today reported an 11.1 percent gain in net income for the first quarter.

title: A ROCKET'S PRIVATE FINANCING
description: While they were students at the Harvard Business School two years ago, three young men undertook a study for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration addressing the question of how the Government might encourage more private investment in space operations. One problem, they discovered, was the lack of entrepreneurs willing to take risks to ''make things happen.''

title: GANNETT CO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOPE STIRS FOR WORLD DEBT RELIEF
description: A Government study, ordered by President Reagan, of the foreign debt crisis has apparently concluded that the problem will be solved by economic recovery among the major industrial nations.

title: STATE OR STALEMATE
description: NOW that King Hussein of Jordan has failed to take up the Reagan plan and come to the negotiating table, there are two options in the Middle East - either stalemate or a peace settlement based on the creation of an independent Palestinian state. Surprisingly, even from an Israeli point of view, an independent state may be the preferable option. Even in the aftermath of the Lebanon war, the Palestine Liberation Organization has stuck to its traditional demands - for selfdetermination, Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank and Gaza and an independent state. The P.L.O. has also been able to prevent Arab endorsement of any alternative proposals - most notably President Reagan's plan for a self-governing Palestinian entity associated with Jordan. Until the P.L.O. defines what it will concede in return for a Palestinian state, the stalemate is therefore likely to continue.

title: MAJOR RETROSPECTIVE HONORS DALI IN SPAIN
description: A major retrospective of the works of Salvador Dali opened in the Museum of Contemporary Art here Friday, and there were one or two touches of semi-anarchy that the aging Surrealist would have approved of.

title: KIDNEYS MAY LINK STRESS TO HIGH BLOOD PRESSURE
description: MEDICAL researchers have long inquired into the role of stress in producing hypertension, or high blood pressure, but the physical pathways by which stress has stimulated the development of hypertension have remained unclear. A team of researchers at the University of North Carolina medical school, however, has concluded that stress appears to cause changes in the ability of the kidneys to excrete sufficient salt and water, thus impairing long-term bloodpressure regulation.

title: NASSAU COUNTY SAYS IT WON'T BUY RUMANIAN BUSES
description: Nassau County officials said today that they had decided not to purchase buses built in Rumania because of that country's ''repressive'' emigration policy.

title: Running Wild
description: Anyone who doubts the popularity of track and field among American youth should look at what's happening nearby the next two weekends. The Rutgers Adidas Relays Thursday, Friday and Saturday at Piscataway, N.J., have attracted almost 4,000 athletes from 105 colleges, 45 clubs and 160 high schools.

title: U.S. WARNS SOVIET ON MISSILE THREAT
description: A senior Pentagon official said today that if the Soviet Union sought to put nuclear missiles into the Caribbean area, the Reagan Administration would take measures like those used by President Kennedy in 1962 to force withdrawal of Soviet nuclear missiles from Cuba.

title: SCOVILL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NEW YORK AIR reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COURT HEARS CIVIL RIGHTS CASE OF WHITES LAID OFF IN BOSTON
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on the term's most contested civil rights question: whether municipal layoffs can be structured to protect recently hired blacks at the expense of the seniority rights of white workers.

title: WESTERN CO OF NORTH AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income. Results include an unusual increase of $3,700,000 in the company's allowance for doubtful receivables.

title: DIASONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JEFFERSON-WILLIAMS ENERGY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $52,000. c-Net loss.

title: ''NIGHT MOTHER' WINS PULITZER DRAMA PRIZE
description: Pulitzer Prizes were awarded yesterday to '' 'Night, Mother,'' a play by Marsha Norman, and to ''The Color Purple,'' a novel by Alice Walker.

title: 'SWEET TOOTH' STUDY SAYS FAT IS CULPRIT
description: Although the proverbial ''sweet tooth'' is commonly blamed for the problem millions of Americans have with excess poundage, a new study indicates that a hidden preference for fat is the real culprit. Dr. Adam Drewnowski of The Rockefeller University and Dr. M.R.C. Greenwood of Vassar College tested the taste preferences of 16 normal-weight college students for 20 different mixtures of dairy products and sugar. The highest rating was given to a mixture of heavy cream, with 37 percent fat by weight, sweetened with 8 percent sugar.

title: FLEXSTEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INQUIRY BEGUN ON CONNECTICUT REALTORS
description: The State Attorney General today announced a major antitrust investigation into Connecticut's real estate industry.

title: CROWN ZELLERBACH CANADA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DANA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COMMISSION OFFERS WAYS TO CUT COSTS
description: A group of top business executives advising President Reagan said today that the Government could save $46.8 billion in three years by better administration of health, transportation, housing and public lands programs.

title: Baldwin Files S.E.C.  Report
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation filed a 10-K report with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday, one business day later than the financially troubled company had promised earlier this month.

title: GULF POWER'S PRESIDENT TO HEAD SOUTHERN CO.
description: The Southern Company, corporate parent of four electric utilities in the Southeast, announced yesterday that the board had named Edward L. Addison president. He will also become chief executive officer in November.

title: JAZZ: JIM GALLOWAY AND SAX
description: IN the 20 years since Jim Galloway arrived in Canada from his native Scotland, he has become one of Canada's outstanding jazz saxophonists and clarinetists. In Toronto, where he lives, he leads a septet, the Metro Stompers, and he also has what he calls his Wee Big Band, a jazz repertory group that plays classic arrangements of the Ellington, Basie, Herman and Lunceford bands.

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Man Shot in Head In an Elevator
description: A 44-year-old man was shot and gravely wounded Sunday night, apparently during a robbery, in the elevator of his apartment building in Washington Heights, the police said.

title: GLOOM ENGULFING ALLEN AND THE METS
description: There is a pall over the Mets these days, and the chief reason may be that Neil Allen, usually a symbol of the team's hope, now seems to be a symbol of its despair.

title: Florida Power Agency Plans Yields Up to 9.3%
description: A $280 million issue of A/A-rated electric revenue bonds of the Florida Municipal Power Agency are tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9.3 percent for bonds due in 2014 through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: CONSOLIDATED RAMBLER MINES LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $900,000 for the latest year and $4,490,000 for the previous year.

title: HAROLD T. JOHNSON
description: Harold T. Johnson, former vice president of James Oliphant & Company, a former Wall Street brokerage concern, died Friday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 94 years old.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $66,621,000 for an accounting change for investment.

title: HARVARD RULE MET BY DEFENSE DEPT.
description: A Defense Department representative participated today in an open meeting at Harvard University on the military's recruitment of homosexuals. The department said it was the first time that it had participated in such a meeting at a university's request.

title: TRANSAMERICA INCOME SHARES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JOSEPH P. CRYNES
description: Joseph P. Crynes, head of Common Sense Systems Inc., transportation consultants, of Bayside, Queens, and Scranton, Pa., died Sunday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan.

title: STANDARD PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. c-After a pretax charge of $1,639,000 for the disposal of a Spanish subsidiary. Share earnings reflect a 3 percent stock dividend last summer and a 3-for-2 stock split in February 1983.

title: 'Stop Nukes'; Then What?
description: The nuclear freeze resolution that comes up before the House of Representatives tomorrow is a primal scream against mankind's atomic predicament. O.K., agreed: The overhanging nuclear nightmare justifies screaming. But then what? To exclaim ''Stop nukes now'' displays passion, but no practicality. What's the next sentence? Where is the credible arms control policy that freeze advocates have failed so far to advance?

title: WALESA, ON HIS WAY TO WARSAW, IS AGAIN DETAINED BY POLISH POLICE
description: The Polish police took Lech Walesa into custody again today, pulling his car off the highway from Gdansk as he was traveling here to lay a wreath on the Warsaw Ghetto monument. He was released late tonight.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing editor, an article on Saturday incorrectly described a Wall Street Journal report on a reputed remark by President Reagan to King Hussein of Jordan. The Journal article did not specify how or where the remark was made.

title: UTILITIES WEIGH PAYING OF SUPPLY SYSTEM BILLS
description: Officials at dozens of utilities in Washington State today hastily arranged meetings to decide whether to meet scheduled payments to the Washington Public Power Supply System.

title: High Court Refuses To Hear Rooney Suit
description: Mickey Rooney today failed to win Supreme Court review of his claim that major Hollywood studios allowed reruns of his pre-1960 films on cable television but refused to pay him.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: JORGENSEN,EARLE M, CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
General Mills Sets $215 Million Sale
description: General Mills Inc. said it had agreed to sell Tom's Foods, a snack foods operation, to Rowntree Mackintosh P.L.C. for $215 million.

title: Canadians Star In Orienteering
description: Two Canadians, Denise DeMonte and Ron Lowry, posted the fastest times over the challenging Ward Pound Ridge Reservations courses as the Golden Apple Orienteering Classic concluded a three-day competition.

title: RANGERS WIN, TIE SERIES AT 2-2
description: Suddenly, the Ranger-Islander playoff series that so many people were anticipating has materialized. The Rangers have thrown some obstacles into what had once looked like a clear path to the next playoff round for the Islanders.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $50,688 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $1.9 million from discontinued operations. d-Net income after a loss of $446,905 from discontinued operations.

title: LOUISIANA LAND & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JOB PLIGHT OF YOUNG BLACKS TIED TO DESPAIR, SKILLS LACK
description: Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said today that the startlingly high unemployment rate among black teen-agers was the result of lack of skills and lack of hope.

title: TAKEOVER CONNOISSEURS BIDDING FOR SOTHEBY'S
description: Stephen Claar Swid is from the Bronx, and Marshall Stuart Cogan is from Brighton, Mass. They met on Wall Street and teamed up to become successful at turning companies around.

title: A Mysterious Rendezous And the Day Is Saved
description: In rainy darkness, two cars made a rendezvous Saturday night at the 178th Street exit of the George Washington Bridge. A man in a trench coat passed a manila envelope to a woman from the other car.

title: Q&A
description: Q. What is escape velocity? Is it different for different planets?

title: THE DATA BASE SEEN IN A BENIGN LIGHT
description: OUR day-to-day lives are filled with data bases. Chances are you never looked at life that way; then again, you're not a computer. But take the telephone book or, for that matter, the ubiquitous grocery list flapping from its magnetic anchor on the refrigerator door, put it into a computer and it's called a data base.

title: COALITION LIKELY AFTER THAI ELECTION
description: Thailand appeared headed tonight for another coalition government as the votes were counted from today's nationwide parliamentary elections.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Beker Industries filed for an offering of 65,000 units, each consisting of $1,000 principal amount of debentures and 30 five-year warrants, through Bear, Stearns & Co.

title: TECHNICOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: WATSON TOOK HIS PLACE UP FRONT
description: Thirty years does not seem all that impressive in a city over 1,000 years old. But for two days last week, at Cambridge University's Churchill College, scientists of many nations gathered for a symposium to celebrate the 30 remarkable years since the discovery of the structure of DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid), the master chemical of heredity, in April 1953 by Dr. James D. Watson and Dr. Francis H.@C. Crick. Their first report was published in Nature, the scientific journal that organized last week's meeting. That knowledge has, in three decades, expanded to make a revolution in biology.

title: WEBSTER ERASES UNPRODUCTIVE PAST
description: There was a time when Marvin Webster was known as the Human Eraser because of his shot-blocking ability. And then there was the period when the Eraser seemed to be worn down, maybe even worn out.

title: SOME DISORDERS APPEAR TO BE LINKED TO BEING LEFT-HANDED
description: HANDED people, already burdened by minor inconveniences in a right-handed world and by a language full of such ego-deflating figures of speech as two left feet, out in left field and left-handed compliment, also seem to face an increased risk of certain disorders that can further impair the quality of their lives.

title: TV: 'NOW WE'RE COOKIN''
description: ''NOW WE'RE COOKIN' '' is almost a television reprise. It is about three former convicts, pals when they worked together in a prison kitchen, now gainfully employed in a restaurant.

title: CRITIC PRESSES FIGHT AT LOUISIANA LAND
description: In 1950 Delo H. Caspary borrowed $3,000 to buy a 26-foot party fishing boat in his hometown of Rockport, Tex., a Gulf resort area. But a business opportunity better than hauling sport fishermen soon presented itself. A drilling rig came to the tidelands region, and Mr. Caspary rented out his boat to its operators. Since then, he has been in oil-industry support services and ''grew with the industry,'' as he put it.

title: SENATE CHIEF SEEKS POWER OVER DEBATE
