description: The majority leader of the State Senate today proposed changing the Senate's rules so he could choke off debate and prevent Democrats from speaking on the floor.

title: U.S.-MEXICAN DISCORD IS OLD
description: Disagreements between the United States and Mexico over how to deal with Nicaragua go back almost 60 years. In 1927, Under Secretary of State Robert E. Olds described Mexico's approach to problems in Central America as ''a direct challenge to the United States.''

title: NEW YORK PLANNING SUIT AGAINST OFFSHORE LEASES
description: New York and other East Coast states are seeking to block the Federal Government from leasing millions of acres of offshore waters for oil and gas exploration.

title: NORTHWEST ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Business and the Law; Proxy Fights Proliferating
description: THIS is the proxy season and, it seems, the season for an unusual number of major proxy fights. Right now, the GAF Corporation, the Trans World Corporation, the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company and the Superior Oil Company are in the middle of proxy fights, with annual meetings for all these companies scheduled within the next month.

title: Gannett Earnings Up
description: Despite continuing start-up costs of its new national newspaper, USA Today, the Gannett Company, which publishes 87 daily newspapers, reported today that net income increased 2 percent in the first quarter of 1983, to $32.2 million, or 61 cents a share, compared with $32 million, or 60 cents a share, in the same period last year.

title: SURGING STOCKS: 4th HIGH IN ROW
description: The Dow Jones industrial average, in another of the dramatic surges characteristic of the stock market rally that began last August, rose to its fourth consecutive record high yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Century Energy Corp., Toronto, has appointed Charles O. Finley chairman and president.

title: Chicago Judge Limits U.S. Domestic Spying
description: A Federal judge today permanently banned the Federal Government from spying on domestic political groups in Chicago solely because they advocate civil disobedience or other illegal acts.

title: WILLIAM J. TAYLOR
description: William J. Taylor, president and chief executive officer of the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad, died Friday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, of an apparent heart attack.

title: German Stock Rally
description: The 100-share index of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung rose to a new high today of 310.73, surpassing the previous record set last Friday by 2.98 points. The Commerzbank index of 60 shares rose 9.4 points, to 931.4, the highest since June 22, 1961.

title: 33 REPORTED KILLED, 80 HURT; PRO-IRAN SECT ADMITS ACTION
description: A bomb exploded in the American Embassy in Beirut today, killing at least 33 people and wounding more than 80 others.

title: NATIONAL-STANDARD CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: Charlotte Curtis; Andres Segovia at 90; 'My most happy moments are when I am with my art and my family'
description: THE hotel suite was unnaturally bright, a tangle of gawky lights, umbrella-shaped reflectors, cameras and people connected in some manner by wires snaking about the floor and over the coffee table. And in the center of things, comfortably wedged into a green velvet armchair, sat the cherubic 90-year-old on whom all this attention was being lavished. Andres Segovia was giving yet another interview.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE WAY WE WERE

title: Soviet-French Satellite
description: Details have been revealed in Soviet press accounts of the payload carried by Astron, a joint Soviet-French astronomical satellite launched March 23 into an orbit that periodically carries it 125,000 miles from the earth - far enough to make observations outside the belts of radiation trapped by the earth's magnetism.

title: UGI CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results include a provision for the estimated cost of terminating operations at the company's Odessa, Tex., carbon dioxide plant, due to a closing of supplier facilities.

title: PIZZA TIME THEATRE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HIS SCORING SLUMP A CONCERN TO BOSSY
description: Mike Bossy knows when to expect criticism, although it hasn't happened much in the past. If he hears criticism, it will be when he is not scoring.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SHERRITT GORDON MINES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: CHINA AND VIETNAM TRADE FIRE
description: Chinese artillerymen inflicted ''heavy casualties'' on Vietnamese gunners who shelled a school, hospital and houses along the embattled frontier, China's official New China News Agency reported today.

title: FIRST COLUMBIA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $447,000 on the sale of assets. b-Net loss including a tax credit of $2.8 million.

title: Piston Coach Out
description: Scotty Robertson was dismissed as coach of the Detroit Pistons yesterday because of what Jack McCloskey, the general manager, called an inability to improve the team defensively.

title: MALPRACTICE SUITS DOWN SHARPLY
description: The number of medical malpractice claims by injured patients nationwide fell dramatically from 1975 to 1978, after registering an equally dramatic increase in the preceding five years, a study released today found.

title: Cuban Official Is Denied Visa To Attend Film Event in U.S.
description: The United States has refused to allow Cuba's Deputy Cultural Minister into the country to attend a film festival in Los Angeles this week, a spokesman for the United States Interests section here said today.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to give effect to the merger of Budget Capital Corp., formerly a wholly owned subsidiary, into Financial Corp. of America and to give retroactive effect to a 3-for-2 stock split in 1982.

title: Technologies Posts A Decline of 32.1%
description: The United Technologies Corporation reported yesterday that net earnings in the first quarter of this year fell 32.1 percent, mostly as a result of an accounting change that increased net income in last year's first quarter. Revenues, however, were up 8.5 percent.

title: CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
GREAT ATLANTIC & PACIFIC TEA CO OF AMERICA (A&P) reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,050,000 for the quarter and $9,850,000 for the year. c-Net loss including an extraordinary credit of $130 million for the quarter and year.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $249,000 for the quarter and $592,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $672,000 for the quarter and $1,481,000 for the 9 months.

title: CAMERA TRACKS BIKE ODYSSEY
description: Sports telecasts have had more than their share of junk food: arm wrestling, stock-car demolition derbies, strongmen racing with refrigerators on their backs. But all that seems a slight price to pay for one lovely, lyrical documentary like ''The Great American Bike Race.''

title: Allegheny May Sell A Unit to Nippon
description: Allegheny International is negotiating the sale of its Special Metals unit to the Nippon Steel Corporation, Japan's largest integrated carbon steelmaker, a spokesman said today.

title: Osborne Product
description: The Osborne Computer Corporation has introduced a personal computer designed for business executives, offering what Osborne said were improvements on its ''portable'' computer.

title: MORTON THIOKOL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $987,000 for the quarter and a gain from discontinued operations of $10,674,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago results have been restated to reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No. 52.

title: CHASE DOWN 7.8% IN QUARTER
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in the first quarter fell 7.8 percent from the same quarter a year ago.

title: TRANE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Court Asked to Bar Choice of Wagner
description: Lawyers representing a group of parents appeared in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday, seeking to block the appointment of Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. as Chancellor of the city school system.

title: GTE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PEERLESS MFG CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bridge: Once in a While, It Seems That an Expert Knows All
description: Inexperienced players struck with awe are often heard to pay a compliment to the ability of some third party: ''After the first three tricks he (or she) knows every card in your hand.''

title: DANCE: FELD PREMIERE
description: ELIOT FELD'S ''Summer's Lease,'' which had its world premiere Saturday night at the Joyce Theater with the Feld Ballet, is nowhere near as good as Mr. Feld's ''At Midnight,'' to which the new ballet might seem related.

title: Goodyear-Citicorp
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it had agreed to sell about $245 million in consumer accounts receivable to Citicorp on a non-recourse basis. The $245 million represents the amount customers currently owe under Goodyear's company-operated credit plan. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Help for Marathoners
description: The immediate future of the London Marathon, which had been in doubt recently because of difficulties between the organizers of the three-year-old event and city officials, has been resolved for at least one year. Chris Brasher, a former Olympic gold medalist and the chief organizer, said that next year's race would take place May 13. Although Gillette has withdrawn as the main sponsor after contributing $150,000 this year, the Greater London Council will donate necessary funds if Brasher is unable to find other sponsors, according to Ken Livinstone, a council leader.

title: A GOVERNMENT'S ULTIMATE SOCIAL SERVICE
description: To the Editor:

title: SENSITIVITY FOUND LACKING IN DOCTORS' TRAINING
description: THE story is told about the doctor who, having died, finds himself waiting in a long line at the gates to heaven. He protests, claiming the privilege of his profession, but is told that here even doctors must wait their turn. Suddenly, he sees an impressive figure in a white coat with a stethoscope around his neck, bypassing the line and walking right through the gates. ''Why can that doctor get in ahead of everybody?'' he asks. The gatekeeper replies: ''That's no doctor.That's God playing doctor.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This criminal attack on a diplomatic establishment will not deter us from our goals of peace in the region.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch by The Associated Press in Sports Pages last Thursday incorrectly described the extent of reading deficiencies found among football and basketball players at Iowa State University. The tests on which the report was based were limited to 28 incoming Iowa State players.

title: COMPUTER RESEARCH CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
PERSHING 2: 'LIFE-THREATENING TO ALL OF US'
description: To the Editor:

title: Short Circuit Blamed In Korean Disco Fire
description: A fire that killed 25 people and injured more than 70 was probably caused by an electrical malfunction in a crowded discotheque whose emergency exit had been blocked off, the police said today.

title: GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S. Doubts States Can Meet Deadline on Nuclear Wastes
description: All but a handful of states will fail to meet a 1986 deadline for having state or regional facilities for disposing of low-level radioactive wastes, the General Accounting Office said today.

title: Basketball Revival?
description: The University of San Francisco, which abandoned its varsity basketball program last July because violations had resulted in embarrasing probations and N.C.A.A. investigations, may resume the sport on the N.C.A.A. Division I level and perhaps will arrange to play a schedule of games during the 1984-85 season. A special task force has recommended resumption of basketball, and the president of the university, the Rev. John LoSchiavo, has passed on its findings for administrative review in advance of a final report that will go to the board of trustees on June 10. Ron Brills, the director of public affairs for the university, said yesterday that the task force's recommendations ''dealt generally with the role of boosters, the financial viability of a basketball program, the philosophy of recruiting and the academic requirements of athletes.''

title: ISRAEL DEDICATES NEW SETTLEMENT
description: Occupied West Bank, April 18 - Over strenuous objections from the opposition Labor Party, the Government used the 35th anniversary of Israel's independence today to inaugurate a major new Jewish settlement on the occupied West Bank.

title: Soviet Politburo Member Absent From Meeting
description: The Politburo met here today without Konstantin U. Chernenko, renewing speculation that the Soviet official is ill or in disfavor.

title: ADMINISTRATION LIFTS ITS BAN ON FINANCING RAIL TRANSIT SYSTEMS
description: The Reagan Administration, which has been adamantly opposed to providing funds for new mass transit rail programs or extensions for existing programs, agreed today to lift the ban, Administration officials said.

title: SUNDSTRAND CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Carriage Drivers Resisting City Hall
description: A handful of horse-drawn carriages stood in the chilly damp outside Central Park yesterday. ''For 114 years we've been in the park,'' groused Joe Vallone, a driver from Fort Lee, N.J. ''Why should we be regulated now?''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a mechanical error, 26 lines of an article on the Style page yesterday about exercise clothing were out of place. The material in columns 4 and 5 beginning ''just about every fitness buff'' and ending ''when she was carrying her'' should have followed the first line in column 3, ending ''sweat in regular clothes.''

title: FOR RETURNING COMMUTERS, JOY AND GRUMBLES
description: Through power shortages and wheel inspections, they stayed true. When fares rose and station platforms crumbled, they grumbled but endured. And yesterday, after six weeks of a strike, many of the 90,000 commuters of Metro-North returned to their trains once more. The fact that the ride was free, most admitted, did not hurt.

title: LEHIGH PRESS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MUD SLIDE CAUSES FLOOD IN UTAH TOWN
description: A mud slide that created a 1 1/2-mile-long lake that inundated this tiny railroad town continued to grow today, breaking a pipe being laid to siphon the rising water, officials said.

title: G.M.-Toyota Pact Studied
description: A decision from the Federal Trade Commission on the proposed joint car production deal between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation will most likely be made in 50 to 60 days, the F.T.C. chairman, James C. Miller 3d, said today.

title: EQUITY STRATEGIES FUND reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Net income figures represent net investment income.

title: Funeral Today for Firefighter Killed in Blaze in East Orange
description: Funeral services will be held Tuesday for an East Orange firefighter who died from burns he received in a blaze the authorities think was set.

title: GENERALS TO DIVERSIFY ATTACK
description: Herschel Walker's 142 yards rushing Sunday left the New Jersey Generals' halfback in a tie with Philadelphia's Kelvin Bryant for the ground-gaining leadership in the United States Football League.

title: SOME WELL-KNOWN NAMES AT U.S.I.A.
description: Like Juliet before him, Senator Edward Zorinsky is musing: ''What's in a name?'' The answer, the Nebraska Democrat suspects, is appointment to ''particularly choice posts'' in the United States Information Agency for relatives and friends of present or past officials of the Reagan Administration.

title: GOODRICH, B F, CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest first quarter include net income of $5 million from a cash refund settlement received by a unit. Year-ago results include a net operating subsidy of $1.9 million received in connection with an acquisition.

title:
THE PALESTINIANS LOSE;
THE failure of Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization to join negotiations over the Reagan plan is a tragedy for everyone in the Middle East but most of all for the Palestinians. The Reagan plan is not some lowlevel trial balloon but, rather, the maximum that Washington will conceivably offer the Arabs. The Palestine Liberation Organization cannot be excluded from a settlement, but short of a significant change in its policy, no workable agreement is likely.
description: Neither time nor leverage favor the P.L.O. or Jordan. Israel continues to build and populate West Bank settlements and to maintain its military superiority. King Hussein understands that the moment is critical and genuinely seeks peace, but a P.L.O. veto prevents him from acting. The P.L.O. distrusts him, fearing that Jordan will pre-empt the West Bank. It wants full recognition leading to an independent Palestinian state.

title: Public Service
description: The Clarion-Ledger

title: Edward McSweeney, 82, Dies; Printing-Industry Consultant
description: Edward McSweeney, a consultant for the printing industry, died Saturday at a nursing home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 82 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: ARGENTINA SEEKING MURDERER OF LETELIER IN ANOTHER KILLING
description: An Argentine judge said today that he was seeking the extradition of an American, Michael V. Townley, on charges of murdering Gen. Carlos Prats Gonzalez, the former Chilean army chief, and his wife in Buenos Aires in 1974.

title: PAINE WEBBER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MOTOROLA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AROUND THE NATION
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today ordered that a special plaque honoring the country's Vietnam War dead be placed at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier, where there is still an empty crypt. The plaque will be dedicated on Memorial Day, the Pentagon said.

title: SUPERIOR INDUSTRIES INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: HOLOCAUST MEMORIAL: A SURVIVOR'S CHOICE
description: To the Editor:

title: FORTUNE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (CLEARWATER, FLA) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Food for Disarmament
description: Some went for the cause, others went for the music, but most of the 75 people gathered in his SoHo loft on Friday went for Giorgio DeLuca's spectacular kitchen and eats.

title: ALL TRAVEL FREE AS METRO-NORTH RESUMES SERVICE
description: Metro-North resumed operations yesterday after a six-week trainmen's strike, carrying tens of thousands of riders between New York City and the northern suburbs with some scattered delays but no major problems. To mark the occasion, everyone rode free.

title: ELCOR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including tax credits of $316,000 for the quarter and $1,813,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: NATIONAL HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-The company went public on Dec. 10, 1982.

title: Room for Trucks Added in Midtown
description: All curb space in the center of the garment district will be reserved for trucks to load and unload goods, officials said yesterday.

title: FIGHT BREWS ON AID TO TEACH SCIENCE
description: Jim Wright was a young Congressman from Texas when President Eisenhower, reflecting widespread national concern over the Soviet Union's launching of the first earth satellite, sent a special education message to Congress in early 1958: ''National security requires that prompt action be taken to improve and expand the teaching of science and mathematics.''

title: MIZEL PETRO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
BROWN PELICAN: A DRAMATIC RETURN FROM DISASTER
description: ON Anacapa Island, off the California coast near Santa Barbara, the brown pelicans are nesting in profusion among the volcanic rocks this spring, a welcome sight to ornithologists who had once feared for their fate. Their eggs are firm and more thick-shelled than in years past. The early hatchlings feed lustily on the regurgitated anchovies in their parents' baggy gular pouches.

title: Far West To Buy Bekins
description: The Far West Financial Corporation agreed to aquire the Bekins Company, the moving and storage concern, for $81.9 million, the companies said.

title: GOULDS PUMPS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
POLITICS IS CITED AS A KEY FACTOR IN MX DECISION
description: The chairman of a Presidential commission that advocates deployment of 100 MX missiles in existing silos said today that the recommendation was shaped as much by political considerations as by military requirements.

title: LEAR PLANS TO BE FULL-TIME PRODUCER
description: Norman Lear, the television producer who created ''All in the Family,'' ''The Jeffersons'' and a string of other hit shows in the 1970's, is returning to a full-time career in television after a three-year absence. In so doing, he will give up his day-to-day role in the film business of Embassy Communications, a film and television studio that he owns with his partner, A. Jerrold Perenchio.

title: Brave Democrats and Withholding
description: Only five - count 'em, five - Democratic Senators are counted as sure votes against repeal of tax withholding on interest and dividends when the showdown comes this afternoon. The irresponsible campaign of the American Bankers Association to kill withholding before it begins has so turned the issue on its head that most Democrats will wind up siding with the banks and the tax cheats: the very same Democrats who, at the drop of a press release, accuse the Reagan Administration of favoring private over public interest.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Defeats Portisch And Advances to Semifinal
description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland won his quarterfinal world championship candidates match in Bad Kissingen, West Germany, with a 6-3 score over Lajos Portisch of Hungary. Korchnoi lost the eighth game but won the ninth to close out the series.

title: JOAN BENOIT SETS WORLD MARK
description: Greg Meyer won the Boston Marathon in 2 hours 9 minutes today. But it was Joan Benoit, shattering the women's world record by 2 minutes 47 seconds, who left an astonishing imprint on the 87th annual race.

title: NETS NEED DAWKINS AS LEADER
description: There are those who still insist that Darryl Dawkins was born with a special gift but that he has failed to use it to its fullest. They are right, to a point. There have been few things more frustrating about the Nets' season than his performances. From brilliant to baffling, his nights as the man in the middle have run the gamut.

title: Western Airlines' Merger Talks End
description: Western Airlines Inc. said it had terminated discussions with Household International Inc. concerning a possible merger of Western and Wien Air Alaska.

title: Charges of TV Piracy Lodged Against Man, 23
description: Frank Cardamone, 23 years old, who called himself the ''HBO Kid,'' was accused today of being the mastermind of a cable television piracy ring, which cost five legitimate companies up to $2.5 million over five years.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allis-Chalmers Corp. shareholders led by Bass Brothers Enterprises Inc. said they had increased their stake in the company's $5.88 convertible preferred stock to 7.9 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: VIOLIN CONCERT: NICHOLAS MANN
description: NICHOLAS MANN is a promising violinist, and his Saturday afternoon concert at the Metropolitan Museum had much to recommend it. He chose an appealingly diverse program and played with intelligence and a restrained warmth.

title: BRUINS TOP SABRES, EVEN SERIES AT 2-2
description: Rick Middleton had two goals and four assists tonight to lead the Boston Bruins to a 6-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres that tied their Adams Division championship series at two games each.

title: Working Up an Appetite And Remembering the Past
description: A small group clustered impatiently one recent evening by the service elevator at the Majestic, on Central Park West, where the main elevator had been out of order all Friday afternoon. Then, at 7:30, workmen had got stuck in the service elevator and could be overheard speculating on various cures.

title: YANKS HALT JAYS, 3-0, ON GUIDRY'S 2-HITTER
description: Those Yankees or Yankee fans who were worrying about Ron Guidry can stop worrying, at least for now. Guidry, who was not worrying, pitched a two-hitter last night as the Yankees defeated the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-0, scoring three unearned runs against Luis Leal in the second inning.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for qtr to Jan 31.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $2,700,000 for the quarter and year. The year-ago results have been restated to give effect to the retroactive change to the equity method of accounting of an investment.

title: THE CONTRADICTORY CASE FOR MX DEPLOYMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: RAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
Abitibi-Price Payout
description: Abitibi-Price Inc. cut its quarterly dividend to 20 cents a share from 30 cents, the Toronto Stock Exchange said today. The dividend is payable April 29, to shareholders of record April 28.

title: PLAN FOR SOUTH AFRICAN CASINO IN ATLANTIC CITY STIRS WIDE PROTESTS
description: A plan by a South African company to build and operate a $300 million casino hotel here has run into protest.

title: TUESDAY, APRIL 19, 1983
description: The Economy

title: HOLLINGS, ANNOUNCING 1984 BID, ASSAILS REAGAN AND HIS OWN PARTY
description: Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina formally entered the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination today and marked the event by denouncing the policies of both the Reagan Administration and his own party.

title: LUKENS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
description: b-Net income.

title: BEAN GENE 'TRICKS' SUNFLOWER
description: Genetic material transferred from a garden bean tricked sunflower tissue into producing a bean protein, scientists at the Agrignetics Corporation in Boulder, Colo., reported Sunday.

title: Market Place; Banks' Role As Discounters
description: DISCOUNT brokerage on securities trades, geared to retail investors seeking reductions of roughly 40 to 75 percent from rates charged by Merrill Lynch and other full-service firms, got a running start nearly eight years ago, thanks to the Securities and Exchange Commission. On May 1, 1975, a date now famous as Wall Street's May Day, the S.E.C. mandated fully negotiated brokerage commissions and, in the process, changed the face of the investment business.

title: A.& P. Has Profit in Quarter
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company yesterday announced final, audited net income for the fourth quarter, ended Feb. 26, of $6.5 million, or 17 cents a share, against a loss of $73 million in the quarter the prior year. Sales declined 1.8 percent, to $1.11 billion, from $1.13 billion.

title: SPARKMAN ENERGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $946,379 from discontinued operations.

title: FOR WARMER DAYS, LOOSE AND EASY
description: Some day soon the rain will stop, the temperature will rise and women will begin thinking about warm-weather clothes. They will pull out last year's cottons and linens and, almost inevitably, will find that some of the luster has faded, that some of the clothes look limp and uninteresting. It happens every year.

title: ISLAMIC ATTACKERS SEEN AS PRO-IRAN
description: The Islamic Jihad Organization, which took responsibility for today's bombing of the United States Embassy here, is believed to be an underground group associated with Moslem Shiite fundamentalists in Lebanon who support the Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Outer Boroughs Need Offices, 2 Say
description: More municipal offices should be situated outside Manhattan, City Council President Carol Bellamy and Donald R. Manes, the Borough President of Queens, said yesterday.

title: MEETING OF JOB BOARD PUT OFF
description: Governor Cuomo today postponed a meeting of the Job Incentive Board, a day before it was scheduled to consider an application by Shearson/American Express for $50 million in tax credits over the next 10 years.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN FLEES HIS TRIAL FOR TREASON
description: A former Methodist minister facing a charge of treason under the security laws was discovered today to have jumped bail and fled South Africa on foot, crossing the border into Lesotho.

title: CORRECTION HEAD IS SAID TO IGNORE A JUDICIAL ORDER
description: A State Supreme Court justice has accused New York City's Corrections Commissioner of disregarding a judicial order meant to protect a 36-year-old Queens hairdresser from being raped or from attempting suicide in jail.

title: LIFEMARK CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $190,000, or 1 cent a share, for the latest first quarter and $159,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Burglars Use Paris Sewers
description: Burglars entered the Malleret Company, a jewelry manufacturer, through the sewer system and stole $550,000 worth of gold jewelry, the police said today.

title: THE CULTURE TAX
description: One cannot blame Mayor Koch, given the city's budget problems, for scratching in every possible cranny and corner for fresh tax revenues. But now, one of his many attempts to find untapped money has led him into a blind alley.

title: MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
KLEER-VU INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
American Airlines
description: American Airlines and its president came ''dangerously close'' to fixing airline ticket prices with Braniff International by proposing that both carriers raise their fares 20 percent, the Justice Department said.

title: Sunken Tug Is Raised
description: Ship salvagers working with a giant crane pulled up a sunken 432-ton tugboat Sunday that had blocked traffic in the Cape Cod Canal for almost a week. The tugboat sank April 11 after a 300-foot gasoline barge it was towing overtook and capsized it under the Bourne Bridge. The tug is owned by the Bouchard Transportation Company of Kicksville, N.Y.

title: Books Of The Times
description: AIN. A Major New Analysis of the Workings of British Power. By Anthony Sampson. 476 pages. Random House. $17.95.

title: Luxury Boxes At '84 Olympics
description: The Raiders announced today that they would build 174 luxury box suites at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, and that the construction would be completed in time for the 1984 Olympics.

title: The U.N. Today; April 19, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee on the Charter of the United Nations and on the Strengthening of the Role of the Organization - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BROWN'S TOUGH STYLE WORKS FOR KNICKS
description: Unless an observer sits close to the Knick bench and watches Hubie Brown at work, the Knick coach is difficult to understand. Before a game he is calm, often talking to friends and jesting with the fans. But once the buzzer sounds, his face grows pale and taut and a different personality emerges as he searches for new strategies and ways to win.

title: FRUSTRATING TIMES FOR DUGUAY
description: What Ron Duguay had most of all was a flair that distinguished him from his teammates and gave him a swinging New York City image that Sonny Werblin liked in his athletes.

title: DEFENSE MINISTER IN SALVADOR QUITS IN MILITARY FEUD
description: El Salvador's Minister of Defense resigned today after weeks of attack from both American and Salvadoran authorities for his management of the war against a leftist insurgency.

title: PENTAIR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
OPERA: SOLTI CONDUCTS 'RHEINGOLD'
description: IT is generally agreed that ''Das Rheingold,'' in which Wagner lays out the groundwork for the three operas to follow in his ''Ring,'' is musically the least interesting work in the cycle. However, any such proposition would have been difficult to entertain last night at Carnegie Hall during the Chicago Symphony Orchestra's concert performance of the opera. Sir Georg Solti, a Wagner conductor with few peers in his generation, kept the score unerringly on course from the first watery, E-flat murmurings of the prelude to the shimmering final pages of the Rainbow Bridge music. This is no easy task in a work that has to spend so much time erecting philosophical and mythological scaffolding.

title: MARSHA NORMAN SAVORS PULITZER PRIZE FOR DRAMA
description: When Marsha Norman learned that she had won the 1983 Pulitzer Prize for Drama yesterday for '' 'Night, Mother,'' she was vacationing by herself in a secluded inn on the California coast four hours north of San Francisco.

title: JEWISH-POLISH BOND IN THE FACE OF GENOCIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: Blocking Agents
description: Curt Warner, Penn State's outstanding tailback for the last four seasons, had to leave his off-campus apartment at times during the last several months in order to avoid agents who were trying to get the rights to negotiate for him in his professional career. It was the only way he could get homework done or have privacy.

title: SEAFIRST APPROACHES INVESTORS
description: The deeply troubled Seafirst Corporation, the largest banking organization in Washington State, has been approaching out-of-state banks and other potential investors for a $200 million infusion of capital, Richard P. Cooley, its chairman and chief executive officer, said yesterday.

title: 130 Arms Demonstrators Arrested in Minneapolis
description: About 130 protesters, including the wife of the city's police chief, were arrested today in a demonstration against Honeywell Inc.'s manufacture of weapons for the Defense Department.

title: MUSIC: AWARD FOR CLIBURN CELEBRATED
description: VAN CLIBURN received the 1983 Albert Schweitzer Music Award at Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon, and appropriately, there was music to celebrate the occasion.

title: FLUKE, JOHN, MFG CO reports earnings for qtr to March 25.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend in February 1983.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
APARTMENT SUBLETTING SHOULD BE BANNED
description: To the Editor:

title: SIERRACIN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Conticommodity Sale Talks Halted
description: The Continental Grain Company said it had terminated exploratory discussions on the sale of its commodity brokerage subsidiary, Conticommodity Services Inc. The subsdidiary, based here, has 37 branches in the United States, Britain, West Germany, the Netherlands, Switzerland and South America.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: NEW YORK exploded. It couldn't help it. On 64th Street, the tulips u nstuck, disclosing mouths of deep fuchsia, fashion's new color. On M adison Avenue, new stores opened like tulips. And all over the East S ide hostesses entertained the fashionable until it seemed there was n o one new to invite, nothing new to wear and everyone had seen one a nother on no less than three occasions when once, and for no longer t han 20 minutes, would have sufficed.

title: COLEMAN CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Wider Swiss Trade Gap
description: Switzerland's trade deficit widened to $499.7 million francs in March from $345.4 million in February and $246.2 million in March 1982, the federal Customs Office said today.

title: Panel's Report Opposes Nuclear Freeze and MX
description: The Trilateral Commission discussed a committee report today that opposed both a nuclear freeze and deployment of the MX missile and recommended that Britain and the United States resume military conscription.

title: SHOULD A YOUNG CHILD'S INWARD-POINTING FEET BE TREATED?
description: FOR years parents of infants with toes that turn inward, a condition often originating in the leg bone, have followed their doctors' advice and had their children fitted with unwieldy and sometimes costly corrective devices.

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including a gain of $361,988 from the disposition of discontinued division. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect adoption of LIFO accounting.

title: CRUMP, E H, COMPANIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect an acquisition on a pooling of interests basis.

title: THE PROBLEM OF KEEPING SO MANY SECRETS SECRET
description: Ever since the Government contrived its system for keeping secrets during World War II, Presidents have been laboring, mostly unsuccessfully, to prevent classified information from spilling out, except when they want it to.

title: STARTS IN HOUSING DOWN 9.2%
description: Housing starts slowed 9.2 percent in March, to an annual rate of 1.6 million units, but the pace of new building still remained far above the level of a year earlier, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: DIETRICH RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net loss.

title: STOCKMAN WARNS BUDGET STALEMATE IMPERILS RECOVERY
description: President Reagan was warned today that a continuing stalemate in Congress over his budget proposals could lead to a breakdown in the budget process and mean that the ''Reagan Administration fiscal revolution and permanent economic recovery will be lost.''

title: MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
description: The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid Dec. 8, 1982.

title: Prison Hostage Standoff Continues in Pittsburgh
description: Two armed inmates at a maximum security prison haggled today over terms of surrender and an official said only a ''handful of items'' blocked release of two hostages that have been held for five days.

title: RULING PROMISED ON JUVENILE DETENTION POLICY
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether juveniles charged with delinquency may be confined before trial to prevent them from committing additional crimes.

title: HEARING ON SHOREHAM PLANT
description: A Congressional subcommittee heard testimony here today on safety requirements for nuclear power plants, including the Shoreham plant in Suffolk County, which is nearly completed.

title: ROGER LYON
description: Roger Lyon, president of the Arizona Bankers Association and chief executive officer of Arizona's largest financial institution, died Saturday. Mr. Lyon, who had cancer, was 55 years old.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, APRIL 19, 1983
description: International

title: G.E. Sale Accord
description: The General Electric Company has signed a definitive agreement to sell two mining concerns to the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Melbourne, Australia, for about $2.4 billion, the two companies said. G.E. said in January that it intended to sell Utah International Inc. and the Utah-Marcona Corporation. Directors of both G.E. and Broken Hill have approved the sales, which are expected to become final this fall. Under sale terms, G.E. will retain the Ladd Petroleum Corporation, a unit of Utah, as well as Utah's interest in the Pathfinder uranium mines in Wyoming, the Trapper steam coal mine in Colorado and some land development properties in the United States.

title: Roger Wolcott Hooker Dies; Ex-Aide at Hooker Chemical
description: Roger Wolcott Hooker, former senior vice president of the Hooker Chemical and Plastics Corporation of Niagara Falls, N.Y., died Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 86 years old.

title: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WELLS FARGO MORTGAGE & EQUITY TRUST reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes gains on sales and recoveries of $1,800,000, or 36 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,000,000, or 43 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Includes a gain on sales and recoveries of $2,800,000, or 69 cents a share.

title: 1965 MEMOS SHOW DOW'S ANXIETY ON DIOXIN
description: Almost 20 years ago, scientists from four rival chemical companies attended a closed meeting at the Dow Chemical Company's headquarters. The subject was the health hazards of dioxin, a toxic contaminant found in a widely used herbicide that the companies manufactured.

title: STEINBRENNER FINED $50,000 FOR REMARK ABOUT UMPIRING
description: George Steinbrenner, who has been a loud and frequent critic of umpires, learned yesterday that it would cost him $50,000 for his spring training remarks about National League umpires.

title: Commuter Rail Ties That Bind
description: The commuter trains of New York's Metro-North limped back into service yesterday and may soon be running with only their customary excuses. The six-week conductors' strike ended anticlimactically with the union's acceptance of binding arbitration of the central issue. Whether this will be a victory for riders and taxpayers, who deserve it, depends on whether the as-yet-unselected arbitrators will enforce the wage and other conditions already agreed to, and develop a fair plan to eliminate unneeded employees in the future.

title: Topics; Out of Work
description: No Favors

title: ZANUCK/BROWN LEAVING FOX
description: After three unhappy years at 20th Century-Fox, Richard Zanuck and David Brown are moving their Zanuck/ Brown Productions to the welcoming arms of Warner Bros.

title: Emil (Dutch) Leonard, Pitched for 21 Years
description: Emil John (Dutch) Leonard, a former major league pitcher who finished his career 9 victories short of 200, died of congestive heart failure at a hospital here Sunday. He was 74 years old.

title: RAPID AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $13,834,000 from the exchange of debentures. c-After extraordinary losses of $288,000 for the quarter and $6,337,000 for the year, and a tax provision of $9,748,000 for the year from the sale of an operation.

title: Court Bars Appeal by Boeing
description: The Supreme Court turned down today an appeal from the Boeing Company in a case involving its method of charging tax costs to the Government in military contracts.

title: First Fannie Mae Profit Since '80
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, today reported its first profit since the end of 1980 - $15 million, or 22 cents a share, for the first quarter.

title: Required Reading; 'You,' 'Us,' 'We'
description: Excerpts from a lecture given by Lord Home, the former British Prime Minister, at ceremonies marking the dedication of the Ditchley Bells, a gift of the Ditchley Foundation in Britain to the United States Congress in celebration of the 200th anniverary of the end of the American War of Independence and the beginning of peace with England. April 18, 1983:

title: IN BRAZIL, EXIT THE BRASS AND ENTER THE POLITICIANS
description: Brazil's military rulers have announced their intention to ''return to the barracks,'' provoking an eruption of campaigning among politicians vying to become the country's first civilian President in more than two decades.

title: FEDERAL SIGNAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $565,000 on the sale of land and buildings. Share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in March 1983.

title: ABC Forgos Bout
description: There was a news conference yesterday to announce Gerry Cooney's return to the ring after what will be more than a year, and Phillip Brown was there because he is the opponent for the June 18 bout, which will be televised by CBS from Las Vegas, Nev. Cooney, who last fought June 11, 1982, when he was stopped in the 13th round by Larry Holmes, remains a big draw, and his comeback fight will naturally do ''big numbers in the ratings,'' according to Bob Iger, the director of sports planning for ABC.

title: NEW ANALYSIS DESCRIBES BIRTH OF THE WHEEL
description: The wheel may have been the most important of all human inventions, but there has never been agreement on how this momentous discovery came about.

title: Japanese Productivity
description: Japan's productivity index in mining and manufacturing industries rose 1.6 percent in 1982, to 162.5, after a 3.5 percent growth in 1981, the Japan Productivity Center said today. The private research body said this is the lowest annual growth since 1976, reflecting sluggish economic activity.

title: UPJOHN CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Net income figures are after capital transactions.

title: ICN PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
School Board Asks Waiver for Wagner
description: The Board of Education yesterday asked the State Education Commissioner, Gordon M. Ambach, to grant Robert F. Wagner Jr. an equivalency certificate so that Mr. Wagner can serve as Chancellor of the city school system.

title: Miss Navratilova Is Seeded No.1
description: Martina Navratilova, the defending champion, was top-seeded today for the French Open tennis championships that begin May 23. The men's seedings are to be announced Wednesday.

title: SENATE PANEL BACKS REVISIONS IN IMMIGRATION LAW
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved a bill that would revise the nation's immigration laws by establishing penalties for employing illegal aliens and by offering amnesty to more than a million illegal aliens already in the United States.

title: Vandals Demolish the Grave Of Hans Christian Andersen
description: Vandals have destroyed the grave of Hans Christian Andersen, the author of fairy tales, a cemetery spokesman said today.

title: DENISON MINES LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIRST BOSTON GAINS
description: Three major securities firms - the E.F. Hutton Group, First Boston Inc. and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. - yesterday reported substantially higher first-quarter net income. The earnings increases reflected commission revenue resulting from the sharp gain in stock market trading.

title: Be Careful About Unisex Insurance
description: The pressure grows to have Congress prohibit discrimination by sex in insurance and pension calculations. The courts have already ruled such discrimination illegal in certain cases. And Senator Packwood and Representative Dingell are, against industry opposition, pushing broader legislation.

title: FIRST VALLEY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CELTICS, SUNS WIN
description: Larry Bird scored 26 points, including 6 in a two-minute span late in the game, and added 15 rebounds to rally the Boston Celtics to a 103-95 playoff victory tonight over the Atlanta Hawks.

title: TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,716,000. c-After a gain of $4,518,000 on the early retirement of debt and an extraordinary charge of $492,000.

title: DIET IN U.S. HELD FAULTY
description: A Government nutrition study has concluded that there are calcium and iron deficiencies in the diets of many women in the United States and that American men eat too much salt.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Jan. 28, 1983.

title: ERRORS ARE CITED IN MURDER HEARING
description: In an unusual admission of errors in a capital murder case, the Virginia Attorney General's office has asked a Circuit Court judge in Alexandria to vacate the death sentence of a convicted murderer.

title: VERMONT AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,950,000, or 30 cents a share, from the sale of the Henry G. Thompson Co. subsidiary.

title: CAPITAL CITIES COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Alaska Bonds Put From 5.5% to 8.6%
description: An $88.6 million issue of Anchorage school district bonds was tentatively offered at yields ranging from 5.5 percent in 1984 to 8.6 percent in 1995-96 by underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities. At those yields, the issue was oversubscribed, the underwriters said.

title: BRIEFING
description: Goldwater Was Upset

title: GOULD INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $500,000 from discontinued operations. c-Including income of $1.3 million from discontinued operations.

title: White Independent Wins Zimbabwe Senate Seat
description: The all-white Republican Front opposition party of Ian D. Smith, longtime Prime Minister of Rhodesia, was defeated again today when an independent white won a vacant seat in the Zimbabwe Senate.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

description: b-Includes a gain of $2,300,000 from the sale of stock in Telesphere International.

title: U.S. Steel Chief Explains Plan
description: David M. Roderick, chairman and chief executive of the United States Steel Corporation, met with members of the Congressional steel caucus today to explain the company's plan to buy and import British slab steel for finishing at the Fairless Hills plant outside Philadelphia.

title: Jays Win on 2 Homers in 9th
description: Cliff Johnson and Lloyd Moseby hit tworun homers off Dan Spillner, a relief pitcher, with two outs in the ninth inning to lift the Toronto Blue Jays to a 9-7 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

title: Careers
description: WHILE many young lawyers are looking for jobs, there is one area that urgently needs legal expertise: the field of computer contracts and computer crime.

title: PAINE'S EXPANSION INTO TEXAS
description: Continuing the trend of regional acquisitions by national financial organizations, Paine Webber Inc. said yesterday that it signed a letter of intent to buy the Rotan Mosle Financial Corporation, the leading regional brokerage house in the Southwest.

title: MERRILL BANKSHARES (BANGOR, ME) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JUSTIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $1,198,000 on the sale of real estate. c-Net loss.

LIEBERT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in February 1983.

title: A BLACK FOR '84
description: For a number of black leaders across the United States who began conferring on a political and policy agenda for 1984 before the Chicago mayoral election loomed quite so large, the issue of a black Presidential candidacy is being considered more seriously than at any time since 1972. That year, plans to ask Carl Stokes, then Mayor of Cleveland, to run were under consideration just as Shirley Chisholm actually entered the race.

title: Diets for Athletes
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
Armatron Deal
description: Armatron International said it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the business and assets of the J.C. Carter Company, Costa Mesa, Calif., a division of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, for about $30 million. The agreement provides for a June 30 closing, subject to the approval of both boards, Armatron said. J.C. Carter makes liquefied natural gas and liquefied petroleum gas pumps used for the transport and distribution of these liquids.

title: FOR FULL-TIME RESIDENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad Day for Reaves
description: John Reaves of Tampa Bay not only had his worst game in the United States Football League season, but also finished it on the sidelines with a broken right wrist. The injury occurred in the fourth quarter of the Bandits' 18-13 loss to the Los Angeles Express Monday night, and it is expected to keep Reaves out at least six weeks.

title: EAST SULLIVAN MINES LTD reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Including a special gain of $336,086 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including a special gain of $266,935 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: TROTTIER EXPECTED BACK FOR GAME FIVE
description: There are no courtesies extended, not even to the injured. ''The last guy off the ice has to pick up the pucks,'' said Bryan Trottier, the Islanders' veteran center, who remained on the ice alone for 45 minutes after today's practice. ''That's the way it's always been.''

title: Accounts
description: * Dayton, Ohio, Chevrolet Dealers Advertising Association to Berger, Stone & Partners.

title: ROBERT GREENFIELD TELLS OF BROOKLYN JEWISH LIFE
description: Robert Greenfield says that he is delighted to have just been selected to win the 1983 National Jewish Book Award for fiction. But in his next breath, he emphasizes, ''I am not a 'Jewish writer.' ''

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: TRANS CANADA GLASS LTD reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $12,066. c-Includes a tax credit of $12,193 and a special gain of $280,748 from the sale of property.

title: New M.A.C. Issue Yields Up to 8.7%
description: The Municipal Assistance Corporation sold $118.3 million of bonds yesterday to underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Higher Drinking Age Vetoed
description: Gov. Richard A. Snelling today vetoed a bill to raise Vermont's drinking age above 18 years, saying he could not ''in good conscience'' discriminate against a small segment of the state's adult population.

title: ACETO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
People Airline Plans Issue
description: People Express Airlines reported yesterday that it planned to file a stock offering of one million shares with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: HASBRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock splits paid in August 1982 and February 1983.

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $4 million, or 10 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: British Aide to Visit Soviet
description: Britain, in a move to improve strained relations with the Soviet Union, announced today that a Foreign Office junior minister would visit Moscow next week. It will be the first visit to the Soviet Union by a Foreign Office minister in six years and comes after a round of retaliatory expulsions by the two countries in the last three weeks. The Foreign Office said Malcolm Rifkind, a junior minister with responsibility for Eastern Europe, would go to Moscow next Sunday for consultations.

title: OVERHEAD DOOR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INEXCO OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CALIFORNIA MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Blazer Is Sued
description: Mychal Thompson of the Portland Trail Blazers has been sued by a bank in Minnesota seeking repayment of what it says is $82,000 in loans and accumulated interest owed by Thompson and a basketball camp he operates in the Bahamas. The suit, filed by the First National Bank of St. Paul, says that Thompson, who played for the University of Minnesota before joining the National Basketball Association in 1978, signed a series of notes from 1980 to 1982, supposedly to finance the basketball camp.

title: SARGENT-WELCH SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bogus Bills Said To Belong to Ring
description: The arrest of a Rockland County man for passing a bogus $20 bill apparently caused a counterfeiting ring to panic and dump more than $4 million in bogus money into a boat basin, Federal authorities said yesterday.

title: ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Why Drive Troubled People Crazy?
description: ''This 35-year-old female had an alcoholic father who put a shotgun in her mouth and threatened to blow her head off when she was a child,'' begins the psychiatrist's report. It goes on to detail the life of a barely functional person who gets along on medication, psychotherapy and a monthly disability check from Social Security.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: KOREAN DISHES THAT HAUNT THE MEMORY
description: THERE are certain dishes I've had just once that were so good the taste of them lingered in my mind long afterward. Among these are two Korean specialties that were first prepared for me years ago in Seoul. Their names, when transliterated, are sin-sul-lo and koochul-paan. They're rather elaborate dishes that are traditionally served for special events.

title: GLEASON WORKS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REGENCY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Investor in Irvine Sees Long-Term Opportunity
description: Donald L. Bren, a southern California home builder and land developer, made real estate history last week when he bought controlling interest in the Irvine Company for a sum estimated at $500 million.

title: REGIME WARNS ON MAY 1 PROTESTS
description: Lech Walesa was questioned by the police today, the third time in less than a week, amid indications of official concern over a call by underground leaders of Solidarity for demonstrations on May 1.

title: FLORIDA PROGRESS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest periods include net gains of $188,000, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and $842,000, or $1.03 a share, for the year from the liquidation of LIFO inventories.

title: COMPUTER CONSOLES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: MANKIEWICZ LEAVING PUBLIC RADIO
description: Frank Mankiewicz, president of National Public Radio, resigned as chief operating officer yesterday. The announcement was made at the annual Public Radio Conference in Minneapolis, where it was learned that the 13-year-old radio network was experiencing unexpectedly serious financial problems.

title: UNITED STATES INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results for the latest quarter include after-tax earnings of $1,000,000, or 5 cents a share, attributed to two acquisitions consummated in January 1983. The year-ago results include a gain of $4,000,000 after tax, or 17 cents a share, associated with litigation settlements.

title: Excelsior
description: Jose E. Serrano has moved into his new office suite in the Legislative Office Building in Albany and is enjoying the view. The South Bronx Democrat was appointed chairman of the Assembly Education Committee on Monday, and he said he found his new job and his new digs ''a pleasant surprise for a kid from the Bronx.''

title: KOCH MOVES TO FILL CITY JOBS WITH BLACK AND HISPANIC WORKERS
description: Mayor Koch, saying he was disappointed by the low number of black and Hispanic people hired by some city agencies, prohibited his commissioners yesterday from filling most jobs that pay $20,000 or more a year until he had time to recommend applicants.

title: LYDALL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: SPECIALTY COMPOSITES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $3,300. c-Net loss after an extraordinary credit of $350.

title: SILVER PLUNGES BY LIMIT; GOLD ALSO MOVE LOWER
description: All silver futures contracts yesterday plunged their daily permissible limit of 50 cents an ounce, while the price of silver for the unrestricted spot delivery fell 74.5 cents. The selling pulled down prices of gold and other metals, brokers said.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: RACK of lamb is, for me, one of the tastiest and best textured of meats to be found in this country. It is also, of course, expensive. Many recipes for rack of lamb call for boning and skinning the lamb and then serving only the tender heart of the rack. The instructions usually say to discard the bones, and I have often been asked if this is not a waste. It certainly seems so.

title: AUTOTROL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Nevada Court Backs Simulcasts
description: A Nevada state court has ruled that Caesars Palace in Las Vegas may resume simulcasts of daily racing held at Aqueduct.

title: PAROLED KILLER IN JERSEY IS LINKED TO 5 SLAYINGS
description: The bodies of two teen-age girls were unearthed on Staten Island yesterday, and the authorities linked their deaths and those of three other people to a man who served 16 years in prison for the murder of a municipal prosecutor in New Jersey.

title: HAZELTINE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $280,000. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-1 stock split declared April 19, 1983.

title: CITICORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

description: Ten hours after she had shattered the women's world record in the marathon, Joan Benoit was still on her feet dancing at a postmarathon party in Boston early yesterday morning.

description: Georgi A. Arbatov, a visiting Soviet official, has been asked by the State Department not to speak with reporters because American officials do not have equivalent access to the Soviet press.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: PUTTING a certain well-known nylon gorilla on top of the Empire State Building was not, as some have suggested, an isolated act of press agentry. No, Metropolitan Diary has learned that Kong was merely a trial balloon for an even bolder scheme to transform the skyline of New York with hundreds of flesh-colored celebrity inflatables.

title: Winning Both Wars in Salvador
description: Somewhere in El Salvador, a workable center may exist that Americans can help with an untroubled conscience. Somehow a paragon may emerge who can contain a leftist insurgency, show respect for human rights and press effectively for social reform. But the frustrations of the search are evident in the rise and fall of Defense Minister Jose Guillermo Garcia, until recently Washington's very model of a good Salvadoran general.

title: ALLIED ADVANCES BY 87.3%
description: The Allied Corporation, which completed its $1.8 billion acquisition of the Bendix Corporation in January, reported yesterday that earnings increased 87.3 percent in the first quarter while sales grew 59.6 percent.

title: A PRESS SECRETARY CAN SAY THINGS A SENATOR CAN'T
description: Shortly before the Senate convenes each day, two dozen reporters walk into the chamber and gather around the desk of Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, for a brief, guarded news conference. The reporters then move to a Capitol alcove, where they surround a short, trim aide who tells them in unvarnished language what the Tennessee Republican meant to say.

title: RARA AVIS FINDS A NICHE IN WORLD OF COMIC BOOKS
description: The balloons are familiar, as are the comic-book faces from which they issue. But the words inside the balloons are startlingly different.

title: Roulette to Decide Chess
description: Robert Huebner of West Germany and Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union played to a draw today in the 14th game of their quarterfinal match in the world chess championships and agreed to let a roulette wheel decide the series winner Wednesday. Both had seven points in the match. Smyslov will have red and Huebner black in the spin of the wheel.

description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee voted 19 to 16 today to deny the Administration's request for an additional $50 million in military aid for El Salvador this fiscal year.

description: The fighting in Central America may have one beneficial effect. Norstar Bancorp
description: The Norstar Bancorp, a Rochester-based bank holding company, announced that it had increased its offer for all of the shares of the Security New York State Corporation that it does not already own.

title: MUSIC: SHAPEY
description: ROBERT BLACK'S piano recital at the Abraham Goodman House Monday night was substantial, imaginative and an act of bravery. All of this music was contemporary in its way. Ralph Shapey's Passacaglia for Piano, written for Mr. Black, had its world premiere, while Donald Martino's Fantasies and Impromptus -though several years old - were being played as a unit for the first time in New York. The evening ended with perhaps the most futuristic music of the three - Beethoven's C minor Sonata (Op. 111). Mr. Black played these difficult works from memory, with technical security and showed a generous, well-intentioned musicality.

title: EARLY GOAL A BIG ONE FOR RANGERS
description: The primary assignment for the Rangers going into Monday night's playoff game against the Islanders at Madison Square Garden was to quickly change the momentum that the Islanders had built the previous night. The Rangers had won that game, 7-6, but the Islanders had scored the last four goals, making for a desperate finish.

title: More Q's Then A's
description: Motorists zipping along the Henry Hudson Parkway have been startled recently by an unusual cluster of abandoned cars where the parkway slips under the George Washington Bridge. About a dozen - mostly gutted and with smashed windows -have been lined up in a neat row at the edge of the northbound lane.

title: 20 UTILITIES SET TO PAY THEIR DEBT
description: Twenty utilities in Washington State, Idaho, Oregon and Montana, which together owe about half of the $7 billion debt on two canceled nuclear power plants, agreed today to pay their accumulated debt into court-administered reserve accounts.

But he left yesterday to prepare there for his middleweight title defense against Wilford Scypion, which takes place in three and one-half weeks.

description: Highland Park, a Kentucky Derby nominee ridden by Jacinto Vasquez, scored a narrow victory today in the $27,400 Calumet Purse at Keeneland.

title: TV: ZOE CALDWELL STARS IN 'MEDEA'
description: ZOE CALDWELL took a risk when she did ''Medea'' on Broadway last season. She played her character with a full-throated, full-blooded womanliness, filling the stage with a heated physicality. A proscenium arch is one thing, however, and a televsion screen is another, and what fills the one can simply overflow the other. On the public television production of ''Medea,'' which will be seen on Channel l3 at 8 o'clock tonight, it is obvious that care was taken so that this didn't happen. The production is a triumph of nuance.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 20, 1983
description: International

title: 50,000 FINE AND DANDY
description: With his usual thoroughness, only four and a half years after George Steinbrenner should have been publicly chastised for questioning the integrity of National League umpires, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn has fined the Yankees' principal owner $50,000 for questioning the integrity of National League umpires. And, in his grandiose surrender to the commissioner's authority, George Steinbrenner even announced that the fine would be paid. Not that he must write a personal check for the amount.

title: MAJOR CRIMES DOWN 4% IN 1982
description: The number of major crimes reported in the United States in 1982 declined 4 percent from 1981, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. It was the first real decline in reported major crimes since 1977, the agency said.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Cleveland Clinic Foundation, a hospital with a double-A bond rating much esteemed by investors, has taken advantage of lower interest rates by announcing an early re-funding of bonds it sold last year when interest rates were much higher.

title: PHILADELPHIA MAYOR CANDIDATES FACE OFF IN DEBATE
description: Frank L. Rizzo and W. Wilson Goode bludg@eoned each other with questions tonight in a debate on which each pinned much hope for the Democratic nomination for mayor.

title: METS NOW LOSING TO THE WEATHER
description: This spring's distinctly unspring-like weather, which has severely hampered the start of the baseball season, continued to disrupt major league schedules yesterday. Among the games postponed was last night's scheduled contest between the Mets and the Pirates at Shea Stadium.

title: THE SYRIANS' NEW VETO OVER U.S. ARMS SALES
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazilian Bank Loans
description: United States banks account for the largest portion, totaling some $600 million, of the $1.5 billion shortfall in interbank lines needed by Brazilian banks, banking sources said today. Sixteen of Brazil's major creditor banks met here yesterday, and pledged to redouble their efforts to persuade smaller banks to increase these money market lines to $7.5 billion, from the current level of $6 billion.

description: Rescue workers pulled more bodies from the rubble of the United States Embassy in Beirut today, but they said many other Americans and Lebanese were still buried under layers of concrete and were presumed dead.

G.O.P. COMPROMISES ON DIVIDEND TAXES, OPPOSING REAGAN
description: Senate Republicans reached a compromise agreement tonight to postpone for four years, and perhaps indefinitely, the withholding of taxes from interest and dividend income.

title: 2 More Dioxin Sites Are Found in Missouri
description: The toxic compound dioxin has been found at two more sites in Missouri, bringing to 29 the number of places in the state contaminated with the toxic chemical, the director of the Missouri Department of Natural Resources announced today.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: No one at work calls him by his proper name. Once his family was looking for him. ''Jim Staveley,'' they said on the phone, but nobody in the stuffy little stationmaster's office at Penn Station knew whom they were talking about. ''He fixes the trains,'' a family member explained. ''Oh, you mean the Flash,'' said one of the stationmasters.

title: Shell Layoffs
description: The Shell Oil Company said that its Shell Chemical Company subsidiary would lay off about 700 employees and about 575 contractors' employees working at Shell facilities. The company added that some of its production capacity would be adjusted, including the closing of a 700-million-pound annual capacity vinyl chloride monomer unit near New Orleans.

title: Eagle Clothes President Drawing on Experience
description: When Marvin A. Blumenfeld started out in business, he went into his father's store, the B and B Clothes Shop in Jamaica, Queens. In 1963, however, Eagle Clothes, a big manufacturer, bought B and B, its first retail purchase.

title: YANKEES ROUTED BY WHITE SOX
description: Escaping a spring snowfall in the New York area, the Yankees came to Chicago and played in dry but near-freezing weather tonight.

Head at Radio Group
description: After a long search and with the help of professional headhunters, the Radio Advertising Bureau has got itself a new president - William L. Stakelin, 40-year-old executive vice president of the Bluegrass Broadcasting Company, Lexington, Ky. He comes into the new job, which also includes the title of chief operating officer, on July 5, filling a vacancy that has existed since Miles David moved up to vice chairman, while remaining chief executive, last July.

title: Warner, Citing Atari, Posts $18.9 Million Loss
description: Warner Communications, whose dramatic growth came to a sudden halt late last year, said yesterday that it lost $18.9 million in the first quarter.

Economic Scene; Rising Deficits And Dangers
description: DESPITE its forecast of a stronger economic recovery than it was predicting in January, the Reagan Administration is now expecting even larger budget deficits in the fiscal years 1983 and 1984.

title: Market Place; Why Market Keeps Rising
description: FOR more than eight months now, the stock market has moved aloft like a giant balloon that dips briefly when buffeted by gusts only to soar again to new record heights.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Canadair Ltd. announced it would lay off 570 employees at its Montreal aircraft manufacturing plant by the end of July because of lagging sales of its Challenger business jet.

title: Gas Pricing Vote Is Set
description: The Senate Energy Committee, taking up natural gas legislation, agreed today to vote Thursday on whether price controls should be lifted on inexpensive ''old'' gas.

title: Grumman Sues Rohr Over Buses
description: The Grumman Corporation filed a $500 million lawsuit against Rohr Industries yesterday charging that Rohr failed to tell Grumman about structural problems with the Flxible Model 870 bus before Grumman bought Flxible from Rohr in 1978.

title: A FANFARE FOR (AND BY) KARL LAGERFELD
description: ''I'VE been going to Radio City since I was 8 years old, and it never looked like this,'' said Arthur Samuels Jr., president of Golo Footwear. He was among the 450 guests in black tie or glittering dress who turned up early Monday evening to sip white wine or stronger drink, dine on shrimp, roast beef and chocolate cake and watch a glamorous fashion show in the transformed Art Deco palace on what was called Sixth Avenue when Mr. Samuels first went to gawk at the Rockettes.

title: CITY IS OFFERING TO SELL BUILDINGS FOR BUSINESSES
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday that it was offering to sell 67 city-owned commercial buildings on shopping thoroughfares in depressed residential neighborhoods.

title: BALLET: ROYAL IN 'CAPRICCI' PREMIERE
description: AND so Britain's Royal Ballet has come back to the Metropolitan Opera House, looking very royal. By that one means last night's world premiere by Sir Frederick Ashton could well be set on the island of Mustique, while ''Enigma Variations,'' Sir Frederick's l968 masterpiece, celebrates a sun-setting era as only an artist born under the British Empire could.

title: ROCHESTER'S OWN: A HOT DOG WITH ZING
description: IT could be said that a city has real problems when the Mayor, the head of the Chamber of Commerce and a sampling of solid citizens agree that their hometown is somewhat dull, doesn't have an image and even lacks its own geographic soul food as a means of sparking instant national identification.

title: Need for a Single Lung
description: In Montefiore Medical Center, the Bronx, a retired Air Force lieutenant colonel who served in three wars, Vandell Bell, has been waiting since April 10 for a lung transplant. As time goes on, his breathing deteriorates further and he requires more and more constant oxygen.

title: JUSTICES CURB BURDENS STATES PUT ON INDEPENDENT CANDIDATES
description: The Supreme Court, sharply divided over issues of state sovereignty, ruled today that states may not require independent candidates for President to meet substantially more onerous requirements than major party candidates to appear on the November ballot.

description: The Federal Highway Administration, under legal challenge from four states because of its orders to admit double-trailer trucks to many principal Federal highways, today allowed those states to cut back the routes the trucks can use.

title: Iran Denies Any Involvement In Bombing of U.S. Embassy

title: Arrows Lose, 11-4

The second game of the two-of-three series will be played at Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, L.I., Saturday night.

description: To the Editor:

title: Counter Demonstrations Held at Mississippi U.
description: Black students prayed and sang in front of the University of Mississippi Administration Building today amid campus tension over use of the Rebel flag as a school symbol.

title: NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: SOME men and women arrive at airports for a trip abroad looking like magazine advertisements. Their beautifully matched or carefully coordinated unmatched luggage is given into the hands of a porter and off they go to the gate, unburdened by anything but passports and traveler's checks. What elegance, what chic!

title: OPERA: SOLTI CONDUCTS WAGNER'S 'RHEINGOLD'
description: IT is generally agreed that ''Das Rheingold,'' in which Wagner lays out the groundwork for the three operas to follow in his ''Ring,'' is musically the least interesting work in the cycle. However, any such proposition would have been difficult to entertain Monday night at Carnegie Hall during the Chicago Symphony Orchestra's concert performance of the opera. Sir Georg Solti, a Wagner conductor with few peers in his generation, kept the score unerringly on course from the first watery, E-flat murmurings of the prelude to the shimmering final pages of the Rainbow Bridge music. This is no easy task in a work that has to spend so much time erecting philosophical and mythological scaffolding.

title: THEATER: A 'DREAM' SET IN CHINA
description: TISA CHANG is offering a breezy, bilingual, cameo version of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' at the Pan Asian Repertory Theater. The production excises the fairies and reduces the cast to 12, cuts the text and expounds many of Shakespeare's most memorable lines in mandarin Chinese. To American ears, ''Ill met by moonlight, proud Titania'' could easily be confused with ''What fools these mortals be.'' Necessarily, there is a linguistic sacrifice in this approach, but the evening does have its own modest virtues.

title: FROM SMALL-SCALE FARMERS, HIGH-QUALITY PRODUCTS
description: TO motorists passing at 3 A.M. on certain days last summer, the Pitts farm in Orange County, N.Y., was an eerie sight, something out of Washington Irving's Sleepy Hollow. Off in the middle of a moonlit cornfield a solitary gas lantern bobbed and swung as a spectral figure lurked amid the shadowy rows. Anyone with temerity enough to investigate might have been rewarded with some of the crispest, sweetest corn ever tasted. Instead, the corn was on its way to selected markets in New York by sunrise. ''In order to get that corn to the city by early morning that's what had to be done,'' explained Morse Pitts, the midnight corn man.

title: Defense Bolsters Rangers' Chances
description: Starting time was a few minutes away for the fourth game of the Rangers-Islander playoff series Monday night, and in locker rooms at opposite ends of the hallway in Madison Square Garden each team was preparing psychologically for the challenge.

title: Price of Failure

The owner even offered to refund 5 percent of some season tickets for each game in the difference between 30 victories and the number of games below 30 the team won.
