description: Quite a few rumors have been making their way around the mainland lately about the destination of the Puerto Rican Tourism Company account, but none of them mentioned AC&R Advertising, the subsidiary of Ted Bates/Worldwide.

title: WINE TALK
description: IF there is a Grand Old Man of American wine, it's Leon D. Adams, a reformed newspaperman who founded the California Wine Institute and ran it for 20 years, all the while turning out a steady flow of good, sensible wine books. His finest work, ''The Wines of America'' (McGraw-Hill), lifted Mr. Adams right out of the wine-writer category and made him a full-fledged social historian. He has been around wine for a long, long time, so when he talks about the future, it's worth listening.

title: The U.N. Today; April 20, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Blues' Sale a Step Closer
description: The Ralston Purina Company agreed today to sell the St. Louis Blues to a group of Canadian businessmen who want to move the team to Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. The company, which has lost millions of dollars on the Blues since buying them five years ago, received authorization for the sale from its board of directors early today and said it was prepared to send a group of executives to Saskatoon to complete the contract.

title: FULL SENATE GETS ABORTION MEASURE
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee today sent a constitutional amendment to the floor that would reverse the 1973 Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion. The vote was 9 to 9, which means that the committee acted without a positive endorsement.

title: SOVIET IS CRITICAL OF CHINESE AGAIN
description: A Soviet newspaper today criticized China more harshly than at any time since moves toward better relations between the two countries began last year.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: IT seems that almost everybody loves the Beach Boys. Apparently James G. Watt, the Secretary of the Interior, does not, but his recent attempt to bar the group from performing on the Mall in Washington brought down such a storm of criticism that one would have thought he was advocating unregulated industrial pollution.

title: OPEC and Soviet
description: The Organization of Oil Exporting Countries hopes to bring the Soviet Union into talks on stabilizing the world oil market, Humberto Calderon Berti, Venezuela's oil minister, said today.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF REAGAN STATEMENT ON REPORT OF STRATEGIC FORCES COMMISSION
description: Following is a White House transcript of a statement by President Reagan today on the report of the President's Commission on Strategic Forces:

title: HELPING JAPAN ON DEFENSE
description: The Pentagon, alarmed that its own complaints about the European defense effort were underminding American public support for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, reversed course last year and began to call attention to the very significant contributions our European allies make - 90 percent of the ground troops in Europe and 75 percent of the tanks and combat aircraft there. It is time that we similarly reversed course and gave Japan credit for its defense efforts.

title: U.S. ASSAILED IN FRANCE OVER STRENGTH OF DOLLAR

title: STAGE: 'TEANECK TANZI,' COMEDY FROM BRITAIN
description: THERE are two diversions to occupy theatergoers just before the start of Claire Luckham's play ''Teaneck Tanzi: The Venus Flytrap.'' The first is the refurbished Nederlander Theater - a Broadway house that the designer Lawrence Miller has ingeniously transformed into a full-fledged wrestling arena. With a burst of gaudy lights above the ring and much architectural fiddling, Mr. Miller transports us well beyond Teaneck - all the way to Atlantic City.

title: ...SCHOOLS THAT ARE NO 'DUMPING GROUND'

FAIRNESS VS. ADVOCACY

For the most part they were independents, the freelancers of television journalism, whose films over the years have included some of the most provocative programs seen on television. The conference was called to examine journalistic standards, although many of the documentary makers there denied they were journalists.

description: A plan to reduce from five to four the number of firefighters riding on 73 of New York City's pumper trucks has been abandoned, officials said yesterday. The budget-balancing move had been scheduled for August.

description: A young farmer who said he was insane when he bludgeoned two people to death, including a man who tape recorded his own slaying, was convicted of murder today in one of the deaths.

Team America's Plight
description: Within walking distance of the White House, at 908 Seventeenth Street N.W., the telephone with a number that corresponds to U-S-A-T-E-A-M rings almost continuously during business hours. Fan and corporate interest in Team America intensified last week, but there was still little interest in playing for the team that will provide the nucleus for the United States national team in World Cup competition.

title: McEnroe Is Upset By Trey Waltke
description: Trey Waltke, ranked 118th in the world last year, upset John McEnroe, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, in the first round of the $400,000 Alan King Tennis Classic today.

title: THE MX'S NEW CLOTHES
description: The argument now being made by President Reagan for building the MX missile is an extreme example of a strange new phenomenon in American statecraft. Our leaders have taken to poormouthing the country: announcing how weak and vulnerable it is. The world will not respect us, they say, unless we show our resolve by doing something foolish and dangerous.

title: Gary Hart Opens Campaign Headquarters
description: A full year before the New York presidential primary, Senator Gary Hart yesterday became the first candidate to open campaign headquarters in New York.

title: OPEC-Japanese Banks
description: Mitsui Bank Ltd. said the 13 member states of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries may withdraw up to $2.5 billion from their holdings in Japan of deposits, bonds and shares in the calendar year 1983. The bank's monthly report, assessing the impact of OPEC's price cut of $5 a barrel, said OPEC nations withdrew an estimated $1 billion from Japan in 1982, leaving their total investments here at the end of 1982 at $39 billion, or 10.3 percent of their total overseas investments.

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Blank Check' for Israel?

title: New Phone Tax
description: Along with the monthly shock of finding you've made more long distance calls than you thought comes a note with the current bill from New York Telephone.

description: A top Salvadoran guerrilla leader, Cayetano Carpio, committed suicide here after discovering that the people close to him had killed his second-in-command, the Nicaraguan Interior Ministry announced today.

title: New Adventure
description: For Carling Bassett, the women's tennis tour is more of an adventure now than a way of making a living. Miss Bassett is only 15 years old and has been a professional for three months, but she is doing well on the tour.

title: Tennessee Bank's Problem Loans
description: The new owner of the failed United American Bank of Knoxville says it does not know how much of the bank's $327 million in problem loans it can recover.

description: Governor Cuomo said here today that he would pursue Federal legislation to place employees on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad under state labor laws.

description: The Egyptian Coptic Church has defied a court order to elect a new pope to succeed the one ousted by President Anwar el-Sadat, a church prelate said today.

Otherwise, when Mark Bradley gets into a rental car and begins searching the neighborhood in the vicinity of Shea Stadium for an apartment, he is on his own. He has become accustomed to traveling alone.

description: The nation's most prestigious home-entertainment center is not a suburban showplace filled with the ultimate in stereo and video equipment. It's an aqua-and-white room that is furnished, for the most part, with tray tables and folding chairs.

description: More than 60 advanced X-ray scanners in use around the country contain a defect that poses ''a serious radiation hazard'' to thousands of patients, a research group charged yesterday. It asked the Government to take steps to limit their use until they are fitted with radiation-reducing filters.

title: News Analysis
description: The New York State Senate has become a house divided against itself - with a vengeance. The partisan battle for control of the Senate, waged with increasing vigor at the ballot box in recent years, has in the last 10 days spilled onto the floor of the usually staid upper house of the Legislature and slowed the body's work to a crawl.

title: Grudging Shift by Kentucky
description: Bill Olsen, Louisville's athletic director, once worked as an assistant to the school's basketball coach, Denny Crum. One of his tasks was to attempt to arrange a game with Kentucky.

FRENCH BROTHER-SISTER TALE
description: PLOT is not paramount in Peter Del Monte's ''Invitation au Voyage,'' but the details of the narrative certainly warrant some mention. A young man named Lucien is grief-stricken at the death of his adored twin-sister Jeanne. So he fits her body into an instrument case and carries her through France atop his car, on a journey home.

Weilbacher, one-time agency executive, and now a consultant on advertising management. It was like saying that there is no Santa Claus.

description: A Denver architect and real-estate developer has given Columbia University $5 million to endow a new center for the study of American architecture, the university is expected to announce today. The gift is believed to be the largest single grant ever made for architectural scholarship and it is one of the largest gifts Columbia has ever received.

HELP FOR WORKERS LACKING CONTRACTS
description: For the more than 70 percent of American workers who are not covered by a collective bargaining agreement or an individual employment contract, dismissal is an ever-present possibility. The nation's courts have traditionally ruled that such employees can be dismissed at any time - for any reason or for no reason - a status known as ''employment at will.''

title: Italy's Payments Deficit
description: Italy's overall balance of payments deficit widened sharply in March, to a provisional $951.3 million, from a provisional $207.3 million in February, the Bank of Italy said today.

title: Taub's Torn Nets
description: Ideally, at the start of the playoffs in any sport, a team should be at its best: playing with confidence and without distractions. But as the New Jersey Nets opened their National Basketball Association mini series with the New York Knicks at Byrne Meadowlands Arena here last night, they were a team in transition, torn and troubled. Their coach, Bill Blair, was an interim choice. They had lost six of their last nine games. And their out-front owner, Joe Taub, announced he might resign as president.

title: AMERICAN IN PARIS WHO'S DISENCHANTED BY UNESCO
description: Chester E. Finn Jr. entered the world of Unesco politics here for the first time this week. It is not, he says, an experience he would wish on a friend.

According to Jim Foley, a spokesman for the Rockets, Sampson would be the club's choice even if Akeem Abdul Olajuwon, Houston's 7-foot sophomore center, decides to cut short his college eligibility.

title: Who Is Poland?

title: Comings and Goings

Ron Fraser of Miami became the third college baseball coach to reach 800 victories when his team beat Florida International, 7-2, Tuesday night. Frank Sancet of Arizona retired with 829 victories and Rod Dedeaux, who is still active at Southern California, has 1,230 victories.

title: MUSEUM GIVEN JAPANESE ART

title: Robelyn Schrade Plays Varied Piano Program
description: The pianist Robelyn Schrade began her Sunday evening Carnegie Recital Hall program with a defiantly romantic, even Stokowskian, rendition of Bach's Toccata in G minor. Miss Schrade's assured technique and intelligence imbued her unconventional performance with conviction, and she made the music live in a way few scholastic zealots can approximate.

title: William Horne, 69, a Tenor With New York City Opera

title: Apple Makes Sale
description: Drexel University said that it had selected a new generation personal computer developed by Apple Computer Inc. for use by its 1983 freshman class and that it would buy the new computers for $1,000 each starting in the winter term. The cost includes the disk-drive unit, built-in software, at least 64,000 bytes of main memory and a high-capacity disk for additional mass memory. The school said that Apple maintained that the average novice could learn to do productive work on the machine in as little as 30 minutes.

title: RESIDENTS SET TO LEAVE HOMES NEAR TOXIC SITE
description: By Thursday, Lloyd Lovejoy and his neighbors along Morrish Road will be the latest in a growing list of refugees from the chemical contaminaton of American neighborhoods.

description: Tom Seaver, for many years the stopper of the Mets' staff, filled that role again last night at Shea Stadium. Seaver, now 38 years old and in his second tour with the Mets after five and a half years in Cincinnati, held the Pittsburgh Pirates to three hits and got a key triple in a 6-0 victory that ended a six-game losing streak for the Mets.

title: DISSERVING CAMBODIA
description: Today, eight years after the Khmer Rouge seized power in Cambodia, Pol Pot and his forces wait in mountain bases near Thailand for an opportunity to return to Phnom Penh. The Cambodian people, who bear the indelible imprint of the terror of Pol Pot's four-year rule, celebrated his ouster from the capital by Vietnamese forces in January 1979. Now they want the Vietnamese occupiers to leave Cambodia - but not if it means risking restoration of the Pol Pot regime.

description: Victor Posner was named chairman yesterday of the Evans Products Company of Portland, Ore. Mr. Posner is chairman and chief executive of the Sharon Steel Corporation, which owns 43.2 percent of Evans's common stock. A plan to combine Evans and Sharon has been terminated, Evans said.

title: Patriots Seeking A Deal for Elway
description: The New England Patriots, who have the 15th pick in the first round of Tuesday's National Football League college draft, have intensified their attempt to obtain the No. 1 pick from the Baltimore Colts.

title: Article 114787 -- No Title
description: A pink diamond valued at $500,000 to $600,000 was reported stolen from Sotheby Parke Bernet galleries the afternoon before it was to be auctioned, the police said yesterday.

title: SAFEWAY STORES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
NUCLEAR METALS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Baldrige View on Volcker
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has done a good job, but that replacing him would not have an adverse impact on the financial markets.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC & GAS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RLC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes income from spun-off operations of $775,000 for the quarter and $1,654,000 for the 6 months. Revenue for the 1982 periods is restated for the spin-off of Rollins Environmental Services Inc. on Aug. 2, 1982.

title: Promotion Effort Near For Gillette Shampoos
description: No question of it, April showers do bring Gillette shampoos. Announcements have just been made promising that from the creative halls of the Marschalk will bubble a new TV and print campaign for Bare Elegance Moisturizing Body Shampoo and from the equally creative precincts of N.W. Ayer in the same media a campaign for the Mink Difference Replenishing Shampoo for the hair.

title: BANCORP HAWAII reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MONEY MARKET RATES AT BANKS SHOW DROP
description: In New York and throughout the nation, interest rates on bank money market deposit accounts declined last week, the Bank Rate Monitor reported yesterday.

title: Music Noted in Brief; 1928 Musical 'Rosalie' In Concert at Town Hall
description: No less than four big Broadway names - George Gershwin, Sigmund Romberg, Ira Gershwin and P.G. Wodehouse - collaborated on the hit 1928 musical ''Rosalie,'' which the New Amsterdam Theater Company presented in a concert version at Town Hall on Monday. ''Rosalie'' was one of the most opulent extravaganzas of the Ziegfeld era - so opulent, in fact, that when it opened, its lavish spectacle outweighed its musical substance in the public mind.

title: MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The per share results for the 1983 period are computed after deducting dividend requirements on $400 million of preferred stock issued by the corporation during the second and third quarters of 1982.

title: GREATE BAY CASINO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results include tax credits equal to 3 cents a share for the latest first quarter and 5 cents a share for the year- ago first quarter. Year-ago revenues have been adjusted to exclude complimentary revenue.

title: Technology Stephen J. Marcus ; Solar-Age Windows
description: A WINDOW'S purpose is to admit light, but it also radiates heat; much of a building's energy goes out the window. This has elevated heating costs and posed problems for architects.

title: WORK WEAR CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $201,000 from discontinued operations.

title: France Bans Slot Machines
description: The French Government has decided to ban slot machines to protect young people from games of chance, Max Gallo, a Government spokesman, said today.

title: STIFF CURB SOUGHT ON 'LEAKS' OF DATA
description: A committee of Reagan Administration officials has proposed a law under which any Government employee who improperly discloses classified information would be subject to a criminal penalty of three years in prison and a fine of up to $10,000.

title: JEC LASERS INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Net income.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, the Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a $2,000,000 pre-tax reserve for phasing out computer manufacturing operations.

title: Bridge: A Beginner Can Resemble A Genius at Certain Times
description: Inexperienced players often contend, rather naively, that they do not follow the basic rules of defense and that consequently an expert opponent would not know what to do against them. In practice, this tends to mean that they make life difficult for their partners and easy for the declarer.

title: Player Hospitalized
description: The outfielder Roy Johnson, the 1982 batting champion of the American Association, entered the Care Manor Hospital of Orange County in San Diego yesterday for treatment of drug and alcohol dependency.

title: ISLANDERS ROUT RANGERS AND TAKE 3-2 LEAD IN SERIES
description: Bourne, Bourne & Sutter, fast becoming a Long Island scoring institution, tonight continued its bull run through the playoffs.

title: PUGET SOUND BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BRAZIL GROUNDS 4 LIBYAN PLANES CARRYING ARMS
description: Brazil announced today that it had decided not to permit four Libyan planes, detained since Saturday, to proceed to Nicaragua with tons of arms and explosives.

title: SBD ELECTRONIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings are restated.

title: Five Metals Producers Post Losses in Quarter
description: Armco Inc., continuing to show large losses from its carbon steel production because of weak demand, reported yesterday that it had a deficit of $128.4 million in the first quarter of 1983.

title: SUPERIOR SURGICAL MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERICA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ECONOMIC GROWTH PUT AT 3.1% RATE IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Spurred in part by a sharp jump in housing construction, the nation's economy grew at an annual rate of 3.1 percent in the first quarter, the largest quarterly rise in two years, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: UNITED STATES SURGICAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $646,000 from the exchange of preferred stock and a note receivable for common stock.

title: POLICE ASSERT FRIEND HELPED SUSPECT MOVE BURIED BODY
description: While police dug in vain yesterday for more bodies at the Staten Island site where two murdered teen-agers were found Monday, officials said privately that a friend of the suspect had helped him move a body from one burial place on the site to another.

title: BTR's Tilling Bid Held Up by Court
description: Thomas Tilling P.L.C. said an Illinois court had issued an order temporarily restraining BTR P.L.C. from making further purchases of Tilling shares.

title: SYMBOL TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
U.S. AIDE IN BOLIVIA ON BARBIE INQUIRY
description: An official from Washington has begun an investigation here into possible connections between a Nazi war criminal and members of United States intelligence agencies.

title: NORTON SIMON INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $17,876,000 for the quarter and $19,570,000 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary gain of $5,435,000 for the 9 months. Results for the latest quarter include a gain of $2,200,000, or 9 cents a share, from the purchase of debentures for ordinary sinking fund requirements. Results for both the latest 9 months and the year-ago 9 months each include a gain of $2,200,000 from the purchase of debentures for ordinary sinking funds requirements.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 25 percent stock dividend issued in January.

title: KNICKS WIN PLAYOFF OPENER
description: Behaving like rude guests in their neighbor's house, the Knicks routed the Nets, 118-107, tonight before a crowd of 15,672 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in the opener of their two-of-three-game National Basketball Association first-round playoff series.

title: BRINK'S DEFENSE LAWYER CALLS PROSECUTORS 'THE REAL CRIMINALS'
description: A defense lawyer in the Federal trial involving the Brink's robbery and murders in Rockland County told the jury yesterday that the prosecutors were ''the real criminals.''

title: PANEL TELLS REAGAN THE RUSSIANS SEEM TO HAVE BROKEN ARMS PACTS
description: An interagency committee has reported to President Reagan that it believes the Soviet Union has violated terms of the 1979 strategic arms accord, and the Administration is under pressure from conservative senators to make that finding public, officials disclosed today.

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WASHINGTON POST (DC) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TO UNCLOG LONG ISLAND COURT CALENDARS
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Carbide Drops 47%; Allis-Chalmers Reports a Loss
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, one of the nation's largest chemical companies, reported yesterday that net income in the first quarter dropped 47 percent, to $48.1 million, or 69 cents a share, from $90.8 million, or $1.32 a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales fell 5.2 percent, to $2.19 billion, from $2.31 billion.

title: Cost of Cities' Repairs Is Called 'Manageable'
description: Streets and roads, sidewalks and curbs and drainage systems are the key public facilities most in need of major repair in United States cities and towns, a survey released today shows.

title: CRONUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $10,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Silas Loses Job
description: Paul Silas, the San Diego Clippers' coach whose job had been on the line throughout the basketball season, lost it yesterday when Paul Phipps, the Clippers' general manager, announced that Silas's contract would not be renewed. The move had been expected since the Clippers had collapsed at the end of the season, losing 22 of the last 27 games and finishing with the second worst record in the National Basketball Association.

title: ROCHESTER TELEPHONE reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HIGH POINT, N.C.
description: DESIGN trends at the Southern Furniture Market this month came wrapped in traditional packages. Rather than emphasize innovative styles, many of the 1,300 manufacturers simply used new fabrics and finishes to dress up furnishings from previous markets.

title: INTEREST RATES DOWN SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday. Treasury market participants said there were no new developments pointing toward significantly higher or lower rates.

title: NET INCOME UP 32% AT MANUFACTURERS
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation yesterday reported a strong gain in first-quarter net income, but earnings of the Continental Illinois Corporation continued under pressure because of nonperforming loans.

title: CBS Radio Station
description: CBS Radio announced an agreement to purchase station KRLD in Dallas from Metromedia Inc. for $27 million. The transaction is subject to approval by the Federal Communications Commission, and CBS must sell one of the seven radio stations it now owns, according to a network spokesman, Pam Haslam. Included in the pending purchase are the Texas State Radio Networks, among them the Dallas Cowboys Football Network.

title: Wild About Asparagus
description: For some, spring means robins and crocuses, but for George Lang it means asparagus. Over the years, he has collected over 500 pieces of art, ceramics and miscellany - from an upholstered bunch of asparagus on his couch to stained glass asparagus to an asparagus potholder (which he framed) to paintings.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

description: International

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Federal Express Head Picked by Carson Pirie
description: Peter S. Willmott, president and chief operating officer of the Federal Express Corporation, announced plans yesterday to resign to become president and chief executive of Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago department store owner.

title: PENNBANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MORE HARM THAN HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: BSL in Chapter 11
description: BSL Technology said it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in the United States District Court in Utah. The company, which designs, assembles and maintains data management computer systems for medical and clinical laboratories, said it was actively pursuing merger possibilities, but it did not say whether any groups had shown interest in such a plan. Its BSL Systems unit did not file for bankruptcy, and will continue its system maintenance and support operations, it said.

title: Answers
description: Nineteen derelict cars have been cleared from the shoulder of the Henry Hudson Parkway near the George Washington Bridge, the Sanitation Department reported yesterday.

PHELPS DODGE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

description: Stock prices soared yesterday, propelled by favorable economic news and by the impressive first-quarter profits reported by General Motors, a market bellwether.

title: INDIANAPOLIS POWER & LIGHT reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TO THE HOME SECTION
description: I read Susan Jacoby's rueful but right article on ''rule-trashing'' and thoroughly applaud her for taking issue and for her clear and frightening analysis of this disturbing situation.

title: Market Place; Analysts Differ On Utilities
description: CHARLES B. JOHNSON, portfolio manager of the Franklin Utilities Fund, believes that the recent steady market action of utility stocks implies that interest rates are heading lower and that inflation will remain moderate.

title: Strike Fails to Halt Racing at Aqueduct
description: The gates to Aqueduct were lined with pickets yesterday afternoon, but track officials insisted that a strike by maintenance workers and possible walkouts by other employees will not disrupt racing or betting.

title: BEARINGS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PRESTON TRUCKING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Washington Post Gains
description: The Washington Post Company reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter increased 21.6 percent, to $6.2 million, or 43 cents a share, from $5.1 million, or 36 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: ETHYL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in April 1983.

title: On Buying Weapons, and Influence
description: Assistant Secretary of Defense Richard Perle recommended that the Army consider buying mortars from an Israeli company a year after he accepted a $50,000 fee from the company's owners. Mr. Perle says he did nothing wrong. That may be, but there's a lot wrong with the procurement practices that encourage such behavior.

title: 3 SOVIET ASTRONAUTS LAUNCED TO DOCK WITH SPACE STATION
description: Three Soviet astronauts were launched into space today aboard a Soyuz T-8 spacecraft for a scheduled docking with an orbiting space station.

TOPPS & TROWSERS INC reports earnings for qtr to Jan 30.
description: b-Net income.

title: C.A.B. ACTS ON TICKETS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board took action yesterday to prevent major airlines that dominate the computerized reservations field from unfairly obtaining temporary use of ticket payments when their flights are not involved.

title: Irish Banks Cut Prime
description: Ireland's big four banks announced cuts of one and a half percentage points in their prime rates, to 15 1/4 percent, effective at the close of business today. The Bank of Ireland, Allied Irish, Ulster and Northern also said the rate for personal loans would drop by one point, to 17 1/4 percent.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income of $3,990,000 related to a change in depreciation methods.

title: PANEL IS TOLD OF FACTORS IN UPRISING AT OSSINING
description: Prison inmates and guards testified publicly today for the first time that officials of the state prison at Ossining had ignored repeated complaints about conditions in the prison in the year before the uprising there in January.

title: 3 STOCK INDEX FUTURES SHOW DISSIMILAR GAINS
description: Prices of all three stock index futures advanced along with the actual stock market yesterday. Only one, however, showed the same gain as its underlying index: the New York Stock Exchange index futures, which climbed 1.11 points, the same gain as registered by the Big Board's composite index.

title: Hyatt Reaffirms Intent To Abandon Braniff Bid
description: The Hyatt Corporation today reaffirmed that it has abandoned its efforts to revive Braniff International, a move that appeared to set the stage for a court showdown between the failed airline's secured and unsecured creditors.

title: Purchase by LTV
description: The LTV Corporation said it had agreed in principle to acquire the Sierra Research Corporation of Buffalo for stock valued at $48 million.

title: T.M. ALEXANDER JR., BANKER IN ATLANTA, LOST OFF HONDURAS
description: T.M. Alexander Jr. of Atlanta, an investment banker and former government official, was lost and presumed drowned in a boating accident Saturday off Honduras.

title: PALMETTO FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOA ASSN (PALMETTO, FLA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
THURSDAY, APRIL 21, 1983
description: The Economy

title: 55 ARE INDICTED IN BRONX IN SALE OF STOLEN GOODS
description: A seven-month undercover operation has led to the indictment of 55 people in connection with the sale of $500,000 in goods stolen primarily from homes in the Bronx and Westchester County, the Bronx District Attorney announced yesterday.

title: Reds 6, Astros 4
description: Cesar Cedeno's two-run double highlighted a six-run fifth inning that helped give the Reds the victory. Houston went ahead, 2-0, in the second inning when Jose Cruz walked, Ray Knight belted an r.b.i. double to right center and Alan Ashby, who had four hits, drove in a run with a single to center.

title: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Wagner's Staff
description: Robert F. Wagner Jr. and Anthony J. Alvarado, who were among the contenders for the job of Schools Chancellor, dined together Tuesday night.

description: b-Including a pretax gain of $3 million on the disposition of assets and a net gain of $10.7 million on the sale of securities. c-After a net loss of $24.6 million from discontinued operations, an accounting gain of $26.4 million and a pretax gain of $17.7 million on the disposition of assets.

title: SORG PAPER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: THREE REPUBLICANS HOLD MAYORAL DEBATE, A RARITY IN PHILADELPHIA
description: For Philadelphia, it was an event worthy of watching if only for its rarity. Three Republican candidates walked into a television studio tonight to battle one another for the privilege of leading their outnumbered party into a race for Mayor.

title: G.M. EARNINGS SURGE FIVEFOLD IN FIRST QUARTER
description: The General Motors Corporation reported today that first-quarter earnings surged more than fivefold, to $653.1 million, or $2.08 a share, its largest quarterly profit in more than four years.

title: LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WHEN ACTORS REVIEW THE AUDIENCE
description: Stage actors and directors talk about audiences all the time. Will the theatrical chemistry work tonight with that group of a thousand or so laughers, coughers and curtain-callers who change at every performance? Is an audience, in the Rodgers and Hammerstein phrase, that fearful ''big black giant''?

title: LEXICON CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
DAVID GREENE, LEADER IN INVESTING IN UNDERVALUED STOCKS, DIES AT 82
description: David J. Greene, the founder of the New York Stock Exchange firm that bears his name and a progenitor on Wall Street of the investor in under-valued ''special situation'' securities, died Monday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I., and Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Cuba Denounces U.S.  Over Ouster of 2 at U.N.
description: Cuba condemned the United States today for its ''despicable'' action in ordering two Cuban diplomats at the United Nations to leave the country within 48 hours.

title: MARION CORP reports earnings for year to Jan 31.
description: The company, which is in Chapter 11 reorganization, said year-ago results are restated for a change to the successful-efforts method of accounting for oil and gas operations.

title: Federated's Chief For Discount Chain
description: Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest operator of department stores, announced yesterday that it would get into the growing industry of selling national brands at discount prices. It named a young executive from a competitor, May Department Stores Inc., to head a chain of stores that will be opened next year.

title: A GUIDE: CHOOSING THE RIGHT COMPUTER CAMP
description: COMPUTERS and robots may not be the stuff of summer camp memories for parents who wistfully recall pitching tents in sylvan glades or coursing through white water on rafts. But for a growing number of today's children, working with high-technology equipment and learning the mysteries of bits and bytes will be a highlight of school vacation. They will attend computer camps, one of the newest specialty sleep-away camps, where novices are taught the basics of programming, and the more experienced can sharpen microcomputer skills.

title: NATIONAL BANCSHARES OF TEXAS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm an old fogey now. I'm 61. But I'm liberated. I never wish to run for anything again in my life.''

ELDON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 19.

A.T.& T.'S NET DROPS BY 15.5%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday that its net income for the first quarter declined 15.5 percent, the result of accounting changes, the economic slump, competition and other factors.

Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period.

title: PRESIDENT COOL ON TAX MOVE
description: The Reagan Administration, in the face of increasing pressure from Capitol Hill, said today that it was not ready to accept the Senate Republicans' compromise agreement that would postpone withholding of taxes from interest and dividend income for at least four years.

title: Rizzo Son-in-Law Gives Up
description: Former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo's son-in-law surrendered today after the police, armed with warrants, arrested at least 11 others in a three-state, $30 million-a-year bookmaking ring. Mr. Rizzo contended that the warrants for his son-in-law, Joseph Mastronardo Jr., 33 years old, and Mr. Mastronardo's younger brother, John, were timed to embarrass him.

title: Campaign Begins For Great Bear Water
description: On Saturday the Great Bear Spring Company, the 95-year-old water bottler in Teterboro, N.J., will start its very first television advertising campaign using the theme line ''Great Bear, because nothing is better.''

title: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MINE SAFETY APPLIANCES CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CENTRAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Phillies 2, Cubs 0
description: PHILADELPHIA (UPI) - Steve Carlton pitched a four-hitter for his 288th career victory, and Joe Morgan accounted for both runs with his first home run in a Philadelphia uniform.

title: INTRIGUING DIVERSITY OF STYLES
description: SHE explained that the imposing chestlike piece of furniture was a kai dansu, a staircase from a Japanese farmhouse, and that the lacquer items in bucket shapes were actually mid-19th century ceremonial sake containers. ''The Japanese are very clever about storage because they have so little space,'' said Diane Love, above, on a tour of her recently expanded shop.

title: Apple Expects Net Rise
description: Apple Computer Inc. expects to report today a 74 percent increase in earnings for its second quarter ended April 1, said A.C. Markkula Jr., president and chief executive. He said revenues rose to about $228 million, from $131 million in 1982, and estimated net income at 40 cents a share, up 66.6 percent.

title: Macmillan Bloedel Net
description: Macmillan Bloedel, a diversified paper products company, yesterday reported net income of $2.4 million in the latest quarter, compared with a net loss of $10.4 million a year earlier. But excluding special gains of $25.4 million on the sale of office buildings and a 50 percent interest in Island Paper Mills, the company had an operating loss in the latest period of $23 million. Sales in the quarter dropped 12.4 percent, to $442 million, from $504.5 million.

title: BLACK YOUTHS ARE AS EAGER TO WORK AS WHITES AND STAY ON JOB LONGER, U.S. PROJECT FINDS
description: Black teen-agers are as eager to work as white teen-agers and tend to stay on the job longer, a federally financed employment program has found.

title: KIDDE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest first quarter include pretax income of $11.9 million comprised of a gain of $25.7 million on the sale of a portion of the company's investment in Victor Technologies Inc. and costs and expenses of $13.8 million related to the curtailment of certain energy equipment operations and plant consolidations.

title: WALESA COMMENTS ON MAY 1 PROTEST
description: Lech Walesa, founder of the Solidarity union, said today that Polish workers had the right to celebrate the May Day holiday ''in their own way.''

description: Results for the latest first quarter include operations of Frank's Nursery & Crafts Inc. since the date of acquisition, March 7.

description: b-Including a gain of $1,420,000 on the sale of discontinued operations.

title: ISRAEL: AN UPHILL FIGHT AGAINST SOCIAL ILLS...
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGH COURT RULES A STATE MAY BAN NEW ATOM PLANTS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states are free to ban nuclear power plants as long as the ban is motivated by doubts about the economics of nuclear power rather than its safety.

title: ENGLISH GARDENS BLOOM UNDER GLASS
description: PINK and red dahlias, white stock, blue delphiniums, golden lilies, blue anemones and white Canterbury bells are but a few of the thousands of flowers blooming under glass right now at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. Set by a facade of a typical English cottage complete with sod roof and brick paving, the display will continue until May 20 in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory.

title: SEALED POWER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DOUBTS ARE VOICED ON SHUTTLE GOAL
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's goal of reaching 30 space shuttle flights a year by 1990 is ''impossible or highly improbable'' with only the four spacecraft that are now financed, according to a panel of aerospace experts assembled by the National Academy of Sciences.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $403,000, or 15 cents a share, from a casualty insurance recovery on a warehouse that burned down.

title: AUTOTROL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: YANKEES TRIUMPH AS RIGHETTI EXCELS
description: Dave Righetti wasn't ready tonight to pitch the first no-hitter of his career, but he provided further evidence that he is ready to display the dominance the Yankees have expected from him.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change in billing procedures that added $12.7 million, or $1.77 a share, to the net income.

title: Q&A
description: Q. We have insulation on our attic floor and plan to add more. During the last snowstorm we noticed that the heating did not go on in the daytime, apparently because of the thick blanket of snow on the roof. We are therefore wondering if we would be better off adding insulation to the underside of the roof rather than putting more on the floor.

title: APOLLO COMPUTER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $727,000. c-Net loss.

title: SPARROW HELPS BEAT TEAM THAT CUT HIM
description: During the Nets' 1980 training camp, Rory Sparrow and Darwin Cook were low draft choices battling for a spot on the roster. Cook beat out Sparrow for the final spot, but tonight Sparrow excelled for the Knicks against the team that had cut him.

title: UNION CARBIDE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results for the latest quarter include a gain of $10,000,000 from advance sales of Uranium and a gain of $6,400,000 from a rebate of surcharges, previously paid by Union Carbide, from the Louisiana Power & Light Co.

title: Jets and Giants In Prime Time
description: The Jets and the Giants have apparently arrived as national drawing cards. Both teams will make three appearances on ABC's prime time pro football schedule next season, according to a fall schedule released by the network and the National Football League.

title: 1,000 Attend Funeral Of Jersey Fire Captain
description: An East Orange fire captain who died after rushing into a blazing building looking for people he believed were trapped inside was given a hero's funeral here today with more than 1,000 mourners present.

title: Argentine Group Issues List of Detention Camps
description: An Argentine human rights organization has made public a list of what it said were 47 secret detention camps where political prisoners were interrogated and tortured by security agents in the late 1970's.

title: HERS
description: ''YOU'LL get married again.'' ''You're lucky that you're young enough to have other children.'' ''You'll get another dog before long.'' People mean well. They think it helps a grieving friend to concentrate on the prospect of replacing whatever or whomever has been lost. It doesn't help - not when fresh grief reminds us, mercilessly and ceaselessly, of the irreplaceable nature of bonds that have been severed forever.

title: Stowaway Boy Is Rescued
description: A stowaway boy was rescued after he leaped from a Panamanian freighter into a river as the ship passed under a bridge into Lake Huron, the authorities said today. The unidentified boy was believed to be 10 to 14 years old and boarded the ship in Conakry, Guinea. He was rescued Tuesday from 40-degree water by a deckhand on a boat ferrying a Great Lakes pilot to the 607-foot Yerel, and was returned to the ship.

title: CORRECTION

title: SAFEGUARDS ON MISBRANDED DRUGS SAID TO FAIL
description: A ''considerable amount'' of misbranded or adulterated prescription drugs reaches the marketplace because the Food and Drug Administration's procedure for seizing these products is cumbersome, according to a recent report by the General Accounting Office, the auditing arm of Congress.

title: Japanese Import Quotas
description: Japan plans to raise its import quotas for beef, oranges and fruit juices by up to 30 percent for three years, the Japanese daily Asahi Shimbun reported. The report said the actions were designed to reduce trade friction with the United States. The newspaper said the import quota for high-quality beef would be increased about 30 percent; for oranges, about 10 percent, and for orange and grapefruit juices, a ''considerable margin.''

description: President Reagan today signed into law the bipartisan plan designed to assure the solvency of the Social Security System for the next 75 years, happily hailing the measure as ''a monument to the spirit of compassion and commitment that unites us as a people.''

BIG-NAME, SMALL-PRICE CLOTHES ARE A HIT
description: THE fall fashion season on and off Seventh Avenue did not get off to a zingy start this week. A number of designers were unduly impressed by the Tokyo school. A master of men's wear faltered when he added a woman's collection. When there was time between the ceaseless flow of showings to reflect a bit, it was clear that the best clothes so far were the less expensive collections done by the best-known designers, whose major shows take place next week.

title: The Budget Process Also Counts
description: President Reagan has wisely offered Congress a compromise, at last, on the defense budget. In the perverted spirit that reckons a village can be saved by burning it down, Defense Secretary Weinberger had wanted the President to hold firm even if this wrecked both the Congressional budget process and the fiscal 1984 budget.

title: PHILHARMONIC: SCHOENBERG'S 2-HOUR 'GURRELIEDER'
description: IN their most ambitious gesture of the season, Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic last night presented Schoenberg's strangest and most grandiloquent score, the two-hour essay in fetid post-Romanticism called ''Gurrelieder.'' This is the work Schoenberg began in 1901, but dropped and then finished a decade later. It is a monster in every way and appears so rarely in the concert hall that every performance has to be marked down as a special event, even if it falls short of complete success, as this one did.

description: The bridge experts of Poland are a formidable group, and they have become a useful source of foreign exchange for their country. They go to most of the major tournaments in Europe, and their skill enables them to take home far more than a normal share of the cash prizes.

JOINT CHIEFS BACK REAGAN'S MX PLAN
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff today unanimously supported President Reagan's proposal to base 100 MX missiles in existing silos and to step up research on a smaller and more deceptive missile that could be deployed in the next decade.

title: U.S. INTEREST RATES UP A BIT
description: Short- and long-term interest rates rose slightly yesterday amid continued quiet trading of Treasury issues, securities dealers said. Although many analysts expect that interest rates might fall later this year, such forecasts have not been enough to raise prices and reduce yields of Treasury securities in recent days. The price of the closely watched 10 3/8 percent bonds due in 2012, for example, fell more than half a point yesterday, to an offering price of 98 18/32 and a yield of 10.53 percent. Late last week, the long-term Treasury bond was traded close to its peak price of 100 1/2 set early last November.

The arrival was to be a signal to all co-hearts, those at the station and their sisters on the train, that the three-day Romantic Book Lovers Conference had begun.

title: The Power To Propose
description: The irony of the Trilateral Commission is that its name became a dirty word on two continents for opposite reasons. In the United States, right-wingers saw a subversive, practically Communist conspiracy for world domination in David Rockefeller's effort to bring people of influence from the United States, Europe and Japan together to discuss key issues. In Europe, leftists saw in it a conspiracy to impose ''monopoly capitalism'' on the world.

description: ''A few years ago,I was taking a taxi downtown after playing in Harlem,'' the bandleader Gunter Hampel said the other day, ''and the driver asked me what I was doing here. When I told him, he said: 'You have a nice life. You go around playing music, and you make people happy.' ''

title: Money Fund Assets Fall

description: One of two bodies dug up on Staten Island was identified today as that of a 17-year-old Brick Township girl who disappeared on Halloween night in 1981, and the Monmouth County Prosecutor said he would seek a murder indictment in the case.

title: NEW MUSIC AT ITS BEST, REFINED TO RAUCOUS
description: NEW YORK being the cultural center it is, many weekends during the season offer a bubbling variety of contemporary-music concerts, but this weekend seems hyperkinetically active. Composers and performers can be found purveying music that reaches from the most refined products of an ''uptown,'' complex sensibility to the meditative or abrasive effusions of the downtowners, from mainstream 20th-century European masters to eccentric Americans, from earnest academics to musicians who used to play jazz but who now work in a style called ''music from the jazz tradition'' - which they rightly espouse as just as legitimate a form of contemporary composition as any other.

title: 2 WARNED OSSINING RIOT WAS 'IMMINENT'
description: Just months before the uprising at the state prison in Ossining, the prison's superintendent and a senior state correction official warned of the imminent danger of a riot by inmates at the facility.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS FALLS 74.4.%
description: Texas Instruments Inc., reporting a 74.4 percent drop in first-quarter net income, said today that declines in consumer products and geophysical operations along with higher operating costs in data systems had more than offset the strength in Government electronics.

title: ADVEST GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in January.

title: ASSAULTS UP 16 PERCENT IN CITY'S LOWER SCHOOLS
description: The number of assaults reported in New York City public elementary schools so far this school year is 16 percent higher than at the same time last year, a school official said yesterday.

title: COURT RESTRICTS SPEECH RIGHTS OF PUBLIC EMPLOYEES
description: The Supreme Court ruled Wednesday, 5 to 4, that the Constitution does not necessarily protect public employees against discharge for complaining about the management of the agency that employs them.

title: JERRICO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago share earnings were restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in March 1983.

title: POP JAZZ
description: COUNT BASIE's orchestra, which first played at the Savoy almost 50 years ago, will be back at the Savoy tonight and tomorrow. But the Savoy has changed. The name no longer designates the ballroom at Lenox Avenue and 141st Street known as ''the home of happy feet,'' where bands of all types, from Chick Webb and Duke Ellington to Guy Lombardo and Glenn Miller, played from 1926 to 1958. The current Savoy is a remodeled theater at 141 West 44th Street.

title: VERNITRON CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
REAGAN IS URGED NOT TO PUBLICIZE ARMS ACCUSATIONS AGAINST SOVIET
description: Two former Carter Administration officials and two Democratic senators said today in interviews that possible Soviet arms violations should be discussed through diplomatic channels. They said a public airing would risk disrupting the 1979 arms accord and current talks.

Profits Scoreboard
description: * See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year-earlier period.

description: * Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

description: b-Includes a gain of $335,000, or 2 cents a share, from a reduction of income tax reserves no longer required.

title: FOR NETS, A SEASON THAT SLIPPED AWAY
description: For 21 minutes of last night's second half, it was like old times for the Nets. They were playing the kind of defense that flattened foes earlier in the season - harassing shots and dominating the boards against the Knicks in the second contest of their two-of-three game series. On the other end of the court, they were fluid and confident. Indeed, they seemed to be in the midst of accomplishing an outstanding playoff comeback.

title: Poems Set to Jazz
description: Settings of William Blake's poems by the British jazz composer Mike Westbrook will be presented on Sunday at 9 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue and 54th Street.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANCORP (SPOKANE, WASH) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: Thrown for a Loss
description: Jack Thompson, the backup quarterback for the Cincinnati Bengals, has lost his bid to become a free agent and jump to the Michigan Panthers of the United States Football League.

title: CROSS & TRECKER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BODOW NAMED WQXR CHIEF
description: Warren G. Bodow has been named president and general manager of WQXR-AM/FM, the radio stations of The New York Times. The appointment was announced yesterday by Charles Brakefield, president of The New York Times Company's broadcasting group.

title: LOWENSTEIN, M, CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 26.
EASTERN FACING DEFAULT
description: Eastern Airlines and its auditors said yesterday that unless the carrier's creditors agree to further modifications of existing loan agreements, Eastern ''anticipates it will be in default'' by next month.

title: SUSQUEHANNA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss after a tax credit of $765,000.

title: Pepsi Approves Syrup Change
description: Pepsico Inc. said that its Pepsi-Cola subsidiary had approved a 50 percent level of high-fructose corn syrup 55 for use in bottled and canned and premixed Pepsi-Cola and regular Pepsi Free. The change from 100 percent sucrose is expected to provide a cost saving in Pepsi-Cola's bottling system and allow the soft drink to become more competitive, a spokesman said.

title: MERRICK SEEKS DIVORCE, PROTECTION OF ESTATE
description: David Merrick, the Broadway producer, is recuperating from a stroke suffered on Feb. 13 and has petitioned the State Supreme Court in Manhattan to appoint a conservator to protect his interests.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including income of $2,660,000 from equity in earnings of other investments and a loss of $4 million on the sale of subsidiaries. c-Net income including income of $11,335,000 from equity in earnings of other investments, a gain of $16,926,000 on the sale of subsidiaries and a loss of $276,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been reclassified.

title: MULTIMEDIA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AIR PRODUCTS & CHEMICALS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest 6 months include a gain equal to 20 cents a share from the sale of tax credits and a charge equal to 8 cents a share related to workforce reduction costs. Year-ago 6 months results do not include a gain of $61,937,000, or $2.16 a share, for a change in accounting.

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIRST N H BANK reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The bank was formerly First Bancorp of New Hampshire Inc.

title: CARNIVORES FROM OUTER SPACE
description: ''THE DEADLY SPAWN,'' which opens today at the Cinerama and other theaters, is an amateurish, resolutely unscary, low-budget horror film about people-eating creatures -looking like tadpoles with teeth - that have ridden to earth on a meteorite. The film may possibly be justified as a metaphor for suburban life in New Jersey, where it was shot.

title: Bidding Perks Goodbye, Even for the Boss
description: Penny-pinching in his new job as chairman and president of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, William Stern has given back six cars to the General Services Administration.

title: UNION PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results include the operations of Missouri Pacific and Western Pacific Railroads acquired in December 1982.

title: MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES INC (ST LOUIS, MO) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DURABLES ORDERS UP IN MARCH
description: Orders to factories for durable goods edged up three-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported today. Increases for military hardware, machinery and household goods outweighed declines for the transportation industries and primary metals.

title: U.S. CHARGES NINE IN KLAN INCIDENT
description: A Federal grand jury today indicted six present or former Ku Klux Klansmen and three American Nazi Party members on charges stemming from an anti-Klan rally in Greensboro, N.C., in 1979 at which five demonstrators were shot to death.

title: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TOP SALVADORAN REBEL CHIEF DIES IN MYSTERY
description: The senior commander of El Salvador's guerrilla forces, Salvador Cayetano Carpio, died last week in Managua, according to Salvadoran guerrilla and Nicaraguan Government reports.

title: German Stocks Up
description: The 100-share index of the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung rose today to a record 315.97, up 3.97 from Wednesday and surpassing the previous record set on Tuesday of 313.25 points. The Commerzbank index of 60 shares rose 10.3 points, to 947.4, the highest since June 9, 1961.

title: EASCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results include operations of K-D Tools since its acquisition on Jan. 28, 1982.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball

title: CONTINENTAL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JOBS BILL? HA!
description: Congress has just enacted an emergency jobs bill to deal with unemployment caused by the recession. While it contained more than $4 billion in public-works and miscellaneous pork-barrel projects, only $255 million in job-training funds were included. A public-works bill? Certainly. A recession-relief bill? Perhaps. A jobs bill? Not by any rational standard.

title: Mutual Funds Set a Record
description: Net sales of mutual funds totaled a record $2.8 billion in March, up from $1.75 billion in February, the Investment Company Institute said today.

title: FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S. FILES A SUIT WITH CALIFORNIA OVER WASTE SITE
description: The United States Government and the State of California filed suit today in Federal District Court here to force operators and major users of the Stringfellow Acid Pits hazardous waste dump to pay as much as $40 million to clean up the site.

title: YANKEES DEFEAT METS AT SHEA
description: Manager Billy Martin made only one trip from the dugout last night as his Yankees won their 10th Mayor's Trophy game against the Mets, 4-1, at Shea Stadium. Martin said he had nothing but thanks for the substitute umpires on hand and he wasn't about to castigate them.

title: South Africans to Review Interracial Sex Laws
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha said today that he would allow a special commission to study whether South Africa should drop its laws outlawing marriage and sexual relations between people of different races.

title: MERCHANTS BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
POE & ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes income of $17,000 from discontinued operations. c-Includes income of $44,000 from discontinued operations.

title: COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Meyer Files Suit
description: Tom Meyer, who was dismissed last Saturday as basketball coach at the University of Illinois-Chicago Circle, filed suit yesterday against the school in an effort to regain the job he held since 1977.

title: PROPER AID TO SOMALIA
description: The House Subcommittee on Foreign Operations plans to hold hearings Tuesday on proposed economic and military aid appropriations to Somalia. The Administration hopes to grant President Mohammed Siad Barre's regime $93 million for fiscal 1984. The subcommittee ought to examine the aid package - its direction, effectiveness and the alternatives.

title: Ex-N.B.A. Player Given 90 Days
description: Jimmy Walker, a former college and pro basketball player, was sentenced today to 90 days in prison on charges of failing to file Federal income tax returns.

title: MCI-Hughes Link
description: The MCI Communications Corporation and subsidiaries of Hughes Communications Inc. announced that MCI had purchased 24 transponders on Hughes's Galaxy Satellite System for an undisclosed amount.

title: UNION PACIFIC NET RISES 30.2%
description: The Union Pacific Corporation and the Southern Pacific Company reported yesterday that profits for the first quarter rose from levels a year earlier. The smaller Consolidated Rail Corporation, known as Conrail, reported net income of $12.6 million, for its first profitable first quarter in seven years.

title: DONALD S. LESLIE SR., 88, DEAD
description: Donald S. Leslie Sr., retired chairman and chief executive officer of the Hammermill Paper Company, died April 12 at Hamot Hospital in Erie, Pa. He was 88 years old.

title: NEWELL COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIRST NATIONAL STATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Court Backs Newspapers On Joint Operations
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the Newspaper Preservation Act, which permits competing papers to enter into joint operating arrangements without violating the antitrust laws.

title: Study Urges U.S. Not to Link Cuban Issue to Namibia Talks
description: A coalition of religious, labor and civil rights groups urged the United States today to remove the issue of the Cuban presence in Angola from negotiations on independence for South-West Africa.

title: PUBLISHING: THE COMPUTER SOFTWARE RACE IS ON
description: ON the basis of a 12-page proposal, John Brockman Associates had scheduled an auction yesterday for ''The Whole Software Catalog'' by Stewart Brand, editor of the best selling ''Whole Earth Catalog.'' ''But we never held the auction because Doubleday came in with a preemptive bid of $1.3 million for the trade paperback rights,'' said Mr. Brockman, whose literary agency recently began representing software authors and publishers.

title: ALL KINDS OF PLACES TO BIKE, IN TOWN AND IN THE SUBURBS
description: PUMP those tires, check those chains, shine those spokes until they sparkle - this is the time of year when bicycling becomes contagious for everyone from competition-class cyclists to those who only wobble and weave. This weekend, the clicking of gears and the squealing of hand brakes will be heard almost everywhere, with a 17,000-cyclist, five-borough bike tour scheduled for the city and several smaller organized journeys planned for nearby bikeways.

title: MINERALS ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for year to Dec 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: MAYTAG CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Renaissance Fair
description: Music, dance and crafts from the Renaissance will be featured on Sunday at the third outdoor Renaissance Fair at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University, Northern Boulevard, Greenvale, N.Y. There will also be jousting matches, magic shows and food.

title: NEWHALL LAND & FARMING CO reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes income from asset distribution of $1,372,000 for the quarter and $6,646,000 for the year. c-After a loss from asset distribution of $193,000 for the quarter and income of $4,252,000 asset distribution for the year.

title: 19 ENTERED IN 2-DIVISION WOOD MEMORIAL
description: As expected, horses are coming out of the woodwork for the Wood Memorial. There were 19 names in the entry box this morning for tomorrow's race, a Kentucky Derby prep, so Aqueduct split the race into two divisions and put up an additional $150,000 to match the purse.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
AT THE MOVIES
description: ''NEXT Monday, Sonny Landham begins work in Arizona on a movie called ''Fear and a Handful of Dust,'' in which he plays a Vietnam veteran, an Indian accused of murder. Mr. Landham is himself part Indian, and a veteran. And he believes the Army's foot-dragging about sending him to Officer Candidate School probably saved his life. ''I'd have been right there in the middle of Vietnam, and I'd have wanted to be there. But I realized I wasn't one for chains of command, talking to one dummy who sends you to another dummy, so I didn't re-enlist. When I got out in 1964, I was still subject to the draft, but I'd already served; they wouldn't have drafted me until eight people after Ladybird Johnson.''

title: VULCAN MATERIALS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: USAIR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
