title: A BLEND REFLECTED IN LIGHT AND SHADOW$: JACKIE PRESSER
description: Jackie Presser, the new president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, seems a fascinating blend of a man.

title: PRESIDENT OF HARVARD BRANDS LEGAL SYSTEM COSTLY AND COMPLEX
description: Derek C. Bok, the president of Harvard University, assailed the American legal system yesterday, calling it ''among the most expensive and least efficient in the world.'' He said law schools bear part of the blame.

title: KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a writedown for an estimated net realized value of shareholdings resulting in a non-recurring charge of $1,454,000.

title: American Ship Building Names New Top Officer
description: George M. Steinbrenner 3d, chairman of the American Ship Building Company, has announced that George A. Chandler will be elected president and chief executive.

title: PACCAR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STERLING DRUG INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RANGERS CONFUSED BY ROUT IN GAME 5
description: The Islanders have two chances to finish off the Rangers in their Patrick Division playoff series. The Rangers have run out of margin for error. They must win Game 6 tonight at Madison Square Garden, or the series is over.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Talks on Bases in Greece
description: Greek and United States negotiators resumed talks on the future of American bases in Greece today after a three-day interruption, a Government spokesman said.

title: AMERICAN BUSINESS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Auerbach May Retire
description: Red Auerbach confirmed last night that he was considering his retirement as the general manager of the Boston Celtics, a position he has held more than 30 years.

title: HAMLETS IN SOUTHERN WYOMING FEAR ISOLATION AFTER AMTRAK SHIFTS A ROUTE
description: It was the railroad that created the towns of southern Wyoming, way stations for travelers and trainmen as the nation's first transcontinental rail route rolled west over the state's low mountain passes and vast treeless plains.

title: NORTHERN TELECOM LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $7,600,000. The year-ago results were restated to conform with a new policy on foreign currency translation adopted by the Canadian Institute of Chartered Accountants, the company said.

title: 'TO BEGIN AGAIN'
description: THE winner of this year's Academy Award as Best Foreign Film, Jose Luis Garci's ''To Begin Again,'' was clearly the sentimental favorite. It tells of a gentle, decent, distinguished man who, as is made known during the course of the story, is also dying. Just after having received the Nobel Prize for Literature, he returns to his native Spain, where he has not been since the Civil War, to visit with a boyhood friend, rekindle a romance with an old sweetheart, and generally retrace his past. Though the film seems to be building toward a four-hanky ending, it concludes on a more reserved, contemplative note of quiet resignation.

title: TENNANT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ALAGASCO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect the reclassification of nonutility revenues and the resolution of a rate case recorded in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1982.

title: All-Season Jets
description: Football has become a four-season sport for the Jets. The team, which played last summer, fall and winter, will now stage three spring minicamps.

title: FRIDAY, APRIL 22, 1983
description: The Economy

title: BRAZIL AND LIBYANS ARE SAID TO DISCUSS UNLOADING OF PLANES
description: Brazilian officials and Libyan diplomats reportedly discussed procedures today for unloading four Libyan cargo planes being held by Brazil after they were found to be carrying arms and explosives destined for Nicaragua.

title: EQUIMARK CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a $440,000 tax credit. There were no per share earnings in the first quarter of 1983 due to preferred dividend requirements.

title: PROGROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
Islander Rings Seldom Worn
description: The Islanders wear their Stanley Cup rings proudly, but not often. ''I know I've only worn mine a few days here and there,'' said Bill Torrey, the club's president and general manager who has directed the Islanders to three consecutive National Hockey League championships.

title: NORTHWEST, SEDCO SEEK 51% OF POGO
description: Northwest Industries and Sedco Inc. said today that they planned to make a tender offer at $25 a share for about 26 percent, or 6.25 million common shares, of the Pogo Producing Company.

title: HEILEMAN,G, BREWING reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Times Mirror Plans Videotex
description: The Times Mirror Company said that it plans to start a commercial videotex service in the greater Los Angeles area in the second quarter of 1984.

title: OLD STONE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $978,000 for the latest quarter against $485,000 for the year-ago period.

title: EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $4,646,000 from disEcontinued operations.

title: Economic Scene; Seattle Looks For Its Future
description: THIS beautiful city is stretching and yawning in the bright spring sunshine - and starting to wake up from the deep recession. In front of the Pike Place Market on the waterfront, a crowd gathers to watch a young woman prancing and kicking up her heels in an improvised dance that goes on and on - sunshine and springtime are especially exhilarating to Seattle, used to melancholy skies and too much rain.

title: 100 Killed in Battles In the Peruvian Andes
description: At least 100 people were killed today in a clash between Maoist guerrillas and Indian peasants in the Peruvian Andes, the police said.

title: SINGER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a benefit of $1,100,000, or 6 cents a share, resulting from a gain on Singer's repurchase of its bonds with funds obtained from the sale of a division.

title: UNITED STATES GYPSUM CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Reliance Group
description: The Reliance Group Holdings of New York said said it had ''decided not to proceed with the proposed purchase of approximately 11,000 apartment units in Toronto, Canada.'' The company said that a study completed this week determined that a transaction would not be able to be completed on a basis consistent with its investment objectives or timing requirements.

title: MEDIQ INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations and nonrecurring items of $174,000 for the quarter and $204,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations and nonrecurring items of $842,000 for the quarter and $849,000 for the 6 months. The year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April 1983.

title: STAGE: 'WINNERS' AT THE ROUNDABOUT
description: THE ROUNDABOUT THEATER, our foremost specialist in reviving forgotten and half remembered 20th-century English plays, has now, quite fittingly, turned its attention to the contemporary Irish playwright Brian Friel. Here is a writer overdue for a serious restoration. Perhaps because most of his plays have been commercial failures on Broadway, his lyrical and at times innovative theatrical sensibility is not nearly as well known in New York as it should be. The mouth waters at the prospect of seeing first-class revivals of such major Friel works as ''Philadelphia, Here I Come!'' (his one unqualified Broadway success, in 1966) and ''The Faith Healer'' (a flop in 1979).

title: WASHINGTON IRVING GALA
description: The mist seeped through the dense gray woods, furling around him as he strode along a slight rise. This soon gave way to level ground and then to a hollow, lying sleepy and shrouded below him. A contagious air appeared to grip the man, infecting him with memories of settings for tales in years to come.

title: Latin Peace Meeting Makes Little Progress
description: A meeting in Panama of the foreign ministers of five Central American and four regional nations has made ''little progress'' in efforts to arrange a negotiated settlement to the widening conflicts in the area, diplomats say.

title: Friday; PUCK ERA ON DISPLAY
description: The Puck Building in SoHo, a Romanesque Revival landmark named after the satiric weekly that was published there, is celebrating its recent restoraFrom Puck 1876-1918: Puck Magazine's Profile of an Era.'' More than 200 lithographs and original drawings from the defunct publication will be on display through Aug. 28 - caricatures of Mark Twain and Thomas Edison, for instance, and cartoon assaults on Tammany Hall politicians, candidates for President, monopolists and overcrowded public transportation. The show is on the second floor of 295 Lafayette Street, at the corner of East Houston Street, and is open from noon to 5 P.M. Thursdays through Sundays. There is no admission charge. JUILLIARD THEATER OPENS

title: Avalanche of Queries About Benefits
description: City employees, present and retired, are swamping the Employee Health Benefits Program offices with phone calls and even personal visits - ''six to seven hundred visitors a day,'' Nelson E. Carpenter, the office's director, said yesterday.

title: LA MAUR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PANCHO'S MEXICAN BUFFET reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Dr. Lawrence Perry, 75, Dies; Ex-Fine Arts Dean at Hunter
description: Dr. Lawrence Perry, formerly a dean of the School of Fine Arts at Hunter College and a music professor at Hunter, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in New Canaan, Conn. He was 75 years old.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Coming attractions for 1983-84 season, musically speaking
description: NOWHERE does hope spring more eternal than on Broadway. The theater industry thrives on the expectation that there is always next year - and next year is already beginning to take shape, musically speaking. Angela Lansbury will soon go into rehearsal for her return in ''Mame,'' Anthony Quinn is touring in a Broadway-bound revival of ''Zorba'' and the first big new musical of the 1983-84 season, ''La Cage Aux Folles,'' went into rehearsal this week.

title: Hu Na Plans Career
description: Her campaign to win asylum in the United States kept Hu Na off the tennis court more than she liked.

title: Chargers Seek Deal In Pursuit of Elway
description: The San Francisco 49ers and San Diego Chargers are close to completing a trade that would give the Chargers the 49ers' firstround choice in Tuesday's National Football League draft for the Chargers' two picks in the second round.

title: STERLING BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The law may seem enlightened and humane, but its constant stream of rules will leave a wake strewn with the disappointed hopes of those who find the legal system too complicated to understand, too quixotic to command respect and too expensive to be of much practical use.'' - Derek C. Bok, president of Harvard University. (A1:6.)

title: CONVICTED KILLER IS FOUND GUILTY IN GUARD DEATH
description: A man imprisoned for two murders and an abduction was found guilty today in State Supreme Court here of strangling a guard at Green Haven State Prison in 1981.

title: LIBERTY UNITED BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The additional number of outstanding shares is a result of shares issued to effect merger with United Kentucky Inc. in December 1982.

title: DOW TOPS 1,200, ENDS DOWN 3.20
description: Stock prices fell yesterday after late selling by nervous investors. The Dow Jones industrial average, which is made up of 30 prominent companies, closed down 3.20 points, to 1,188.27, after briefly setting a new high of 1,202.11 early in the day. Broader market averages also slipped.

title: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI'S 'TRAVIATA'
description: OPERA does not transfer easily to the screen. When it is done more or less straight, as a stage production recorded on film, it tends to look like a gigantic, somewhat clumsy marionette show, no matter how fine the voices. Not much more successful have been attempts to make opera cinematic by placing it in recognizable landscapes, played by nonsinging actors from whose bodies enormous voices magically flow without apparent physical effort.

title: Bar to Rail Strike Extended in Jersey
description: A Federal court order barring a new strike by conductors against nine commuter rail lines in New Jersey was extended today until a special three-judge panel in Washington rules on a union dispute over seniority work rules. Hearings are scheduled for Tuesday.

title: Topics; Matters of Shelter; Still Waiting
description: Standing in a bus-stop shelter at Third and 55th the other day, we wondered why three buses went by without stopping. After the third one passed us up, we noticed a faint printed paper sign on the wall; it said the bus doesn't stop here any more.

title: MEM CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CHRYSLER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $239 million from the sale of Chrysler Defense Inc.

title: 'EXPOSED'
description: THE title of James Toback's ''Exposed'' suggests sensationalism, a quality the film simultaneously attempts and disdains. International terrorism, fashion modeling and the attention-getting casting of Rudolf Nureyev and Nastassia Kinski are the film's most noticeable ingredients, yet it affects such insouciance that these elements are never fully exploited.

title: HOWARD G. GAMSER, A FORMER CHAIRMAN OF MEDIATION BOARD
description: Howard G. Gamser, a New York lawyer who became chairman of the National Mediation Board, died of pneumonia Wednesday at George Washington University Hospital, Washington. He was 64 years old and lived in Georgetown, Va.

title: United in Purpose
description: To try to persuade Americans that Irishmen of varying persuasions can get along, the Lord Mayors of Dublin in the Irish Republic and of Belfast in Northern Ireland started a tandem tour of the United States yesterday. They began with a visit to their New York City counterpart, Mayor Koch.

title: Partisan in the Parks
description: For James Watt, Morris Udall once gibed, a wilderness is a parking lot with no yellow lines. The Interior Secretary invites such acid comments with his own divisive rhetoric. When he foolishly criticized the Beach Boys, the President himself, one of their fans, made him swallow his words. But Mr. Watt's capricious management of the national park system has so far gone uncorrected.

title: BLASSPORT: NEAT AND CASUAL FOR BOTH DAY AND NIGHT
description: Blassport, the sportswear arm of Bill Blass's fashion operation, turned out to be one of the most satisfactory collections of the first week of New York fall openings. The mood seemed exactly right for today's living: neat, light and sufficiently casual. The clothes were hardly restricted to leisure daytime wear - they moved deftly into evening with some of the most contemporary-looking styles for dinner and after.

title: ARIZONA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

description: Bryan Little drove in two runs with two doubles to lead the Montreal Expos to a 6-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals today.

Richard Turner, now dean of the faculty of arts and sciences at N.Y.U., at a better moment for the art-historical institution. According to a recent survey published by the Conference Board of American Research Councils, the institute has a better reputation among scholars in the field than any other art-history graduate school in the country.

title: Fannie Mae Set to Offer $800 Million Debt Issues
description: The Federal National Mortgage Assocation, known as Fannie Mae, said yesterday that its new $500 million issue of debentures due February 1988 would be offered today at a price of 100 with a stated interest rate of 10.3 percent, while a $300 million issue due May 10, 1990, would be offered at 100 with a stated interest rate of 10.75 percent.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
35 Die in Indian Bus Blaze
description: A crowded bus traveling in hill country in southern India lost its brakes, plunged down a ravine and burst into flames today, killing at least 35 passengers and injuring 50, the Press Trust of India said. The bus was traveling from Kottayam on the southwest coast of India toward the interior of Kerala State, about 1,260 miles south of New Delhi.

title: Bid for Conrail Is Advanced
description: Employees of Conrail took another step yesterday in their efforts to purchase the railroad from the Federal Government.

DEMOCRATS SETTLE ON SAN FRANCISCO OVER CHICAGO FOR 1984 CONVENTION
description: The Democrats decided today to hold their 1984 national convention in San Francisco, heading for Ronald Reagan's home state to pick the candidate they hope will replace the incumbent in the White House.

title: CBS IS TOLD TO GIVE WESTMORELAND INTERNAL STUDY ON VIETNAM REPORT
description: A Federal District judge ordered CBS News yesterday to give Gen. William C. Westmoreland the text of its investigation into a television documentary that charged that the General had conspired to falsify figures on enemy troop strength in Vietnam.

title: MAYOR CONCEDES USING 'INTUITION' IN CLAIM ON JOBS
description: Mayor Koch, who said on Tuesday that it was ''a fact'' that he had hired a higher percentage of black and Hispanic people than his commissioners, conceded yesterday that his claim was based on ''intuition'' and not statistics. He said he did not have statistics when he made the earlier statements and did not have them now.

title: Armonk Antiques Show
description: More than 50 antiques dealers from the three-state area will display their wares this weekend at the sixth Armonk Antiques Show at the Byram Hills High School, Tripp Lane, Armonk, N.Y. Among the items at the show will be turn-of-the-century wicker furniture and copper engravings from the early 1800's.

title: NBI INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Nuggets Even Series
description: Kiki Vandeweghe scored 26 points and Dan Issel got 25 to lead the Denver Nuggets to a 113-99 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight, squaring their Western Conference series at one victory apiece.

title: Jury Convicts Man In 1981 Killing
description: Despite testimony by the only defense witness that he, not the defendant, committed the murder, a jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday found the defendant guilty of a 1981 slaying in East Harlem.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Robert C. Roebling, 78, Dies; Georgia Prize Cattle Breeder
description: Robert C. Roebling, philanthropist, prize cattle breeder and the great grandson of John A. Roebling, the designer of the Brooklyn Bridge, died Monday at Candler General Hospital in Savannah, Ga. He was 78 years old.

title: SENATE VOTES, 91-5, A DELAY IN PAYING WITHHOLDING TAX
description: The Senate, ending more than a month of contention, approved a compromise today that would postpone tax withholding from interest income and dividends for at least four years. The vote was 91 to 5.

Reagan Meets E.E.C. Chief
description: President Reagan, stepping up preparations for the Williamsburg economic meeting next month, conferred today with Gaston E. Thorn, President of the European Economic Community, and pledged to make ''urgent efforts'' to resolve differences with Europe on trade.

description: Citicorp said that it had acquired four million shares of its common stock, for $166 million, in open-market transactions and that the repurchase program announced Feb. 15 had been completed. Citicorp purchased the shares with part of the $390 million proceeds of a four-million-share offering of $100 liquidation value adjustablerate preferred stock sold in February. The remainder of the proceeds of the issue have been added to the corporation's equity capital, which totaled $5.2 billion at the end of March.

description: Excerpts from an April 18 colloquy on the Senate floor on the diversity of West Virginia: Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia: I am glad I am from a state that had split loyalties during the Civil War. Part of it is above the Mason-Dixon line, part of it is south.

The 1982 figure included an extraordinary gain of $19.9 million from the exchange of Alcoa stock for sinking fund debentures.

Suspect Arrested In Uptown Slaying
description: A 26-year-old man was arrested yesterday for the fatal shooting Sunday night of Eli Wechsler, a toy importer, in the elevator of Mr. Wechsler's apartment building at 570 Fort Washington Avenue in Washington Heights, the police said.

title: QUAKER STATE OIL REFINING CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Marathon Trips
description: Mike Kasser has done some intriguing things, but last week's international caper was a personal best. It began four weeks ago when the 42-year-old Off Broadway producer learned that the London Marathon would be April 17, the same time he would be there on theater business.

title: REYNOLDS, R J, INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results for 1983 include the operations of Heublein Inc. acquired in October 1982.

title: Odyssey Partners
description: Odyssey Partners said a Federal court in New York had rejected an attempt by the Trans World Corporation to prevent Odyssey from presenting its proposal at the annual meeting of stockholders on April 27. The court also refused to enjoin Odyssey from soliciting or voting proxies for its proposal, which calls for the separation of Trans World's diverse businesses.

title: DOCKING CANCELED FOR SOVIET CRAFT
description: The docking of the Soviet Soyuz T-8 spacecraft with the Salyut 7 space station has been canceled, Moscow radio reported early today.

title: 'BANKING ON THE BRINK,' REPORT ON PROBLEM LOANS
description: ''NBC REPORTS'' looks at the banking industry tonight and finds it distressed, caught in problems of its own making. Banks, NBC finds, are in flux, searching for higher and higher profits and often acting imprudently while they search. The provocative program, ''Banking on the Brink,'' will be seen on Channel 4 at 10 P.M.

title: 5 FIREMEN HURT IN A SMOKY FIRE AT 25 BROADWAY
description: Five firemen were injured and 800 office workers were evacuated yesterday afternoon when a suspicious three-alarm fire broke out in an unoccupied storage room on the sixth floor of a 22-story building in the heart of the financial district.

title: SALVADOR'S ABILITY TO WIN DOUBTED IN REPORT
description: Senior United States military commanders concluded two years ago that even with increased military assistance from the United States the Salvadoran military as then constituted could not defeat opposition guerrilla forces, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: REAGAN BACKS MEDICAL HELP FOR UNEMPLOYED, WITH RESTRICTION
description: President Reagan today approved a fivepoint program of medical assistance for unemployed workers, but he insisted that there could be no Federal outlays for the program without new tax revenue, according to Administration officials.

title: LEAR SIEGLER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
An Act of Charity
description: Three years ago, while making a celebrity guest appearance on Long Island, Marty Lyons, the Jet defensive tackle, met a 3-year-old boy suffering from advanced leukemia. In the months that followed, Lyons spent time with the youngster, whose eventual death had a powerful impact on the football player. Now, as a kind of a memorial to that friendship, Lyons has started the Marty Lyons Foundation, which will try to satisfy the ''special wishes'' of terminally ill youngsters on Long Island.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: OPENED eight years ago, Chez Pascal remains one of the city's most consistently fashionable and popular French restaurants. Tucked away in a town house on 82d Street between Lexington and Third Avenues, the setting is graceful, intimate and stylish, with soft lighting and old shutters accenting natural rose-brick walls. Some tables are cramped and noisy, but most are comfortable. A recent improvement is the handsome new second-floor dining room that is available for private parties.

title: DAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Like Jack, Like Jill
description: To celebrate her 16th birthday yesterday, Jill Kaenel decided to go horseback riding. That's something a lot of teen-age girls like to do, but, unlike most young horse lovers, Jill did her riding at Pimlico Race Course, and very well, too.

title: FINDING OF BANNED PESTICIDE SETS OFF INVESTIGATION
description: A termite-control pesticide banned in New York State since 1973 has been found at a chemical distributor on Long Island and offered for sale by another New York dealer, leading to an investigation by the state's Environmental Conservation Department.

title: ART: RENATO GUTTUSO
description: WITH the floodgates opened here by the success of neo-Expressionist figure painters from Italy, it was inevitable that someone would think of repackaging for New York the work of Renato Guttuso, a social realist who is one of Italy's left-wing cultural celebrities. Now 71 years old, Mr. Guttuso is known in his native country as a founder of the postwar movement called the New Art Front, which linked art with social concerns, as a member of the Italian Senate, as a recipient of the Lenin Peace Prize and as a painter whose political ideology has often showed in brash canvases not noted for subtlety in technique or subject matter.

title: Kotar Is Home From the Hospital
description: The former Giant running back Doug Kotar, hospitalized for nearly eight months because of an inoperable brain tumor, is now back home, where he is visited by physical therapists several times a week.

title: NATIONAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a gain of $10,500,000 from the sale of excess coal reserves in Illinois and an extraordinary gain of $9,400,000 from the exchange of treasury shares of common stock for outstanding mortgage bonds.

description: b-After a gain from accounting adjustment of $14,850,000.

description: A judge ordered the International Gold Bullion Exchange to cease business and gave it until Friday afternoon to voluntarily declare bankruptcy.

description: b-Net loss including an extraordinary credit of $183,000.

title: Attenborough Boycotts 'Gandhi' in South Africa
description: The Academy Award-winning movie ''Gandhi'' premiered Wednesday in South Africa, where Gandhi first tried out the passive resistance that eventually ended British colonial rule in his native India.

title: DATA DIMENSIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including net income of $1,400 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $469,200 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations.

title: 'The Little Guy'
description: Larry Brown is gone as coach of the Nets, now at the University of Kansas. But Hubie Brown, the coach of the Knicks, found time Wednesday night after the Knicks had beaten the Nets in the opener of their playoff series, to stir the ashes of a longstanding feud.

title: WHAT THE REAGAN ADMINISTRATION HAS DONE FOR THE HUNGRY
description: To the Editor:

title: SHERWIN-WILLIAMS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an after-tax gain of $702,000, or 4 cents a share, from the sale of property. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid March 1983.

title: RURAL OFFICIALS STRIKE BACK AT WOOD THIEVES
description: There is a lust for wood in these parts that sometimes carries a man outside the law. With the proliferation of wood stoves and the rising price of wood to stoke them, law enforcement authorities here and elsewhere in the rural areas of New Jersey, New York and Connecticut are encountering a new brand of outlaw - the wood rustler.

title: Condemned Man Given 24-Hour Stay by Judge
description: The condemned murderer John Louis Evans 3d tonight won a stay of execution for 24 hours after his attorneys made an 11th-hour plea to a Federal judge in Mobile, prison officials said.

title: The Good News About Busing
description: American society may now accept the need for school desegregation, but neither blacks nor whites are enthusiastic about busing as a way to accomplish it. Whites in many areas continue to resist out of racism and fears that busing students will erode the quality of education. Many black communities have grown more interested in the possibilities for developing neighborhood schools.

title: CONTINENTAL BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The results were restated for the merger with York Bancorp consummated on March 18 and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: U.S. AIDES SEE NEED FOR BIG EFFORT TO AVERT REBEL VICTORY IN SALVADOR
description: A range of Administration officials say the United States must make a sustained, increased effort in El Salvador or lose the war to the guerrillas.

title: DRIVING OUT TENANTS IS REPORTED SPREADING
description: Harassment of low- and middle-income tenants by landlords seeking to empty their buildings has increased in the last two years, according to the Manhattan District Attorney. His office has set up a special unit to deal with the problem.

title: City Won't Extend Trash Pickup Fees
description: Thomas J. Cuite, the City Council majority leader, yesterday announced cancellation of a plan to make nonprofit institutions pay for garbage pickups.

title: 16 HANOI SOLDIERS KILLED, CHINA SAYS
description: China announced today that its frontier guards had killed 16 Vietnamese soldiers in clashes Wednesday along the border of Yunnan Province.

title: HYBRITECH INC reports earnings for qtr to April 1.
INTER-REGIONAL FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 25.
SENATE PANEL CLEARS COMPROMISE BILL ON CABLE TV
description: The Senate Commerce Committee approved compromise legislation today that restricts the power of local governments to regulate cable television but also gives the cities explicit authority to grant franchises and negotiate cable services.

title: Goodyear Rating Is Raised by S.& P.
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said it had raised its rating for senior debt of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Corporation to A-, from BBB, and affirmed the company's A-2 commercial paper ratings.

title: WEYERHAEUSER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a gain of $45,106,000 from the net effect of an accounting change.

title: TOP P.L.O. OFFICIALS ARE MEETING IN TUNIS ON RIFT WITH JORDAN
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, opened a meeting today of the P.L.O. executive committee that will focus mainly on Palestinian-Jordanian relations, a P.L.O. spokesman said.

title: Italy's Socialists Seek To Bring Down Fanfani
description: The leader of Italy's Socialist Party, Bettino Craxi, will call for early general elections on Friday, setting the stage for the collapse of Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani's four-party coalition, political officials said today.

title: MUSIC: TAPED STUDIO WORKS
description: AS part of the Britain Salutes New York festival, the Electro-Acoustic Music Association of Great Britain sent the composer Stephen Montague to the Experimental Intermedia Foundation with two evenings' worth of works on tape. All of the pieces were created in the recording studio.

title: BOURNE'S GOAL FROM THE PAST
description: It was such a beautiful play, mixing sheer athletic ability and skating skill, that the players did not equate it with anything in their professional careers.

title: BURT E. LANPHER
description: Burt E. Lanpher, secretary-treasurer of the Staff Officers Association of America, ship pursers union, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Cliffside Park, N.J. He was 62 years old.

title: ART: STANLEY SPENCER
description: IN the England of the 1920's and 30's there were two painters, and two only, who caught the imagination of the mass public. One was Augustus John, who at the time carried all before him by reason of his wit, his flamboyant personal beauty, his apparently unlimited success with beautiful women and the dash and bravura of his formal portraiture.

title: 6 EX-LABOR SECRETARIES URGE JOB BILL
description: Six former Secretaries of Labor have urged President Reagan to rearrange his priorities and initiate a ''substantial'' job program that would require ''a large expenditure of public funds.''

title: TIDWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

description: Investors in bonds for two abandoned nuclear power plants financed through the Washington Public Power Supply System may have received a psychological lift this week when several utilities indicated a willingness to pay overdue bills. But the development did little to improve the supply system's deteriorating financial condition.

title: EQUITABLE BANCORPORATION (BALTIMORE, MD) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

description: Nobody has seen such flamboyant white scarves with acting to match since Snoopy played out his Red Baron fantasies on top of the doghouse. Stephen Moore almost instantly achieves the same effect on Broadway.

title: CITY HOUSING PARTNERSHIP GETS MARKETING SPECIALIST
description: Alvin Preiss, a New York City-based real estate consultant, has directed marketing campaigns for numerous residential developments geared both to the upper middle class and the very wealthy.

Nicklaus's 65 Leads by 2
description: Jack Nicklaus, whose ailing back forced him to withdraw from the Masters two weeks ago, shot his best round of the year, a 7-under-par 65, and took a two-stroke lead after the first round of the $400,000 Tournament of Champions today.

3 SOVIET DIPLOMATS ARE OUSTED BY U.S. IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday announced the expulsion of three Soviet diplomats as spies. One was a military attache at the Soviet Embassy who was reportedly caught in the act of retrieving what he thought were stolen American military secrets from the base of a tree in rural Maryland.

title: Children in Need Of Love and Parents
description: Lorenzo, 8 years old, is smart, has difficulty with his peers and needs weekly therapy. Christine, 12 years old, is shy but sings in her school choir.

title: CHEMICAL INDUSTRY'S INFLUENCE IS STUDIED
description: A House subcommittee is investigating whether the Dow Chemical Company and the Chemical Manufacturers Association, with help from the Environmental Protection Agency, were able to bypass regular channels and exert improper influence on the United States position on the international marketing of toxic chemicals.

title: ALLEGHANY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: Production Of Cars Dips
description: Domestic auto makers are curtailing car production slightly this week compared with last week, an industry trade journal reported today.

title: EVANS PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a net loss of $6,868,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Chock Full o'Nuts Selects a President
description: The Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation, which has been seeking a president, announced yesterday that it had found one. He is Gordon M. Garrett, who has been serving as vice president for marketing at the Eckerd Drug Company, a national drugstore chain.

title: SOME JEWS QUIT WARSAW CEREMONIES AFTER A WEEK
description: Representatives of the World Jewish Congress said today that they would not participate further in the 40th anniversary commemoration of the Warsaw ghetto uprising against the Nazis. A spokesman said they had been subjected to ''a week of provocation and manipulation.''

title: ALLEN ORGAN CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago share earnings reflects a 3 percent stock dividend paid in March 1983.

title: WAVETEK CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: The year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid March 1983.

title: 'Teaneck Tanzi' Closes
description: ''Teaneck Tanzi: The Venus Flytrap,'' the comedy by Claire Luckham, closed after Wednesday evening's performance at the Nederlander Theater. The two alternating pair of leading roles were played by Caitlin Clarke and Scott Renderer and Deborah Harry and Thomas G. Waites. The play, directed by Chris Bond, ran for 13 previews and two performances.

title: BRISTOL-MYERS UP
description: Schlumberger Ltd., citing the severe decline in oil well testing services, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of this year plunged 26.9 percent as revenues declined 11 percent.

title: Tribal rarities at Sotheby's
description: AMERICAN Indian quillwork, weaving and basketry are among the more important offerings next Friday in an auction of American Indian, African and Oceanic artworks at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street. Also of interest are a Tlingit dagger of copper and sheep horn from the Pacific Northwest and a Hawaiian necklace of hair and ivory. The items will go on view tomorrow, with the sales set for next Friday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. and Saturday at 10:15 A.M.

title: SEXUAL REPRESSION IN THE LAND OF THE KAMA SUTRA
description: It was just an obscure, two-paragraph item in the papers a few days ago. One Satya Singh was convicted and sentenced to a year's ''rigorous imprisonment'' and a fine of more than $100 for ''outraging the modesty of a girl by kissing her.''

title: ONE TAX RESISTER'S ANARCHISTIC ARGUMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: CONQUERING AIDS
description: Several years ago, healthy young men began to die in large numbers from an unknown disease. As so often happens in the history of medicine, the early cases were considered isolated extremes in the normal spectrum of an illness and there was, in retrospect, an inadequate appreciation by the health profession of a growing disaster. Slowly, but inexorably, the numbers afflicted grew and an insidious outbreak exploded into a frightening epidemic.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Miami Beach's Water Is Found Tainted
description: Miami Beach residents were told to boil their drinking water today after routine sampling of the supply turned up small amounts of possibly harmful bacteria, officials announced.

title: Strike Grows at Aqueduct
description: A strike by track and stable maintenance workers at Aqueduct spread yesterday to hundreds of other employees, sharply reducing betting revenues at the track and causing severe inconvenience to patrons.

title: STALEY, A E, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $3,736,000, or 16 cents a share, from a debt-for-equity swap.

description: Debt Issues

title: APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIVE PARTIES DISCUSSING NEW CAPITAL FOR SEAFIRST
description: The Seafirst Corporation has received no formal offers in its monthlong effort to raise $200 million in new capital, Richard P. Cooley, chairman and chief executive, said today.

title: Cigna Cuts Stake
description: The Cigna Corporation said it had lowered its stake in Paine Webber Inc. to 3.05 million shares, or 20.7 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Cigna reported that between March 16 and March 29, a subsidiary had sold 200,000 Paine Webber shares for approximately $48 a share. The transactions were made under an agreement with Paine Webber, it said.

title: WORLD AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: Results for the 1982 year reflect a nonrecurring gain of $4,100,000 from the sale of securities and property and the elimination of certain debts. Results for the 1981 year include a nonrecurring gain of $4,000,000 from the sale of property and the elimination of debt.

News Summary; FRIDAY, APRIL 22, 1983
description: International

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
RON KITTLE IS CHICAGO'S KIND OF ROOKIE
description: Despite his 50 home runs, Ron Kittle knew that he wasn't the most popular athlete in the town where he played baseball last year. The town was Edmonton, Alberta, and everybody knew who the most popular athlete was.

title: BUDGET ROLL-CALLS
description: Following are the roll-call votes by which the Senate Budget Committee today approved a measure sponsored by Senator Lawton Chiles, Democrat of Florida, to raise $30 billion in additional revenue in the 1984 fiscal year, and then a budget resolution calling for $848.8 billion in expenditures and $686.7 billion in revenue. FOR THE CHILES MEASURE - 13 Republicans - 4 Domenici, N.M. Kassebaum, Kan.

title: OHIO LEADER NAMED TEAMSTERS' CHIEF
description: Jackie Presser, an aggressive teamster leader from Ohio, was elected president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters today. He replaced Roy L. Williams, who was convicted in December on Federal fraud and bribery charges and resigned to avoid being sent to a Federal prison hospital.

title: State Powers, Nuclear Power
description: Regulating nuclear energy has long been the almost exclusive prerogative of the Federal Government. That commanding position has now been weakened by a deft challenge from the state of California. A decision by the U.S. Supreme Court Wednesday makes clear that Congress has given the states the right to say no to new plants, provided their objection is based on economic grounds, not radiation hazards.

title: COMSHARE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $248,600 for the quarter and 9 months on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $105,400 for the quarter and $399,100 for the 9 months.

SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

SHAPING RESPONSE TO THE 'MISTAKE' IN EL SALVADOR
description: On a recent trip to Nicaragua, Representative Clarence D. Long startled some local businessmen attending a luncheon at the United States Embassy. The Maryland Democrat asserted that American aid was overrated and that some nations prospered with less.

title: VOTES OF DEMOCRATS ENABLE DOMENICI TO FREE UP BUDGET
description: Disregarding a White House plea for delay, Pete V. Domenici, the Republican chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, formed a temporary alliance with the panel's Democratic minority today to break a weeklong impasse and send a draft budget resolution for 1984 to the Senate floor.

title: SOME C.I.A. DEAD GET ONLY A STAR
description: In an area full of monuments to the nation's heroes, one of the starkest and most mysterious is the memorial facade on the north wall of the foyer at the Central Intelligence Agency's headquarters in Langley, Va. It consists of 38 five-point stars chiseled into two marple slabs, in memory of C.I.A. officers killed in the line of duty.

title: AMERACE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $774,000 from discontinued operations and a loss of $7 million on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-Net income after a loss of $322,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Failure to Communicate

title: No Action on Charge
description: The president of the Minneapolis Urban League, citing a published charge that the Minnesota Twins discriminate against black players, has sought unsuccessfully to have the municipal operators of the Metrodome intervene.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TLC, With a New Meaning
description: The Chemical Bank branch at Columbus Avenue and 72d Street is only a block east of the Citibank branch at Broadway and 72d Street, the ''flagship'' in Citibank's exiling under-$5,000 account holders from teller service.

title: A RECORD QUARTER FOR CHRYSLER
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which has been working its way back from near bankruptcy in 1980, reported today that its first-quarter net income was $172.1 million, or $1.97 a share, a quarterly record.

title: DATA DIMENSIONS INC reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31.
description: b-Including net income of $1,400 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $469,200 for the quarter and year from discontinued operations. Corrected from Friday's editions.

title: M.P. Baron Marries Karen Howell Shaw
description: Karen Howell Shaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley Warren Shaw of Summit, N.J., was married in Manhattan last evening to Melvin Philip Baron, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hazen Jay Baron of Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about new music gave an incorrect date for performances by Sonny Rollins and Wynton Marsalis. They play in Town Hall tonight at 8 and 11:30.

title: 14 Years of Downs and Ups
description: Charlene and James Nederlander had a terrific time at their belated wedding reception at Regine's Thursday night. They were married 14 years ago but they've been pretty busy in the intervening years, seasoning their marriage with various ups and downs and sporadic splits and reconciliations. They've even seasoned their friends, who now expect the unexpected. When the orchestra, for reasons unknown, swung into ''Happy Birthday'' immediately after the toast to the happy couple, there wasn't a raised eyebrow. These things happen with the Nederlanders.

title: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BENKINS TO BE SOLD TO JACOBS
description: Irwin L. Jacobs, the multimillionaire Minneapolis investor in undervalued companies, has won a short-lived battle with the Belzberg brothers of Canada to acquire the Bekins Company, a major Los Angeles-based moving corporation.

title: Award for the Rozelles
description: Pete and Carrie Rozelle of New York have been chosen as the first couple ever to receive the Alexis de Tocqueville Award, the highest honor given by the United Way. The French historian and philosopher, you may recall, remarked on the unique aspects of volunteerism in America during his journey here in 1831.

title: KENNAMETAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: MARCH PRICE INDEX ROSE BY ONLY 0.1%
description: Despite a sharp jump in food costs, consumer prices inched up only one-tenth of 1 percent in March, the Labor Department reported today.

title: CITY WILL EXTEND TAX ABATEMENTS
description: The Board of Estimate announced yesterday that it would extend for another five years the ''temporary'' tax abatements on 76 Mitchell-Lama apartment buildings. The action means that 32,200 middle-income tenants will not face rent or cooperative maintenance increases that would have averaged about $40 a month.

title: Ronald Bornstein to Run National Public Radio
description: Ronald C. Bornstein, director of the University of Wisconsin-Extension Telecommunications division, has been named acting operating officer of National Public Radio.

title: Acid-Filled Can Ties Up Traffic
description: Traffic around Columbus Circle was tied up for two and a half hours yesterday morning by hazardous material oozing out of a coffee can, authorities said.

description: To the Editor:

title: ISLANDERS, ON 3 IN 3D, ELIMINATE RANGERS IN 6 GAMES
description: No matter what the score was, no matter which way the momentum was swinging, no matter how loudly the Madison Square Garden fans shrieked for the home team, the Islanders remained relentless in their assault on the Rangers' end of the ice last night.

title: CBS NEWS LOSES APPEAL BID
description: CBS News will give General William C. Westmoreland a copy of the investigation it made into a CBS television documentary that he says libeled him, a lawyer for the network said yesterday.

title: WAGNER IS REFUSED A WAIVER BY STATE TO BE SCHOOL CHIEF
description: The State Commissioner of Education refused yesterday to approve Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. as Chancellor of the New York City public school system.

title: DANCE: BLACK FESTIVAL IN BROOKLYN
description: The Dance Black America festival, which presented the first of six varied performance programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Thursday, did not simply offer an overview of black dance in America. It also had the audience laughing and cheering. And it brought leading American choreographers and performers together on one stage in a stunning program that promises to be a major event of the dance year.

title: Sholem Aleichem Salute At YIVO Tomorrow
description: It is 67 years since Sholom Aleichem, the great writer of tales of life in Yiddish-speaking Eastern Europe, and in New York, died at his home on Kelly Street in the Bronx. The annual memorial to him by his descendants and admirers has become a fixture of New York cultural life.

description: Asset figures represent net assets. The per share figure for the latest year is after a capital gain distribution of $3.23 paid in February.

Zimbabwe Arrests 3 For Murder of a Senator
description: Three anti-Government rebels have been arrested in connection with the murders of a white senator and two others, and the search for suspected accomplices has spread to Botswana, a Government spokesman said today.

title: WAITING FOR MT. ETNA, 'THE MONSTER THAT ADVANCES'
description: Europe's highest volcano is active again, spitting forth ponderous masses of molten lava. And as they have done through the ages, dwellers on its flanks stand by helplessly as the inexorable flow crushes their houses, buries their orchards and erases the roads they have built.

title: ASBESTOS FIBERS PUT FEAR IN 130 LIVES
description: John Insalaco sat today in the kitchen of the home he helped build on the site he carefully picked out nine years ago and said, ''I would love to be able to just move out of here - now.''

MONEY SUPPLY OFF $3.1 BILLION
description: The nation's basic money supply plunged by $3.1 billion for the week ended April 13, its first decline in four weeks, the Federal Reserve reported late yesterday.

AUSTRIAN SAYS HE'LL QUIT IF VOTERS DENY HIM A CLEAR MAJORITY
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky, who has headed the Austrian Government for 13 years, said Thursday that if his Socialist Party did not win a clear majority of seats in parliamentary elections Sunday he would step aside.

title: HIGH MOSCOW AIDE MISSES 3D MEETING
description: Konstantin U. Chernenko, who has been regarded as the No. 2 official in the Soviet hierarchy since the death of Leonid I. Brezhnev, did not appear today at one of the major events on the Kremlin's political calendar.

title: Martin Fined
description: Billy Martin has been fined $5,000 by Lee MacPhail, president of the American League, for a heated exchange with Umpire Vic Voltaggio last Friday night in a game against the Toronto Blue Jays at Yankee Stadium and for comments about the umpiring in the season opener at Seattle. In disclosing that he had been fined, Martin, the manager of the Yankees, said last night, ''I'm not going to argue it. He's the president and I'm going to accept whatever he says.''

description: His position and nickname imply strength but his ego is as delicate as fine crystal. In eight previous seasons, Leonard (Truck) Robinson had been among the best power forwards in professional basketball, a strong-arm rebounder and dependable scorer who, if anything, took too much responsibility for his team.

One Who Knows

''I know what they're going through, and I sympathize with them,'' said Minnix, a running back for Notre Dame from 1969 to 1971, and a former high school all-American.

title: BAYLESS,A J, MARKETS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
A New Band of Protesters Marches at Columbia
description: Fifteen years ago today, Columbia University's dean of students, Henry Coleman, was taken hostage by students who were protesting the Vietnam War, the university's work for the Institute for Defense Analysis and the construction of a new gym in Morningside Park.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 17.

title: 3 SOVIET ASTRONAUTS RETURN AFTER DOCKING FAILURE
description: Three Soviet astronauts returned safely to the earth today after problems with their Soyuz T-8 spacecraft forced them to abandon attempts to rendezvous and dock with the Salyut 7 orbital laboratory.

title: IN THE HEAT OF HOUSE DEBATE ON NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: Advocates of a nuclear freeze assert that a clear majority of the House of Representatives favors their resolution, that their arguments have been sharpened and refined, and that the public overwhelmingly supports an immediate halt in the growth of atomic weapons arsenals.

title: PEARL STILL GLITTERS
description: Among the many nicknames Earl Monroe earned, the best known, of course, is the Pearl. But some former teammates greet him with, ''Puff o' Smoke.'' The name derived from his manner of appearing and disappearing on the basketball court and elsewhere.

title: SOUTHWESTERN ENERGY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GAF TAKES STEP TO LIQUIDATE
description: The end of the GAF Corporation is at hand. The company, torn by a bitter proxy fight, yesterday announced an agreement to sell its chemicals business to the Allied Corporation for $410 million in cash. GAF acknowledged that, with the sale of the chemicals unit and the impending sale of its building products division, its management intends to liquidate the company.

title: Team America Adds 2
description: On the eve of its first North American Soccer League game, Team America added two players to its roster yesterday, bringing the squad up to 15 players. The latest additions, both of whom will be playing with the new team on a day-to-day loan from their home clubs, are Boris Bandov, a Cosmos defender, and Alan Green, a Golden Bay striker. Green, an Englishman who is in the process of becoming an American citizen, will not be allowed to play for Team America, the United States national team, in international competition until his naturalization is complete.

title: BALTIMORE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TWO MORE BODIES IDENTIFIED IN MURDER INQUIRY IN JERSEY
description: A 17-year-old New Jersey girl and a 34-year-old video-games operator were identified today by the Monmouth County Prosecutor as two more murder victims of Richard F. Biegenwald.

title: STREET FAIR TO ASSIST THE PUBLIC
description: THE week of April 24 has been designated by President Reagan as E ducation Week and by Governor Cuomo as New York State Consumer E ducation Week. Locally, both events will begin with a community s treet fair to be held tomorrow at the plaza of the Harlem State O ffice Building, 163 West 125th Street at Adam Clayton Powell B oulevard.

description: Borden Inc., producer of a wide variety of foods, dairy products and chemicals, reported yesterday that earnings in the first quarter of 1983 rose 13.8 percent while sales edged up 1 percent.

title: DYING ETHIOPIAN JEWS
description: Hundreds of black Ethiopian Jews, mostly children, died last year in refugee camps just outside Ethiopia's border. Activists on their behalf charge that the Israeli Government and the worldwide Jewish community could have saved them and did not. They are right.

title: School Districting Approved by U.S.
description: The Justice Department yesterday approved the boundaries of all community school districts in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx as nondiscriminatory under the Federal Voting Rights Act. The approval cleared the way for the school board elections May 3.

title: WHAT IS A FAMILY FOR?
description: Long life creates enormous tax burdens. Witness the latest Social Security Act with its stiff new tax increase, weighted heavily on low-income people. Witness the bankruptive Medicaid costs being met by the states to pay nursing-home bills for old people.

title: BAIL TERMS EASED IN DE LOREAN CASE
description: A Federal judge today released to John Z. DeLorean the equivalent of half the $5 million bail he has posted while he is awaiting trial on charges he conspired to sell $24 million worth of cocaine.

title: COMDATA NETWORK reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Rocket Coach Resigns
description: In his four years as head coach of the Houston Rockets, Del Harris took the team to the National Basketball Association playoffs three years in a row and made it to the championship round in 1981. But this season, after Moses Malone was traded to Philadelphia, the Rockets slumped to a 14-68 record, the league's worst. Yesterday, after what was described as ''mutually beneficial'' talks with the Rockets' general manager, Ray Patterson, Harris resigned. ''I have the satisfaction of knowing I did my job this past year with dignity,'' said Harris, who had spent seven years with the Rockets, three as an assistant coach.

description: A Congressional hearing this week on security at the Smithsonian Institution took up the escape of a magpie from a bird cage at the institution's National Zoo. Its accomplices were two parakeets, the authorities said.

title: Big Expectations
description: Although 25-year-old John McComish is only in his first year on the Professional Golfers Association tour, he is not surprised that his average driving distance for 11 tournaments is the highest on the P.G.A.'s list. His average of 276.9 yards is more than 5 yards better than Tom Weiskopf's 271.5.

title: THE DIARIES OF HITLER ARE REPORTED FOUND BY GERMAN WEEKLY
description: The West German magazine Stern said today that it had discovered 60 volumes of previously unknown handwritten diaries of Hitler and would begin publishing them Monday.

title: Deadline on Noise Given 19 Airlines
description: The head of the Port Authority has told 19 airlines, most of them charter and cargo companies, that they will be barred from Kennedy, La Guardia and Newark Airports if they fail to meet noise restrictions by July 20.

title: Accord at Unesco Meeting

title: Officer Is Not Indicted In Slaying of Boy, 5
description: A grand jury declined Thursday to indict a policeman who shot and killed a 5-year-old boy after mistaking his toy gun for a real one.

title: THE GOOD LIFE OF 1883
description: Whenever the headlines become so awash with nuclear dangers, thrill killings, terrorist bombings and dioxin in the drinking water as to suggest the globe may soon fly off its orbit, citizens are heard expressing sentiments of yearning for those simpler times in the old days.

Patents;
'Talking' Metronome Devised

A metronome usually controls the timing of musical instruments by repeated clicks audible to the players but the Holcomb invention does the regulation by its synthetic speech.

title: Too Much Law - and Too Little
description: From the university that produces the most lawyers and many of the most successful ones comes a welcome note of dissatisfaction. Derek Bok, the president of Harvard and former dean of its law school, complains of an overlawyered society too bent on individual success to deliver justice to all its citizens.

description: Nolan Ryan of the Houston Astros struck out three batters tonight in a 6-3 loss to the the Philadelphia Phillies, giving him 3,504 strikeouts in 16 major-league seasons.

description: President Reagan announced tonight that he was ending the ban on negotiations of a long-term grain agreement with the Soviet Union. He had imposed the ban last year out of concern for the political situation in Poland.

description: State officials today barred the sale of hardshell clams by a Long Island seafood supplier. Clams sold by the company were ''the probable cause'' of an outbreak this month of gastroenteritis in upstate Oneida County, officials said.

description: Ken Burrough, the Houston Oiler wide receiver who had been accused of assaulting a parking guard last Feb. 12, was acquitted after only eight minutes of deliberation by a jury in Houston.

description: In what they call a ''test case for the nation,'' business executives are taking the lead in efforts to reverse a decline in the quality of public education in California.

Editorial Notebook; Armenian Memory, Turkish Amnesia
description: The saddest date on the Armenian calendar is April 24, when a scattered people remembers a catastrophe most of us have forgotten. It happened in 1915, when a large and thriving Armenian community in Turkey became the object of the century's first official genocide.

title: Your Money; Reinvestment Plans, Proxies
description: AS the corporate annual meeting season reaches its peak, some stockholders who own shares through a dividend reinvestment plan are worried about whether they will receive proxies to vote for the election of directors and other matters.

title: Brooklyn Fire Kills 3 Children
description: Three children were killed last night when a fire of undetermined origin swept through their sixth-floor apartment at 425 Keap Street in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn. The police said the children, Juan Calderon, 3 years old; his sister Ineabella, 2, and his half-brother Migual Lozada, 1, were alone in the apartment when the fire broke out at 9:10 P.M. No other tenants were injured, and the fire was confined to the apartment. It was brought under control within 20 minutes, the police said.

title: Delta Acquiring 33 Boeing 737's
description: Delta Air Lines said that it had signed contracts to acquire 33 Boeing 737-232 aircraft and that it intended to operate them under leasing arrangements in short-haul domestic markets. The delivery is to be in the fourth quarter and in 1984.

title: Texaco-Pogo

title: RANGERS RUN OUT OF MIRACLES
description: Rob McClanahan believes he has seen miracles before on different teams, one in particular. But not with the Rangers last night. ''I honestly didn't think we were going to lose tonight,'' said the Rangers' left wing after their season-ending, 5-2 loss to the Islanders at Madison Square Garden. ''Even when it was 3-2, even when it was 4-2, I thought we were going to tie it up and go ahead to win.

title: Why Empty Wall Street?
description: Does New York City need a stock transfer tax? Last November, Mayor Koch argued that a tax on prosperous Wall Street should be part of the city's program to balance its 1984 budget. The political logic behind such a tax is clear - but not the economic. The Mayor would be wise to reconsider it before unveiling his budget next week.

ROYAL BALLET: NEW FACES IN CONTEMPORARY WORKS

description: Does the Constitution give a few states the right to force the two-party system on the rest of the nation for Presidential elections? Fortunately, it doesn't. The Supreme Court ruled this week that Republicans and Democrats couldn't manipulate state laws to squeeze out independent competitors.

title: ANTI-SANDINIST AID SPLITS HOUSE PANEL
description: The House Intelligence Committee was badly split today, mostly along party lines, about whether to recommend cutting off funds for covert support of rebels seeking to overthrow the Sandinist Government of Nicaragua.

title: NUCLEAR EVACUATION
description: The United States Court of Appeals in New York City and the Nuclear Regulatory Commission are considering arguments that could result in the closing of the Indian Point nuclear reactors, 35 miles north of midtown Manhattan. Soon, the commission will consider whether an operating license should be issued for the nearly completed Shoreham Nuclear Power Station on Long Island, about 55 miles east of Manhattan. These deliberations are concerned with a number of issues local to the two sites, but a single question is prominent in both: Are emergency plans being drawn for each plant adequate to protect the public if there is an accident serious enough to require evacuation?

description: Jim Paxson scored 26 points, including two baskets in the final minute and a half tonight, to lead the Portland Trail Blazers to a 105-96 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics and a two-game sweep of their playoff series. description: King & Spalding, if not Atlanta's largest or most academically glittering law firm, is by common consensus its most powerful. description: The San Diego Clippers star rookie, Terry Cummings, underwent his first day of testing for a heart disorder Friday and will remain hospitalized over the weekend while examinations continue. The 22-year-old forward was admitted Thursday to Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago for tests to determine the cause of the irregular heart rhythms that caused him to miss the final six games of the regular season. He fainted during a game in Salt Lake City on Dec. 15 and has since complained of fatigue, shortness of breath and dizziness after strenuous activity.

Stevens Arts Center opens in Winston-Salem, N.C. 15 New York Philharmonic plays Schoenberg's ''Gurrelieder'' 15 CBS agrees to provide documents to Westmoreland in libel case 15 ''Voices: A Memoir'' by Frederic Prokosch reviewed 17 Dance Black America festival under way in Brooklyn 17 Fred Silverman is wheeling and dealing again 48 Style Consumer Saturday: Street fair to assist the public 11 G.M. complaint-settling process criticized 11 Fourteen years of downs and ups 11 De Gustibus 11 Washington Talk Briefing 8 In the heat of House debate on nu- clear freeze 8 Health/Science Three Soviet astronauts return after docking failure 24 State bars sale of hard-shell clams by Long Island company 48 Education/Welfare Los Angeles students feel impact of new grades policy 7 Obituaries David Sher, lawyer and philan- thropist 10 Sports Pages Islanders beat Rangers, 5-2, and win Patrick Division title 19 Rangers run out of miracles 19 Yankees beaten by Twins' homers, 5-3 19 Chas Conerly races for recogni- tion 19 Braves defeat Mets, 5-4, in At- lanta 20 Hawks win, 95-93, tie series with Celtics 20 Arrows even series with Balti- more, 1-1 20 Scouting: Bill Emslie would rather be behind the plate 20 Sutton, Wadkins and Nicklaus share lead by 3 at 137 20 Ira Berkow on Earl Monroe 21 Physical condition of 76ers' Ma- lone is in doubt 21 Players: Truck Robinson proves his point 21 Features/Notes Saturday News Quiz 14 Going Out Guide 17 Sports People 20 About New York 27 New York Day by Day 27 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22

title: AIR BOARD ACTING ON SMOKING
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board, responding to a critical court ruling, has proposed tighter requirements to protect nonsmokers on commercial jetliners.

title: HEIN-WERNER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Sale Talks Reported
description: Carl Yastrzemski, the Red Sox slugger, may be the middle man in a projected sale of a 40 percent interest in the club to a Boston television executive.

title: PARK CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Australians Oust A Soviet Envoy as Spy
description: A top Soviet diplomat was ordered out of Australia today on charges of spying. Foreign Affairs Minister Bill Hayden said the Soviet Embassy's First Secretary, Valery N. Ivanov, had been asked to leave within a week.

title: BRAVES RALLY TO BEAT METS, 5-4
description: For the third time in little more than a week, Neil Allen tonight threw a two-out, last-inning pitch that cost the Mets a ball game.

title: FRED SILVERMAN PRODUCING, AND SMILING AGAIN
description: Fred Silverman is chuckling again. Sitting in his dimly lit office at the M-G-M studios, the man who ran prime-time programming at all three major networks in the 1970's slipped a cassette into his video player. He lit a cigarette, smiled and then chortled as his latest discovery, a comedian from Canada named Alan Thicke, popped into view on the television screen.

title: BRIEFING
description: The Great Equalizer

title: LINGUINE NEEDN'T BE TOO REFINED
description: With so much emphasis on the elegant food of northern Italy these days, a number of wonderful and earthy favorites of the southern Italian kitchen are being forgotten or are given short shrift. Among those is my favorite of all pasta combinations, linguine with white clam sauce.

title: Megan Keller, an Editor, Weds Richard A. Taylor
description: Megan Elizabeth Keller and Richard Andrew Taylor, graduates of Colgate University, were married in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Soviet Weighing Case Of U.S.-Soviet Couple
description: Soviet emigration authorities were reconsidering the application to emigrate of a Soviet man married to an American lawyer today. The re-examination came after a protest on the couple's behalf in a major hotel.

title: MORE NURSING-HOME BEDS IS NOT THE ANSWER
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $518,000, or 6 cents a share, from the sale of real estate.

title: STEVENS ARTS CENTER OPENS IN NORTH CAROLINA
description: An all-star cast, including Leonard Bernstein, Isaac Stern, Agnes de Mille, Gregory Peck, Zoe Caldwell and Jean Stapleton, along with Heather Watts and Mel Tomlinson of the New York City Ballet, appeared here tonight to pay tribute to Roger L. Stevens, and to celebrate the opening of a new art center named in his honor.

title: MEMPHIS-UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
LEXIDATA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income

title: PROGRESSIVE CORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,255,000.

title: FRED A. LYNCH
description: Fred A. Lynch, an early technician in the recording industry, died April 15 at a nursing home in Pleasantville, N.J. He was 93 years old and had been a longtime resident of Surf City, N.J.

title: CHURCH OPENS A RESTAURANT IN BROOKLYN
description: Seated at tables laden with sliced sirloin steaks, tarts and fresh-cut flowers, several hundred members of a black church in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood in Brooklyn congratulated one another yesterday in their new restaurant.

title: PROVIDENT BANCORP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
He'd Rather Be Behind the Plate
description: Bill Emslie, whose dismissal from the International League umpiring staff last December resulted in the major league umpires' decision to boycott Thursday's Mayor's Trophy game between the Yankees and Mets, lives in Clearwater, Fla.

title: COLONIAL BANCORP (WATERBURY, CONN) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EXPLORATION SURVEYS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: TEXAS-NEW MEXICO POWER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BANK COLLAPSE JOLTS TENNESSEE
description: In the two months since the collapse of Jake Butcher's United American Bank of Knoxville, the fallout in Tennessee has been both extensive and expensive. The aftershocks have included lawsuits, bankruptcies, fraud investigations, runs on banks, Federal agency bailouts, bank sales and legislative action. And some analysts think that more problems are on the way.

title: U.S. and Soviet Argue Blame For Prolonging Madrid Talks
description: The Soviet Union and the United States accused each other again today of prolonging the Conference on European Security and Cooperation, which has been in virtual stalemate for over 30 months, delegates said.

title: WOODHEAD, DANIEL, INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-After an expense of $550,000 to relocate a manufacturing plant.

title: CONCERT: 'GURRELIEDER' SCHOENBERG BY MEHTA
description: In their most ambitious gesture of the season, Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic Thursday night presented Schoenberg's strangest and most grandiloquent score, the two-hour essay in fetid post-Romanticism called ''Gurrelieder.'' This is the work Schoenberg began in 1901, but dropped and then finished a decade later. It is a monster in every way and appears so rarely in the concert hall that every performance has to be marked down as a special event, even if it falls short of complete success, as this one did.

title: ANTHEM ELECTRONICS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in March.

title: MITE CORP reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,280,000 from flood loss net of insurance proceeds.

title: SHELL CANADA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for year to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes income of $75,000 from discontinued operations. c-Net loss after loss of $916,673 from discontinued operations. Results for the 1983 year include the operations of Protective Closures Co. acquired on Jan. 7.

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect the retroactive effect of a 2 percent stock dividend.

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FEDERATED GUARANTY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Killer, 71, Sentenced to Die
description: A 71-year-old man who confessed the shooting deaths of five men in 1981 was sentenced today to death in the electric chair.

title: E.P.A. Failed to Check U.S. Acts, Report Says
description: In a sharply critical report, the Acting Inspector General of the Environmental Protection Agency said today that the agency ''failed to fulfill its obligations'' to monitor the environmental impact of Government activities.

title: NUCLEAR BOARD VOTES OPPOSITION TO SHOREHAM PLANT TEST LICENSE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's licensing board has recommended that the Shoreham nuclear plant on Long Island be denied a license to operate at low power for testing.

title: ROBLIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,336,000 from discontinued operations, a gain of $475,000 from the disposition of operations, and a tax credit of $425,000.

title: ALABAMA EXECUTES KILLER, 7TH IN U.S. TO DIE SINCE '76
description: John Louis Evans 3d was electrocuted at Holman Prison tonight. He was the seventh person executed in America since the Supreme Court reinstated capital punishment in 1976 and the first to be put to death in Alabama since 1965.

title: HAWAII EMPLOYEES, UNHAPPY OVER PAY, CONSIDERING A STRIKE
description: Frustrated and unhappy because they will not get pay increases this year despite a surplus in the state treasury, many of Hawaii's 44,000 public workers are now considering a strike.

title: SCHOOLS VARY IN SEX EDUCATION
description: ''OUR 11th-grade students can watch a film of a naked woman giving birth, and later have an open discussion about it in a coed classroom without any giggling or tittering,'' said Dr. Norman Schwartz, assistant superintendent of secondary education for Syosset public schools. ''Kids can discuss topics that would make some of their parents blush. The more educated we get about sex, the less prurient is our interest in it.''

title: THE RICHNESS OF CONFIT
description: Preserved foods such as goose and duck have become increasingly popular with Americans who have visited France. The French name for this preparation is confit, and it is especially chacteristic of the Gascony region, in the southwest corner of France.

title: A HOUSE IN THE GEORGIAN MODE
description: If David Anthony Easton has anything to say about the future of American architecture, a third category will vie with modernism and postmodernism - a classification that might be dubbed premodernism. Its most salient characteristic: the absence of any trace of having been created in the 20th century. The Illinois house shown here and on the following pages is just one of several ambitious ''period'' houses that have been designed since 1976 by David Easton's New York firm. Although he has architects on his staff, Easton is an interior designer. He brings to his houses a concern for surface and an unabashed affection for history that make them differ materially from work done by architects - even those few who claim to be traditionalists.

title: Q&A
description: Question: Next year I plan on taking my two granddaughters, who will be 7 and 10 years old at the time, to England for a month. I would appreciate suggestions on places to visit that would be of special interest to children. I want this trip to be a memorable one for the two girls. - M.F., Oakdale, N.Y.

title: And Bear in Mind
description: Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: ALL AMERICAN MUSIC, by John Rockwell. (Alfred A. Knopf, $15.95.) A study of contemporary American music, popular and highbrow.

title: YOUTH SERVICES CALLED IN DISARRAY
description: A severe management breakdown in the youth services division of the City Probation Department and the failure of the city and state to solve the problem has placed the division in a state of disarray, according to a state report issued last week.

title: Cheryl Dee Eidelberg To Marry a Physician
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Eidelberg of Rahway, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cheryl Dee Eidelberg, to Dr. James H. Frost, son of Dr. and Mrs. William R. Frost of Wayne, N.J. The wedding is to be in September 1984.

title: BRAVES, METS IN RAINOUT
description: Rain added another complication to the difficult life of the Mets tonight when their game against the Atlanta Braves was delayed three times and finally was postponed.

title: Lost Sailor Reached on Radio
description: Nearly 36 hours after the satellite transmitter on his yacht had stopped sending signals, Richard Konkolski of Czechoslovakia was reached on the radio yesterday by Dan Byrne of the United States, a fellow competitor in the single-handed round-the-world race, ending fears for his safety.

title: Portugal, Austria Go to the Polls
description: The Social Democratic tradition in Western Europe is on the line in elections in Austria today and Portugal tomorrow and in neither country is it certain of a clear-cut victory. Chancellor Bruno Kreisky and his Socialists have governed Austria for 13 years.

title: PARLEY TOLD OF NEVADA RULING
description: THEIR state's need for jobs and tax revenue was a consideration in the decision to license Clifford Perlman to operate a Las Vegas casino, Nevada gambling regulators told a recent conference on gaming here.

title: RAIL BUFFS BID ADIEU TO RIO GRANDE ZEPHYR
description: With four quick blasts on the diesel horn, the engineer, John Schoening, eased the Rio Grande Zephyr out of Denver's Union Station this morning and into history.

title: HOME FOR HOMELESS SOUGHT IN BERGEN
description: THE closing next month of the temporary shelter here for Bergen County's homeless has prompted the formation of a coalition to provide a permanent refuge.
