title: SEARCH FOR HITLER DIARIES LED TO HAYLOFT IN EAST GERMANY
description: A West German journalist has been credited with the discovery of what are said to be 60 volumes of diaries kept by Hitler.

title: DOCTOR OUSTED BY HARVARD ALSO SUSPECTED OF FALSIFYING RESEARCH AT EMORY
description: The Emory University School of Medicine has disclosed that a young doctor who was earlier detected cheating on experiments at the Harvard Medical School is suspected of falsifying a large number of research papers on which he acted as co-author with some of Emory's leading professors.

title: Vacancy Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: LOW-KEY CELEBRATION FOR A MASTER
description: Harold C. Schonberg, cultural correspondent of The New York Times, writes primarily on music.

title: RAMS GET 2D PICK IN A BID FOR DICKERSON
description: The Houston Oilers yesterday traded the second pick in Tuesday's National Football League draft to the Los Angeles Rams for the third pick over all and the Rams' fourth-round selections this year and next year, according to Ladd Herzeg, the Houston general manager.

title: Julie Williamson To Marry June 4
description: Dr. and Mrs. John A. Williamson of San Antonio have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Elizabeth Williamson, to Michael Keady Whitcomb, son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Whitcomb of New Canaan, Conn. A June 4 wedding is planned.

title: MORE MUD, MORE FUN AT RALLY OF 'OFF-ROADERS'
description: THE usual tranquillity of the rural Franklin Woods, a few miles north of Norwich, will be shattered next weekend when more than 50 drivers in Jeeps, Broncos, Blazers and assorted other four-wheeldrive vehicles take to the hills for the Eighth Annual Spring Fever rally.

title: Summer Nuptials For Jenai Sullivan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Maurice J. Sullivan of Honolulu have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Jenai Sullivan, to Roger John Wall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Wall of Garden City and Cutchogue, L.I. The wedding is to be in July.

title: CARPENTERS INVEST IN A SUBDIVISION
description: A Carpenters Union local in Rockland County has put up $1,600,000 from its pension fund to restart what its builder says is the largest single-family home development in the county.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Kate Stone Plans To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Stone of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kate Lawson Stone, to Michael J. Lombardi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Lombardi of Rockville, Md. A June wedding is planned at the home of the bride's parents.

title: THE FRESCOBALDI PUZZLE IS SOLVED
description: This year marks the 400th anniversary of the birth of Girolamo Frescobaldi, a man who was, with Monteverdi, one of the two most original and important Italian composers of his time. But very little of Frescobaldi's music has come down to us. There are some compositions for keyboard, a smattering of sacred music, and one set of 19 madrigals, which the composer published in 1608. Until recently, the only surviving copy of the madrigals was the one safely entombed within Oxford's Bodleian Library. But it was incomplete, containing part books only for the two sopranos, tenor and bass, lacking the crucial alto line. When Carlo Felice Boghen published six of these madrigals in 1920, he had to reconstruct the alto part through educated guesswork.

title: BANKRUPTCY AS SHIELD IN JOB CLAIMS
description: There are times when the practice of law verges on metaphysics. The ongoing bankruptcy proceedings involving three asbestos companies are just such a case.

title: GREAT BOOKS GROUPS: HARDY PERENNIALS
description: WHEN many New Yorkers are cooking dinner, watching television, or s itting in a neighborhood bar, members of the mid-Manhattan Great B ooks group are meeting in an East Side brownstone sharing thoughts o n existential philosophy.

title: That's Entertainment?
description: Felt a bit foolish after watching that prime time sit-com? Balanced your checkbook instead of tuning in the nightly shoot-em-up? A new survey commissioned by the National Association of Broadcasters points to silliness and violence in programming as just two of the reasons people are watching less television than they used to. And perhaps feeling more guilty about the less they watch.

title: Teamsters Union Fills the Throne
description: That the executive committee of the teamsters last week took one of its own - Jackie Presser, an international vice-president from Ohio who is often described as colorful - to serve out the term of resigning president Roy Williams was no surprise. That is teamster democracy.

title: RUTGERS ENLIGHTENS NEOPHYTE OFFICIALS
description: NEW local officeholders who do not know malfeasance from nonfeasance, or cash-basis budgeting from zero-base budgeting, can try to fill the gaps in their understanding at classes offered by Rutgers, the State University.

title: U.S. TRADE OFFICIAL WARNS EUROPEANS ON CURBING EXPORTS TO SOVIET
description: A Reagan Administration trade official has warned Western European diplomats that there could be an ''isolationist reaction'' by the United States if Europeans were not more cooperative in restricting exports of high technology to the Soviet Union.

title: OBTAINING A CAREER VIA MAIL ORDER
description: WHEN Harold L. Schwartz of Great Neck was growing up in Brooklyn, he used to help after school in his father's grocery in Bensonhurst. ''That's where I learned to get along with people, and also selling,'' he said. ''I remember a woman came in and ordered $35 worth of merchandise, which was a lot of merchandise.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE ONLY LIVING WITNESS By Stephen G. Michaud and Hugh Aynesworth. Illustrated. 332 pp. New York: Linden Press/ Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: 2 BASEBALL WIVES CALL IT AS THEY SEE IT
description: The wives of professional baseball players would seem, on the surface, to lead glamorous lives marked by travel, affluence, the adulation of fans and access to interesting people.

title: THE EXAMINED WARDROBE
description: For years I have been under the impression that Socrates said, ''The unexamined life is not worth living,'' and it has had a powerful effect, for I know Socrates was a wise man who knew what he was talking about. Hence, I have spent a great deal of time examining my life when I might have been busy doing something less melancholy.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: About a dozen young people, describing themselves as members of an ''anti-imperialist'' commando unit, attacked the Museum of the Legion of Honor on Friday, slashing paintings, destroying showcases and causing damage estimated at ''several million francs.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
LOOKING FOR SIGNS OF AUTHENTICITY
description: HOW do you tell American handcrafted furniture of the 17th, 18th and early 19th centuries from the mass-produced, machine-made reproductions of 100 or more years later?

title: PLANS UNDER WAY FOR 1984 PRIMARY
description: IT may be 11 months away, but the early maneuvering for Connecticut's 1984 Presidential primary election is already under way. State Democrats have adopted the delegate selection plan that will translate the results of the primary into votes at the party's national convention to be held in July 1984, and the Democratic Presidential contenders are beginning to get organized and to make appearances in Connecticut.

title: FOR THE TV NETWORKS, THE KEY TO SUCCESS IS A LONG STORY
description: The phone began ringing in Stu Samuels's office at ABC's West Coast headquarters the morning after the first installment of ''The Winds of War,'' last January. The ''overnight'' ratings indicated that ABC had a major hit on its hands in the 18-hour adaptation of Herman Wouk's saga set in the period before World War II, and television producers around Hollywood started calling with their own ideas for war stories.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: SOME politicians learn to orate in law school, others in debating class and still others as heads of corporations. One State Senator, however, learned from his dental practice.

title: Charles G. Berry, Lawyer, Marries Kathryn McGraw
description: Kathryn McGraw, an architect with Kohn Pederson Fox Associates in New York, was married yesterday to Charles Gordon Berry, an associate with the New York law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy. The Rev. Frederick S. Baldwin, assisted by the Rev. William J. Chase, performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: SURVEYING THE NEEDS OF ELDERLY
description: THE voluntary Northern Westchester Geriatric Committee, which for 10 years has sought to increase services to the elderly, has begun an effort to determine the needs of aged Northern Westchester residents in such areas as adult day care, home care, transportation and programs for the frail elderly. The committee has also applied for incorporation, in order to permit tax-deductible contributions.

title: UCONN'S SCHOOL OF DESPAIR
description: EVEN the radio station in Torrington could not resist joining what it called ''the theatrics of defeat'' - the local displays of anger, shock, frustration and resentment that followed a 12-to-1 vote by the Board of Trustees of the University of Connecticut earlier this month to close the institution's Torrington campus. The campus is to close on Aug. 15, due to insufficient enrollment.

title:
DINING OUT;
THE PERILS OF OWNING A RESTAURANT
description: THE Saddle River Inn occupies an old barnlike mill house that overlooks a pond on one side and, on the other, a charming courtyard ringed with small stores. The inside has been minimally decorated: Just one large flower painting, lace curtains and white cloths that make the tables stand out against the wood walls, floors and twostory-high ceiling. There are stairs leading to two dining balconies, and a long table near the entrance holds the bottles of wine brought by patrons.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE Newark Boys Choir School, which for the last decade and a half has trained hundreds of youngsters for the internationally acclaimed Newark Boys Choir, will move next door to the city's Symphony Hall in the fall.

title: POISON DUMP STIRS ALARM IN POCONOS
description: Residents of this Pocono Mountains village are surprised and alarmed at the discovery that toxic chemicals and industrial waste were illegally buried in a clearing in the woods.

title: FINDING SHELTER IN LATER LIFE
description: AFTER my father's death, my mother's life shrank. She retreated inside her house, closing the door on the world. Then ever so slowly she realized that she must give up that 20-year-old protective roof. (Because of my father's sudden illness, he left behind no will or mortgage insurance.) My mother could no longer afford to live there.

title: Eleanor L. Vogelbach Is Wed to John M. Gavin Jr.
description: Eleanor Lindsay Vogelbach, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Vogelbach of Thompson Ridge, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John Martin Gavin Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gavin of Philadelphia. The Rev. Peter Braun performed the ceremony at the Hopewell Presbyterian Church.

title: FENCING SOUGHT FOR PALISADES
description: ''LOSE your footing or horse-around here, the way kids do, and you can go right down, a sheer drop of 150 feet - 350 feet if you bounce off the first landing,'' said Richard J. Olsen, assistant superintendent of Palisades Interstate Park.

title: NO LAUREL-RESTING FOR DOUBLE HELIX PIONEERS
description: TWO names, J.D. Watson and F.H.C. Crick, appeared on a letter in the April 25, 1953, issue of the British journal Nature suggesting a ''radically different'' double helix structure for DNA, or deoxyribonucleic acid.

title: Commuting and Complaining
description: Metro-North rail service resumed last week after a 42-day absence that didn't seem to make the hearts of many of its 90,000 daily riders grow any fonder. ''It was as bad as ever,'' was the way one Larchmont, N.Y., passenger put it.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE RETURN OF THE TRAINS
description: ''IT'S the greatest sound I've heard, the sound of people's voices, the sound of the trains, the sound of cash,'' said, Terry Marafito, a blind news dealer at the Croton-Harmon railroad station. The 42-day Metro-North strike that came to an end last Monday failed to run Mrs. Marafito and her blind husband, Jerry, out of business. But the Croton station, like many others on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven Lines, had not been bustling with commerce.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEDAL MARKS BROOKLYN BRIDGE CENTENNIAL
description: For years buying'' the Brooklyn Bridge has come to be synonymous with gullibility---but now there is a way to obtain a piece of the bridge in completely legitimate fashion. To help mark the landmark's 100th anniversary, the Brooklyn Bridge Centennial Commission has authorized the sale of a special bronze medal that has a piece of the original steel cable from the span embedded in it.

title: TRACES OF A TRIBE OF LOWER HUDSON
description: WHEN the conductor calls out the next town, chances are about fifty-fifty that it will have what to outsiders would be a strangesounding name. It will doubtless be of Indian origin, and hardly anyone will think twice. Those names have been absorbed into our culture and into our routine, while the traces of the Indian culture have been buried under parkways and shopping malls.

title: REFOCUSING SCIENCE AND MATH
description: ONCE AGAIN, as it was 25 years ago, The Congressional Record is d otted with statistics about the scientific acumen of Soviet high school students. Close behind are test results for schoolchildren in Japan and Western Europe. And once again, the numbers are intended to spur a rededication to old fashioned mathematic and scientific principles, the basics that form the underpinnings of a technological society.

title: GIRL IN A 'BOYS' SCHOOL: THE WAY IT WAS
description: In the beginning I felt like a novelty. I was, sometimes, the only girl in a class of 34, and wasn't quite sure if I liked it. Some of the teachers found it difficult to adjust to the female sex seated beside the ''future male leaders of the world.'' Now, I can say with relief that things have changed for the better.

title: A CASE OF LYME DISEASE IN KATONAH
description: ON April 11, 10-year-old Nino Hamawy of Katonah began to run a high fever. Nino's parents were not initially concerned because everybody in the family, including Nino's 8-year-old brother, Benjy, was down with flu and was feeling feverish and headachy. The Hamawys live on a quiet country road in a three-bedroom ranch house. Their property borders 100 acres of woods that reverted from abandoned farmland early in the century and now are full of deer. Nino and Benjy spend a lot of time in the woods, looking for things with Nino's metal detector and helping their father gather deadwood for their woodstove.

title: Golf Title to Army
description: Army, led by the tournament medalist Frank Vana, who shot a 73, captured its second straight Metro-Atlantic Athletic Conference golf title today. On their course, the Cadets posted a team score of 393.

title: Miss Poole Plans Atlanta Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Parrott Poole of Atlanta have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Parrott Poole, to John Walter Zick Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Zick of Greenwich, Conn. A fall wedding is planned at the North Side United Methodist Church in Atlanta.

title: States Rights On Nuclear Power
description: Last week started out smelling like roses for the nuclear industry, but it ended with the industry badly wilting. The Supreme Court first ruled that psychological stress suffered by surrounding neighborhoods is not a factor in authorizing nuclear power plants.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Defense Inequality

title: PARKING: ISSUE TO STIR PASSIONS
description: IT has been called a ''chronic problem'' in Southampton Village, a political ''hot potato'' in tiny North Haven, the ''basic issue'' in the Village of East Hampton. On the issue of parking, local governments on the East End sometimes stand or fall, and James Davidson, president of a New York-East End bus service, has described the problem as a ''lurking crisis out here,'' one that has not yet ''really been dealt with.''

title: AT MIDLIFE, AND NOT READY
description: WHEN I grow up, I am going to be a famous writer. I am going to stop biting my fingernails and throwing my clothes around the room. And I am not going to have tantrums anymore, or cry for no reason at all. But next year I will be 40.

title: WHAT KIND OF IS THE BEST FOR YOU?
description: When it comes to buying a home or an apartment, its location, basic cost and amenities are naturally paramount. Secondary to these considerations, but nonetheless important, is the question of what form of ownership is being offered.

title: Egypt Observes Return Of Last Portion of Sinai
description: Egypt, in a ceremony in this dusty, northern desert town, today marked the first anniversary of Israel's restoration of the last part of the Sinai Peninsula to Egyptian control.

title: K.M. Seperack to Wed Tricia Witham in July
description: Col. Bertram High Witham, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Witham, of Stamford, Conn., and Pebble Beach, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Louise Witham, to Kenneth Michael Seperack, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Robert Seperack of Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Putting Juries On the Couch
description: Morton Hunt's article ''Putting Juries on the Couch'' (Nov. 28) contained some errors. The D.G. Group Inc. of Chicago, and specifically David Green and myself were retained by Jenner & Block to assist them with jury selection and other matters in the M.C.I. v. A.T.&T. case.

title: M. Jenny Kuntz and James D. Frost Are Married
description: M. Jenny Kuntz, daughter of Barbara P. Isserman of River Forest, Ill., and the late Donald L. Kuntz, was married yesterday to James David Frost, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Frost of Stuart, Fla. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. David Robertson at the First Presbyterian Church in River Forest.

title: AS A BARGAINING CHIP, MX MAY BE NO BARGAIN FOR THE SOVIETS
description: IS the United States, with or without the Soviet Union, about to enter a new era in strategic nuclear forces? ''Major new departures'' in long-range missiles and arms control is exactly what the President's Commission on Strategic Forces promised two weeks ago. Commission members proclaimed the end of an era of huge weapons with multiple warheads and the beginning of a more stable age of single-warhead missiles.

title: Peter J. Rondinone Marries Kathrine Debra Jason
description: Kathrine Debra Jason, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Jason of New York, was married yesterday to Peter J. Rondinone, son of Cora Rondinone of New York and the late Joseph Rondinone. Rabbi Burt Siegel performed the ceremony in a penthouse loft at 126 Fifth Avenue.

title: LESSONS FROM IWO JIMA AND BEYOND
description: AS I grow older and some of the memories of my childhood begin to fade, one seemingly small recollection still burns brightly: The day my father taught me ''The Marine's Hymn.''

title: ARTISTS JOIN IN UNUSUAL BENEFIT PROJECT: A PRINT PORTFOLIO
description: DESPITE the area's international reputation as a resort for the rich and famous, the Hamptons still have a small-town air about them. So when the local hospital, Southampton Hospital, approached some local folks for fund-raising aid, they all pitched in.

title: YOUNG AMERICANS WITH NO SENSE OF HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: 20 Arrested in Killing of 2 On Coast Reservation
description: Two people were shot to death today as they drove on the Soboba Indian Reservation and about 20 reservation residents were arrested by deputies who found themselves in the line of fire, the authorities said.

title: READING'S THE THING IN SHAKESPEARE CONTEST
description: The scene: a town house on East 69th Street. The players: five high school students reading Shakespeare, in competition. The only problem: the judges sat near a window, and on several occasions heard such as the following: ''Let me not to the marriage of true HONK! admit impediments.''

title: SOUTHERN CONDUCT
description: SOUTHERN HONOR Ethics and Behavior in the Old South. By Bertram Wyatt-Brown. 597 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: A SCHOOL TO KEEP THEM IN PUBLIC SCHOOL
description: FOR youngsters interested in the performing arts and not enrolled in a special school, acting classes are often an after-school or weekend activity. But for Jamie Nodell, a 12-year-old who lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan and wants to be an actor, classes in the theater arts in his public school are as much a part of his curriculum as math and science.

title: EASTERN DOCKERS GET 3-YEAR PACT
description: The International Longshoremen's Association and seven major employer groups in Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports have reached agreement on a new three-year master contract five and a half months before the old pact expires.

title: ARROWS ELIMINATED BY BLAST
description: The New York Arrows, the only champions in the Major Indoor Soccer League's four previous seasons, were eliminated in the quarterfinal round by the Baltimore Blast, who scored an 8-3 victory tonight before a standing-room crowd of 11,223 at the Baltimore Civic Center.

title: VARIABLES CLOUD PRICE OUTLOOK FOR NATURAL GAS
description: WHILE Congress continues to debate President Reagan's bill calling for full price decontrol of natural gas in 1986, the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has taken steps to help lower gas prices now.

title: WHAT COLLEGES WILL DO TO PAY THE RENT
description: EUREKA COLLEGE in Illinois, President Reagan's alma mater, sponsored a one-time Adopt-a-Student alumni appeal and raised $25,000 for student financial aid.

title: ACADEME IN THE GROVES OF TECHNOLOGY
description: WHEN C.P. Snow warned 20 years ago about the great divide between science and the humanities, such concern was viewed largely as a mere debate among scholars. Today, it is seen as a crisis in education anda threat to the capacity of ordinary citizens to function in the modern world. Out of this sense of inadequacy, the search for ''the new liberal arts'' was born.

title: SCOTLAND'S STARK AND TRANQUIL ISLES
description: It was delight in the majestic prose and severe intelligence of Samuel Johnson that spurred me to follow in that great man's footsteps through Scotland, to see what he had seen, to speak to the descendants of those to whom he had spoken. He and James Boswell had come north in 1773, when transport was primitive, accommodations sparse, and knowledge of Highlands and islands small. It was an enterprise of courage to venture to the Inner Hebrides, the chain of islands that lies just off the west coast of the Scottish mainland. Johnson and Boswell each wrote accounts of the journey, Johnson's a report from the heights, orotund, Boswell's down-to-earth and chatty.

title: Losing Patience On the Budget
description: ''It's obvious we have three sides in the tax debate,'' Senator Pete V. Domenici said after a heated meeting of Senate Budget Committee Republicans and senior White House officials. By week's end, there were only two. Propelled by institutional pride, practical politics and not a little anger, Mr. Domenici and four compatriots reached across the hearing room table and sent a Democratic budget resolution to the Senate floor.

title: SUIT BACKS WOMEN JAILED ON RIKERS I.
description: About once a month, an inmate being held on Rikers Island is taken to the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, Queens, to give birth. After a short stay in the hospital, the mother and child are separated. The mother is returned to her cell and the infant is placed with a family member or in a foster home.

title: COUNTY WEIGHS WILDCLIFF SUIT
description: THE Wildcliff Museum in New Rochelle is closed but its problems appear to be mounting. Once a haven for youth-oriented programs in the county, the museum underwent a series of financial setbacks that led to its closing in August 1981. There have been repeated attempts to revitalize the museum, including a plan submitted in October 1981 by a task force composed of museum trustees and several county and New Rochelle officials.

title: Philadelphians Warm Up to Vote
description: After a round of televised debates last week, it appeared that Philadelphia's mayoral race could turn out to be as hotly contested as Chicago's -but perhaps less racially divisive.

title: SECULAR REQUIEMS: DEATH AS PUBLIC ART
description: According to legend it was Death himself - not Count Walsegg-Stuppach - who commissioned a Requiem from the ailing Mozart. Berlioz's Requiem commission did not come from a patron; he had to wrestle it from the French government: ''It was a prey I had long stood in ambush for,'' he wrote. Cherubini, penned his first Requiem for the anniversary of the execution of King Louis XVI; his second was for his own funeral. Faure was stirred by the death of his father; Verdi, by the death of a countryman; Dvorak's was commissioned by the English Birmingham Festival.

title: Council on Arts On Federal Cutbacks
description: On behalf of the Council for the Arts in Westchester, I'd like to congratulate Tessa Melvin for her work on the two arts pieces that appeared on March 27. As she pointed out in the article about the General Foods consumer study (''Council Heartened by First Arts Poll''), we are pleased with the number of Westchester residents who indicated that they are active in the arts, and with the opportunities for increased service by Westchester arts organizations that the study revealed.

title: COMPETITION IN BALLET SET FOR JUNE 1984
description: The first New York International Ballet Competition will take place in June 1984 at City Center. Founded by Ilona Copen and Richard Thomas, dance teachers here, the competition will be open to 24 male and 24 female dancers from the ages of 17 to 23 years.

title: Poet of the Bogs
description: What's this preoccupation with soil quality in analyses of Seamus Heaney's work (''Poet of the Bogs,'' by Francis X. Clines, March 13)? ''Seamus of the Bogs,'' ''sod-loving Irishman'' - why not call Wordsworth ''William of the Meadows,'' or Omar Khayyam ''that duneloving Persian''? And what's all the to-do about Heaney's ''nonliterary past,'' ''simple early education,'' ''humble bogside origins''? From the medieval period to the present day, the bulk of Ireland's enormous poetical contributions was born of just such ''bogside origins.'' And any traveler who has ever stopped awhile in rural Ireland can report on the delights that await the ear in the rich, shapely language of everyday discourse. In the play ''Translations,'' by Seamus Heaney's Ulster compatriot Brian Friel, one character explains: ''You'll find, sir, that certain cultures expend on their vocabularies and syntax acquisitive energies and ostentations entirely lacking in their material lives.'' MARGARET SPILLANE, New Haven

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The young Finnish violinist Pyry Mikkola is a pupil of Nathan Milstein and was a prize winner in the International IV Jean Sibelius Contest for Violinists in 1980. His Carnegie Recital Hall debut on April 16 gave evidence of a versatile talent, capable of dazzling an audience with flamboyant Paganini display pieces one moment, and neatly dissecting Bartok's astringent Solo Sonata the next.

title: A PESTICIDE TOO GOOD TO BE TRUE?
description: The road between New York and Florida is well-worn, but mostly by people. Now controversy over the pesticide Temik, which was withdrawn from agricultural use on Long Island in 1980, has moved South, as well. Last week, Florida Agricultural Commissioner Doyle Conner extended his earlier three-month ban on the chemical to the end of the year so that scientists will have a chance to further study the extent of its proliferation in the state's water supply.

title: Colorado String Quartet Is Naumburg Winner
description: The Colorado String Quartet has won the Naumburg Foundation's 1983 chamber-music prize.

title: Anthony Coleman Marries Miss Randjic in Yugoslavia
description: Anthony Grad Coleman, a New York composer and pianist, was married on April 16 in a civil ceremony in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, to Ljiljana Randjic, an artist and sculptor. Mr. Coleman, who is in Belgrade for a concert, met his bride in 1981 at the Centre Acanthes in Aix-en-Provence, France, where he was studying.

title: WAYS TO STRENGTHEN THE WEAKEST OF THE THREE STRATFORD 'SISTERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: TOURNAMENTS HELD FOR THE HANDICAPPED
description: THE few hundred children gathered around the Centennial Avenue pool in Cranford were acting the way that most young participants do before a sports competition: poking each other with nervous affection and crowding in front of a camera to get in the picture.

title: MYSTIC'S SEAL TO START JOURNEY
description: LIKE many fortunate individuals, Andre spends his summers in Maine. But Andre is a harbor seal who swims there from Connecticut each spring and must be transported back by plane each autumn.

title: THE COMPUTER: A PRIMER FOR PARENTS
description: BOMBARDED by advertisements from computer manufacturers, advised by high-technology gurus about the educational value of computers and besieged with equipment requests from their own children, many parents feel pressured and confused about what computers can and can't do for their children.

title: HOUSE PANEL SCHEDULES A VOTE ON MILITARY AID TO EL SALVADOR
description: The chairman of a key House subcommittee said today that he had scheduled a vote for Tuesday on a Reagan Administration request to redirect $60 million in military aid to El Salvador. The aid is currently earmarked for other countries.

title: Board Rooms, Clubs and Identity
description: WHEN sociologists and social psychologists look at the American b usiness community, their focus is on such things as status-seeking, g amesmanship, organizational maintenance, and above all, power - thata ll-pervasive and elusive something whose basic mechanisms are i nclusion and exclusion.

title: NOW PITCHING FOR OTHERS
description: FOR eight years, Dave Lemanczyk earned his living throwing fast balls for the Detroit Tigers, the Toronto Blue Jays and the California Angels. In 1981, after an injury brought his major league pitching career to an abrupt halt, the Baldwin resident experienced considerable difficulty accepting his new role as a mere civilian facing the realities of an occupational crisis.

title: CAREFUL COOKERY AND CREATIVE, TOO
description: JUST over the Nassau County line in Little Neck, Queens, Trattoria la Pergola is a small den. Actually, it is not as small as it was when it first opened a number of years ago, occupying only the limited space of a single storefront. It has expanded into the adjacent store, adding a few more tables, and also opened a pasta shop on the corner.

title: Mary Fulham to Wed in June
description: The engagement of Mary Margaret Fulham to James Edward Reynolds, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Weldon Reynolds of Brighton, Mass., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Norris Fulham of Wellesley Hills, Mass., parents of the future bride. A June wedding is planned.

title: Morgan State Wins 5
description: Morgan State was the top winner today as the Rutgers Relays wound up a three-day competition. The Baltimore team recorded victories in three men's relays and two women's events.

title: Miss Burt to Wed Dr. Joseph Kagan
description: Dr. and Mrs. James Gordon Burt of Oxford, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Arabella Felicity Taber Burt, to Dr. Joseph Philip Kagan, son of Marcina Kagan of Rhinecliff, N.Y., and the late Dr. Samuel Kagan. The wedding is planned for June 26.

title: MORE JAZZ TREASURES FROM THE PAST
description: It has been four years since George H. Buck Jr., who owns such labels devoted to swing and traditional jazz styles as Jazzology, G.H.B., Circle and Audiophile, began releasing material from the catalogue of World Transcriptions, which he had acquired a decade earlier.

title: FINDING POETRY IN THE ORDINARY
description: In an age when many photographers devote a great deal of energy to developing a recognizable style and sticking to it, Jan Groover is exceptional. Possessed of a contrary spirit, she seems to veer off in new directions whenever her work threatens to become her signature. After gaining a considerable reputation in the mid-70's for her formally complex color triptychs, she surprised everyone with a show of boldly decorative still lifes of kitchen utensils and house plants. And when these pictures, too, entered the canon of contemporary photography, she forsook color and began what seemed a calculated recapitulation of early Modernist black-and-white photographic practice, complete with view camera, platinum printing and ''quotations'' from Stieglitz, Strand and Weston.

title: WOOD CAPTURED BY SLEW O' GOLD
description: For six months, the owners and trainer of Slewpy and Slew o' Gold have been hinting that Slew o' Gold was the better of the two stablemates, both 3-year-old sons of Seattle Slew. Slewpy had been the more precocious of the two all along, but yesterday the stable's opinion was finally proved right. Slew o' Gold won the second and faster division of the split Wood Memorial at Aqueduct, and Slewpy finished a poor fifth behind Bounding Basque in the first division.

title: ON THE QUESTION OF TAXING MUSEUMS
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STAMPEDE TO EQUITY MUTUAL FUNDS
description: IT was almost inevitable that last year's falling interest rates andt he surge in stock prices would set off a rush to mutual funds that i nvest in common stocks. And indeed, they did. But that flood of m oney has yet to peak, and fund managers are expecting that 1983 s ales of equity funds will break even the records set in 1982.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN FOOD REGULATION;
KEEPING SACCHARIN ON THE SHELVES
description: Each time a new moratorium forbidding the F.D.A. to ban saccharin has arisen during the last five years, Congress has debated, but failed to resolve, broader food safety questions. The third and current moratorium expires Aug. 13, and Congress voted earlier this month to extend it for two years, pending Presidential approval.

title: U.S. AND YALE AGREE ON GRANTS
description: Yale University and the United States Department of Health and Human Services have worked out an agreement that ends a three-year dispute over the reporting of federally financed research and other activities.

title: THE LITTLE BROOK THAT TUMBLED INTO TROUBLE
description: THE culprit, all those years, was Tercia Brook - a watercourse so unimpressive that no one has ever bothered to nail down the correct spelling of its name. (Some think it should be Tertia.) Nevertheless, the brook has produced controversy, not to mention property damage, that would not disgrace a good-sized river.

title: Jennifer Crewe to Marry Oliver Conant
description: Dr. and Mrs. Albert V. Crewe of Palos Park, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Elisabeth Crewe, to Oliver Conant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Conant of New York. The wedding is to be June 25.

title: South Africa Postpones Vote on Charter Changes
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha has postponed a referendum on his proposed constitutional changes, which would allow Asians and people of mixed race to be represented in a new Parliament alongside whites.

title: SPRING IS A GOOD TIME TO RECONDITION YOUR AIR-CONDITIONER
description: TO some it may seem a bit early to start thinking about the need for air-conditioning, but this is actually the best time of year to get your unit ready for the summer. By doing so you will avoid the possibility of an unpleasant surprise when you turn the machine on for the first time in the hot season and discover it is not working properly.

title: Leslie Ann Moraller and Neil C. Krauter to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Kendall Moraller of Fair Haven, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ann Moraller, to Neil Clark Krauter of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Frederick Krauter of Rumson, N.J. An October wedding is planned.

title: Jobless Marching to London
description: Sixty unemployed workers began a seven-week, 400-mile march to London today to ask for jobs. They were sent off by Michael Foot, leader of the opposition Labor Party, who said, ''I hope this march is going to help to awaken the conscience and understanding of the nation.'' He assailed the Government for tolerating unemployment of 13.6 percent, or 3.1 million people.

title: AN OUTSIDER IN L.A.
description: At the Academy Awards presentation at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion in Los Angeles the other week, we were treated not only to British, Italian, French and Austrian accents, but also to actual swatches of Spanish, Polish, German and Prehistoric, all of which served as a timely reminder of the increasing prominence and sophistication of the place named on Aug. 1, 1769, El Pueblo Nuestra Senora la Reina de los Angeles de Porciuncula (The Town of Our Lady Queen of the Angels of Porciuncula) - from which the queen departed long ago.

title: WEIGHING FUTURE OF HOUSE WITH A PAST
description: A HOUSE with historic significance in Southold is on the market. But the sole purchase offer has been from commercial investors who plan to demolish the house and build a fast-food chain in its place.

title: BECOMING MRS. ARTHUR WALEY
description: A Half of Two Lives By Alison Waley Illustrated, 326 pp, New York: McGraw-hill Book Co $16.95

title: Wilderness Life Isn't Easy
description: EVERYBODY knows that record numbers of Americans have been seeking recreation in the great outdoors, but now a new study suggests that the nation's devotion to the outdoor life may be even stronger than anyone had suspected.

title: MAIL SERVICE TOLD TO UPDATE SYSTEM
description: The United States Postal Service, praised for its progress as a reorganized agency in the 1970's, is headed for extinction unless it moves more boldly into the electronic age, according to the head of a panel that studied it for two years.

title: WINDOW ON ANCIENT TURKEY
description: SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of

title: FIFTEEN YEARS LEAVE THEIR MARK ON PINK FLOYD
description: Pink Floyd's first album and initial burst of popularity on the London rock scene came in the summer of 1967. It was the Summer of Love, L.S.D., and the most outlandish millennial expectations, and London's hippie community was buzzing with rumors. Flying saucers had landed and made contact with carefully chosen mystics and seers; the antichrist had been born and announced his identity to a terrified London couple; the worldwide destruction that would precede the dawning of the Aquarian Age was about to begin. Fashionably deckedout flower children exchanged news of the latest signs and portents at the Roundhouse, a London nightclub where they danced through the amoeba-like patterns of a light show to the ricocheting pings and beeps and ominously pulsating hum of Pink Floyd's futuristic spacerock.

title: SIBLING ANALYSTS MADE THE JUMP FORM CARE PACKAGES TO WALL STREETS
description: CHRISTOPHER C. DEMISCH and Wolfgang H. Demisch lean back on their chairs, which face each other across identical desks in their seventh-floor office at the First Boston Corporation. The office is large, but windowless, and the pale blue walls are lined with company annual reports: Lockheed. General Dynamics. Boeing.

title: RECITAL: SOPRANO, VIOLINIST
description: The truly joint recital, with two artists sharing equal billing, is all too rare. But Young Concert Artists presented just such a concert on Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y with the soprano Beverly Hoch and the violinist Daniel Phillips, in which both artists were accompanied by the pianist Margo Garrett.

title: LEBANON STEPPING UP SECURITY AFTER BOMBING
description: Lebanese troops are standing guard outside the American University of Beirut these days, part of the stepped-up security measures at foreign buildings ordered by the Lebanese Government in the aftermath of the bombing on Monday of the United States Embassy.

title: FREE PRESS-FAIR TRIAL (CONT'D)
description: JOURNALISTIC sensationalism surrounding the kidnapping-murder trial of Bruno Richard Hauptmann and the equally notorious Hall-Mills double-homicide case come to mind as New Jersey judicial authorities again grapple with the seemingly ageless controversy over the extent to which the press should be allowed to report criminal-trial procedures.

title: Sonny Rollins, Jazz Musician, Collapses on Town Hall Stage
description: Sonny Rollins, one of the country's leading jazz saxophonists, collapsed on stage at Town Hall last night, during one of his rare concert appearances.

title: Word Games; Writers' Block
description: Rumania, it appears, is the source of the latest thing in word processors. The keyboards of these computerized writing machines include keys to do things like DELETE WORD or DELETE PARAGRAPH.

title: N.J. DEATH PENALTY GETS A DAY IN COURT
description: After years of debate, New Jersey's new death penalty law was put to the test last week at a murder trial in Monmouth Superior Court. From its first application, what emerged most clearly was the enormous responsibility the new law gives the jury to decide who should live and who should die.

title: The N.S.A.'s Accountability
description: In his article ''The Silent Power of the N.S.A.'' (March 27), David Burnham writes that ''no laws define the limits of the National Security Agency's power'' and ''no Congressional committee subjects the agency's budget to a systematic, informed and skeptical review.''

title: 2 TO MISS COSMOS OPENER
description: The Cosmos will open the defense of their North American Soccer League title Sunday with two of their regular defenders missing. Franz Beckenbauer is still in Europe and Darryl Gee, destined to be the right fullback, sprained an ankle and will not play against the Blizzard here.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER

title: POSTINGS
description: With state and local agencies investigating the possible contamination of some Long Island homes with termite control chemicals, this might not seem like the best time to promote the idea of building all-wood house foundations.

title: Kathleen Ash to Wed John R. Lange in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry M. Ash 3d of Allamuchy, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Louise Ash, to John Richard Lange of Bedford Hills, N.Y., son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur N. Lange of Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Joan Dank Engaged to Glenn Butterton
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Milton Dank of Wyncote, Pa., of the engagement of their daughter, Joan Reva Dank, to Glenn Richard Butterton, son of Mrs. David Guthrie Alexander of Wezembeek-Oppem, Belgium, and the late Gale Houston Butterton of Los Angeles.

title: RUSSIANS MAY HAVE FEARED DISASTER IN SPACE
description: Accounts of the Soviet manned space flight that was aborted Friday indicate that the three astronauts underwent exceptional stress in their unsuccessful attempt to dock with an orbiting laboratory and their subsequent return to the earth.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: In 1974 when he was a star linebacker for the Anacostia High School football team in Washington, Carl Greene made a tackle that cost him the use of his left arm. He reinjured the arm that had been hurt in practice a few days earlier.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: Come fill the cup, and in the fires of spring Your Winter Garment of Repentance fling. MOST of Baldwin is just getting around now to taking old Omar's advice, the weather being what it hasn't been. For weeks under lead skies, only the occasional gold flash of forsythia or bluish flare of a Korean azalea, here and there, served notice that the equinox had really come and we could stop repenting 1983's winter of our discontent.

title: The 'Folly' of the MX Missile
description: Stansfield Turner's article on the MX missile reflected a thoughtfulness and sobriety all too rare in these troubled and passionate times (''The 'Folly' of the MX Missile,'' March 13). He argued cogently that United States security required a stable ''balance of terror,'' not a volatile arms race, with each country's finger constantly on the trigger. He made a convincing case that the MX would foster strategic instabiliy by engendering in Soviet minds the threat of a United States first strike. It is clear from his article that other strategic options, such as cruise missiles, provide the safest measure of security.

title: U.S. IS BRINGING STRONGER ACTION IN WASTE CASES
description: The Justice Department has begun a crackdown against illegal dumpers of hazardous wastes by bringing criminal charges before 25 grand juries in 14 states.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: THIS is what Dick Smith has in his basement: false teeth, plastic eyes, a little box marked ''liver spots and freckles,'' wax, putty, atomizers, blood pumps, syringes, adhesive tape, rubber tubing, tubing clamp and a gooey substance for making scars. He also has an oven, a huge motorized mixing bowl and an elaborate power saw.

title: COLLEGE BUYS 22D COPY OF DECLARATION
description: A recently discovered copy of the Declaration of Independence sold Friday morning at Christie's for $412,500 to Williams College. The sale was made minutes after the remainder of the money needed for its purchase was raised over the telephone by contributions from 20 of the college's alumni.

title: New Data on Jobless Voters
description: Members of Congress may have a leg up on Election Day if they've supported Federal aid for the jobless -or so Census Bureau data released last weekend seem to suggest.

title: Miss Curtis Plans to Wed Dr. Alan M. Gross in June
description: Rose Curtis of College Point, Queens, and Denis Curtis of Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Denise Curtis, to Dr. Alan Mark Gross, son of Cecilia Gross of New York and the late George Gross.

title: A CONCRETE APPROACH TO ART
description: IF YOU want to explore ''the new Hoboken,'' but do not know where to start, the Unicorn Cafe Bookstore at 518 Washington Street might be a good place.

title: A Low-Rent Legacy
description: Question: I recently bought a building with two five-room apartments and a retail store, which I operate. One of the apartments is rentcontrolled with a base rent of $52 a month. The former landlord never filed for rent increases. Do I have any recourse? The tenants are elderly and I do not want to cause them a hardship, but I cannot meet my expenses with the normal allowable increases. ... L.G., Brooklyn

title: A FEW DISSENTING THOUGHTS ON THE LOVE OF NATURE
description: WHEN spring unfolds, opinion pages are filled with articles singing the praises of the new season and celebrating Long Island's many natural wonders. I must confess that I always feel deeply ambivalent whenever I read these well-meant essays -essays that become positively rhapsodic as they extol the virtues of wind-swept beaches and glorious sunsets.

title: WURZBURG
description: To the Editor:

title: Karen M. Benore Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Charles A. Benore of Darien, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Karen Marie Benore, to Halsey M. Whitney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wayne Whitney, also of Darien. A July 3 wedding is planned. Miss Benore is in her junior year at the University of Texas at Arlington.

title: Sports of The Times; Playing With Pain
description: AS nimble in commerce as he is on the court, Paul Westphal immediately saw a benefit in the dark circle developing around his left eye.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: INDIA BY PALACE CAR, THE CARIBBEAN OFF SEASON
description: In a bygone era, maharajahs, viceroys and governors-general traveled the vastness of the Indian subcontinent in private trains or private railroad cars - ornate carriages upholstered in pink velvet, their windows curtained with fabric embroidered in silver or gold, their couches covered in plush and adorned with brass knobs.

title: N.Y.U. INTENSIFIES EFFORT TO PUT STUDENTS IN JOBS
description: In one of several identical cubicles, lined floor and wall with new beige carpeting, Cynthia Jeu, an economics student in an oversized dark blue New York University sweatshirt, sat listening as Juan Reyes, an employment counselor, spoke softly with her about preparing to seek a job.

title: THE BUNGLED INITIATIVE
description: It is a basic rule of foreign affairs. A great power does not launch big initiatives on difficult problems unless it is serious: unless its leaders are prepared to invest their time and effort, to persuade friends, to use muscle.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Miss Kimber to Marry A Printing Executive
description: Mr. and Mrs. Warren S. Kimber Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Martha's Vineyard, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Rhodes Kimber, to Paul Marion Gerrard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Gerrard of Mount Sinai, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

title: Roberta Trehub Is Married
description: The marriage of Roberta Leigh Trehub, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Trehub of Wellesley, Mass., to Stephen F. Hoechster, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ludwig Hoechster of Brooklyn, took place yesterday at Temple Beth Avodah in Newton, Mass. Rabbi Robert Miller performed the ceremony. The couple work for New York advertising agencies. The bride is an account executive with Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc. and her husband is an account supervisor with Ally & Gargano Inc.

title: Eject Mechanism
description: Raymond A. Peck, the head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, hit the road last week. He gave no reason for his resignation, but speculation in Washington had it that his new boss, Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Dole, had no desire to see more of the head-on collisions that marked Mr. Peck's dealings with Congress and consumer groups during his two-year tenure. He helped ease a number of safety requirements for auto manufacturers and was accused by one senator of being on a ''search and destory mission against any useful idea.''

title: CUOMO WINNING ON L.I. POST
description: WITH the opposition within his own party collapsing, Governor Cuomo will push ahead with the appointment of a Nassau Democrat, Harold D. Berger, as regional director of the state's Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Roosevelt's Days
description: To the Business Editor:

title: If Not Hitler's Hand, Whose?
description: If not a sensational find, the West German magazine Stern can certainly claim a sensational announcement: 60 volumes of diaries handwritten by Hitler between 1932 and 1945 have been found, or so the magazine said last week. Stern added that it will begin publishing the diaries tomorrow.

title:
STAMPS;
VOLUNTEERISM HAILED ON NEW COMMEMORATIVE
description: A commemorative for the role of volunteerism in America and the contribution of millions of volunteers to the national well-being has just been put out by the United States Postal Service. Originally scheduled for several months ago, the belated 20-cent stamp, which was issued with the barest advance notice, came out in Washington, D.C. on April 20 with first-day ceremonies at the White House. President Reagan was the principal participant.

title: Mary Neroda Affianced
description: Mary I. Neroda of Brooklyn Heights, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Ignatius Neroda, and Daniel J. O'Connor, son of Mrs. Denis M. O'Connor of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. O'Connor, plan to be married in September in East Meadow, L.I. Miss Neroda is a broker with the Corcoran Group, a New York real estate concern. The bridegroom, a widower, is with the security department at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I. He is a retired sergeant of the New York City Police Department. Miss Neroda's father was a pressman at The New York Times.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: GRAMERCY PARK
description: TO THE Rev. Stephen Garmey, sorting out the lore of Gramercy Park is like keeping a family album. From the archives of Calvary Church to what he hears ont he streets, he collects stories about the park, tidbits of information - even fables - and recounts them with affection.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE storm that lashed parts of the state last weekend and caused sporadic flooding had other repercussions for sea life and oceanfront residents alike, including an oil spill, the sinking of a fishing boat, a stranded dolphin and the reported beaching of 15 sea horses.

title: Miss Famolare to Wed Nicholas P. Heymann
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Famolare Jr., of New York and Florence have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bibiana Famolare, to Nicholas Paul Heymann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Heymann of Toledo, Ohio. A July 30 wedding is planned.

title: Joan Kingsly Is Engaged To Lawrence Gottesman
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sanford N. Kingsly of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Kingsly, to Lawrence Gottesman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gottesman of Red Bank, N.J.

title: SIMPLE ANSWERS
description: ALTERNATIVE AMERICA Henry George, Edward Bellamy, Henry Demarest Lloyd and the Adversary Tradition. By John L. Thomas. Illustrated. 399 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: WASHINGTON IRVING AS COLLECTOR
description: The 200th-anniversary celebration of the birth of Washington Irving has focused renewed attention on Sunnyside, the author's Tarrytown, N.Y., home, the period contents of which reveal much about the man and his times. Irving is described as something of an antiquarian by Joseph T. Butler, curator and director of Sleepy Hollow Restorations, which owns Sunnyside and other historic sites. That's because, as Mr. Butler points out, Irving pioneered in collecting antiques and chose a 17th-century Dutch farmhouse as his home, transforming it into what he called a ''snuggery.''

title: Corgi Is Winner
description: A 3-year-old Pembroke Welsh corgi, Ch. Wey Smut, owned by Rosemary and Arturo Carvallo of Elmont, L.I., was named best in show by Glen Sommers today at the Old Dominion Kennel Club of Northern Virginia show in Bull Run Regional Park. With 3,515 dogs, it was the largest show in the United States this year.

title: NEW CO-OP RULING AIDS TENANTS
description: A RECENT ruling by the State Attorney General's office will make tenants' cases stronger in instances where landlords are seeking to convert rental units into cooperative apartments. The ruling is expected to evoke a flurry of lawsuits.

title: PRINCETON SEMINARY PRESIDENT RETIRING
description: AFTER 24 years as president of Princeton Theological Seminary - a period during which the school's enrollment doubled - Dr. James Iley McCord will retire at the end of the academic year.

title: TEAM SPREADS 'GOSPEL' OF LACROSSE
description: CLUB lacrosse players not only love to play the game and drink beer afterward, but they also have a missionary zeal about the growth of their sport.

title: WHITHER THE SMOKE IN OLD SMOKESTACK INDUSTRIES?
description: Economic and political forecasters concentrating on the outlook for the emerging recovery found good signs again last week.

title: Sissy Bostwick Becomes a Bride
description: Marie Stokes Bostwick, daughter of Mrs. George H. Bostwick of Old Westbury, L.I., and Aiken, S.C., was married yesterday in Aiken to Charles M. Armstrong, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Armstrong of Kingsville, Tex. The Rev. Howard McKay Hickey of St. Thaddeus Episcopal Church in Aiken performed the ceremony at the Bostwick home.

title: THE SEASON FOR SHAD
description: IRENE LARSEN, up to her elbows in shad and shad roe, shrugs goodnaturedly. ''To me, it tastes like a sandy beach,'' she says, referring to roe, a delicacy that has been her bread and butter for 35 years.

title: Kathryn Hellstrom Will Become Bride Of Dr. Douglas S.T. Green, an Intern
description: Announcement has been made by David Ingemar Hellstrom of Framingham, Mass., of the engagement of his daughter, Kathryn Hellstrom, to Dr. Douglas S.T. Green, son of Mrs. Roger Starr of New York and the late David Eliot Green. A June wedding is planned.

title: Miss Avery, R. G. Renault Are Married
description: Andrea Louise Avery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin Avery Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and New York, was married yesterday to Richard Gilbert Renault, son of Genevieve Rossi of Versailles, France, and the late Gilbert Renault of Paris. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church.

title: Glenn, Hollings Make It Official: They're Running
description: After a countdown that lasted for months, John Glenn, who parlayed an orbit around the Earth two decades ago into a seat in the United States Senate, launched his Presidential campaign last week.

title: GIRL IS AWARDED $3 MILLION IN SUIT THAT FAULTED PROTECTION BY POLICE
description: A jury has awarded $3 million to a Bronx girl who was stabbed and mutilated by her father in 1975. The girl's suit had charged that the city had failed to provide her proper police protection.

title: Unionized Clergy
description: Some 100 ministers, priests and rabbis who worked for New York City as chaplains heard the call in September 1982: Unionize. Explaining that faith in the city's charity was not getting them enough pay, the chaplains voted to join District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.

title: PROGRAM FOR YOUNG ALCOHOLICS
description: DR. ROBERT F. STUCKY, a physician here, had been helping to rehabilitate alcoholics for a decade before he went to an Alcoholics Anonymous meeting in Minneapolis three years ago. He had seen a lot in that time; in a way, he thought he had seen it all.

title: DANCE: CONWAY TROUPE
description: The Carol Conway Dance Company's program Thursday night in the Washington Square Church was particularly attractive when Miss Conway's choreography was simple. Even more attractive were two dances in which Miss Conway managed to be simple in form but mysterious in content.

title: CONSUMER RATES
COUNTRY ARTISANS' GALLERY
description: For a little over three years artisans from all over the 13-state Appalachian region - quilters from Tennessee, potters from Pennsylvania and upstate New York, woodworkers from Georgia and West Virginia, glass blowers from North Carolina - have been shipping their finest work to the sales gallery at the Joe L. Evins Appalachian Center for Crafts in Smithville, Tenn. This retail outlet, a short detour from Interstate 40, is the largest in the Southeast for quality work by craftsmen and women who live in or near the Appalachian range.

title: CONCERT: BARENBOIM
description: The Orchestre de Paris and its conductor Daniel Barenboim were in New York this past week playing concerts in both the city's major orchestra halls. Thursday's concert at Carnegie Hall offered very familiar repertory - the Brahms Third Symphony, Debussy's ''La Mer'' and the second suite from Ravel's ''Daphnis et Chloe.'' Friday's at Avery Fisher Hall featured only one composer and two works but was the more interesting of the two.

title:
GARDENING;
HEDGES: ALWAYS POPULAR AND USEFUL
description: ONE wonders who might have been the first person to plant a hedge. It may have been a member of some tribe that decided to trade the nomadic way of life of the hunter and herder for that of the sedentary farmer. Families and flocks would have required protection against marauding neighboring tribes and wild predators, and crops planted in those earliest of gardens would have been at the mercy of domesticated and wild animals. Fences would have been nonexistent, for tools with which to make posts and boards would have been exceedingly primitive.

title: YANKS, WITH RAWLEY, SCORE 7-4 VICTORY
description: Billy Martin has safely made it past the first land mine of his third managerial tenure with the Yankees. In directing the team to a 7-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins at the Stadium yesterday, Martin lasted through the 15th game of the season. A year ago, Bob Lemon was let go after 14 games, with a 6-8 record. Yesterday's victory put the Yankees at 7-8.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
NAUTICAL NORTHPORT
description: As a place where folks always went down to the sea in ships, Northport has a past - and present - rich in things nautical. To explore this water-oriented heritage, the Northport Historical Museum has mounted an exhibition that, with early photographs, ship models, a diorama and vintage artifacts, tells the harbor's story as a source of food, recreation, sports and transportation. Running through the summer, ''Nautical Northport'' can be seen from 1 to 4:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Sundays at the museum, 215 Main Street. Admission is $1, or 50 cents for children and the elderly.RENAISSANCE FAIR

title: PRESIDENT HONORS AMERICANS KILLED BY EXPLOSION IN BEIRUT
description: In an emotional ceremony, President Reagan and other top Administration officials gathered tonight at Andrews Air Force Base to honor 17 Americans killed in last Monday's bombing of the U.S. Embassy in Beirut.

title: SPRING VEGETABLES IN STEWS
description: YOUNG spring vegetables are back in the markets again. Although these vegetables are superb when they are simply steamed or sauteed in a little butter, they also combine well with meats and complementary vegetables in light, delicate stews. Asparagus goes with chicken in white wine; fava beans and Swiss chard can be added to a golden lamb stew that has been simmered with lemon peel, paprika, cumin and turmeric. Baby carrots and artichoke hearts are fine foil to veal in a garlic and lemon-flavored sauce.

title: British Official Says Leftists Dominate Antinuclear Drive
description: Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine of Britain said today that leaders of Britain's antinuclear movement were ''full-time Socialists and Communists.''

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN FOOD REGULATION;
IS THE HOT DOG AN ENDANGERED SPECIES?
description: Gerber ''meat sticks,'' which have been on the market for 22 years without reported problems, will soon be carrying labels urging that ''to reduce the possibility of choking,'' consumers should ''serve these sticks only to toddlers who have learned to chew solid foods properly.''

title: RISING JAIL POPULATION CAUSING CONCERN
description: THE Westchester County Jail, a collection of low-rise brick structures on a grassy knoll here, looks benign on the outside. The County District Attorney calls it ''a country club compared to Attica and other upstate prisons.'' But a continuing influx of prisoners has kept it filled to capacity, and some officials are concerned about a possible further increase.

title: ABOUT BOOKS & AUTHORS
description: The Steel Industry

title: A BALANCHINE STAR REFLECTS ON CITY BALLET
description: The history of the New York City Ballet has been one of great ballerinas. But few have been so long and so closely identified with City Ballet as Suzanne Farrell, to many the prime interpreter of the work of George Balanchine, whose ballets serve as the company's matrix. ''I feel as if Suzanne is Balanchine,'' Stacy Caddell, a young City Ballet dancer, says.

title: Symphony Space Plans Spring Gala on May 9
description: Isaac Stern, John Rubinstein and Marilyn Sokol are among those who will take part in the Fourth Spring Gala on May 9 at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street

title: THINGS OF THIS WORLD
description: THE UNEXPECTED VISTA A Physicist's View of Nature. By James S. Trefil. Illustrated. 209 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $14.95.HOW LIFE LEARNED TO LIVE Adaptation in Nature. By Helmut Tributsch. Translated by Miriam Varon. Illustrated. 218 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $19.95.

title: Iran Reports 37 Dead In Iraqi Missile Attack
description: Thirty-seven people were killed, 210 were wounded and 200 houses and shops were destroyed or damaged when three long-range Iraqi missiles struck a residential area in the Iranian city of Dizful Friday night, the Iranian press agency said today.

title: PUTTING A CAP ON NUCLEAR COSTS
description: THE sharply rising cost of electricity is joining death and taxes as a certainty for Connecticut citizens. If your utility company happens to be building a nuclear facility, as is Northeast Utilities, the rate increases are likely to come more frequently. Recognizing the inevitable, the question is, ''How high is up?''

title: Yale Crew Wins
description: Yale's varsity crew won the Blackwell Cup today and only victories by Pennsylvania's freshman heavyweight crews prevented an Eli sweep of the 52d rowing of the regatta on the rainswollen Schuykill.

title: Scenery and Mood
description: To the Editor:

title: Racism Charged About Comment
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: TAIWAN FLIER DEFECTS TO CHINA WITH JET
description: A Taiwan air force pilot has defected to China with his reconnaissance aircraft, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: Lemon Law
description: As State Representative John J. Woodcock 3d of Connecticut saw it, the legal deck was stacked against the new-car buyer who got a defective product. ''The financial and emotional squeeze of a lemon car,'' he declared in April 1982, ''must be put on the manufacturer, where it belongs.''

title: Victoria W. Darlington Wed To Glenn Yoder 3d, a Banker
description: Victoria Wilde Darlington, daughter of Mrs. Grant G. Simmons Jr. of Atlanta, Upper Saranac Lake, N.Y., and Hilton Head Island, S.C., and Henry Darlington Jr. of New York, Dallas and Palm Beach, Fla., was married in New York yesterday to Glenn Yoder 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yoder Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C. The Rev. Charles Sheerin, chaplain of the Trinity-Pawling School, performed the ceremony in the Chapel of the Beloved Disciple at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, where the bride's grandfather, the late Rev. Dr. Darlington, was rector for many years.

title: Pamela Ramsdell, Teacher, Married To John Mitchell
description: Pamela Barclay Ramsdell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Alan Ramsdell of White Plains and Mantoloking, N.J., was married yesterday to John Tusting Mitchell, son of Capt. Billy Ross Mitchell, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Mitchell of Orange Park, Fla. The Rev. J. Norman Hall performed the ceremony at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in White Plains.

title: PETER QUENNELL AND FRIENDS
description: Since the age of 17, when his poems were included in Edward Marsh's famous anthology of ''Georgian Verse,'' Peter Quennell, now 78, has been a citizen of good standing in the English literary community, and in recent years he has emerged as one of its most eloquent and entertaining Boswells. In three volumes of memoirs - the latest, ''Customs and Characters,'' was published in January - he has used his considerable skills as a biographer and critic to create a portrait of his generation.

title: ONE AGAIN, 'WINGS' SOARS TO DRAMATIC HEIGHTS
description: With a riveting production of Arthur Kopit's ''Wings'' this Tuesday, on WNET/Channel 13 at 9 P.M., the ''American Playhouse'' series, now more than half-way through its second season, is proving once again to be a splendid asset for public television. So far in the current 39-week run that began in January, the new productions, totaling 20 in all, have included: a haunting black-and-white adaptation of Nathanael West's ''Miss Lonelyhearts,'' starring Eric Roberts in a film by Michael Dinner and Robert Bailey, with superb photography by Juan Ruiz-Anchia; a live broadcast of Thornton Wilder's ''The Skin of Our Teeth'' from San Diego's Old Globe Theater; ''The File on Jill Hatch,'' an often powerful three-part portrait of racial attitudes in this country and in England; and a moving biography of Medgar Evers, with the slain civil-rights leader depicted by Howard Rollins, in ''For Us, the Living.'' Combined with reruns from a strong season last year, that is the kind of programming lineup that commands serious and grateful attention.

title: 4 Connected With a Band Held on Rape Charges
description: A bass player and three road crewmen of a rock band called ''Grand Slamm'' were charged today with raping and kidnapping an 18-year-old woman, the police said.

title: IF YOU WANT TO MAKE MOVIES, LEARN TO BE A SALESMAN
description: Buried somewhere deep in my psyche, but still as restless as one of Val Lewton's unquiet dead, is the memory of the day I learned that it takes a good deal longer to make a movie than it does to watch it. I'm still not sure why I was suprised by this bit of arcane information, given to me by the same older brother who had earlier dropped the bombshell about Santa Claus. Perhaps because I had assumed, and still want to assume, that movies are life - the way things are. In a perfect world, I had believed, if one wanted to make a movie, one just went out and ran the camera for 63 or, maybe, 75 minutes, however long it took Hopalong Cassidy to settle matters at Bear Creek before riding off into the sunset.

title: A FORTNIGHT OPENS WITH A FEW FINALES
description: DIVERSITY is the word for the next two weeks, with everything from a Bach cantata to Israeli songs on the county's concert schedule. To begin with some finales, Friends of the Chappaqua Library winds up its ambitious dance, recital and chamber-music programs today at 7:30 P.M., when Rebecca Kelly leads her dance company in ''Exploring Lyrical, Humorous and Dramatic Themes.'' The Westchester Symphony celebrates the conclusion of its first season under the revitalizing music directorship of Martin Canellakis by giving its last concert twice: on April 30 at 8 P.M. is the regular subscription performance at Harrison High School, and the following evening at 7 o'clock the orchestra travels to Peekskill's Paramount Theater for an encore. The program on both occasions is a Spring Pops Gala, with crowd-pleasers such as Grieg's ''Peer Gynt Suite,'' Strauss's ''Die Fledermaus'' overture and - with the young prize-winner Jon Klibonoff as piano soloist - Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue.'' For tickets at Harrison, call 472-3595; at Peekskill, 739-2333.

title: Nuptials for Dana Schmidt
description: Dana Ruth Schmidt, daughter of Mrs. Joseph V. Buck of Wilton, Conn., and the late Louis Henry Schmidt Jr., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Edwards Bruno, son of Mrs. John J. Bruno of Norwalk, Conn., and the late Mr. Bruno. The Rev. Dr. Zednek Bednar performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Wilton.

title: ART
description: One of the most gifted artists to have come out of England in recent years is Tony Cragg, whose new sculptures can be seen at the Goodman Gallery, 24 West 57th Street.

title: LABOR SEEKS RETRAINING
description: UNTIL recently, many labor leaders talked lightly of the impact of n ew technology on the workplace. In the 1950's and 60's, dire w arnings had been sounded about the impact of automation, but many oft hese warnings did not come true. And many labor men were lulled intob elieving that this time, as before, warnings about new technologies a nd their effects were alarmist. Job training for young workers, or t he disadvantaged, or minority workers - this was important, the l abor leaders said. But there was little talk of the need for r etraining.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: WHEN the Connecticut River Foundation dedicates its new Thomas A. Stevens Library at 4 P.M. today at the foot of Main Street in Essex, it will be an occasion of pride mixed with sadness.

title: Karen S. Algus Will Wed Marc Gedansky on June 5
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Algus of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Sue Algus, to Marc Gedansky, son of Evelyn Gedansky of Haverhill, Mass., and the late Nathan Gedansky. The wedding is to be June 5.

title: WURZBURG
description: To the Editor:

title: Shots and Echoes In Brink's Case
description: Those with dim memories of the ''Days of Rage'' got a replay of sorts last week. In Federal District Court in Manhattan, opening statements by the Government set out to prove conspiracy in the trial involving the 1981 Brink's robbery and murders, while the other side called the defendants ''freedom fighters'' and spurned the charges.

title: LISTENING AT HOME TO THE NEW COMPACT DISKS
description: Most of what has been written thus far about the new compact digital players and disks (known as CDs) has been written either by technical experts or by music critics who listened to the new system under controlled, showcase conditions. But now the Sony player is actually on the market, and CBS-Sony has released the first batch of CDs. From the perspective of the music lover, rather than the sound cultist, what are the new disks like - when heard on a player plugged into one's home system?

title: GLENN'S NEW CONCORD
description: At this early stage of the 1984 Presidential election, attention is focused on statistics and techniques: who's ahead in the polls, who has raised the most money, and put together the best organization, and attracted the most support from labor, the blacks, the conservationists, the antinuclear voters, etc.

title: Sgt. Michelle E. Smith Wed at Naval Station
description: Sgt. Michelle Elaine Smith and Sgt. Lawrence E. McNamee Jr., both of the Marine Corps, were married yesterday in the chapel of Naval Weapons Station Earle in Colts Neck. N.J. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Smith Jr. of Highlands, N.J. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. McNamee of Woodbury, N.J. Lieut. Comdr. John J. Egan, Chaplains Corps, U.S.N., a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Leslie Stephen
description: What makes John Russell assert in his ''Reading and Writing'' essay (March 27) that Leslie Stephen is ''best known today as the father of Virginia Woolf''? Best known to whom? Such a remark is perhaps more revelatory of the insular world of literary criticism than of Stephen's present reputation. If the four fascinating volumes of his ''Hours in a Library'' are less read than formerly, ''The English Utilitarians'' and the two-volume ''History of English Thought in the 18th Century'' are still authoritative and regularly cited, no doubt by many who are unaware that Sir Leslie's fame is supposed to have sunk into that of a more illustrious progeny. FRED SOMKIN, Ithaca, N.Y.

title: A Correction
description: An article about Syracuse University's lacrosse team in the sports section last Sunday omitted the name of another major undefeated team. It is Cornell University.

title: Correction
description: A photograph of John F. Kennedy that appeared in the issue of April 17 was incorrectly dated. The correct date is 1963.

title: O'ROURKE ASKS REAGAN FOR TROOPS IN INDIAN POINT PLAN
description: ''IT took five letters, two telegrams and 15 telephone calls,'' County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said Wednesday in a telephone call from the White House, ''but we made it.'' He had just met with President Reagan in an effort to promote a plan that would enlist Federal troops in a nuclear emergency.

title: Sears Sets Pace for Tar Heels' Lacrosse
description: When Willie Scroggs, lacrosse coach at North Carolina, describes his all-America goalie, Tom Sears, superlatives abound: ''He is an exceptional athlete with great anticipation. He has great speed and confidence in handling the ball. He plays with intensity and a degree of enthusiasm that allows him to do just a little bit better.''

title: PUTNAM ACCUSED OF A CONFLICT
description: AN AD HOC coalition of enviromentalists, trade unionists and firefighters that has been supporting the state's proposed Community and Workers Right to Know Act has filed a conflict of interest charge against Borden R. Putnam, the state's Commissioner of Commerce and Economic Development.

title: MOQUECA: A TASTE OF BAHIA
description: Night was falling on Salvador, and the rising wind off the ocean stirred the coconut palms on the beach. At a nearby shorefront home, Carlos Bastos, an internationally known painter, and Jorge Amado, Brazil's best-known writer, were carrying on a cheerfully rowdy conversation.

title: PANEL WAS DIVIDED ON BID BY WAGNER FOR SCHOOLS POST
description: Six of the 13 members of a panel set up to review the credentials of Robert F. Wagner Jr. for the post of New York City schools chancellor considered him qualified, participants said yesterday.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE deadline is approaching for visual, performing and literary artists and arts organizations to sign up for this year's Celebration of the Arts, scheduled for Labor Day weekend on the grounds of the County Center for the Fine Arts in Roslyn Harbor.

title: NEW PRIORITY: TECHNOLOGICAL LITERACY
description: COLLIN FISHER, a 14 year-old freshman at Brooklyn Technical High School, clutched a large chunk of hardened plastic foam at the Stauffer Chemical research facility in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., and explained where it came from. ''They poured two liquids together - it looked like mustard,'' she said. ''And then it started to grow.''

title: 'SHOW BOAT' SAILS INTO THE PRESENT
description: ''Show Boat,'' by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d, arrived at the Ziegfeld Theater on Dec. 27, 1927, riding on the biggest advance sale recorded up to that time. It was a year when no fewer than 53 new musicals opened on Broadway, including major hits by the Gershwins (''Funny Face'') and Rodgers and Hart (''A Connecticut Yankee''). Brooks Atkinson hailed ''Show Boat'' in The New York Times as ''a captivating production ...woven of beauties.'' George Gershwin had high praise for it. Richard Rodgers called it ''a trailblazing musical.''

title: Dutch Treat
description: To the Editor:

title: Wilhelm Reich
description: To the Editor:

title: LEAVE SOME ROOM FOR THE LIBERAL ARTS
description: ''RENDER therefore unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's; and unto God the things that our God's.'' Jesus's evasive reply to the Pharisees acknowledges the conflicting claims of the secular and spiritual world. The history of the efforts to mediate between the material and the spiritual, moral, intellectual and esthetic - and of giving each fear its just due - has traditionally been told through humanistic or liberal-arts education.

title: No Headline
description: April 24, 1983 NONFICTION ALTERNATIVE AMERICA: Henry George, Edward Bellamy, Henry Demarest Lloyd and the Adversary Tradition. By John L. Thomas. 9 FRIDA: A Biography of Frida Kahlo. By Hayden Herrera. 10 FROM IMMIGRANTS TO ETHNICS: The Italian Americans. By Humbert S. Nelli. 14 A HALF OF TWO LIVES. By Alison Waley. 10 HOW LIFE LEARNED TO LIVE: Adaptation in Nature. By Helmut Tributsch. 7 KANBAN: Shop Signs of Japan. By Dana Levy, Lea Sneider and Frank B. Gibney. 11 THE LIFE OF HERBERT HOOVER: The Engineer, 1874-1914. By George H. Nash. 11 MAN AND THE NATURAL WORLD: A History of the Modern Sensibility. By Keith Thomas. 8 THE NEXT AMERICAN FRONTIER. By Robert B. Reich. 1 THE ONLY LIVING WITNESS. By Stephen G.
