Michaud and Hugh Aynesworth. 16 PROMETHEAN FIRE: Reflections on the Origin of Mind. By Charles J. Lumsden and Edward O. Wilson. 7 SERVING WOMEN: Household Service in Nineteenth-Century America. By Faye E. Dudden. 14 SOUTHERN HONOR: Ethics and Behavior in the Old South. By Bertram Wyatt-Brown. 8 SPHERES OF JUSTICE: A Defense of Pluralism and Equality. By Michael Walzer. 1 THE UNEXPECTED VISTA: A Physicist's View of Nature. By James S. Trefil. 7 FICTION THE AVENGING ANGEL. By Rex Burns. 21 FAMOUS ALL OVER TOWN. By Danny Santiago. 12 GOODBYE GOLIATH. By Elliott Chaze. 21 HEARTBURN. By Nora Ephron. 3 HERE TO GET MY BABY OUT OF JAIL. By Louise Shivers 12 ICEBREAKER.

title: SUN VALLEY'S OTHER SEASONS
description: Getting to Sun Valley is, well, a quarter of the fun. It is not one of the most accessible of resorts, which is nally created by Averell Harriman to allow the Union Pacific Railroad to cash in on the winter sports trade. Scheduled passenger runs ended in the early 1960's, and the occasional wintertime Snowball Express made its last journey in 1968.

title:
LEISURE;
DOGWOODS: WILL THEY SURVIVE?
description: One of the most splendid sights in spring is the fleecy white flowering dogwood. But in the Northeast these trees show unmistakable symptoms of decline.

title: REDISTRICTING PLANNED FOR WESTCHESTER BOARD
description: The Westchester County Board of Legislators may have its first black representative next year under a redistricting plan submitted this week to a committee of the 17-member body.

title: JAZZ: BUDDY RICH, BAND
description: After suffering a heart attack in January, followed by triple bypass surgery, Buddy Rich was back at his drums again on Thursday evening at the Bottom Line, leading his big band and giving no overt indication that anything had happened.

title: NEW CITY ASSESSMENT POLICY HURTS BROWNSTONE SALES
description: With the decline in mortgage interest rates over the last year houing activity in general has improved across the board. Sales of new and existing housing have picked up and so have construction starts.

title: RUM, EIGG, MUCK, CANNA
description: Off the jagged coastline of western Scotland lie more than 600 islands. A group of them near Ardnamurchan Point, the westernmost tip of the British mainland, form the Inner Hebrides. Four of these - Rum, Eigg, Muck and Canna - constitute the Small Isles Parish. Three - Eigg, Muck and Canna - are farmed by tiny resident communities headed by a laird and totaling less than a hundred people. The fourth and largest, Rum, is a wild and magnificent nature reserve, the southern part studded by craggy hills rising to 2,664 feet with Norse names like Barkeval, Hallival, Askival and Trollaval -''mountain of the goblins.''

title: Fighting Crime With Legislation
description: Certainly, Harry Ellerton of East Meadow, in the Opinion Page of March 6, reflected succinctly what many residents of the metropolitan area are thinking today (''Where's the Legislation to Help Combat Violent Crime?'').

title: Connors and Edmondson Reach Final
description: Jimmy Connors moved one step closer to winning the Alan King-Caesars Palace title for a fourth time when he outlasted Hank Pfister, 6-3, 1-6, 7-5, in a semifinal match today.

title: Eva Margaret Nutt Marries Robert Nies, a Lawyer
description: Eva Margaret Nutt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Tysen Nutt of Scotch Plains, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Edwin Nies, son of William Arthur Nies of Little Falls, N.J., and Mrs. Joseph Simmons of Southwest Harbor, Me. The Rev. Henry Schreitmueller performed the ceremony in the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scotch Plains.

title: Susan Thompson to Wed Paul Thomas Ciborowski
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Wright Thompson of Summit, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Ruth Thompson, to Paul Thomas Ciborowski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Peter Ciborowski of Baltimore.

title: Malta
description: To the Editor:

title: GANDHI'S U.S. DEBT, PAID IN FULL
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 2 P.M. In the finale of a three-game series, Frank Viola, the former St. John's star, opposes Ron Guidry. (Television - Channel, 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Braves, doubleheader, at Atlanta. After these games, the Mets visit Cincinnati Tuesday and Wednesday before returning to Shea Stadium to meet the Braves next weekend. (Television - Channel 9, 1:40 P.M. Radio - WHN-AM, 1050; 1:40 P.M.) Basketball Knicks vs. 76ers at Philadelphia, opening game of Eastern Conference semifinal series. (Television -Channel 2, 3:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW, 1130 3:30 P.M.) Celtics vs. Atlanta Hawks, at Boston. This is the deciding game of the three-game miniseries, and the winner will meet the Milwaukee Bucks in the other Eastern Conference semifinal. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M.) Suns vs. Denver Nuggets, at Phoenix. This is the deciding game of this miniseries, and the winner will meet San Antonio. (Television - ESPN, 10 P.M.) Boxing Alexis Arguello vs. Claude Noel, 10 rounds, junior welterweights, at the Sands Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. (Television - Channel 4, 4:30 P.M.) Eusebio Pedroza vs. Rocky Lockridge, 15 rounds, W.B.A. featherweight championship, at Bormio, Italy. This is the 16th title defense for Pedroza, who is 34-3-1 with 23 knockouts. Lockridge is 27-2 with 23 knockouts. (Television - Channel 7, 4:45 P.M.) Football Boston Breakers vs. Philadelphia Stars at Philadelphia's Veterans Stadium. (Television - Channel 7, 1:30 P.M.) Hockey Oilers vs.

title: 3 Kentucky Prisoners Escape From Jail
description: Three McCracken District Jail inmates threatened prison officials with a gun and knife and escaped today, the authorities said.

title: Festival Announcements
description: One-minute announcements of coming events in the Britain Salutes New York Festival will be broadcast four times daily on WNYC-FM (94). The broadcasts will be heard throughout the day, and will run through May. In addition, the station will present a two-and-a-half hour program, ''The 20th-Century English Musical Renaissance,'' on May 2 at 8 P.M. Among those whose music and voices will be heard are Ralph Vaughan Williams, Benjamin Britten, Andre Previn, Yehudi Menuhin, Aaron Copland and Nadia Boulanger.

title: FORMER AIDE SAYS U.S. IGNORES MINING VIOLATIONS
description: The Interior Department is filing virtually no criminal actions against violators of the strip-mining law and is delinquent in collecting millions of dollars in civil penalties and fees from violators, according to a lawyer recently dismissed by the department.

title: A HOME-GROWN COMPANY FROM HELSINKI VISITS THE MET
description: At home in Helsinki, the Finnish National Opera occupies a veritable bandbox of a theater. Built for Russian soldiers once garrisoned in the city, the Victorian lemon-with-white-trim house seats only about 550, suffers an orchestra pit that holds fewer than 50, and possesses a stage too small to accommodate Wagner properly.

title: SHAW TAKES A TURN WITH GREELEY STREET
description: THEORETICALLY, it is idealistic for a new theater to follow a policy of producing new plays exclusively. Realistically, what it needs to survive and to thrive - is an occasional touch of the tried-and-true with, preferably, a legitimate stage name attached.

title: EXPULSIONS TIED TO FEAR OF TECHNOLOGY LEAKS
description: The expulsion this week of three Soviet diplomats accused of spying was part of a campaign by Western nations to crack down on the illegal transfer of sensitive technology to the Soviet Union and the Communist bloc, according to Reagan Administration officials.

title: MUSIC: CLASSICAL VS. JAZZ
description: For decades, jazz and classical composers have eyed each other over the fence. Classical composers envy the melodic verve, spontaneity and open emotion of improvisation; jazz musicians look to the larger scale, the coloristic and rhythmic flexibility and the respect given classical music.

title: Times Reporter Wins Award For His Articles on Congress
description: Martin Tolchin, Congressional correspondent for The New York Times, will receive the 1982 Everett McKinley Dirksen Award for Distinguished Reporting of Congress.

title: REVUE: 'CORKSCREWS!'
description: One could scarcely imagine a more economical use of talent than is found in ''Corkscrews!'' a compact revue that takes over the tiny stage at Palsson's, 158 West 72d Street, on Monday nights at 11, when the long-running ''Forbidden Broadway'' is off. It is the work of three people - Tony Lang, who wrote the sketches and lyrics, Arthur Siegel, who composed most of the music, and Miriam Fond, who staged it. The entire cast consists of Miss Fond, Mr. Lang and Mr. Siegel.

title: CARRINGTON WARNS ON EAST-WEST TIES
description: Lord Carrington, the former British Foreign Secretary, has issued a warning to the West that ''the dehumanization'' of relations with the Soviet Union ''would be the quickest road to catastrophe.''

title: No Headline
description: Francis Clines is correct when he states that Seamus Heaney is a great admirer of the late Robert Lowell.

title: Index; International
description: Around the World 5 Greens may be factor in Austrian election today 6 Lord Carrington issues warning on relations with Soviet Union 9 House panel schedules a vote on military aid to El Salvador 10 Andropov compares U.S. Latin policy to Moscow's Afghan role 10 Britons in Argentina get threatening phone calls 11 Embassy bombing casts shadow on 5,000 Americans in Lebanon 13 or face extinction 27 Job-training bills proposed in Al- bany Assembly 35 U.S. agrees to defer oil leasing off L.I. and Virginia 36 General Many of Hawaii's 44,000 public employees ponder a strike 17 heart bypass 53 Style Two baseball wives call it as they see it 54 Obituaries Buster Crabbe, former swimmer and actor 33 Features/Notes Man in the News: Gordon M. Am- bach, state education chief 30

title: Southern Accent Garnishes the Pulitzer Prizes
description: Speaking with the same brutal honesty through characters seeking to control their own lives, two women of the South received Pulitzer Prizes last week - Alice Walker cited for a novel ''at once political and spiritual,'' and Marsha Norman for a ''deeply moving'' drama.

title: Wagner's Skills Don't Match the Job, Says State
description: In Robert F. Wagner Jr., the Board of Education thought it had a Schools Chancellor with an unrivaled knowledge of the city and how it works. But last week State Education Commissioner Gordon M. Ambach ruled that Mr. Wagner didn't know his way around a classroom and refused to approve him as head of the nation's largest school system.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Outfits That Begin With Size 0

title: Filipinos Demand Release of a Mayor
description: Thousands of people marched through this southern Philippine city today demanding the release of their Mayor, who was jailed last Sunday on orders of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: WHERE TO EARN AN MBRRR
description: THE oak trees, survivors only in a more temperate climate, stop about five miles south. The sub Arctic begins here, and a small group of researchers and students wants to know more about it.

title: VERMONT CONTINUES TO RESIST RISE IN DRINKING AGE
description: For the second consecutive year, Gov. Richard A. Snelling has vetoed a bill to raise the legal drinking age in this state to 19 years from 18. His veto means that Vermont continues to go against a national trend and will have the lowest drinking age in the region.

title: FOR A PRODUCTIVE, JUST AMERICA
description: THE NEXT AMERICAN FRONTIER By Robert B. Reich. 324 pp. New York: Times Books. $16.60.

title: Barbara McDonald to Wed
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. James P. McDonald of Latham, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Barbara J. McDonald, to Robert P. Moriarty, son of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Moriarty of Fairfield, Conn. A July 17 wedding is planned. Miss McDonald is a systems engineer with the International Business Machines Corporation in Harrison, N.Y. Her fiance is an associate with the Bridgeport, Conn., law firm of Pullman, Comley, Bradley & Reeves.

title: Dorothy W. Mayo To Wed in August
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Frederic B. Mayo of Swampscott, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Dorothy Ward Mayo, to John Leonard Moore 3d, son of Mrs. R. Norman Tottenham-Smith of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mr. Moore Jr. An August wedding is planned.

title: Marathon Marvel
description: Perhaps never in the 87-year history of the Boston Marathon has the 121st finisher received as much acclaim as Joan Benoit got last week.

title: WOMEN AND BLACKS GAINED IN JOBS, U.S. SAYS
description: Over the past decade almost half the nation's household servants left their work, many for better pay as bus drivers, bartenders, house painters and salesmen, according to Census Bureau officials.

title: What a Waste!
description: The best and the brightest tend to be drawn to the ''most expensive and least efficient'' legal system in the world, according to no less an authority than Derek C. Bok, the president of Harvard University and former dean of the law school.In his annual report to the Harvard overseers, Mr. Bok said law schools were partly to blame for the ''massive diversion of exceptional talent'' into pursuits that contribute little to society. High-priced lawyers from top law schools would do better to follow the enlightened example of physicians and other professionals, he suggested.

title: ROAD TO CAMP KOM-PU-TAH
description: WHEN Mark Casway's parents first suggested that he spend a couple ofw eeks at a summer camp learning computers, the 14-year-old from H artford was not too excited. This summer he's going back for a thirdt ime.

title: STAGE: 'TAKING STEAM,' LIFE ON THE SUNSET SIDE
description: ''Taking Steam,'' the play by Kenneth Klonsky and Brian Shein at the Jewish Repertory Theater on East 14th Street, has no relation to other steam dramas this season. This one is a slice of life in a health club, an aging spa where bagels and cream cheese and maybe a drink or two go down with the exercises of the Jewish members who are growing old along with the place.

title: Mary Cummings, Teacher, Is Wed To D.B. Johnsen
description: Mary C. Cummings, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cummings of Providence, R.I., was married yesterday in New York to Daniel B. Johnsen, son of Mrs. Del Stelling of Burnsville, Minn., and Dr. Henry Johnsen of Edina, Minn. The Rev. Normand J. DeMers performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: FOSTER PARENT FOR THE SCHOOLS: BUSINESS
description: YEAR-OLD Lanorda Chapman, a fifth-grader from the George Washington Carver Elementary School, has a career goal: She wants to be a bank teller. And Lanorda has a fairly accurate idea of what her chosen career involves, though she has never been inside a bank.

title: JOB-TRAINING MEASURES INTRODUCED IN ALBANY
description: Assembly Democrats proposed a series of measures this week to train workers who have been laid off, as well as those just entering the work force, for jobs in such growing fields as high technology and service businesses.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MADRID
description: The picadores and banderilleros are back in the bullrings after settling their strike. Workmen are putting in red and yellow tulips around the fountains and statues on the Castellana. Waiters are serving at sidewalk cafes, and parks are sprouting tables and chairs almost as quickly as the almond trees are blossoming.

title: A TRAILBLAZER WHEN FOUNDED IN 1883, OBERLIN IS STILL BENT ON DOING GOOD
description: IT is probably significant that among the nation's top small institutions of higher learning Oberlin College, which is celebrating its 150th year, has no difficulty describing itself. Serious. Studious. Intense. Bent on doing good in the world, in making the world better, for that matter. In its century and a half, while Harvard worried about the classics and Yale about God, Oberlin worried about the state of America and the world beyond. The fruit of these concerns was a pioneering 19th-century program in which Oberlin, unlike any other college in the nation at that time, accepted blacks and women to its campus.

title: The Good Life in North Carolina
description: Ever since my Army service in the Carolina maneuvers in 1941, I have been in love with North Carolina (''The Good Life in North Carolina,'' by Wendell Rawls Jr., March 20). The warm hospitality shown to a damned Yankee has rarely been equaled in my wide travels.

title: Sensitive Article On Divorce
description: It is not my style to write a letter to the editor. However, I was so impressed with Phyllis Bernstein's recent article (''Coping With Divorce in Later Life''), I felt compelled to write.

title: Philadelphia Rail Union To Cross Picket Line
description: A rail union that has been honoring picket lines at the city transit authority since March 15 has voted to cross the lines next week, but train service is not expected to resume on the struck line.

title: PROTECTIONISM RISING, SO WORLD TRADE ISN'T
description: If the frequency of high-level meetings were an indication of economic health, the world would appear to be on the verge of one of its most buoyant periods of growth.

title: PURSUING FISCAL ORDER AMID 'PLANNED CHAOS'
description: It seemed poetic coincidence last week that as scientists gathered in Baltimore to debate the nature of gigantic holes found in the universe, the politicians of Washington were concocting fresh strategies for dealing with a void newly poked in their budgetary cosmos. The scientists squared off in two schools for the ''top-down'' and ''bottom-up'' theories of forming the universe. Much the same way, the politicians, including a reluctant President Reagan, shifted from the committee method of shaping a budget to the far more galactic approach of trying to create a fiscal plan on the floor of the full Senate.

title: The New* Corvette Makes Its Debut
description: FIRST off, let's get the asterisk out of the way: There is no 1983 Corvette. That is going to put a gap in the data books, but it doesn't mean anything more. Chevrolet has very definitely produced an '83 model, even if it is called an '84, and the statisticians are going to have to settle for the fact that their loss is our gain. The newest Chevy is one of the supercars of the world.

title: THE DIMINISHED ALLURE OF ANNUITIES
description: IN the fast-changing world of consumer financial products, annuitiesc onjure up the image of high-button shoes, and many investors' eyes g laze over at the mention of them. Yet until recently, one p articular variety - the single-premium deferred annuity - has been o ne of the hottest-selling items around, offering investors an a ttractive way to build a tax-sheltered retirement nest egg.

title: THE MEANING OF 'TRYOUT'
description: town'' trial runs, the plays that open on or off Broadway often make the trip through round-about, unpredictable routes.

title: AFTER THE RAIL STRIKE, LIFE RETURNS TO NORMAL-SORT OF
description: THOMAS PAPPAN was flipping fried eggs on the grill at the Commuter Coffee Company at the Westport railroad station. Before he could give his attention to the hash-brown potatoes, he wiped his hands on a white apron so that he could extend one to a customer who had just walked in.

title: NUCLEAR ARMS FOE IS STILL AN OPTIMIST
description: HIROSHIMA and Auschwitz conjure up images of humankind's darker side. They are places where 20th-century technology meshed with political motivations to bring massive death.

title: OTHER TREES TO CONSIDER IN PLACE OF DOGWOODS
description: The decline of the native dogwood, may force gardeners to consider other small specimen trees to grace their properties. Magnolias, crabapples and Chinese dogwoods are commonly seen, but too much of the same thing gets boring even, in a home garden.

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: The recovery is slowly but surely marching ahead. At least that's what the newest batch of Government statistics seems to indicate. Gross national product rose at a 3 percent annual rate in the first quarter, lower than the Government's ''flash'' estimate of 4 percent, but still the best showing since early 1981. Personal income gained a strong six-tenths of 1 percent in March, brightening the prospects for a revival in consumer spending. Consumer prices rose a mere onetenth of 1 percent, increasing the likelihood of continued noninflationary growth. And the nation's factories operated at 69.4 percent of capacity, the highest rate since last summer.

title: Save the Theaters Unit Plans Benefit Tonight
description: A benefit revue, ''Theater Lights,'' will be presented tonight at 8:30 o'clock in the Savoy Theater, 141 West 44th Street, by Save the Theaters Inc. The show will raise matching funds for grants by the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Trust for Historic Preservation for a preservation, development and management plan for Broadway theaters.

title: NUMBER OF CONSULTANTS ON THE RISE
description: INSTEAD of leaving her Greenwich home early each morning bound for the nearby offices of the Talon-American Corporation, a ritual she followed for seven years, Carol Lindstrum works as a marketing consultant from a roll-top desk in her foyer.

title: The Mayor Acts Affirmatively
description: Mayor Koch rewrote City Hall's affirmative action policy last week amid charges that he was trying to rewrite history as well. Expressing disappointment in public that private prodding had not persuaded his commissioners to hire more minority-group members, Mr. Koch ordered them to inform him of all vacant positions which pay $20,000-a-year or more and for which there are no lists of Civil Service candidates. The Mayor then will have two weeks to put forth the names of black, Hispanic and female candidates recommended by civic and political groups.

title: Special for Spring
description: As the days get longer and the air grows warmer, New York City's trade book publishers are perking up a bit. Several, it seems, are currently inclined to view the recent past as a period of adjustment rather than a prelude to disaster.

title: RANGERS TEARY-EYED OVER SEASON'S END
description: Ed Mio was dressed and ready to leave, wearing a nubby tweed jacket and a tie, his shag haircut neatly combed. The Rangers' goaltender could have passed for a young businessman ready for a night on the town, at least until someone noticed the very red rims of his eyes.

title: Turtle Land
description: Some taxpayers thought it was a bit expensive - $519,000 for a 132-acre swamp in Putnam County - but the New York State Commissioner of Environmental Conservation said in July 1981 that the purchase was necessary to protect the bog turtle from extinction in the state.

title: The Price of the A.T.& T. Breakup; GET READY FOR PHONE BILLS TO DOUBLE
description: ON Jan. 1, 1984, the telcommunications industry as we know it today w ill come to a swift end, when the American Telephone and Telegraph C ompany divests itself of its 22 local operating companies.

title: PERFORMANCES MARK NATIONAL DANCE WEEK
description: FROM today through next Sunday, dancers throughout the country will be doing their best to carry out the theme of National Dance Week: ''Keep America Dancing.''

title: DODGERS DEFEAT PIRATES
description: Jose Morales, a pinch-hitter, doubled in the winning run in the seventh inning, and Pedro Guerrero contributed a two-run home run today in a 3-2 victory by the Los Angeles Dodgers over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: CITY PUTS HOUSING BARGAINS ON THE BLOCK
description: ''O WN a Piece of New York City,'' read the sign in the lobby of 1 Police Plaza. Just a few feet away, about 800 prospective bidders were crowding into the 700-seat Police Headquarters auditorium for a crack at purchasing city-owned residential property.

title: BRITISH URBAN AIDES TAKE NEWARK TOUR
description: WHAT do Newark, N.J., and Newark-on-Trent, England, have in common other than their names? According to American and British urban affairs specialists who have compared notes on strategies for attracting private investment to distressed urban areas, there are a number of similarities.

title:
CAMERA;
SUMMER WORKSHOPS FOR VACATION TIME LEARNING
description: Summer workshops on photography are an ideal way to combine vacation time with the study of photography. They enable the enthusiast to spend anywhere from one day to a week or more learning more about his or her favorite activity, and there is enough variety to offer something for everyone, from beginner to expert. The surroundings are always pleasant and accommodations range from plush to spartan.New York City

title: WASHINGTON
description: To the Editor:

title: Wadkins Leads by a Stroke
description: Hal Sutton three-putted the final hole and let Lanny Wadkins take a one-stroke lead today in the third round of the $400,000 MONY-Tournament of Champions.

title: 'RACIST SOPHISTRY' ON WORLD WAR II INTERNMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. SEEKS TO GET ISRAELIS TO YIELD ON ARMY PULLOUT
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that they hoped the participation of Secretary of State George P. Shultz would prompt Israel to make concessions in negotiations on troop withdrawals from Lebanon.

title: Ireen Eve Kudra Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Kudra of Washington Crossing, Pa., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ireen Eve Kudra, to Roland Foster Miller Jr., son of Mrs. Donald L. John of Sarasota, Fla., and the late Mr. Miller.

title: Wurzburg
description: To the Editor:

title: Starling Wins and Gains 2 Welterweight Titles
description: The welterweight Marlon Starling of Hartford scored a unanimous 12-round decision over Kevin Howard of Philadelphia to capture the United States Boxing Association and North American Boxing Federation titles today at the Hartford Civic Center.

title: FILMING A RAY BRADBURY FANTASY
description: For the last 50 years, Ray Bradbury has protected himself against the world by spewing out allegories of civilization's eventual end in fire, ice, nuclear rain or silence. ''Every single day for 50 years, if I can get to my typewriter by 9 o'clock, by 10:30 I'm protected against the world,'' he says.

title: Virginia R. Perry, A Teacher, Weds Peter Worcester
description: Virginia Riker Perry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt O. Perry Jr. of Southport, Conn., was married there yesterday to Peter Campbell Worcester, son of Dr. and Mrs. James N. Worcester Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Stephen P. Chinlund performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: COUNTING THE CASUALTIES IN BEIRUT AND BEYOND
description: It is rare in Lebanon that a single act of violence touches the deepest emotions of this hard-bitten nation. The bombing of the American embassy in Beirut last Monday was such an occasion. The explosion at the United States diplomatic mission first shocked, then appalled and finally frightened the residents of the Lebanese capital. It was an emotional bull's-eye that has set off political tremors that are likely to be felt in Lebanon and the Middle East for months.

title: HE COULD SEE GOLD THROUGH THE GROUND
description: THE LIFE OF HERBERT HOOVER The Engineer, 1874-1914. By George H. Nash. Illustrated. 768 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $25.

title: SUNDAY, APRIL 24, 1983
description: International

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: ICEBREAKER By John Gardner. 301 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $10.95. THE LONESOME GODS By Louis L'Amour. 450 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $16.95. VOICE OF THE HEART By Barbara Taylor Bradford. 732 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: By David Quammen; David Quammen"s novel, "The Zolta Configuration," will be published in May.
description: FAMOUS ALL OVER TOWN, By Danny Santiago. 285 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95. THE RIVER WHY, By David James Duncan. 294 pp. San Francisco: Sierra Club Books. $12.95. HERE TO GET MY BABY OUT OF JAIL, By Louise Shivers. 136 pp. New York: Random House. $11.95.

title: GORING GIVES ISLANDERS A LIFT
description: Butch Goring was doing his best to explain last year. He was talking about the playoffs, specifically what he hadn't done to help the Islanders win their third consecutive Stanley Cup.

title: New York Times Magazine April 24, 1983
description: William Safire 12 On Language X Marks the Verb Russell Baker 16 Sunday Observer The Examined Wardrobe John Russell 28 The New European Painters David Shribman 44 Mr. Sikorski Goes to Washington Gerry Sikorski of Minnesota was one of 80 newcomers who traveled the tortuous route to Congress this year. Richard Bernstein 48 Samoa: A Paradise Lost? The South Pacific archipelago, the center of an anthropological debate, has paid a telling price for its Westernization.

title: 'FRIGHTENED FOR THE FUTURE OF HUMANITY'
description: The following statement was signed by 70 scientists who contributed to the development of the first atomic bomb, in 1943. Among the signatories are five Nobel Prize winners - Hans Bethe, Owen Chamberlain, Richard Feynman, Ed McMillan and Emilio Segre. Others include Robert Marshak, Victor Weisskopf and Frank Oppenheimer.

title: Jays Beat Royals on 5-Run 8th
description: The Toronto Blue Jays combined run-scoring singles by Garth Iorg, Cliff Johnson and Willy Upshaw and three Kansas City errors for a five-run rally in the eighth inning to beat the Royals, 5-4, tonight.

title: Deborah Brown Wed to a Lawyer
description: Deborah Childs Brown, daughter of Jeanne Janney Brown of Fredericksburg, Va., and Robert F. Brown of Raleigh, N.C., was married yesterday to Thomas David Silverstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard L. Silverstein of Bethesda, Md. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jerome Hall, a Roman Catholic chaplain at Georgetown University, at the Fredericksburg Country Club.

title: ABRAMS BIDS A RISE IN AID TO VICTIMS
description: ALTHOUGH 90 percent of the crimes solved in New York State are solved not by detective work but by ''victims coming forward,'' Attorney General Robert Abrams told a White Plains audience last week, that less than 1 percent of the state's total criminal-justice budget is spent on victims.

title: STOPPING DECAY
description: The story of four six-story buildings on Sedgewick Avenue, in the Kingsbridge Heights neighborhood of the Northwest Bronx, is much the same as elsewhere in the city's boroughs: the housing is sound, but old. Boilers, plumbing, electrical systems and roofs need replacement, and abandonment seems only a step away.

title: EARL HINES, 77, FATHER OF MODERN JAZZ PIANO, DIES
description: Earl (Fatha) Hines, the father of modern jazz piano, died Friday in Oakland, Calif., after a heart attack. He was 77 years old. In his pioneering work with Louis Armstrong in the late 1920's, Mr. Hines virtually redefined jazz piano. With what he called ''trumpet style,'' Mr. Hines played horn-like solo lines in octaves with his right hand and spurred them with chords from his left. He thus carved a place for the piano as a solo instrument outside the rhythm section and defined the roles of both hands for the next generations of jazz pianists.

title: SOCCER, RAIN OR SHINE
description: Several members of the New York Cosmos, the North American Soccer League champions, will conduct a clinic at Manhattanville College Saturday as part of an International Soccer Bazaar scheduled from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. on the Purchase campus.

title: CONCERT: 2-PIANO MUSIC
description: Britain continued to salute New York on Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House, this time with two pianos and three composers. The music was by Sir Arnold Bax, Gustav Holst and Richard Rodney Bennett.

title: PRESERVATIONISTS ASSAY COUNTY TREASURES
description: THE eyes of preservationists from all parts of the state were focused on the county last weekend when 320 people, 236 of them visitors to Westchester, gathered at the Tarrytown Hilton for the yearly meeting of the Preservation League of New York State.

title: New Statistic Is Misleading
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Anne Johnson Marries Mark Johnston
description: Anne Pemberton Johnson of Baltimore, daughter of Mrs. Dean L. Johnson of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Mr. Johnson, was married yesterday to Mark D. Johnston, son of Col. Roy B. Johnston, Chaplains Corps, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Johnston of Omaha. The ceremony was performed at the Greenville Community Church in Scarsdale by the bridegroom's father, a Presbyterian minister, assisted by the Rev. John D. Elliot Jr. of the Dutch Reformed Church in America.

title: IN THE END, ALL IS WELL
description: Director Trevor Nunn is not a man who can be accused of underplaying his hand. Give him a piece of material like ''Nicholas Nickleby'' and he will not only cram all of Dickens into it, brilliantly, but will look around for open spaces he can fill out of his own teeming imaginative energies - for good or ill. In ''Nickleby,'' for instance, he came to a moment in which a provincial touring company was to do a spot of Shakespeare, and by the time Mr. Nunn got through adding extra spots of Shakespeare from half the other plays Shakespeare wrote he'd done more than seize the moment. He'd extended it to approximately 20, improvising like a madman the while. In the current ''Cats'' he's transformed the Winter Garden ceiling into a kind of heaven for creatures who don't have nine lives, he's inflated Old Deuteronomy into some sort of God, and he's created an alley-cat saint to climb that golden stairway to the Great Beyond even though his supposed source, a slender volume of verse by T.S. Eliot, has nothing to do with heaven, God, a saint or the three-ringcircus strategies of Mr. Nunn. Sometimes grand and sometimes gratuitous are these additions by Britain's busiest director.

title: Atlantic City Draws the Line
description: As if the problems of crime, poverty, unemployment and the mob weren't enough, Atlantic City now has a foreign policy crisis. Citizens and elected officials last week joined forces to oppose a plan by a South African company to build and operate a $300 million casino hotel.

title: The General Gets Reinforcements
description: After two strikes in the same Federal court, CBS News last week declared itself out of legal arguments. Gen. William C. Westmoreland will get an internal report this week on a CBS documentary that he says libeled him.

title: 3 Jersey Garbage Aides Are Sentenced for Plot
description: Three key defendants in a conspiracy to monopolize competition in New Jersey's garbage industry have been sentenced to six months in jail and fined a total of $130,000.

title: BIOLOGICAL RESEARCH TAKES ON LIFE OF ITS OWN AT CAMBRIDGE
description: A few miles south of this ancient city is a modern four-story monument to the potency of basic biological research and to the truth of a favorite litany in science - that basic research is usually the best road to important practical results. It is the brick, concrete and glass building that houses the Medical Research Council's Laboratory of Molecular Biology, where scientists are working to revolutionize our understanding of the chemistry of life.

title: DISCOVERING HEROD'S ISRAEL
description: Christians know King Herod as the man who ordered the Massacre of the Innocents in Bethlehem. In Jewish tradition he is remembered as the Idumean who was made king by the might of Rome, not by the grace of God. Yet archeology reveals another side of Herod: a genius for architecture. Two thousand years after his reign the modern-day traveler can visit the remains of Herodian structures scattered through Israel.

title: Francesco Siravo Wed to Ann S. Pulver
description: Ann Stewart Pulver, daughter of Josephine Thomas Pulver of Milwaukee and George Marsh Pulver of London, was married in Washington yesterday to Francesco Siravo, son of Grazia Toraldo of Rome and Giulio Siravo of Turin, Italy. Bishop Thomas H. Wright of Wilmington, N.C., retired Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of East Carolina, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's cousin, Mrs. Parke H. Brady.

title: WITH IMPOSSIBLE ODDS, NO ADVICE CAN HELP
description: To be two games down in a match with only two games left to play is an impossible situation, one for which there is no good advice. Not since the system of candidates matches to determine a challenger for the world championship was instituted in 1965 has anyone made a comeback against such odds.

title: Crash Fatal to Woman Injures a B.Y.U. Back
description: A Brigham Young University quarterback, Steve Young, was injured today in an automobile accident that killed a young woman.

title: POMONA GETS MULTIBILLION-DOLLAR F.A.A. PROGRAM
description: THE Federal Aviation Administration has designated its Technical Center at Pomona, 10 miles northwest of here, as the ''brain'' and implementation site for its national Airspace System Plan.

title:
GARDENING;
HEDGES: ALWAYS POPULAR AND USEFUL
description: ONE wonders who might have been the first person to plant a hedge. It may have been a member of some tribe that decided to trade the nomadic way of life of the hunter and herder for that of the sedentary farmer. Families and flocks would have required protection against marauding neighboring tribes and wild predators, and crops planted in those earliest of gardens would have been at the mercy of domesticated and wild animals. Fences would have been nonexistent, for tools with which to make posts and boards would have been exceedingly primitive.

title: AN ARIA IN TIME SAVES NINE
description: What do you do when you're 21, all alone in Florence with a vocabulary that consists of ''spaghetti,'' ''mama mia'' and ''o sole mio,'' and you get yourself arrested? All I was trying to do was take a picture of ''The Wrestlers'' in the Uffizi Gallery, when suddenly there was a large mass of something in front of my lens and a firm hand on my arm. I lowered the camera and found myself looking into a black uniform, topped by a dazzling patent-leather hat and an ugly scowl. ''Uh, oh. This man does not want me to take pictures in his museum,'' I sensed. I'll just smile sweetly and put the camera away and surely he'll let me go.

title:
NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
CHAMPIONSHIP SKATING
description: Scott Hamilton and Rosalyn Summers, the current world champion figure-skaters, will perform at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena Saturday evening, when the 1983 World Figure-Skating Tour makes its only appearance in the metropolitan area before the 1984 Olympics.

title: DICTIONARY IS EFFORT TO RECORD DISAPPEARING INDIAN TONGUE
description: Theresa Lame Bull, a 77-year-old Gros Ventre Indian who lives on the Fort Belknap Indian Reservation in north central Montana, remembers when she and other Gros Ventre children were punished for speaking their native language on school grounds.

title: TRENTON WEIGHS FORGIVENESS FOR MUNICIPAL DEBTORS
description: FIFTY TWO municipalities and sewerage authorities being sued by the state to recover about $8 million in loans for the design of sewagetreatment plants are awaiting the outcome of a bill that would convert those loans into grants.

title: STAGE: ACTING COMPANY
description: Two seasons ago at the Jean Cocteau Repertory, Toby Robertson took an inventive approach to ''Pericles,'' turning it into a play within a play, a cross between Genet's ''The Balcony'' and the musical ''Cabaret.'' In his new production for the Acting Company, beginning a two-week season of repertory at the American Place Theater, he has moved the play into a madhouse. This eccentric, androgynous version is, to use Charles Ludlam's word, a ''deconstruction'' of the text.

title: ARGENTINE CALLERS THREATEN BRITONS
description: Britons living in Argentina say they have received threatening telephone calls in the last week, and some say they consider the threats serious enough to take precautions.

title: COLLEGES JOIN THE UNEMPLOYMENT BATTLE
description: COLLEGES and universities used to be structurally unemployed in the nation's unemployment problems, confining their interest to studies in the classroom. But no more. Prompted by record unemployment rates of 30 percent or more in some parts of the nation, an increasing number of them are providing tuition for the jobless, retraining for the hard-core unemployed and aid to governmental agencies, civic groups, and unions in finding new positions for blue-collar workers as well as professionals.

title: WITH USER FEES PROLIFERATING, THEY ASK WHO'S USING WHOM
description: Each year the United States Coast Guard spends millions of dollars in steaming to the aid of boating enthusiasts who have run out of gas or who misnavigated themselves onto sand bars or shoals. The financial strains of these missions have long been ignored because the Coast Guard in many cases is actually saving lives.

title: EXHIBITIONS WITH A FRENCH ACCENT
description: FRANCE and French Canada have temporarily taken over the University of Connecticut's Benton Museum in Storrs. One is represented by a show of about 60 Vuillard drawings, the other by 87 photographs that focus on the brightly colored houses owned by Acadians in eastern Canada. Both displays remain through May 28.

title: Lebanon Charges a Guerrilla With Attack on U.S. Marines
description: A Lebanese member of a radical Palestinian guerrilla group was charged today with the March 16 grenade attack that wounded five United States marines.

title: DALTON PLAN FINDS A HOME IN JAPAN
description: EVERY weekday morning at 10 o'clock, Waki Hideki joins his 5-yearold classmates in the lobby of the Dalton School. As he changes into slippers, he talks about his plans for the rest of the day. He will color a pterodactyl, walk the balance beam, fold paper and perhaps harvest sweet potatoes from the playground garden.

title: Miss Casey Wed To Denis Cullen
description: Elizabeth Winn Casey, daughter of Mrs. Raymond Patrick Murphy of Colorado Springs and the late Maj. Gen. George Casey of the Army was married yesterday to Denis Dyson Cullen, son of Mrs. J. Cox Cullen of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late James Freston Cullen. The Rev. Charles Quinn performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour in New York.

title: JAZZ
description: For all dyed-in-the-wool Ellingtonians, this week is the high point of their musical year. It starts Sunday afternoon with the 23d annual concert of the Duke Ellington Society and concludes on Friday with the 10th annual celebration of the late composer, pianist and orchestra leader's birthday by the Jazz Ministry of St. Peter's Church.

title: A FRENCH INN'S QUIET COMFORT
description: BARBARA BELL is a writer who lives in Paris.

title: An Athlete's Pressure
description: He set rushing records at Maryland, and even after a disappointing season in his senior year, Charlie Wysocki seemed assured of being drafted by a National Football League team last year. So assured, in fact, that he invited scores of friends, relatives and newsmen to the Wysocki home in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., last spring to await the call from the N.F.L. The call never came.

title: A FORCE THAT COULD STOP MALONE
description: MOSES MALONE, who is not known for his verbosity, invariably makes h imself perfectly clear, however. And last Thursday morning he was t roubled.

title: RAIL STRIKE WAS NOT ALL THAT BAD
description: NOW that Metro-North is chugging again, I cannot say I found the strike too unbearable. Looking back, it was a change of pace in a timetabled life.

title: Sylviane Gold
description: Sylviane Gold writes frequently about the theater.

title: BITS OF EVIDENCE ARE FOCUS IN THE CBS KILLINGS
description: Almost every day a prosecutor wheels a grocery cart brimming with cardboard cartons into a Manhattan courtroom. From the cart, the prosecutor, Gregory L. Waples, plucks out hair samples, .22-caliber shell casings, a bed sheet with a bullet hole, blood scrapings, aluminum siding pocked with bullet holes, license plates, tire tracks, greasy clothing, cans of paint remover and scores of other items he piles on a shelf before a jury.

title: A SENSE OF PLACE
description: Missed Connections by Elaine Ford 229 pp. New York. Random House. $13.95

title: PLEASURE AND PERILS OF STUDY ABROAD
description: DEBBIE DRUCKER, a senior at Drew University, finished her junior year at City of London Polytechnic in England. Rena Ronson studied abroad for a year, first in South America and then in Madrid. While Blair Boyer's friends were milling around the campus pub at Bucknell University in their spare time, he spent his milling around Kings Road and the clubs of London. Like most others, they found that studying abroad was exciting, though not always as glamorous as it seemed at first.

title:
THE WORLD;
A Tense Buildup To May Day In Poland
description: Polish workers have a right to observe May Day ''in their own way,'' Lech Walesa said last week. This was precisely what Poland's authorities were worried about. They nervously questioned the former leader of Solidarity for the fourth time in a week and issued repeated warnings to a resentful citizenry not to heed an underground call for protests on the traditional workers' holiday.

title: 'BRIDGING YEAR' TO COLLEGE
description: ''I FELT that my senior year at home would have been just a waste of time,'' said 17-year-old Jeffrey Fishman of Oakhurst, N.J. ''I felt ready to make a head start toward college, and I haven't regretted coming here.'' Mr. Fishman was talking about the ''bridging year'' at the Clarkson School here, where the senior year of high school is combined with the freshman year of college in a way few schools in the country have tried. The school, a division of the Clarkson College of Technology, has enrolled about 25 students annually for the last five years for the special program. It has led to a camaraderie among the students that did not exist at Mr. Fishman's previous school.

title: FIFTEEN AND MALE AND HETEROSEXUAL
description: THE NATURAL MAN By Ed McClanahan. 229 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.50.

title: THE FIRST FREEZE
description: On FEB. 6, 1922, the world's major naval powers - the United States, Britain, Japan, France and Italy -signed a treaty limiting naval armaments.

title: Jury Awards $3 Million to Girl Raped in Stairwell of a School
description: A jury has ordered the Board of Education to pay $3 million in damages to an 18-year-old girl who was raped in the stairwell of a Bronx junior high school five years ago by an older student with a history of sexual assaults.

title: ENGLISH NATURE
description: MAN AND THE NATURAL WORLD A History of the Modern Sensibility. By Keith Thomas. Illustrated. 426 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $19.95.

title: THE TECHNOLOGICAL SOCIETY
description: WHILE applauding attempts by educators to improve computer training a nd other specialized education, business leaders are complaining a bout American higher education as they have never done before.

title: GRADE-SCHOOLERS LOOK AT ALCOHOLISM
description: THE topic was peer pressure and alcohol, but no one in Ann Fitzgerald's sixth-grade class at Public School 32 in Flushing, Queens, seemed intimidated by it. ''There is a chance,'' said Gary Z anelli, a lively pupil in the class with blond hair and a bright smile, ''that me and my friends will turn to alcohol, drugs, or even crime because of peer pressure. If I do get involved with any of those things, I hope I can be helped before something happens to me.''

title: HOUSING PROBLEMS SQUEEZING THE ELDERLY
description: NEW JERSEY, like the rest of the country, is growing older. And as its population increases, elderly peopl in the state are finding themselves squeezed ever harder by rising costs, growing alienation, and a scarcity of affordable housing.

title: H.M. Brinkley Jr. Wed To Katherine Sweeney
description: Katherine M. Sweeney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Sweeney of Titusville, Pa., was married yesterday in New York to Hugh M. Brinkley Jr. of Palm Beach, Fla. He is a son of the late Hugh M. Brinkley and Mrs. Brinkley of Memphis.

title: Not First-Class
description: To the Business Editor:

title: HOW TO MAKE $109.23 IN SHORT ORDER
description: MY favorite spectator sport has always been reading how other people make money, but when I saw a feature about tag sales I felt I could at last leave the side lines. I was still feeling excited when my friend Trudy dropped in, and I decided to enlist her help.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: FROM IMMIGRANTS TO ETHNICS The Italian Americans. By Humbert S. Nelli. 225 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: The Secret About Secrets
description: As most people concerned about guarding Government secrets discover, the trouble is there are too many of them. They pile up so fast they spill over, leak out, indeed, have to be routinely poured out with every official transaction. But this fact of Washington life eludes an Administration team now studying the question. It dreams about a law that would make it a crime to divulge any information classified as secret.

title: CORPORATE PUSH FOR SPACE LASERS
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN'S recent call for a defensive shield in space has b een roundly criticized, even ridiculed, as a high-level but fancifulw ish for a technological coup that would end the nuclear arms race. Y et serious research efforts on exotic non-nuclear methods of d efense, such as lasers, have been proceeding steadily, if slowly, f or years.

title:
THE TECHNOLOGICAL SOCIETY;
PLUGGING TEACHERS INTO COMPUTER ERA
description: AT Taft High School on the Northwest Side last month, before television crews and a slew of reporters and photographers, Chicago's large, financially drained school system began tackling what may be the most critical issue in education today. Sitting in front of 100 donated machines, the first of all of the city's 22,000 elementary and secondary public-school teachers and 500 of its administrators began attending one-day, six-hour workshops designed to introduce them to the microcomputer in the classroom.

title:
DINING OUT;
HEARTY FARE IN WHITE PLAINS
description: RESTAURANTS that serve foreign foods are a plus to any community, and White Plains has had its share. In the last 10 years, many have vanished as a result of that city's changing profile; however, Le Pastis seems to be holding its own, offering a very little bit of Belgian cooking, along with a lot of French and Continental touches. Unlike Asian cooking, for example, the cuisine at Le Pastis holds no surprises; the food is familiar, hearty peasant fare. And choosing carefully, diners can have a satisfactory meal here.

title: MR. SIKORSKI GOES TO WASHINGTON
description: STILLWATER, Minn., is an old lumber town on the St. Croix River. In the last century, when the white pine still stood high on the hills and when settlers traveled to the Middle West by steamboat and stagecoach, some enterprising pioneers built a sawmill there. Later, when the railroads inched west and when millions of logs were being sorted every year at the boom site just beyond town, a modest downtown started to grow, and there sprouted a brewery, an opera house and a series of mansions. The logging ended decades ago, but Stillwater endures, a small town with a hardware store, a drug store, a grocery store and an elegant old hotel. The butcher knows the name of just about everyone in town. The meters charge a dime for two hours' parking.

title: DANCE: ROYAL BALLET'S 'MAYERLING'
description: ''Mayerling,'' Kenneth MacMillan's controversial bed-and-ballroom ballet - which had its New York premiere Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House with the Royal Ballet, and was scheduled for only three performances - may not be the hit of the dance season but it would surely have been one of the hits of the theater season.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: 2 Meet Marks Set In the Iona Relays
description: One Long Islander, Cheryl Klein of Bellport High School, set a meet record in the shot-put and another, Charmaine Smith of Uniondale, set a record in the high jump at the 29th annual Iona College Relays yesterday at Downing Stadium.

title: BRITAIN'S SCIENCE CORRIDOR
description: PLANES swooping into Heathrow International Airport on the western outskirts of this city almost always land on a huge east-west runway north of the main terminal. One of the last things passengers see before landing - if the weather permits them to see anything at all - is a six-lane expressway also running east-west. The M4.

title: ROOSEVELT'S DAYS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: DANCE
description: Sunday is the last chance to attend the stage performances, film showings and panel discussions that close the Dance Black America festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: VARIETY IN VIOLIN CONCERTOS
description: Amid the vastness of the standard orchestral literature, violin concertos hold a special place: Unlike keyboard concertos, in which an alien sonority is woven into and pitted against a symphonic texture, violin concertos take the most central of the orchestra's instrumental voices and force it to shine out against a sonic backdrop that it more naturally tends to blend with. The latest disk releases just about run the gamut of this repertory, from Bach and Vivaldi, through the Romantic warhorses, to the early 20th-century works of Prokofiev. At the same time, these new disks -some of them historical reissues -offer an array of stylistic approaches that can coexist peacefully in any collection.

title: CULT SYNDROME HAS CLAIMED ANOTHER VICTIM
description: DEAR TOWN OF MINE:

title: China's Pressure On Vietnam
description: In February 1979, Chinese troops invaded Vietnam ''to teach it a lesson.'' This precedent is one reason for more than usual interest in the latest flareup of hostilities - a series of mortar and artillery duels and a clash of frontier guards last week that each side accused the other of provoking. China said 16 Vietnamese were killed when they tried to cross into Yunnan Province.

title: A MEETING IN SHANGHAI
description: Two cosmopolitan characters from opposite ends of the earth formed an impromptu partnership recently. One was Jaime Ortiz-Patino of Switzerland, the globe-trotting president of the World Bridge Federation. He fitted a visit to the Shanghai international tournament into a busy schedule that will include in the next four months a South American tour and zonal championships in Mauritius and Germany.

title: Peter Low Wed To Miss Kissin
description: Amanda Kissin and Peter D. Low were married yesterday at the Georgian Suite, 1A East 77th Street, by Rabbi Marc Tanenbaum. The bride is a daughter of Irving Kissin of New York and the late Janet Kissin.

title: A DISHY ROMAN A CLEF WITH RECIPES
description: HEARTBURN By Nora Ephron. 179 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: Marcos Seizes An Old Broom
description: If you're Phillippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos, there's no need to fight city hall. You arrest it. Last week, Mayor Aquilino Pimentel of Cagayan de Oro City was reported to have been detained in the Government's latest crackdown on suspected subversives.

title: MOTHER LIVES WELL
description: NATURAL VICTIMS By Isabel Eberstadt. 480 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: Where to in Central America?
description: If President Reagan persists in committing the nation's honor and arms to the political wars of Central America, it is high time that he fully state why, what he aims to achieve and how. His decision to speak out next Wednesday is therefore welcome, if late. Congress and all Americans deserve to know what interests are truly at risk and whether the responses Mr. Reagan recommends are indeed adequate, lawful and sensible.

title: ON THE QUESTION OF TAXING MUSEUMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Breton Farmers Storm Prison After Arrest of Two Militants
description: About 1,500 farmers, angered by the arrest of two young farm union militants and falling farm prices, attacked a prison in this Breton town on Friday, the police said today.

title: THE 'PRE-K' WAY OF STARTING SCHOOL
description: SINCE September a special group of public school students here have learned to write their names and zip up their jackets. They can pick out a likeness of George Washington on a dollar bill and talk about Martin Luther King, Winnie the Pooh, Pilgrims and Indians and the Chinese New Year. One day this month, they released into the air 700 helium-filled balloons after having learned what a circle was.

title: A $10,000 COUPON
description: ''The point is to move the merchandise,'' says John L. Baldwin, and as a senior vice president of the advertising agency, Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, Inc., he knows how to do that. Even when the merchandise is his own, single-family house in Old Greenwich, Connecticut.

title: 2 YANKEES DIFFER ON PLATOONING
description: When Rick Cerone is asked how the Yankees' two-catcher system is working, he shrugs and says: ''It's tough not playing every day. I guess it's ... I don't know. I'm not used to it. You're talking about getting 10 at-bats a week, instead of 30. We've played 13 games and I don't have many more bats than games played.

title: BRISTOL BRASS IS BACK AT WORK
description: AFTER sitting idle for almost nine months, the machines are running again at the Bristol Brass Company. ''We are producing materials now for orders that will be going out within the next three or four weeks,'' said Arthur R. Brown, executive vice president of the company.

title: INFLUENCE OF POLITICAL ACTION GROUPS DISPUTED
description: Political action committees have much less influence on elections and Congressional votes than their critics give them credit for, according to research presented to the Midwest Political Science Association.

title: Facts and Fiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Portugal
description: To the Editor: In commenting on fish auctions in Nazare, Portugal, letter writer Bruce Henderson (Travel, April 3) may be interested to know that the ''decreased-bidding'' system is not ''unique to Portuguese fish auctions.''

title: BOARD CHIEF DOES NOT FAVOR AN APPEAL ON WAGNER
description: The president of the Board of Education said yesterday that he did not favor appealing the State Education Commissioner's refusal to approve Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. as Chancellor of the New York City school system.

title: HOW A POET GUIDED THE ART BRUSH
description: OUR great nature poet, William Cullen Bryant - prob ably the Island's most famous resident in the 19th century - made contributions to American literature that are universally admired. Less familiar, however, are his contributions to art, a situation that the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art hopes to remedy with its new exhibition opening today, ''William Cullen Bryant, the Weirs and American Impressionism.''

title: WHAT ARE THE USES OF OPERATIC ARGOT?
description: Why is life so full of simple questions to which there are no simple answers? Like that one, for instance. Why, a female reader inquires, has the Italian term prima donna been taken into the English language but not its masculine counterpart, primo uomo? I don't really know, though I suspect the answer lies somewhere in the underground caverns of folk consciousness. Literally, prima donna means nothing more than ''first woman'' or, in theater parlance, ''leading lady.'' That is the first definition given in Webster's New World Dictionary: ''the principal woman singer in an opera or concert.'' But definition 2 is the one commonly meant in everyday English speech: ''(Colloq.) a temperamental, vain or arrogant person; esp., such a woman.''

title: THE NEW EUROPEAN PAINTERS
description: THE NEWS FROM THE ART WORLD IS that European painting is back. Not only is it back, but it is big. Museum directors stand in line for it. Collectors buy the paintings in batches of a dozen at a time. (Prices range from $25,000 to $60,000 and up.) Dealers go after them the way a bear goes after honey. The New European Painters are in every art magazine you pick up, and many is the critic, the curator and the esthetic impresario who is building a career upon them.

title: SOME GAMES THAT LET ADULTS BE YOUNG
description: START with something quiet like Blind Triangle, add some mystery with Killer and Plague, mix in something physical like Frenzy, and top it off with Mohawk Walk and Leap-for-Life. No, this isn't the test center for a video game manufacturer - it is part of a special workshop given for adults by the Project Adventure Team at the Hommocks School in Larchmont.

title: E.J. Kulik Jr., Executive, Weds Marybeth Griswold
description: Marybeth Griswold, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren I. Griswold of East Longmeadow, Mass., and Edward J. Kulik Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Kulik of Longmeadow, Mass., were married yesterday at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Longmeadow.

title: WORD GAMES; Coffee Table Comic
description: The status coffee table (amoeba-shaped, 50's) stands on a Chinese rug (30's) and supports an art pottery vase (New Jersey, 1917) in which is stuck a branch of forsythia (forced). It also holds two art books (one of them ''Rockwell Kent'') and a novel (probably ''Ancient Evenings'').

title: 76ers Try Again
description: Julius Erving is the Philadelphia 76ers' captain, their leader and the most likely player to be asked for an autograph or an interview. In the seven seasons the 6-foot-6-inch forward has worn the 76er uniform, he has scored 12,731 points, appeared in seven consecutive all-star games and was named the league's most valuable player for the 1980-81 season.

title: First-Place Liverpool Loses to Norwich, 2-0
description: Norwich City upset first-place Liverpool, 2-0, today in a First Division game of the English Soccer League.

title: IS OUR CULTURE IN OUR GENES?
description: PROMETHEAN FIRE Reflections on the Origin of Mind. By Charles J. Lumsden and Edward O. Wilson. Illustrations by Whitney Powell. 216 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $17.50. uf720

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BARBARA'S BIRTHDAY, Written and illustrated, by James Stevenson. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $9.50. (Ages 3 to 5)

title: BOARD EXAMINING 2 A.M. BAR CLOSINGS
description: EFFORTS by towns, villages and individual residents in the county to persuade the state to close Westchester bars two hours earlier each night appeared last week to be having a minimal effect.

title: EMOTIONS RAN HIGH ON DEATH SENTENCE
description: FOR five hours last Tuesday, friends and relatives of Joseph Hicks, the first murderer to be convicted under New Jersey's new capitalpunishment law, waited in a hallway of the Monmouth County Courthouse as 12 jurors decided whether to impose the death sentence.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: RENTING A CAR IN EUROPE
description: Avis advertises that you can rent a car in Britain this summer with unlimited mileage for as little as $125 a week. But when Virginia Grimes of Levittown, L.I., began asking questions, the lowest price quoted her was $275 for the type of car that she considered minimal to her needs. And that was before the cost of gasoline, insurance and a 15 percent tax.

title: Debra D. Estes Is Bride
description: Debra Denise Estes, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Manson P. Estes of Bridgewater, Va., was married yesterday in Charlottesville, Va., to William Milne Ewing Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ewing of New York.

title: FACTORY-BUILT HOUSES LOOKING LIKE HOME
description: AS long as anyone can remember, manufacturers of mobile and modular h omes have been saying that their time finally has come, that the e conomies of building complete houses in factories and trucking them t o sites are so compelling that the public, at last, has to accept t hem.

title: In Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: A CENTENNIAL FOR S.P.C.A. IN THE COUNTY
description: ON March 12, 1883, the State Legislature approved the incorporation of the Sing Sing branch of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, ''to enforce by any and all lawful means all acts of the Legislature of this state for the prevention of such cruelty to animals.''

title: THE BIG FUSS OVER GOOD FOOD
description: A nine-member committee named April 15 by the Agriculture Department has found itself at the center of an uproar over revisions to a set of guidelines, which are considered to be the Government's advice on proper nutrition and health habits.

title: TURNTABLES ARE TAKING A FRESH LEASE ON LIFE
description: The uses of adversity have long been debated by moral philosophers, and the topic now comes to mind in connection with turntables. The dawn of digital record players, just now being introduced - along with the growing popularity of cassettes - undercuts the future of conventional record players. Fatality looms. Their ultimate departure is merely a matter of time.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: RIGHT-TO-KNOW: JOBS AT ISSUE
description: TRADE associations representing some 12,000 businesses in New Jersey are setting forth a familiar argument - jobs vs. the environment - as part of their challenge to the proposed Community and Workers Right to Know Act.

title: AT ZAHN, JOB SNAG IS TOPIC
description: AN industrial park on the former site of Zahn's Airport was supposed to create jobs for residents of North Amityville. In the Town of Babylon's application for Federal funds to improve the 123-acre site, it was estimated that 1,000 ''employment opportunities'' for ''low-income groups'' would be provided there by now.

title: REAGAN WILL TAKE SOME MAJOR RISKS BEFORE JOINT SESSION
description: ONLY nine times in the past quarter of a century have American Presidents gone before a special joint session of Congress. In 1972, Richard Nixon reported on the arms agreements signed in Moscow with the Soviet leadership. In 1978, Jimmy Carter shared the triumph of the Camp David talks on the Middle East. In earlier times, Lyndon Johnson made a major address on voting rights legislation, Harry S. Truman announced Marshall Plan aid to Europe and Franklin D. Roosevelt reported on the Yalta conference.

title: CALMING THE ECONOMY ALSO STIRS IT UP
description: The word came in a good news, bad news format, but to the people of Brazil it was no joke. Rather, it dramatized the dilemma facing Latin American nations that are looking for ways out of debt.

title: BUILDING CENSUS MAKING ITSELF COUNT
description: The Census to Save New York, the effort to build a computerized store of information about the city's 850,000 buildings, is going beyond its original goal of preserving historic stuctures. Now it also is gathering data that will help communities identify other buildings that give a neighborhood character and allow them to work more amicably with developers.

title: Test of Law At Acid Pits
description: California's Stringfellow Acid Pits may be ranked only 32nd on the Environmental Protection Agency's list of 418 most dangerous chemical dumps, but it is certainly among the agency's worst political headaches. Last week the Justice Department and the State of California filed suit to force operators and users of the site to pay for a cleanup, which the E.P.A. estimates will cost at least $35 million.

title: 17 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 17 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named seven that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and three that were closed for failing to do so.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the article 'Joie de Vivre of Montreal' in 'The Sophisticated Traveler' (Part 2 of The New York Times Magazine, March 13), the name of Louis Joseph Papineau, the 19th-century political figure, was misspelled because of a typographical error.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The New Jersey Generals have signed Lance Olander, a free-agent running back from the University of Colorado. He is expected to play tomorrow night against Chicago. ... Leroy Haley will defend his superlightweight title against Bruce Curry in Las Vegas May 18. ... Matt Centrowitz, who set a course record in winning the Lilac 10-kilometer race last year in Rochester, will defend his title this year on May 15. ... Jacquelyn Hernandez was an effective fund-raiser for her son's Little League team in San Francisco, and her husband, John, coached in the program. On May 22 the couple will be honored as the 1983 Baseball Parents of the Year by the Little League Baseball Association at a ceremony in Busch Stadium in St. Louis where their son, Keith Hernandez, plays first base for the Cardinals.

title: 'CIRCUMSPECT' COMMISSIONER: GORDON MAC KAY AMBACH
description: In trying to think of the best way to describe the State Education Commissioner, a member of the Board of Regents and a longtime friend pointed without hesitation to Gordon M. Ambach's refusal Friday to approve Robert F. Wagner Jr. as New York City Schools Chancellor.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: SPYTRAP By William Crisp. 190 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $12.95.

title: TRYING TO EXPRESS THE OUTRAGE OF WAR
description: ALTHOUGH armed conflict has been an artistic theme for many centuries, it has taken on a special urgency in the atomic age. At the same time, the artist's role as communicator and interpreter of events has been largely usurped by the mass media, which now bring images of death and destruction into every living room.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN FOOD REGULATION;
HITTING A SNAG IN THE SALT WARS
description: When Arthur Hayes became commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration in April 1981, he jettisoned nearly all of the Carter Administration's ambitious mandatory labeling plans for a variety of food ingredients and began a vigorous public relations drive against one - sodium.

title: A TAX REFORM BILL THAT ADDS INJURY
description: To the Editor:

title: 'CONFUSION TIME' RESUMES TODAY IN UNION CITY, INDIANA/OHIO
description: On the face of it, it should be very simple: To gain an extra hour of summer daylight, about 220 million Americans turn their clocks ahead one hour.

title: IN CALIFORNIA, REACTORS ARE A COSTLY BARGAIN
description: A few miles down the coast from here, on a buffcolored plain at the edge of the Pacific, work is moving ahead at the San Onofre nuclear power plant. Its second power unit is expected to be the next nuclear reactor to go into operation in California after a start up planned for later this year, with a third power unit slated soon to follow.

title: GREEN PARTIES MAY BE FACTOR IN AUSTRIAN VOTE
description: The people of Austria are to decide in a general election Sunday whether they will follow West Germany and admit maverick environmentalists to Parliament.

title: TO CURB A WIFE-BEATER
description: To the Editor:

title: LITTON'S ANGRY LABOR CONGLOMERATE
description: IN the 1960's, Cesar Chavez and the grape pickers organized a bitter nationwide campaign that led to widespread consumer boycotts, the founding of the United Farm Workers and the unionization of part of California's agribusiness. In the 1970's, it was the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union at J.P. Stevens that won broadbased support from unions and consumers in its campaign for the first collective bargaining contract in the company's history.

title: FOR A PRODUCTIVE, JUST AMERICA
description: SPHERES OF JUSTICE A Defense of Pluralism and Equality. By Michael Walzer. 345 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: VIDES'S FIRST TARGET IS ARMY BRASS
description: GEN. Carlos Eugenio Vides Casanova, who was named Defense Minister of El Salvador last week, immediately indicated one basic change in attitude. The man he replaced, Gen. Jose Guillermo Garcia, ''told me everything was ready'' to win the war quickly, General Vides Casanova remarked to reporters. ''But this war is going to be long, and we have to find where the army is failing and bring in adequate people,'' the new defense chief said.

title: Subletting 'Peril'
description: To the Editor:

title: OH NO! A WEDDING INVITATION!
description: I HAVE been invited to a wedding. Ugh! Oh, the ceremony is all right, 20 minutes tops and it is fun to see what the bride is wearing. The receiving line I can bear even if it is a large wedding and takes a while to get to the couple and offer congratulations. It is the endless purgatory of the reception that I object to.

title: TO BALLPLAYERS IN NEW YORK PARKS, A DIAMOND IS RARE INDEED
description: Four times in the last week, Vladimir Abouzeide has pulled on his blue sweatshirt, picked up his mitt and headed to the softball fields in Central Park. But all four times the fields have been taken, and he has left without swinging a bat or fielding a ball.

title: DATA BANK
THE TECHNOLOGICAL SOCIETY NO JOB, NO SCHOOLING: WHAT'S IT LIKE
description: JACK NEILSON is a 48-year-old unemployed but once highly paid auto w orker who left high school when he was 15 years old. He recently t ried to enroll in a trade school that teaches entry-level skills in c omputer maintenance, programming and word processing, but was told t hat schools of its kind only accepted high school graduates, and h is application was rejected.

title: National Party Headquarters For the Democrats Is Started
description: For the first time since it was founded, the Democratic Party is building a home of its own, a $6 million national headquarters near the Capitol.

title: Barbara Sica to Wed M.D.J. Henley in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas A. Sica of Bedford, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Carol Sica, to Mark Dean Jendraszek Henley, son of Henry Jendraszek of New London, Conn., and the late Elizabeth Ann Henley.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a reporting error, an article last Sunday incorrectly stated the age of United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison and the name of his wife. Mr. Morrison is 38 years old. His wife is Jane.

title: Closing Windows, Opening Doors On Missile Debate
description: Congress seems balky about almost everything President Reagan proposes these days. But he may find it easier to sell the latest basing plan for the MX missile after being turned down on the densepack plan in December. The proposal, which the President endorsed last week, to put the MX in hardened minuteman silos in Nebraska and Colorado and to develop a smaller, mobile single-warhead missile for the 1990's came from bipartisan experts, the Commission on Strategic Forces.

title: COLLEGE STUDENT '83; WARY COMMITMENT
description: MUSIC pounds, the building throbs. Like so many white rabbits popping from their holes, youths bob up, down and sideways to the beat. The music is New Wave - a deafening, definite sound. High heels are in, lipstick is back, girls are again wearing dresses.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 6 THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $15.95.) An English girl caught between Israeli intelligence agents and P.L.O. terrorists. 2 3 3 CHRISTINE, by Stephen King. (Viking, $16.95.) A car that kills at large among a Pennsylvania town's high-school set. 3 2 3 WHITE GOLD WIELDER, by Stephen R. Donaldson. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) Book Three of ''The Second Chronicles of Thomas Covenant,'' a fantasy saga. 4 5 4 VOICE OF THE HEART, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Doubleday, $17.95.) The friendship of two women survives the strains of 25 years in the worlds of show business, politics and big business. 5 4 4 THE LONESOME GODS, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $14.95.) A rugged adventurer stakes his claim in 19th-century southern California. 6 6 4 BANKER, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $14.95.) London bankers gamble on the ability of a horse breeder to produce a star race horse. 7 7 7 THE DELTA STAR, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $15.45.) Los Angeles cops contend with their own city's underworld, some would-be Nobel Prize scientists and an elusive Soviet sub. 8 8 30 SPACE, by James A. Michener.

title: Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDROPOV COMPARES LATIN POLICY OF U.S. TO MOSCOW'S AFGHAN ROLE
description: Yuri V. Andropov, in an interview with the West German news magazine Der Spiegel, contends that the Soviet military presence in Afghanistan is analogous to what he termed United States efforts to protect its national interests in Central America.

title: ON EVE OF CONVENTION, NEWSPAPER PUBLISHERS SAY BRIGHTER DAYS LIE AHEAD
description: After nearly a decade of concern about how a faltering economy and competing technologies were jeopardizing their newspapers, many publishers now say that the worst part of a major shakeout is over.

title: A GOLF HOLIDAY: GETTING BACK TO BASICS
description: Scottish golfers have a maxim: ''If it's nae wind, and nae rain and nae cold, it's nae golf.'' The same wisdom, in a different brogue, is applicable in Ireland. The Scots could have added ''rough'' to their ''If nae...'' The gorse, heather, broom and whin are dense enough to hide a soccer ball, let alone a golf ball 1.68 inches in diameter. And terrain: The fairway of the 18th hole at Ireland's Ballybunion is pinched into a narrow defile that evokes images of those heroic chaps of the Light Brigade charging into a hopeless situation.

title: Recent Sales
description: East Brunswick $149,000 *2*6 Theodore Drive, 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*new contemporary; central air-conditioning, *2*skylights, deck; taxes $3,600. Sanwood $86,000 *2*233 Belvidere Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*33-year-old colonial, new kitchen and furnace, *2*waterproofed basement; taxes $1,943. Lake Mohawk $100,000 *2*38 Shawnee Trail, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old *2*colonial, full basement, fireplace, *2*2-car garage; taxes $2,575. Maplewood $85,000 *2*71 Midland Boulevard, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*50-year-old colonial; basement recreation room, *2*enclosed porch; taxes $2,467. Ramsey $225,000 *2*12 Sunwatch Court, 3-bedroom, 3-bath, *2*4-year-old contemporary; wine cellar, sunken *2*master bedroom, gazebo; taxes $5,568. Springfield $110,000 *2*30 Washington Avenue, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 5-year-old *2*bilevel; mother-daughter with two kitchens; *2*taxes $2,196. OTHER AREAS Medford, L.I. $65,000 *2*32 Madison Avenue, 4-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*5-year-old high ranch; 2 kitchens, dining *2*room; taxes $1,900. Bethel, Conn. $130,000 *2*28 Pell Mell Drive, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2 bath, *2*7-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, *2*1.5 acres; taxes $2,118. Armonk, N.Y. $128,000 *2*10 Yale Place, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old *2*frame ranch; recreation room, *2*2.1 acres; taxes $2,609.

title: X MARKS THE VERB
description: ''The Federal bureaucracy has invented a new verb,'' says Charles DeLaFuente of Kew Gardens, N.Y., who had just sent in his 1040 income-tax return to the Internal Revenue Service. He attached an addressed envelope that he had received from the I.R.S.; in the upper left-hand corner, where the return address of the taxpayer belongs, is the heavy black outline of a box. Next to the box are the words ''X box if refund.''
