title: A REGULATOR'S PATH ISN'T A ROSE GARDEN
description: When President Jimmy Carter appointed me Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in 1977, a Connecticut business friend phoned, ''not to congratulate you,'' he said, ''but to empathize. If you do your job right, you'll have 60 percent of the people mad at you at least 50 percent of the time.'' How right he was about a regulator's inevitable fate. No one knows this better than William D. Ruckelshaus, whom President Reagan is bringing back to help put the troubled E.P.A.'s affairs in order. The public, perhaps, doesn't understand it quite so well.

title: WORD GAMES; Why Not the Worst?
description: A cheer for Scott Rice, a California professor of English, who recognizes that bad writing also deserves attention. He has devised the Bulwer-Lytton Fiction Contest, now in its second year, with the prize going to the worst opening sentence for a novel.

title:
HIGHER EDUCATION;
MAKING IT AS A WHITE AT A BLACK COLLEGE
description: AT Howard University, one of the most prestigious black schools in the nation, copies of the National Black Monitor and photographs of the black sports heroes Hank Aaron and O.J. Simpson are displayed prominently in the lobby of the main dormitory, Cook Hall.

title: RARE SPECIES: COLLEGE CHIEFS WHO TEACH
description: TRYING to track down a college president on his campus is often d ifficult, but at St. John's University the Very Rev. Joseph T. C ahill, president of the university, can always be found inside G iblin Lecture Hall at 10 A.M. on Mondays, Wednesdays and Fridays. S tanding at the front of a modern auditorium, speaking above the din o f chatter, Father Cahill addresses the other occupants of the room: ' 'I know it's a beautiful day and the sap is running,'' he says, ' 'but you only have 55 minutes.''

title: AN ORIENT EXPRESS LOOKALIKE IN ENGLAND
description: Robert W. Stock, a senior editor on The New York Times Magazine, assisted in the preparation of this article.

title: Feat Makes a Star of a Safety
description: The outstanding single performance in the short history of the United States Football League was accomplished by Luther Bradley earlier this month when the free safety for the Chicago Blitz intercepted six passes in a game against the Tampa Bay Bandits.

title: Genalo Beats Haskell In L.I. Bowling Final
description: Don Genalo of North Merrick, L.I., defeated Roger Haskell of Renton, Wash., 215-189, in the final of the $110,000 Long Island Open of the Professional Bowlers Association Tour today at Garden City Bowl.

title: ADVENTURE AND VARIETY IN PLEASANTVILLE
description: COMMUNITY theaters may come and go; estimates of those in the area range from 50 to 200. The Pleasantville Music Theater, however, has come of age. Few rival its longevity or approach its sense of adventure in the middle of variety.

title: BEN KINGSLEY TURNS FROM GANDHI TO KEAN
description: For Ben Kingsley, collecting the Oscar was only an exciting interlude in the serious business of preparing for a first night. Within three days of triumphing in Hollywood, he was onstage in West London, his tuxedo replaced by doublet and hose, receiving a standing ovation for a one-man show as different as conceivable from the performance that had established him as the best screen actor of 1982. The gentle sage Gandhi had become the early 19th-century thespian Edmund Kean: megalomaniac, roue and (some historians would claim) the most thrilling talent ever to have graced an English theater.

title: CABARET: PEGGY KING IS BACK
description: After more than two decades of retirement, Peggy King, who was noted in the 1950's for a tomato-sauce commercial on radio and as the singer on George Gobel's popular television show, is back in show business at Michael's Pub, where she will be singing until May 7.

title: Private Satellites
description: It was, as one headline writer put it, ''one small step for capitalism'': Con-estoga I, the private spacecraft built from surplus parts, lifting off Matagorda Island in Texas and arching on a sub-orbital flight into the Gulf of Mexico 321 miles away.

title: NETS' FALL TRACED TO RICHARDSON
description: The feeling of defeat and disappointment seeped into the hallway at the end of the tunnel Thursday night at Madison Square Garden. The Nets, once one of basketball's proud young teams, had just been rudely swept from the National Basketball Association playoffs by their cross-river rivals, the Knicks, in two games. Joe Taub, the team president, walked through a crowd of reporters waiting outside the locker room and paused at the closed door.

title: PAINSTAKING TASK OF FINDING RIGHT PLAYERS FOR JETS TO PICK
description: HOW do you see 1,100 college football players and then narrow down your choice to one? That's the problem that will be confronting directors of player personnel when the annual National Football League selection meeting starts next Tuesday.

title: THE RACE IS ON FOR FASTER HORSES
description: TWO chestnut mares, stomachs protruding, graze in the sweetsmelling field, oblivious to the quail rustling in the bushes and the voices of young children playing nearby. Their 30-acre home is a beautiful farm, Sunninghill, in Glen Head, 30 minutes from Manhattan and 20 minutes from the Belmont Park Race Track.

title:
GARDENING;
HEDGES: ALWAYS POPULAR AND USEFUL
description: ONE wonders who might have been the first person to plant a hedge. It may have been a member of some tribe that decided to trade the nomadic way of life of the hunter and herder for that of the sedentary farmer. Families and flocks would have required protection against marauding neighboring tribes and wild predators, and crops planted in those earliest of gardens would have been at the mercy of domesticated and wild animals. Fences would have been nonexistent, for tools with which to make posts and boards would have been exceedingly primitive.

title: Robin Goldstein and John Mintz, Reporters, Marry
description: At B'nai Israel Synagogue in Rumson, N.J., yesterday, Robin S. Goldstein, a reporter for The Asbury Park (N.J.) Press, was married to John D. Mintz, a reporter for The Washington Post. Rabbi Jack Rosoff performed the ceremony.

title: A HOST OF DAFFODILS
description: A sea of daffodils, kept separated and fresh in water-filled beer bottles, will be unloaded in Greenwich Wednesday and Thursday by dozens of amateur gardeners from the New York-Connecticut area. The occasion is the 26th annual Connecticut Daffodil Show, taking place at the Greenwich Garden Center, Bible Street, Cos Cob, from 2 to 7:30 P.M. Thursday. The show is sponsored by the Greenwich Garden Society and approved by the American Daffodil Society.

title: BUSTER CRABBE, SWIMMER AND ACTOR, DIES AT 75
description: Buster Crabbe, a top swimmer of his day who went on to become a popular movie actor and successful businessman, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 75 years old.

title: U.S. AGREES TO POSTPONE OIL LEASING OFF L.I. COAST
description: The Federal Government has agreed to postpone the leasing of more than one million acres of offshore waters for oil and gas exploration until a judge rules on lawsuits filed by New York and Virginia seeking to prevent drilling in those waters.

title: Shoring Up U.S. Diplomacy
description: The terrorist explosion that devastated the United States Embassy in Beirut last week may have propelled Secretary of State George P. Shultz out of his long hesitation about using personal diplomacy in the Middle East. He was to embark today on a visit to Israel and at least five Arab countries, including Lebanon.

title: DEBATE ON DREDGING: STILL WATERS DON'T ALWAYS RUN DEEP
description: DAVID FINKELSTEIN does not read navigational charts to take his 31-foot cruiser in and out of Stony Brook Harbor. He knows that the chart says the harbor is generally not open to navigation. Local knowledge, the chart reads, is a must.

title: CONCERT: LEE LUVISI PLAYS BEETHOVEN
description: The pianist Lee Luvisi was a student of Rudolf Serkin and Meiczyslaw Horszowski, and he could have made a major career as an independent artist or based at a highly visible Eastern conservatory. Instead, he returned in 1963 to his hometown of Louisville, Ky., where he is now artist in residence at the Louisville School of Music. He also teaches every summer at the Aspen Festival.

title: U.S. PRESENTS FIRST WITNESSES IN BRINK'S RACKETEERING TRIAL
description: Federal prosecutors have presented their first witnesses in a trial involving charges that a radical group carried out the 1981 Brink's robbery and several other armed robberies. The crimes resulted in four slayings.

title: IS PAUL TAYLOR'S 'SUNSET' HAPPY OR SAD OR BOTH?
description: Every so often, Paul Taylor likes to come up with a good detective yarn. Two years ago, in ''Le Sacre du Printemps (The Rehearsal),'' he gave us one replete with gangsters and a private eye. Now he has come up with a real mystery story on a very different level.

title: 2 WEEKS OF APHASIA TURNS LIFE AROUND
description: IF one were asked to describe Jacqueline Doolittle in a word, that word might be ''articulate.'' An effervescent woman with a silvery voice and ready laugh, she seems to assemble sentences and convey ideas with particular ease and verve.

title: VIDEO COMES INTO ITS OWN AT THE WHITNEY BIENNIAL
description: Like any big art show nowadays that professes to survey the current scene, the 1983 Biennial Exhibition at the Whitney Museum, Madison Avenue and 75th Street, has its share of video, the hybrid and muchmaligned form that falls confusingly between film and fine art. In fact, it has some five-and-a-half hours of programming (through May 29) contributed by 15 artists. . In showing video together with more traditional art forms, it's the intention of John Hanhardt, curator of the museum's very active film and video department, to give it peer status with them. But many of those who go to see art in its more kosher forms - if you can say that about the work in the main galleries - tend to be somewhat video-shy. ''It's so boring!'' is the knock most frequently voiced about video. Some of it is, indeed, but boredom is also engendered by other art forms whose esthetic legitimacy we don't question.

title: Federal Science Award Goes to Frederick Seitz
description: Frederick Seitz, president emeritus of Rockefeller University and of the National Academy of Sciences, has been selected to receive the fourth Vannevar Bush Award from the Federal Government.

title: SCHEDULE IS SET FOR OUTDOOR SHOWS
description: WITHIN a fortnight, the antiques business in Connecticut will become an al fresco trade. From then through the Columbus Day weekend, show exhibitors and their customers will conduct a great deal of business on school grounds, village greens and the lawns of historic houses.

title: GEORGE STREET EXIT IS A SO-SO 'SLEUTH'
description: AFTER presenting a striking and affecting evening of new one-act plays by Ken Jenkins, the George Street Playhouse is playing it safe with ''Sleuth,'' the last production at the theater's present site, a converted supermarket.

title: SOCIALIST PREACHES GLOOM IN PORTUGAL
description: As his large blue-and-white campaign bus plies the hairpin turns between fishing villages and poor farming towns in the northern hinterland, Mario Soares, uncharacteristically, is delivering a message of gloom.

title: MUSEUM GETS DAUMIERS
description: Armand Hammer donated 1,000 Daumier lithographs to the Corcoran Gallery of Art here today. The works are intended to become the the basis of a center for study and research into the works of Honore Daumier and his contemporary 19th-century French artists.

title: MADRID RIGHTIST'S BODYGUARD QUITS AMID SCANDAL
description: The security guard for Spain's right-wing opposition leader has resigned in a scandal centering on charges that he organized death squads in Argentina in the 1970's.

title: Penn Dixie
description: To the Business Editor:

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: SERVING WOMEN Household Service in Nineteenth-Century America. By Faye E. Dudden. 344 pp. Middletown, Conn.: Wesleyan University Press. $19.95.

title: Future Events; Art, Ballet, Concerts
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Youthful Addition April 27 - For its gala benefit at the Joyce Theater, at Eighth Avenue and 19th Street, the Feld Ballet will be augmented by 41 youngsters from city public schools, all students at the New Ballet School, in a 15-minute demonstration of classroom dance technique. Champagne will flow during intermissions and the evening will end with supper at L'Express, a brand-new restaurant next door offering French cuisine and decor inspired by the Paris Metro. Proceeds to the company and its associate school. Tickets, $150 for whole evening; $35 for performance and Champagne only, from 212-777-7710.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: LIEUT. GOV. ALFRED B. DELBELLO and John S. Dyson, Chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York, have exchanged letters over a series of newspaper advertisements that assure the public that the Indian Point nuclear power complex is safe and reliable.

title: CONGRESS SEEKS TO DISCOURAGE TILLAGE OF ERODIBLE GRASSLAND
description: The Reagan Administration, backed by conservationist, environmental and agricultural groups, wants to penalize farmers if they plow under too much of the country's most fragile rural land.

title: John Carlos Returns
description: Fifteen years after he raised his fist in a black-power salute on the victory stand and was sent home from the Olympic Games in Mexico City, John Carlos has returned to the Olympic fold.

title: CHARTER COMMISSION WEIGHS ITS MANDATE AGAINST ITS DEADLINE
description: As the New York City Charter Revision Commission prepares to meet this week, one of its most vexing decisions will be just how much of the charter to revise. The panel's main problem, of course, is the City Council's system of at-large respresentation, which has been declared unconstitutional. But that is by no means its only one.

title: YALE OPENS THE DOOR ON FUTURISM
description: OF all the avant-garde art movements crowding the early years of the 20th century, Futurism was perhaps the most forceful, the most contagious and the loudest.

title: PROBLEMS OF NUCLEAR COSTS GAIN URGENCY
description: CONNECTICUT, one of the most nuclear dependent states in the nation, got a boost last week in its steps to regulate nuclear power when the United States Supreme Court upheld the right of states to bar new reactors until the Federal Government solves the waste disposal problem.

title: CRIME
description: THE AVENGING ANGEL by Rex Burns (Viking, $12.50) is the fifth in the series featuring Detective Gabriel Wager of the Denver Police Department. The first, ''The Alvarez Journal'' of 1975, won an Edgar from the Mystery Writers of America.

title: ISRAEL AGAINST ITSELF
description: The setback to the Reagan peace initiative in the Middle East has given the Israeli Government (which rejected the plan) a sense of relief. With King Hussein of Jordan still unwilling to negotiate on behalf of the Palestinians, the Begin Government is spared a showdown with the United States over the occupied territories. And the Israeli public is spared, at least for the time being, the agony of defining its borders -and its future. But how long can such postponements go on? And at what price?

title: WHAT JOBS WILL BE OUT THERE IN 2001?
description: LEAPFROGGING over the immediate future to the year 2000 and beyond suggests an employment picture dominated by two major themes: catering to the needs of the elderly and working with computers regardless of one's field.

title: JAPANESE SIGNS AND SYMBOLS
description: American graphic artists have begun to pay more attention to functional Japanese design recently - not only to the traditional woodcuts, but to banners, posters and typography. An exhibit of one unusual form, the signboard known as kanban, is now on display at the Japan House Gallery in Manhattan.

title: Paris Prince Is Winner Of the California Derby
description: Paris Prince earned a trip to the Kentucky Derby today when he pulled away in the stretch and captured the $199,300 California Derby at Golden Gate Fields. Tanks Brigade outlasted the fast-closing favorite Billy Ball in the final steps and took second place by a nose. Paris Prince covered the mile and an eighth in 1:51 1/5 and paid $13.80 for $2.

title: Alison Kapner Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fred Kapner of Valley Stream, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Kapner, to Neal Richard Schwartz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Schwartz of Baldwin, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: RANGERS: 1940 AND 2022
description: UP in the Rangers' offices in Madison Square Garden, a thick black headline in a framed newspaper page proclaims, ''Rangers Win Stanley Cup.'' No, it's not one of those newspaper headlines made up in a Broadway arcade. That headline actually appeared in 1940, the year that haunts the Rangers more and more, haunts their front office, haunts their players, haunts their frustrated followers. The year that the Rangers hear chanted in the Nassau Coliseum as Islander followers gloat about their team that now is only eight victories away from a fourth consecutive Stanley Cup championship.

title: FOOTLOOSE AND FANCY
description: The first pair of running shoes Victor Favuzza ever transformed were dyed purple. Even before he got around to trying yellow and green, he had ruined several bathmats and made a mess of the family tub.

title: 2 BIG COAST BANKS ANNOUNCE MERGER
description: The ailing Seafirst Corporation, parent of the largest bank in Washington State, reached an agreement tonight to merge with the BankAmerica Corporation of San Francisco, holding company of the nation's largest bank.

title: A RIBBON AROUND A BOMB
description: FRIDA A Biography of Frida Kahlo. By Hayden Herrera. Illustrated. 507 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $21.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let us here in their presence serve notice to the cowardly, skulking barbarians in the world that they will not have their way.'' - President Reagan, as the bodies of 16 Americans killed in Beirut arrived home. (1:6.)

title: FEELING LOW ABOUT HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: LATELY, I spend a good deal of time staring out the window, watchingt he world pass me by. Yes, I'm aware of the high tech revolution. AndI could run out and enlist. Plenty of my peers take computer courses,s ubscribe to Popular Robotics and make regular pilgrimages to ' 'Silicon Valley.'' But frankly, I'm not interested.

title: CONCERT: FIRES OF LONDON GROUP
description: For the first time since the Bicentennial, Peter Maxwell Davies's new-music group, the Fires of London, has returned to New York, this time under the auspices of ''Britain Salutes New York.'' This is a notable event, and its notability was attested to Friday night when a distinguished assortment of New York new-music specialists and opera enthusiasts turned out at Symphony Space for the ensemble's first concert (the third and final one is tonight).

title: All Things Considered...
description: National Public Radio apparently won't be free of Government subsidies by 1987, as Frank Mankiewicz, its president, had predicted. But N.P.R. will be free of Mr. Mankiewicz, who quit as chief operating officer last week. His resignation came shortly after it was disclosed that N.P.R. was facing a budget deficit more than twice the $2.8 million gap estimated only a month ago. Mr. Mankiewicz, a lawyer and journalist who has headed the network nearly six years, will be succeeded by Ronald Bornstein, director of the University of Wisconsin Telecommunications division.

title: A VIEW THAT IS POSTCARD-PRETTY
description: PROMS, graduation and wedding parties, celebratory days for mothers and fathers, all loom ahead on the late spring calendar. At such festive times, the attention of many residents of Fairfield County seems to tilt northwestward toward a particular restaurant in Weston by a waterfall. We decided recently that we too, after a long hiatus, should tilt in that direction and see how Cobb's Mill Inn is handling its mature years.

title: SAMOA: A PARADISE LOST?
description: At first sight, the island village of Luma seems an unlikely place to achieve fame. Bounded by the milky sea on one side and a jungled hill on the other, it consists of clapboard and stucco bungalows roofed with corrugated iron. There are some shanties by the beach, a small shop, two enormous churches - one sparkling white with pastel trim and the other, abandoned, standing like a gray, stained ghost on the edge of a sandy field where small boys play rugby and cricket. The village has tropical beauty, sun-saturated tranquillity and languor. At the same time, it is shabby and oppressively hot, like many quiet, forgotten backwaters of the third world. But Luma is anything but forgotten. It is on the island of Tau, part of the tiny Manua archipelago of the Samoan islands, which includes the larger, independent country of Western Samoa and the unincorporated territory of American Samoa (see map on page 50). It is here that the 23-year-old fledgling anthropologist Margaret Mead did her first field research some 58 years ago, arriving by boat from Pago Pago, the capital of American Samoa, about 70 miles across the South Pacific. She stayed for about half a year, and while clearly captivated by the people of Tau, she complained of the heat, which made it impossible for her to work for several hours at midday. Later, a devastating hurri-cane left only five houses standing in Luma and prevented her from interviewing villagers for several weeks on the island, a part of American Samoa.

title: Salute to Gonzales
description: He rarely comes east from his retreat in Las Vegas, Nev., but Richard (Pancho) Gonzales will make a nostalgic return to Forest Hills, where 35 years ago he won the first of his two straight United States tennis titles. The Old Lion, as he was popularly known in the twilight of his career, will be honored by the West Side Club for his ''contributions to the traditions of Forest Hills'' in a ceremony during the Mercedes Tournament of Champions, which starts an eightday run May 1.

title: 2 EAGLETS DOUBLE POPULATION OF BALD EAGLES IN NEW JERSEY
description: The bald eagle population of New Jersey doubled this week when a pair of two-week-old eaglets were placed in a nest in this Cumberland County community on Delaware Bay.

title: POWER OF OPEC BEGINNING TO FALL BECAUSE OF DECLINE IN PRICE OF OIL
description: Weakening oil prices are beginning to erode the power of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Changes in the attitude of Western business and governments toward OPEC have been gradual and hesitant, because no one is sure whether prices will stabilize at current levels, fall further or eventually move up again under the impact of another disruption in oil supplies.

title: Headliners; A Sad Solution
description: Though he is a man of letters, Georgi N. Vladimov has mixed feelings about one he wrote three months ago to Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader. In the letter, the dissident writer requested that he and his family be allowed to emigrate rather than face police harassment. But when permission to leave for West Germany was granted last week, Mr. Vladimov said he was ''hoping they would turn us down'' and that he was ''very sorry to be leaving Russia.'' Mr. Vladimov got the star treatment after his first novel, ''Big Ore,'' in 1961, but later fell into disfavor.

title: Valerie Patt to Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael Patt of Longboat Key, Fla., and Kings Point, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Valerie Patt, to David Alan Lederman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Lederman of Rockville Centre, L.I. The wedding is planned for Nov. 26. Miss Patt is a member of the class of '83 at New York University. Her fiance, who attended Monmouth College, is sales manager of EnRoute Maternity Modes Inc. in New York.

title: MILITARY BACKED IN POLL, BUT SPENDING STIRS DEBATE
description: A new public opinion survey has found that Americans have a high regard for the military as an institution but that ''the priority they give military expenditure veers from extreme to extreme.''

title: Lamberto Maggiorani Dead; Starred in 'The Bicycle Thief'
description: Lamberto Maggiorani, who starred in one of Italy's best-known postwar films, ''The Bicycle Thief,'' is dead at the age of 73.

title: BRAZIL CONFIRMS ARMS ON JETS
description: Military technicians boarded three detained Libyan jet transports today and confirmed that they were carrying arms, explosives and ammunition. Nicaragua has confirmed that the supplies were being sent to Managua.

title: Zimmer's Arm Placed in a Cast
description: Don Zimmer, the Yankees' third-base coach, wore a cast on his left arm after the victory yesterday, but the injury did not come from waving six runners home in the third inning.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE HUG THERAPY BOOK, By Kathleen Keating. (CompCare Publications, $4.95.) The bear hug (above, left) is one of many embraces Kathleen Keating illustrates and describes in her warmhearted paperback about ''the power of touch,'' a book that appears to be catching on. With 50,000 copies off the presses after a second printing, its Minneapolis-based publisher reports that the title is selling nationwide. In a gesture readers may interpret as affectionate, CompCare has lowered the price (it cost $6.95 at first). Above, right: from the chapter on ''Ethics and rules of conduct'' a drawing captioned, ''Ask first.''

title: COACH LOOKS EAGERLY TO THE DRAFT
description: THE National Football League's player draft Tuesday will be my first as a head coach, and I feel good about it. To start with, this draft is deep with good players, which makes my position as a head coach better. There's more talent available than usual, so we have a better chance to get players who can help us.

title: Will Iron Bars Plug the Leaks?
description: Precisely which of Washington's veritable torrent of leaks led to the Administration's preoccupation with spilled secrets is still a secret. But last week yet another proposal for keeping the lid on became public.

title: Mary Golden Has Nuptials
description: Mary Francina Golden, an actress with the New Globe Theater in New York, was married yesterday to Kenneth Victor Handal, a partner in the New York law firm of Hall, McNicol, Hamilton, Clark & Murray. The Rev. Paul Walsh performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

title: THE ENGLISH AS HOLBEIN SAW THEM
description: Nothing of its kind could be more remarkable than ''Holbein at the Court of Henry VIII,'' which can be seen at the Pierpont Morgan Library through July 30. The drawings in question have been lent from the Royal Library in Windsor Castle, and they set the standard by which all later portraiture must be judged.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS: LOCAL OFFICIALS MUST SPEAK OUT
description: AN elected official need not represent an entire state or nation in order to feel strongly about human rights violations and bring them to the attention of his or her constituents. Alerting other people to the horrors that too many human beings undergo at the hands of their governments is not solely the responsibility of those who vote on international legislation. In fact, in many cases the efforts of a local official, simply by virtue of his proximity to the people, can be far more effective.

title: TEACHERS TRY TO BUILD MOMENTUM FOR PHYSICS
description: All eyes were on Harold Weisenbloom, who was frantically multiplying his classmates' weight by the length of two wooden planks.

title:
GARDENING;
HEDGES: ALWAYS POPULAR AND USEFUL
description: ONE wonders who might have been the first person to plant a hedge. It may have been a member of some tribe that decided to trade the nomadic way of life of the hunter and herder for that of the sedentary farmer. Families and flocks would have required protection against marauding neighboring tribes and wild predators, and crops planted in those earliest of gardens would have been at the mercy of domesticated and wild animals. Fences would have been nonexistent, for tools with which to make posts and boards would have been exceedingly primitive.

title: FINANCIAL FUTURES: A HOT NEW ACT
description: ABOUT midway through dessert in the executive dining room of a p restigious Chicago bank, Ronald Young shifted uncomfortably in his c hair. The food had been great as usual, but he had a feeling the n ext course would be less pleasant. For the second time in as many y ears, the bank's well-trained portfolio managers were about to r eport that the endowment money the bank invested for Mr. Young and o ther parents of the Lake Forest Country Day School had u nderperformed the market.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: In a new docudrama, the assasination of former President John F. Kennedy is tied to the intense struggle that existed between U.S. Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy and Jimmy Hoffa, the president of the crime-linked International Brotherhood of Teamsters. ''Blood Feud'' will be broadcast on Channel 11 in two parts: part 1 on Manday from 8 to 10 PM (to be repeated Monday at the same time) and part II on May 2 with a rebroadcast on May 4. Robert Blake portrays Mr. Hoffa and Cotter Smith is Robert Kennedy.

title: A HAMPTONS TOUCH IN 'STALLION' SEQUEL
description: A 15-YEAR-OLD boy, his mother and the horse he idolizes live, idyllically, on a farm - location unspecified - somewhere outside New York City. Suddenly, the barn is set ablaze, the horse is kidnapped and the adventure of ''The Black Stallion Returns,'' the recently released sequel to the successful 1979 film, ''The Black Stallion,'' begins.

title: Market Place; Profit Trend Helps Stocks
description: ''LET your profits run.'' Investors heeded that Wall Street adage last week as the Dow Jones industrial average again led other major market indicators to new highs. The Dow closed Friday at 1,196.30, its highest finish on record, after advancing 24.96 points for the week.

title: A BETTER AMBIANCE FOR ELDERLY PARENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: CORPORATE PROFITS ARE IMPROVING
description: A reviving economy, lower interest rates and drastically pared operating costs are beginning to have a healthy impact on corporate profitability.

title: News Analysis
description: After President Reagan pulled Paul A. Volcker aside last Wednesday to apologize for news stories suggesting that he would be let go as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, two things became apparent to aides and economists close to the President.

title: Madeline Kay Carr Weds Dr. Steven Wengrover
description: Madeline Kay Carr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene M. Greenburg of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married in White Plains yesterday to Dr. Steven I. Wengrover, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Wengrover of Manhasset, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi James Perman performed the ceremony at Stouffer's Inn of Westchester.

title: CELTICS TOP HAWKS, 98-79, TO WIN SERIES
description: Larry Bird scored 26 points, and Kevin McHale added 14 in the second quarter to lead the Boston Celtics to a 98-79 victory over the Atlanta Hawks today in the third and deciding game of their playoff series.

title: MIDEAST: A NASTY WAIT
description: Secretary of State George Shultz's trip to the Middle East this week responds more to an American need than to an opportunity for diplomacy.

title: Advertising for Access
description: Ads going up this week in 3,000 subway cars and 1,500 Metropolitan Transportation Authority buses show wheelchairs in use at subway stations and bus stops. The campaign is by the Eastern Paralyzed Veterans Association, which has 1,000 members in the city.

title: BRIEFING
description: Just a 'Technical' Change

title: 2 New Parties Gain Parliament in Iceland
description: Two new political parties - a feminist group and a breakaway group from the Social Democrats -have won entry to Iceland's Parliament, according to final returns today from Saturday's national elections.

title: JETS SEEK HELP FOR FUTURE AND GIANTS WANT IT NOW
description: WHEN the Giants make the 10th pick of the first round in the National Football League draft tomorrow, the player they want is Chris Hinton. But they are sure he will be gone, and they will be happy to settle for Jimbo Covert or Terry Kinard.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: THE STAGE: 'SHOW BOAT,' A THEATRICAL TREASURE
description: DURING the first 25 minutes or so of the new revival of ''Show Boat,'' you'll be nervous. This production, which originated at the Houston Grand Opera, has been traveling the country for months previous to its arrival at the Uris - and looks it. The sets are touring sets, flimsy and crudely lighted; the staging, by Michael Kahn, seems to be chiseled in stone. But it's amazing what glorious voices, in concert with beautiful theater songs, can do to make you forget about all that. My guess is that you, like me, will begin forgetting about all that from the moment Bruce Hubbard sits on a barrel to sing ''Ol' Man River.''

title: UTILITIES LIMITED IN PASSING ALONG COST OF MESSAGES
description: Utilities in New York State that enclose political messages with the bills they send customers will no longer be allowed to pass on the entire cost of those messages to customers under a ruling by the Public Service Commission.

title: Recent Clarinet Music Played by Ian Mitchell
description: Under the auspices of the New York new-music group North-South Consonance, as well as of the ''Britain Salutes New York'' festival, the English clarinetist Ian Mitchell offered a diverse overview of 20th-century British clarinet music last Wednesday night at Symphony Space, attended by a few forlorn souls; being large, Symphony Space looks especially empty when only 20 or 30 people turn up.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1983
description: International

title: A Very Unusual Lie
description: Dennis Walters says he had disproved the theory that ''nothing good can come from hanging around bars.'' Walters, who was heading for a promising career in professional golf until a golf-cart accident rendered him a paraplegic, found while sitting on a bar stool that he could hit a golf ball and make a career as a trick-shot artist.

title: FILIAL TAX INCENTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWSPAPERS SEEK MORE NATIONAL ADVERTISEMENTS
description: The boards of two major newspaper groups this weekend endorsed changes in advertising formats intended to attract additional revenue from national advertisers.

title: KILLINGS OF ARMENIANS MARKED
description: Gov. George Deukmejian told several thousand fellow Armenian-Americans at a rally today that they must not forget the killings of as many as 1.5 million Armenians in Turkey in 1915.

title: TV: HOFFA VS. KENNEDY, A 2-PART DRAMATIZATION
description: WE are in the presence, or at least the shadow, of real people in ''Blood Feud,'' the two-part docudrama, part of ''Operation Prime Time,'' starting on Channel 11 at 8 tonight.

title: KREISKY TO RESIGN
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky's Socialist Party lost its clear majority in Parliament in national elections today, and the Chancellor said tonight that he had decided to resign.

title: THANK HEAVEN FOR PROCRASTINATORS!
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW MAYOR OF CHICAGO INHERITS HEAVY DEFICITS
description: When Representative Harold Washington takes office as Mayor Friday, he will inherit financial problems that will shape his first year in office and may imperil some of the ambitious programs he has proposed.

title: Arguello Stops Noel In 3d Round
description: Alexis Arguello stopped Claude Noel today in the third round of a scheduled 10-round junior-welterweight bout.

title: BETTY FRIEDAN DEFIES BRITONS, WINS DEBATE
description: Betty Friedan was, as she said later, irritated. She had endured the first gibes and sexist jokes in a sporting way, smiling pleasantly. The young British speakers in evening clothes and patent leather shoes at the Cambridge Union Society seemed to be testing the American feminist leader for a sense of humor. But as the onslaught continued, and each speaker who preceded her lampooned the feminist movement and painted rude oral cartoons of what they saw as manly activist women, her smile gave way to a frown.

title: Driver Is Killed
description: Rolf Stommelen of West Germany died of injuries suffered when his sports car crashed midway through The Los Angeles Times-Datsun Grand Prix of Endurance today, a race spokesman said. Stommelen's Porsche 935 lost its left front wheel on the 96th lap of the 6 1/2-hour race and flipped over several times before catching fire. The 38-year-old driver was pulled from the wreck and transported from Riverside International Raceway to Riverside Community Hospital where he died, said Bob Russo, a track spokesman.

title: A Slow Time for the Horse Players
description: THERE is a strike at Aqueduct. The two winning horses showed their solidarity with the striking track-maintenance workers on Saturday by turning in the second and fourth slowest times in the last 30 years of the Wood Memorial.

title: Pedroza Retains W.B.A. Crown
description: Eusebio Pedroza of Panama retained his World Boxing Association featherweight title today when he took a unanimous 15-round decision from Rocky Lockridge of the United States.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day April 13 about insider trading in stock options misstated the title and provisions of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Section 16(a) requires officers, directors and principal shareholders of publicly held corporations to disclose their trading in their company's shares. Section 16(b) requires that if they profit by buying and selling the shares within a six-month period, they turn over such ''short swing'' profits to the company.

title: Good Knees, Bad Ankle
description: DURING their bye in the National Basketball Association playoffs, the Philadelphia 76ers gathered for a few days at nearby Franklin & Marshall college. Thursday night several of them were watching the Knicks finish off the Nets in their miniseries on television, when they heard the Madison Square Garden crowd chanting: ''We want Philly! We want Philly!'' With his soft smile, Julius Erving stared at the TV set.

title: MONDAY, APRIL 25, 1983
description: The Economy

title: JUSTICE DEPT.'S PROSECUTION OFFICE FOR POLLUTERS STRUCK BY FIREBOMB
description: A firebomb was thrown into a ground-floor office of the Justice Department's environmental crimes unit Sunday night, causing minor damage.

title: Cruise Missile Plans Protested in Canada
description: In two demonstrations over the weekend, thousands of Canadians protested plans to test the United States cruise missiles in western Canada.

title: Test Firing of Rockets Is Set In May on Wayward Satellite
description: Engineers trying to rescue the satellite that went astray after it was launched from the space shuttle Challenger will test fire the satellite's maneuvering rockets in early May, the space agency said Friday.

title: HEAVY SUPPLY OF TAX-EXEMPTS DUE
description: The supply of new tax-exempt securities is heavy this week, while relatively few Treasury and corporate issues are scheduled for sale. Analysts at Salomon Brothers estimated that more than $2.8 billion of bonds are scheduled for sale this week, bringing the total for April to $8.3 billion, the largest since last November. The record supply of tax-exempts continues to be aborbed by individuals investors, because demand from banks and casualty insurance companies has been modest.

title: Bronwen E. Williams Is Married to Michael Kaleko
description: Bronwen Elizabeth Williams, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Williams of Dallas, was married there yesterday at the Doubletree Inn to Michael Kaleko, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome D. Kaleko of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi Saul P. Besser performed the ceremony.

title: Bridge: New Yorkers in Shanghai Had to Start Early in Day
description: One of France's world champions, the great Paul Chemla, is reputed to have abandoned a university position as professor of the humanities in favor of bridge because he liked to sleep late in the mornings.

title: FOR DUVALL, 52 IS ONLY HALFWAY IN HIS CAREER
description: HE has been called ''the American Olivier,'' but although he has appeared in 33 films in the last 20 years - some of them major hits - and has acted on Broadway as well, he can still walk down the street without being recognized.

title: Unions Reach Accord With Pittsburgh Brewing
description: Three union locals accepted a new three-year contract with the Pittsburgh Brewing Company today, more than a year before the current pact expires.

title: Daniel B. Herman Marries Beth Falk
description: Beth Falk, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leslie Falk of Nashville, was married in New York yesterday to Daniel Ben Herman, son of Pauline Herman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Melvin Herman. Rabbi Stephen Lerner performed the ceremony at the Columbia University Faculty House.

title: Stepfather Held in Infanticide
description: A 2-year-old Bronx boy, Alexis Castro, died last evening at Lincoln Hospital of extensive bruises - apparently the result of a beating - shortly after he was brought by ambulance from his home at 974 Sheridan Avenue in the Melrose section. The police charged his 21-year-old stepfather, Hector Delgado, with second-degree murder.

title: Quest for 4 Eagles
description: Four eagles from Brooklyn, in exile since 1966, may soon return. For the last several years the 500-pound bronze sculptures have ornamented Parks Department headquarters at the Arsenal in Central Park.

title: Books Of The Times
description: REVOLUTIONARY ROAD. By Richard Yates. 337 pages. Delta-Seymour Lawrence. $7.95.

title: THE 'RIGHT TO DIE': IS IT RIGHT?
description: SINCE the apparent suicide in March of Arthur Koestler and his wife in London, something of an o ld subject - euthanasia - has been debated anew. Only last week, theK oestler deaths were the focus of intense discussion in Dallas at t he annual meeting of the American Association of Suicidology, the g roup of suicide-prevention professionals.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SHADOWY CBS MURDER CASE
description: He is accused of being the hired gunman in a multiple murder case, but after three weeks of testimony by 82 witnesses, a jury has been able to glean little information about the background of the defendant, Donald Nash.

title: D'Arcy Gives Up Heublein Account
description: Alvin Hampel, chairman of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York has resigned the Heublein account because of a ''difference of opinion.'' Heublein, a client for 15 years, currently has at D'Arcy its Harveys Bristol Cream and Don Q Rum, which together bill about $6 million. Heublein's other major agencies for its Spirits division are Marschalk and Laurence, Charles & Free.

title: Knapp's Decker Back in New York
description: Just a month ago, Knapp Communications in Los Angeles announced that, although John L. Decker was to be replaced as group publisher, he would remain at headquarters in a ''yet to be determined capacity.''

title: Swedish Stock Delay
description: Sweden's stock exchange will suspend trading for six days from this Friday because of technical problems at the computerized Securities Registration Center, according to exchange officials.

title: Royals 7, Blue Jays 1
description: Hal McRae hit two singles, had two runs batted in and scored twice to lead the Royals.

title: THE FERMENT OVER CENTRAL AMERICA
description: The House Intelligence Committee is normally a discreet, disciplined group that follows the lead of its chairman, Representative Edward P. Boland, a veteran Massachusetts Democrat not known for rocking many boats.

title: Playing With the Pros
description: Robert Lipeles, a 40-year city employee now with the Department of Ports and Terminals, played piano in Beethoven's ''Archduke'' Trio yesterday. With him were Simca Heled, former first cellist of the Israel Philharmonic, and Dora Schwarzberg, a Russian-born concert violinist.

title: Michael D. Riggs Marries Lisa Borman in Princeton
description: Lisa Borman, a partner in the New York public-relations agency of Borman/Williams Inc., was married yesterday to Michael David Riggs, technical editor of High Fidelity magazine. Rabbi Joshua Glatzer performed the ceremony at the Scanticon-Princeton Hotel in Princeton, N.J.

title: MUSIC: FIRES OF LONDON PLAYS DAVIES
description: PETER MAXWELL DAVIES'S ''Image, Reflection, Shadow'' (1982) received its United States premiere Saturday night at Symphony Space as part of a trilogy of concerts presented by the Fires of London, the British music group under Mr. Davies's direction. The work's ''program'' is taken from a poem by Charles Senior, which imagines a gull gliding over a still bay, its reflection speeding over the water's surface, while obliquely, a dark shadow moves along the green sea floor. It is an arresting image, and Mr. Davies gave it an equally arresting musical reflection.

title: QUARTERBACKS AND OTHERS: A VERY GOOD YEAR
description: THE year 1954 was such a good one for college quarterbacks that four - Bobby Garrett, Lamar McHan, Cotton Davidson and Bernie Faloney - were selected in the first round of the National Football League draft. That had happened only twice before, in 1949 with John Rauch, Stan Heath, Bobby Thomason and Frank Tripucka, and in 1952 with Bill Wade, Babe Parilli, Larry Isbell and Harry Agganis.

title: BIG DAY, BIG GAMES IN BOSTON
description: Doug Kuehl's day at the Boston Garden ended much too soon, some 20 minutes after the Celtics abruptly ended the season of the Atlanta Hawks.

title: Donnelly Leaving Young & Rubicam
description: William J. Donnelly, the Young & Rubicam man who has been in the forefront of cable TV, is leaving the agency. His first priority is to write a book.

title: Mattel Direct Marketing Chooses N.W. Ayer
description: Last December, Mattel Inc. created Mattel Direct Marketing, and last week, the subsidiary chose N.W. Ayer and its subsidiary, Ayer Direct, as its agency.

title: MARCH TOOL ORDERS UP IN MONTH, BUT OFF FROM '82
description: New orders for machine tools -often taken as a barometer of the economy's health - fell sharply last month and for the first quarter of 1983, when compared with 1982 levels. But the March total was sharply improved from the month before and was the highest monthly total since June 1982.

title: EXECUTION LOTTERY
description: Whether Thomas Barefoot lives or dies is not the only question that the United States Supreme Court must decide after hearing his appeal tomorrow. The Justices are also likely to say if other death row inmates are entitled to full appeals before execution. Mr. Barefoot's case thus will affect more than 1,100 men and women sentenced to die nationwide and many more capital defendants to come.

title: Richardson Seeks Sassoon
description: Richardson-Vicks Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Vidal Sassoon Inc., the Los Angeles-based marketer of haircare products. Terms were not disclosed.

title: The Synergy of Jobs and School
description: The high rates of teen-age unemployment and dropouts from school continue to frustrate social planners. A recent experiment suggests that both problems may be better addressed if they are joined together.

title: Sixth Suspect Seized In the Sentry Robbery
description: A sixth suspect in the $11 million Sentry Armored Car robbery in the Bronx on Dec. 12 was arrested last night at Kennedy International Airport when he returned by plane from Greece.

title: STEINBRENNER FINE, $45,000 OVER LIMIT, RAISES QUESTIONS
description: Did Commissioner Bowie Kuhn consider suspending George Steinbrenner for two months before fining him $50,000 for his comments about National League umpires?

title: PEACE IN NICARAGUA
description: Peace is just an empty word if it is not directed at society's well-being. And well-being cannot be achieved by violence. Violence destroys what it attempts to create, be it maintaining the privileges of some or attempting to impose needed changes.

title: SOTHEBY'S TO QUESTION FITNESS OF AMERICANS SEEKING TO BUY IT
description: Sotheby Parke Bernet, the beleaguered auction house, is preparing to mount a counterattack designed to undermine the reputations of two Americans who are trying to buy it, but the Americans remain confident that they will gain control early next month.

title: Jeffrey Pomerantz Marries Donna Greene, a Reporter
description: Donna Greene of Greenwich, Conn., a reporter with the Gannett Westchester Newspapers, and Jeffrey Pomerantz of Greenwich, an investment broker with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., were married yesterday at the Scarsdale (N.Y.) Woman's Club. Rabbi Nicholas Behrmann performed the ceremony.

title: DALLAS SOIL TAINTING: RELOCATION URGED
description: The cigar-shaped, brick and concrete smokestack towers 300 feet above the ground, but it looms even larger in the minds of the people who live in the tumbledown, red-brick West Dallas housing projects just north of the RSR Corporation's lead smelter.

title: MISSING FORMER G.M. OFFICIAL FOUND SLAIN IN BEAR MT. LAKE
description: A man's body recovered earlier this month from a New York State lake has been identified as that of a missing former General Motors executive who had extensive business contacts in Europe and South America. He had three bullets in his head and weights attached to his legs.

title: TURKEY PERMITS POLITICAL PARTIES BUT KEEPS BAN ON FORMER LEADERS
description: Turkey's military Government announced today that it would allow the establishment of political parties, but reiterated that former high-ranking members of outlawed parties could not participate in political activity.

title: CAR OWNERS FORCE RECONSIDERATION OF CRACKDOWN ON DOUBLE-PARKING
description: Angry automobile owners who felt that a time-honored privilege had been taken from them have forced a Manhattan community board to reconsider its demand that the city crack down on double-parking in their neighborhood.

title: Prosecutor vs. the Police
description: Fighting what is perceived as internal discrimination is not normally part of a District Attorney's job, but consider Elizabeth Holtzman's battle to have a woman as a bodyguard:

title: TOPPING OUT CONVENTION CENTER COST OVERRUNS
description: To the Editor:

title: BALLET 'MAYERLING' A TRIUMPH
description: WITH a new young dance sensation in the person of 19-year-old Alessandra Ferri and an exceptionally exciting performance from Wayne Eagling in the leading role, Kenneth MacMillan's ''Mayerling'' closed the Royal Ballet's season Saturday night on a note of exhilarating triumph.

title: SKEPTICISM GROWING OVER THE 'HITLER DIARIES'
description: Skepticism over the authenticity of Hitler's purported diaries widened yesterday among historians, former aides of the dictator and handwriting experts in Britain, West Germany and the United States as the first excerpts were published.

title: Key Solidarity Figure Arrested in Wroclaw
description: One of the top five fugitive leaders of the Solidarity union has been captured by the police, the official Polish press agency said today.

title: THE LIFELONG SOCIALISTS WITH A TOUCH OF THE HAPSBURGS
description: Three days ago, sitting in his magnificent office evocative of the Hapsburgs, Bruno Kreisky was talking about last month's electoral defeat of the West German Social Democrats.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp's $200 million offering of 12-year floating rate notes was priced at 99 7/8, to yield 9.45 percent initially, through Oct. 31, through Salomon Brothers. The rate will float at 70 basis points over the six-month Treasury bill rate.

title: Two Scandinavians Sing at Alice Tully Hall
description: A joint recital by the Swedish mezzo-soprano Sylvia Lindenstrand and the Finnish baritone Jorma Hynninen at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday afternoon was a teaming of two great artists at the height of their powers. Although the hall was not sold out, it was filled with a visceral excitement one could have peeled off the walls; word of mouth should insure that this will be the last time either artist plays to an empty seat in New York.

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE DEBATE SPAWNS METAPHOR WAR
description: As debate has droned on over whether the United States and the Soviet Union should freeze their nuclear arsenals, proponents and opponents have reached deeper and deeper into their bags of rhetorical tricks. Following are two metaphorical views presented a few days ago as the House moved toward a final vote on the issue:

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REAL DOLLS

title: Patricia Griffith Weds Rogih Yazgi, a Lawyer
description: Patricia Jean Griffith, daughter of Mrs. Everett Carson Furman of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Leonard Raymond Griffith, was married yesterday to Rogih Yazgi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tom Yazgi of Jacksonville, Fla. The Rev. Michael Crimmins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

title: Accounts
description: * Better Homes and Gardens magazine to Creswell, Munsell, Fultz & Zirbel Inc. for trade advertising.

title: Playoff to Charles
description: Bob Charles made a 48-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff to beat the local favorite, Greg Powers, in the Tallahassee Open today.

title: TEAMSTERS' NEW LEADER FACES MANY CHALLENGES
description: Jackie Presser, the new president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, faces formidable challenges in attempting to reinvigorate his union, still the largest in America but hardly the strong, feared union it was for decades.

title: SWEDES RANKLED BY TAXES
description: The more that Swedes think about their Government's latest efforts to prop up their welfare state by raising taxes, the less they like it.

title: A LANGUAGE WELL WORTH A FEW YEARS' STUDY
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewis's 9.93 Time Voided by Wind
description: Carl Lewis ran the 100 meters in 9.93 seconds today at the Mt. San Antonio College Relays, but the mark will not count as a world record because of aiding winds.

title: Taiwan Says Its Flier Was Lost, Not a Defector
description: The Defense Ministry today disputed China's report that a Taiwan military pilot had defected, saying it was ''obvious'' he had lost his way in thick fog and flew his propeller-driven plane to China by mistake.

title: EFFECTS OF BIG DEFICITS ON RATES WORRY DEALERS AND INVESTORS
description: Investors and securities dealers are constantly looking for the forces that inevitably will interrupt or reverse the decline of interest rates that has been under way since mid-1982.

title: PEDESTRIAN DEATHS FELL IN CITY BY 22.8% IN 1982
description: The number of people killed in traffic-related deaths in New York City dropped by almost a quarter last year, and the police said the reduction was due largely to a special traffic safety program.

title: Washington Watch; Computer Tax Rules Assailed
description: MANY companies are protesting regulations drafted by the Internal Revenue Service that they say threatens to undermine American efforts to remain pre-eminent in computers. So far they've met little success.

title: L.I.R.R. READY FOR RENOVATION AT PENN STATION
description: The Long Island Rail Road will soon begin a multimillion-dollar renovation of its platforms and waiting space in Pennsylvania Station, one of the nation's busiest terminals.

title: Waltrip a Winner
description: Darrell Waltrip led for all but one of the last 346 laps today as he beat Harry Gant in the Virginia National Bank 500 to win a second straight Grand National stock car race.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Minnesota Twins, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. This game, postponed yesterday because of rain, will match the Twins' Frank Viola, a former St. John's star, against Ron Guidry.

title: Loose Talk About Soviet Cheating
description: President Reagan has been playing with the idea of accusing the Soviet Union of violating arms control agreements. The White House has remanded the matter for further study, but appears eager to dust it off at any time. Asked at a recent photo ceremony if the Russians had violated the SALT treaties, Mr. Reagan replied, ''When have they stopped?'' For the sake of short-term gain, such as helping the defense budget through Congress, the President was evidently tempted to jeopardize the very treaties he would accuse the Russians of violating.

title: Third of Eastern Bloc Envoys Are Spies, Head of F.B.I. Says
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William H. Webster, said today that the F.B.I. had identified one of every three Soviet and Eastern bloc diplomats in the United States as a known spy.

title: SOCIALISTS ARE FAVORED TO WIN THE PORTUGUESE ELECTION TODAY
description: Lisbon fell quiet today on a mandated ''day of reflection'' that precludes campaigning in advance of Monday's general elections.

title: MEDIA PROGRAM NOTES
description: Who conducts the Media Philharmonic? What unseen batons cause the reputations of high Administration officials to reach crescendo and dip to diminuendo?

title: Strike at Caterpillar Ends After 205 Days
description: Members of the United Auto Workers union in six states prepared today to go back to work at the Caterpillar Tractor Company, ending a 205-day strike.

title: Oratorio Society Offers Mendelssohn's 'Elijah'
description: Rediscovery of Mendelssohn's ''Elijah'' as a 19th-century masterpiece seems to be under way, and the performance given the dramatic work by the Oratorio Society at Carnegie Hall last Wednesday night should encourage the movement. The overall interpretation by the chorus, orchestra and five soloists under the direction of Lyndon Woodside was impressive.

title: TV: MARTIN'S 'MAGIC FLUTE' DANCED
description: BOY meets girl. Boy almost loses girl. But boy finally gets girl with the help of a magic flute. That's what happens in the New York City Ballet's production of ''The Magic Flute,'' and that's also what happens in the television version of Peter Martins's ballet, which will be shown tonight at 9 on Channel 13 as a ''Dance in America'' presentation in the ''Great Performances'' series.

title: WADKINS, ON 72-280, KEEPS TITLE BY SHOT
description: Lanny Wadkins, struggling over the final four holes, salvaged a round of par 72 today and won the Tournament of Champions for the second straight year.

title: EXPOS SEND REDS TO 3D LOSS IN ROW, 5-4
description: Andre Dawson hit a two-run homer, and Bryan Little singled in a run in the eighth inning as Montreal rallied to beat the Reds by 5-4 in Cincinnati yesterday.

title: People
description: * Larry J. Iannuzzelli and Rein Luik elected group senior vice presidents at Doyle Dane Bernbach Inc.

title: LOST NEIGHBORHOOD FOUND IN MEMORY
description: Clustered around signs that bore the names of the streets they once lived on, people who had not seen each other in decades and whose memories of being together included playing stickball or sitting outside on milk crates and eating jelly apples, met each other again.

title: Military Analysis
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz's visit to the Middle East comes amid indications that the military situation between Syrian and Israeli forces in Lebanon is growing more tense.

title: STUDY FINDS TV WATCHERS IMPULSIVE
description: The average television viewer today is often restless, distracted and impulsive in his or her viewing habits, and the audience attachment to even the most highly rated programs varies widely, according to a new study of the television audience by a research company in Cambridge, Mass.

title: SEAFIRST'S BUYER GETS LOSS SHIELD
description: The BankAmerica Corporation's $400 million agreement to buy the Seafirst Corporation has been framed to narrow BankAmerica's potential losses from loan problems that might develop at Seafirst, Washington State's biggest bank holding company.

title: Prison Population Sets Record
description: The number of prison inmates in the United States grew by a record 42,915 in 1982 to reach an all-time high of 412,303, the Justice Department said today.

title: OILERS AGAIN TRADE A FIRST-ROUND PICK
description: The Houston Oilers changed first-round positions in Tuesday's National Football League draft for the second time in two days yesterday when they gave Seattle the third pick in exchange for the Seahawks' ninth pick. The Oilers also acquired Seattle's choices in the second and third rounds.

title: U. N. Envoy Says U. S. Backs Central America 'Good Guys'
description: The chief United States delegate to the United Nations, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, said today that Washington was supporting ''the good guys'' in Central America, and she urged Americans to take seriously the Soviet threat in the region.

title: CAREW'S FIVE HITS LEAD ANGELS OVER ORIOLES
description: Brian Downing got the tiebreaking home run, and Rod Carew continued his hot hitting with a triple, double and two singles today to help carry the California Angels to a 7-3 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Valuable Time
description: Last week, when the nation's No.1 sports fan sat down with the coach of the nation's No.1 college basketball team, there was some concern for the country.

title: FOR FALL, A LONGER, LEANER LOOK
description: Though some designers faltered when faced with the new season, others were inspired. Among those who coped ably with the vicissitudes of a new fashion season and a new silhouette were Harriet Winter, Bill Haire and Albert Capraro. Bob Mackie, ignoring reality completely, presented clothes in the familiar Hollywood tradition, not stinting on beads, curves or glamour.

title: BANKS SHOW STRONG EARNINGS
description: Despite soaring loan losses and problem loans, most of the nation's largest bank holding companies reported basic earnings strength in the first quarter of 1983.

title: COLLEGES TURNING MORE TO AID BASED ON MERIT, NOT ON NEED
description: Malcolm Darrell Jones was offered $4,000 in financial aid from Harvard College last year but chose instead to go to the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, which offered him a prestigious Morehead Scholarship covering all his expenses for four years.

title: WINTER WHEAT FARMERS HOPEFUL, BUT NOT ON PROFITS
description: Across Kansas, deep green rectangles and circles of winter wheat lie like brightly colored rugs among the dull beige pastures and unplanted fields.

title: Opening of Babe Play At the Public Is Delayed
description: ''Buried Inside Extra,'' the new comedy by Thomas Babe, which is in previews at the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, has delayed its opening until May 4.

title: News Analysis
description: He emerged from a pack of political hopefuls to become one of the most popular mayors in recent New York City history, but a word often used these days to describe Edward I. Koch's standing is vulnerable.

title: HORNER CLOUTS 2
description: The Mets, who apparently do not travel well, lost their seventh and eighth straight games on the road today when the Atlanta Braves defeated them in a doubleheader, 6-3 and 5-3.

title: AGNES W. KAMMERER
description: Agnes W. Kammerer, retired chairman of the executive committee of the Girl Scouts of the U.S.A., died of a heart attack Friday at New York Hospital. She was a 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Jane Ira Bloom Plays At Village Vanguard
description: Jane Ira Bloom has been leading jazz groups in New York for the last five years, using an instrument, the soprano saxophone, that has not yet found a secure contemporary identity after the overpowering aura that Sidney Bechet brought to it 40 years ago. Moreover, she has been bucking the reluctance of audiences to accept women as hornplaying group leaders, even after the advances of the feminist 1970's.

title: BULLION DEALER'S CLOSING SPARKS INVESTOR WORRY
description: William Lynn Alderdice frequently boasted to reporters and potential investors that he was building his International Gold Bullion Exchange and affiliated corporations into the biggest business on the planet. In a little more than three years he had already parlayed a storefront jewelry shop into what he said was the largest gold and silver dealer in America.

title: BRUINS TAKE SERIES
description: Brad Park's second goal of the game 1:52 into overtime capped a Boston comeback that lifted the Bruins to a 3-2 victory over Buffalo tonight in the seventh and deciding game of their National Hockey League quarterfinal playoff series.

title: Miss Cooke Weds Rev. B.B. Lawrence
description: Miriam Cooke, assistant professor of Arabic at Duke University, was married yesterday at the university in Durham, N.C., to the Rev. Bruce Bennett Lawrence, professor of religion at Duke. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert C. Gregg, an Episcopal priest and a professor at Duke's Divinity School.

title: SOGGIEST APRIL SETTING MARKS DROP BY DROP
description: There has been a far wetter month in New York than this one. There have also been trolleys drawn by horse on Broadway and dozens of schooners berthed at South Street. All these events are equally remote.

title: Advertising; Corporate Campaign For Xerox
description: THE Xerox Corporation, which has sponsored a number of NBC News ''White Paper'' shows over the last couple of years, will use tomorrow night's segment on the subject of ''Crime and Insanity'' to introduce its new corporate ad campaign.

title: Pact at Madison Newspapers Approved to End 5-Year Strike
description: The National Labor Relations Board has approved a settlement to end a strike five and a half years old against Madison Newspapers Inc., which publishes The Wisconsin State Journal and The Capital Times.

title: HINDU CENTER CELEBRATES A MILESTONE
description: From an altar bedecked with thick bouquets of flowers, swamis and scholars yesterday hailed a Hindu society that has brought the insights and practices of the Indian religion to the East Side of Manhattan for a half century.

title: Tigers 4, Mariners 2
description: Larry Herndon's run-scoring triple sparked a tworun, third-inning rally as Detroit completed a sweep of the threegame series.

title: Suddenly, Medically Vulnerable
description: Patients with advanced medical problems tell their doctors they didn't come for help sooner because they had no way to pay. ... Public hospitals are threatened by a surge of bad debt. ... Women arrive at obstetrics wards having had no preparatory care during pregnancy.

title: Letter: On Waterfront Development Keep an Eye on the Port Authority
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND SALVADOR OFFICALS NOTE STEADY REBEL GAINS
description: The last six months have been a period of steady military progress for guerrillas in El Salvador, according to both Salvadoran and American officials.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: A runner with one foot on first base and the other in fair territory is struck by a line drive. The ball bounces into foul territory before it passes first base. What is the ruling? Would it be different if, in the same situation, the runner had one foot in foul territory?

title: Brewers 3, Rangers 1
description: Don Sutton yielded only four hits over eight innings for Milwaukee.

title: Hot Water Cooling Tied To Legionnaires' Disease
description: Energy conservation measures encouraged by the Government may have contributed to outbreaks of Legionnaires' disease in the last decade, an Ohio State University study has concluded.

title: WOOD YIELDING FEW FOR DERBY
description: The skies were too stormy for planes bearing horses to fly to Louisville yesterday, but the air traffic won't be much busier when the weather clears up. Of the 15 horses who ran in the split Wood Memorial Saturday, only Slew o' Gold appears certain to run in the Kentucky Derby May 7. Five other Wood horses -Bounding Basque, High Honors, Country Pine, Parfaitement and Slewpy -are Derby possibilities, but all may be too sore or too poor to make the trip.

title: DELAY FOR GERMAN VIDEOTEX
description: West Germany's ambitious plan to start a nationwide videotex system, called Bildschirmtext, will be delayed because the International Business Machines Corporation could not meet a deadline to get the system's central computers into operation.

title: Creamer Get PPG's Pool-Cleaning Product
description: Creamer's Pittsburgh office has just been assigned PPG's Swimming Pool Chemicals division, which was previously at Ketchum Advertising, long-time agency for all of PPG Industries.

title: Hollis Stacy Victor
description: Hollis Stacy shot a final par 72 today, coasting to a six-stroke victory in the S & H Classic.

title: Marketer Will Lead Wharton Econometric
description: Bruce R. Lippke has been named president of Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates, which started out as a nonprofit corporation owned by the University of Pennsylvania and is now owned by Compagnie Internationale de Services Informatique, a Paris computer company.

title: Canada Triumphs In World Hockey
description: Brian Propp of the Philadelphia Flyers scored two goals and set up a third today as Team Canada defeated East Germany, 5-2, at the world ice hockey championships.

title: Tennis, Everyone
description: There will be a new city game in the public school playgrounds of New York, which over the years have spawned legions of basketball players.

title: Adept Wins Top Flight
description: Adept, a wet-track specialist, splashed to a front-running upset victory under Karen Rogers yesterday in the $108,600 Top Flight Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: The U.N. Today; April 25, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FAST CHILE SLIDE INTO DEPRESSION BRINGS SUFFERING
description: Chile, whose fast-growing free market economy was being hailed just two years ago as a ''miracle,'' has since plunged into one of South America's worst depressions.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am resigning as Chancellor. I am of the belief that with such an election result one has to draw the consequences.''

title: White Sox 9, Indians 3
description: Scott Fletcher knocked in four runs and scored another as Chicago ended a three-game losing streak.

title: FROM TREES TO REPTILES: A CENTRAL PARK CENSUS
description: Sixteen urban forestry students with 16 clipboards and 16 pencils ventured into an urban forest called Central Park last summer and began to count trees.

title: DIPLOMATS AT U.N. FEAR COUNCIL IS LOSING ITS TEETH
description: The Security Council, the world organization's principal body for settling disputes and keeping the peace, has recently been holding debates without voting on resolutions, and to many delegates here this is a troubling development.

title: Chief Fighting Back At Louisiana Land
description: The man in the spotlight at the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company is John G. Phillips, chairman and chief executive, who is directing the strategy against a bid by a Texas group to oust management and take over the company.

title: PUERTO RICANS SEE GAIN IN POLITICAL POWER
description: Puerto Ricans from across the United States gathered here over the weekend for the second National Congress for Puerto Rican Rights. They conceded the loss of some ground in their struggle for social and economic equality but were pleased about what they characterized as a signal for future gains: the election of Representative Harold Washington, who is black, as Mayor of Chicago.

title: Rose Brooks and Ivan Veit Are Married in Manhattan
description: Rose Brooks, associate director of the office of alumni affairs and development at Columbia College, and Ivan Veit, a retired executive vice president and a former member of the board of directors of the New York Times Company, were married in their Manhattan home yesterday.

title: COSMOS LOSE, 2-1, IN SEASON OPENER
description: The Cosmos, looking disorganized because of a makeshift lineup, lost to the Toronto Blizzard, 2-1, today in their North American Soccer League season opener.

title: Miss Navratilova Wins
description: Martina Navratilova fought off a second-set surge by Andrea Jaeger today to win, 6-1, 7-5, and take her fourth title in the $200,000 United Airlines Tournament of Champions.

title: Houston Symphony Under Comissiona
description: There's been a seven-year hiatus between Houston Symphony Orchestra performances at Carnegie Hall, but Saturday night's concert was well worth the wait. Under the vigorous leadership of its music directordesignate, Sergiu Comissiona, the Houston Symphony proved a disciplined, euphonious ensemble; at its best, this is an orchestra capable of crossing swords - or violin bows - with the most distinguished competition.

title: Red Sox 4, A's 2
description: Dwight Evans hit a bases-empty homer in the first inning and a three-run homer in the eighth to lead Boston.

title: Connors Takes King Final, 7-6, 6-1
description: Jimmy Connors defeated Mark Edmondson of Australia, 7-6, 6-1, in a windswept final of the Alan King-Caesars Palace Tennis Classic today.

title: SQUEEZE AT EASTERN AIRLINES
description: During most of the recession, and in the face of losses, Eastern Airlines has clung to its bold strategy of modernizing its fleet of planes, once one of the most outdated in the country.

title: LEARY LECTURES AT HARVARD FOR FIRST TIME IN 20 YEARS
description: For the first time since his dismissal from Harvard 20 years ago for experimenting with mindaltering drugs, Timothy Leary returned today to praise the university as the ''big league of chemical psychedelic experimentation.''

title: MALONE LEADS 76ERS PAST KNICKS IN OPENER, 112-102
description: Moses Malone, following some uncertainty over whether his aching knees would allow him to play today, not only played, but also devastated the Knicks.

title: CHINA'S VITAL BIRTH-CONTROL EFFORT DOES NOT INCLUDE INFANTICIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPERTS TO STUDY CRAWL TOWARD METRIC SYSTEM
description: Representatives of industry, Government and other interested organizations plan to gather Monday to assess the conversion of the nation to the metric system of measurement from inches and pounds, a drive that has slowed to a crawl.

title: Commodities; Institutions Are Wary Of Futures
description: IF the stock options and index markets are made to order for equities portfolio managers, which they are, then why do so few of the institutions use them? After all, where else can a pension fund, bank trust or mutual fund manager get such cheap ''insurance'' against a decline in the value of the institution's stock portfolio?

title: RIDING THE WHITE WATER
description: WITH the recent heavy rains swelling the rivers and quickening their rush to the sea, canoeing offers a variety of challenges to stir the adventurers, from the white-water novice to the expert.

title: Index; International
description: Diplomats at U.N. fear Council is losing its teeth A2 Socialists are favored to win the Portugese election today A6 Turkey permits political parties but bans former leaders A6 Around the World A7 Lifelong Socialist with a touch of the Hapsburgs A8 Government/Politics Utilities may not pass along cost of political statements B2 New Chicago mayor will inherit heavy financial problems B11 Washington Talk Ferment over the question of more aid for Central America A14 The rhetorical fallout from the nuclear freeze debate A14 The Calendar A14 Briefing A14 General Around the Nation A10 Winter wheat farmers optimistic, but not about income A10 Relocation urged for families near Dallas lead smelter A10 Timothy Leary returns to Har- vard for first time in 20 years A12 Reminiscences bring a Bronx neighborhood alive again B1 Surveys in Central Park count everything from trees to fish B1 Agreement made on uniformity in size of newspaper ads B4 Puerto Ricans see encourage- ment in Chicago's election B6 California's Governor marks deaths of Armenians B10 New Teamster president Jackie Presser has tough job ahead B12 Religion Hindu center on east side cele- brates its 50th anniversary B2 SportsMonday Baseball: Steinbrenner fine, over limit, raises questions C2

title: 5,000 at Boston Rally Protest Animals' Use in Experiments
description: A crowd of 5,000 demonstrators was told today that protests would increase until no more animals were harmed in scientific experiments.

title: OLD U.S. WEAPONS AMONG ARMS FOUND ON A LIBYAN PLANE
description: The Brazilian Air Force today finished unloading four Libyan planes being detained in Brazil, and a military spokesman said preliminary examination of the cargo had turned up arms of both Soviet and United States manufacture.

title: NEEDLESS FEDERAL SECURITY IS CHARGED
description: In House and Senate hearings last week, the Reagan Administration was accused of consistently trying to restrict the public's access to information about the Government without adequately demonstrating that the release of information had resulted in any damage.

title: Study Says OPEC Trims Aid to Third World
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries provided aid to developing countries in 1981 that, as a proportion of gross national product, was four times that given by Western industrial countries and Japan, an official report published today showed.

title: ** Company Reports ** WASHINGTON MUTUAL SAVINGS BANK (SEATTLE, WASH)
description: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Net loss 1,300,000 b6,300,000 b-After an extraordinary gain of $3,200,000 on bond repurchase.

title: Digital, Prime Nets Off
description: Two major manufacturers of minicomputers, the Digital Equipment Corporation and Prime Computer Inc., yesterday reported lower earnings for the most recent quarter, partly as a result of the recession.

title: SULLIVAN MINING GROUP LTD reports earnings for qtr to Feb 28.
description: b-Includes tax credits of $243,000 for the quarter and $599,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes tax credits of $101,000 for the quarter and $252,000 for the 6 months.

title: German Tube Mill Plan
description: Mannesmannroehrenwerke A.G. plans to build a new tube rolling mill in Duisburg, a company spokesman said today. He said that an investment of more than $140 million would be needed.

title: ** Company Reports ** SYSTEM INDUSTRIES INC (O)
description: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Revenue 20,601,000 16,956,000 Net inc 71,000 381,000 Share earns .02 .10

title: ALLIED RESTRUCTURE DROPS 'PARACHUTES'
description: The Allied Corporation announced today that its recent takeover of the Bendix Corporation had prompted a major restructuring and the elimination of executives' lucrative severance agreements known as ''golden parachutes.''

title: SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a realized investment gain of $45,852. c-Includes a realized investment gain of $177,400.

title: EASTERN CO reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net income.

title: ** Company Reports ** CONSOLIDATED-TOMOKA LAND CO (O)
LITTLE EFFECT SEEN FROM REACTOR BAN
