description: The Supreme Court's ruling that states may block construction of nuclear power plants will have no impact on construction in the next few years, according to spokesmen for utilities and public service commissions and groups opposed to such construction.

title: TEAMSTERS END DISPUTE WITH DANNON COMPANY
description: The Dannon Company and the union that represents its drivers and production workers have reached an agreement ending a sometimes violent, three-month-long labor dispute, the two sides announced yesterday.

title: SILICON VALLEY GROUP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
WISCONSIN POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DISTILLERS CO. TO GET NEW CHAIRMAN IN FALL
description: John M. Connell has been named chairman of the world's largest producer of Scotch whisky, the Distillers Company. He will take on the new job in September.

title: ** Company Reports ** RIHT FINANCIAL CORP
description: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Net inc 1,104,000 1,794,000 Share earns .52 .89

title: MAGIC CHEF INC reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
WESTSIDE FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a net writeoff of $1,390,000 from the sale of low rate mortgages.

title: SPRING FLOODS HEAD FOR TOXIC SWAMP
description: The floodwaters are rising in Devil's Swamp on schedule. It happens every April and June. The big cypress swamp in the Mississippi River flood plain just north of Baton Rouge fills with water running down from the north and soon the swamp is more of a morass than ever, a greasy brown slough of river water, bayou water and leaching toxic chemicals.

title: OUTLOOK FOR SUMMER JOBS SAID TO IMPROVE SLIGHTLY
description: For the first time in at least two years, government officials believe the summer job outlook for young people in the New York area has improved. But they emphasize that jobs will still be hard to get and that many young people will be left with none.

title: ** Company Reports ** SUBURBAN AIRLINES
description: Qtr to March 31 1983 1982 Revenue 4,095,750 3,792,559 Net loss 23,786 b115,927 Share earns .05 b-Net income.

title: ** Company Reports ** FOSTER WHEELER CORP (N)
East Meets West on S.I.
description: East Meets West on S.I.

description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $617,000 0 HECLA MINI QtrtoMarch31 1983 1982 Revenue 20,398,000 12,910,000 Netinc 7,642,000 1,057,000 Shareearns .41 b-Net loss.

title: ** Company Reports ** HUGHES TOOL CO (N)
** Company Reports ** PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF N C INC (O)
ROYAL CROWN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOMAC INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $1,260,000 for the quarter and six months. c-Net loss. d-Including an extraordinary credit of $46,000 for the quarter and six months.

title: ** Company Reports ** CANADA PACKERS LTD
description: Year to March 26 1983 1982 Sales 3,000,000,000 2,940,000,000 Net inc 20,961,000 30,039,000 Share earns 3.49 5.01 The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: TV: 'CRIME AND INSANITY' ON NBC
description: AN NBC ''White Paper'' looks at criminal insanity tonight, particularly at the role of psychiatrists in the criminal justice system. NBC doesn't like what it sees, but concludes, more or less, that it doesn't know what to do about it. The program, ''Crime and Insanity,'' will be shown on Channel 4 at 10 P.M.

title: ZENITH RADIO CORP reports earnings for qtr to April 2.
description: b-Net loss.

title: BIRTCHER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CENCOR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Minorities, Merit and the Schools
description: The New York City schools chancellor choice was already a painful tangle. Then Gordon Ambach, the state Education Commissioner, ruled Robert Wagner Jr. technically unqualified to serve - leaving the city's Board of Education with an even tighter knot. Unless the board now acts with careful concern for black and Hispanic minorities, the charges of white racism that have so troubled the search will flare even higher.

title: ** Company Reports ** REPUBLIC AUTOMOTIVE PARTS INC (O)
Trantino Loses Bid For Earlier Parole
description: Thomas Trantino, imprisoned for almost 20 years for killing two police officers during a 1963 holdup in a Lodi bar, today lost his latest bid for freedom.

title: ** Company Reports ** ASHLAND OIL INC (N)
Atlanta Ballet Gets Role With Brooklyn College
description: The Atlanta Ballet will become the resident dance company of the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College.

title: DR PEPPER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
UNITED MISSOURI BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: Sikh Youth Kills 2 in India
description: A Sikh youth firing a submachine gun killed a police official and a 9-year-old boy at a Sikh temple today, prompting Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to call an emergency Cabinet meeting. News reports said the official, Deputy Police Chief A.S. Atwal, and the boy, Bir Inder Singh, were gunned down outside a temple in Amritsar in Punjab state. Mrs. Gandhi called the Cabinet meeting to seek ways of preventing new violence in Punjab.

title: Tandy Upgrading TRS-80 Computer
description: The Tandy Corporation today will introduce a replacement for the mainstay of its personal computer product line, the TRS-80 Model III. The new TRS-80 Model 4 will have a number of improvements over the Model III, including extra memory and the ability to display 80 letters on a line of text, instead of 64. The new computer will also be able to run the popular CP/M operating system, which is an internal control program, as well as programs now used on the Model III.

title: J.P. Stevens Pact Ratified

The votes were unanimous, according to Bert Beck, a union spokesman. He said the 25-month contract, which covers about 3,500 employees and replaces the union's first pact with Stevens, reached in 1980, did not deal with wages or fringe benefits but with ''conditions of life with the company.''

title: NEW FOCUS ON DIAGNOSING TESTICULAR CANCER

title: SCIENTISTS UNRAVELING MYSTERY OF TOXIC SHOCK
description: WHILE public concern about toxic shock syndrome has waned and tampon use has reportedly returned to former levels, new studies of the life-threatening disease are finally beginning to reveal how and why it occurs and exactly what relationship it has to tampons.

title: OBERLIN: POINTED WAY 150 YEARS AGO

description: It was a far cry from their natural habitat, the bustling city rooms and the thrashing pressrooms that churn out America's newspapers. But the leaders of American journalism eased quite comfortably into the Waldorf-Astoria's East Foyer yesterday afternoon, where they sipped drinks under chandeliers during a free moment at the 97th annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.

title: Anne H. Cahn and James F. Leonard
description: President Reagan may yet face a crucial decision: what to do about possible Soviet violations of arms control agreements. Administration debate pits the State Department, much of the intelligence community and the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency against the Defense Department. The Pentagon, led by the Under Secretary for Policy, Fred C. Ikle, and Assistant Secretary for International Security Policy, Richard N. Perle, reportedly wants Mr. Reagan to go public with accusations; the others counsel caution, urging him to first submit the allegations to the United States-Soviet Standing Consultative Commission. Mr. Reagan indicated Saturday that the Administration might first go to Moscow through private channels. If in the end, after an Administration study, he chooses to go public, that act will have weighty domestic and foreign policy implications.

title: MGM/UA Debt
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company said it used the $342 million in net proceeds from a 10-year note sale last week to reduce its bank debt by more than $215 million. The company also repurchased for $124 million a $130 million note issued to the Transamerica Corporation in 1981 when MGM/ UA acquired United Artists. The refinancing puts the company's total long-term debt at about $500 million, with $136 million owed to banks at interest rate of 0.5 percent above the prime lending rate and approximately $335 million in long-term notes paying 10 percent, according to Jason Rabinovitz, vice president of finance for the company's MGM unit.

CITY'S 'SPECIAL TAXES' FOUND LAGGING
description: Collections are lagging on a variety of New York City's ''special taxes,'' Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday. On the eve of publication of a city budget in which the list of potential new city taxes and the amounts they are to raise have been reduced, Mr. Goldin said the city was ''losing millions of dollars a year in revenues'' from the special taxes, including levies on cigarettes, hotel charges and retail wines and liquors.

title: Cost of Competing
description: Eating disorders such as anorexia nervosa and bulimia are common among gymnasts, some participants in the sport say, and Cathy Rigby McCoy says she was no exception. Mrs. McCoy, who led the American women's gymnastic team to its best showings ever in the 1968 and 1972 Olympics, said she first became involved with bulimia - binge eating followed by induced vomiting - while training for the 1968 Olympics. Mrs. McCoy, now 30 years old, said: ''I wanted to be a top gymnast. Nobody can tell you that you're thin enough.''

From his simple glen-plaidp ants suits - the fashion term is being revived by a number of d esigners this season - to his extraordinary beaded evening sweaters w orn with slim silk pants or asymmetrically hemmed floating skirts, t he collection was remarkably well executed.

His style of play invited comparisons to Bobby Orr, comparisons that Potvin did not try to discourage.

title: The Long Season
description: If the National Basketball Association championship series goes to its limit, the date of the final game would be June 12, the latest in league history. The latest finish was last year, when Los Angeles defeated Philadelphia in six games, wrapping up the title on June 8.

ARMSTRONG WORLD ELECTS NEXT CHIEF
description: Armstrong World Industries, which makes flooring and other interior furnishings, said yesterday that its board of directors had named Joseph L. Jones as chairman, chief executive officer and president, effective Aug. 1.

title: 4 Die as 8 Vehicles Crash Upstate
description: Four people were killed and four injured in an eight-vehicle accident last night on Interstate 81 at Whitney Point, N.Y., 15 miles north of Binghamton.

title: ISLANDERS-BRUINS: A MATCHUP OF TWO TENACIOUS SURVIVORS
description: The Boston Bruins remain in the Stanley Cup playoffs with three teams that did not beat them during the regular season. The Bruins were 3-0 against the Edmonton Oilers, 3-0 against the Chicago Black Hawks and 2-0-1 against the Islanders. Moreover, the Islanders scored only one goal in each of those three games.

title: ROBINSON NUGENT INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 28, 1983.

title: LESSONS FOR ARABS
description: Following the Palestine Liberation Organization's rejection of the proposed agreement by King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat for negotiations based on President Reagan's Middle East peace plan, Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned that leadership has ''to be exercised constructively,'' and that the P.L.O. had failed ''to measure up to those responsibilities.'' To underscore his point, he said, ''There's a saying around here, 'Use it or lose it.' '' Now embarked upon his first official trip to the Middle East, he might well counsel Arab leaders and Palestinians to examine how leadership has been exercised by Israelis.

title: INGREDIENT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HURDLES TO ARCTIC NATION-BUILDING
description: To the Editor:

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Japan Cycle Exports Off
description: Japan's motorcycle exports in the last fiscal year fell to 3.4 million units from 4.3 million the year before, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: JERSEY COURT RULES PRETRIALS MUST BE OPEN TO PUBLIC
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the public and press have the right under both the Federal and State Constitutions to attend pretrial hearings in criminal prosecutions.

title: 12 Schoolchildren Are Killed In Bus-Truck Collision in Italy
description: Twelve schoolchildren died and 35 other people were injured today when a bus crashed head-on into a truck near this central Italian city.

title: SHELLER-GLOBE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Hartford Rejects Drinking Age Rise
description: The State Senate rejected today a bill to increase Connecticut's legal drinking age to 21 from 19.

title: CBS RELEASES ITS STUDY OF VIETNAM DOCUMENTARY
description: CBS News yesterday made public the text of an internal inquiry into charges that it had violated its own standards in preparing a 90-minute documentary on the Vietnam War, broadcast last year.

title: Hoechst-Kuwait Link
description: Abdul Baqi al-Nouri, chairman and director of Kuwait's Petrochemical Industries Company, will be proposed for election to the board of Hoechst A.G., a Hoechst spokesman said today. Last September, Hoechst said that Kuwait had obtained a stake of more than 24 percent in the company.

title: Pennsylvania Bank Borrowings
description: The First Pennsylvania Corporation said it had prepaid some $150 million on borrowings that were part of a 1980 rescue loan from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and a group of banks that was intended to prevent the collapse of First Pennsylvania Bank.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have always believed that allspice is a blend of many spices designed as a simple ingredient for fruitcakes, spice cakes and so on. A friend says that it is a single spice. Can you enlighten me?

title: WINE TALK
description: A NUMBER of readers, including one physician, have inquired about the relationship between wine and diabetes. Essentially they want to know if diabetics can drink wine. In most cases they are confused by the talk of sugar in wine and in the wine-making process.

title: Change for Blue Grass
description: Whichever horse wins the Blue Grass Stakes at Keeneland here Thursday could become the favorite for the Kentucky Derby May 7. It has happened five times in the last 10 years, and 11 of the last 24 Derby winners ran first or second in the Blue Grass. But this year, Marfa, the early favorite for both races, and several others in the Blue Grass field of 13 may come up short when they hit the stretch, or what is left of it.

title: LERMAN NAMED EDITOR OF VANITY FAIR
description: Leo Lerman has been named editor in chief of Vanity Fair, the recently revived magazine of arts and culture. He replaces Richard Locke, whose departure after only three issues had been predicted because of his stormy relationship with the magazine's publisher and because the magazine has met with unfavorable critical reviews.

title: WHO ADVISES REAGAN?
description: President Reagan's White House staff is divided into three parts: the upstairs part headed by the pragmatic James Baker; the downstairs part headed by the conservative Judge Clark; and the backstairs part patrolled by their assistants, who tell the press about the differences between upstairs and downstairs.

title: Sotheby Expects Profit
description: The Sotheby Parke Bernet Group P.L.C. said today that it expected to show a profit this year and if so would resume dividends. Sotheby's made the statement in its formal defense against the bid for the group by the GFI/Knoll International Holding Company.

title: CHB FOODS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 27.
U.S. WORRIED OVER IRAN'S BAHAIS
description: Reports reaching the State Department and members of the Bahai faith in the United States reveal new persecution in Iran against the Bahais, including executions and the barring of tens of thousands of Bahai children from attending school.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MONDALE'S ADDRESS TO PUBLISHERS
description: Following are excerpts from a speech by former Vice President Walter F. Mondale to the 97th annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association in New York yesterday, the text of which was made available by his staff:

title: Reagan Picks an Envoy
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate Curtin Winsor Jr., president of the Winsor Pittman Coal Company in West Virginia, to be Ambassador to Costa Rica.

title: WYOMING TOWN SINKING INTO HISTORY AS ABANDONED MINE SHAFTS COLLAPSE
description: The corner of Fred Radosevich's house is sagging, and the sidewalk alongside is buckling. When it rains, he says, the ground near his driveway sometimes disappears, like sand through the neck of an hourglass.

description: Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda announced unexpectedly today that he was retiring from politics and would not accept a second term.

description: Dr. Sheldon Novick, a former president of the Brooklyn Psychiatric Association, died of cancer Sunday at North Shore University Hospital, Manhasset, L.I..

description: MOST economists think a recovery has started in the United States and perhaps in the rest of the industrial North. But in the developing countries of the South, depression and the threat of financial ruin persist.

title: Giants Get Kinard, Safety, as Top Pick
description: The Giants entered the National Football League draft yesterday seeking help on the offensive and defensive lines, and at safety and tight end. They used the first 4 of their 13 choices to help fill the gaps, with three predictable selections and one mild surprise.

title: CHANGE IN PUERTO RICO'S STATUS DEBATED AT HARVARD
description: The leaders of Puerto Rico's three main political parties shared the stage at a Harvard Law School forum Monday night, each painting a dismal picture of economic conditions on the island.

title: ROYAL TRUSTCO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
3,000 Mourn Victims Of Embassy Bombing
description: More than 3,000 mourners filled the Washington Cathedral today in a tribute to 17 Americans killed in the bombing last week of the United States Embassy in Beirut, Lebanon.

title: SEGMENTING OF TRANS WORLD UP FOR VOTE
description: Four months ago Odyssey Partners, one of many Wall Street houses on the prowl for undervalued stocks, disclosed that it held more than a million shares of the Trans World Corporation.

title: Cuba Accuses U.S.  Of Violating Airspace
description: Cuba said today that a United States reconnaissance plane had violated Cuban airspace in what it called ''a deliberate and cold provocation.''

title: COUNCIL BOLSTERS LAW TO PENALIZE NUISANCE STORES
description: The New York City Council amended the ''public nuisance'' law yesterday to make it easier for the city to close down or fine chop shops, which sell stolen car parts; smoke shops, which sell marijuana, and hotels with prostitution and narcotics rings.

title: LOSSES FOR U.S. STEEL, BETHLEHEM
description: The nation's two largest steelmakers yesterday reported sizable first-quarter losses, reflecting the steel industry's continuing lag behind the nation's economic recovery. The United States Steel Corporation, the No.1 producer, lost $118 million in the first quarter, and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported a $175 million loss.

description: As the superintendent at 400 East 77th Street, Fred Pedreira made a lot of telephone calls to Manhattan Cable TV. The building is being converted into a co-op, and many apartments are vacant.

title: Questions Blocked In DeLorean Case
description: An attorney for the creditors of the DeLorean Motor Company said efforts to question a Swiss lawyer who may know what happened to some $17 million will continue despite a courtroom setback.

description: The $225 million fraud by O.P.M. Leasing Services Inc. depended for its success on the ''ignorance, carelessness, poor judgment or selfinterest'' of many businessmen and professionals who dealt with the company, a bankruptcy trustee said in a report released yesterday.

description: Two Thai nationals were arrested and 80 pounds of nearly pure heroin were confiscated in one of the largest heroin seizures in United States history, Federal investigators said today.

5 Arrested in Sale Of Guns at Grocery
description: Four Queens men were arraigned yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on charges of illegally transporting handguns into New York City and selling them at a Corona grocery.

title: SMALL BOMB EXPLODES AT WAR COLLEGE
description: A bomb apparently placed in a flowerpot exploded on the front steps of the National War College at Fort McNair tonight, blowing out windows and causing other structural damage. No injuries were reported.

title: Power Plant Law Facing Challenge
description: In what could become a reversal of Government policy, the Federal agency that regulates hydroelectric power has decided, in effect, to challenge the law under which utilities owned by municipalities will be given the right to acquire privately built dams with hydroelectric plants.

title: Barclays Debentures Sold at 11.69% Yield
description: The Barclays North American Capital Corporation, a subsidiary of Barclays Bank P.L.C., sold $400 million of 20-year debentures that were offered at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 11.69 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: MUSIC: A FINNISH OPERA, 'TEMPTATIONS,' AT MET
description: THE world knows the Finns to be a musical people, thanks largely to the creative labors of Sibelius, but their tiny nation has not been generally identified with opera except as a recent source of some excellent singers. No Finnish opera has yet been able to push its way into the international repertory. However, in hopes of rectifying that situation, the Finnish National Opera company has exported two contemporary works to the Metropolitan Opera House for a fourperformance run.

title: WRITER, EDITOR AND EARLY FEMINIST
description: Suzanne La Follette, an early feminist who wrote on conservative issues and was a founding editor of several magazines, including The National Review, died last Saturday at the Stanford University Hospital Nursing Home in California. She was 89 years old.

title: How the Draft Works
description: Each year the 28 teams in the National Football League replenish their supply of players through the college draft. The teams, picking roughly in inverse order of the previous season's records, can select any player whose original college class is graduating.

title: THE CARTER LESSON FOR BLACK VOTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: New British Securities Rules
description: Stricter Government controls over licensed securities dealers will go into effect on June 1, the Trade Department said today.

Composer at Tanglewood
description: The German-born composer Hans Werner Henze has been named composer-in-residence for this year's season at Tanglewood's Berkshire Music Center. Mr. Henze, who has composed works for ballets and operas as well as orchestral, choral and chamber pieces, will join the center in July. Several works by Mr. Henze will be presented this season, including ''Bacarola,'' which is scheduled to be performed by the Boston Symphony Orchestra on July 17.

title: BBDO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After foreign currency translation losses of $50,000 in the latest first quarter and $108,000 in year-ago first quarter.

title: The Shultz Shuttle's Destination
description: By offering to shuttle around the Middle East until everyone agrees to withdraw from Lebanon, Secretary of State Shultz may have condemned himself to do his Christmas shopping in the souks of Jerusalem. If Mrs. Shultz doesn't mind an excess of copper trinkets, the time may be well spent.

title: Stanley Roth Sr. Dies; Headed Retail Groups
description: Stanley Roth Sr., a retailing executive for 61 years, died Thursday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan. Mr. Roth was a former chairman of Apparel Buying Associates Inc., president of Grayson-Robinson Stores Inc., president of the Darling Stores Corporation, a vice president and managing director of the Golden Rule Department Store in St. Paul, and vice president of Gimbel Brothers and general manager of Gimbels in Milwaukee.

title: EL PASO CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Fannie Mae Denial
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan yesterday denied a request by the Federal National Mortgage Association to sell its debentures in the Eurobond market through its Netherlands Antillies subsidiary. Mr. Regan said approval of the request could have an ''adverse effect'' on current renegotiations of the United States tax treaty with the Netherlands Antilles.

4 Cuomo Nominees Approved by Senate

title: TIME SAYS IT NEGOTIATED TO BUY DIARY
description: Time magazine said yesterday that it had negotiated to buy the rights to the purported diaries of Adolf Hitler from Stern, the West German news magazine. But the deal came apart, a spokesman said, when the two parties were unable to overcome several major stumbling blocks, including the price to be paid for the rights.

title: CHINESE SCHOLAR SEEKING ASYLUM HELD IN SEX CASE
description: A Chinese research scientist who is seeking political asylum in the United States was unexpectedly arrested as a sex offender today midway through a hearing at which the Reagan Administration was seeking to justify its refusal to grant him asylum.

title: TAMPAX INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MAYOR FEINSTEIN, BY WIDE MARGIN, DEFEATS SAN FRANCISCO RECALL BID
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein tonight won a resounding endorsement as San Francisco voters rejected the attempt of a tiny political group to remove her from the office she has held since December 1978.

title: Ex-CBS President Buys Upstate TV Station
description: John D. Backe, a former president of CBS Inc., is developing a new communications company and for starters, he announced yesterday the acquisition of a Schenectady, N.Y., television station from the General Electric Company.

title: ELDORADO BANCORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest first quarter reflect the acquisition of the Bank of India completed on April 2, 1982.

title: 400 OF 4,000 SITES DRAW OIL BIDDERS
description: At the Interior Department's latest - and largest - offshore leasing auction, held in New York yesterday, 12 oil companies, led by Shell Offshore Inc., the Atlantic Richfield Company and the Gulf Oil Corporation, bid on only 40 of the more than 4,000 blocks in the mid-Atlantic that were available.

title: CLEVETRUST REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: SHULTZ SAYS EGYPT AND THE U.S. AGREE
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Egypt and the United States had identical views on the need not only for all foreign forces to be withdrawn from Lebanon but also for them to be withdrawn in a way that ends local resistance to Beirut's rule over the countryside.

title: 14-Year Fill-In
description: Al Attles, who resigned as coach of the Golden State Warriors on Monday, may have been the longest interim coach in National Basketball Association history.

title: Seat Belt Rejection Defended
description: The Reagan Administration met skeptical questions today when it told the Supreme Court that it scrapped a requirement for automatic seat belts in cars on the ground that the devices would not increase safety.

title: MCA HIRES IRVING AZOFF
description: MCA announced today that Irving Azoff, the personal manager of a dozen top record artists, has been named president of the MCA Record Group and vice president of MCA Inc.

title: 52.9% Gain for Witco
description: The Witco Chemical Corporation, producer of a wide variety of specialty chemical and petroleum products, said yesterday that its net income in the first quarter climbed 52.9 percent, to $10.7 million, or $1.11 a share, from $7 million, or 74 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales slipped 3.3 percent, to $323 million, from $334 million.

title: Louisiana Land Royalty Trust
description: Directors of the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company, who are fighting a takeover attempt, announced a plan to create a royalty trust with distributions for stockholders as soon as possible.

title: French Steel Move
description: The Commerce Department has ruled that France is dumping several specialty steel products on the United States market at 3 to 14.8 percent below a fair market price, a department spokesman said today. The ruling, one of many charging Britain, Brazil, France, West Germany and Spain with unfair import practices, now goes to the United States International Trade Commission, which must find the domestic industry is being harmed before penalty duties are imposed.

title: NORTHWEST ENERGY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $1,400,000 from the discontinuation of coal operations. The year-ago revenue figure is restated to exclude coal revenues.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE REPORTS 10.1% GAIN
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the nation's leading producers of household items and pharmaceuticals, said yesterday that its first-quarter profit increased 10.1 percent, while sales rose 1.3 percent.

title: ENERGY DEPARTMENT ROUTE TO ARMS CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: HENRIETTA BUCKMASTER, 74, WAS A NOVELIST AND EDITOR
description: Henrietta Buckmaster, a popular novelist, historian and editor best known for her portrayal of the underground railroad and the abolition movement in the novel ''Let My People Go,'' died Tuesday after a short illness at a convalescent home in Chestnut Hill, Mass. She was 74 years old and lived in Boston.

title: NATO Secretary Says Soviet Will Delay on an Arms Accord
description: The Soviet Union is unlikely to make any significant moves toward an arms reduction agreement until the United States begins deploying new intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe later this year, Joseph M.A.. Luns Secretary General of ther North Atlantic Treaty Organization,, said today.

title: News Analysis
description: Warnings that New Yorkers are facing tough times have been standard fare in every budget message since the onset of the city's fiscal crisis eight years ago, but those Mayor Koch issued last January were more dire than most.

title: CARBONATED WATER: MORE THAN A MATTER OF TASTE
description: NEW YORK CITY supermarkets and specialty stores seem to be drowning in a sea of carbonated waters: naturally sparkling mineral water, naturally sparkling spring water, seltzer, sparkling seltzer, club soda, sparkling club soda, pure mineral water with effervescence, natural mineral water. The bewildering array of these products has engendered enormous confusion among consumers, most of whom are uncertain about the differences.

title: U.S.-Philippine Maneuvers
description: The United States and the Philippines began 20 days of joint military maneuvers today that will involve more than 14,000 troops and at least 15 American warships.

title: MELVILLE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid April 13.

title: A REMEMBERANCE OF SODA FOUNTAINS PAST
description: ONCE they were so ornate, so baroque that they resembled nothing less than elaborate, oversized wedding cakes, rendered in marble. Their faces, shelves and counters were often of beautifully veined and matched slabs of Carrara. Behind them were etched mirrors framed in carved and varnished mahogany. Their many spigots were usually of glistening, polished brass, arranged in tiers so that each soda-water flavor flowed untainted by other flavors.

title: 'ANGELO MY LOVE,' DUVALL TALE OF GYPSIES
description: ANGELO EVANS, who stars as himself in Robert Duvall's new film ''Angelo My Love,'' is a motion picture natural like Cary Guffey, the little boy in ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' and Drew Barrymore in ''E.T.'' That's apparent throughout this easygoing, high-spirited lark of a movie that Mr. Duvall, still better known as an actor than as a writer-director, has made about New York City gypsies, focusing mainly on the restless life and times of Angelo Evans.

title: House Unit Votes U.S. Boxing Bill
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee today approved a bill that would create a Congressional Advisory Commission on professional boxing.

description: Sweden protested today against ''the gross violations of Swedish territorial integrity of which the Soviet Navy has been guilty'' and threatened to sink any submarine that enters its waters without permission.

title: Freedom Reported For Afghan Prisoners
description: The Soviet-installed Government of Afghanistan has announced that all female prisoners and some male prisoners will be freed to mark Wednesday's fifth anniversary of the coup, a Western diplomat here reported today. The diplomat said there were at least 100,000 people in Afghan prisons.

title: STANDARDS FOR MINERAL WATER
description: Traditionally, a primary reason for drinking sparkling mineral waters has been belief in their health-giving properties. Because there are no Federal regulations for bottled mineral water, however, it has been difficult to determine whether it is more healthful or safer to drink than ordinary tap water. Some states, including New York, have set up their own standards governing the acceptable levels in mineral water for mineral content, herbicides, pesticides, bacteria and radiological matter. The State Health Department is in the process of certifying mineral waters that meet these standards. When a mineral water exceeds the standards it can still be certified if the company agrees to put a notice on the label advising consumers that the product should not be used as the sole source of drinking water. Exemptions are based on the premise that no one would drink more than two liters of the water per day. The state has had difficulty in getting some of the foreign producers of mineral water to comply with the certification process. Many companies list no American address on their labels, and communications to their offices abroad often go unanswered. A state regulation, currently under review but not yet in effect, would require bottled mineral waters to carry the state certification number on their labels; currently, its use is voluntary. Of the bottled sparkling mineral waters tasted last week, only Appolinaris displays its certification number. In addition to Appolinaris the state has certified the following sparkling mineral waters, which do not display their certification numbers: Ferrarelle, Montclair, Perrier, Poland Spring, Ramlosa with an exemption for fluoride, S. Pellegrino with an exemption for sulfate, and Vittelloise.

description: Though he played football, coached football, and now is a television commentator about football, John Madden thinks there is too much football.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If an unfriendly foreign power had attempted to impose on America the mediocre educational performance that exists today, we might well have viewed it as an act of war.'' - The National Commission on Excellence in Education. (A1:4.)

title: COOLIDGE'S LATIN FOLLY
description: Tonight, President Reagan will discuss Central America before an increasingly skeptical Congress. He is expected to push a $110 million military aid package for El Salvador and defend the Central Intelligence Agency's covert operations in Nicaragua.

title: VERY SMALL BUSINESS
description: News item: At New York's giant Citibank, people with less than $5,000 on deposit are no longer permitted to deal with a teller. A new bank policy requires them to transact their business with a machine.

description: The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it was entering into an agreement with the General Motors Corporation setting up an arbitration program to resolve consumer complaints about engine and transmission problems.

description: The United States, trying to revive its bid to be host for the 1986 World Cup, formally appealed to the Federation Internationale de Football Association, soccer's world governing body, to inspect facilities in this country.

title: PROSECUTOR TO INVESTIGATE 2 MORE SITES IN JERSEY SHORE SLAYINGS
description: The Monmouth County Prosecutor said today that the investigation surrounding the accused killer Richard F. Biegenwald would continue for two to three months and would take investigators to ''two additional sites.''

title: RESCUERS BRING OUT 8 EXPLORERS TRAPPED 3 DAYS IN A CAVERN
description: Eight explorers were rescued today from a cavern where they were trapped by high water for three days. They said they cracked jokes and made up songs while battling cold and fear.

title: Oilers Rout Hawks For 2-0 Series Lead
description: Glenn Anderson scored four goals and Mark Messier three tonight as the Edmonton Oilers defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 8-2, to take a 2-0 lead in the series for the Campbell Conference championship.

This week the big-name designers took to the runways, scheduling their showings back to back. There was hardly time for the audience to get from one place to another.

title: EASTERN AIR LINES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest first quarter include a net gain of $8.3 million from the sale of tax credits on new equipment.

title: A NEW PLAN TO REJUVENATE BROOKLYN ARMY TERMINAL
description: For almost two decades there have been a number of proposals to rejuvenate the old Brooklyn Army Terminal and use its four million square feet of space to create jobs and spur economic growth in the area.

title: Voices of Experience
description: One commencement speaker kissed the other when the 99-year-old American Academy of Dramatic Arts awarded 105 diplomas at the Royale Theater on West 45th Street yesterday. And the speakers, Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy, got three standing ovations.

title: Ralston Seeking Pair For Dog Food Packages
description: Now here is a wonderful opportunity about to come your way from Ralston Purina, with advertising supplied by Wells, Rich, Greene. The winner of a contest that the St. Louis company is going to conduct for its Purina Dog Chow will get his or her picture on two million packages of the product.

title: Panel Votes Extension Of Capitol West Front
description: A House Appropriations subcommittee agreed today to allocate $70.5 million to extend the west central front of the Capitol.

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: JAN DISMAS ZELENKA'S Trio Sonata No. 5 for Two Oboes, Bassoon and Continuo in F served as a sprightly curtain-raiser for the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's Alice Tully Hall concert Sunday evening. The two oboists, Maurice Bourgue and Leonard Arner, made much of Zelenka's gently imitative part writing, while Loren Glickman's bassoon growled an obstreperous descant.

title: Eurobonds Trading Quiet
description: Some of the new dollar Eurobond rates were off 1/4 point today in quiet trading as dealers held back ahead of the United States Treasury refunding details to be announced Wednesday.

title: Mitterrand Jeered In Speech to Farmers
description: Angry farmers jeered President Francois Mitterrand in northern France today, and a convoy of 1,000 pig farmers converged on Paris to show their growing displeasure with low prices.

title: YES, MORE ARMS, BUT.
description: In the debate about President Reagan's defense budget, dispassionate analysis often gets swamped by a torrent of clever but misleading arguments, homely but irrelevant analogies and popular but erroneous cliches. There are, however, relatively straightforward economic propositions that can help cut through the rhetoric.

title: TEXT OF SHULTZ'S LETTER TO LONG ON EL SALVADOR
description: Following is the text of a letter from Secretary of State George P. Shultz that was delivered today to Representative Clarence D. Long, chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, as made available by Mr. Long's office: Dear Mr. Chairman: Consultations between the Department of State and your subcommittee in recent weeks have demonstrated that there exists broad agreement on the seriousness of the situation in Central America and on the need for us to maintain a comprehensive security, political and economic strategy to address this situation. These consultations have focused on four specific areas of immediate concern to both of us. I would like to set out our views on these concerns and the nature of the programs and policies we have implemented, or will be implementing, in each of these areas.

title: J.& L. Chief Moving To U.S. Steel Corp.
description: The United States Steel Corporation reached into the rival Jones & Laughlin Steel Company yesterday for a new leader of its steel operations.

They took a 4-0 lead over the Kansas City Royals last night at the Stadium, saw it disappear in a barrage of 17 hits and took a 10-4 pounding with few redeeming moments.

title: CARROLL GLENN, CONCERT ARTIST
description: The violinist Carroll Glenn died of a brain tumor Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at 310 West 83d Street and in Manchester, Vt., where she and her husband, the pianist Eugene List, founded the Southern Vermont Music Festival.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: EARLIER this month, the Food and Drug Administration granted marketing approval to a new method of birth control, the vaginal contraceptive sponge. When the product becomes available nationwide next September, it will widen the choices for Americans interested in preventing unwanted pregnancies.

title: SYRIA REPORTS CLASH WITH ISRAELIS
description: Syria said its forces opened fire today on an Israeli bulldozer and an armored personnel carrier that had advanced on a Syrian position in the Bekaa, Lebanon's eastern Valley.

title: Market Place; Near-Term Stock Outlook
description: WITH the Dow Jones industrial average soaring to a record close yesterday at 1,209.46 on a 22.25-point gain, many analysts are trying to decide where the stock market is headed for the near term.

title: CHANGES PROPOSED IN BUDGET PROCESS
description: Several Democratic House committee chairmen, irritated by the Congressional budget process as it has evolved, are drafting a bill that would modify the Congressional Budget Act. A main purpose, they said, is to provide earlier passage of spending and tax bills.

OPERA DRAWN FROM HISTORY
description: Although operas have been composed in Finland since 1852, Finnish authorities date a modern-day resurgence of interest in the genre from the premiere in 1975 of Joonas Kokkonen's ''The Last Temptations.''

title: BBDO Earnings Up
description: BBDO International is the first of the publicly held agencies to get out of the gates with its first-quarter earnings. And they are up. Revenues were $57.8 million, a 22.5 percent gain from the $47.2 million in the comparable period last year, while net income rose 15.6 percent, to $3.7 million, or 64 cents a share, from $3.2 million, or 57 cents a share.

title: REAGAN SAID TO ASK EX-SENATOR TO BE LATIN ENVOY
description: Administration officials disclosed today that President Reagan, in a move to placate Congress, had asked former Senator Richard B. Stone of Florida to become a special envoy to Central America.

title: West German Fetus Ruling
description: West Germany's high court ruled today that a nine-month-old fetus was not legally a person. It overruled a lower court that had convicted a doctor of negligent homicide after his treatment caused a still birth.

title: SIGNAL TIES ITS LOSS TO REVAMPING
description: The Signal Companies said yesterday that it was reorganizing itself as a high-technology and engineering company and would dispose of its money-losing Mack Trucks division.

title: Trading Up
description: President Reagan's idea of better government is less government, so he must have swallowed hard before proposing a new Department of International Trade to replace the Commerce Department and the Special Trade Representative. His plan is still loosely defined, but his objective is worthy.

title: ALLEGHENY POWER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
New York's Pennies From Heaven
description: For New York City the last three months have not only been wetter than expected but also wealthier, making possible predictions of $545 million more in revenue than anticipated in January. It is a modest amount, considering the magnitude of the city's human needs and the difficulty of dividing it. Still, the Mayor's budget for the year beginning July 1 shows laudable prudence in the handling of the windfall.

title: President of Mohasco Named Chief Executive
description: The Mohasco Corporation yesterday named its president and chief operating officer, Herbert J. Broner, to the additional post of chief executive.

title: STATES CAN TRANSFER PRISONERS TO OTHER STATES, COURT HOLDS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that states are free under the Constitution to transfer prison inmates to prisons in other states, even if the transfer cuts a prisoner's ties with his family.

title: Jet Choices
description: Round 1 - Ken O'Brien, quarterback, California-Davis. Round 2 - Johnny Hector, running back, Texas A&M.

LEON L. LEVY
description: Leon L. Levy, senior partner of the law firm of Levy, Levy & Albert in Trenton, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Lawrenceville, N.J. He was 70 years old.

title: Rumasa Summons
description: The former head of Spain's giant holding group Rumasa, taken over by the Government in February, has been summoned to appear in court here within the next few days, a court official said today. Jose Maria Ruiz Mateos, 51 years old, in London since shortly after the takeover, has been accused by the state prosecutor of financial and currency fraud in the business empire he built into Spain's largest private holding group.

title: Stamp to Salute Met Opera
description: A 20-cent commemorative stamp marking the centenary of the Metropolitan Opera will be issued next fall by the United States Postal Service. The stamp, the first commemorating an opera company, contains features of the former and present Metropolitan Opera houses. A ceremony is planned for Sept. 14 - the first day of issue - at Lincoln Center.

title: A U.S.-JAPANESE CRISIS COULD BECKON MOSCOW
description: To the Editor:

title: Giant Choices
description: Round 1 - Terry Kinard, safety, Clemson. Round 2 - Leonard Marshall, defensive tackle, L.S.U. Round 3 - from San Francisco, through Los Angeles Rams, Jamie Williams, tight end, Nebraska; Karl Nelson, offensive tackle, Iowa State.

title: KOCH SAYS THE NEW SCHOOLS CHIEF SHOULD BE ONE OF FOUR RUNNERS-UP
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city's next Schools Chancellor should be one of four finalists who lost out to Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. almost three weeks ago. The Board of Education picked Mr. Wagner for the job, but he was rejected by the State Education Commissioner last week.

title: RISING WITH A NETWORK OF CONTACTS
description: Kenneth L. Adelman's confirmation hearings lasted three days, and even then the Senate Foreign Relations Committee sent the nomination to the Senate floor without recommending that he be confirmed as director of the Arms Control and Disarmanent Agency.
