title: FIRE INSPECTOR FINED $25,000
description: A veteran of 23 years on the Fire Department has agreed to pay a $25,000 departmental fine after being accused of accepting bribes from after-hours clubs in Manhattan.

title: DOW UP BY 22.25, TO 1,209.46
description: The bull market passed another major milestone yesterday when the Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 1,200 mark for the first time, pushed up by a surge of late buying.

title: Ethiopian Guerrillas Kidnap; 10 Western Relief Workers
description: Ethiopian anti-Government guerrillas have kidnapped 10 Western relief workers, including one American, possibly to give aid to rebel comrades in a droughtstricken northern province, diplomats and aid officials said today.

title: 'GANDHI' MAY EARN $30 MILLION MORE WITH OSCAR
description: Of the five movies nominated for an Academy Award as the best picture of 1982, the eventual winner, ''Gandhi,'' was the film that should profit the most.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Advertising; Newspaper Ad Growth Seen in '83
description: THE American newspaper industry may have suffered an estimated 4 percent drop in advertising linage last year, but things may be looking up for 1983.

title: Behind the Scenes
description: Along with his other appearances in Manhattan today, President Reagan will meet quietly with a s0all group of Republican party leaders, public officials and contributors. The unpublicized noon meeting gives a glimpse of how politicians - even Presidents - try to solidify every base before going public.

title: MCWILLIAMS HURLS 1-HITTER FOR PIRATES
description: Larry McWilliams pitched a one-hitter, allowing only a fifth-inning single by Fred Brenly, as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the San Francisco Giants, 3-0, tonight. Bill Madlock hit a two-run double.

title: Wendy's Earnings Up
description: Wendy's International Inc., a restaurant chain, said today that first-quarter earnings rose 25 percent, to $10.1 million, or 25 cents a share, compared with $8.1 million, or 21 cents a share, a year ago. Wendy's chairman, Robert L. Barney, said first-quarter sales were up 12 percent, to $153.5 million, compared with $137.6 million a year ago.

title: DORSEY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $67,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: AMF INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income after a charge of $670,000.

title: CLOROX CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the year-ago third quarter and 9 months reflect a net charge of $1.3 million relating to a decision to discontinue marketing the company's Duraflame brand of firelogs.

title: SPURS TOP NUGGETS; LAKERS MOVE TO 2-0
description: George Gervin scored 42 points as the San Antonio Spurs defeated the Denver Nuggets, 152-133, tonight in the first game of their Western Conference semifinal playoff match.

title: The Jets' Surprise No. 1
AMERICAN HERITAGE LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
OUI, JA, AN ABUNDANCE OF 'QUAINT CONERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME CHEESE MAKER
description: WITH the dozens of domestic and imported cheeses commercially available, one wonders why anyone would want to go through the long, slow process of making it at home.

title: E.E.C. Tallies Young Jobless
description: One out of every three workers under 25 was jobless in March in some countries of the Common Market.

title: Members of Education Panel
description: Here are the names of the 18 members of the National Commission on Excellence in Education, which reported today on the status of schools in the United States: Gardner, David Pierpont, commission chairman, now president of the University of Utah and president-elect of the California State Colleges system. Larsen, Yvonne W., vice chairman, past president of the San Diego school board.

title: DRUG CASE STRESSES FETUS RIGHTS
description: A physician has gone to court in an effort to force a pregnant woman to stop taking drugs, which he says threaten the well-being of her unborn child.

title: READING & BATES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FIRST SECURITY reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
METRO-NORTH GOAL
description: To the Editor:

title: Indians Are Suing Stadium Corp.
description: The Cleveland Indians filed a $1,250,000 suit in Cuyghoga County Common Pleas Court against the Stadium Corporation today, contending that the club is owed ancillary revenue.

title: SEAVER IS ROUTED AS REDS TROUNCE METS
description: Tom Seaver was something less than terrific when he returned to Riverfront Stadium to face his former Cincinnati teammates tonight.

title: ABORTION BATTLE CATCHES DUBLIN LEADERS UNAWARE
description: At a time when the new coalition Government of Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland is making overtures to Unionists in Northern Ireland to discuss political reunification, his leadership of the republic is being eroded by an emotional debate on abortion.

title: LETTING HAIR DOWN
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Envoy's Son Charged in Italy
description: Law enforcement officials said today that they had charged David Michael Martin, son of Graham Anderson Martin, a former American Ambassador to Italy and Vietnam, with raping three women this month.

title: ABC POSTS 42.6% DROP IN QUARTER
description: American Broadcasting Companies Inc. announced yesterday that its first-quarter profits declined 42.6 percent, to $13.9 million, or 48 cents a share, from $24.2 million, or 84 cents a share, in the period a year ago.

title: Athletes on Blacklist
description: The names of 200 world athletes, including 45 Americans, have been added to the United Nations anti-apartheid blacklist for competing in South Africa last year. Among those added to the list, compiled by the United Nations' Special Committee Against Apartheid and released in both New York and London, were the tennis players Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, Buster Mottram of Britain, and Vitas Gerulaitis and Billie Jean King of the United States; the golfers Greg Norman of Australia, Seve Ballesteros of Spain and Johnny Miller, Jack Nicklaus and Lee Trevino of the United States.

title: GETTY OIL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Rainier Weighs Seafirst Move
description: Officials of Rainier Bancorp, the second largest bank in the state of Washington, are considering whether to challenge the proposed takeover of its larger competitor, the Seafirst Corporation, by the nation's second-largest bank holding company, the BankAmerica Corporation.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
U.S. Officer Says Soviet Tested 2 New Missiles
description: An American general said today that there was abundant evidence that the Soviet Union had test-fired two new nuclear missiles, but he said it was difficult for United States intelligence agencies to prove it.

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
FILM: 'MOON OVER THE ALLEY' RETURNS
description: ''Moon Over the Alley'' was shown as part of the 1976 New Directors/ New Films Series at the Museum of Modern Art. Following are excerpts from a review by Lawrence Van Gelder that appeared in The New York Times of April 3, 1976. The film opened yesterday at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: STELCO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income. There were no share earnings applicable to common shares after preferred dividend requirements. The company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto Stock Exchanges.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year-earlier period.

title: FELD BENEFIT TO SALUTE COMPANY AND ITS HOME
description: There will be no guest stars at the Feld Ballet's benefit tonight at the Joyce Theater in Chelsea. Instead, the Feld will celebrate itself and the theater and neighborhood in which it has found a home and perhaps a new lease on life in the year since the theater opened.

title: Paul Griffith, Writer and Aide For the Fellowship in Prayer
description: Paul Griffith, a novelist, book critic and executive director of the Fellowship in Prayer, an interfaith organization dedicated to world peace, died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Lawrenceville, N.J. He was 61 years old.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: DAVE ALVIN, lead guitarist and song writer for the Los Angeles band called the Blasters, wore tight blue jeans, a blue denim jacket, a red bandanna and a spiffy, broad brimmed Stetson to a recent party for the group in a midtown Manhattan apartment. ''Uh oh, here come the punk rockers,'' the Blasters saxophonist Steve Berlin joked when Mr. Alvin and some friends made their appearance, and laughter rippled through the room.

title: SCIENCE LEADER SAYS REAGAN GETS MIXED MARKS ON SUPPORT
description: Frank Press, president of the National Academy of Sciences, praised the Reagan Administration and Congress today for their ''generally positive'' support of scientific research budgets. But he criticized them for actions that he said threatened scientific excellence in several key research areas.

title: JERSEY REACTOR IS CLOSER TO A RESTART
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission agreed today to permit the Salem 1 reactor in New Jersey to reopen as soon as its operators can convince the commission that they have corrected faults that led to a failure of safety equipment two months ago.

title: Zenith Posts Profit
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation reported today that it made a profit of $8.9 million in the first quarter, compared with a $2.4 million loss in the period last year.

title: Thrift Units' Losses Shrink
description: The nation's savings and loan associations lost about $1 billion during the second half of last year; nevertheless, it was a great improvement from the first half, Government figures indicated today.

title: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 27, 1983
description: Markets

title: POLITICAL CHARGES TRADED IN SCHOOL ELECTION FIGHT
description: An unusual coalition of Democratic elected officials is trying to defeat one of the early proponents of school decentralization in a bitter school board contest in Brooklyn.

title: EXCERPTS FROM THE REPORT ON EXCELLENCE IN EDUCATION
description: Following are excerpts from ''A Nation at Risk,'' a report by the National Commission on Excellence in Education that was released today at the White House:

title: PROPER QUESTIONERS OF WOULD-BE JURORS
description: To the Editor:

title: HEADQUARTERS OF U.P.I. MOVING TO WASHINGTON
description: United Press International will move its headquarters and principal editing offices from New York to Washington by August, officers of the wire service said yesterday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transcription error, an article yesterday about the New York City Board of Education misquoted its president, Joseph G. Barkan. He said some potential candidates for Schools Chancellor might not have applied because of the ''chilling effect of the media and publicity.''

title: STUDY SUGGESTS COST ESTIMATE AND SAVINGS FOR PUBLIC WORKS
description: The Congressional Budget Office estimated today that the nation needed to spend $53.4 billion a year on repairs and construction of public works such as highways, bridges, subways, airports, dams and sewage treatment facilities over the next eight years.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Sulfite Notices Urged Councilwoman

title: Hot Dog Nostalgia
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ametek Inc. said it had agreed to buy Du Pont Co.'s microfoam plastics packaging materials business for more than $11 million.

title: DELMARVA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Bridge:; Touring New Yorkers Find A Fresh Idea in Melbourne
description: The bridge players of Melbourne, the staid old lady of Australian cities, showed the visiting New York Precision team something new.

title: DI GIORGIO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $560,000 from the sale of a facility.

title: UNITED STATES STEEL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: GULF STATES UTILITIES CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SANTA FE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Albert B. Kahn Is Dead at 83; Partner in Trenton Law Firm
description: Albert B. Kahn, a lawyer active in civic affairs in Trenton, died Saturday at his home there. He was 83 years old. Mr. Kahn established a law practice in Trenton in 1924 and was a partner in Kahn, Schildkraut & Levy.

title: King Hopes to Play
description: There was optimism at the Knicks' practice yesterday at Upsala College that Bernard King would play in tonight's second game at the Spectrum in Philadelphia.

title: 6-FOOT-5 PAC-MAN IS SCORING IN WESTPORT
description: Randy Miller, 16 years old, thought he had died prematurely and gone to heaven when he walked into Arnie's Place, a luxurious video game palace the likes of which he had not seen. But there were those in the community who believed that he and his fellow youths were being led down the road to damnation. The game he was playing was called Satan's Hollow.

title: SOUTHERN NEW ENGLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BEHIND NICARAGUAN BUILDUP: SOVIET-BLOC AID CITED
description: Nicaragua has converted an irregular guerrilla force into a sizable army with the help of the Cubans, East Germans, Bulgarians, Russians and French, according to Defense Department officials.

title: NORTON CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
BARBECON INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MANNES SCHOOL MOVING TO WEST SIDE
description: The Mannes College of Music, one of the most distinguished conservatories in the world, and a fixture on Manhattan's Upper East Side since 1916, will relocate to expanded facilities on West 85th Street in February 1984, it was announced yesterday.

title: COLTS PICK ELWAY, BUT THE QUARTERBACK REFUSES TO GO
description: The Baltimore Colts opened the National Football League draft yesterday by selecting Stanford's all-America quarterback, John Elway. But hours later his father, Jack, said that Elway ''will never play for Irsay or Coach Kush.'' And, at a news conference in San Jose, Calif., his hometown, John Elway said:

title: PHILLIPS PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest quarter have been restated to reflect the adoption of an accounting change dealing with foreign currency translation procedures.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: The U.N. Today; April 27, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: REAGAN ARMS POLICY ASSAILED BY MONDALE AS 'WEAKENING' U.S.
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale charged yesterday that the Reagan Administration's arms policies were ''weakening America'' and proposed instead a series of specific steps, including a summit meeting with the Soviet Union, that he said would insure peace and national strength.

title: JUSTICES STUDY STANDARDS FOR DEATH ROW APPEALS
description: The Supreme Court, troubled by a growing number of last-minute appeals in death penalty cases, heard arguments today on the standard that Federal appeals courts should apply to requests for stays of execution by death-row inmates whose final appeals are still unresolved.

title: Lithuanian Bishops Hopeful of Soviet Pact
description: A Vatican official said today that four Lithuanian bishops who met with Pope John Paul II this month had returned home hopeful of major progress in relations between the Soviet Government and the church in their Roman Catholic nation.

title: GROLIER INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a foreign currency translation gain of $471,000. c-After a foreign currency translation loss of $1,937,000.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: MY favorite fish, I think, is salmon, not only for its unique flavor but for its texture and keeping qualities. The salmon at my local fish market may have come from the West Coast, Canadian waters or even from Norway and yet - if it has been perfectly kept - it has a taste of freshness, as though caught the day before.

title: COMMISSION ON EDUCATION WARNS 'TIDE OF MEDIOCRITY' IMPERILS U.S.
description: A bipartisan Federal commission called today for a significant upgrading of American education at all levels. In an ''Open Letter to the American People,'' the 18-member National Commission on Excellence in Education said that America's economic, cultural and spiritual role in the world was being threatened by lax standards and misguided priorities in the schools.

title: The Elway Poker Game
description: At its annual college draft yesterday, the National Football League had the lights, the cameras and the action - everything except the background music - for the John Elway poker game.

title: HOUDAILLE REBUFFED ON IMPORT PETITION
description: The Reagan Administration has turned down an appeal by a Florida machine tool maker for protection against what it called unfair Japanese competition.

title: Playoff Thoughts
description: There is strong sentiment among National Hockey League executives and players to revise the playoff format next season so that the point standing for the regular season means something again in determining home-ice advantage for the late rounds. Under a format adopted last season, home-ice advantage alternates between divisions in the semifinal round and between conferences in the final.

title: DONALD A. OAKIE
description: Donald A. Oakie, a former president of the American Contract Bridge League, died Friday at his home in San Jose, Calif.

title: Article 127732 -- No Title
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed a $16.7 billion budget for New York City that restores most of the service cuts and avoids most of the tax increases that he threatened three months ago.

title: Princess Rooney Still Out of Derby
description: ''Anybody who runs a filly against colts is just on a big ego trip,'' said Frank Gomez only moments after Princess Rooney won the Gardenia Stakes at the Meadowlands last October. That was the sixth victory without a defeat for Princess Rooney, the sensational 3-yearold filly Gomez trains, and she has now won three more times to move her record to nine for nine.

title: INDIANA FINANCIAL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: A $300 Million Jacksonville Issue
description: The Jacksonville, Fla., Electric Authority began the financing of two coal-fired power plants this week with a $300 million bond issue that was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9.33 percent for bonds due in 2013. Underwriters for the issue, led by Shearson/American Express Inc., tentatively priced shorter maturities to yield from 6.75 percent in 1988 to 9 percent in 2000 and 9 1/4 percent in 2007.

title: 2 WITNESSES IN CBS CASE ADMIT LYING
description: Two nephews of Donald Nash acknowledged in testimony yesterday that they had lied to the police and a grand jury about possible evidence that might implicate their uncle in as many as five murders.

title: Former U.S. Prosecutor Indicted by Grand Jury
description: A Federal grand jury in Atlanta indicted a former Federal prosecutor today on charges he tried to sell sensitive information about a Government drug investigation to the subjects of the inquiry.

title: SPONSOR OF LAW BACKS REDUCING TEST DISCLOSURES
description: The chairman of the State Senate's Higher Education Committee said yesterday that he would propose an amendment to a state law to assure that the College Board would continue to offer a battery of college admissions tests it said would otherwise be eliminated in New York after June.

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
News Summary; WEDNESDAY, APRIL 27, 1983
description: International

title: WEINBERGER ASKS ARMS FUNDS
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger urged Congress today to appropriate $478.6 million for full-scale deployment of Pershing 2 missiles in Europe, warning that a failure to do so would leave West European allies and the Soviet Union questioning United States military resolve.

title: Man and 2 Women Are Shot to Death
description: The bodies of two women and a man in their early 20's who had been fatally shot in the head were found in an apartment above a bar here tonight, the police said.

title: BRIEFING
description: The High Cost of Help

title: Times Beach, Mo., Board Moves to Seal Off Town
description: Town officials moved today to blockade this dioxin-contaminated St. Louis suburb, where most of the residents have been driven out by flooding or dixoin contamination.

title: DEPOSITORS CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Year-ago per share figures have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May 1982.

title: CHEEKS KEY MAN FOR 76ERS
description: Maurice Cheeks was at his best in the opening game of the Eastern Conference playoff semifinal. With his chewing gum usually protruding halfway out of his mouth, the Philadelphia 76ers' elusive playmaker blew past the Knick guards and the halfcourt trap defenses for 14 points and 10 assists.

title: 'NONBANK' TREND ASSAILED
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, called on Congress today to close ''loopholes'' in the Bank Holding Company act that have allowed securities firms and insurance companies to cross traditional industry barriers into the banking business.

title: Big Loss At Eastern In Quarter
description: Frank Borman, chairman, president and chief executive officer of Eastern Air Lines Inc., announced at the annual meeting yesterday a first-quarter loss of $60.7 million, which he attributed to heavy fare discounting.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HAROLD WINDERBAUM is a father first, and only secondarily a cabdriver. This ordering of priorities is apparent to anyone who rides in his Checker cab, which is part family album, part classified advertising column on wheels.

title: Conrail Assets
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. and the Canadian National Railway Company said they had agreed with the Consolidated Rail Corporation to buy certain Conrail assets in Canada. The assets include Conrail's leases of the Canada Southern Railway Company and the Detroit River Tunnel. They will also acquire 72 percent of Canada Southern's shares and all the Detroit River Tunnel shares from Conrail.

title: Invoking the Familiar
description: Guests at the American Newspaper Publishers Association's breakfast Monday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel heard the Rev. Thomas D. Bowers, the rector of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, give the benediction.

title: MITEL CORP LTD reports earnings for year to Feb 25.
description: The year-ago results have been restated.

title: SANITATION UNIT AND MERCHANTS TRADING CHARGES
description: When the Sanitation Department's first class of nonuniformed enforcement agents was sent to city streets in August 1981, Sanitation Commissioner Norman Steisel said the new unit was bettertrained and more cost-effective than the uniformed force from the sanitation police that it succeeded.

title: EMERY E. NEFF
description: Emery E. Neff, professor emeritus of comparative literature at Columbia University, died Saturday at a nursing home in Keene, N.H. He was 91 years old, and lived in Westmoreland, N.H.

title: BORG-WARNER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Lebanese Party Surrenders Man Held in Leader's Death
description: The Phalange Party of President Amin Gemayel turned over the man charged with killing his brother Bashir to the Government today after holding him for seven months.

title: BLUE BELL INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After a loss of $2.8 million for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations. c-After losses of $948,000 for the quarter and $1.4 million for the 6 months from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOUSE PANEL CUTS REAGAN'S REQUEST FOR SALVADOR AID
description: A House Appropriations subcommittee today approved $30 million in additional military aid for El Salvador, half the amount asked by President Reagan.

title: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: Micro Peripherals, CTS Plan Merger
description: The CTS Corporation and Micro Peripherals Inc. plan to merge, the companies said.

title: Blasting Etna Is Proposed
description: Catania University's experts on volcanoes today suggested blasting holes in Mount Etna to try to divert a four-week-old lava flow that is creeping closer to three villages. A Government committee will consider the idea Wednesday.

title: FOR A SPRIGHTLY GARNISH, BUTTER WITH FLAVORS ADDED
description: SPRING evokes a multitude of yearnings in a cook, foremost among them eagerness to celebrate the arrival of locally grown fruit and vegetables. For six months we have been hostages of those megafarms in California and Mexico, subsisting on little Turtle Waxed torpedoes that pass for cucumbers, leathery green beans, crenulated softballs called lettuce and dehydrated herb flakes. The challenge of abundance is upon us again, and none too soon.

title: AMERICAN BROADCASTING COMPANIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INTEREST RATES SLIGHTLY LOWER
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading as dealers in Treasury securities waited for today's announcement of a large financing expected next week while dealers in tax-exempt securities digested a large supply of new issues.

title: EASTOVER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $331,000 from the sale of real estate. b-Including a tax credit of $245,000 and a gain of $788,000 from the sale of real estate.

title: STANDARD OIL OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
N.Y.F.E. Picks Lord, Geller
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, after a competition that involved speculative presentations by four agencies, has won a new Wall Street client - the New York Futures Exchange for its Stock Index Futures contract.

title: Careers; Job Outlook Dimmer for Class of '83
description: AT many colleges the corporate recruiters have come and gone, and the students who were interviewed are anxiously awaiting an invitation for a second interview or an actual job offer. Many of the nation's 965,000 college seniors, especially liberal arts majors, have still not been able to land a job.

title: FIRST HAWAIIAN BANK reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
LOBBYIST MOVES TO OTHER SIDE OF THE LOBBY
description: When Mayor Koch killed the proposed New York City theater ticket tax, it came as no great surprise to Peter A. Piscitelli. ''We lobbied it good,'' Mr. Piscitelli said yesterday, the day after the Mayor offered a municipal budget without the tax. His old friends in city government, he said, had not told him in advance in so many words that the tax he was working against was out. ''But they'd smile when you talked with them,'' Mr. Piscitelli said, ''and they'd say, 'Hey, you might have a winner.' ''

title: AMERICAN NATURAL RESOURCES CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a gain of $18.6 million, or 79 cents a share, from the sale of rights to lignite in North Dakota.

title: AUTOMATIC SWITCH CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
SPECIALTY STEEL HELP IS ADVISED
description: The International Trade Commission recommended today that President Reagan place quotas on specialty steel imports for three years to protect American manufacturers.

title: CAM-OR INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: PIEDMONT AVIATION INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Cigar, a division of American Brands, has appointed Felipe Silva chairman and chief executive officer; George L. Theophilos president and chief operating officer, and M.B. Hiott Jr. executive vice president.

title: COUNTY CLERK OUT OF STATE JOB AGAIN
description: The state took direct charge of motor vehicle bureaus again in Westchester County today after it filed a notice of appeal that automatically removed the County Clerk as overseer.

title: CCX INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $9,960,000 for the quarter and $11,442,000 for the 9 months.

title: VICON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
HOPES DIM FOR LAUNCHING GOAL
description: The space agency, with one of its huge tracking satellites already in trouble, says that the launching of a second tracking satellite in August is now ''very doubtful.''

title: TRI-CHEM INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
MOLEX INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: The year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 50 percent stock dividend paid April 25, 1983.

title: Koch Seeks to End At-Large System
description: Mayor Koch yesterday urged the Charter Revision Commission to abolish the at-large seats on the New York City Council because, he said, the system is not only ''perceived as unfair to minorities but is in fact unfair.''

title: Mob Linked to Unions, Senate Panel Is Told
description: A reputed Chicago crime figure, Tony Accardo, ''hand-picked'' the presidents of two labor unions as part of a plan that skimmed millions of dollars from employee benefit funds, a witness told Senate investigators today.

title: Man Sentenced For '81 Murder
description: A Brooklyn man was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison for the murder and robbery of the owner of a Westbury, L.I., rooming house.

title: AUTOMATIX INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: DECORATING WITH ELECTRONICS IN MIND
description: APROLIFERATION of electronic gadgetry - including advanced stereo systems, television sets that rise on command and computerized lighting - made its presence felt in both traditional and contemporary rooms at the Decorator Show House of the Kips Bay Boys' Club, which opened to the public yesterday.

title: INSIDE LONDON MUSEUMS
description: ONE of the hardest things to find in a bookstore is a really good guide to museums. This is not a matter of location, listing and admission times. For that, almost any decent guidebook will serve. It is a matter of characterization. We need to know the specific personality of each museum, and why some are loved the world over while others languish.

title: STONE CONTAINER CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net income.

title: RAVITCH MEETS THE COMPETITION FOR U.S. RAIL FUNDS
description: Two weeks of behind-the-scenes lobbying broke into the open today as the interests of New York City, seeking to refurbish its 79-year-old subway system, clashed with those of Houston and Los Angeles, which are planning their first subways.

title: TOURS OF HOUSES TO BENEFIT CHARITIES
description: Tours of private houses and of historic houses specially decorated by designers are taking place this month. Proceeds will benefit charities. Tours of Designer Houses

title: PRODUCTIVITY SURGES
description: Productivity in nonfarm American businesses rose at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the first three months of this year, the best showing in two years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: CONNELLY CONTAINERS INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
JERUSALEM PRIZE TO NAIPAUL
description: V.S. Naipaul was awarded the Jerusalem Prize by Mayor Teddy Kollek today today in a ceremony at the Khan Theater that was held as part of the Jerusalem Book Fair. The novelist and essaysist was cited for his lifetime writings that have contributed to ''the freedom of the individual to society.''

title: RSC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to April 3.
Faye and Kaye
description: The Young twins, Faye and Kaye, for most of their 27 years have led mirror-image lives. Born in Bunn, N.C., they attended the same schools and continued together through North Carolina State University, where they played on a women's basketball team that was ranked No.3 in the nation in 1978. They proceeded together to professional careers for two years with the New York Stars and one with the New Jersey Gems before the Women's Basketball League folded in 1981.

title: NEW BRUNSWICK TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PENNSYLVANIA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $51,000. c-Net loss after an extraordinary gain of $25,000.

title: United of Omaha
description: The United of Omaha Life Insurance Company has bought World Book Life Insurance, for an undisclosed amount of money, from the Scott Fetzer Company.

title: CITY BALLET: A TRIUMPH FOR BALANCHINE WORK
description: THE splendor of ''Concerto Barocco,'' George Balanchine's greatest ballet, raised the curtain Tuesday night on the New York City Ballet's spring season at the State Theater.

title: EXXON CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

Countering an N.C.A.A. argument that Kentucky - Hornung's home state and the site of his original suit -lacked jurisdiction, Hornung's lawyers have refiled the $3 million damage suit in Kansas, where the N.C.A.A. has its headquarters.

That hit drove in one of the runs as the Mets won their first game of the season on the road after nine defeats, a 2-1 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: HERS

MUSIC: FINNISH OPERA OFFERS SALLINEN'S 'RED LINE'
description: TO be quick about it, Aulis Sallinen's ''Red Line'' is the best new opera I have heard in many a year. The work's first United States performance, last night at the Metropolitan Opera House, sent me away persuaded that the talk we have heard recently about an opera renaissance in Finland is justified. Although this two-act work, brought here by the Finnish National Opera, was remorselessly harsh in its depiction of farm life in Finland shortly after the turn of the century, it proved as gripping in its way as ''Wozzeck'' or''Jenufa,'' to mention two 20th-century classics that speak in similarly grim terms.

title: FOR GLITTERING EVENINGS AHEAD
description: INVENTIVENESS in fashion design is not an unmixed blessing. While it is exciting to view original constructions and the fresh use of fabric, the results can be clothes that are too complicated or too extreme for everyday wear. So it is pleasant to report that Geoffrey Beene, who has been exploring new fashion areas for some seasons, has achieved both simplicity and luxury. His clothes, shown yesterday in the NBC television studios, are so light they look airborne. They float around the body easily, not restricting movement but enhancing it.

title: Mrs. Boepple Gets City U. Job
description: Margaret L. W. Boepple, the city's director of intergovernmental relations, has been appointed to the City University of New York's new post of vice chancellor for university relations, effective Sept. 1. Mrs. Boepple, 38 years old, is a doctoral candidate at New York University. She has spent the last five years in the Koch administration.

title: SCHOOL BOARD HEARS CRITICS AND FAILS TO PICK CHANCELLOR
description: After listening to nearly two hours of criticism from demonstrators at a public meeting yesterday, members of the New York City Board of Education deliberated privately but failed to reach a decision on the selection of a new Schools Chancellor.

title: INTERIOR DEPT. DEFENDS COAL LEASES AND CALLS HOUSE REPORT DECEITFUL
description: The Interior Department defended its coal leasing program today as serving the national interest, and said a Congressional report attacking the program was ''a deceitful political document.''

title: SHIRLEY OF YANKEES TURNS BACK ROYALS
description: Bob Shirley returned from three weeks of exile last night in Yankee Stadium and pitched the Yankees to a 6-0 victory over the freehitting Kansas City Royals, and not even George Brett spoiled the evening.

title: STUDENT ARCHITECTS USE LESSONS AT HOME
description: FROM the outside, neither of the buildings is exceptional. They are the sorts of places where collegians have always lived - utilitarian and a little disheveled. Brent Sherwood lives in New Haven, a few blocks from the Yale University campus, in a one-family home built in 1840 and long since converted into apartments. An unused fireplace is in the hallway. Wallpaper is on some walls, paint on others. Each of the six or seven mailboxes bears layers of masking tape, scribbled over with the names of the apartment's residents for semesters past.

title: Syria Again Opens Fire On Israelis in Lebanon
description: Syrian troops fired on Israeli bulldozers building fortifications in the Bekka, Lebanon's eastern valley, for the second day today.

title: GERMAN BISHOPS UPHOLD A CASE FOR A-ARMS
description: The Conference of Catholic Bishops in West Germany made public a pastoral letter on war and peace today that asserts ''nuclear deterrence is not a reliable instrument for preventing war in the long run.''

title: PAPERCRAFT CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
GIANTS RATED LOW PICK HIGHLY
description: When the National Football League's college draft ended at about 1:45 A.M. today, the Giants had taken 15 players.

M.T.A. MAKING MAJOR ADDITION TO CAPITAL PLAN
description: Twenty-eight subway stations will get face lifts, 196 subway cars will get air conditioning, New York City will get two new bus depots and riders will get fare cards instead of tokens, according to plans released yesterday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: A Defiant Argentine Admiral Is Sentenced to Year in Prison
description: The chief of the critical Southern Naval Zone was sentenced to a year in jail today for criticizing the way his superior handled last year's disastrous Falkland Island war with Britain, the official news agency Telam reported.

title: DEUKMEJIAN FAVORS EASING OF RULES ON COASTAL ZONING
description: California's 11-year-old coastal zoning law, the first and most comprehensive effort by a state to regulate the development of its coastline, is under strong attack by Gov. George Deukmejian.

title: Viking Arrested On Drug Charge
description: Dennis Johnson, a linebacker with the Minnesota Vikings, was arrested Tuesday when cocaine was found in his car during a routine traffic investigation.

description: The Polish Government told the United States today that American radio broadcasts beamed into Poland were ''aggressive and slanderous.''

title: Briggs & Stratton Recalling 800
description: The Briggs & Stratton Corporation, maker of engines and automotive locks, announced a recall of 800 hourly employees beginning next Monday in response to increased demand for lawn and garden equipment.

title: COMPUTER OR VIDEO GAMES
description: It is becoming harder and harder to tell the difference between video games and home computers.

title: U.S. Rate Rise Seen
description: United States interest rates will bottom out between now and summer, then gradually rise over the next three years, as Congress lacks the will to reduce United States budget deficits, James Howell, senior vice president and chief economist of the First National Bank of Boston, predicted today.

title: U.S. ASKS ISRAEL TO TAKE PRO-NAZI TIED TO ANTI-JEWISH RIOTS IN 1941
description: The Justice Department has asked Israel to accept a former Nazi sympathizer who has been ordered deported from the United States because he incited anti-Jewish riots in Rumania in World War II.

title: Upstate Woman Dies at 105
description: Mary Reynolds, the oldest voter in Monroe County, died Tuesday at Genesee Hospital at the age of 105. Mrs. Reynolds, who outlived 2 husbands and 9 of her 17 children, had 62 grandchildren, 105 great-grandchildren, 43 great-great-grandchildren and 5 great-great-great-grandchildren.

title: For Park, a Perfect Moment
description: The moment was as close to perfect as Brad Park had known in his hockey career. In the overtime period of the seventh game of the playoff series against the Buffalo Sabres last Sunday, his blocked shot had rebounded before him. He was about 30 feet from the net, and the puck was as flat and nearly as still as the black ''B'' imprinted at center ice at Boston Garden.

title: FEDERAL SCREW WORKS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: Killer Told of Remorse Shortly Before Execution
description: John Louis Evans 3d, the confessed murderer who was executed Friday, said on videotape that he was tortured by the memory of the man he killed.

title: AUTOPSIES SHOW 1 IN 4 DIAGNOSES WERE WRONG
description: Doctors at a leading Boston hospital did not give the correct diagnosis in nearly a quarter of the studied cases of patients who died there, according to research reported yesterday in The New England Journal of Medicine.

title: SWEDEN'S CHARGES DENIED IN MOSCOW
description: The Government press agency Tass today denied Swedish charges that Soviet submarines infiltrated Swedish waters last October.

description: The Times Mirror Company reported today that net income increased 45.5 percent, to $29.4 million, or 86 cents a share, in the first period, from $20.2 million, or 59 cents a share, in the period a year earlier.

title: Pacers Are Sold; Will Stay
description: An agreement to purchase the Indiana Pacers, a club that has struggled for financial survival since it entered the National Basketball Association in 1976, was announced today by two Indianapolis brothers making their first venture into professional sports.

title: SYRACUSE SUPPLY CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
PROSECUTOR SAYS 2 ITEMS TIE NASH TO CBS DEATHS
description: Two pieces of circumstantial evidence, orders for a pistol silencer and a record of a telephone call to a murder victim, were introduced yesterday at the murder trial of Donald Nash. The prosecution said the evidence would directly connect Mr. Nash to the murders of four people in a Hudson River parking lot last year.

title: ANDREA RADIO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: The Candidates and the Borders
description: Here is a political truism: It's a primary duty of national government, along with providing defense and printing money, to decide whom to let into the country. Here's another truism: It's a primary duty of Presidential candidates to rise above localism and address issues from a national perspective.

title: Learning to Smile Brightly
description: Tooth fairies are apparently out at Public School 55 in the South Bronx. What's in is a corps of fifth graders called Health Angels, who graduated yesterday to the rank of Tooth Tutors.

description: The National Security Agency, the nation's largest and most secretive intelligence organization, has directed a private library in Virginia to halt public access to personal letters mentioned in a book critical of the agency, according to library records.

title: TYMSHARE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Not Ready for Trade War
description: When Houdaille Industries petitioned for protection from Japanese competition, it did not arouse the same attention as similar pleas by the makers of steel and autos. But the issues raised by the Florida machine-tool company were at least as important. President Reagan's courageous decision to deny it relief should slow, if not reverse, the nation's dismal slide toward trade war with its allies.

The retailer's action was the latest of a series of announced purchases of banks or savings institutions by insurance companies, brokerage houses, retailers and others expanding into financial services.

RYAN STRIKES OUT 5 TO BREAK CAREER MARK WITH 3,509
description: Nolan Ryan surpassed Walter Johnson's career strikeout record of 3,508 today, a mark that stood since 1927. ''I don't get too excited about anything,'' Ryan said after pitching the Houston Astros to a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Expos and striking out 5 batters for a total of 3,509. ''I was more relieved than anything else. Now I can sit back and relax and get more satisfaction out of it.''

title: FORD MOTOR CO OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Guyana Rejects Loan
description: Guyana has rejected the International Monetary Fund's conditions for a loan, which included a 100 percent devaluation of the Guyana dollar, President Forbes Burnham was quoted as saying by the Government-owned Chronicle newspaper. The report follows the departure from Guyana of a fivemember mission from the I.M.F. and the World Bank. President Burnham told The Chronicle that the I.M.F. team wanted the Government to increase prices for a host of commodities and services and to freeze wages. Mr. Burnham did not disclose the extent of the loan sought, but a Government official said it was more than the $176 million sought last year.

title: OPERA BASED ON BOOK BY ILMARI KIANTO
description: Aulis Sallinen's ''The Red Line'' is based on the 1911 novel of the same title by Ilmari Kianto (1874-1970). The libretto, written by the composer, tells of a poor Finnish family's struggle to survive in a grim time, early in the 20th century, when their country was trying to resist being swallowed by its neighbor, czarist Russia.

title: CABARET: BLOSSOM DEARIE

The Ballroom, which originated in SoHo 10 years ago and started the cabaret revival of the 70's along with the room called Reno Sweeney, moved uptown a year ago to 28th Street and Eighth Avenue. The new owners had their own problems, however, and, after a year, the original owners are back, led by Greg Dawson, who started the SoHo Ballroom.

Massey-Ferguson
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. intends to close its Toronto plant, where most of the 1,200 employees are now on layoff, probably within the next two years, and consolidate the operations with those in Brantford, Ontario, Victor A. Rice, chairman, said at the annual meeting here. In addition he said the company was considering going to the market with an equity issue but the timing depended on an improvement in the company's results. Speaking to reporters after the annual meeting, Mr. Rice said the issue, likely to comprise common shares, would come after the company produces two consecutive quarters at least close to breakeven levels.

NUCLEAR NOTHING
description: The struggle against domestic nuclear power in America is not over. Despite such serious setbacks to the nuclear power industry as the Three Mile Island accident in 1979 and, last week, the United States Supreme Court's stunning 9-0 ruling that states have the authority to veto construction of nuclear-power plants within their borders - this applies only to future construction - the foundering industry is far from dead.

title: DISNEY'S BRADBURY
description: IN the center of a small, old-fashioned town, the autumn leaves are blowing down Main Street -that is, a wind machine is blowing the leaves across a movie-set evocation of small-town Americana. ''Something Wicked This Way Comes,'' the Walt Disney production of Ray Bradbury's 1962 novel, begins on such an overworked Norman Rockwell note that there seems little chance that anything exciting or unexpected will happen.

title: A STRIKEOUT PINCH-HITTER WON'T FORGET

ARGENTINE JUNTA GIVES ACCOUNTING OF WAR AGAINST LEFTISTS IN THE 70'S
description: The Argentine Government, in an accounting today of its war against leftist terrorism in the 1970's, justified the actions that led to the disappearance of thousands of people as legal and necessary to defend the nation.

title: EX-SANDINIST HERO TO GO TO WAR AGAINST OLD ALLIES
description: Eden Pastora Gomez, a hero of the Nicaraguan revolution who later broke with the Sandinists, will begin ''major military actions'' within a matter of days to overthrow the Sandinist Government, one of Mr. Pastora's political allies, Alfonso Robelo Callejas, said today.

title: IT'S MAY, TIME TO SEE WHAT'S UP OUTDOORS
description: THIS weekend it might be wise to follow the lead of the tigers and elephants at the Bronx Zoo's Wild Asia. After having been cooped up for months in their winter cages, the animals will again roam free in their sprawling outdoor habitat, beginning tomorrow. For humans, too, this weekend can be a time to get reacquainted with the outdoors. In New York City and the suburbs, dozens of outside events beckon. There are organized walks and house tours, nature strolls and plant sales, a Fifth Avenue parade and an open-air train to see the animals at Wild Asia.

title: STAGE: DREYFUSS IN 'TOTAL ABANDON'
description: FOR a while laughter is the best defense against ''Total Abandon,'' the preposterous new melodrama at the Booth. Almost nothing in it makes sense -starting with the facts that Richard Dreyfuss agreed to star in it and that Jack Hofsiss, the director of ''The Elephant Man,'' decided to stage it with an overblown portentousness suggesting a summer-stock ''Oedipus at Colonus'' in modern dress. But if ''Total Abandon'' is unintentionally funny at times, you don't leave the theater smiling: the joke turns too sick for that.

title: MUSIC: FINNISH OPERA OFFERS SALLINEN'S 'RED LINE'
description: TO be quick about it, Aulis Sallinen's ''Red Line'' is the best new opera I have heard in many a year. The work's first United States performance, Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, sent me away persuaded that the talk we have heard recently about an opera renaissance in Finland is justified. Although this two-act work, brought here by the Finnish National Opera, was remorselessly harsh in its depiction of farm life in Finland shortly after the turn of the century, it proved as gripping in its way as ''Wozzeck'' or ''Jenufa,'' to mention two 20th-century classics that speak in similarly grim terms.

title: DELAY IN GAF'S PROXY TALLY

Yesterday the Board of Education selected him as Schools Chancellor, and celebrations erupted in Mr. Alvarado's East Harlem office, where he has served as school superintendent of District 4 for the last decade.

title: Arrests Concern Oilers
description: For a team with an experienced secondary, the Houston Oilers sure seemed to be picking a lot of defensive backs in the National Football League draft this week. Now Ladd Herzeg, the club's general manager, has explained the reason why: the off-season arrests of three defensive veterans -Greg Stemrick and J. C. Wilson, and a safety, Vernon Perry.

title: City Approves Sale Of Its Horse Farm

But in voting for the sale, the board stipulated that the farm, near Otisville, N.Y., in Orange County, will continue to provide ''a permanent home for retired police horses.''

title: Japanese Steel Slump
description: The slump in the Japanese steel industry is likely to continue throughout the 1983 fiscal year, which ends next March, the Mitsui Bank said today in a report. Demand is likely to be lower than in the fiscal year 1982, when production of crude steel was 96.3 million tons. It was the first time in 11 years that output had dropped below 100 million tons, the report said.

They are Miriam and John Blaylock - young, beautiful and permanently engaged in a search for new blood.

description: President Reagan today named former Senator Richard B. Stone, a conservative Democrat, as his Ambassador at Large for Central America, as Congressional Democrats reacted cautiously to Mr. Reagan's appeal for bipartisan support of his policy for the region.

description: The French Government announced today that it was ending the cumbersome inspections of all imported Japanese video recorders at a tiny customs depot in Poitiers in central France. The inspections had virtually cut off the flow of foreign video recorders into France.

title: Panel Approves I.M.F. Funds
description: President Reagan's request for an increase in United States contributions to the International Monetary Fund cleared another Congressional hurdle today with approval from the Senate Banking Committee.

title: Meyer Reinstated
description: Tom Meyer, who was relieved of his basketball coaching job at the University of Illinois-Chicago last week, was reinstated yesterday. Meyer had litigation pending against the school as a result of the removal for the way he handled players, but Donald Langenberg, the school's chancellor, said that the reinstatement was made ''on my own initiative.'' The chancellor said the basketball program would not be the subject of any changes until he received a report from a panel regarding the charges against Meyer.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Hole in Holistic Medicine
description: Holistic medicine is dear to the heart of William Stern, the head of New York's Urban Development Corporation. He believes it is ''going to be an important area of high-tech growth. I'm interested in the state and the U.D.C. helping out.''

title: Peace Institute Moving And Taking a New Name
description: Moorhead C. Kennedy Jr., a former hostage in Iran, will move the Cathedral Peace Institute out of St. John the Divine Cathedral on May 12. It will become a secular organization, the Council for International Understanding, within the Myrin Institute, a nonprofit educational organization at 136 East 64th Street.

title: BRUINS GET 2 SHORT-HANDED GOALS, EVEN SERIES AT 1-1
description: The Islanders built their three consecutive Stanley Cups around power plays and penalty-killing. They destroyed opponents with their power play, and often demoralized them with short-handed scores. They were certain signs of spring on Long Island.

title: Britain Ready For Cable TV
description: The British Government has announced its proposals for developing cable television. Wednesday's action clears the way for approval this year of up to 12 privately operated pilot projects.

title: POP JAZZ
description: THE tenor saxophonist ''Big Nick'' Nicholas has just finished recording his first album as a bandleader, and it's due next month on India Navigation Records. Tonight through Sunday, however, he is doing what he has done since 1940 - playing three sets a night at a jazz club, with a rhythm section that, he said, is ''cooking.'' The club is Fat Tuesday's, at Third Avenue and 17th Street (533-7900). Sets are at 9 and 11 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is an $8.50 cover and a $5 minimum. It's a bit late for him to be making his solo recording debut - he is 60 years old - but the album's projected title sums up Mr. Nicholas's approach perfectly: ''Big and Warm.''

TV: MISS WALTERS AND THE HINCKLEYS
description: JOHN W. HINCKLEY JR. was described by his parents in a television interview last night as having been ''happy as a child,'' the ''gentlest'' of their three children and the product of a ''closeknit, loving family.'' The interview, with Barbara Walters on ABC's ''20/ 20,'' marked the first time the Hinckleys have commented about their son on television. On March 30, 1981, he attempted to kill President Reagan. At his trial, where both parents testified, he was found not guilty by reason of insanity. Much of the television interview was a reprise of the testimony.

title: BASEBALL SCOUTS ARE WARY ON ELWAY
description: Baseball scouts largely agree that, though John Elway of Stanford may be a great quarterback, he is three years from major league baseball and is probably a risk if he costs the Yankees big money.

description: YALE UNIVERSITY PRESS is about to publish the memoirs of an American woman who was active in the Austrian underground in World War II, memoirs that raise questions about Lillian Hellman's similar account of anti-Fascist and anti-Nazi activities.

title: FABERGE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
EARLY-MUSIC GROUPS HAVING A RENAISSANCE
description: IN recent years, there has been a revival of interest in medieval and Renaissance music. Gone are the days when college textbooks condensed all composers before Bach into one opening chapter. Now early-music performance groups abound, their recordings sell briskly and when they peform, concerts halls are filled with rapturous listeners. Some of the sounds are so fresh and daring - the radical harmonies of Don Carlo Gesualdo's madrigals, the brimming passion of Monteverdi's operas - that they appeal to us with the urgency of our contemporaries.

title: MISS ROWEN KEEPS TITLE IN 1,500 METERS
description: Michelle Rowen and Kim Ryan complained about the heat today at Franklin Field and said it affected their running. If it did, it was hardly noticeable. Both girls won their high school individual events with ease today at the Penn Relays.

title: Comings and Goings
description: After nine years with the Canadian Football League and twice its most valuable player, Dieter Brock, the quarterback for the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, says the time has come to try his arm in the United States Football League. The Bombers, however, have refused Brock's request for release from the final three years of his $1.1 million five-year contract. As a result, Brock said yesterday, he is retiring immediately. ... The Chicago Bulls extended the contract of the club's general manager, Rod Thorn, but gave no details of the multiyear pact. ... Wilfredo Gomez said yesterday that he would relinquish his World Boxing Council super-bantamweight title next month because he has been unable to meet the 122-pound weight.

The orchestra, which has strengthened its usual force of 65 to close to 90 for this tour, plays a role in Finland similar to the Met orchestra's here - principally as a pit ensemble but stepping out occasionally for concerts of its own.

title: The Issue Is Salvador, Not the Alamo
description: The notable thing about President Reagan's latest rendering of policy in Central America was its extraordinary definition of the stakes and its skimpy account of the realities. Mr. Reagan gave a dozen inflated reasons for defending the isthmus, yet said almost nothing about the practical problems involved or how he proposes to solve them.

title: FLOWER ART FROM VOYAGE OF CAPT. COOK COMES TO U.S.
description: THE final fruits of Capt. James Cook's round-the-world voyage for botanical exploration, New York's own cherry blossom festival and African violets in bloom can all be seen this weekend by the hardy flower fancier. The American Museum of Natural History is exhibiting ''A Flowering of Science,'' 37 engravings of plants gathered in eastern Australia in 1770 by the Cook expedition, along with living examples of some of the plants, dried botanical specimens from the 1768-71 voyage and some of the watercolors upon which the engravings were based. These are all from the British Natural History Museum to which they were bequeathed, and this is their first showing in North America, part of the ''Britain Salutes New York'' festival.

In the meantime, he called on David Rockefeller, who was honored this year, to come over to the podium and join him ''because I feel more secure when you are around.''

description: b-Net income.

title: ART: STUDIO MUSEUM EXHIBITS ALMA THOMAS
description: THE late-blooming career of Alma Thomas (1891-1978), who was nearly 70 before she had her first solo exhibition as a painter, is one of those lovely success stories that almost make us suspend our disbelief in the rewards of virtue. Born to middle-class black parents and brought up as a Southern lady, she taught art at a junior high school in Washington for 35 years, devoting most of her time and energy to spurring the creativity of black youngsters. Though she always studied and worked at painting, she began to make a serious commitment to it only in 1950, 10 years before her retirement. Over a decade, she progressed from academic still lifes to a vibrant abstract idiom unmistakably her own, and her first show in Washington in 1960 was an immediate success.

title: A NEW SUBWAY UNIT TICKETS 2,143 RIDERS IN DRIVE ON SMOKERS
description: In a one-month crackdown on smoking in the subways, a special transit police squad issued 2,143 summonses, nearly a third of them to marijuana smokers.

description: Officials of both Miami and Dade County have begun reassessments of their police recruiting, hiring, firearms and discipline policies after a rash of shootings in the last six months.

title: 11.12 GAIN PUTS DOW AT 1,219.52
description: The stock market resumed its upsurge yesterday in active trading, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing at another new high. The Dow average, which is made up of 30 leading stocks, rose 11.12 points, to 1,219.52, after losing 1.06 points on Wednesday, mainly because of profit taking. Yesterday was the eighth time in the last 12 trading days that the indicator had closed at a record level.

title: BTR's Stake in Tilling
description: BTR P.L.C. said today that it had purchased one million more shares of Thomas Tilling P.L.C. on Wednesday.

title: Michael Bennett provides first home for new musicals
description: MUCH of what will be seen in the way of new musicals next season will be taking shape over the next couple of months in a downtown building affectionately known to theater people as Michael's. The building, at the corner of Broadway and 19th Street, is the spacious studio owned by Michael Bennett. Mr. Bennett works on his own shows there - it is where ''Dreamgirls'' was born - and he also rents the space to other productions. At the moment, the studio is occupied by the Broadway-bound musical ''La Cage aux Folles,'' which has just begun rehearsals.

title: Hearty Hungarian and old steakhouse
description: READING the menu of the Mocca Hungarian Restaurant, it is easy to get the impression that you are looking at an antique. It is hard to believe that a restaurant so clean, cozy and inviting can still afford to serve huge and savory main courses that cost as little as $6.95 to $8.25. Opened two years ago on Second Avenue near 82d Street, Mocca has a friendly, efficient and accommodating staff and a relaxed, amiable neighborhood clientele.

FASSBINDER'S LAST
description: BECAUSE it happens to be Rainer Werner Fassbinder's final film, ''Querelle'' has had imposed on it a terrible burden. Even the ads imply this, describing it with solemnity as ''Fassbinder's last statement,'' which it is, but only in terms of chronology. It's as if we were meant to believe that Fassbinder knew he was going to die last June and prepared ''Querelle'' as a summation of everything that had gone before. It's not. Fassbinder had many talents, but soothsaying wasn't one of them.

title: PROTESTS BY STUDENTS AND FARMERS TOUCH OFF NEW WORRIES FOR FRANCE
description: Thousands of students and farmers have taken to the streets here and around France this week in a series of demonstrations that have sharpened worries about social unrest and have bred talk about ''a hot spring'' akin to that of May 1968.

title: Zeffirelli talks about prima donnas
description: IN the hotel room, something smells delicious, like hyacinths. ''It's me, darling,'' Franco Zeffirelli says. ''It's my perfume.'' Although ''La Traviata'' (at the Paris) is Mr. Zeffirelli's first attempt to bring an opera to the screen, the Italian director says he has been ''drenched'' in music all his life. He was 8 when his aunt and uncle took him to a performance of ''Die Walkure.'' ''They were sure I would sleep,'' he says, ''but there were 100 gentlemen playing instruments, and I got lost in this miracle. I still remember the fire at the end, encircling the body of Brunnhilde. I went home and started drawing theaters.''

His ''company,'' meaning his admirers, tends to revere him for his exquisite scale, line and color and for his wit, as well as a childlike quality. A student going through a Klee phase is liable to be sustaining an attack of preciousness.

description: The Board of Education, ending almost a week of uncertainty, selected Anthony J. Alvarado yesterday to be the next Chancellor of the New York City school system.

WHEN A DEFRAUDED GOVERNMENT WON'T SUE
description: To the Editor:

title: PROBLEMS ON SEVERAL FRONTS ARE CLOUDING THE IMAGE OF KENTUCKY GOVERNOR
description: Be it fried chicken or politics, Gov. John Y. Brown adds plenty of spice. Mr. Brown, the former Kentucky Fried Chicken entrepreneur who interrupted his honeymoon in 1979 to jump into the governor's race on an impulse, is confronting some problems that have eroded his image as a reform politician and raised questions about his personal life.

title: Pittsburgh Gets U.S.F.L. Team
description: Commissioner Chet Simmons of the United States Football League announced today that Pittsburgh had been awarded the league's first expansion franchise and that it would begin play next season. The new team, he said, will belong to the sports entrepreneur Edward J. DeBartolo of Youngstown, Ohio.

title: CONTEMPORARY WESTERN
description: ''COWBOY,'' tomorrow's television movie on Channel 2 at 9 P.M., seems to have been pasted together by a committee more interested in audience demographics than in believable drama.

title: News Analysis
description: The departure of Ariel Sharon from the post of Defense Minister appears to have changed the way the inner circle of the Israeli Government makes policy.

description: b-Net loss. Sales for the year-ago quarter include sales from continuing operations of $8,336,000, the company said. Because sales volume and net income for the year-ago quarter include results from several plants which were closed in the first half of last year, 1983 and 1982 results aren't comparable, the company said.

title: A PLENTIFUL PLACE FOR ANGLERS
description: During the last few weeks, fishing for coho salmon and brown and lake trout in Lake Ontario has often been excellent, and it will continue to improve, says Capt. Bill Kelley, a charter-boat skipper in Rochester.

title: Football Leagues Overlap Draftees
description: Most of the New Jersey Generals' January draft choices were selected in high rounds by National Football League clubs Tuesday. Fourteen of 15 on the Generals' negotiating list were in the N.F.L. draft, and 12 were chosen on the fifth round or higher. ''Most of our opinions were fairly well substantiated,'' said Chuck Fairbanks, the president and coach of the team.

description: Despite higher unemployment and fuel costs, in most areas the mild winter apparently prevented any surprising increases in customers facing cutoff of utility service for nonpayment.

description: Command Sgt. Maj. Ronald J. Hammer, the top noncommissioned officer at this sprawling Army post, leaned across his desk and said, ''I'm telling you, we are so damn much better today than we were a year ago.''

The nominations must be submitted by Aug. 1 and the induction ceremonies are scheduled for Feb. 12, 1984.

ACTRESS 3 DECADES
description: Selena Royle, a leading lady on Broadway in the 1920's and 30's and a character actress - often a mother -in movies of the 1940's and early 50's, died last Saturday in a nursing home in Guadalajara, Mexico, after a short illness. She was 78 years old and had lived in nearby Teuchitlan for nearly 30 years.

title: United, Finally, Behind the Schools
description: The Board of Education's choice of Anthony Alvarado as Chancellor of New York City's schools should bring an end to a campaign that grew too bitter for the good of anyone, most of all the city's schoolchildren.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS' PANEL, IN SHIFT, SAID TO URGE 'HALT' ON ATOM ARMS
description: The committee of American Roman Catholic bishops preparing a pastoral letter on nuclear arms has reversed itself and will suggest language to intensify the letter's opposition to such weapons, according to a committee staff member.

title: Atlanta Doctors Join To Treat Unemployed
description: More than 400 doctors in metropolitan Atlanta have formed a nonprofit corporation to provide free treatment for unemployed people. The program, known as Operation Care Inc., was announced today by the Medical Association of Georgia.

description: A magnetic lock that is highly pick-resistant has been invented by Joseph W. Woolfson, a professor of mathematics at Sarah Lawrence College, Bronxville, N.Y. He was granted patent 4,380,162 for the lock.

title: WATT CHOICE FOR SOUTHWEST WATER JOB ASSAILED
description: The appointment of a longtime aide and ally of Interior Secretary James G. Watt to a key regional post affecting water development in the arid Southwest has provoked criticism and concern in Arizona.

description: Coal mine fatalities decreased sharply in the first four months of 1983, dropping to 16 from 52 in the same period last year, the Mine Safety and Health Administration reported today.

description: A year-old program to restrict the export of sophisticated American technology has begun to cut into the loss of industrial secrets to foreign countries, Federal officials say.

title: U.S. TRADE GAP WIDER IN MARCH
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit widened slightly to $3.63 billion in March despite a drop in the price of imported oil to the lowest level in three years, the Commerce Department reported today. The volume of oil imports remained at a decade low.

title: ZORAN AND SANCHEZ: 2 OPPOSITE VIEWS
description: As a coda to the fall fashion openings, store executives trooped downtown to see two individual views of dressing presented in informal ways. Fernando Sanchez inaugurated his new design studio at 19th Street and Fifth Avenue with a showing of his collection of evening clothes. Then everyone moved on to Zoran's loft on Sullivan Street to see his cashmere knits.

title: Holders Gain at Biscayne Federal
description: Shareholders of the insolvent Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association won a sigificant procedural victory today in their lawsuit to recover the Miami thrift institution from Federal regulators.

title: PHILHARMONIC: SCHOENBERG
description: The highlight of the New York Philharmonic's Thursday evening concert at Avery Fisher Hall was a virtuosic rendition of Arnold Schoenberg's epochal Variations for Orchestra (Op. 31). Zubin Mehta conducted with a penetrating understanding of this masterpiece, striving for a sense of continuum and Brahmsian solidity.

title: 'Total Abandon' Closes
description: ''Total Abandon,'' the play by Larry Atlas starring Richard Dreyfuss, closed after Thursday evening's performance at the Booth Theater. Directed by Jack Hofsiss, the play about child abuse ran for one performance and seven previews.

title: MORGAN IS SELECTIVE ON DISCLOSING RATES
description: In the race for the consumer's dollar, most New York banks go to great lengths these days to publicize the interest rate that customers can earn on new money market accounts. But that is not the case at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.

description: The Reagan Administration's chief civil rights enforcer said today that racial preferences for hiring and promotion and mandatory school busing to achieve racial balance are morally wrong and have created a ''racial spoils system in America.''

Generation Gap
description: John Kiley, the organist at the Boston Garden for more than 40 years, qualifies as an expert on the music played at professional sports arenas. And, in his opinion, the business could use a lift.

Driesell Is Reprimanded
description: Lefty Driesell, Maryland's basketball coach, was reprimanded by the university today for telephoning a student to persuade her to drop charges of sexual misconduct against one of his players. She had filed the charges with the student judicial system.

title: TURKEY WILL VOTE NOV. 6, JUNTA SAYS
description: The head of the Turkish military junta said today that a general election would be held Nov. 6. Gen. Kenan Evren, in a speech at a military exercise at Erzincan, said those who intended to form political parties should unite into bigger parties to create a stable majority in the Parliament and give the country stability for the next five years.

title: Auerbach Will Stay
description: Red Auerbach announcing yesterday that he would remain as the club president and general manager for at least one more year. Originally, he had planned to give up the day-by-day work and spend more time at his home in Washington. But the 64-year-old Auerbach cited the persistence of Harry Mangurian, the team owner, in keeping him fulltime.

title: GILLIES IS RETURNING FOR GAME 3
description: Maybe Clark Gillies will make a difference. Or perhaps the Islanders will find Nassau Coliseum an edge. Whatever the factors, the defending Stanley Cup champions know they must play better tonight than they did in Thursday night's 4-1 loss to the Boston Bruins in the Wales Conference final playoff series.

title: KNICKS, DOWN 2-0, TRY AGAIN AT HOME
description: On April 15 against Detroit, the Knicks needed a victory over the Pistons to qualify for the playoffs. They responded. Two days later in Chicago, they had to beat the Bulls to clinch the fifth playoff spot. They did. Coach Hubie Brown asked the best from his team in the opening round of the playoffs against New Jersey. They swept the Nets in two games.The Knicks will be asked to respond again this afternoon and tomorrow afternoon at Madison Square Garden in the third and fourth games of the Eastern Conference semifinal against the Philadelphia 76ers. The Knicks trail, 2-0, in the four-of-seven-game series.

description: A British film dramatizing a 1974 trial here that resulted in the convictions of the three executors for mismanaging the estate of the painter Mark Rothko has inflamed both sides in the case. The movie is scheduled to be shown on public television on Tuesday night.

title: BRUINS' GOALTENDER HAS SUCCESSFUL STYLE
description: Life always seems to become more complicated when Pete Peeters leaves the area that has been set aside just for him. One of the few advantages of being a goaltender is your own space, a rectangle marked by a thin red line that extends one foot from the outside of each goal post and four feet across. The rules of the National Hockey League say that opponents are not allowed inside. The tradition of the sport says that the occupant should remain within the rectangle. Or else.

Roderick, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said he would hold discussions this weekend at his home with the chief executive officer of the British Steel Corporation, Ian MacGregor, but said there was only a ''50-50 chance'' that an deal would be reached on a joint venture involving U.S. Steel's Fairless Works in eastern Pennsylvania.

title: THAT LAST GENTEEL BREED OF FAN
description: The subspecies Hockey Animalia, commonly known as ''hockey fan,'' has thrived this season, just as he always has. Even now, into the playoffs, the hurling of obscenities, the spitting on opponents and the throwing of various goods onto the ice not only disrupt games and embarrass and infuriate the fan of a more advanced classification - indeed, such do exist, though they may be a rare subspecies - but also have come close to another form of antisocial behavior, homicide.

description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin discussed with Secretary of State George P. Shultz today a possible compromise on the role of Maj. Saad Haddad, the southern Lebanese militia commander, Israeli and American officials said. Jim Burnett, upon receiving a note from 13-year-old Andrea Gann of Chelsea, Okla., went even further. He got on a plane and went to her school to present her with a prize.

title: AMERICA'S HAIR APPARENT
description: What this country needs is a bald-headed President. As a member of one of the nation's largest and least powerful minorities - the bald - I think it is high time we came out of the closet, got our act together and elected an egghead who will shine like a beacon of hope to us forgotten Americans, as well as our hairy compatriots.

''We saw some genuinely hungry people, probably more than I've seen in other areas,'' he said.

title: ANNUAL REPORTS: MORE CANDOR
description: When it comes to delivering bad news, annual reports are usually a tribute to the art of understatement. For years, muted colors, small type and oblique references to hard times have been relied on to play down corporate misfortune.

title: The Cabbie Who Loves The Philharmonic
description: For the last two years, Paul B. Kerner, a 45-year-old Brooklyn cabdriver, has donated a weekend's tips -about $100 - to the New York Philharmonic's Radiothon.

title: PURZER, ON 64-135, SHARES 1-SHOT LEAD
description: Tom Purtzer and Mike Donald each shot a seven-under-par 64 and tied for the second-round lead today in the $400,000 Byron Nelson Classic.

title: CORSICA GROUP CLAIMS 15 BOMBINGS ACROSS FRANCE
description: Banks, railway stations and public buildings here and in three other French cities were damaged today by a series of bombs.

title: POLAND'S 'PARALLEL ECONOMY' THRIVING
description: Coffee, shoes, stereo equipment, ball-point pens, books, punk-rock tapes, all the things that Poles cannot find in their stores are spread out, although perhaps not in profusion, in a large field on the edge of Warsaw each Saturday morning.

title: CONSUMER PRODUCT AGENCY: SMALL BUT BUSY
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission is the smallest Federal safety agency and has great restrictions on its regulatory authority. Nevertheless, a Louis Harris poll earlier this year showed that a great many Americans think it is doing a better job protecting consumers than any other Federal or state group, including Congress.

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $200,000.

title: The Parcells Way
description: It was Day One yesterday for Bill Parcells, running his first practice as the 12th head coach of the Giants in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Calling All Babies
description: For the 19th year in a row, the name Michael was chosen for more New Yorkers' 1982 male babies than any other, the Department of Health reported this week. For 34 years, the name has been in the top 10.

Bergt Quits at Western
description: Neil G. Bergt, a colorful entrepreneur and one-time bush pilot, resigned yesterday as chairman and a director of Western Airlines. Western said Mr. Bergt would be succeeded as chairman by Gerald Grinstein, a Seattle lawyer who has been on Western's board since 1977.

title: LAST PUSH FOR WAGNER PUT OFF CHANCELLOR VOTE
description: The Board of Education waited an extra day to choose Anthony J. Alvarado as Schools Chancellor because city lawyers thought they might have new grounds to reinstate the Board of Education's first choice, Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr.
