description: The company went public in April 1982.

title: DIGILOG INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
CONCERT: FINNS PERFORM ALL-SIBALIUS PROGRAM
description: The Finnish National Opera has been performing at the Metropolitan Opera this week, and Thursday night the company's orchestra under Ulf Soderblom took over the stage for an all-Sibelius concert. The orchestra, which has strengthened its usual force of 65 to close to 90 for this tour, plays a role in Finland similar to that of the Met orchestra's here - principally as a pit ensemble but stepping out occasionally for concerts of its own.

title: REECE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ALVARADO TAILORS SCHOOLS TO STUDENTS
description: Ten years ago, when Anthony J. Alvarado became the Superintendent of Community School District 4, it had the lowest reading scores in the city. When Mr. Alvarado becomes Chancellor of New York City's public schools in about two weeks, he will leave a district that now ranks 15th out of 32.

title: TEXACO INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Results for the latest quarter include a last-in, first-out inventory drawdown benefit of $35,000,000 after related income taxes and a gain of $40,000,000 from foreign currency translations net of related income. Results for the year-ago quarter include a last-in, first-out inventory drawdown benefit of $80,000,000 after related income taxes, a gain of $61,000,000 from foreign currency translations net of related income, and a gain of $43,000,000 from an exchange of Texaco Treasury shares for outstanding debentures with a face value of $95,000,000.

title: Jobless Claims in the Nation Climbed to Almost 4 Million
description: The number of Americans receiving unemployment checks in regular state programs rose to nearly 4 million in the first week of April, the Labor Department reported Thursday.

title: DATA-DESIGN LABORATORIES reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
INDICTED EXPERT ON MIDEAST IS FOUND DEAD IN VIRGINIA
description: Waldo H. Dubberstein, a former Defense Department intelligence analyst who was indicted Thursday on charges of selling secret military data to Libya, was found dead today in a storage room of an apartment building in nearby Arlington, Va. The police said he apparently killed himself with a shotgun.

title: U.S. STUDIES SHIFT IN STAND AT STRATEGIC ARMS TALKS
description: An interagency working group is considering revisions of the Administration's strategic arms proposal that could narrow differences with the Soviet position and lead to the development of a new single-warhead missile, Administration officials said today.

title: The Talk of Soweto
description: Those who disparage David Thebehali, the canny and affable ''Mayor'' of South Africa's largest black settlement, like to point out that he gained his position with only 97 votes in a widely boycotted election five years ago. Disputing that tally with a wounded expression, Mr. Thebehali insists he was actually the choice of 295 of Soweto's inhabitants - none of whom, including himself, have an unambiguous claim to citizenship under the country's laws.

title: Letter: On Training Lawyers Prepared to Conciliate or Litigate
description: To the Editor:

title: Crocodiles As Partners
description: Finally - in spite of itself - this city's hopeless Board of Education has chosen as Schools Chancellor the person who was demonstrably the best educator of all the candidates.

title: IDAHO POWER CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
A PARENT'S KEEPER
description: To the Editor:

title: FARM PRICES UP 2.2% IN APRIL
description: Prices farmers get for raw products rose 2.2 percent in April, the fourth consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Auditor Worried About Air Florida
description: The independent auditor of Air Flordia has warned that the carrier ''may be unable to continue as a going concern.''

title: NAVCO CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
JULIEN ELFENBEIN
description: Julien Elfenbein, a writer and former professor of journalism at New York University, died Thursday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: Simultaneous Translations
description: A lot was going on simultaneously when Robert J. Smithdas read his poetry at the New York Society for the Deaf on East 14th Street, where the Hebrew Association of the Deaf holds its weekly social.
To the Editor:

title: LEVESQUE SAYS PARTY NEEDS TO SPUR QUEBEC SEPARATISM
description: Premier Rene Levesque said today that his party would have to stoke up what he described as a ''dormant'' separatist consciousness in Quebec to pave the way for an election within two years that will clearly be run on the issue of independence.

title: MONARCH MACHINE TOOL CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm not perturbed by the idea we might not have covert aid. I have no fear at all of funding what we have to do down there overtly.'' - Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., Republican of Tennessee. (1:6.)

title: Thrift Agency Gets Chairman
description: President Reagan today designated Edwin Gray as chairman of the three-member Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the agency that regulates federally insured savings and loan associations.

title: Beset by Mediocrity
description: Wednesday morning it was waking up to the New York Times headline that said '' 'Tide of Mediocrity' Imperils U.S.'' Eyes still gummy with sleep and still unable to read the fine print transmitted the headline to the brain.

title: INTERSTATE MOTOR FREIGHT SYSTEM reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including a tax credit of $5.9 million and a gain of $8.5 million on the sale of the company's Canadian unit. c-Net loss after a loss of $754,000 from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. FINES TANNERY POLLUTERS $475,920
description: One of the country's larger leather tanning companies and five of its executives have been fined a total of $475,920 in the first major Federal felony prosecution of a criminal pollution case.

title: THE COMMUNITY BORED
description: I was elected, three years ago, to the District 2 community school board, in a large, multi-ethnic district where 16,500 children are enrolled in 29 elementary and junior high schools. These schools are found on the East Side, in Chinatown, Greenwich Village, ''Little Italy'' and Chelsea-Clinton, and I was eager to meet the challenge of helping to set policy for such a diverse population. Little did I imagine that 28 months later, overwhelmed by frustration and disappointment at what I feel is mismanagement of the district by our board and administrators - feelings compounded by the deep apathy of parents and other community members - I would resign.

title: A Timely Shift by Mayor Koch
description: Without making a big splash about it, Mayor Koch has, commendably, changed his mind on the desirability of continuing the at-large seats in New York's City Council.

title: FIRST WYOMING BANCORP (CHEYENNE, WYO) reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $328,000 from the sale of a bank.

title: MORE EXITS AT GRAND CENTRAL PLANNED TO EASE BOTTLENECK
description: A $26 million plan to build six street-level entrances and exits for the northern side of Grand Central Terminal was approved yesterday by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. It will mark the first major renovation of the transportation complex since the terminal was built in 1913.

title: Argentina Junta Bars Visit to the Falklands
description: The Argentine military Government today diverted a planned trip to the Falkland Islands by relatives of Argentine servicemen killed in last year's war with Britain.

title: LIFE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ASTROS TOP CARLTON WITH 3 IN 10TH, 6-3
description: Phil Garner lined a two-run single with the bases loaded in the top of the 10th inning tonight to lead the Houston Astros to a 6-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

Convict Who Escaped Found Guilty in 2 Deaths
description: William Timothy Kirk, a convict who escaped with his lawyer four days before his trial was to begin, was convicted in absentia today of voluntary manslaughter in two prison deaths. He was also convicted of aggravated kidnapping stemming from the abduction of four prison guards, and of assault with intent to commit manslaughter.

title: FOXBORO CO reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Comings and Goings
description: The Cosmos put Ivan Buljan, a 33-year-old Yugoslav midfielder who has been with the team two years, on waivers for the termination of his contract, which expires Nov. 15. . . .Carl Yastrzemski, the 43-year-old Red Sox slugger, was in traction at a hospital near Boston undergoing familiar treatment for a familiar muscular ailment. ''It's the same kind of spasms that I get every year,'' said Yastrzemski, noting that his doctor ''usually puts me in traction for four or five days and I'm all right.''

title: Eight Are Killed in Crash Of Ecuadorean Airliner
description: Eight people were killed and dozens injured today when an Ecuadorean airliner carrying 100 people crashed while attempting an emergency landing at the airport at Guayaquil, the police said.

title: WAYNE-GOSSARD CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: Share earnings for the year-ago quarter were negligible because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: CORRECTION

description: The company is a subsidiary of the St. Regis Paper Company.

description: The definitive recipe for any Italian dish has not yet appeared, according to Luigi Barzini, the journalist who wrote both ''The Italians'' and the recently published ''The Europeans.''

SOTHEBY TAKEOVER GAINS ON A BRITISH DECISION
description: A governmental watchdog agency has decided not to intervene in the attempt by two American financiers to take over Sotheby Parke Bernet, the ailing international auction house, political and business sources reported today.

title: PRESIDENT MOCKS MONDALE IN TEXAS
description: President Reagan, showing some early partisan fire for next year's election, mocked Walter F. Mondale tonight as ''former Vice President Malaise'' and said the Reagan Administration had reversed ''the economic crisis we inherited'' from the Democrats.

description: The Government ordered the Soviet Union's Novosti press agency to close its bureau in the Swiss capital of Bern today and gave the agency's chief correspondent in Switzerland 10 days to leave.

title: A Giant Sounds Off
description: The San Francisco Giants, who have lost 13 of 19 games and taken over last place in the National League's Western Division, must be doing something wrong. Jack Clark, a regular in the outfield, thinks he knows what it is: just about everything.

title: Bridge:; American Team May Get Chance to Beat the French
description: Twice in the past four years - in Valkenburg, the Netherlands, in 1980 and in Biarritz, France, in 1982 - top-ranked United States teams have clashed with France in the final of a world team championship and come off second best.

FREE PRISONERS, POPE ASKS POLAND
description: Roman Catholic Church officials indicated privately today that Pope John Paul II had written to the Polish authorities asking that all political prisoners be released before his visit in June.

title: METS' 3 HOMERS HELP TOP BRAVES
description: The Mets collected nine hits last night, but three were home runs that helped them beat the Atlanta Braves, 6-5, at Shea Stadium. George Foster got the first homer, puting the Mets ahead, 1-0, in the second inning. Dave Kingman's homer in the sixth tied the score at 3-3. And Mookie Wilson's drive in the seventh sent the Mets ahead to stay. It came off the Braves' starter and loser, Rick Camp, who was unbeaten in three previous decisions.

title: BUCKS TAKE 2-0 LEAD
description: The Celtics charged about Boston Garden, seemingly in total command of the Milwaukee Bucks, for most of the game tonight. But after leading by as many as 17 points in the second half, the Celtics, playing without the ailing Larry Bird, missed 13 of their last 14 shots and scored only 9 points in the final quarter as the Bucks surged to a 95-91 victory.

title: Press Secretary Returning to Writing
description: Evan W. Cornog, Mayor Koch's press secretary, said that June 10 would be his last day in City Hall.

title: KAY CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: 1. After originally vouching for 60 volumes recently presented as the diaries of Hitler, Mr. Trevor-Roper, the British historian, voiced doubts on their authenticity.

title: U.S. GIVES STATE DATA FOR CASES ON 6 POLICEMEN
description: The Federal prosecutor's office has turned over to state investigators information about possible crimes by six police officers who had been assigned to Manhattan's 10th Precinct, the authorities said yesterday. The 10th Precinct had been the focus of an F.B.I. inquiry into police corruption.

description: A group of leading businessmen and educators called yesterday for a major effort by the Government and the private sector to reverse the long-term slowdown in the growth of productivity in the American economy.

description: Governor Cuomo faced a crowd of unemployed workers this afternoon, told them $1 million in special state aid was going to western New York and blamed President Reagan for many of their problems.

description: Harold Washington was sworn in today as the city's 42d Mayor in an unusual and emotional inauguration ceremony. description: An article in Business Day on April 16 about the L.M. Ericsson Telephone Company misidentified its president. He is Bjorn Svedberg. Mr. Svedberg was also misidentified in a picture caption accompanying the article; he appeared to the right of Fritz Staffas, Ericsson's chief financial officer.

title: Secrecy and Insecurity
description: When President Reagan came to talk to the newspaper publishers in New York this week, he said he wouldn't pander to them and ''put in a few lines about the importance of a free press and the First Amendment.'' He implied that he recognized the importance of both, but his actions say the opposite. His Administration is abandoning even the pretense of openness.

Italy's Premier Quits; New Vote Looks Certain
description: The Government of Prime Minister Amintore Fanfani resigned today after losing the support of the Socialist Party.

title: BALDWIN & LYONS reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Second Title Bout Off
description: Bob Arum, the boxing promoter, formally called off the title fight between the World Boxing Association's junior middleweight champion, Davey Moore, and Roberto Duran that had been scheduled as part of a double card in Bophuthatswana May 27. The action came a day after a broken collarbone forced Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini, the W.B.A. lightweight champion, to bow out of his title defense against Ray Bogner on the same card. Arum said the Moore-Duran bout would be rescheduled for June at a site to be determined.

description: b-Net loss The latest quarter results include a $788,000 gain on the issue of Treasury shares by affiliate, Whim Creek Consolidated NL.

title: LILCO SAYS CUSTOMERS WILL PAY MORE IF SHOREHAM ISN'T OPENED
description: The typical Long Island consumer's monthly electric bill would be about $33 higher if the nearly completed Shoreham nuclear power plant was not put into operation, Long Island Lighting Company officials said today after a State Assembly committee hearing.

title: URBAN FARMERS SEEK TO KEEP GARDEN GROWING
description: For five years now, the urban tillers of the soil have been working the land on West 48th Street. Just a block and a half west of the rundown bars and tough street life of Eighth Avenue, it is an unlikely bit of land on which to raise crops. It is also a startling area of town to find 105 garden plots about to burst into bloom.

title: Jets Cut Newton, A Reserve Back
description: The Jets have dropped Tom Newton, their longtime reserve fullback, in order to give more time to younger players.

title: SEAGULL PIPELINE CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
F.B.I. to Investigate Fatal Detroit Beating
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun an inquiry into a possible civil rights violations in the case of a man fatally beaten with a baseball bat, officials said today.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: To people elsewhere in the city, with other jobs and other concerns, the first sign of spring may be the tulips on Park Avenue, the first day without a jacket, the first toddlers in overalls on the swings in the playgrounds.

title: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
STATE DEMOCRATS URGE MAY 22 PRESIDENTIAL PRIMARY
description: A state Democratic committee yesterday recommended that the Presidential primary next year be scheduled for the relatively late date of May 22 in the hope that the state could play a decisive role in the selection of the party's nominee.

title: Early Cancer Reported Found With Injections
description: A new method of detecting early stages of cancer by injecting tiny bubbles of fat called liposomes that seek out tumors has been successfully tested in the laboratory, researchers say.

title: FAMILY FEUD AT SUPERIOR OIL
description: After William M. Keck died in 1964, the leadership of a small company he founded -Superior Oil - fell to his son, Howard B. Keck, who built it into a premier independent explorer and producer.

title: Foes Outsmarted, Not Outscored
description: It seems that even when the New Jersey Generals get a really big break, they aren't able to take advantage of it. Last Monday in Chicago, for instance, they lost in overtime to the Blitz, 17-14, their sixth defeat in eight games.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rate Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

description: International

title: CONCERT: NEW WORLD QUARTET
description: The New World String Quartet, which won the Naumburg Chamber Music Award in 1979, is a professional, polished ensemble. And at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night, the players -Curtis Macomber and William Patterson, violins; Robert Dan, viola, and Ross Harbaugh, cello - gave a witty, energetic performance of Hugo Wolf's ''Italian Serenade'' and a voluble, well-shaped performance of Brahms's Quartet in C minor (Op. 51, No. 1).

title: Pentagon Nominates Once-Criticized General
description: A general who received White House criticism and reassignment for saying that the Soviet Union had achieved ''strategic superiority'' over the United States and that this was producing a ''drift toward war'' has been nominated for another star, the Pentagon announced today.

title: A Convicted Robber Is Seized In Killings of Three in Newark
description: A convicted robber was arrested today in the Tuesday-night shotgun slayings of two women and a man in a Newark apartment.

title: CINTI FINANCIAL reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Elizabeth Frelinghuysen Dies; Active in Historical Societies
description: Elizabeth Lyman Frelinghuysen, a vice president and trustee of the New Jersey Historical Society, died Thursday at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. She was 76 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: GENERAL DATACOMM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE REMAINS OF LENIN
description: A garaguantan Lenin, glorified as immortal though dead only 59 years, will gaze down on Red Square tomorrow, as he does every May Day. Below his idealized and somewhat youthful face, and smaller portraits of his aged successors in the Politburo, a row of party and Government dignitaries - literally standing over his dead body -will review mass demonstrations. The cult goes on, serving political ends.

title: GENERAL PUBLIC UTILITIES CORP reports earnings for qtr to March 31.

title: Block Announces Cutbacks In Cheese Program for Needy
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said Wednesday that the Government's cheese donations to help feed needy families would be scaled back to help protect the commercial cheese industry.

title: 7 LEADING NATIONS PLAN CURRENCY 'COORDINATION'
description: Finance ministers of the seven leading industrial countries said today that they were willing to undertake ''coordinated'' intervention in foreign exchange markets to try to prevent excessive gyrations of currency values.

title: MEXICAN FOOD TRIPS ASIAN REFUGEE IN SPELLING BEE
description: Linn Yann had been in forced labor camps since she was 5. When she came to the United States as a refugee four years ago, the only English words she knew were numbers, one through ten. Now she was on a stage, standing behind microphones as tall as she was, trying to win her way to the National Spelling Bee in Washington.

title: RISE IS 7TH IN ROW
description: The Government's index of leading economic indicators rose 1.5 percent in March, the Commerce Department reported today, a signal that the economic recovery, which began in the first quarter, will continue to move ahead.

title: Dan Lloyd Bows Out
description: Dan Lloyd, the former Giant linebacker who has been trying for a comeback in the United States Football League after recovering from cancer, has been put on waivers by the Washington Federals at his request, according to Coach Ray Jauch. . . . Greg Stemrick, one of three Houston Oiler starters in the secondary charged with drug and alcohol offenses, has been waived. Stemrick, a nine-year cornerback, pleaded no contest to a charge of cocaine possession and will be sentenced June 6. . . . Matt Robinson, the quarterback who once contended with Richard Todd for the starting job on the Jets, as been let go by the Buffalo Bills.

title: YESTERYEAR'S SCHOOL: GOOD RIDDANCE OR REGRETS?
description: To the Editor:

title: KEANE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
TECHAMERICA GROUP INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
Rail Service to Boston Is Restored by Amtrak
description: Amtrak travel between New York and Boston resumed today after the derailment of four train cars Thursday that injured 12 passengers.

NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for qtr to Feb 26.
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split to be paid May 31.

title: SATURDAY, APRIL 30, 1983
description: The Economy

title: Panhandle Wants To Lower Prices
description: The Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company asked Federal regulators for permission to reduce its natural gas prices by 13 percent on June 1, citing a need to keep gas competitive with fuel oil.

title: GISCARD CALLS FOR AN END TO EXCHANGE RATE FLOAT
description: Valery Giscard d'Estaing, France's former President and Finance Minister, has proposed an end to floating exchange rates and urged that the dollar and yen move within predetermined limits around Western Europe's currencies.

title: HEALTHDYNE INC reports earnings for qtr to March 31.
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago results because the company changed from a fiscal year to a calendar year.

title: DUKE POWER HALTS ATOM PLANT PROJECT
description: The Duke Power Company today canceled construction of its Cherokee nuclear plant near Gaffney, S.C., and said it would seek rate increases to cover $565 million already spent on it.
